30C70, 49J40')]), '\n', TexCmd('date', [BraceGroup('December 2, 2010')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('keywords', [BraceGroup('Rank-one-convex and Quasi-convex Variational Integrals, Critical Sobolev Exponents, Extremal Quasiconformal Mappings,  Jacobian Inequalities')]), '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', [" Inspired by Morrey's Problem (on rank-one convex functionals) and the Burkholder integrals (of his martingale theory)  we find that the Burkholder functionals ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 2'], []), ',  are quasiconcave, when tested on  deformations of identity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f', TexCmd('in'), ' Id + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), '_', TexCmd('circ'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'], []), ' \nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Df(x)) ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 0'], []), ' pointwise, or  equivalently, \ndeformations\n such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|D f |^2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('p-2')]), 'J_f '], []), '.\n In particular, this holds in  explicit neighbourhoods of the identity map.\n Among the many immediate consequences, this gives\nthe strongest possible ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p'], []), '- estimates for the gradient of a principal solution to the Beltrami equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), ' = ', TexCmd('mu'), '(z) f_z', '\\,'], []), ',  for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '  in the critical interval ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1+1/', '\\|', TexCmd('mu'), '_f', '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.\nExamples of local maxima lacking symmetry manifest the intricate nature of the problem.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nA continuous function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' : ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R', '\\,'], []), '  is said to be  \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('quasiconvex')], []), ' if for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f ', TexCmd('in'), ' A + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), '_', TexCmd('circ'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ', ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^n)'], []), ' we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('columbo')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' E', '[', 'f', ']', ' ', '\\;', ':=', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_ ', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' E(Df)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x ', TexCmd('geqslant'), '  ', TexCmd('int'), '_ ', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' E(A)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x', '\\;', ' =   ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' E(A) |', TexCmd('Omega'), '|,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'A', '\\,'], []), ' stands for an arbitrary  linear mapping (or its matrix) and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), '  ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^n'], []), ' is any bounded domain. In other words, one requires that compactly supported  perturbations of linear maps do not\ndecrease the value of the integral. This notion is of fundamental importance in the\ncalculus of variations as it is known\nto characterize lower semicontinuous integrals ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('M')]), '. A weaker notion is that of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['rank'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['one'], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['convexity'], []), ', which requires just that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' ', '(A+tX)  '], []), ' is convex for any fixed matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and  for any rank one matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X.'], []), "\nRank-one convexity of an integrand  is a local condition and thus much easier to verify  than quasiconvexity. That quasiconvexity implies rank-one convexity was known  after Morrey's fundamental work in 1950's, but one had to wait until ", TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('S')]), 'ver', "\\'", BraceGroup('a'), "k's paper ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Sv')]), ' to find out that the converse is not true. \n\nHowever, ', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('S')]), 'ver', "\\'", BraceGroup('a'), "k's example works only in dimensions ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 3'], []), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PS')]), '. This leaves the possibility for different outcome in dimension 2, see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('FS')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Mu2')]), ' for evidence in this direction. Morrey himself was not quite definite in which direction he thought things should be true, see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('M')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('M2')]), ', and ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Sect. 9'), BraceGroup('Ball3')]), '. \nWe reveal our own thoughts on the matter by recalling the following conjecture  in the spirit of Morrey:\n', TexNamedEnv('conjecture', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup("Morrey's")]), '\nContinuous rank-one convex functions  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' : ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'], []), ' are quasiconvex.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nOne says that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('E')])], []), ' is rank-one concave (resp. quasiconcave) if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('E')])], []), ' is  rank-one convex (resp. quasiconvex), and null-Lagrangian if both quasiconvex and quasiconcave. In the sequel we will rather discuss concavity, as this turns out to be  natural for our methods.\nThe most famous (and, arguably, the most important) rank-one concave function in two dimension is the Burkholder functional from ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bu1')]), ',  defined for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' \nby\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('burk')]), '\n ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(A) = ', '\\,', TexCmd('Big(\'), '; ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('det'), ' A  ', '\\;', ' +', '\\;', ' ', '(1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('big{|'), '}', 'A', TexCmd('big{|'), '}', '^2 ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('Big)\'), 'cdot', ' |A|^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ',', TexCmd('qquad'), '  p', TexCmd('geqslant', [BraceGroup('2')]), '.\n'], []), '\nAbove, we have chosen the normalization ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Id', '\\,', ') = 1'], []), ' with the identity matrix and the absolute value notation is reserved for the operator norm.\nIt is well known that among the wealth of important results the quasiconcavity of the Burkholder functional would  imply e.g.  the famous Iwaniec conjecture on the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '-norm of the Beurling-Ahlfors operator.\n\nThe purpose of the present paper is to validate Conjecture ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup("Morrey's")]), ' in an important special case, namely for the above Burkholder functional, in case of  non-negative integrands, and for perturbations of the identity map:\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('MainTh3')]), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('subset', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R')]), '^2'], []), ' be a bounded domain and denote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Id:', TexCmd('Omega', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R')]), TexCmd('to'), '^2'], []), ' the identity map. Assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f ', TexCmd('in'), ' Id + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), '_', TexCmd('circ'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'], []), '\nsatisfies  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', TexCmd('bigl'), '(Df(x)', TexCmd('bigr'), ')', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 0'], []), '  pointwise in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. Then\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Df)', '\\,', ' dx', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '  ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Id', '\\,', ')', '\\,', ' dx =|', TexCmd('Omega'), ' |, ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  p', TexCmd('geqslant', [BraceGroup('2')]), ',\n'], []), '\nor, written explicitly\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('uusi22')]), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '  ', '\\,', TexCmd('Big(\'), '; ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\;', ' J(z,f)   + ( 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')', '\\;', ' |Df|^2 ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('Big)\'), 'cdot', ' |Df|^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ' ', '\\,', '  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', '\n |', TexCmd('Omega'), ' |.\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nOur proof of the above result  is based on holomorphic deformations and quasiconformal methods, and we next explain some of the relations between the Burkholder integrals and these maps. The reader is referred  to Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:proof')]), ' for the needed notation. \nOne observes that the condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Df)', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 0'], []), ' is  equivalent to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|D f |^2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('p-2')]), 'J_f '], []), ', which actually amounts to quasiconformality of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), '. \nIn this setting our result reads as follows:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f : ', '\\,', TexCmd('Omega', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('longrightarrow'))]), '\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'K'], []), '-quasiconformal map of a bounded open set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C', '\\,'], []), '  onto itself, extending continuously up to the boundary, where it coincides with the identity map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'Id(z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' z'], []), '.  Then\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Df)', '\\,', ' dx', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '  ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Id', '\\,', ')', '\\,', ' dx ', '\\,', '=', '\\,', ' |', TexCmd('Omega'), ' |,\n', TexCmd('quad'), '\\,', '  ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('for all ')]))]), ' ', '\\;', '\\,', ' 2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup('K-1')]), '\\,', '.\n'], []), ' \nFurther, the equality occurs  for a class of (expanding) piecewise radial mappings discussed in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:radial')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' \nThis result says, roughly, that the Burkholder functional is quasiconcave within  quasiconformal perturbations of the identity.\nIt is quite interesting that indeed  there is an equality in the above theorem for a large class of radial-like maps. When smooth and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p< 2K/(K-1)'], []), ' these are all local maxima for the functional, see Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('locmaxima')]), ' for details. In particular, the identity map is a local maximum of all the Burkholder functionals in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('burk')]), '.\n\n\nFrom the point of view of the theory of nonlinear hyperelasticity of\nJohn Ball  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ball1,Ball2')]), ' and his collaborators ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('An,C')]), ', for homogeneous materials the elastic deformations  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f', TexCmd('colon'), '  ', TexCmd('Omega'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^n', '\\;'], []), ' \nare  minimizers of  a given  energy integral\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' E', '[', 'f', ']', ' ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_ ', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' E(Df)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x  ', '\\;', ' <', TexCmd('infty'), ' \n'], []), '\nwhere the so-called ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('stored energy function')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' E', TexCmd('colon'), '  ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), 'arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R', '\\,'], []), ' carries the mechanical properties of the elastic material in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), '. \nBy virtue of the principle of non-interpenetration of matter the minimizers ought to be injective. It is from these perspectives that our energy-estimates, although limited to (quasiconformal) homeomorphisms, are   certainly not short of applications.\n\n\n\n Among the strong  consequences of the theorem,  one obtains (with the same assumptions as in Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ') that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lp')]), '\n', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('Omega'), '|')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), '  ', TexCmd('big'), ' | Df(z)', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('\\,', 'p ')]), '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup(' 2K ', '\\;', '-', '\\;', ' p', '\\,', '(K-1)')]), '\\;', ',', TexCmd('quad'), ' for', '\\;', '\\;', ' 2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p < ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup('K-1')]), '\\,', '\n'], []), '\n with equality  for piecewise power mappings, such as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' f(z) =  |z|^', BraceGroup('1-1/K'), ' z ', '\\,'], []), ' in the unit disk, see Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('best')]), ' below. \nThe  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W'), '^', BraceGroup('1,p')], []), '-regularity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K-'], []), 'quasiconformal mappings, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p < 2K/(K-1)'], []), ', was established  by the first author in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('As2')]), ', as a corollary of his area distortion theorem. However, there  the  bounds for integrals such as in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lp')]), ') were described  in terms of unspecified constants depending on the distortion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '. Here we have obtained the sharp explicit bound for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L'), '^p'], []), '-integrals of the derivatives of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiconformal mappings.\n\nSimilarly, for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiregular mapping ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W')]), '^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup('loc'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ', injective or not, we can improve the local ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W'), '^', BraceGroup('1,p')], []), '-regularity to weighted integral bounds at the borderline exponent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=2K/(K-1)'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup(' ')]), '\n', '( ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('K(x)')]), '\\;', ' -', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('K')]), ' ', ')', '\\;', TexCmd('big|D'), '\\!', 'f(x)', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup('K-1')]))]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^1_', BraceGroup('loc'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ').\n'], []), '\nWe refer  to Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:proof')]), ' for a more thorough discussion and Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:radial')]), ' for elaborate examples of extremal mappings. \n\n\n\nWe next describe shortly the ideas behind the proofs of our main results which  are given in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:proof')]), '. In fact we will prove a slightly generalized form of  Theorems  ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh3')]), ' -- ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ', where we relax the identity boundary conditions to asymptotic normalization at infinity.\nThis is done in Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]), ' below, where we will interpolate between the natural end-point cases ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.\nThe holomorphic interpolation method used is inspired by the variational principle of thermodynamical formalism and the underlying analytic dependence coming from holomorphic motions. The latter tools already figured prominently in the proof of the area distortion theorem ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('As2')]), ' by the first author.  \n\nHere these are developed to a key ingredient of our argument,\na new variant of the celebrated  Riesz-Thorin interpolation theorem. We believe that the usefulness of this result may go beyond our interests here.  \nIn order to describe this result,\nlet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ',', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' be a measure space and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' M(', TexCmd('Omega'), ',', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ') ', '\\,'], []), ' denote the class of complex-valued ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('sigma')], []), '-measurable functions on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. The Lebesgue spaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p (', TexCmd('Omega'), ',', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' are  (quasi-)normed by\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n  ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '\\|', '_p  = (', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' |', TexCmd('Phi'), '(z)|^p ', '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('sigma'), '(z))^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p')])), '\\,', ',', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '0 < p<', TexCmd('infty'), '\\;', ', ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('and')]), '\\;', '\\;', '\\|', TexCmd('Phi'), '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', '\\;', '= ', TexCmd('underset', [BraceGroup('z', TexCmd('in'), '\\,', TexCmd('Omega')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('ess', '\\,', 'sup')]))]), ' ', '\\,', '\\;', '|', TexCmd('Phi'), '(z)|\n'], []), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('subset')], []), ' be a domain. We shall consider  analytic families ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' of measurable functions in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), ' ,'], []), '  i.e.  jointly measurable functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), ')', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' f_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '(x)'], []), ' defined on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('times'), ' U'], []), ' such that for each fixed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' f(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), ')'], []), ' is analytic in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), '. The family is said to be ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' non-vanishing'), ' if there exists a set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E', TexCmd('subset'), TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '-measure zero such \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('vanishing')]), '\nf(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), ')', TexCmd('not'), '=0', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for ', '\\;', ' all')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' x', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('setminus'), ' E', '\\;', '\\;', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and'), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' U.\n'], []), '\nWe state our interpolation result first in the setting of the right half plane,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U =  ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H_+ := ', '\\{', ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), ': ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('re'), TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\,', '>', '\\,', ' 0', '\\}', ' '], []), ', in order to facilitate comparison with the Riesz-Thorin theorem:\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('interpolation2')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', '0 ', '\\,', '<', '\\,', ' p_0, ', '\\,', ' p_1 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' and\nlet   ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', '\\{', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), '\\,', ';', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), '  ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H_+', '\\}', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), '\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' M(', TexCmd('Omega'), ', ', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' be an analytic and non-vanishing family,  with complex parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' in the right half plane.\nAssume further that for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 0'], []), ',\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nM_1', '\\;', ':=', '\\;', ' ', '\\|', '\\,', TexCmd('Phi'), '\\,', '_1', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_1'), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', '<', '\\;', TexCmd('infty'), '  ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('and ')]), '\\;', ' M_0', '\\;', ':=', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('underset', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), '  ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H_+'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sup'))]), '\n', '\\,', 'e^', BraceGroup('- a', TexCmd('re'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', '\\|', '\\,', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_0'), ' ', '\\;', '<', TexCmd('infty'), '. \n'], []), '\nThen,  letting  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', ' M_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\;', ':=', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('big{\'), '|', '}', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('big{\'), '|', '}', '_', BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta')), '\\;'], []), ' with ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('displaystyle'), '\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta'))]), '=(1-', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ')', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_0')]), ' + ', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_1')]), ','], []), '\nwe have  for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<', TexCmd('theta'), '< 1', '\\,'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('logconcav')]), '\nM_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '  ', '\\;', 'M_0^', BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('theta')), TexCmd('cdot'), ' M_1^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), '\\;', '<', '\\,', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', '\\;', '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('Interpolation Lemma')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('remark', [' Compared to Riesz-Thorin, our result needs the bound for the other end-point exponent only at one single point, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' = 1'], []), ' !  However,  without  the non-vanishing condition the  conclusion of the interpolation lemma breaks down drastically. A simple example (where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=0'], []), ') is obtained by taking ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_0=1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1=', TexCmd('infty')], []), ',  and considering the\nfamily ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', ')=(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('lambda'))]), ')g(x)'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('re'), TexCmd('lambda'), ' >0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), ' ,'], []), '\nfor a function  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^1 (', TexCmd('Omega'), ',', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', TexCmd('setminus'), '(', TexCmd('bigcup'), '_', BraceGroup('p>1'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p (', TexCmd('Omega'), ',', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')).'], []), '\n'], []), '\nIn applications one often has rotational symmetry, thus requiring a unit disk version of the interpolation. After a  M', '\\"', 'obius transform in the parameter plane the interpolation lemma runs as follows (observe that we have interchanged the  roles of the indices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1'], []), ' only for aesthetic reasons): \n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('interpolation')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<p_0 ,p_1 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', '\\{', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), '\\,', ';', '\\;', ' |', TexCmd('lambda'), '| ', '\\,', '<', '\\,', ' 1', '\\}', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), '\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' M(', TexCmd('Omega'), ', ', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' be an analytic and non-vanishing family  with complex parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' in the unit disc.\nSuppose\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nM_0', '\\,', ':=', '\\,', ' ', '\\|', '\\,', TexCmd('Phi'), '\\,', '_0', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_0'), ' ', '\\;', '<', TexCmd('infty'), ',', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '  M_1', '\\,', ':=', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('underset', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('lambda'), '| <1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sup'))]), ' ', '\\|', '\\,', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_1'), ' ', '\\;', '<', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('and ')]), '\\;', ' M_r ', '\\,', ':=', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('underset', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('lambda'), '|=r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sup'))]), '\\,', TexCmd('big{\'), '|', '}', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('big{\'), '|', '}', '_', BraceGroup('p_r'), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', [' \n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_r')]), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-r'), BraceGroup('1+r')]), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_0')]), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2r'), BraceGroup('1+r')]), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_1')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('vskip'), '8pt\n\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' Then, for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' 0', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' r < 1', '\\,'], []), ',  we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nM_r ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '  ', '\\;', 'M_0^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-r'), BraceGroup('1+r')])), TexCmd('cdot'), ' M_1^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', '\\,', 'r'), BraceGroup('1+r')])), '\\;', '<', '\\,', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', '\\;', '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('Interpolation Lemma for the disk')]), '\n', '\nAs might be expected, passing to the limit in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('uusi22')]), ') as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'p', TexCmd('to'), ' 2', '\\,'], []), '  or as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'p', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty'), '\\,'], []), ' will yield interesting sharp inequalities.  The first mentioned limit leads to \n\n \n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('corollary', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('LlogL Th')]), '  Given a bounded domain  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('subset'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), ' and a homeomorphism  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f', '\\,', ' : ', '\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('overset', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tiny', [BraceGroup('onto')]))])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('longrightarrow'))]), '\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), ' such that\n  ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['f(z) -  z ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W')]), '^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_0(', TexCmd('Omega'), '),'], []), ' \n  we  then have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('LlogL1')]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '\\,', '(1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' |Df(z)|^2 ', '\\,', ' ', ')', '\\,', ' J(z,f)', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  ', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '  |Df(z)|^2  ', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n'], []), '\nEquality occurs for the identity map, as well as for a number of piece-wise radial mappings discussed in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:radial')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' Reflecting back on Conjecture ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup("Morrey's")]), ', note that the functional ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), '  F'), '(A) = ', '\\,', '(1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' |A|^2 ', '\\,', ' ', ')', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('det'), '(A)', '\\,', ' - ', '\\,', ' |A|^2', '\\,', ' '], []), ' is \n rank-one concave. However, with growth stronger than quadratic it is not polyconcave ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ball1')]), ', i.e.~cannot be written as a concave function of the minors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '. According to   Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL Th')]), ' this functional is nevertheless quasiconcave with respect to  homeomorphic perturbations of the identity. Going to the inverse maps yields a quasiconcavity result for the functional\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('functional'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' H')]), ' ', '(A):=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|A|^2'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' det'), '\\,', ' A')]), '+', TexCmd('log'), ' ', TexCmd('big({'), TexCmd('rm'), ' det', '}', '\\,', ' A', TexCmd('big)-'), TexCmd('log'), ' |A|, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' det '), '\\,', ' A >0.\n'], []), '\n This can be interpreted as a sharp integrability of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' J(z,f)', '\\,'], []), ' for planar maps of finite distortion, see Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('loginv')]), '  below.  \n \nIt is  of course classical  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Mu,GI')]), ' that the nonlinear differential expression\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J(z,f) ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\,', '|Df(z)| ^2'], []), ' belongs to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^1_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('loc')])), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), '\n  for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', ' f ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W')]), '^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('loc')])), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' whose\nJacobian determinant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' J(z,f) = ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('det')]), '\\,', 'Df(z)', '\\,'], []), ' is nonnegative.\n The novelty in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL1')]), ') lies in the best constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'C= 1'], []), ' in the right hand side, and the proof of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('log')]), TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L'], []), '-integrability of the Jacobian is new. \n \nIn turn, the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'p', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty'), '\\,'], []), ' yields the following sharp inequality.\n', TexNamedEnv('corollary', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('expint')]), '\nDenote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbf'), ' S')], []), ' the Beurling-Ahlfors operator (defined in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('56')]), ')) and assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is a measurable function with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), '(z)'], []), ' for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')])], []), '. Then\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('expint1')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('big(\'), ', 1 - |', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|', TexCmd('big)\'), '; \ne^', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('bigl'), '| ', TexCmd('exp'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('S')]), TexCmd('mu'), '(z)'), ') ', TexCmd('bigr'), '| ', '\\;', 'dz ', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ' .\n'], []), '\nEquality occurs  for an extensive class of piece-wise radial mappings discussed in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogLeq')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' Prior to the above result, it was known that the area distortion results ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('As2')]), ' yield the exponential integrability of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('re', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbf'), ' S')]), TexCmd('mu')], []), '  under the strict inequality\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\|', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty'), ' <1'], []), ', see ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('p. 387'), BraceGroup('AIMb')]), '.  \n\nThe proofs of the Corollaries are found in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:limitcases')]), '.\nSection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:radial')]), ' contains further observations on the Burkholder functionals. For example,  their local maxima are  discussed and  new conjectures are posed also in the higher dimensional setup. We finally mention that an extension of Burkholder functionals to all real values of the exponent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' is given in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:proof')]), '.\n\n\n\n \n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Proof of the Interpolation Lemma')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('se:interpolation')]), '\n', '\nBefore embarking into the proof, let us remark that often analytic families of functions are defined\nby considering analytic functions having values in the Banach space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p (', TexCmd('Omega'), ',', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', '\\,'], []), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1.'], []), ' In this case it is well-known (e.g. ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Thm. 3.31'), BraceGroup('R')]), ') that one may define analyticity of the family by several equivalent conditions, e.g. by testing elements from the dual. This notion agrees with the definition given in the introduction, see ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 5.7.1'), BraceGroup('AIMb')]), '.\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' \nWe may, and do, assume that   ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'M_0 = 1', '\\,'], []), ' and that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=0'], []), '; the case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a>0'], []), ' reduces to this by simply considering the analytic family ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup('-a', TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '(x)'], []), '. Similarly by taking restrictions we may assume\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ') < ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.\n\n\nWe first consider the case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<p_0, p_1<', TexCmd('infty'), ','], []), ' and   establish the result  in the situation  where for a fixed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(1,', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', ')'], []), ' there  is the uniform bound\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('uniform')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('leqslant'), ' | ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '(x) | ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('leqslant'), ' A', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for ', '\\;', ' all')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_+', '\\;', '\\;', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and'), '\\;', '\\;', '\nx', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '.\n'], []), '\nThis is to ensure that all of our integrals and computations below are meaningful.\nAt the end of the proof we  get rid of this extra assumption.\n\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(0,1)'], []), ' be given as in the statement of the lemma. First, we will find the support line to the convex function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac'), '1p ', TexCmd('mapsto'), '  ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\|', '_p'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta'))])], []), '. We are looking for a function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_p(', TexCmd('theta'), ')'], []), ' with the following properties,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:supportline')]), '\nu_p(', TexCmd('theta'), ') = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p')]), ' ', '\\,', ' I + u_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ') ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '  ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\|', '_p  ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('and')]), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' u_', BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta')), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ')= ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta')), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ')'], []), ' are independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. Using the concavity of the logarithm function we can write down these terms explicitly. Indeed, by concavity, for any probability density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wp'), '(x)'], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' and for any exponent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0< p < ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ',\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('wp'), '(x) ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), '(x)|^', BraceGroup('p')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('wp'), '(z)')]), ')', '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p'), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere equality holds for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=p_', TexCmd('theta')], []), ' with the following choice of density\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dens')]), '\n ', TexCmd('wp'), '(x) ', '\\;', ': = ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('big|\'), 'Phi', '_', TexCmd('theta'), '(x)', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta'))])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('big|\'), 'Phi', '_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '(y) ', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta'))]), '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '(y)')]), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('wp'), '(x)', '\\,', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '(x)', '\\;', '= 1.\n'], []), '\nIt is useful to note that because of our assumptions ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('uniform')]), ', the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wp')], []), ' is uniformly bounded from above and below.\nWith this in mind we find the coefficients in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq:supportline')]), ', by using the fixed density  ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('dens')]), ' and by writing \n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', [' I:= ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('wp'), '(x) ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('wp'), '(z)')]), ')', '\\,', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('sigma'), '\n', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('and')]), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' u_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('theta'), '):=', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('wp'), '(x) ', TexCmd('log'), ' |', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), '(x)|', '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('sigma'), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe key idea in this representation is that  we may embed the line ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_p(', TexCmd('theta'), ')'], []), ' in a harmonic family of lines parametrized by \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H_+')])], []), ',  \n\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', [' u_p(', TexCmd('lambda'), '):= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p')]), ' ', '\\,', ' I + u_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('wp'), '(x) ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(x)|^', BraceGroup('p')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('wp'), '(z)')]), ')', '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('sigma'), '.\n'], []), '\nIt is important  to notice  that we kept the slope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ' fixed and because of the non-vanishing assumption the constant term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('lambda'), ')'], []), '  becomes a harmonic function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ". \nAgain, in view of Jensen's inequality\nwe have the envelope property, the analogue of ", TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq:supportline')]), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H_+')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:envelope')]), '\n u_p(', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\|', '_p ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('and')]), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' u_', BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta')), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ')= ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta')), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nBy our assumptions, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p= p_0'], []), ' we thus have  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('p_0'), '(', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_0'), ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 0'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_+'], []), ". Here  Harnack's inequality for nonpositive harmonic functions in  ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H_+'], []), ' takes a particularly simple form when  restricted to \nthe interval ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(0,1)'], []), ': \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:harnack')]), '\nu_', BraceGroup('p_0'), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ')', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), '\\,', ' u_', BraceGroup('p_0'), '(1)', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(0,1).\n'], []), '\nFinally combining  the estimates ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq:envelope')]), ' and ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq:harnack')]), ' yields\n ', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('kaava')]), '\n ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('theta'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))), '  ', '&=& u_', BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta')), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ') = u_', BraceGroup('p_0'), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ')  + \n ( ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta'))]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_0')]), ' ', ') I   \n&', TexCmd('leqslant'), '& ', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\,', ' u_', BraceGroup('p_0'), '(1) + ', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_1')]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p_0')]), ' ', ') I  \n& = &  ', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\,', ' u_', BraceGroup('p_1'), '(1) \n', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('log'), ' M_1,\n'], []), '\nwhich is exactly what we aimed to prove. \n\n\nThe argument can easily be adapted to accommodate the cases when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_0=', TexCmd('infty')], []), '  or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1=', TexCmd('infty')], []), '. We will instead use a limiting argument. First, normalize to  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')=1'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\|', ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p')], []), ' increases with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' and one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\|', ' f', '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty'), '=', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('p', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')), '\\|', ' f', '\\|', '_p .'], []), ' Hence, as ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('uniform')]), ' holds, we\nobtain the desired result by  approximating the possibly infinite exponents by finite ones.\n  \nLet us finally dispense with the extra assumption (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('uniform')]), '). Since the removal of a null set from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' is allowed, we may assume that the non-vanishing condition holds\nfor every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), ' ,'], []), ' i.e.  one may take  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E=', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('vanishing')]), '). \nChoose first a family ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_n(', TexCmd('lambda'), ')'], []), ' of M', '\\"', 'obius transformations such that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_n(1) = 1, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_n (', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', ')=', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('lambda'), ', ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_+, ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '_n (', TexCmd('Hr'), '_+ )')]), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '_+, ', '\\;', '\\;', '  n ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' N,\n'], []), '\nand let  for any positive integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('goodset')]), '\n', TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup('n,k'), ':=', '\\{', ' x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '\\;', ' :', '\\;', ' |', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '(x)|', TexCmd('in', [BracketGroup('1/k, k')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for ', '\\;', ' all '), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '_n (', TexCmd('Hr'), '_+ )')]), ' ', '\\;', ' ', '\\}', ' .\n'], []), '\nThe measurable sets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup('n, k')], []), '  fill the space,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bigcup'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup('n ,k'), '=', TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. Moreover, for each fixed  integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'], []), ' the non-vanishing analytic family\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', '(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', ')', TexCmd('mapsto'), '  ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '_n'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('lambda'), ')'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')]), '(x), ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' x ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup('n,k'), ',  ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_+, \n'], []), '\nsatisfies the uniform bound (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('uniform')]), '), and thus we may interpolate it. Letting  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')], []), ' gives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '_n (', TexCmd('theta'), ')'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('p_', TexCmd('theta')), TexCmd('leqslant'), ' M_1^', TexCmd('theta')], []), ', and  the claim ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('logconcav')]), " follows by Fatou's lemma taking a second limit ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.  \n'], [BracketGroup('Proof of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation2')]))]), '\n', '\nWe remark that the Harnack inequality used above can be deduced from the standard Harnack inequality in the unit disc ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'u(w) ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-|w|'), BraceGroup('1+|w|')]), '\\,', ' u(0)'], []), ' by a change of variables ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '=(1-w)/(1+w). '], []), ' The very same change of variables allows one to deduce Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation')]), ' for the values ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(0,1)'], []), ' as a consequence of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation2')]), ', and rest follows from rotational symmetry.\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Proofs of the Main Theorems')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('se:proof')]), '\n', '\nWe start with some preliminaries. Our goal is to  apply the Interpolation Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation')]), ' in estimating  the variational integrals   such as ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('uusi22')]), ', and therefore we look for  analytic and  nonvanishing families of  gradients of mappings. In view of the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' Lambda-lemma'), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('MSS')]), ' this takes us  to the notion of  quasiconformal mappings.  By definition, in any dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 2'], []), ' these are homeomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f:', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), "'"], []), '  in the Sobolev class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,n'), '_', BraceGroup('loc'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ' for which \nthe differential matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D', '\\!', 'f(x) ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' n')], []), '  and its determinant are coupled in the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('distortion inequality')]), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('distortion')]), '\n |D', '\\!', 'f(x)|^n  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' K(x)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('det'), ' D', '\\!', 'f(x)', '\\;', ',', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('where')]), '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '|D', '\\!', 'f(x)|  = ', TexCmd('max'), '_', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('xi'), '| =1'), ' ', '\\;', ' |D', '\\!', 'f(x) ', TexCmd('xi'), '|,\n'], []), '\nfor some bounded function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(x)'], []), '. The smallest  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '  K(x) ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1 ', '\\,', ' '], []), ' for which (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('distortion')]), ') holds almost everywhere is referred to as the  ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('distortion function')]), ' of the mapping ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f'], []), '. We call ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiconformal if  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(f) := ', '\\|', ' K(x)', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' K'], []), '. \n\nIn dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'n=2', '\\,'], []), '   it is useful to employ complex notation by introducing the  Cauchy-Riemann operators \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('partial'), ' f = f_z= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' z')]), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x')]), ' - i ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' y')]), ' ', ')', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('and')]), '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '  ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'))]), ' f = f _', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('bar'), ' z')]), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x')]), ' + i ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' y')]), ')   '], []), '\nWriting\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n  |D', '\\!', 'f(z)|  ', '\\,', '= |f_z|', '\\;', '+', '\\;', '|f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '|', '\\,', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('and')]), TexCmd('quad'), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('det'), '\\,', 'D', '\\!', 'f(z) ', '\\,', ' = ', '\\,', 'J(z,f) ', '\\,', '= ', '\\,', '|f_z|^2', '\\,', '-', '\\,', '|f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '|^2,\n'], []), '\nwe see that for a planar Sobolev homeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiconformality simplifies to a linear\nequation\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Bel1')]), '\n', '\\,', ' f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), ' = ', TexCmd('mu'), '(z) f_z\n'], []), '\ncalled the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' Beltrami equation'), '. Here the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' dilatation function'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is measurable and\nsatisfies\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\|', ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty'), ' =:k=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('K-1'), BraceGroup('K+1')]), '<1'], []), '. \n\nThe Beltrami equation  will then enable holomorphic deformations of the homeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' and of its gradient. Indeed,  under a proper normalization the solutions  to  ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Bel1')]), ' and  their derivatives  depend holomorphically on the coefficient ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ', see ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('p. 188'), BraceGroup('AIMb')]), '.  \n\nFor choosing the normalization,  recall that  Theorems ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh3')]), ' - ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), '  consider identity boundary values, and thus mappings that extend conformally outside ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. We therefore look for solutions to   ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Bel1')]), ' defined in the entire plane ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C'], []), ', with the dilatation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' vanishing outside the  domain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), '.  \nOn the other hand,  the identity boundary values cannot be retained under general holomorphic deformations; one needs to content \nwith the asymptotic normalization\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('principal')]), '\n', '\\,', 'f(z) = z + b_1 z^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' + b_2 z^', BraceGroup('-2'), ' + ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', '\\;', ',', '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('for')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' |z| ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty'), ' \n'], []), '\nGlobal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W'), '^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup('loc')], []), '-solutions  to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Bel1')]), ' with these asymptotics  are called  \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), '  principal solutions'), '. They exist and are unique for each coefficient ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), '  supported in the bounded domain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), ', and each of them is a homeomorphism. They can be found simply in the form of the Cauchy transform\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nf(z) = z + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), ')', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d ', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(' z - ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ')]), '\\;', ',', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('where')]), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('omega'), ' = f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^2(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)\n'], []), '\nSubstituting  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('omega'), ':= f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z')], []), ' into (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Bel1')]), ') yields a  singular integral equation for the unknown density function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^2(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)'], []), ',\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('SBel')]), '\n', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', '\\;', '-', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' S ', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', TexCmd('mu'), '\\;', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^2(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)\n'], []), '\nHere the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Beurling Transform')]), ', a  Calder', "\\'", 'on-Zygmund type singular integral,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('56')]), '\n ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' S ', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', '\\;', '= ', '\\;', '- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), '  ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), ')', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d ', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(' ', '(z - ', TexCmd('xi'), ')^2 ')]), '\\;', '= ', '\\;', ' f_z', '\\,', '-', '\\,', ' 1\n'], []), '\nis an isometry in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), '  L^2(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)'], []), ', whence (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('SBel')]), ') can be solved by the Neumann series. We refer to the well-known monographs ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ah')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LV')]), ' and ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('AIMb')]), ' for the basic properties and further details on quasiconformal mappings.\n\nRegularity results in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,p'), '_', BraceGroup('loc')], []), ' originated in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bo2')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bo1')]), ', where  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf'), ' S'], []), ' was considered on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p'], []), ' for suitable exponents ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>2'], []), '. \nAs a Calder', "\\'", 'on-Zygmund operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathbf'), ' S', '\\;', ' '], []), ' is bounded in  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p'], []), ', but determining here the operator norm is a much harder question. The as yet unsolved conjecture ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Iw4')]), ' of Iwaniec asserts that\n', TexNamedEnv('conjecture', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('p-norm')]), '\nFor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '1<p<', TexCmd('infty'), '\\,'], []), ' it holds\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('55')]), '\n', '\\|', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('S')]), ' ', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), '  L^p(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)'), ' = p^* - 1 := ', '\\;', '\\{', TexNamedEnv('array', [' p-1', '\\;', ',', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('qquad'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('if')]), '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' 2', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p < ', TexCmd('infty'), '\n       ', '\\;', '\\;', '1/(p-1) ', '\\;', ',', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('if')]), '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' 1<p', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 2\n       '], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '.\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' As mentioned in the introduction, the full quasiconcavity of the Burkholder functional ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' B'), '_p'], []), ' would, among its many potential consequences, imply also  ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('55')]), '.\nThis follows from another very useful inequality of Burkholder ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bu1')]), '. Namely,  with the positive constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'C_p = p(1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p')]), '  ', ')^', BraceGroup('1-p')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), '2', '\\,'], []), ',  we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation*', ['C_p ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('big(\'), ',|f_z|^p ', '\\;', ' - (p-1)^p |f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '|^p ', TexCmd('bigr'), ')  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('big(\'), ',|f_', BraceGroup('z'), '|', '\\,', '-', '\\,', '(p-1)', '\\,', '|f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '| ', TexCmd('big)\'), 'cdot', ' ', TexCmd('big(\'), ',|f_z|', '\\;', '+', '\\;', '|f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '|', TexCmd('big)^', [BraceGroup('p-1')]), '\\,', TexCmd('equiv'), '  ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' B'), '_p(Df)\n'], []), "\nThus  Burkholder's functional can be viewed as a rank-one concave envelope of the \n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), "-norm functional of the left hand side. It is because of this connection why Morrey's Problem becomes relevant to Conjecture ", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('p-norm')]), '.\nFor precise statements and further information on related topics we refer to ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ba1,BL,Bu1,VN')]), ". \n\nIt is also appropriate to note that the origin of the Burkholder functional lies in Burkholder's groundbreaking work on  sharp estimates for martingales  ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bu4')]), ' -  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bu1')]), '. This work has been later on extended in various ways, including  applications to computing optimal or almost optimal estimates for norms of singular integrals, e.g. of the Beurling-Ahlfors operator. Also the Bellman function techniques (see e.g.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('NTV2')]), ') are closely related. We mention only\n  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BJ2')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BW')]), ', \n ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bu1')]), ',  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DV')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('GMS')]), ',    ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('NTV2')]), ',   ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('NTV')]), ',  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PV')]), ',    ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('VN')]), '      \nand refer to the  recent survey ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ba1')]), " for a wealth of information and an extensive list of references.\n\n\n\nWe next recall  some standard facts on smooth approximation of principal solutions of the Beltrami equation. Especially, we have a special interest in the Jacobian and whether it is strictly positive. Schauder's regularity theory of elliptic PDEs with H", '\\"', BraceGroup('o'), 'lder continuous coefficients becomes useful. It applies to general quasilinear Beltrami systems, see Theorem 15.0.7 in  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('AIMb')]), '.\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')]))]), '\\;', ' = ', '\\;', TexCmd('mu'), '(z,f)  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' z')]), ' ', '\\;', '+ ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('nu'), '(z,f) ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' f'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' z')]))]), '\\;', ',', TexCmd('quad'), '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z,f)| + ', '\\;', '| ', TexCmd('nu'), '(z,f)| ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' k < 1\n'], []), '\nwhere the coefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', ' ,', '\\,', TexCmd('nu'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', TexCmd('alpha'), '( ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)', '\\,', ',', '\\,', '\\;', ' 0<', TexCmd('alpha'), '<1', '\\,'], []), '. Accordingly, every  solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('loc')])), '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)'], []), ' is  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', BraceGroup('1,', '\\,', TexCmd('alpha')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('loc')]))], []), '-regular. Of course, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f', '\\,'], []), ' is quasiconformal, then the inverse map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' h(w)  = f^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(w)', '\\,', ' '], []), ' is also ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', BraceGroup('1,', '\\,', TexCmd('alpha')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('loc')]))], []), '-regular  since it solves similar system\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' h'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('w')]))]), ' ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', ' -', TexCmd('nu'), '(h,w) ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' h'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' w')]), ' ', '\\;', '- ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '(h,w)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' h'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' w')]))]), '\n'], []), '\nThus, we have\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('aregu')]), '\nThe principal solution of the Beltrami equation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Bel1')]), ') in which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', TexCmd('alpha'), '( ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)', '\\,', ',', '\\;', ' 0<', TexCmd('alpha'), '<1', '\\,', ',', '\\,'], []), ' is a\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', BraceGroup('1,', '\\,', TexCmd('alpha')), '( ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C )', '\\,'], []), ' - diffeomorphism. In particular, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '|f_z|^2 ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' J(z,', '\\,', 'f) > 0', '\\,'], []), ',  everywhere.\n'], [BracketGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', BraceGroup('1,', '\\,', TexCmd('alpha'))], []), '-regularity')]), '\nAs might be expected, almost  everywhere convergence of the Beltrami coefficients yields ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,', '\\,', '2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('loc')]))], []), '- convergence of the principal solutions. The precise statement \nreads as follows:\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', ['\nSuppose the Beltrami coefficients  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('ell')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C_', TexCmd('circ'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), '  satisfy ', '\\,', ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '|', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('ell')), ' ', '(z)|  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' k < 1 '], []), ' , for all  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('ell'), ' = 1,2,... '], []), ',  and converge almost everywhere to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,'], []), '. Then the associated principal solutions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' f^', TexCmd('ell'), '\\,', ':', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C', '\\,'], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', TexCmd('infty')], []), '-smooth diffeomorphisms converging in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,', '\\,', '2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('loc')])), '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C) ', '\\,'], []), ' to the principal solution of the limit equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), ' ', '\\,', '=', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '(z) f_z', '\\,'], []), '.\n'], [BracketGroup('Smooth Approximation')]), '\n', '\nEvery measurable Beltrami coefficient satisfying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)| ', '\\,', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', ' k', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('chi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '(z)', '\\;', ',', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' 0', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' k  <1', '\\,'], []), ',  can be approximated this way.\n\nAs the last of the preliminaries, in applying  the Interpolation Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation')]), ' we will \nneed  sharp ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('L')]), '^2'], []), '-estimates of  gradients, valid for all complex deformations of a given mapping. For the principal  solutions in the unit disk ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'], []), ', these result from the classical  Area Theorem (see e.g.', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('p. 41'), BraceGroup('AIMb')]), ').\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('lem:areaineq')]), '\nThe area of the image of the unit disk under a principal solution in  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'], []), ' does not exceed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('pi')], []), '. It equals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('pi'), '\\,'], []), ' if and only if the solution is the identity map outside the disk.\n'], [BracketGroup('Area Inequality')]), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' Let us recall a proof emphasizing the null-Lagrangian property of the Jacobian determinant. On the circle we have the equality\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f(z) =  g(z)', '\\,'], []), ',  where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'g ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D) ', '\\,'], []), ' is given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'g(z) =  z + ', TexCmd('underset', [BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sum'))]), '\\,', ' b_n ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('\\;', 'z', '\\,')]), '^', BraceGroup('n'), '\\;'], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '|z| ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1', '\\,'], []), '. \n This yields\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D ', '\\,', 'J(z, f)', '\\,', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'z = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D ', '\\,', 'J(z, g)', '\\,', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'z = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D ', TexCmd('big(1'), ' -|g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '(z)|^2', '\\,', TexCmd('big)\'), ',', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'z  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '\n'], []), '\nEquality occurs if and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 0 ', '\\,'], []), ', meaning that all the coefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b_n ', '\\,'], []), ' vanish.\n\n\nHaving disposed of these lemmas, we can now proceed to the proof of the main integral estimate, where\nin the  complex notation the  Burkholder functional takes the form  ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Burkh1')]), '\n ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', ' ', '\\,', ':=', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', TexCmd('big(\'), ';|f_', BraceGroup('z'), '|', '\\,', '-', '\\,', '(p-1)', '\\,', '|f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '| ', '\\;', TexCmd('big)\'), 'cdot', ' ', TexCmd('big(\'), ';|f_z|', '\\;', '+', '\\;', '|f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '|', '\\;', TexCmd('big)^', [BraceGroup('p-1')]), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z', '\\;', ',', '\\;', '\\;', 'p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 2.\n'], []), '\nWe will actually  deduce (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('uusi22')]), ') from a slightly more general result, where \nwe  relax the identity boundary values  and allow  principal mappings:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f :', '\\,', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C', '\\,'], []), ' be the principal solution of a Beltrami equation;\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('6')]), '\nf_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '(z) ', '\\;', '= ', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)', '\\;', ' f_z(z) ', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)| ', '\\,', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', ' k', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('chi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), ' ', '(z)', '\\;', ',', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' 0', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' k  <1,\n'], []), '\nin particular,  conformal outside the unit disk ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'], []), '. \n\nThen, for all exponents ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '2', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1 + 1/k'], []), ',  we have \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Mainineq')]), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), ' ', '(1', '\\;', ' -', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p', '\\,', ' |', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1+', '\\,', '|', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|')]), ')', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('big(|'), 'f_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup('z')), '(z)|+ |f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '(z)|', TexCmd('big)^', [BraceGroup('\\,', 'p ')]), '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('pi'), '.\n'], []), '\nEquality occurs for some fairly general  piecewise radial mappings discussed in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:radial')]), '.\n'], [BracketGroup('Sharp  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L'), '^p'], []), '-inequality')]), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' The above form of the main result gives a flexible and remarkably precise local description of  the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p'], []), '-properties  of derivatives of a quasiconformal map,  especially interesting in the borderline\nsituation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1+1/k'], []), '. Indeed, combined with the Stoilow factorization, the theorem gives for any  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W'), '^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup('loc'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), '-solution to (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('6')]), '), injective or not, the estimate\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('bigl'), '(k - ', '\\,', ' |', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|', TexCmd('bigr'), ')', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('big'), ' | Df(z)', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('\\,', '1 + 1/k ')]), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^1_', BraceGroup('loc'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ').\n'], []), '\nThus  for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiregular mappings we obtain optimal weighted higher integrability bounds  at the borderline case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p =  2K/(K-1)'], []), '. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p '], []), ' below the borderline, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W'), '^', BraceGroup('1,p'), '_', BraceGroup('loc')], []), '-regularity was established already in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('As2')]), '.\nThe borderline integrability was previously covered ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('AsN')]), ' only in the very special case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('mu'), '|=k ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '_E'], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')])], []), ', in Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]), '.\n \nThe proof of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]), ' applies the Interpolation lemma in conjunction with analytic families of quasiconformal maps. However, the choice of the specific analytic family  for our situation is quite non-trivial, in order to enable sharp estimates. In a sense the speed of the change with respect to the analytic parameter must be localized in a delicate manner, see (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:tau')]), ') below.\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nGiven a principal solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('6')]), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '(z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 0'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|z|>1'], []), ', we are to prove the integral bounds (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Mainineq')]), ').\nThere is no loss of generality in assuming that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C_', TexCmd('circ'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D)', '\\,'], []), ', for if not, we approximate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,'], []), ' with  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C_', TexCmd('circ'), '^', TexCmd('infty')], []), "-smooth Beltrami coefficients,\nand, thanks to Fatou's lemma, there is no difficulty in passing to the limit in (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Mainineq')]), '). On the other hand, this reduction could be avoided by using the argument of  Remark ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rem:nonvanishing')]), ' below.\n\n With this assumption we fix an exponent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1+ ', '\\|', TexCmd('mu'), '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' and look for  holomorphic deformations of the given function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ', via an analytic family of  Beltrami equations together with their principal solutions,\n  ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('defo')]), '\n   F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), '  =  ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), '(z)', '\\,', ' F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_z,', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '   ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), '(z) = ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z) ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '(z)'), BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ' \n'], []), '\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)'], []), ' is an analytic function in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' to be chosen later  with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)| < 1'], []), '. \nWe aim to explore Interpolation in the disk, Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation')]), ', \nby applying it to a suitable non-vanishing analytic family constructed from the derivatives of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)'], []), '. Hence the question is the right choice of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda')], []), '.\n\nWe want ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F^0(z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' z'], []), ', thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_0(z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 0'], []), ', while for some value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' = ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')], []), '\nwe need to have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')), '(z) = |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'], []), ', so that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' f = F^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')), ' '], []), '. \nComparing the exponents in  (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Mainineq')]), ') and  in Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation')]), ' suggests that we choose\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pee')]), '\np = 1 + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'),
