'_', TexCmd('circ'))]), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_0 = ', TexCmd('infty'), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_1 = 2.\n'], []), '\nThese conditions will  then be confronted with the need of  weighted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('L')]), '^2'], []), '-bounds consistent with  the inequality ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Mainineq')]), '.\n \n To make the long story short, we choose \n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:tau')]), '\n', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), '(z) = ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z) ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '(z)'), BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ', ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(' where ')]), ' ', '\\;', ' \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)'), BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)')]), ' = p ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1+|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('lambda'))]), ', \n'], []), '\n or more explicitly,\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n   ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), '(z)', '\\,', ' =', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p', '\\,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)'), BraceGroup('(1+', TexCmd('lambda'), ')', '\\,', ' ', '(1', '\\,', '+', '\\;', ' |', '\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|', '\\,', ')', '\\;', '  - ', '\\;', ' p ', '\\,', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\;', '|', '\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), '\n'], []), '\n The complex parameter  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' runs over the unit disk, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '  |', TexCmd('lambda'), '| < 1', '\\,'], []), '. One may visualize \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)'], []), ' as the conformal mapping  from the unit disk onto the horocycle\n ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [' ', TexCmd('Big\{w'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D :  ', '\\;', ' 2 ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('re'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('w'), BraceGroup('1 + w')]), ')  <  p ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1+|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ' ', TexCmd('Big\}')], []), '\n determined by the weight function in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Mainineq')]), '.\n\nFrom ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq:tau')]), ' one readily sees that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '|', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), '(z) |  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' |', TexCmd('lambda'), '|', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('chi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), '(z) '], []), ', furthermore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', TexCmd('in'), '  ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)', '\\,', ',', '\\,', '0<', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1', '\\,'], []), '  . Therefore the equation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('defo')]), ') admits a unique principal solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'F^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\,', ':', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C', '\\,'], []), ', which is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', BraceGroup('1,', '\\,', TexCmd('alpha'))], []), ' - diffeomorphism. It depends analytically  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('AhBers')]), ' on the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\\,'], []), ', as seen by  developing ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('SBel')]), '  in a Neumann series, and we have\n ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n       |F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_z|^2 ', '\\;', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' ', '\\;', '|F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_z |^2 ', '\\,', '-', '\\,', ' |F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), ' |^2 ', '\\;', ' = ', '\\;', ' J(z,F^', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', '\\;', ' > ', '\\;', '0', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(' everywhere in ')]), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C.\n '], []), '\n Moreover, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F^0(z) = z'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')), ' = f'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')], []), ' was defined by ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('pee')]), '.\n \n  As the non-vanishing analytic family ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup('_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))), '\\}', '_', BraceGroup('_', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('lambda'), '| < 1')), '\\,', ' '], []), ' we choose\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fii')]), '\n ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), '(z)= F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_z(z) (1+', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)).\n '], []), '\n  Explicitly,\n  ', TexNamedEnv('equation*', ['\n  ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), '(z) ', '\\,', '=', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(1+', TexCmd('lambda'), ')', '\\,', '( 1+  |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|', '\\,', ')', '\\;', ' F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_z(z)'), BraceGroup('(1+', TexCmd('lambda'), ')', '\\,', ' ', '(1', '\\,', '+', '\\,', ' |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|', '\\,', ')', '\\;', '  - ', '\\;', ' p ', '\\,', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\;', '|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), '\\,', ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('neq'), '\\,', '0', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('for all')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' z', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D\n  '], []), '\n  Furthermore, since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', '\\;', ' F^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' f', '\\,', ', ', '\\;', '\\;', ' F^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')), '_z ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' f_z', '\\,', ', '], []), ' \n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('mapping')]), '\n |', TexCmd('Phi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')), '(z)| =', '\\;', '( 1+ |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|', '\\,', ') |f_z| =  ', '\\,', ' |f_z| ', '\\,', '+', '\\,', ' |f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), '| ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', ' |Df|\n  '], []), '\n', '\n We shall then apply the Interpolation Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('interpolation')]), ' in the  measure space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' M(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' over the unit disk, where\n  ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n    ', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d ', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z)  = ', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('Big(1'), ' ', '\\,', '-', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p', '\\;', '|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1 + |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('Big)\'), ';', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' dz\n  '], []), '\n  We start with  the centerpoint ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' =0'], []), ', where  the  Beltrami equation reduces to the complex Cauchy-Riemann system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '\\,', 'F_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 0', '\\,'], []), ' with principal solution   the identity map. Hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'F^0_z ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 1', '\\,', ', ', '\\;', TexCmd('Phi'), '_0 (z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 1', '\\,'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'M_0 = ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_0', '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty'), '=1', '\\,'], []), '.\n\nThe estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' M_1 = ', TexCmd('sup'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), '\\|', '', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\|', '_2  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1', '\\,'], []), ' requires just a bit more work.\n First, in view of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('lem:areaineq')]), ',\n  ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n    ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D J(z, F^', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  ', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '\n  '], []), '\n  with equality  if and only if  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' z', '\\,'], []), ' outside the unit disk.\nHere we find from ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq:tau')]), ' that\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n J(z, F^', TexCmd('lambda'), ') = |F^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_z(z)|^2(1-|', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)|^2)=|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)|^2 ( 1-2 ', TexCmd('re'), ' \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)'), BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)')]), ' ', ') = '], []), '\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)|^2 ( 1-p ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1+|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ' ', TexCmd('re'), '  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('lambda'))]), ' ', ') ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' \n|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '(z)|^2 (1-p ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1+|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ' ', ')\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' Hence\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n|', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', '(z) |^2 ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d ', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z)  ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '  ', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), '\\,', 'J(z, F^', TexCmd('lambda'), ')', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n'], []), '\nand, therefore,\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n M_1 ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', TexCmd('sup'), '_', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('lambda'), '| < 1'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D  |', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', '(z) |^2 ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d ', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z) ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('sup'), '_', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('lambda'), '| < 1'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '  ', '_', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D  J(z, F^', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' dz ', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), '\\;', ' 1\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('vskip'), '7pt\nWe are now ready to interpolate.  For every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' r <1', '\\,'], []), ', in view of the interpolation lemma, we have\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n  M_r = ', '\\;', TexCmd('sup'), '_', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('lambda'), '| = r '), ' ', '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('Phi'), '_', BraceGroup('_', TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', '\\|', ' ', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1+r'), BraceGroup('r')])), ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' M_0 ^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-r'), BraceGroup('1+r')])), ' ', '\\,', ' M_1 ^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2r'), BraceGroup('1+r')])), '  ', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1.\n'], []), '\nIt remains to substitute ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'r = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('p-1')]), ' = ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')], []), '\\,', '. The desired inequality is now immediate,\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), ' ', '\\;', ' ', '( 1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p', '\\,', ' |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1+', '\\,', '|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|')]), ' ', ')', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('big'), ' | Df(z)', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('\\,', 'p ')]), '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n', '\\;', ' = ', TexCmd('pi'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' D'), ' ', '\\;', '  ', TexCmd('big|\'), 'Phi', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('circ')), '(z) ', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1+r'), BraceGroup('r')]))]), '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d ', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z) ', '\\;', '\n', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('pi'), '  \n'], []), ' '], [BracketGroup('Proof of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' To infer Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ' we extend ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f'], []), ' as the identity outside ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' is bounded, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' |Df|^2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' K ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' J(x,f) < ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), '. But then one easily verifies that the extended function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), '    defines an element of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '_', BraceGroup('loc'), '()'], []), ', and accordingly, a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiconformal map of  the entire plane.\n\nConsider then a disk ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' D_R ', TexCmd('supset'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. By re-scaling, if necessary, Inequality (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Mainineq')]), ') applies to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'D_R'], []), ' in place of the unit disk and with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', '|D_R|'], []), ' in place of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('pi')], []), '. This yields ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^p_', BraceGroup('D_R'), '[', 'f', ']', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^p_', BraceGroup('D_R'), '[', 'Id', ']', ' '], []), '. On the other hand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^p_', BraceGroup('D_R', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')), '[', 'f', ']', ' ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^p_', BraceGroup('D_R', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')), '[', 'Id', ']', ' ', '\\,'], []), ', by trivial means. Hence Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ' follows. \n\nTheorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh3')]), ', in turn, is a direct consequence of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), '. The pointwise condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(Df)', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 0'], []), ' for  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f = z + h(z)'], []), ', together with the boundary condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C')]), '^', TexCmd('infty'), '_0(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ', ensures that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' represents  a (smooth) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiconformal homeomorphism of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' having identity boundary values. Here ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' are related by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=2K/(K-1)'], []), ' and we may apply Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ' at the borderline exponent.\n'], [BracketGroup('Proof of Theorems ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh3')]), ' and ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('remark', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rem:nonvanishing')]), '\nAbove we employed a standard approximation by smooth homeomorphisms in order to easily ensure that our analytic family of quasiconformal maps has non-vanishing Jacobian everywhere. It might be of interest to observe that actually all analytic families of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), '_z'], []), '-derivatives of  quasiconformal maps are non-vanishing, i.e.~non-vanishing outside a common set of measure zero. This can be deduced via a standard reduction from the following result:\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [' \nAssume that the measurable dilatation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' depends analytically on the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' U'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('subset')], []), ' is a domain. Suppose also\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), '| ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' a ', '\\,', TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega'))], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' a < 1'], []), ',  for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' U'], []), '. \n \n Let   ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f=f(', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ,z)'], []), ' be  the principal solution of the Beltrami equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), '=', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' f_z. '], []), ' Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('to'), ' f_z'], []), ' yields  a non-vanishing analytic family.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' \nBy localization we may assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), 'U='], []), '. If the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' are  smooth functions of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), '-variable, the non-vanishing property is due to Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('aregu')]), '.  \nFor a  general  non-smooth  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' we introduce the mollification ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' , n'), ':=', TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('1/n'), '*', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))], []), ', where  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '_', TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), ' is a standard approximation of identity. Then for any compact subset  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('raja')]), '\n', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('sup'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), ' K'), '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ',n'), ' -', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'), '=0', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for ', '\\;', ' any')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' p>1.\n'], []), '\nDenoting by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_n=f_n(', TexCmd('lambda'), ', z)'], []), ' the principal solution corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ,n')], []), ' and by choosing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' large enough,  we may utilize ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 5.3.1'), BraceGroup('AIMb')]), ', \nto see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\|', ' ', '(f_n)_z - f_z ', '\\|', '_2 ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ', uniformly in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' K'], []), '.\n \nNext,    developing  the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('L')]), '^2(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), '-valued analytic functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' f_z'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '(f_n)_z'], []), '  as a power series in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ", we see from Cauchy's formula that the Taylor coefficients of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '(f_n)_z'], []), ' converge in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('L')]), '^2(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ' to those of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' f_z'], []), '. Thus,   moving to a subsequence if needed, we have outside a set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' of measure zero,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pointwise')]), '\n ', '(f_n)_z(', TexCmd('lambda'), ',z )', TexCmd('to'), ' f_z(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('lambda'), ' ,z), ', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' local ', '\\;', ' uniformly ', '\\;', ' in ')]), '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('in'), '. ', TexCmd('qquad'), '\n'], []), '\n', "\nNow, according to Hurwitz's theorem, the limit of a  sequence of non-vanishing analytic functions converging locally uniformly is either everywhere non-zero, or identically zero. Choosing a parameter ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_0'], []), ', the derivative \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_z(', TexCmd('lambda'), '_0, ', TexCmd('cdot'), ') '], []), ' can vanish only on a set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_0'], []), ' of measure zero ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Corollary 3.7.6'), BraceGroup('AIMb')]), '. Thus  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_z(', TexCmd('lambda'), ',z) ', TexCmd('neq'), ' 0'], []), ' for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ' and every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', '(E ', TexCmd('cup'), ' E_0)'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nThe notions of quasiconvexity and rank-one convexity extend to\nfunctions defined on an open subset  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' O'), TexCmd('subset'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2')], []), '.  Rank-one convexity now demands that\nfor any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' O'), TexCmd('in')], []), ' and rank-one matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2')], []), ' \nthe map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' E(A+tX)'], []), ' is convex in a neighbourhood of zero. The condition for being rank-one concave or null Lagrangian is modified analogously. Similarly, in the definition of quasiconvexity (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('columbo')]), ') one simply restricts to linear maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and perturbations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f', TexCmd('in'), ' A+', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', TexCmd('infty'), '_0(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ' such that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Df(z)', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' O'), TexCmd('in')], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '.'], []), '\n', '\nWith the above generalized definitions in mind we  next explore a dual formulation to Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ', i.e. we\nwill pass via the inverse map from expansion estimates to compression\nestimates. \nIn doing so, we shall restrict to the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' O'), '=', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '_+'], []), ' consisting of matrices with positive\nJacobian determinant.\nThe  inverse functional takes the form\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', [' ', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('E')]))]), '(A) := ', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(A^', BraceGroup('-1'), ') ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('det'), ' A, ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('det'), ' A >0, '], []), ' \nand it preserves rank-one convexity, quasiconvexity as well as polyconvexity\n', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('p.~211'), BraceGroup('ball77')]), '. One should also note that for  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', TexCmd('infty'), '_0(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ' the condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Df(z)=A+D', TexCmd('phi'), ' ', '(z)', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '_+'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' automatically implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' is a diffeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f:', TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('to'), ' A(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), '. This enables one to switch to inverse map if needed.\nOur main  observation here is that the procedure of taking inverse functionals naturally leads to a full\none-parameter family of Burkholder functionals.   \n\nLet us recall the standard case ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('burk')]), ' where one now includes all exponents\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'], []), ',\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(A) = ', '\\,', '\n', TexCmd('Big(\'), ',', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), '  ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('det'), ' A  ', '\\,', '+ ', '\\;', '(1-', '\\,', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', ')', '\\,', '|A|\n^2', '\\,', TexCmd('Big)\'), 'cdot', ' |A|^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ' ', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1\n'], []), '\nWe set for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1'], []), ',\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', [' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p', '\\,', '(A) :=  ', TexCmd('Big(\'), ',', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), '  ', '\\,', ' |A|^2 ', '\\,', '+ ', '\\;', '(1-', '\\,', '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', ')', '\\,', TexCmd('det'), ' A ', '\\,', TexCmd('Big)\'), 'cdot', ' |A|^', BraceGroup('-p'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), '\\,', ' ', '(', TexCmd('det'), '\nA)^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p-1'), ' ', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('quad'), '  ', TexCmd('det'), ' A > 0.\n'], []), '\nThen  the functionals  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p'], []), ' are homogeneous of degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ',  depend\ncontinuously on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', and we have for the inverse transformation\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('B')]))]), '_p = ', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_q'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p+q=2'], []), '. These facts justify\nthe definitions.\nNote that, in particular, we recover the null-Lagrangian cases ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=2'], []), ' as smooth phase transition points between the rank-one convex\nand rank-one concave regimes:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', [' In the space of matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), '\n2'), '_+'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nA ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p (A) ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('is')]), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\n', '\\{', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('rank-one convex')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' 0', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 2'], []))]), ' \n', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('null-Lagrangian')]), ' ', '&  ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' p = 0 '], []), '\\;', ' or', '\\;', ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' p= 2 '], []), '\\;', '\\;', '\n', '\\;')]), '\n', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('rank-one concave')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' p', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 0', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('or')]), '\\;', '\n', '\\;', '\\,', ' p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 2'], []), '. ')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), ' .\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nThe standard case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'], []), ' above goes back to Burkholder\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bu1')]), ' and the rest follows from applying the inverse\ntransformation.\nIn the complex notation we have, for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), ',\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', ' ', '\\;', '= ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p (Df) =\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', TexCmd('Big(\'), ',|f_', BraceGroup('z'), '|', '\\;', TexCmd('mp'), '\\;', '(p-1)', '\\,', ' |f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '| ', '\\;', TexCmd('Big)\'), 'cdot', '\n', TexCmd('Big(\'), ';|f_z|', '\\;', TexCmd('pm'), '\\;', '|f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('z')])), '|', '\\;', TexCmd('Big)^', [BraceGroup('p-1')]), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textrm'), ' d z ', '\\;', ', \n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('pm'), '\\,'], []), ' stands for the sign of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', '(p-1)'], []), '.\n\nAnother application of the inverse transformation, this time to Theorem\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ' leads to\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f : ', '\\,', TexCmd('Omega', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('longrightarrow'))]), '\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'K\n'], []), '-quasiconformal map of a bounded open set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C', '\\,', '\n'], []), '  onto itself, extending continuously up to the boundary, where it\ncoincides with the identity map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'Id(z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' z'], []), '.  Then\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', ' ', '\\;', '\\,', TexCmd('leqslant'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', TexCmd('Omega'), '\n', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'Id', '\\,', ']', '\n', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('for all ')]))]), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), '\\,', ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('K-1')]), ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p\n', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 0', '\\,', '.\n'], []), '\nFurther, the equality occurs  for a class of (compressing) piecewise\nradial mappings discussed in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:radial')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Sharp ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('log')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L', '\\,'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p'], []), ' and Exponential \nintegrability')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('se:limitcases')]), '\n', '\nThe sharp integral inequalities provided by  Theorems ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]), ' and ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), '  give us a number of interesting  consequences. We start with the following optimal form of the Sobolev regularity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiconformal mappings.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('corollary', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('best')]), '\nSuppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), ' is any bounded domain and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f:', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K-'], []), 'quasiconformal mapping, continuous up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(z) = z'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. Then  ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lp1')]), '\n', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('Omega'), '|')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), '  ', TexCmd('big'), ' | Df(z)', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('\\,', 'p ')]), '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup(' 2K ', '\\;', '-', '\\;', ' p', '\\,', '(K-1)')]), '\\;', ',', TexCmd('quad'), ' for', '\\;', '\\;', ' 2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p < ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup('K-1')]), '\\,', '\n'], []), '\nThe estimate holds as an equality for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(z) = z|z|^', BraceGroup('1/K - 1')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', as well for a family of more complicated maps described in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogLeq')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' Inequality (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lp1')]), ') is straightforward consequence of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ', since for  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p < 2K/(K-1)'], []), ' we have pointwise ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' B'), '_p', TexCmd('bigl'), '( Df(x)', TexCmd('bigr'), ')  ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' |Df(x)|^p ', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K - ', '\\;', 'p', '\\,', '(K-1)'), BraceGroup('2K')]), '\\,'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe next introduce yet another rank one-concave variational integral, simply by differentiating  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', '\\,'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'p=2', '\\,'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Buus')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' F_', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', ' := ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('p ', TexCmd('searrow'), ' 2'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', '\\;', ' -', '\\;', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', '2'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', '\\,'), BraceGroup('p ', '\\,', '-', '\\,', '2')]), '\\;', '=\n'], []), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Big[\'), ',(1 + ', TexCmd('log'), ' |Df(z)|^2  )', '\\,', ' J(z,f)', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  ', '\\;', '\\;', '-', '\\;', '\\;', ' |Df(z)|^2  ', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z ', '\\,', TexCmd('Big'), ' ', ']', '\n'], []), '\nThe nonlinear differential expression\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n  J(z,f) ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '\\,', '|Df(z)| ^2 ', '\\,', ','], []), ' for mappings with nonnegative Jacobian, is well known to be locally integrable, see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('GI')]), ' for the following qualitative local estimate on concentric balls ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'B', TexCmd('subset'), ' 2B ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('LlogL')]), '\n ', TexCmd('Xint'), '- _B J(z,f) ', '\\;', TexCmd('log'), ' ', TexCmd('Big(e'), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('\\;', '|Df(z)|^2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xint'), '-_', BraceGroup('_B '), '|Df|^2')]), '  ', TexCmd('Big'), ' ', ')', '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z ', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', ' C', '\\,', TexCmd('Xint'), '-_', BraceGroup('2B'), ' |Df(z)|^2 ', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n'], []), '\nsee also Theorem 8.6.1 in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IMb')]), '.  \nHowever, for global estimates one must impose suitable boundary conditions on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f'], []), '. For example, global ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L', TexCmd('log'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L (', TexCmd('Omega'), ') ', '\\,'], []), ' estimates follow from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL')]), ') if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f', '\\,'], []), ' extends beyond the boundary of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), ' with finite Dirichlet energy and nonnegative Jacobian determinant. This is the case, in particular, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f(z) - z ', TexCmd('in'), '  ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), '.   \n\n Let us denote the class of homeomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' f ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('loc')])), '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)', '\\,'], []), ' which coincide with the identity map outside a compact set by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C) ', '\\,'], []), '.  It is useful to observe (see e.g. ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Thm. 20.1.6'), BraceGroup('AIMb')]), ') that such a map is automatically uniformly continuous. \nFurther, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', TexCmd('infty')], []), '-smooth diffeomorphisms in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C) ', '\\,'], []), ' are dense. Precisely, one has\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('approximation1')]), '\n  Given any homeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C) ', '\\,'], []), ', one can find  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^', TexCmd('infty')], []), '-smooth diffeomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C) ', '\\,', ',', '\\,', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1', '\\,'], []), ',  such that\n  ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\\|', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), '\\,', '-f', '\\|', '_', TexCmd('infty'), ' + ', '\\,', '\\;', '\\|', 'D(f^', TexCmd('ell'), '\\,', '-f', '\\,', ')', '\\|', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^2(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C)'), '\\;', 'arrow 0, ', TexCmd('quad'), '  ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' as ')]), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('ellarrow'), TexCmd('infty'), '. '], []), '\nPassing to a subsequence if necessary,  we may ensure that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', 'Df^', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('longrightarrow'), ' Df', '\\,'], []), ' almost everywhere.\n'], [BracketGroup('Approximation Lemma, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Thm. 1.1'), BraceGroup('IKO')])), '\n ')]), '\n', '\nWith estimates for the Burkholder integrals we now arrive at  sharp global ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L', TexCmd('log'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L (', TexCmd('Omega'), ') ', '\\,'], []), ' bounds.\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nUpon the extension  as identity outside ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f ', TexCmd('in'), '  ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C) ', '\\,'], []), '. We use the sequence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '\\,', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), '\\,', '\\}', '\\,'], []), ' in the approximation Lemma  ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('approximation1')]), ', and view each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), '\\,'], []), ' as a principal solution to its own  Beltrami equation\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n  f^', TexCmd('ell'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), ' ', '\\;', '= ', '\\;', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), '(z) ', '\\,', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), '_z ', '\\;', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('quad'), '\\;', '\\;', ' |', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), '(z) | ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' k_', TexCmd('ell'), ' <1', '\\;', ', ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), '(z) = 0', '\\;', ', ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('for')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' |z| ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' R.\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'R', '\\,'], []), ' is chosen, and temporarily fixed, large enough so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' D_R = ', '\\{', 'z', '\\;', ': |z| < R', '\\}', '\\,'], []), '. It is legitimate to apply  Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ' for each of the maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), ':  ', '\\,', 'D_R ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', '\\,', 'D_R', '\\,'], []), ',\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n  ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^p_', BraceGroup('D_R'), '\\,', '[', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), ']', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', '|D_R| ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^2_', BraceGroup('D_R'), '\\,', '[', 'f^', TexCmd('ell'), ']', ' ', '\\;', ',', TexCmd('quad'), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('whenever')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' 2', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1 + k_', TexCmd('ell'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\n'], []), '\nLetting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'p ', TexCmd('searrow'), ' 2', '\\,'], []), ' we obtain \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), ' ', '\\,', '(1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' |Df^', TexCmd('ell'), '(z)|^2 ', '\\,', ' ', ')', '\\,', ' J(z,f^', TexCmd('ell'), ')', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  ', '\\;', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), '  |Df^', TexCmd('ell'), '(z)|^2  ', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n'], []), '\nConvergence theorems in the theory of integrals let us pass to the limit when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('ellarrow'), ' ', TexCmd('infty'), '\\,'], []), ', as follows\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), ' ', '\\,', 'J(z,f)', '\\,', '[', '1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' |Df(z)|^2 ', '\\,', ' ', ']', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  = '], []), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), ' J(z,f)', '[', '1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), '(1+ |Df|^2) ', '\\,', ' ', ']', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z', '\\;', '\n-', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('liminf'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ellarrow'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')), ' ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), ' ', '\\,', 'J(z,f^', TexCmd('ell'), ')', '\\,', '[', '1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), '(1+ |Df^', TexCmd('ell'), '|^2) ', '\\,', ' ', ']', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z '], []), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['-', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ellarrow'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), ' ', '\\,', 'J(z,f^', TexCmd('ell'), ')', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '( 1 + |Df^', TexCmd('ell'), '|^', BraceGroup('-2'), '  ', '\\,', ' ', ')', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  '], []), '\n Here the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('liminf'), ')'], []), "-term is justified by Fatou's theorem while the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('lim'), ')'], []), '-term by the Lebesgue dominated convergence,  where we observe that the integrand is dominated point-wise by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' J(z,f^', TexCmd('ell'), ')', '\\,', '| Df^', TexCmd('ell'), '| ^', BraceGroup('-2'), '\\,', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1'], []), '. The lines of computation continue as follows\n ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n  =', '\\;', '\\;', TexCmd('liminf'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ellarrow'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')), ' ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), ' ', '\\,', 'J(z,f^', TexCmd('ell'), ')', '\\,', '[', '1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), '|Df^', TexCmd('ell'), '|^2 ', '\\,', ' ', ']', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '\n '], []), '\n', '\n ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n ', TexCmd('liminf'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ellarrow'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')), ' ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), '  |Df^', TexCmd('ell'), '|^2 ', '\\,', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  = ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R'), ' ', '\\,', ' |Df(z)|^2 ', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n '], []), '\nFinally, we observe that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '\\,', 'J(z,f)', '\\,', '[', '1', '\\,', ' + ', '\\,', TexCmd('log'), ' |Df(z)|^2 ', '\\,', ' ', ']', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z  = ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('D_R', TexCmd('setminus'), TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '\\,', ' |Df(z)|^2 ', '\\,', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z', '\\;', ','], []), '\nwhich combined with the previous estimate yields ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('LlogL1')]), ',\nas desired.\n'], [BracketGroup('Proof of Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL Th')]))]), '\n', '\n The above energy functional can be further cultivated by applying  the inverse map, as described at the end of Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('se:proof')]), '.  A search of minimal regularity in  the corresponding integral estimates leads us to  mappings of integrable distortion.\n \n ', TexNamedEnv('corollary', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('loginv')]), ' Let  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('subset'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), ' be a bounded domain, and suppose  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W')]), '^', BraceGroup('1,1'), '_', BraceGroup('loc'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), '  is a homeomorphism of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h(z) = z'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), '.\n Assume ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' satisfies the distortion inequality\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('distortion2')]), '\n|D h(z)|^2', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' K(z)J(z,h),', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' a.e', '\\;', '\\;', ' in')]), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' K(z)<', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' almost everywhere in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '.'], []), ' The smallest such function, denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' K(z,h)'], []), ', is assumed to be integrable. \n Then\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('loginvar')]), ' 2 ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('log'), ' |Dh| - ', TexCmd('log'), ' J(z,h) ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '  ', '\\;', '  ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '  K(z,h) -  J(z,h)\n '], []), '\nIn particular,  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('log'), ' J(z,h)'], []), ' is integrable. Again there is a wealth of functions, to be described in Section 5, \n satisfying  ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('loginvar')]), ' as an identity.\n '], []), '\n Note that in fact\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nK(z,h)=', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|Dh(z)|^2'), BraceGroup('J(z,h)')]), ', & ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' if'), '\\;', '\\;', '  J(z,h) > 0,\n1, & ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' otherwise'), '.', '\\;', '\\;', '  \n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '.\n'], []), '\nThus according to the corollary, the functional ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' H'), ' ', '(A)'], []), ' in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('functional')]), ' is quasiconvex at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A= Id'], []), ', in its entire natural domain of definition  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' O'), '=', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '_+'], []), '.\n \n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nIt was observed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('AIMO')]), ' that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h:', TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('to'), ' h(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'], []), ' is a homeomorphism of Sobolev class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_', BraceGroup('loc'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'], []), ' with integrable distortion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(z,h)', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^1 (', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '),'], []), ' then its inverse map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f= h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ': h(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')', TexCmd('overset', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' onto')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('to'))]), TexCmd('Omega'), ' '], []), ' belongs to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), ' ', '(h(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '))'], []), ' and one has \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('aimo')]), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('h(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'), ' |Df|^2=', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' K(z,h).\n'], []), '\nEnhancement of this identity for mappings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,1'), '_', BraceGroup('loc'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'], []), ' is given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('HKO')]), '.\n\nIn our situation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(z)-z=h^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(z)-z'], []), ' is continuous in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega'))])], []), ', vanishes on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), TexCmd('Omega')], []), ',\nand belongs to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'], []), '. It is well-known that this implies  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(z)', TexCmd('in'), ' z+', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '_0(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ').'], []), ' Thus it is legitimate to apply  Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL Th')]), ' to deduce\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('jj')]), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega'), ' '), ' 1+ 2', TexCmd('log'), ' ', TexCmd('Bigl'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|Dh|'), BraceGroup('J(z,h)')]), TexCmd('Bigr'), ')', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' K(z,h).\n'], []), '\nHere we used the identity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|A^', BraceGroup('-1'), '| = |A|/', TexCmd('det'), '(A)'], []), ' and a change of variable, made legitimate by the fact  that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' is a homeomorphism of Sobolev class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,2'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ').'], []), ' The claim obviously follows from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('jj')]), "), and Hadamard's inequality  yields the logarithmic integrability, \n", TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['- ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '  ', TexCmd('log'), ' J(z,h) ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 2 ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('log'), ' |Dh| - ', TexCmd('log'), ' J(z,h),\n'], []), '\nwith equality here for the indentity mapping.\n'], [BracketGroup('Proof of Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('loginv')]))]), '\n', '\n ', '\nIn particular,  the Jacobian of a map with integrable distortion cannot approach zero too rapidly. This result is in fact known ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KO')]), ', the novelty in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('loginvar')]), ') is the sharpness.\n\n\n\n\nWe next turn to  the exponential integrability results, which will follow from  Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]), ' at the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty'), ' .'], []), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' Let us assume we are given a function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ',  supported in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), '\\,'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' |', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('in'), '.'], []), '  We (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-|', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|'), BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' |', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)|')]), ')', TexCmd('big|\'), ', Df(z)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('1+1/', TexCmd('varepsilon'))]), '\\,', ' dz', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ' .\n'], []), '\nBy applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L'), '^2'], []), '-isometric property of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbf'), ' S')], []), ', wee see that for\nalmost every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', developing ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('SBel')]), '-', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('56')]), ' to  a  Neumann\nseries represents  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_z '], []), '  as a power series in  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), ', with  convergence radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'], []), '. Baernstein and S. Montgomery-Smith, or in the paper  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Iw1')]), ' of the second author.\nLet us start by  describing the building block of the maps that yields equality in our main result. For any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' r<R'], []), ' consider the radial map\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rad')]), '\ng(z) = ', TexCmd('rho'), '(', '\\,', '|z |', '\\,', ') ', '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('z  '), BraceGroup('|z|')]), '\n'], []), '\ndefined in the disc ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', ' |z|', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' R', '\\}', '.'], []), ' We assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ':', '[', '0,R', ']', TexCmd('to', [BracketGroup('0,R')])], []), ' is  absolutely continuous and strictly increasing with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(0)=0'], []), ', and that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' is linear on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '0,r', ']'], []), '. We first restrict ourselves to the situation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'], []), ', and then   need the following ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('expanding assumption')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('expanding')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'))]), '(t)', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 0', '\\;', ',', TexCmd('qquad'), ' t', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(r, R)\n'], []), '\ntogether with the normalization ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R)=R.'], []), '  Hence on the boundary\nthe map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' coincides with the identity map, and if needed we may extend ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' to the exterior ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', ' |z|', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' R', '\\}'], []), ' by setting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g(z)=z'], []), ' for these values. \n\nThe differential of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' exhibits the following rank-one connections\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:diff')]), '\nDg(z)= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(|z|)'), BraceGroup('|z|')]), ' Id + ( ', TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'))]), '(|z|) - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(|z|)'), BraceGroup('|z|')]), ' ', ') ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('z ', TexCmd('otimes'), ' z'), BraceGroup('|z|^2')]), '.\n'], []), '\nIt is known, see ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Proposition 3.4'), BraceGroup('Ball90')]), ' that concavity along the indicated rank-one lines already secures the quasiconcavity\ncondition for the radial map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '.\nIn our situation the assumption (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expanding')]), ') indeed ensures that the\nBurkholder integrals become linear on the rank-one segments displayed in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq:diff')]), ', which implies\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:radialquasiconcavity')]), '\n ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup('B(0,R)'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n     ', ")'", '\\;', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), ' t  ', '\\;', '=', '\\;', '  ', TexCmd('pi'), '\\;', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('[', '\\,', TexCmd('rho'), '(R)', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup('B(0,R)'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'Id', ']', ' .\n     ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n     '], []), '\nThe above computation indicates that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'r = 0', '\\,'], []), ',  we must  in addition require  \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('aa1')]), '\n', '\\,', TexCmd('rho'), '(t) = o( t^', BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('p')])), ')', '\\,', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' as')]), '\\;', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', ' t', TexCmd('to'), ' 0', '\\,', '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nAssume then that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_0(z)=az+b'], []), ' is a (complex) linear map defined in a bounded domain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('subset'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '.'], []), ' Given ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' r<R'], []), ' and a   ball ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(z_0,R)', TexCmd('subset'), ' ',
