',\nag(z-z_0)+(az_0+b) & ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' if'), '\\;', '\\;', '  z ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup('B(z_0,R)')]), ',\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '.\n'], []), '\nBy scaling, (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:radialquasiconcavity')]), ') shows that we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup('B(z_0,R)'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f_1', ']', ' = ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup('B(z_0,R)'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f_0', ']', ','], []), ' and, consequently\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq101')]), '\n ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega'), ' '), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f_1', ']', ' = ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega'), ' '), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f_0', ']', '.\n'], []), '\nIn the next step we may deform ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_1'], []), ' in a disc that is contained in either  one of the sets  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('setminus'), ' B(z_0,R)'], []), ' or  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' B(z_0, r)'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_1'], []), ' is linear. Inductively one obtains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_n'], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('n-1')], []), ' by deforming ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('n-1')], []), ' accordingly in the domains of linearity. \n   By induction, we see that all such mappings  have the same energy, which is equal to the energy of their linear boundary data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'az + b'], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('energy')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), '\n ', '\\,', '[', ' f_', BraceGroup('n'), ']', '\\;', '=', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '\\,', '[', 'az+b', ']', ' ', '\\;', ' =', '\\;', ' a^p', '\\,', '|', TexCmd('Omega'), '|\n'], []), '\n', '\n  ', '\n', '\nThis iteration process may, but need not, continue indefinitely so as to arrive at e.g.  Cantor type configuration of annuli and a homeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f_', TexCmd('infty'), ' :', '\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('overset', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tiny', [BraceGroup('onto')]))])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('longrightarrow'))]), '\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '^*', '\\,', ':=a', TexCmd('Omega'), ' +b'], []), '.    Without going to the formal definition, we loosely refer to reasonable (e.g. converging in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,1')], []), ') such limits ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f=', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')), ' ', '\\,', 'f_n'], []), '  as ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('piece-wise radial mappings')]), ', see Figure 1.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=4.5in'), BraceGroup('packing3.pdf')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Annular Packing')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', [' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'], []), ' and let  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' C', '\\,'], []), ' be any nonempty \n bounded domain.  \nThe class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' consists  of  piece-wise radial mappings \n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f_', TexCmd('infty'), ' : ', '\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('overset', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tiny', [BraceGroup('onto')]))])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('longrightarrow'))]), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), '   whose construction starts with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', ' f_0(z) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' z', '\\,'], []), ', the convergence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', TexCmd('infty'), '=', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')), ' f_n'], []), ' takes place in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,p'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ')'], []), ' and the condition (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expanding')]), ') is in force.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' The following observation is a direct corollary of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('energy')]), ').\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Equality')]), '\nFor any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1'], []), ' and   ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), 'f', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '^p(', TexCmd('Omega')], []), ') we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('aaaaa')]), '\n', '\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f', ']', ' = ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('Id')]), ']', ' ', '\\,', '= |', TexCmd('Omega'), '|.\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' In interpreting this conclusion one may say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,'], []), ' is a null Lagrangian when restricted to   ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), '\\,', '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), '.\n\nWe get a plethora of fairly complicated maps that produce equality in our main Theorems.\nOne just needs to consider any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\,', '^p', '\\,'], []), ' that satisfies the additional\ncondition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf'), ' B_p(Df(x)) ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 0,'], []), ' i.e. in the construction one applies maps  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' that\nsatisfy\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rho4')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'))]), '(t)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Big(1'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', TexCmd('Big)\'), ', ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), '.\n'], []), '\nIn case of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh3')]), ', in order to satisfy the smoothness assumption  one of course has to pick the functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' in the construction  so that the (possibly limiting) map belongs to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Id + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), '_', TexCmd('circ'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', ').'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n In order to incorporate the range  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' 1'], []), ', one introduces  the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('compressing assumption')]), ', the opposite of \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expanding')]), '):\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nonexpanding')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('leqslant'), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'))]), '(t)', '\\;', ',', TexCmd('qquad'), ' t', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(r, R)\n'], []), '\ntogether with the condition\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['  ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('t', TexCmd('to'), ' 0^+'), TexCmd('rho'), '(t)/t^', BraceGroup('1-2/p'), '=', TexCmd('infty')], []), '\nin case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p<0'], []), '.\nThe previous construction yields after finitely many iterations non-trivial examples of maps that satisfy \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('aaaaa')]), ') in case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p<1.'], []), ' Also limiting maps can be considered, but then one has to take care of  the Burkholder functional to remain well-defined.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn view of Conjecture ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup("Morrey's")]), ', the maps in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), '\\,', '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' are potential global\n extremals for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,'], []), '. Indeed, it can  be shown that they are critical points of the associated Euler-Lagrange \nequations. Furthermore, this property to a large extent characterizes Burkholder \nfunctionals: these functionals are the only (up to scalar multiple) isotropic and homogeneous \nvariational integrals with  the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), '\\,', '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' as their  critical points. This topic will be discussed in a companion paper. \n\nHere, we \ncontent with pointing out the following result, where we employ  the customary  notation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,', ' = ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')]), ' ', '\\,', '+ ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1_', TexCmd('circ'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ', where  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1_', TexCmd('circ'), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' stands for the space  of functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1'], []), ' -smooth up to the boundary of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), ' and vanishing on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\,'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('corollary', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('locmaxima')]), '\nThe Burkholder functional ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '_', TexCmd('Omega'), '\\;', ' :  ', '\\;', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ') arrow ', '\\,', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R', '\\,'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '\\,', 'p> 2', '\\,', ','], []), ' attains its local maximum at every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1'], []), '- smooth piece-wise radial map in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), '\\,', ' ', '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,', ' '], []), ' for which the condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rho4')]), ')'], []), ' is  further reinforced  to:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rho3')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'))]), '(t)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('K')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' K< ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('p-2')]), '.\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['The lower bound (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rho3')]), ') can be used to verify that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-quasiconformal with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K<p/(p-2).'], []), '\n Namely, as  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f ', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('id')])), '(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ', one checks that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' is necessarily conformal at points corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t=0'], []), ' and the derivative is non-vanishing.  Hence the strict inequality for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' will not be destroyed by small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' C^1'], []), ' -perturbations.  Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh2')]), ' applies, and by combining it with Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Equality')]), ' the claim is evident. \n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Equality in Corollaries ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL Th')]), ',   ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expint')]), ',  ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('best')]), ' and ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('loginv')]))]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('LlogLeq')]), ' \n', '\nIf one substitutes in the formula ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Buus')]), ' a function for which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '_', TexCmd('Omega', [BracketGroup('f')]), ' ', '\\;', ' = ', '\\;', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B^', BraceGroup('\\,', '2'), '_', TexCmd('Omega', [BracketGroup('f')])], []), ', we  acquire\n the equality in the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('L', TexCmd('log'), ' L')])], []), '-inequality  of  Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL Th')]), '. Especially, by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('aaaaa')]), ') we obtain\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' be a bounded domain in the plane.\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' belongs to class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bigcup'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), BraceGroup('p>2'), '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ', then there is equality in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('LlogL1')]), '  in Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('LlogL Th')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' Actually, one checks that in the construction condition (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('aa1')]), ') can be replaced by the analogue\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(t)=o', TexCmd('big(\'), 'log', ' ', '(1/t)^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('big).')], []), ' Concerning Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('loginv')]), ', an alternative route to its  integral estimates comes by taking the derivative  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), '_p ', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' B_', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'p'), '\\,', '[', 'f', ']'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0'], []), '.\nThus elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bigcup'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), BraceGroup('p<0'), '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), ' give the identity at ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('loginvar')]), '.\n\nWe next turn our attention to  Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expint')]), '. It turns out that there, as well, one has a very extensive class of functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' of radial type that yield an equality in the estimates. These functions can be viewed as infinitesimal generators of the expanding class of radial mappings defined above. \n \n ', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('exponentialexample')]), '   Let  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('colon'), ' ', '(0,1)', TexCmd('to', [BracketGroup('0,1')])], []), ' be measurable and with the property\n ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('int'), '_0^1 ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('alpha'), '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), '  dt= ', TexCmd('infty'), ' . \n '], []), '\n Set ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mu'), '(z) = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('z'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z')]), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '(|z|) ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' for  ')]), ' |z| < 1,   ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '(z) = 0', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' for ')]), ' |z| ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' 1.'], []), ' Then\n there is equality in Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expint')]), ', i.e.\n ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['  ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('int'), '_ (1-|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|) ', '\\;', 'e^', BraceGroup('\\,', ' |', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)| ', '\\,'), '\\,', '  ', TexCmd('bigl'), '| ', TexCmd('exp'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('S')]), TexCmd('mu'), '(z)'), ') ', TexCmd('bigr'), '| ', '\\;', 'dz = ', TexCmd('pi'), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(z) = 2 z ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('|z|'), '^1 ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), ' ', '\\,', ' dt'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|z| < 1'], []), ' and set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(z) = 0 '], []), ' elsewhere. Then we compute that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), ' ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', BraceGroup('1,2'), '()'], []), ' with\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [' ', TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' z'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('phi'), '_z = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('beur')), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z) = 2', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('|z|'), '^1 ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '(t)'), BraceGroup('t')]), ' ', '\\,', ' dt - ', TexCmd('alpha'), '(|z|), ', TexCmd('quad'), ' |z| < 1.\n'], []), '\nThus\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\n', '&& ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('D')]), TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.5cm')]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_ (1-|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)|) e^', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mu'), '(z)| + ', TexCmd('re'), '  ', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('beur')), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(z)'), ' dm  && = \n2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('int'), '_0^1 ', TexCmd('bigl'), '(1-', TexCmd('alpha'), '(t)', TexCmd('bigr'), ') ', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup(' 2', TexCmd('int'), '_t^1 ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '(s)'), BraceGroup('s')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ds   ')]), ' ', '\\;', 't ', '\\,', ' dt  = ', TexCmd('pi'), ',\n'], []), '\nas we have the identity\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('dt')]), ' ', '( t^2  ', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup(' 2', TexCmd('int'), '_t^1 ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '(s)'), BraceGroup('s')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ds   ')]), '  ', ') = 2t  ', TexCmd('bigl'), '(1-', TexCmd('alpha'), '(t)', TexCmd('bigr'), ')  ', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup(' 2', TexCmd('int'), '_t^1 ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '(s)'), BraceGroup('s')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ds   ')]), '\n'], []), '\nand our assumption gets rid of the substitution at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t=0'], []), '.\n'], []), '\nMore complicated examples may be obtained by a similar iteration procedure as described above.\n\nFinally, equality in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lp1')]), ') obviously implies that necessarily  the distortion function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(z,f) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' K'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), '. Hence examples are produced by specific functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('rad')]), ', the powers\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_K(t) ', '\\;', ' = ', '\\;', ' R^', BraceGroup('1-1/K'), ' ', '\\;', 't^', BraceGroup('1/K'), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' r <  t < R,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_K(t)'], []), ' is linear on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(0,r', ']'], []), ', if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r >0'], []), '. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2 ', TexCmd('leqslant'), ' p < ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup('K-1')])], []), ' \nlet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), '\\,', '_', BraceGroup('K'), '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' denote the subclass of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), '\\,', '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' consisting of  those piecewise radial mappings where, first, we fill the domain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), ' by discs or annuli up to measure zero, second,  at each construction step  choose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' = ', TexCmd('rho'), '_K'], []), ', and third, choose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=0'], []), ' at any possible subdisk remaining in the limiting packing construction.\nThis ensures that the limiting function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' does not remain linear  in any subdisk,  so that we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(z,f) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' K'], []), ' up to a set of measure zero. Then, as  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('Omega'), '|<', TexCmd('infty'), ' ,'], []), '  it is easy to see that convergence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', TexCmd('infty'), '=', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')), ' f_n'], []), ' takes place in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr'), ' W^', BraceGroup('1,p')], []), ' since now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1- p|', TexCmd('mu'), '_n (z)|(1+|', TexCmd('mu'), '_n (z)|)^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', TexCmd('geqslant'), ' c_0>0'], []), '. Moreover, since there is equality in\nTheorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MainTh')]), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(z,f) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' K'], []), ', one obtains for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' A'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\,', '_', BraceGroup('K'), '^p(', TexCmd('Omega'), ')', '\\,'], []), ' that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('Omega'), '|')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), '  ', TexCmd('big'), ' | Df(z)', TexCmd('big|^', [BraceGroup('\\,', 'p ')]), '\\;', TexCmd('textnormal'), ' d z\n=  ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2K'), BraceGroup(' 2K ', '\\;', '-', '\\;', ' p', '\\,', '(K-1)')]), '\\;', '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('On ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p'], []), '-bounds for Quasiconformal Mappings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^n'], []), ' ')]), '\nLet us close with a discussion on higher dimensional analogues of our optimal results in plane.\nThis leads to new conjectures on the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('mathscr'), ' L^p'], []), '-regularity problem of quasiconformal maps in space. We begin with the following statement in all dimensions.\n ', TexNamedEnv('theorem', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Bp')]), 'The functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\;', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'n'), ' : ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R', '\\,'], []), '  defined by\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('BpInt')]), '\n', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_p^', BraceGroup('\\,', 'n'), '\\,', '(A) = ', '\\,', TexCmd('Big(\'), '; ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('n')]), TexCmd('det'), ' A  ', '\\;', ' +', '\\;', ' ', '(1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('n')]), ')', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('big{|'), '}', 'A', TexCmd('big{|'), '}', '^n ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('Big)\'), 'cdot', ' |A|^', BraceGroup('p-n'), ',', TexCmd('qquad'), '  p', TexCmd('geqslant', [BraceGroup('n')]), '.\n'], []), '\nare rank-one concave.\n'], []), '\nFor the proof  and more information on this topic see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Iw1')]), '. Of course, one may be tempted to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup(' B_p^')]), BraceGroup('n'), ' ', '\\,'], []), ' is quasiconcave, but that is beyond our reach in such a generality. \nHowever, we state here  potential consequences of the conceivable quasiconcavity of the above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '-dimensional Burkholder functional for quasiconformal maps, i.e. analogues of our optimal results in plane. \n\n  \n', TexNamedEnv('conjecture', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sharp')]), '\n Suppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'f:', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' B arrow ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' B', '\\,'], []), ' is a  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', 'K', '\\,'], []), '-quasiconformal mapping of the unit ball onto itself that is equal to the identity on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' B', '\\,'], []), '.\nThen,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', BraceGroup('\\!', '\\!', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' B'), '( n -
