For any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' V(G)'], []), ', the restriction\nof this distribution to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_X'], []), ' yields a balanced probability\ndistribution on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), '.  The following easy fact will be used\nseveral times throughout the proof:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('cla', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cl:balanced')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic bridgeless graph and consider ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' X\n  ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' V(G)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=', TexCmd('delta'), '(Y)'], []), ' is a 3-edge-cut in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. For\n  any balanced probability distribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), ', and any\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G,X)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('bM'), ' =M')]), '>0'], []), ', we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|M', TexCmd('cap'), ' C|=1'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nGiven some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G,X)'], []), ', a cycle of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ' is\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-alternating')]), ' if it has even length and half of its edges are\nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' ', '(it alternates edges in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' and edges not in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '). Let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a(G,X,M)'], []), ' denote the maximum number of disjoint ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-alternating\ncycles in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ' ', '(equivalently, the maximum number of components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M\n', TexCmd('triangle'), " M'"], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M' ", TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G,X)'], []), ').\n\nWe define a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('burl')]), ' as a vertex set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' V(G)'], []), ' such that\nfor any balanced probability distribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('tfrac'), '13'], []), '. Note that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a burl, any set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y\n', TexCmd('supset'), ' X'], []), ' is also a burl, since any balanced probability distribution\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,Y)'], []), ' induces a balanced probability distribution on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), '. We would like to insist on the fact that we consider the\nwhole set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), ', and not only ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'M ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('cap'), ' E_X, M ', TexCmd('in'), '\n', '(G)', '\\}'], []), '. This way, being a burl is really a local property of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '\nand is completely independent of the structure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|(V(G) ', TexCmd('setminus'), '\nX)'], []), '. This aspect of burls will be fundamental in the proof of\nTheorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main2')]), '.\n\nA collection of disjoint vertex sets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'X_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',X_k', '\\}'], []), ' is a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), '\n  foliage'), ' if each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i'], []), ' is a burl.  Assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' contains such a\ncollection of disjoint sets, and consider a balanced probability\ndistribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,V(G))=(G)'], []), '. This distribution\ninduces balanced probability distributions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup('X_i')], []), ' on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X_i)'], []), ', for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i ', TexCmd('le'), ' k'], []), '. By definition of a burl, we\nhave ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('tfrac'), '13'], []), ' for each each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i ', TexCmd('le'), '\nk'], []), '. By linearity of expectation, the maximum number of disjoint\nalternating cycles of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' is then expected to be at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k/3'], []), '. We\nget the following key fact as a consequence:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('cor', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('c:FoliageApplied')]), '\n  If a cubic bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' contains a foliage ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')])], []), ', then\n  there exist perfect matchings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M,M' ", TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M\n  ', TexCmd('triangle'), " M'"], []), ' has at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '||/3'], []), ' components.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nWe now introduce a special class of burls. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic\nbridgeless graph and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' V(G)'], []), '. We say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '-twig')]), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)|=2'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '-twig')]), ' if\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)|=3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|X| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 5'], []), ' ', '(that is, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is neither a triangle,\nnor a single vertex).  A ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('twig')]), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '- or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '-twig.\nBefore we prove that every twig is a burl, we need a simple lemma.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:smallcount')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic bridgeless graph. Then\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n ', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  The first item follows from the classical result mentioned in the\n  introduction: every edge of a cubic bridgeless graph is contained in\n  a perfect matching.  The second is implied by the bound ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m(G)', TexCmd('geq'), '\n  ', TexCmd('tfrac'), ' 14|V(G)|+2'], []), ' from~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('edmondslp82')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:twigs')]), '\nEvery twig ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' in a cubic bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' be a balanced probability distribution on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), '.\n\n  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '-twig, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' be obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ' by adding an\n  edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' joining the two vertices incident with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(X)'], []), '. Then\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' is cubic and bridgeless. By applying Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:smallcount')]), '(1)\n  to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ', we see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ' contains at least one ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-alternating\n  cycle for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G,X)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('cap'), '\n  ', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)=', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), '. Note that since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' is cubic, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|X|'], []), ' is even,\n  and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' either contains the two edges of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(X)'], []), ', or none\n  of them. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' is balanced, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('bM'), ' ', TexCmd('cap'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)=\n  ', TexCmd('emptyset'))]), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 1-1/3=2/3'], []), '. Hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('tfrac'), '23'], []), ' and\n  we conclude that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a burl.\n\n  Suppose now that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '-twig. Let\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(X)=', '\\{', 'e_1,e_2,e_3', '\\}'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' be obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by\n  identifying all the vertices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G)-X'], []), ' ', '(removing loops but\n  preserving multiple edges). We apply Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:smallcount')]), '(2) to\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ', which is again cubic and bridgeless. It follows that for some\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 3'], []), ', the edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_i'], []), ' is in at least two perfect\n  matchings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), '. Therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ' contains at least one\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-alternating cycle for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G,X)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('cap'), '\n  ', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)= ', '\\{', 'e_i', '\\}'], []), '. By Claim~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cl:balanced')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('bM'), ' ', TexCmd('cap'), '\n  ', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)= ', '\\{', 'e_i', '\\}')]), '=', TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup('e_i ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('bM'))]), '=1/3'], []), '. It implies that\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('tfrac'), '13'], []), ' and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('weight')]), ' of a foliage ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')])], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' twigs is defined\nas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '() := ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('beta'), '_1 k + ', TexCmd('beta'), '_2 (||-k)'], []), ', that is each twig\nhas weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_1'], []), ' and each non-twig burl has weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_2'], []), '. Let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '(G)'], []), ' denote the maximum weight of a foliage in a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Reducing on small edge-cuts')]), '\n', '\n', '\nWe now describe how we reduce on 2-edge-cuts and 3-edge-cuts, and\nconsider how these operations affect ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(G)'], []), ' and foliages.  Let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '-edge-cut in a cubic bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. The two graphs\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by identifying all vertices on one\nof the sides of the edge-cut (removing loops but preserving multiple\nedges) are referred to as ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '-contractions')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and the\nvertices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' created by this identification are called\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('new')]), '.\n\nWe need a similar definition for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '-edge-cuts. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=', '\\{', "e,e'", '\\}'], []), ' be a\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '-edge-cut in a cubic bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. The two\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '-contractions')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' are now obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by\ndeleting all vertices on one of the sides of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' and adding an edge joining\nthe remaining ends of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["e'"], []), '. The resulting edge is now called\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('new')]), '.\n\nIn both cases we say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('are obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\n  by a cut-contraction')]), '. The next lemma provides some useful\nproperties of cut-contractions.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:Contraction')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a graph, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '- or a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '-edge-cut in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', and\n  let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' be the two ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '-contractions. Then\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nIt is not generally advantageous to reduce on a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '-edge-cut arising\nfrom a triangle, unless this reduction leads to a chain of similar\nreductions.  Thus we wish to get rid of certain triangles from the\noutset.  We say that a triangle sharing precisely one edge with a\ncycle of length three or four in a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('relevant')]), ', and\notherwise it is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('irrelevant')]), '.  A graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('pruned')]), ' if it\ncontains no irrelevant triangles.  The following easy lemma shows that\nwe can prune a bridgeless cubic graph by repeated cut-contraction\nwithout losing too many vertices.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:ContractTriangles')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic bridgeless graph, and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' be the size of\n  maximum collection of vertex-disjoint irrelevant triangles in\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Then one can obtain a pruned cubic bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' from\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|V(G')| ", TexCmd('geq'), ' |V(G)|-2k'], []), ' by repeatedly contracting\n  irrelevant triangles.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  We proceed by induction on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '. Let a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' be obtained from\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by contracting an irrelevant triangle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '. The graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' is\n  cubic and bridgeless by Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Contraction')]), '(1).  Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is\n  irrelevant in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', the unique vertex of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' obtained by\n  contracting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is not in a triangle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), '. Therefore if\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' is a collection of vertex disjoint irrelevant\n  triangles in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' ', TexCmd('cup'), ' ', '\\{', 'T', '\\}'], []), ' is such a\n  collection in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. (After the contraction of an irrelevant triangle,\n  triangles that were previously irrelevant might become relevant, but\n  the converse is not possible.) It follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '| ', TexCmd('leq'), '\n  k-1'], []), '. By applying the induction hypothesis to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ', we see that the\n  lemma holds for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('cor', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('c:Prune')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic bridgeless graph. Then we can obtain a cubic\n  bridgeless pruned graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|V(G')| ", TexCmd('geq'), ' |V(G)|/3'], []), '\n  by repeatedly contracting irrelevant triangles.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe wish to restrict our attention to pruned graphs, so we must make\nsure that the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(G)'], []), ' and the maximum size of a\nfoliage does not increase when we contract a triangle.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:Triangle')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' be obtained from a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by contracting a\n  triangle. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), "(G') ", TexCmd('leq'), ' m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(G)'], []), ' and the maximum\n  size of a foliage in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is at most the maximum size of a foliage\n  in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['xyz'], []), ' be the contracted triangle, and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_x'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_y'], []), ', and\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_z'], []), ' be the edges incident with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' and not contained in\n  the triangle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' be the vertex of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' corresponding to\n  the contraction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['xyz'], []), '. Every perfect matching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' has a\n  canonical extension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ': assume without loss of generality\n  that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_x'], []), ' is the unique edge of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' incident to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), '.  Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '\n  consists of the union of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['yz'], []), '. Observe that perfect\n  matchings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['yz'], []), ' necessarily contain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_x'], []), ', so every\n  edge of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is contained in at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), "(G')"], []), ' perfect\n  matchings.\n\n  Now consider a burl ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["X'"], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), '. We show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["X=X'\n  ", TexCmd('cup'), ' ', '\\{', 'x,y,z', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' t'], []), ' is a burl in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' be a\n  balanced probability distribution on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), '. By\n  Claim~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cl:balanced')]), ' and the remark above, we can associate a\n  balanced probability distribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')]), "'"], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), "(G',X')"], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), '\n  such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' ='], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["X'"], []), ' is a\n  burl in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ', this expectation is at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tfrac'), '13'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a\n  burl in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n\nSince a burl avoiding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is also a burl in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', it follows\n  from the analysis above that the maximum size of a foliage cannot\n  increase when we contract a triangle.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Proving Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main2')]))]), '\n', '\n', '\nWe say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('has a core')]), ' if we can obtain a cyclically\n4-edge-connected graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|V(G')|", TexCmd('geq'), ' 6'], []), ' by applying a\n(possibly empty) sequence of cut-contractions to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' ', '(recall that this\nnotion was defined in the previous subsection).\n\nWe will deduce Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main2')]), ' from the next two lemmas.  This\nessentially splits the proof into two cases based on whether or not\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' has a core.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a pruned cubic bridgeless graph. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' V(G)'], []), '\n  be such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('delta'), '(Z)| = 2'], []), ', or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 4'], []), ' and\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('delta'), '(Z)| = 3'], []), '. Suppose that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(Z)'], []), '-contraction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z ', TexCmd('subseteq'), " V(G')"], []), ' has no core. Then there exists a\n  foliage ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')])], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bigcup'), '_', BraceGroup('X ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '), 'X ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' Z'], []), '\n  and ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '() ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '|Z| + ', TexCmd('beta'), '_2.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nBy applying Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), ' to a cubic graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' without a core and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z=V(G) ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', '\\{', 'v', '\\}'], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(G)'], []), ', we obtain the following.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('cor', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('c:Klee')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a pruned cubic bridgeless graph without a core.\n  Then ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '(G) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '(|V(G)|-1) + ', TexCmd('beta'), '_2.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nOn the other hand, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' has a core, we will prove that either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '(G)'], []), '\nis linear in the size of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' or every edge of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is contained in an\nexponential number of perfect matchings.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:MainInduction')]), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a pruned cubic\n  bridgeless graph. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' has a core then\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(G) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '|V(G)|-(G)+', TexCmd('gamma')), '.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe finish this section by deriving Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main2')]), ' from\nLemmas~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), ' and~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:MainInduction')]), '. \n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '3656\n  :=1/'], []), '.  By Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:Prune')]), ' there exists a pruned cubic\n  bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|V(G')| ", TexCmd('geq'), ' |V(G)|/3'], []), ' obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\n  by repeatedly contracting irrelevant triangles. Suppose first that\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' has a core. By Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:Prune')]), ' and Lemmas~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Triangle')]), '\n  and~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:MainInduction')]), ', condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf', [BracketGroup('S1')]), ' ')], []), ' holds as long as\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '|V(G)| ', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "|V(G)|/3-(G')"], []), '. Therefore we assume\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), "(G') ", TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('tfrac'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' 3-', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')|V(G)|'], []), '. It follows from the\n  definition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), "(G')"], []), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' has a foliage containing at least\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('tfrac'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' 3-', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')|V(G)|/', TexCmd('beta'), '_1'], []), ' burls. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' has no\n  core then by Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:Klee')]), ' and the fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), '\n  ', TexCmd('beta'), '_2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), "(G')", TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', "(|V(G')|-1)+", TexCmd('beta'), '_2 ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "|V(G')|"], []), ',\n  so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' contains a foliage of size at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), "|V(G')|/", TexCmd('beta'), '_1\n  ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '|V(G)|/3', TexCmd('beta'), '_1'], []), '.  In both cases condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf', [BracketGroup('S2')]), ' ')], []), ' holds\n  by Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:FoliageApplied')]), ' and Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Triangle')]), ',\n  since Equation ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const2')]), ')'), ' tells us that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('leq', [BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('tfrac'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '3 -', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')')]), '/', TexCmd('beta'), '_1'], []), '.\n'], [BracketGroup('Proof of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main2')]))]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Cut decompositions')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('s:CutDecompose')]), '\n', '\nIn this section we study cut decompositions of cubic bridgeless\ngraphs. We mostly follow notation from~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('chudnovskys11')]), ', however we\nconsider ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '- and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '-edge-cuts simultaneously. Cut decompositions play a\ncrucial role in the proof of Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), ' in the next section.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a graph. A ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('non-trivial cut-decomposition')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a\npair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T, ', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' such that:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n ', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\nFor an edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ', let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_2'], []), ' be the two components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T\n', TexCmd('setminus'), ' f'], []), ', and for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i = 1,2'], []), ' let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i = ', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(T_i)'], []), '. Thus\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X_1,X_2)'], []), ' is a partition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G)'], []), ' that induces an edge-cut\ndenoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f)'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f)| ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', '2,3', '\\}'], []), ' for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f\n', TexCmd('in'), ' E(T)'], []), ' we call ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T, ', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('small-cut-decomposition')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T, ', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be a small-cut-decomposition of a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '-edge-connected\ncubic graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_0'], []), ' be a subtree of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' such that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(V(T_0)) ', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',T_s'], []), ' be the\ncomponents of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' V (T_0)'], []), ', and for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' s'], []), ' let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i'], []), ' be the unique edge of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' with an end in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(T_0)'], []), ' and an end in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(T_i)'], []), '. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' s'], []), ', let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i = ', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(V(T_i))'], []), '. Thus\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_0,X_1, ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ,X_s'], []), ' form a partition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G)'], []), '.\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' be the graph obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' as follows.  Set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_0=G'], []), '.  For\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',s'], []), ', take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('i-1')], []), ' and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_i'], []), ' be the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f_i))'], []), '-contraction containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_0'], []), '. Now let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' denote\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('s')], []), '.\nNote that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is cubic. We call ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('the hub of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_0'], []))]), '\n', '(with respect to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T, ', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), '). If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_0 ', TexCmd('in'), ' V (T)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t_0)\n', TexCmd('ne'), ' ', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), ', by the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('hub of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_0'], []))]), ' we mean the hub of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_0'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_0'], []), ' is the subtree of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' with vertex set\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 't_0', '\\}'], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' be a collection of disjoint subsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G)'], []), '. We say that\na small-cut-decomposition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('refines')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' if\nfor every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ' there exists a leaf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y\n= ', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(v)'], []), '. Collections of subsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G)'], []), ' that can be refined\nby a small-cut decomposition are charaterized in the following easy\nlemma.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:RefinableCollections')]), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic\n  bridgeless graph.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' be a collection of disjoint subsets\n  of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G)'], []), '. Then there exists a small-cut-decomposition refining\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Y| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('delta'), '(Y)| ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', '2,3', '\\}'], []), ' for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y\n  ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', and either\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n ', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  We only consider the case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), '||', TexCmd('geq'), ' 3'], []), ', as the other cases are\n  routine. Take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' to be a tree on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), '||+1'], []), ' vertices with\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), '||'], []), ' leaves ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), 'v_Y ', '\\:', ' | ', '\\:', ' Y ', TexCmd('in'), '  ', '\\}'], []), ' and a non-leaf\n  vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_0'], []), '. The map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is defined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(u)=v_Y'], []), ', if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u ', TexCmd('in'), '\n  Y'], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(u)=v_0'], []), ', otherwise.  Clearly,\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' refines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' and is a small-cut-decomposition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n ', '\nWe say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('calY')], []), '-maximum')]), ' if it refines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(T)|'], []), ' is maximum among all small-cut decompositions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\nrefining ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), '. The following lemma describes the structure of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), '-maximum decompositions. It is a variation of Lemma 4.1 and\nClaim 1 of Lemma 5.3 in~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('chudnovskys11')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:CutDecompose')]), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic bridgeless\n  graph. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' be a collection of disjoint subsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G)'], []), ' and\n  let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), '-maximum small-cut-decomposition of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Then for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), ' either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t)=', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), ', or\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), '(t)', TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', or the hub of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' is cyclically\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-edge-connected.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  Fix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t) ', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), ' and\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t) ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')]), TexCmd('not'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ', f_k'], []), ' be the edges\n  of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' incident with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ', T_k'], []), ' be the\n  components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', '\\{', 't', '\\}'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i'], []), ' is incident with a\n  vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_i'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' k'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_0'], []), ' =\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t)'], []), ', and for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' k'], []), ' let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i =\n  ', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(V(T_i))'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' be the hub of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), '\n  be the graph obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' by subdividing precisely once every\n  new edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' corresponding to the cut-contraction of a cut ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' with\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|C|=2'], []), '. The vertex on the subdivided edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' is called ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('the\n    new vertex corresponding to the cut-contraction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []))]), ', by\n  analogy with the new vertex corresponding to the cut-contraction of\n  a cyclic 3-edge-cut.\n\n  Note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is cyclically 4-edge-connected if and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), '\n  is cyclically 4-edge-connected.  Suppose for the sake of\n  contradiction that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=', TexCmd('delta'), '(Z)'], []), ' is a cyclic edge-cut in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' with\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|C|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 3'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|C|', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', '2,3', '\\}'], []), ' by Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Contraction')]), '(1),\n  as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' is a subdivision of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' can be obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\n  by repeated cut-contractions.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["T'"], []), ' be obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' by by\n  splitting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' into two vertices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["t'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["t''"], []), ', so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), ' is\n  incident to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["t'"], []), ' if and only if the new vertex of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), '\n  corresponding to the cut-contraction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f_i)'], []), ' is in\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), "'(t')=X_0 ", TexCmd('cap'), ' Z'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), "'(t'')=X_0  ", TexCmd('setminus'), '  Z'], []), ', and\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), "'(s)=", TexCmd('phi'), '(s)'], []), ' for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s ', TexCmd('in'), " V(T') ", TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', '\\{', "t',t''", '\\}'], []), '.\n\n  We claim that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["(T',", TexCmd('phi'), "')"], []), ' is a small-cut-decomposition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\n  contradicting the choice of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '. It is only necessary to verify that\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(s)|+', TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup("T'"), '(s)', TexCmd('geq'), ' 3'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', "t',t''", '\\}'], []), '. We have\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), "(t')|+", TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup("T'"), "(t')-1=|Z ", TexCmd('cap'), " V(G'')| ", TexCmd('geq'), ' 2'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' is a\n  cyclic edge-cut in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), '. It follows that\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), "(t')|+", TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup("T'"), "(t') ", TexCmd('geq'), ' 3'], []), ' and the same holds for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["t''"], []), '\n  by symmetry.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.5'), BraceGroup('twigs')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Isomorphism classes of subgraphs induced by elementary\n  twigs.')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('f:twigs')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('htbp')]), '\n', '\nWe finish this section by describing a collection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' to which we\nwill be applying Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:CutDecompose')]), ' in the sequel.  In a cubic\nbridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' a union of the vertex set of a relevant triangle\nwith the vertex set of a cycle of length at most four sharing an edge\nwith it is called ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('a simple twig')]), '. Note that simple twigs\ncorresponding to distinct relevant triangles can intersect, but one\ncan routinely verify that each simple twig intersects a simple twig\ncorresponding to at most one other relevant triangle. ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('An\n  elementary twig')]), ' is either a simple twig, that intersects no simple\ntwig corresponding to a relevant triangle not contained in it, or the\nunion of two intersecting simple twigs, corresponding to distinct\nrelevant triangles. An elementary twig is, indeed, a twig, unless it\nconstitutes the vertex set of the entire graph. Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('f:twigs')]), '\nshows all possible elementary twigs. The next corollary follows\nimmediately from the observations above and\nLemmas~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:RefinableCollections')]), ' and~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:CutDecompose')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('cor', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('c:ElemTwigs')]), '\n Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic bridgeless graph that is not cyclically\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-edge-connected with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(G)| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 8'], []), '. Then there exists a\ncollection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' of pairwise disjoint\n elementary twigs in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' such that every relevant triangle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is\ncontained in an element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), '.\n Further, there exists a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), '-maximum\n small-cut-decomposition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T, ', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), '\n V(T)'], []), ' either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t)=', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), ', or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t)'], []), ' is an\n elementary twig, or the hub of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' is cyclically\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-edge-connected.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Proof  of Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), '.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('s:Klee')]), '\n', '\nThe proof of Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), ' is based on our ability to find burls\nlocally in the graph. The following lemma is a typical example.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:4Burl')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic bridgeless graph and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' V(G)'], []), ' be\n  such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)|=4'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m(G|X) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  Note that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G,X)'], []), ' contains no edges of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(X)'], []), '\n  then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ' contains an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-alternating cycle. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' be a balanced\n  probability distribution on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), '. As ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('cap'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '(X)'], []), ' is\n  even for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G,X)'], []), ' we have ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('tfrac'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' 43= ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2', TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('bM'), ' ', TexCmd('cap'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '(X) ', TexCmd('neq'), '\n  ', TexCmd('emptyset'))]), '.'], []), ' Therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('bM'), ' ', TexCmd('cap'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '(X) = ', TexCmd('emptyset'))]), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n  1/3'], []), '. Hence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), ' ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('tfrac'), '13'], []), ' and so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe proof of Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), ' relies on a precise study of the\nstructure of small-cut trees for graphs with no core. The following\ntwo lemmas indicate that long paths in such trees necessarily contain\nsome burls.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:3Burl')]), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be a small-cut-decomposition\n  of a cubic bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' be a path in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' with\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(P)|= 10'], []), '. If we have\n ', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n ', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nthen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(P)'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["P'=v_", BraceGroup('-1'), 'v_0', TexCmd('ldots'), ' v_', BraceGroup('9'), 'v_', BraceGroup('10')], []), ' be a path in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' such that\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P=v_0', TexCmd('ldots'), ' v_', BraceGroup('9')], []), '.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i=v_', BraceGroup('i-1'), 'v_', BraceGroup('i')], []), ' and let\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_i=', '\\{', 'e^i_1,e^i_2,e^i_3', '\\}', '=', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f_i)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('le'), ' i ', TexCmd('le'), ' 10'], []), '. Let\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X:=', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(V(P))'], []), '.  It is easy to see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(v_i)'], []), '\n  contains precisely two vertices joined by an edge, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('le'), ' i ', TexCmd('le'), ' 9'], []), '.\n\nWe assume without loss of generality that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ' contains no cycles of\nlength ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ', as otherwise the lemma holds by Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:4Burl')]), '.  Let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' be the set of ends of edges in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' outside of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '\nbe the set of ends of edges in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('10')], []), ' outside of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '.  Observe that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_X'], []), ' consists of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' internally vertex-disjoint paths from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ', as well as one edge in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', '\\{', 'v_i', '\\}', ')'], []), ' for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leq'), ' i', TexCmd('leq'), '\n9'], []), '.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_3'], []), ' be these three paths from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ',\nand let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_j'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_j'], []), ' be the ends of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_j'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ',\nrespectively, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j=1,2,3'], []), '.  For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 9'], []), ', we have\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(v_i)=', '\\{', 'x_i,y_i', '\\}'], []), ' so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_i ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(R_j), y_i ', TexCmd('in'), '\nV(R_', BraceGroup("j'"), ')'], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', "j,j'", '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' ', '\\{', '1,2,3', '\\}'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j', TexCmd('ne'), " j'"], []), '    ; let the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('index')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_i'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_i'], []), ' be defined as\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', "j,j'", '\\}'], []), '. Since there is no 4-cycle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_i', TexCmd('ne'), '\n  ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('i-1')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i', TexCmd('le'), ' 9'], []), '.  Let the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('type')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_i'], []), ' of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_i'], []), ' ', '(for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i ', TexCmd('le'), ' 8'], []), ') be defined as 0 if\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('i-1'), '=', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('i+1')], []), ', otherwise let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_i=1'], []), '.\n  \n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j,k'], []), ' be integers such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('le'), ' i < j< k', TexCmd('le'), ' 10'], []), '\n  which will be determined later. Let\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1:=', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', '\\{', 'v_i,', TexCmd('dots'), ',v_', BraceGroup('j-1'), '\\}', ')'], []), ',\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2:=', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', '\\{', 'v_j,', TexCmd('dots'), ',v_', BraceGroup('k-1'), '\\}', ')'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_0=X_1', TexCmd('cup'), ' X_2'], []), '.\n\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' be a balanced probability distribution on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), ',\n  let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_0'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_2'], []), ') be the maximum number of disjoint\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), '-alternating cycles in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X_0'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X_2'], []), ',\n  respectively). Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('ell'), '=|', TexCmd('cap'), ' C_', TexCmd('ell'), '|'], []), ', for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ', and\n  let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y=Y_i+Y_j+Y_k'], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' is balanced, we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Y)=3'], []), ';\n  moreover, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_i', TexCmd('equiv'), ' Y_j ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' Y_k ', TexCmd('pmod', [BraceGroup('2')])], []), '. Therefore,\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=1)=0'], []), '; ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y=3'], []), ' if and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_i=Y_j=Y_k=1'], []), '; and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Y=2'], []), ' if\n  and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'Y_i,Y_j,Y_k', '\\}', '=', '\\{', '2,0,0', '\\}'], []), '.\n\nAssume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j,k'], []), ' fulfill the following conditions:\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\nFirst, we derive ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Z_0)', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('frac'), '13'], []), ' from these assumptions, then we\nprove the existence of such a triple ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j,k'], []), '.\n\nObserve that the first condition yields ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Z_0', '\\,', '|', '\\,', 'Y=0)', TexCmd('ge'), ' 2'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Z_0', '\\,', '|', '\\,', 'Y=2)', TexCmd('ge'), ' 1'], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Y)=3'], []), ', we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3', TexCmd('cdot'), '\n', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=0)+', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=2) ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y', TexCmd('ge'), ' 4)'], []), '. This gives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y', TexCmd('ne'), ' 3)', TexCmd('le'), ' 4', TexCmd('cdot'), '\n', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=0) + 2', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=2)'], []), ', and hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Z_0', '\\,', '|', '\\,', 'Y', TexCmd('ne'), ' 3)', TexCmd('ge'), '\n', TexCmd('frac'), '12'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_t=', '\\{', 'e_1,e_2,e_3', '\\}'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e=e_1'], []), '. Let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i=', TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('bM'), TexCmd('cap'), ' C_t=', '\\{', 'e_i', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('wedge'), ' Y=3')])], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,2,3'], []), '. Clearly\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1+p_2+p_3=', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=3)'], []), '. On the other hand, since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' is balanced,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac'), '13-p_1 ', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('frac'), '13-p_2+', TexCmd('frac'), '13-p_3'], []), ' ', '(all elements of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G,X)'], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' together with some other edge from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_t'], []), '\ncontain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), '). Hence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('frac'), '12', TexCmd('cdot'), '\n', '(', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=3)-', TexCmd('frac'), '13)'], []), '.\n\nAltogether, in this case\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), TexCmd('gathered'), ' ', '(Z_0)=(Z_0', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '\\,', '|', '\\,', 'Y', TexCmd('ne'), ' 3)', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y', TexCmd('ne'), '\n3)+(Z_0', '\\,', '|', '\\,', 'Y=3)', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=3)', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('tfrac'), '12', TexCmd('cdot'), '\n', '(1-', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=3))+', TexCmd('tfrac'), '12', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Pr'), '(Y=3)-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '13) =\n', TexCmd('tfrac'), '13.\n', TexCmd('endgathered'), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nNow we prove that there is always ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j,k'], []), ' such that both conditions\n(1) and (2) are satisfied. Note that (1) is satisfied if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j-i=3'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('i+1'), '=1'], []), ', or if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j-i', TexCmd('ge'), ' 4'], []), '; the same holds for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' ', '(to\nobserve this, see Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:tbd')]), ').\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup('\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('tbd.1')]), '\n', TexCmd('hfil'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('tbd.2')]), '\n')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('If there are three consecutive pairs of pairwise distinct\n  indices contained in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X'], []), ', there is always an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-alternating cycle\n  for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('calM'), '(G,X)'], []), ' using just the vertical edges (left); the\n  same is true for any four consecutive pairs (right).  ')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:tbd')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nConsider the sequence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' of 8 types occuring in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '. \n\nSuppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1111'], []), ' as a subsequence, say\ne.g. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_2=', TexCmd('psi'), '_3=', TexCmd('psi'), '_4=', TexCmd('psi'), '_5=1'], []), '. Then for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j=4'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=7'], []), ' the\ncondition (1) clearly holds. The condition (2) holds for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X_0'], []), ' in\nthis case, see Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:psi')]), ', left.\nOne can prove that the following subsequences \nare feasible as well by drawing triples of figures (we omit the details):\n00011, 01011, 100000, 100010, 100100, 101000, 101010,\n100110, 110110, 1000010, 1001010, 1010010, 00000000.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup('\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi2.3')]), '\n', '&\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi1.1')]), '\n', '&\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi3.1')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi2.2')]), '\n', '&\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi1.2')]), '\n', '&\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi3.2')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi2.1')]), '\n', '&\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi1.3')]), '\n', '&\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('psi3.3')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), '\n')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1111'], []), ' ', '(left), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['111'], []), ' ', '(center) or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0001'], []), '\n  ', '(right) as a subsequence, then for each perfect matching containing\n  the bottom-leftmost edge such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y=2'], []), ' there is an alternating\n  cycle. Observe that there is always one case out of three which is\n  not possible.  ')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:psi')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nSimilarly, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_1=', TexCmd('psi'), '_2=', TexCmd('psi'), '_3=1'], []), ', then we may pick ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j=5'], []), ',\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=9'], []), ' ', '(or even ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=8'], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_6=1'], []), '). In this case the condition\n(2) holds for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|X_1'], []), ', see Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:psi')]), ', center. Analogously\nit works with 0001. It means ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['111**', '\\,', '1'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['111****'], []), ' are feasible as well, and so are\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0001**', '\\,', '1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0001****'], []), '.\n\nIt remains to prove that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' always contains at least one feasible\nsubsequence, which is a routine case analysis.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:2Burl')]), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be a small-cut-decomposition\n  of a cubic bridgeless graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_1,t_2 ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), ' be a pair of\n  adjacent vertices of degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '. Suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f)|=2'], []), ' for\n  every edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f ', TexCmd('in'), ' E(T)'], []), ' incident to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_1'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_2'], []), '.  Then\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', '\\{', 't_1,t_2', '\\}', ')'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_0t_1t_2t_3'], []), ' be a subpath of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' and let\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_i=', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t_', BraceGroup('i-1'), 't_', BraceGroup('i'), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,2,3'], []), ' be an edge-cut of size\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '.  Assume that both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t_1)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t_2)'], []), '\n  have at most one perfect matching. By Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:4Burl')]), ' it\n  suffices to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', '\\{', 't_1,t_2', '\\}', ')'], []), ' has at least two\n  perfect matchings.  As the hub ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_1'], []), ' is cubic and\n  bridgeless it contains at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' perfect matching avoiding any\n  edge.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1, e_2 ', TexCmd('in'), ' E(G_1)'], []), ' be the edges in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E(G_1)-E(G)'], []), '\n  corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_1'], []), '- and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_2'], []), '-contraction, respectively.  By\n  assumption, at most one perfect matching of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' avoids both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), '\n  and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), '.  It follows that either two perfect matchings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), '\n  avoid ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' and contain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ', or one avoids ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ' and one\n  avoids ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' and contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' be the hub over\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_2'], []), '. The symmetric statement holds for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), '. In any case, the\n  perfect matchings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' can be combined to obtain at\n  least two perfect matchings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', '\\{', 't_1,t_2', '\\}', ')'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nFrom the definition of a small-cut-decomposition, we immediately get\nthe following corollary:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('cor', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('c:2Burl')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be a small-cut-decomposition of a cubic bridgeless\n  graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' be a path in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' in which every vertex has\n  degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), '.  Suppose there exist three edges ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_3'], []), ' of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' incident to vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' such that\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f_1)|=|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f_2)|=|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f_3)|=2'], []), '.  Then\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(P)'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_3'], []), ' denote the cubic graph consisting of two vertices joined by\nthree parallel edges.  Lemmas~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:3Burl')]), ' and~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:2Burl')]), ' imply\nthe following.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('cor', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('c:TreeBranch')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be a small-cut-decomposition of a cubic bridgeless\n  graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' be a path in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(P)|=32'], []), '. If for\n  every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(P)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_T(t)=2'], []), ' and the hub of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' is\n  isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_4'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_3'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(P)'], []), ' is a burl.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  If at least three edges incident to vertices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(P)'], []), ' correspond to\n  edge-cuts of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' then the corollary holds by\n  Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:2Burl')]), '.  Otherwise, since there are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['33'], []), ' edges of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' incident to vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ', there must be 11 consecutive edges\n  incident to vertices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' corresponding to edge-cuts of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '.\n  In this case, the result follows from Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:3Burl')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('vskip'), ' 10pt\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  We proceed by induction on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z|'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z| ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 6'], []), ' then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' is a\n  twig. In this case the lemma holds since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_1 ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '_2 +\n  6', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' by ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const3')]), ')'), '. We assume for the remainder of\n  the proof that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 7'], []), '. It follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is not cyclically\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-edge-connected, as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' has no core. Therefore\n  Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:ElemTwigs')]), ' is applicable to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ' be a\n  collection of disjoint elementary twigs in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' such that every\n  relevant triangle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is contained in an element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), ', and\n  let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Y')])], []), '-maximum small-cut decomposition of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), '. By Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:ElemTwigs')]), ', the hub at every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), '\n  with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t)|', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), ' is either an elementary twig, in\n  which case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' is a leaf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ', or is cyclically\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-edge-connected, in which case it is isomorphic to either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_4'], []), '\n  or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_3'], []), '.\n  \n  In calculations below we will make use of the following claim: If\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_T(t)=2'], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t)| ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 2'], []), '.\n  If this is not the case, the hub at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' is isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_4'], []), ', and\n  at least three of its vertices must be vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.  It follows\n  that there is an edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f', TexCmd('in'), ' E(T)'], []), ' incident to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' for which\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f)|=2'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f) ', TexCmd('triangle'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '(v)'], []), '\n  is a 3-edge-cut in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. We now have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), "(t't'')=C"], []), ' and the\n  new small-cut-decomposition contradicts the maximality of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), '. This completes the proof of the claim.\n\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_0 ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), ' be such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t_0)'], []), ' contains the new\n  vertex or one of the ends of the new edge in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is\n  pruned, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' contains at most one irrelevant triangle, and if such a\n  triangle exists, at least one of its vertices lies in\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t_0)'], []), '. As a consequence, for any leaf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('ne'), ' t_0'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ',\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t)'], []), ' is a twig. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^', BraceGroup('*'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T) ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', '\\{', 't_0', '\\}'], []), ' be\n  such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup('T'), '(t^', BraceGroup('*'), ')', TexCmd('geq'), ' 3'], []), ' and, subject to this condition,\n  the component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', '\\{', 't^', BraceGroup('*'), '\\}'], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_0'], []), ' is\n  maximal. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup('T'), '(t) ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 2'], []), ' for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T) ', TexCmd('setminus'), '\n  ', '\\{', 't_0', '\\}'], []), ', we take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^', BraceGroup('*'), '=t_0'], []), ' instead.\n\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',T_k'], []), ' be all the components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T ', TexCmd('setminus'), '\n  ', '\\{', 't^', BraceGroup('*'), '\\}'], []), ' not containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_0'], []), '. By the choice of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^', BraceGroup('*')], []), ', each\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_i'], []), ' is a path. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(T_i)| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 33'], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' k'], []), '\n  then let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["T'"], []), ' be the subtree of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_i'], []), ' containing a leaf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' and\n  exactly ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['32'], []), ' other vertices. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' be the unique edge in\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), "(T')"], []), '. \n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' ', '(resp.~', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["H'"], []), ') be the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f)'], []), '-contraction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' ', '(resp.~', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ')\ncontaining ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["V(G')", TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), "(T')"], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["Z'"], []), ' consist of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["V(H') ", TexCmd('cap'), ' Z'], []), ' together with the new vertex created by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(f)'], []), '-contraction (if it exists). If\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' is not pruned then it contains a unique irrelevant triangle\nand we contract it, obtaining a pruned graph.\n  By the induction\n  hypothesis, either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|Z'| ", TexCmd('leq'), ' 6'], []), ' or we can find a foliage ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), "'"], []), '\n  in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["Z'"], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), "(')", TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "(|Z'|-2) + ", TexCmd('beta'), '_2'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|Z'|\n  ", TexCmd('leq'), ' 6'], []), ' let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), "' := ", TexCmd('emptyset')], []), '.\n\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["t'"], []), ' be a vertex of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["T'"], []), ' which is not a leaf in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '. Since\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), "_T(t')=2"], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), "(t')|", TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('emptyset')], []), '. This implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), "(T')"], []), '\n  contains an elementary twig and a burl that are vertex-disjoint,\n  where the elementary twig is the preimage of the leaf. Note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(T_i)'], []), ' contains a twig for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('leq'), '\n i', TexCmd('leq'), ' k'], []), '.
