Therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z| ', TexCmd('leq'), " |Z'|+70k+4"], []), '. It\n follows from ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const5')]), ')'), ' that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '() ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "(|Z'|-2) + ", TexCmd('beta'), '_2 + (k-1)', TexCmd('beta'), '_1 ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '|Z|\n+', TexCmd('beta'), '_2 -76', TexCmd('alpha'), '  +(k-1)(', TexCmd('beta'), '_1-70', TexCmd('alpha'), ') ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '|Z|+', TexCmd('beta'), '_2.'], []), '\n', '\nNow we can assume ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^*=t_0'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(T_0)|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 6'], []), '.  First\nsuppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^* ', TexCmd('neq'), ' t_0'], []), ' but ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(T_0)|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 6'], []), '.  Then again\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t^*)|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 4'], []), ', so we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 70k+10'], []), '.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')])], []), ' be\nthe foliage consisting of twigs in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',T_k'], []), '.  Thus by ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), '\n  ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const6')]), ')'), ', we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation*', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '()=k', TexCmd('beta'), '_1 ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('alpha'), '|Z|+', TexCmd('beta'), '_2) +\nk(', TexCmd('beta'), '_1-70', TexCmd('alpha'), ')-10', TexCmd('alpha'), ' -', TexCmd('beta'), '_2 ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '|Z|+', TexCmd('beta'), '_2.'], []), '\n', '\nFinally we can assume ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^', BraceGroup('*'), ' = t_0'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t^*)|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 4'], []), ',\nunless ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(t^*)'], []), ' is an elementary twig.  In either\ncase, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 70k+8'], []), ' and the equation above applies.\n'], [BracketGroup('Proof of Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]))]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Proof of Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:MainInduction')]))]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('s:MainInduction')]), '\n', '\nThe following lemma is a direct consequence of a theorem of Kotzig,\nstating that any graph with a unique perfect matching contains a bridge\n(see~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('esperetkss10')]), ').\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:prop-double')]), '\nEvery edge of a cyclically ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-edge-connected cubic graph with at\nleast six vertices is contained in at least two perfect matchings.\n'], []), '\n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cubic graph. For a path ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1v_2v_3v_4'], []), ', the graph\nobtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' splitting along the path ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1v_2v_3v_4'], [])), ' is\nthe cubic graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' obtained as follows: remove the vertices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_2'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_3'], []), ' and add the edges ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1v_4'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["v'_1v'_4"], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["v'_1"], []), ' is\nthe neighbor of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_2'], []), ' different from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["v'_4"], []), ' is the\nneighbor of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_3'], []), ' different from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_4'], []), '. The idea of this\nconstruction (and its application to the problem of counting perfect\nmatchings) originally appeared in~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('voorhoeve79')]), '. We say that a\nperfect matching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('canonical extension')]), ' of a\nperfect matching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M ', TexCmd('triangle'), " M' ", TexCmd('subseteq'), ' E(G)\n', TexCmd('triangle'), " E(G')"], []), ', i.e. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' agree on the edges shared by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), '.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('l:splitting')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a cyclically 4-edge-connected cubic graph with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(G)| ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n6'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is the graph obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by splitting along some\npath ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1v_2v_3v_4'], []), ', then\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('vskip'), ' 10pt\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n  We proceed by induction on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(G)|'], []), '. The base case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(G)|=6'], []), '\n  holds by Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:prop-double')]), ' and ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const7')]), ')'), '.\n\n  For the induction step, consider first the case that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is\n  cyclically 4-edge-connected. Fix an edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e=uv ', TexCmd('in'), ' E(G)'], []), '. Our goal\n  is to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' is contained in at least\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '|V(G)|-(G)+', TexCmd('gamma'))], []), ' perfect matchings.\n\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w ', TexCmd('neq'), ' u'], []), ' be a neighbor of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_2'], []), ' be the\n  two other neighbors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_i,y_i'], []), ' be the neighbors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_i'], []), '\n  distinct from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,2'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',G_4'], []), ' be the graphs\n  obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by splitting along the paths ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['vww_1x_1'], []), ',\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['vww_1y_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['vww_2x_2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['vww_2y_2'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'_i"], []), ' be obtained from\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_i'], []), ' by contracting irrelevant triangles for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',4'], []), '. By\n  Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:splitting')]), '(2) we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|V(G'_i)| ", TexCmd('geq'), ' |V(G)|-6'], []), '.\n\n  Suppose first that one of the resulting graphs, without loss of\n  generality ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'_1"], []), ', does not have a core. By Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:Klee')]), ',\n  Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Triangle')]), ' and Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:splitting')]), ', we have ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '\n  |V(G)| ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', "(|V(G'_1)| + 6) ", TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('leq'), ' ', "(G'_1)+ 7", TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('alpha'), ' -', TexCmd('beta'), '_2\n  ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', '(G_1)+ 7', TexCmd('alpha'), ' -', TexCmd('beta'), '_2 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', '(G)+ 2', TexCmd('beta'), '_1 +7', TexCmd('alpha'), '\n  -', TexCmd('beta'), '_2.'], []), ' Therefore ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '|V(G)|-(G)+', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' +\n  2', TexCmd('beta'), '_1 +7', TexCmd('alpha'), ' -', TexCmd('beta'), '_2 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), ' by ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const8')]), ')'), ' and the\n  lemma follows from Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:prop-double')]), '.\n\n  We now assume that all four graphs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'_1,", TexCmd('ldots'), ",G'_4"], []), ' have a\n  core. By Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:splitting')]), '(4), every perfect matching\n  containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_i'], []), ' canonically extends to a perfect matching\n  containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' be the sum of the number of perfect\n  matchings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_i'], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '1,2,3,4', '\\}'], []), '. By\n  induction hypothesis and Lemmas~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Triangle')]), '\n  and~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:splitting')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S ', TexCmd('ge'), ' 4 ', TexCmd('cdot'), '\n  2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '(|V(G)|-6)-(G)-2', TexCmd('beta'), '_1+', TexCmd('gamma'))], []), '. On the other hand, a\n  perfect matching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' is the canonical\n  extension of a perfect matching containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' in precisely three of\n  the graphs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_i'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '1,2,3,4', '\\}'], []), '. For instance if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_1y_1,ww_2\n  ', TexCmd('in'), ' M'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_2'], []), ' is the only graph (among the four) that does not\n  have a perfect matching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' that canonically extends to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' ', '(see\n  Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('f:voo')]), '). As a consequence, there are precisely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S/3'], []), '\n  perfect matchings containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Therefore,\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(G) ', TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('tfrac', [BraceGroup('4'), BraceGroup('3')]), TexCmd('cdot'), '\n2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '(|V(G)|-6)-(G)-2', TexCmd('beta'), '_1+', TexCmd('gamma')), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '|V(G)|-(G)+', TexCmd('gamma')), ','], []), ' by ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const9')]), ')'), ', as\ndesired.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.35'), BraceGroup('voo')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Perfect matchings in only three of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_i'], []), "'s canonically\n  extend to a given perfect matching of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), '.')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('f:voo')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('htbp')]), '\n', '\n  It remains to consider the case when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' contains a cyclic edge-cut\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' of size at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), '. Suppose first that for such edge-cut ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ',\n  both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '-contractions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2'], []), ' have a core. Then, by\n  Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Contraction')]), '(3), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '(G) ', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(H_1)+(H_2)-2', TexCmd('beta'), '_1'], []), '\n  and, by induction hypothesis, applied to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2'], []), ' ', '(after\n  possibly contracting one irrelevant triangle in each) and\n  Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Contraction')]), ',\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(G) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(H_1)m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(H_2) ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '|V(G)|-4', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('alpha'), '-(G)-2', TexCmd('beta'), '_1 +2', TexCmd('gamma')), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '|V(G)|-(G)+', TexCmd('gamma')), ','], []), ' by ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('e:const10')]), ')'), ', as desired.\nFinally, if for every cyclic edge-cut ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' of size at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' only one\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '-contraction has a core, we apply Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:ElemTwigs')]), ' to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' be the resulting small-cut-decomposition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\nThere exists a unique vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(T)'], []), ' such that the hub ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\nat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' is cyclically ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-edge-connected with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V(H)|', TexCmd('geq'), ' 6'], []), '. Let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ', T_k'], []), ' be the components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T - t'], []), ' and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_i =\n', TexCmd('phi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(V(T_i))'], []), '. We apply Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), ' to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',Z_k'], []), '. Note that Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:Klee')]), ' is indeed applicable,\nas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is pruned, and therefore every triangle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' belongs to an\nelementary twig. Consequently, no edge-cut corresponding to an edge of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T,\n', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' separates exactly ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_1,', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_2,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',_k'], []), ' be the foliages satisfying the\nlemma. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_0'], []), ' be the maximal foliage in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' avoiding new\nvertices and edges created by contraction of the edge-cuts\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(Z_1),', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('delta'), '(Z_k)'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '(', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '_0) ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n', '(H)-k', TexCmd('beta'), '_2'], []), ', as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' contains no twigs (it is cyclically\n4-edge-connected). Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_0 ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('cup'), ' ', '_1 ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('cup'), ' ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ', TexCmd('cup'), ' ', '_k'], []), '\nis a foliage in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' we have\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '(G) ', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(H)-k', TexCmd('beta'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_2 + ', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^', BraceGroup('k'), '(_i) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(H) +\n', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^', BraceGroup('k'), '|Z_i|,'], []), ' by the choice of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_1,', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('ldots'), ',_k'], []), '.  It remains to observe that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(G) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '(H) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '|V(H)|-(H)+', TexCmd('gamma')), '\n', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '(|V(G)|-', TexCmd('sum'), '_', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw'), BraceGroup('i=1')]), '^', BraceGroup('k'), '|Z_i|)-(H)+', TexCmd('gamma')), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '|V(G)|-(G)+', TexCmd('gamma')), ','], []), ' by the above.\n'], [BracketGroup('Proof of Lemma~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('l:MainInduction')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Concluding remarks')]), '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Improving the bound.')]), ' We expect that the bound in\nTheorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main')]), ' can be improved at the expense of more careful\ncase analysis.  In particular, it is possible to improve the bound on\nthe length of the path in Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('c:TreeBranch')]), '. We have chosen\nnot to do so in an attempt to keep the argument as straightforward as\npossible. \n\nIn~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('cyganps09')]), ' it is shown that for some constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c>0'], []), ' and every\ninteger ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n '], []), ' there exists a cubic bridgeless graph on at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '\nvertices with at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c2^', BraceGroup('n/17.285')], []), ' perfect matchings.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Number of perfect matchings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '-regular graphs.')]), '\nIn~', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Conjecture 8.1.8'), BraceGroup('lovaszp86')]), ' the following generalization of\nthe conjecture considered in this paper is stated. A graph is said to\nbe ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('matching-covered')]), ' if every edge of it belongs to a perfect\nmatching.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('conj', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('conj:kregular')]), '\n  For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 3'], []), ' there exist constants ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_1(k), c_2(k) > 0'], []), ' such that\n  every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '-regular matching-covered graph contains at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_2(k)\n  c_1(k)^', BraceGroup('|V(G)|')], []), ' perfect matchings. Furthermore, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_1(k) ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '\n  as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWhile our proof does not seem to extend to the proof of this\nconjecture, the following weaker statement can be deduced from\nTheorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main')]), '. We are grateful to Paul Seymour for suggesting\nthe idea of the following proof.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thm', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('t:kregular')]), '\n  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '-regular ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k-1)'], []), '-edge-connected graph on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '\n  vertices for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 4'], []), '. Then\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('log'), '_2', BraceGroup('m(G)'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '1k)(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '2k) ', TexCmd('tfrac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ceps'))]), '.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ["\n  It follows by Edmonds' characterization of the perfect matching\n  polytope~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('edmonds65')]), ' that there exists a probability\n  distribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), '(G)'], []), ' such that for every edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', TexCmd('in'), '\n  E(G)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup('e', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('bM'))]), '=', TexCmd('tfrac'), '1k'], []), '.\n\n  We choose a triple of perfect matchings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' as follows. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_1\n  ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G)'], []), ' be arbitrary.  We have ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('E')]), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('2k')]), '.'], []), ' Therefore we can choose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_2 ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G)'], []), ' so\n  that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|M_2 ', TexCmd('cap'), ' M_1|', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('2k')])], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z ', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' V(G)'], []), ' be\n  the set of vertices not incident with an edge of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_1 ', TexCmd('cap'), '\n  M_2'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Z| ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '1k)', '\\,', ' n'], []), '. For each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v ', TexCmd('in'), ' Z'], []), ' we\n  have ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('Pr', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('bM'), ' ', TexCmd('cap'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '(', '\\{', 'v', '\\}', ') ', TexCmd('cap'), ' ', '(M_1 ', TexCmd('cup'), ' M_2) =\n  ', TexCmd('emptyset'))]), '=1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '2k.'], []), ' Therefore the expected number of vertices\n  whose three incident edges are in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_2'], []), '\n  respectively, is at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '1k)(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '2k)', '\\,', 'n'], []), '. It follows\n  that we can choose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_3 ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(G)'], []), ' so that the subgraph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' of\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["E(G')=M_1 ", TexCmd('cup'), ' M_2 ', TexCmd('cup'), ' M_3'], []), ' has at least\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '1k)(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '2k)', '\\,', 'n'], []), ' vertices of degree three. Note that\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is by definition matching-covered. It follows that the only\n  bridges in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' are edges joining pairs of vertices of degree\n  one. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' be obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' by deleting vertices of degree\n  one and replacing by an edge every maximal path in which all the\n  internal vertices have degree two. The graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G''"], []), ' is cubic and\n  bridgeless and therefore by Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t:Main')]), ' we have\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('log'), '_2', BraceGroup('m(G)'), '> ', TexCmd('log'), '_2', BraceGroup("m(G')"), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('log'), '_2', BraceGroup("m(G'')"), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), '\n', TexCmd('tfrac'), '1', BraceGroup('3656'), "|V(G'')| ", TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '1k)(1-', TexCmd('tfrac'), '2k)\n', TexCmd('tfrac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ceps'))]), ','], []), ' as desired.'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibliographystyle', [BraceGroup('plain')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('chudnovskys11')]), ' M. Chudnovsky and P. Seymour, ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Perfect\n    matchings in planar cubic graphs')]), ', Combinatorica, to appear.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('cyganps09')]), ' M. Cygan, M. Pilipczuk and R. ', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('S')]), 'krekovski,\n  ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('A bound on the number of perfect matchings in klee-graphs')]), ',\n  preprint.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('edmonds65')]), ' J. Edmonds, ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Maximum matching and a\n    polyhedron with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(0,1)'], []), '-vertices')]), ', J.~Res. Nat. Bur. Standards~B\n  ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('69')]), ' ', '(1965), 125--130.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('edmondslp82')]), ' J.~Edmonds, L.~Lov', BraceGroup("\\'", 'a'), 'sz, W.~R.~Pulleyblank,\n  ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Brick decompositions and the matching rank of graphs')]), ',\n  Combinatorica ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 2'), ' ', '(1982), 247--274.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('esperetkk11')]), ' L.~Esperet, D.~Kr', BraceGroup("\\'", 'a'), "l', F.~Kardo", TexCmd('v'), ' s, ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('A\n    superlinear bound on the number of perfect matchings in cubic\n    bridgeless graphs')]), ', manuscript (2010).\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('esperetkss10')]), ' L.~Esperet, D.~Kr', BraceGroup("\\'", 'a'), "l', P.~", TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('S')]), 'koda, and\n  R.~', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('S')]), 'krekovski, ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('An improved linear bound on the number of\n    perfect matchings in cubic graphs')]), ', European J. Combin. Storchi-Bergmann, eds.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nWe use data from large surveys of the local Universe (SDSS+Galaxy Zoo) to show that the galaxy-black hole connection is linked to host morphology at a fundamental level. The fraction of early-type galaxies with actively growing black holes, and therefore the AGN duty cycle, declines significantly with increasing black hole mass. Late-type galaxies exhibit the opposite trend: the fraction of actively growing black holes increases with black hole mass.\n', TexCmd('keywords', [BraceGroup('galaxies: evolution, galaxies: Seyfert, galaxies: active')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('firstsection'), '               ', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\nIn order to probe the connection between black hole growth and galaxy evolution, we required an accurate picture of which galaxies host active galactic nuclei (AGN) and how they compare to their normal (non-active) counterparts. We combine data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey DR7 ', TexCmd('citep', [BraceGroup('2009ApJS..182..543A')]), ' with morphological classifications provided by citizen scientists taking part in the Galaxy Zoo project', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('See ', TexCmd('texttt', [BraceGroup('http://www.galaxyzoo.org/')]))]), ' ', TexCmd('citep', [BraceGroup('2008MNRAS.389.1179L')]), ' to investigate the extent to which black hole growth in early- and late-type galaxies is different.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('angle=90,width=', TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('sy_frac.ps')]), ' \n ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The distribution of the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('fraction')]), ' of galaxies that host AGN on the color-mass diagram. The contours represent the normal galaxy population while the green shaded contours trace the AGN fraction. In the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('top-right')]), ' panel, we show the entire galaxy population, while in the following panels, we show only normal galaxies and AGN host galaxies with specific morphology. The AGN fraction in a specific sub-population (e.g. early-type galaxies of a certain color and stellar mass) is a proxy for the duty cycle of AGN in that population. This figure thus reveals which galaxy populations have a high AGN duty cycle and illustrates the importance of morphology for understanding the role of black hole growth in galaxy evolution (figure from ', TexCmd('citealt', [BraceGroup('2010arXiv1001.3141S')]), ').', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:sy_frac')]))]), '\n', '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!h')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Two modes of black hole growth in the local universe')]), '\nIn Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:sy_frac')]), ', we present the color-mass diagram of a sample of local (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.02 < z < 0.05 '], []), ') galaxies (black contours; from ', TexCmd('citealt', [BraceGroup('2010arXiv1001.3141S')]), '). The shaded green contours represent the fraction of galaxies that host AGN. The AGN are obscured, narrow-line Seyferts identified using emission line ratio diagnostic diagrams ', TexCmd('citep', [BracketGroup('e.g.'), BracketGroup(), BraceGroup('1981PASP...93....5B,2001ApJ...556..121K')]), '. The panels in Figure  ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:sy_frac')]), ' split the normal and AGN host galaxy population by morphology, thereby revealing important differences between the two.\n\nIn the early-type galaxy population, it is preferentially low-mass (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), '10^', BraceGroup('9')], []), ') objects with intermediate (or ``green valley") host galaxy colors that host AGN. A detailed analysis of their stellar populations shows that these are post-starburst objects migrating at fixed mass from the blue cloud to the low-mass end of the red sequence ', TexCmd('citep', [BraceGroup('2007MNRAS.382.1415S')]), '.\n\nThe late-type galaxy population presents a different picture. While late-type AGN host galaxies also feature intermediate or green host galaxy colors, they are significantly more massive (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), '10^', BraceGroup('10')], []), ') than early-type host galaxies. The extra mass is contained in a massive stellar disk; the median black hole masses of late-type AGN hosts are comparable to those of the early-type hosts. These massive stellar disks are likely to be very stable which, combined with the lack of blue objects at similar stellar masses to form plausible progenitors, suggests that their green host galaxy colours are unlikely to be due to some recent quenching of star formation.\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('angle=90,width=4.0in'), BraceGroup('sy_f_mbh.ps')]), ' \n ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Which black holes in the local universe are growing? The answer depends strongly on host galaxy morphology. We show the fraction of galaxies that host AGN luminous AGN selected by emission line diagrams as a function of the host black hole mass measured via the ', TexCmd('Msigma'), ' relation ', TexCmd('citep', [BraceGroup('2000ApJ...539L...9F, 2000ApJ...539L..13G, 2002ApJ...574..740T')]), '. The fraction of early-type galaxies with actively growing black holes, and therefore the AGN duty cycle, declines significantly with increasing black hole mass. Late-type galaxies exhibit the opposite trend: the fraction of actively growing black holes increases with black hole mass over the same range before possibly dropping at the highest black hole masses (figure from ', TexCmd('citealt', [BraceGroup('2010arXiv1001.3141S')]), '). ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:sy_f_mbh')]))]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!t')]), '\n', '\nThe fact that the median black hole masses of early- and late-type host galaxies are comparable can mask further differences. If instead we calculate the fraction of AGN host galaxies as a function of black hole mass within each morphology class (shown in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:sy_f_mbh')]), '), the difference between the black hole growth in early- and late-type galaxies is further underlined. Amongst early-type galaxies, the AGN fraction decreases with increasing black hole mass, while the opposite is the case for late-types.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgements')]), '\nThis publication has been made possible by the participation of more than 250,000 volunteers in the Galaxy Zoo project. TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('alpha'), '_i, ', TexCmd('beta'), '_i)'], []), ' from the Markov Chain for the cosmographic parameters. Columns are as in Table I.')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '_i = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('C')])), '_i'), BraceGroup(' ', '( ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('A')])), '_i ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_M + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('B')])), '_i  ) (r_c H_0)_', BraceGroup('fid'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('C')])), '_i')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq: defalpha')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('beta'), '_i = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' ', '( ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('A')])), '_i ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_M + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('B')])), '_i  ) (r_c H_0)_', BraceGroup('fid')), BraceGroup(' ', '( ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('A')])), '_i ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_M + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('B')])), '_i  ) (r_c H_0)_', BraceGroup('fid'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('C')])), '_i')]), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq: defbeta')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe constraints on the fiducial ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i'], []), ' and the scaling parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('alpha'), '_i, ', TexCmd('beta'), '_i)'], []), ' obtained by evaluating these quantities along the Markov chain for the cosmographic parameters are summarized in Table II. Considering the median values and the quite narrow confidence ranges, we find that that the scaling parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('alpha'), '_i, ', TexCmd('beta'), '_i)'], []), ' are well consistent with the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i'], []), ' being linear functions of the inverse of the crossover scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), '  hence allowing us to easily estimate the impact of uncertainties on this parameter on the final estimate of the present day values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(R)'], []), ' and its derivatives. Somewhat surprisingly, the fiducial ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i'], []), ' are reasonably well constrained notwithstanding the large uncertainties on the cosmographic parameters. Such a result can be qualitatively understood noting that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i'], []), ' depend on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(q_0, j_0, s_0, l_0)'], []), ' through a ratio of coefficients so that it is possible that a variation in the numerator is compensated by a similar variation in the denominator in such a way that the final ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_i'], []), ' is unaltered. As a consequence, the dependence on the cosmographic parameters is made weaker thus reducing the impact of the parameters uncertainties. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conclusions')]), '\n', '\nCosmography is a useful method to give a picture of the observed\nuniverse considering minimal assumptions (isotropy, homogeneity,\nTaylor series expansion of distances) without choosing any\ndynamical model a priori.\n\nIn this paper, we have taken into account the problem to test\nbrane-cosmology, where an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(R)'], []), '-term is present in the boundary\n4D-action, by cosmography. Being ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), 'CDM a realistic picture\nof the today observed universe, we have adopted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), 'CDM\nobservational results as priors for our approach. We assumed the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(R)'], []), ' function to be analytical in order to evaluate the\nhigher-order curvature contributions with respect to general\nrelativity contribution, i.e. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(R)= R'], []), '. The results are\nencouraging since small higher-order deviations with respect to\ngeneral relativity give dynamical behaviors, consistent with\nobserved cosmic acceleration, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' without'), '  introducing  dark\nenergy terms.\n\nHowever, the approach should be consistently probed at small,\nmedium and high redshift by selecting suitable standard candles\nor, at least, reliable distance indicators at any scale. Despite\nof this technical difficulty, the method outlined here  deserves\nfurther investigations since it is connecting a fundamental\ntheory, as the DGP-brane model,  with data coming from precision\ncosmology. We have here addressed this point in a preliminary way\nby only using SNeIa and BAO, but other probes (such as GRBs) may be added to further\nnarrow the constraints on the present day values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(R)'], []), ' and its second and\nthird derivatives with respect to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), '.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgments')]), '\n', '\nMBL is  supported by the Portuguese Agency Funda', TexCmd('c', [BraceGroup('c')]), '\\~', BraceGroup('a'), 'o para a\nCi', '\\^', BraceGroup('e'), 'ncia e Tecnologia through the fellowship\nSFRH/BPD/26542/2006. She also wishes to acknowledge the\nhospitality of LeCosPA at the National University of Taiwan during\nthe completion of part of this work. SC acknowledges INFN support\nfor this research.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('Perlmutter:1998np')]), '\n  S.~Perlmutter et al.,      Astrophys. cecchini@bo.infn.it')]), '                               \n', TexCmd('thanks', [BracketGroup('rfemail4'), BraceGroup('E-mail: fabbri@dffs.unifi.it;fabbri@fi.infn.it')]), ' BraceGroup('E-mail: elena@astro.ubc.ca')]), '                                                \n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nWe derive the angular power spectra of intensity and polarization of\nGalactic synchrotron emission in the range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['36', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('la'), '  10^3'], []), ' from\nthe Parkes survey mapping the southern Galactic plane at 2.4 GHz.\nThe polarization spectra of both electric and magnetic parity\nup to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 10^3'], []), ' are approximated very well by power laws with\nslope coefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4'], []), ', quite different from the CMB spectra.\nWe show that no problem should arise from Galactic synchrotron\nfor measurements of CMB polarization in the cosmological window.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('keyword', ['\nBackground radiations --- Radio continuum: general --- Methods: statistical\n\nPACS: 98.70-f, 98.70.Vc\n\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction and main results')]), '\n', "\nThe purpose of this work is to compute the angular power spectra of\nsynchrotron emission from the Galaxy, and in particular of its polarized\ncomponent. Synchrotron radiation is expected to dominate the linearly\npolarized component of the sky background in a wide frequency range up to\na few tens of GHz. It is important for the knowledge \nof the Galactic structure, and\nalso because it will be a major contaminant in forthcoming measurements of\nthe polarization of the cosmic microwave background (CMB), planned from\nground  (Keating et al., 1998; Sironi et al., 1997; \nPisano, 1999; Hedman, 1999) \nand from space (Wright, 1999; Cortiglioni et al., 1999; \nDe Zotti et al., 1999).\n\nSeparation of the various contributions to the total background in the\n``cosmological window'' (say, ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('simeq'), ' 50 - 90'], []), ' GHz) \npromises to be a delicate job, and its success will\nrely on sensible assumptions about the spectral and spatial properties of\nGalactic foregrounds (e.g., Tegmark et al. 2000, Prunet et\nal. 2000). In this connection we observe that at frequencies of tens of GHz the\ndominant contribution to the angular spectrum may be a Galactic foreground\n(synchrotron or dust), the integrated background of unresolved extragalactic\nsources, the primordial anisotropy of CMB or a non-primordial anisotropy\n(for instance arising from the gravitational lens effect) depending on the\nrange of the spherical-harmonic index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l'], []), '. Therefore the cosmological window\nshould be understood as a bidimensional region of the (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), ' '], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l'], []), ') plane,\nwhich is furthermore different for anisotropy and polarization.\nFor this reason angular power spectra, which provide a\nstandard tool for CMB analysis, are becoming relatively commonplace also for\nforegrounds, although in the latter case they provide an incomplete\ndescription because of the strong phase coherence of Galactic emission.\nIntensity (or temperature) power spectra of foregrounds \nare reasonably approximated by\npower laws, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('I', TexCmd('ell'), ' '), TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I')], []), ', with slopes steeper than\nCMB. For the latter the scale-invariant adiabatic-wave spectrum predicts ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' CMB')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 2'], []), ' on large scales and power excess at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^2', TexCmd('la'), '  ', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('la'), '  10^3'], []), ' because of several acoustic peaks. Both the\nlarge-scale behaviour and the first acoustic peak appear to be confirmed by\nexperiment (Barreiro, 1999, de Bernardis et al. 2000, Hanany et\nal. 2000). For synchrotron, values ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' syn')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 2.5', TexCmd('div'), ' 3'], []), ' have been derived from the 408-MHz maps of Haslam et al. \n(1981) by Tegmark ', '\\&', ' Efstathiou (1996) and Bouchet et al. (1996), and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' syn')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 3'], []), ' from\nthe 1420-MHz northern sky survey \n(Reich ', '\\&', ' Reich, 1986) by Bouchet ', '\\&', ' Gispert (1999). However, \nthe analysis of Tenerife patch at the same frequencies provides a nearly\nscale-invariant spectrum, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' syn')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 2,'], []), ' except near the\nresolution limit of the maps \n(Lasenby, 1997). For dust emission Gautier et al. (1992) gave ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' dust')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 3'], []), ' down to the IRAS\nresolution of a few arc minutes, and a similar result was found for DIRBE \n(Wright, 1998); from the combined DIRBE and IRAS maps Schlegel et al. (1998)\nderive ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' dust')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 2.5'], []), '. The situation is less\nclear for free-free emission: While Kogut et al. (1996) find ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '\n', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' FF')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 3'], []), ' correlating COBE-DMR with DIRBE, Veeraraghavan ', '\\&', '\nDavies (1997) derive ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' FF')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 2.3'], []), ' at 53 GHz from H', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' '], []), ' maps but with a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' much lower'), ' normalization. The discrepancy\nsupports the case for dust emission in the cosmological window, the\nmechanism of rotational excitation of small grains having been proposed by\nDraine ', '\\&', ' Lazarian (1998). \nAngular spectra of polarized emission have been measured so far neither for\nCMB nor for Galactic foregrounds. Theoretical modeling for CMB gives (for\nthe electric-parity polarization excited by density waves in the\nstandard-model) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' CMB'))], []), ' rather close to zero, which means\nmuch smaller spatial correlations \nat large angular scales than for temperature fluctuations. A\ncorresponding excess of small-scale structure (in comparison to temperature\nfluctuations) is found by Prunet et al. (1998) for polarized dust\nemission in modeling based on the HI maps of the Leiden-Dwingloo survey\n', '[', 'see also Sethi et al. (1998) and Prunet ', '\\&', ' Lazarian (1999)', ']', ':\nTheir results are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' dust')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_B^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' dust')), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4'], []), ' for the electric and magnetic parity spectra, respectively.\nThe angular power spectrum is therefore steeper for\nGalactic dust than for CMB.\n\nNow an important question should be posed: can this result be generalized to\nother foregrounds? If so, the separation of CMB polarization signals would\nbe easier. The present work considers the polarization spectra of Galactic\nsynchrotron, and can be regarded as complementary to that \nof Prunet et al. (1998)\nsince polarized free-free emission should not be dominant at any\nfrequency. Our approach is the analysis of low-frequency maps. Unfortunately\nno full-sky survey is available for the polarized component of synchrotron,\nthe largest coverage being provided by Brouw ', '\\&', ' Spoelstra (1976) at\nthe expense of a quite sparse sampling. Here we make use of the Parkes\nsurvey of the southern Galactic plane (Duncan et al., 1995, 1997)\nwhich, although limited\nto a relatively small window of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.39'], []), ' sr, provides uniformly covered\nmaps, not suffering from undersampling. Its frequency of 2.4 GHz probably\nallows a reasonable extrapolation to the cosmological window, thanks to the\nlimited effects expected from Faraday \nrotation. The typical values of 5--10 rad m', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' for\nthe rotation measure (RM) reported by Spoelstra (1984) and\nWieringa et al (1993) allow to estimate a negligible depolarization \nof few percent at 2.4 GHz. \n\nThe main result of this paper is that the synchrotron\npolarization spectra \nup to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 10^3'], []), ' are approximated very well by power laws with\nslope coefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_B ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4'], []), ', a result very\nclose to that of Prunet et al. (1998). The intensity spectrum\nis also found to have a moderate slope, close to that of polarization\nspectra, unless we use alternative maps (available at the\nParkes WEB site', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('http://www.atnf.csiro.au/database/astro', '\\_', 'data/2.4Gh', '\\_', 'Southern')]), ') \nwhere Galactic-plane sources have been removed; therefore\nthis result should not be extrapolated to the whole sky.\nIn the last section of this paper we provide reasons, suggesting that\nthe slopes of polarization spectra are likely to apply to the whole sky.\nWe show that if this assumption is correct, synchrotron emission\ncannot be a problem for CMB polarization measurements in the\ncosmological window. Otherwise,  \na value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4'], []), ' can\nbe used as a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' lower limit'), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E'], []), ' and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_B'], []), ';\nthen the slope differences with respect to the CMB polarization spectra \nwould still be larger,\nand the CMB polarized signal would prevail even more strongly in the\ncosmological window.  \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Angular spectra in the Parkes survey')]), '\n', '\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('syncmaps')]), ' shows the sky coverage of the Parkes 2.417 GHz survey\nand other available surveys as well. The Parkes survey covers a strip, 127', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' ')], []), ' long and at least 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' ')], []), ' wide, with a FWHM resolution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), ' '), '.4'], []), '. Maps are available at the Parkes WEB site for the total\nintensity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ' both before and after subtraction of structures with size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('leq'), ' 2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' ')], []), ', and for the Stokes parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' with no source\nsubtraction.\n\n', BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=13cm\n', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('mapspol.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Sky coverages of synchrotron polarization surveys. We\nreport the regions observed at 0.408-1.411 GHz by\nBrouw ', '\\&', ' Spoelstra (1976); in the 2.417-GHz Parkes survey\n(Duncan et al., 1995, 1997); at Effelsberg, 2.695 GHz\n(Junkes et al. 1987; Duncan et al., 1999) and 1.4 GHz \n(Uyaniker et al. 1999);\nand in the Canadian Galactic Plane survey (CGPS, \n0.408 and 1.420 GHz)  (English et al., 1998). ')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('syncmaps')]), '\n'], [])), BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=12cm\n', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('testfit.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The input and output CMB spectra (dotted and full line, respectively)\nfor a test of Fourier analysis in the Parkes survey window. The input\nspectrum is \ncomputed for a standard CDM model with a secondary-ionization optical depth\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_', BraceGroup('ion'), '  = 0.18'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('testcmb')]), '\n'], [])), '\n', '\nBecause of the limited sky coverage, spherical-harmonic spectra are suitably\nobtained from a standard Fourier analysis according to the technique\ndeveloped by Seljak (1997) for the CMB polarization and applied by \nPrunet et al. (1998)\nto the polarized dust foreground. After\nthe Fourier components of Stokes parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')'], []), ' are computed on a map covering a solid angle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), ' '], []), ', the\nestimators for the power spectra of intensity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('I', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), ' and total\npolarization ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('P', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), ' can be readily computed by means of the equations \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nC_', BraceGroup('I', TexCmd('ell'), ' '), ' ', '&=&', '\\{', ' ', TexCmd('frac'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')', ']', ' -w_I^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\\}', ' b^', BraceGroup('-2'), '(', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', '),  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('intens')]), ' \nC_', BraceGroup('P', TexCmd('ell'), ' '), ' ', '&=&', '\\{', ' ', TexCmd('frac'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega', [BraceGroup('N_', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')]), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l')), '[', ' Q(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')Q^', BraceGroup('*'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')+U(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')U^', BraceGroup('*'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')', ']', ' -2w_P^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\\}', '\nb^', BraceGroup('-2'), '(', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', '),  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('polar')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere the sums are performed over the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', TexCmd('ell'), ' '], []), ' modes with wavevector\nmagnitude around ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' '], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b(', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', ')'], []), ' is the window function and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_', BraceGroup('I,P'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '=', TexCmd('Omega'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('I,P'), '^2/N_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' pixel'))], []), ' is the\npixel-independent measure of noise with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('I,P')], []), ' the pixel \nnoise. The electric and magnetic parity of\npolarization can also be separately computed by means of \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nC_', BraceGroup('E', TexCmd('ell'), ' '), ' ', '&=&', '\\{', ' ', TexCmd('cos'), ' ', '(2', TexCmd('phi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l')), ')+U(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')', TexCmd('sin'), ' ', '(2', TexCmd('phi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l')), ')|\n^2-w_P^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\\}', ' b^', BraceGroup('-2'), '(', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', '),  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('electr')]), ' \nC_', l')), '| -Q(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')', TexCmd('sin'), ' ', '(2', TexCmd('phi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l')), ')+U(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), ')', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('magnet')]), '\n'], []), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'))], []), ' the direction angle of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' l'), '.'], []), '\n', '\nFor the Parkes survey the window function can be approximated by a Gaussian, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b(', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', ')=', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup(' -', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ell'), ' +1)', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' b')), '^2/2')]), ' '], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' b')), '=4^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), ' '), '.4'], []), ' . The polarization noise is not constant,\nbeing 11 mJy beam area', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' for most of the sky coverage but as low as 6\nmJy beam area', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' in some regions. We chose to extract from the survey\nconstant-noise square patches of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' '), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' ')], []), ' ', '(i.e.,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['150 ', TexCmd('times'), ' 150'], []), ' pixels). We thereby obtained\n12 independent submaps (the first one being centered at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l = 360^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'))], []), ' and moving toward decreasing Galactic longitudes),\nand on each of them we performed the Fourier\nanalysis and derived a set of four spectra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), ' ', '(with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X=I'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ') by means of Eqs. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('intens')]), ')-(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('magnet')]), ') (the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' spectrum\nwas in fact redundant, but we computed it for all of the submaps for checks\nof consistency). \nA potential problem with the Fourier analysis, when it is applied to small\nmaps, arises from border effects, which may give spurious contributions\nto the spectra. A solution to this problem is considered by \nHobson ', '\\&', ' Magueijo (1996),\nwho suggest to modulate the signal by some function vanishing\nat the borders (apodization). \nWe carried out our analysis both with appropriate cosine functions\nand with no modulation. The differences turned out to be small in the\nrange ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('la'), ' 1000'], []), ', except for the intensity maps\nwith source subtraction. In Figures ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('twelvepatch')]), '-', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('meanspec1')]), '\nwe explicitly report the results\nobtained with the cosine modulation up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' = 1100'], []), ', which is\nclose to the resolution limit of the survey.\nIn order to test the reliability of the computed spectra,\nwe also built up simulated maps for CMB, using angular spectra\ncomputed by means \nof CMBFAST (Seljak ', '\\&', ' Zaldarriaga, 1996) and HEALPix package', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('http://www.tac.dk/~healpix')]), ',\nand performed the Fourier analysis on them\nwithin the Parkes survey window. The results shown in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('testcmb')]), '\nprove that the method is quite reliable: The output spectrum differs from\nthe input one only for some smoothing of the sharpest features,\nwhich is particularly evident for low values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' '], []), '. \nSmoother spectra -- such as those expected for synchrotron -- are less\naffected by the procedure. The results\nfor all of the 12 submaps also are mutually consistent in the CMB case.\n\n', BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=12cm\n', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('powsp12.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The angular power spectra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('I ', TexCmd('ell'), ' '), ' '], []), '  and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('E ', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), ' ', '(dashed and full lines, respectively) for the 12 submaps of the\nParkes survey.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('twelvepatch')]), '\n'], [])), BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=12cm\n', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('teb.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The mean\npower spectra in the Parkes survey. The curves give the intensity \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('I ', TexCmd('ell'), ' '), ' '], []), ' with\nand without source subtraction (full and dotted lines, respectively)\nand the polarization ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('E ', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), ' and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('B ', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), '  \n', '(dash-dotted and dashed).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('meanspec0')]), '\n'], [])), BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=12cm\n', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('clfits.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The intensity and electric parity spectra compared to the \nfitting functions described in the text.\nThe best-fit parameters refer to the range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['36 ', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('le'), ' 800'], []), "\nand to averaging ``method 2''.")]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('meanspec1')]), '\n'], [])), '\n', '\nThe spectra obtained from synchrotron submaps, however, \nshow large variations in the normalization; this fact is\ncertainly not unexpected, due to the phase coherence of Galactic structure.\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('twelvepatch')]), ' shows the results for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('I', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), ' ', '(with no source\nsubtraction) and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('E', TexCmd('ell'), ' ')], []), ' from the individual submaps; the results for\nmagnetic parity polarization are similar to those for electric parity\n(the intensity spectra after source removal, however, are much steeper than those\nreported in the Figure, as we will discuss below).\n\nThe normalization variations for intensity and polarization cover different\nranges (spanning more than 3 and about 2 orders of magnitude, respectively), and\nthey are not strictly correlated since the polarization degree is far from\nbeing constant. The slopes of the curves up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 10^3,'], []), ' however,\nare much more mutually consistent than normalization. Visual inspection of\nFig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('twelvepatch')]), ' shows a couple of low-emission regions\n(submaps 9 and 12, placed at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' l < 280^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' ')], []), ') with\nparticularly flat intensity curves\nat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('ga'), ' 10^2'], []), ', but this feature does not appear in\npolarized emission. Clearly most of the curves \nare reasonably approximated by power\nlaws, but when we fit the data with functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('ell'), ' '), '=A_X', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_X')], []), ', \nthe logarithmic slopes vary with both the chosen submap\nand the range of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' '], []), '.\nIn Table ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('slopes1')]), ' we report angular-spectrum\nbest-fit slopes for all of the submaps with no source subtraction. \nColumns 2 to 4 (primed quantities) refer to the range \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 500'], []), ', and the remaining (unprimed quantities) to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 800'], []), '. Only for two submaps and for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 500'], []), ' the intensity spectra are steeper than\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I = ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.32', TexCmd('pm'), ' 0.13'], []), '   ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('lllllll')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('*')], []), 'After source subtraction\n'], [BracketGroup('t'), BraceGroup('4.in')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe then have to combine the results from the 12 submaps in some way.\nA simple method is to compute weighted averages of the best-fit\nparameters; this implies weighting with statistical\nerrors, with no regard to the strength of the emission in the submaps.\nTable ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('slopes2')]), ' gives the mean parameters (including the normalization\nfactors, denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_X'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_X^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), ' ')], []), ") obtained in this way, \nas well as the statistical errors; they are collected in the Table rows\nreferring to averaging ``method 1''. According to such results, \nthe slope of the intensity spectrum slightly decreases for increasing\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' '], []), ' and can be hardly distinguished from that of polarization spectra \nat large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' '], []), ': \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E ', TexCmd('simeq'), '  ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_B ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 1.5,\n', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', ' ', '(', TexCmd('ell'), ' = 36 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 800,', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('method')]), '\\;', ' 1).\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('method1')]), '\n'], []), ' \nSimilar results are found with the simpler treatment with no signal\ncosine modulation; the differences with respect to the results in the\nTable are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_X ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 0.1'], []), '.\n\nIt can be argued that because of the averaging method, the slopes given by\nEq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('method1')]), ') may be\nnot representative of the full Parkes\nsurvey, since low-emission and high-emission subwindows are considered on\nequal footing. An alternative approach is\naveraging the spectra of the 12 subwindows:\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('meanspec0')]), " reports the mean spectra, \nand includes magnetic parity and the\nintensity spectrum after source subtraction. \nWe thereby performed best fits as above also on such mean\nspectra. This procedure, referred to as averaging\n``method 2'' in Table ", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('slopes2')]), ', clearly gives stronger \nweights to high-emission\nsubmaps.\nThe results are quite different for the normalization factors \n(and especially for intensity), but no large variation is found for the\nslope factors. The slope of the intensity spectrum however\nis slightly increased now, \ndue to the scarce weight given to the nearly flat spectra of a couple\nof low-intensity submaps, the larger value being found\nin the smaller range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' = 36 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 500'], []), '; no clear change \nhowever is found for\npolarization:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ' ', '_I ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.8, ', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), '_E ', TexCmd('simeq'), '  \n', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), '_B ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 1.5,\n', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', ' ', '(', TexCmd('ell'), ' = 36 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 500,', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('method')]), '\\;', ' 2).\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('method2')]), '\n'], []), '  \n', '\nAs shown by Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('meanspec1')]), ', the fitting functions with the\nparameters found  in the larger range (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('le'), ' 800'], []), ') describe \nvery well the polarization spectra, whereas a modest discrepancy\nappears for the intensity spectrum at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('le'), ' 100'], []), ".\n\nWe also tried with a further procedure, \nrenormalizing the spectra of the 12 submaps to a same mean intensity value\nand then constructing mean curves. The parameters of such mean curves are\nreferred to as averaging ``method 3'' in the Table, and show slightly\nsmaller slopes. For\nthe range ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' = 36 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 800'], []), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I ', TexCmd('simeq'), '  ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E ', TexCmd('simeq'), '  ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_B ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4,  ', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', '\n', '(', TexCmd('ell'), ' = 36 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 800,', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('method')]), '\\;', ' 3).\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('method3')]), '\n'], []), '  \n', '\nA quite different result is found for the intensity maps with source\nsubtraction. The slope is now much higher, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I ', TexCmd('simeq'), '  5'], []), '. At\nlarge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ' the signal is very small, and it would be overcome by border\neffects in the absence of apodization even for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' < 10^3'], []), '. \n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Discussion')]), '\n', '\nThe most attractive conclusion we can draw from the present work regards the\nangular spectrum slope of the polarized synchrotron emission up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '\n', TexCmd('approx'), ' 10^3'], []), '. Since this slope substantially differs from that of polarized\nCMB, provided it can be extrapolated to the cosmological window the\nseparation of cosmological and Galactic signals \nbecomes easier. In\nparticular, at a given frequency CMB polarization is expected to prevail\nbetter at smaller scales; this result is derived from Galactic-plane maps\nwith no source subtraction. It is interesting to observe that essentially\nthe same slope, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_B', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4,'], []), ' was found by Prunet et\nal. (1998) for polarized dust emission. We may speculate that this coincidence\nmay be due to the similarity of polarizing/depolarizing \nmechanisms inscribed in the\nGalactic structure.\n\n', BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=12cm\n', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('orsonfig.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The angular spectra of polarized synchrotron extrapolated\nto 22, 32, and 60 GHz (full line, from top to down) with the linear\nfits (dashed line), compared to the CMB E-spectrum computed for\na standard CDM model (dot-dashed line) and a CDM with a secondary \nionization optical depth\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('ion'), ' = 0.2'], []), ' ', '(dotted line).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('synchcmb')]), '\n'], [])), '\n', '\nOn the other hand, our results on the total intensity spectrum might\nlook somewhat intriguing at first\nsight. The original Parkes maps with no source subtraction support only\na moderate slope, close to that of polarization spectra. \nThis contrasts sharply with the\nresults of  Tegmark ', '\\&', ' Efstathiou (1996), Bouchet et al. (1996) and Bouchet\n', '\\&', ' Gispert (1999);\nthe discrepancy is much smaller with the analysis of \nLasenby (1997) on the Tenerife patch. Removal of sources up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' ')], []), ' wide,\nhowever, gives a much larger slope, beyond the more \nfamiliar result ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I', TexCmd('approx'), ' 3'], []), '. This fact can be readily interpreted,\nobserving that in the Parkes survey\nthe intensity angular spectrum at large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' '], []), ' is dominated by Galactic-plane\nsources. An obvious consequence is that no real contradiction exists with \nprevious work, since such results as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4 ', TexCmd('div'), ' 1.8'], []), '\ncannot be extrapolated outside the\nGalactic plane.\n\nWe then should ask, which values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_X '], []), ' \nwould be appropriate for the whole sky. \nClearly the subtraction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('circ'), ' ')], []), ' sources as described\nat the Parkes WEB site is a quite radical procedure, cutting out \nhigh-order harmonics very efficiently. It\nis then easy to infer that the full-sky ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I '], []), ' \nmust lie somewhere\nbetween 1.4 and 5; however the existing support for the value\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I', TexCmd('approx'), ' 3'], []), ' is not very strong, in view of\nthe results of  Lasenby (1997), supporting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_I', TexCmd('approx'), ' 2.'], []), '\nOn the other hand, we believe that our results on the polarization slope \ncan be extrapolated out of the Galactic plane\nwith some confidence. The inspection of Fig.\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('twelvepatch')]), ' shows that for polarization \nno systematic differences of slope exist\nbetween high and low emission submaps. As already remarked,\nthe overall normalization (rms signal)\nhas much weaker variations than for intensity spectra. \nThus the role of Galactic-plane \nsources\nis less important. Also, the agreement with Prunet et al. (1998) is\nimpressive.\n\nAssuming that the polarization angular spectra are correct for the full sky, \nwe can try to extrapolate them to frequencies higher that 2.4 GHz and compare\nthem to CMB spectra. Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('synchcmb')]), ' shows such extrapolations to\n22, 32 and 60 GHz, where the average\nParkes survey normalization and a synchrotron spectral index of 3 are \nassumed. Obviously this procedure is expected to overrate the synchrotron\nfull-sky spectra. The comparison of synchrotron and CMB angular\nspectra shows that for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' > 10^2'], []), ' the latter prevail\nat 60 GHz in spite of the above Galactic-plane normalization.\n\nFinally, we may ask how this conclusion should be changed if the\npolarization slopes of Table ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('slopes2')]), ' cannot apply to a\nfull-sky survey. According to the reasoning expounded for intensity spectra,\nwe can state that values ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('simeq'), ' 1.4'], []), ' can\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' at least'), ' be used as lower limits to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_E'], []), ' and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '_B'], []), '.\nThen the slope differences with respect to the \nCMB polarization spectra would still\nincrease in comparison with the scenario described by Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('synchcmb')]), ',\nand the CMB signal would prevail even more strongly in the\ncosmological window.  \n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgments')]), '\n', '\nWe thank S. \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('|c|c|c|c|c|c|')])], [])], [BracketGroup('h')]), ' \nWe now compare our results with those in the literature\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('rad1,rad2,radtau')]), '.\nAs shown in Table 2,\nthe decay branching ratios\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' l^+ l^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('l'), '=e, ', TexCmd('mu')], []), ')\nwithout long distance contributions\nfound in our calculations\nare smaller than those in the constituent quark model ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('rad2')]), ', whereas\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('d'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' l^+ l^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' the statement are much smaller than ones.\nIt is mainly due to that in the constituent quark model\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('rad2')]), ' the decay rate\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('q'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' l^+ l^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' is proportional to the inverse of\nthe quark mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_q'], []), '.\nIt is interesting to see that our results are close to those in \nthe light-cone QCD sum rule model ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('rad1,radtau')]), '. \nWe note that the SD contributions for the decays in both constituent quark\nand light-cone QCD sum rule models are sensitive\nto the values of the decay constants ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('B_', BraceGroup('s,d'))], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conclusions')]), '\n', '\n  ', '\n', '\nWe have studied the decays of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s,d'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' l^+ l^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' within the\nlight-front model.\nWe have calculated the tensor type form factors and used these\nform factors to evaluate the decay branching ratios.\nWe have found that, in the standard model, the branching ratios of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s(d)'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+ e^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s(d)'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '^+ ', TexCmd('mu'), '^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s(d)'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '^+', TexCmd('tau'), '^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' are \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['7.1', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-9')], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.5', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-10')], []), '), \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['8.3', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-9')], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.8', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-10')], []), ') and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.6', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-8')], []), ' \n', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['6.2', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-10')], []), '), respectively. Comparing with the purely leptonic \ndecays of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s,d'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' l^+ l^-'], []), ', we have shown that the  branching ratios \nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s,d'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' l^+ l^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' have the same order \nof magnitude for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' channel but that of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s,d'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+ e^-\n', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' \nare much larger.\nWe conclude that some of the radiative leptonic decays of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('s,d'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('l'), '^+ ', TexCmd('l'), '^- ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' could be measured in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' factories\nas well as LHC-B experiments, where approximately,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['6 ', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('11'), '(2 ', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('11'), ')~B_d(B_s)'], []), ' mesons are expected to be\nproduced per year.\n\n\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('1cm')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Acknowledgments')]), '\n', '\nThis work was supported in part by the National Science Council of the\nRepublic of China under contract number NSC-89-2112-M-007-013 and\nNSC-89-2112-M-006-026 .\n\n\n', TexCmd('newpage'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('bi', [BraceGroup('ckm')]), '\nN.
