4090 ***Failed to finish ren-charm.tex: [Line: 0, Offset 306] Malformed argument. First and last elements must match a valid argument format. In this case, TexSoup could not find matching punctuation for: {.
Just finished parsing: ['{', '\\}', BraceGroup('jtstrut'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vrule'), ' height5ex depth0pt width0pt'), ' ', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('Renormalization approach to constituent quark models of\n  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Q'), 'uarkonium', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Supported by Ministerio de Ciencia y\n    Tecnolog', "\\'", TexCmd('i'), " a under Contracts no. FPA2010-21750-C02-02, by the\n    European Community-Research Infrastructure Integrating Activity ''Study of\n    Strongly Interacting Matter'' (HadronPhysics2 Grant no. 227431),\n    the Spanish Ingenio-Consolider 2010 Program CPAN (CSD2007-00042),\n    the Spanish DGI and FEDER funds with grant no. FIS2008-01143/FIS,\n    Junta de Andaluc", BraceGroup("\\'", TexCmd('i')), 'a grants no. FQM225.')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('J. Segovia')]), TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('segonza@usal.es')]), '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('D.R. Entem')]), TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('entem@usal.es')]), '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('F. Fern', "\\'", 'andez')]), TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('fdz@usal.es')]), '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('Grupo de F', "\\'", BraceGroup(TexCmd('i')), 'sica Nuclear and IUFFyM,  Universidad de Salamanca, \nE-37008 Salamanca, Spain')]), '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('E. Ruiz Arriola')]), TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('earriola@ugr.es')]), ' ', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('Departamento de \nF', "\\'", 'isica At', "\\'", 'omica, Molecular y Nuclear,  Universidad de Granada, E-18071 \nGranada, Spain.')]), '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup(' Instituto Carlos I de F', BraceGroup("\\'", TexCmd('i')), 'sica Te', "\\'", 'orica y Computacional,\n  Universidad de Granada, E-18071 Granada, Spain')]), '\n', TexCmd('date', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('today'))]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', [' \n', TexCmd('rule', [BraceGroup('0ex'), BraceGroup('3ex')]), ' Constituent quark models, while successful, require a\ngreat deal of fine tuning of the short distance interactions by\nintroducing phenomenological gluonic form factors which are ultimately\ndesigned to accurately reproduce the spectrum. We apply and develop\nrenormalization ideas to reduce the short distance sensitivity and\nshow that, as naively expected, but not explicitly implemented in the\nmodels, the physics of binding is entirely linked to the string\ntension whereas leptonic decays depend more on the gluon exchange\npotential.  We also show how the spectrum of S- and D-\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1^', BraceGroup('--')], []), ' states is successfully intertwined through the singular tensor \ninteraction. \n\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('pacs', [BraceGroup('14.40.Gx, 12.39.Pn, 11.10.Gh')]), ' \n', TexCmd('keywords', [BraceGroup('Charmonium, renormalization, quark models')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nAfter the discovery of the first heavy-quark bound states, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi')], []), '\nand the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Upsilon')], []), " systems, it was soon realized that a\nnonrelativistic picture seemed to hold for them. The charmonium system\nhas become the prototypical 'hydrogen atom' of meson spectroscopy and\ntherefore it was the first and simplest case where a bound state of\nquarks could be studied. The old Cornell\npotential~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Eichten:1979ms')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV(r)=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('3r')]), '+', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r\n'], []), '\nprovides a rough estimate of the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1^', BraceGroup('--')], []), ' charmonium spectrum and in particular \nof the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' resonance (see e.g.\nRef.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lichtenberg:1987ms,Voloshin:2007dx')]), ' for a review and references\ntherein). In potential models, One-Gluon Exchange (OGE) short distance\nsingularities appear and phenomenological gluonic form factors must be\nintroduced (see e.g.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Weinstein:1983gd')]), ' for an early proposal).  This\ntriggers an unpleasant short distance sensitivity, and as we will show it mainly\nhides the fact that the ground state is actually being used as an input rather\nthan a prediction. In this paper we want to make this statement more\nquantitative and to analyze to what extent can one disentangle the physics of\nthe ground state to that of the excited states. The method which we will be\nusing is based on renormalization ideas. To provide a proper and broad\nperspective and to avoid confusion with other approaches closely related, it is\nof interest to review some relevant developments in what follows. \n\nFor the lowest-lying bound states the size of the system is smaller or\ncomparable than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' QCD')], []), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Titard:1993nn,Titard:1994id')]), ',\nwhereas excited states start feeling the long range string tension. In the case\nof charmonium this is so until one reaches the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('D')]), 'D'], []), ' production\nthreshold. Of course, one expects that at short distances corrections are\ncomputable within perturbation theory due to asymptotic freedom, whereas\nat long distances one  must resort to lattice calculations.\n\nFor heavy particles the static energy, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E(R)- 2 m '], []), ', is an observable\nand thus a gauge and scale independent quantity. The rigorous\nnon-perturbative definition of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), ' Q Q'], []), ' potential is the\nexpectation value of the Wilson loop and has been continuously used on\nlattice calculations~(a review on potentials from lattice QCD can be\nfound e.g. in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bali:2000gf')]), '). It should be noticed that\npotentials are computed for point-like sources, i.e. structureless\nquarks. The determination of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), ' Q Q'], []), ' potential has been carried\nout in perturbation theory up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N^3\nLO'], []), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PhysRevLett.104.112002,PhysRevLett.104.112003')]), '. Looking for\na scale independent potential generates the Renormalon problem (for a\nreview see e.g. Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Beneke:1998ui')]), ') which causes serious\nconvergence difficulties.  Effective Field Theory (EFT) methods\ndisentangle the hard, soft and ultrasoft scales\nperturbatively~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Brambilla:2004jw')]), ' and explicitly solve the\nproblem.\n\nThe pNRQCD approach~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Pineda:1997bj,Brambilla:1999xf')]), ' is an EFT which has\nbetter convergence properties than NRQCD since it encodes the ultrasoft scales\nnon-perturbatively in terms of potentials which enter as Wilson\ncoefficients and should be obtained directly from the lattice or string models\nenabling a reliable description of excited states. The bottomline seems to be\nthat perturbative potentials should be treated perturbatively whereas non\nperturbative potentials should be treated non-perturbatively.\n\nFollowing an observation~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Beneke:1998rk')]), ' that the renormalon problem is\ntriggered by an illegal extension of Fourier integrals to all momenta, a\nparametrization of the lattice data in the short distance  region, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r ', TexCmd('le'), '\n0.15 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), ', has been proposed~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Laschka:2011zr')]), ' cutting off low momenta\nbelow ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_f ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 1 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV')], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_f ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ' a flagrant lack of convergence\nof perturbation theory has been pictorially represented in \nRef.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Laschka:2011zr')]), ';  depending on the scheme proposed one may\neven violate fundamental inequalities~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bachas:1985xs,Nussinov:2000kn')]), '. It\nshould be noted that this representation smoothly matches the current lattice\ndetermination of the static energy allowing an analysis of the quarkonium\nspectrum, but suggests that the non-perturbative contribution corresponds to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q\n', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '_f'], []), ', larger than the ultrasoft scales expected from pNRQCD. Unlike the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_f ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ' case the convergence is very good and basically a simple OGE\npotential is left.\n\nOf course all these considerations could less transparently be handled from a\nfundamental point of view by solving the theory ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ab initio'), '. However, direct\nlattice QCD calculations of quarkonium spectrum require small enough lattice\nspacings, so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M a ', TexCmd('ll'), ' 1 '], []), ' and so far promising calculations operate at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a\n', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.1-0.2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), ' producing some over-estimation of excited\nstates~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Burch:2009az')]), '.\n\nTurning to a less fundamental approach such as the non-relativistic\nquark model and in the spirit of the Cornell potential and extensions\nof it let us mention that the standard regularization of the short\ndistance contributions to the OGE potential (corresponding to delta\ncontact interactions and the tensor and spin-orbit pieces), actually\ncorresponds to tune the parameters of the regulator to fit the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' mass. In addition, one of the usual parameters which are\nadjusted is the strong coupling constant, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), '. However, the\nworld average strong coupling constant is\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '(M_', BraceGroup('Z^', BraceGroup('0')), ')=0.1184', TexCmd('pm'), '0.0007'], []), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bethke:2009jm')]), '. The\nmeasured values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '(Q^', BraceGroup('2'), ')'], []), ', covering energy scales from\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q', TexCmd('equiv'), ' M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau')), '=1.78 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['209 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV')], []), ', exactly follow\nthe energy dependence predicted by QCD and therefore significantly\ntest the concept of Asymptotic Freedom. Therefore, the value of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), ' at the charm quark mass is fixed and is not larger than\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.2-0.3'], []), '. This value contradicts some quark models.\n\nA nonperturbative determination of the QCD potential at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(1/m)'], []), ' was\nundertaken for the first time in~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koma:2006si,Koma:2006fw')]), ', they found a\npotential which depends on the interquark distance as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-c/r^', BraceGroup('2')], []), ' and it is\ncomparable with the coulombic term of the static potential when applied to\ncharmonium and amounts to one-fourth of the coulombic term for bottomonium.\n\nLattice calculations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/m'], []), ' corrections based on the Bethe-Salpeter\namplitude~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ikeda:2011bs')]), ' ', '(see also ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kawanai:2011xb')]), ') reveal\nthat the dependence with the interquark distance of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/m'], []), '\ncontributions to the potential is the same than in the case above but\nother term which grows logarithmically with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' was found. When the\ndata are fitted taking into account LO and NLO contributions to the\npotential, the coefficients which accompany Coulomb and string forces\nare comparable to those calculated through Wilson loops.\n\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(1/m^2)'], []), ' spin-dependent and momentum-dependent corrections are\ninvestigated in SU(3) lattice gauge theory~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koma:2009ws')]), '. These\ncorrections are relevant ingredients of an effective field theory for heavy\nquarkonium called potential nonrelativistic QCD.\n\nIn the present paper we want to address the question on how much can\nwe deduce for the charmonium spectrum from the knowledge of the\npotential at long distances in a way that our ignorance at short\ndistances needs not play a crucial role. This allows to disentangle\nthe physics of the ground state to that of the excited states which\nare sensitive to the perturbative (Coulomb like) and non-perturbative\n(String like) corrections. Actually, our original motivation for the\npresent study was to analyze the role of regulators within constituent\nquark models like that of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Vijande:2005eu')]), '. However, our\nideas can be generally extended to any quark model and shed some light\non their predictive power.\n\n\nThe plan of the paper is as follows. In Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:toy')]), ' we\nprovide a simplified and pedagogical discussion of our main points in\nthe simplest case of the Cornell potential. The role of singular\ntensor and spin-orbit interactions is analyzed in\nSection~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:toy-coupled')]), ' where an interesting correlation between\nS- and D-waves is found. In Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:oldmodel')]), ' we review the\nbases of the constituent quark model proposed in\nRef.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Vijande:2005eu')]), '. In Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:renormodel')]), ' we focus\non the new renormalized charmonium model where the short distance\nregulators have been removed as they turn out to be physically\nirrelevant for most observables. Interesting issues regarding the scope and applicability\nof these renormalization ideas are scrutinized in\nSection~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:applic')]), '. Further aspects are dealt with by an\nenlightening analysis of the Bosonic String Model (BSM),\nSection~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:bsm')]), '.  Finally, we give some conclusions in\nSection~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:conclusions')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Renormalization of the Cornell Potential')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:toy')]), '\n', '\nIn this section, we provide a comprehensive discussion of the\nrenormalization approach as applied to heavy quark systems and  \nconfining potentials within the context of non-relativistic quantum\nmechanics. The Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q q '))]), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 ', TexCmd('Psi'), '  + V(r)  ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Psi'), ' ', '&=&  ', '\\,', ' \n', '(M-m_q - m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q'), ') ', TexCmd('Psi'), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q q '), '= m_q m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q'), '/(m_q + m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q'), ') '], []), ' is the\nreduced ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), ' q-q'], []), ' mass and the normalization condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('int'), ' d^3 r\n|', TexCmd('Psi'), '(', TexCmd('vec'), ' r)|^2'], []), ' = 1 must be imposed on the solution. We use the\nstandard Cornell potential  \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV(r)=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('3r')]), '+', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:pot-cornell')]), '\n'], []), '\nfor the purposes of illustration. The more elaborated potentials,\nwhere relativistic effects and spin-dependent corrections are added, \nwill be discussed in later Sections. It is remarkable that such a\nsimple potential not only captures the relevant physics of the problem\nbut also is accurately described by lattice calculations (see\ne.g.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Necco:2001xg')]), ') where Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:pot-cornell')]), ') is favoured\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4 ', TexCmd('alpha'), '_s/3= 0.25(1)'], []), ', extremely close to the bosonic string\nmodel ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s=', TexCmd('pi'), '/16'], []), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Alvarez:1981kc,Arvis:1983fp')]), '. It is worth\nmentioning that the lattice calculations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), ' q - q'], []), ' potentials\ncorrespond to using point sources, i.e., elementary quarks until\ndistances comparable to the lattice spacing. A smooth transition below\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.2 ', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), ' towards OGE has been observed. Unless otherwise stated\nwe will take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s= ', TexCmd('pi'), '/16'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '= (420 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), ')^2=0.1764 ', '\\,', ' \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV'), '^2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('J/', TexCmd('psi')), '=3096.916 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV')], []), ', \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c=1200', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c=0.3-0.01 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), '. \n\nFor the spherically symmetric Cornell potential the total relative\nwave function can be factorized in the usual fashion, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(', TexCmd('vec'), ' r) =\n(u(r)/ r) Y_', BraceGroup('l m'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('hat'), ' r)'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u(r)'], []), ' the reduced wave function and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_', BraceGroup('lm'), '(', TexCmd('hat'), ' r)'], []), ' the conventional spherical harmonics.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Review of the Renormalization approach')]), '\n', '\nLet us consider the standard non-relativistic Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation for bound \nstates in S-waves \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('mu'))]), 'u_', BraceGroup('n'), "''(r)+V(r)u_", BraceGroup('n'), '(r)=E_', BraceGroup('n'), 'u_', BraceGroup('n'), '(r),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:sch_Swave')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('n'), '(r)'], []), ' vanishes at long distances and the energy is defined\nwith respect to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), ' q - q'], []), ' threshold, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_n = M_n - m_q - m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q')], []), '. \n\nAnticipating our discussion we will assume for definiteness a short\ndistance auxiliary cut-off, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ', below which the potential\nvanishes. This cut-off is just a parameter which will ultimately be\nremoved while keeping some physical condition fixed. In our case we\nwill choose to fix the ground state energy to the experimental\nvalue. In the numerical application we will be concerned with the\nresidual cut-off dependence of observables induced by such a\nprocedure.\n\n\nUsing the standard trick of multiplying the Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:sch_Swave')]), ') by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r)'], []), ' and subtracting the similar equation with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n rightarrow m)'], []), ', we\nget for two different energies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('n'), TexCmd('neq'), ' E_', BraceGroup('m')], []), ' the orthogonality relation\nbetween their bound state wave functions\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& u_', BraceGroup('n'), "' (r_", BraceGroup('c'), ') u_', BraceGroup('m'), ' ', '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ') - u_', BraceGroup('n'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ') u_', BraceGroup('m'), "' (r_", BraceGroup('c'), ') ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  ', '&&= 2\n  ', TexCmd('mu'), '(E_', BraceGroup('n'), '-E_', BraceGroup('m'), ')', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('r_', BraceGroup('c')), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' u_', BraceGroup('n'), '(r) u_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r) ', '\\,', ' d r.\n'], []), '\n', '\nNote that ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' usually'), ' the regularity condition at the origin, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('n'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')=0'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c'), TexCmd('to'), '0'], []), ', is imposed.  Whence orthogonality of wave \nfunctions with different energies holds.  However, this is not the only \nsolution to the orthogonality requirement. Instead the \ncommon boundary condition, we may as well take\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('m'), "'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('n'), "'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('n'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), ',\n'], []), '\nfor any two states, meaning that the logarithmic derivative at short distances \nbecomes state independent. In particular, choosing the ground state as a \nreference state we get the condition\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('0'), "'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('n'), "'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup('u_', BraceGroup('n'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:bc')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nHow can this logarithmic derivative be determined? If we know the\nenergy of the ground state and the potential we may integrate from the\nlong distance region inward to deduce ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('0'), "'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')/u_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')'], []), '.\nOnce this number is known, we may use Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:bc')]), ') to integrate\nout the excited state and the corresponding bound state energy can be\nfixed by requiring the wave function to vanish at large\ndistances. Thus, such a procedure allows to treat the ground state\nenergy, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ', as an independent variable from the potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(r)'], []), '\nand still deduce wave functions and the excited spectrum.  There is of\ncourse the question on how to interpret the short distance cut-off,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), '. In principle one may look for stability at scales below the\nrelevant sizes.  Actually, by varying the cut-off in this region this\nis a way of assessing theoretical uncertainties~', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('In a model\nwhere phenomenological form factors are implemented ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ad hoc'), ', just\nto prevent singularities, the assessment of theoretical errors could\nbe done by choosing ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' all possible'), ' regularization functions,\nunless the form factor is known from first principles.')]), '. However,\nthere are situations where the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c'), TexCmd('to'), '0'], []), ' is rather smooth and\ninduces moderate changes in observables.\n\nA good feature of the present approach is that since wave functions are matched\nat short distances the resulting energies are largely independent on the short\ndistance behaviour of the potential~', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('The previous approach is well\ndocumented in the mathematical literature as the theory of self-adjoint\nextensions of hermitian operators. This endows the Hilbert space with a\ncommon domain of functions where the solutions of the Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation\nspan a complete set. The generation of a new scale independently on the\npotential resembles the well known phenomenon of dimensional transmutation.')]), '.\n\nThe previous discussion has been conducted for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-waves and regular\npotentials, i.e. fulfilling ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('r ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), ' r^2 |V(r)| <\n', TexCmd('infty')], []), '. Higher partial waves cannot be renormalized in this fashion\nas short distances are dominated by the centrifugal barrier. This also\nhas the benefit of diminishing the dependence on the short distance\npotential since the short distance behaviour of the wave function,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u(r) ', TexCmd('sim'), ' r^', BraceGroup('l+1')], []), ', is not controlled by the potential.\n\nThe case of singular potentials has also been discussed at length (see\ne.g. Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('RuizArriola:2007wm,PavonValderrama:2005wv,Arriola:2009wi')]), '\nregarding nuclear or atomic systems). The relation to momentum space\nrenormalization and the corresponding Lagrangian counterterms is discussed in\nRef.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Entem:2007jg')]), '. The irrelevance of form factors is analyzed in\nRef.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Arriola:2009wi,Cordon:2009pj')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Analysis of the linear potential')]), '\n', '\nIn order to provide a clear picture of the procedure to be carried out\nin the present work, we discuss the issue within the framework of the\nsimplified model where the OGE piece is neglected. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-wave\ncharmonium states we have the simplified problem\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('m_c')]), ' u_', BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('c')])), "''(r)+", TexCmd('sigma'), ' r  ', '\\,', ' u_', BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('c')])), '(r) &=& E ', '\\,', ' \nu_', BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('c')])), ' ', '(r). \n'], []), '\nAs it is well known, the general solution in the inner region is a\nlinear combination of regular and irregular Airy functions\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu_', BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('c')])), '(r)=c_', BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ai'), '(z)+c_', BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Bi'), '(z),\n'], []), '\nwhere the dimensionless variable \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nz=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('c'), '(-M+2m_', BraceGroup('c'), '+r ', TexCmd('sigma'), ')'), BraceGroup('(m_', BraceGroup('c'), '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')^', BraceGroup('2/3'))]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:z_def')]), '\n'], []), '\nhas been introduced. At large values of the argument one has\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['(z) &=&  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('3')]), 'z^', BraceGroup('3/2'))), BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), ' z^', BraceGroup('1/4')), BracketGroup(' 1 + \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(z^', BraceGroup('-3/2'), ') ')]), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Bi')]), '(z) &=&  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('3')]), ' z^', BraceGroup('3/2'))), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), ' z^', BraceGroup('1/4')), BracketGroup(' 1 + \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(z^', BraceGroup('-3/2'), ') ')]), ', \n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ai')]), '\nso that for bound states and assuming no opening of meson decay channels we may \ndiscard the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Bi'), '(z)'], []), ' function. The standard approach consists of \nrequiring the regularity condition at the origin.\n\nIndeed, the regular solution at the origin requires finding the zeros of the Airy \nfunction, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ai'), ' ', '(z_n)=0'], []), ', yielding the quantization formula\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nz_', BraceGroup('n'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('c'), '(-M_', BraceGroup('n'), '+2 m_', BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup('(m_', BraceGroup('c'), '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')^', BraceGroup('2/3'))]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z_', BraceGroup('0'), '=-2.33811,z_', BraceGroup('1'), '=-4.08795,z_', BraceGroup('2'), '=-5.52056,z_', BraceGroup('3'), '=-6.78671,\nz_', BraceGroup('4'), '=-7.94413,', TexCmd('dots')], []), ' are the corresponding lowest zeros.  Note that\nin this particular case the string tension and the quark mass\ndetermine the binding energy completely.\n\nAn alternative procedure might be as follows. Since we want to fit the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' mass and we are confident that the long distance\ndynamics is given by the linear potential~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bali:2000gf')]), ', we are\nquite certain that at long distances the wave function is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu_', BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('c')])), '(r)=c_', BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ai'), '(z),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:asympt')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('J/', TexCmd('psi'))], []), ' is taken as an ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' input'), '. Of course, for a\ngeneric value of the string tension the wave function will fail to\nvanish at the origin (see Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:wave-functions')]), '). This may be\nseen as a drawback but the gain is in the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' prediction'), ' of the\nexcited spectrum. This is done by matching logarithmic derivatives at\nthe origin or at a short distance cut-off, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:bc')]), '), yielding\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ai'), "'(z_", BraceGroup('0'), ')'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ai'), '(z_', BraceGroup('0'), ')')]), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ai'), "'(z_", BraceGroup('n'), ')'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' \nAi'), '(z_', BraceGroup('n'), ')')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z_', BraceGroup('n')], []), ' is given by \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nz_', BraceGroup('n'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('c'), '(-M_', BraceGroup('n'), '+2m_', BraceGroup('c'), '+', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup('(m_', BraceGroup('c'), TexCmd('sigma'), ')^', BraceGroup('2/3'))]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThis condition guarantees the orthogonality of states and provides\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('n')], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' for any value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), '. Note that by definition\nthe short distance behaviour of the wave functions is very similar, so\nthat even though we may not know accurately the potential at short\ndistances there is an increasingly large cancellation. The cut-off\ndependence of the states is depicted in\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:cut-off')]), '~', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('The cut-off dependence can be\nunderstood on purely analytical grounds as carried out in\nAppendix~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:errors')]), ' for a wide class of potentials.')]), '. As we see,\nchanging the scale provides a mild dependence featuring the advertised\nshort distance insensitivity.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=wf_lineal_color.eps,height=6.5cm,width=6cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Wave functions for the different states. The normalization is\n  such that at the matching point, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), ', the\n  functions and derivatives of the different states coincide.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:wave-functions')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=energy_vs_rc_color.eps,height=6.5cm,width=6cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Dependence of the excited charmonium states on the short distance \ncut-off.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:cut-off')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Inclusion of One-Gluon Exchange')]), '\n', '\nIn heavy quark systems the OGE potential is considered to be a very\nimportant ingredient to provide some additional short range\ncorrections. Here we will show that as far as binding is concerned\nthis OGE contribution becomes almost irrelevant. Contrary to what one\nmight naively think this is actually good news.  Indeed, as we\nmentioned in the introduction the short distance part of the potential\nis not well known even at the OGE level. If we write the OGE potential\nin the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(r)=-4', TexCmd('alpha'), '_s(', TexCmd('mu'), ')/3r'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('MS')])], []), '\nrenormalization scale, it is not obvious what scale should one use\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' a priori'), '. Lattice calculations display such a behaviour at\nshort distances (see the recent update where running is actually\nobserved~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Donnellan:2010mx')]), '). There have been attempts to improve\non this by imposing renormalization group invariance of the\npotential. Unfortunately such a procedure breaks down due to the\nappearance of renormalons (see e.g. Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Beneke:1998ui')]), ' and\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Laschka:2011zr')]), ') which spoil a convergence pattern. In addition,\nthere is also the problem on how far should this OGE force be\nextended, since it only applies to very short distances. However, one\nexpects that as compared to the linear potential the long range effect\nis not crucial.\n\nThe region where OGE becomes comparable with the linear potential is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r', TexCmd('sim'), '\nb=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_s/', TexCmd('sigma'))]), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.2-0.3 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), ' where the total potential is\nabout ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(r) ', TexCmd('sim'), ' -180 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV')], []), '. At much larger distances we may neglect the\nOGE component so that we may take the asymptotic behaviour of\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:asympt')]), '). The resulting wave functions without and with OGE are\ndepicted in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:wave-functions-OGE')]), '. Similarly to the case without OGE\nthe procedure is as follows. We start from the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' given'), ' ground state energy\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_0= M_', BraceGroup('J/', TexCmd('psi'))], []), ' integrating inward down to the short distance cut-off radius,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), ', the full Cornell potential, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:pot-cornell')]), '). To facilitate the\ncomparison we take the same asymptotic wave function for both cases,\nwithout or with OGE. As can be seen, the OGE attraction provides a larger\nprobability in the inner region below the scale where OGE starts being\nnegligible. Our numerical calculations indicate that this long distance scale is\nabout ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.5 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), '. From the ground state we can construct the remaining\nexcited states by matching logarithmic derivatives at the short distance\ncut-off, as indicated above.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=wf_lineal_gluon_color_2.eps,height=6.5cm,width=6cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Charmonium wave functions for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(1S)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(2S)'], []), '\nstates without (solid line) and with (dashed line) One Gluon Exchange potential. \n')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:wave-functions-OGE')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\nThe short distance cut-off dependence of the excited charmonium states for\nseveral values of the strong coupling constant is similar in all cases to the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '=0'], []), ' situation shown in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:cut-off')]), '. While at large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), '\nthe calculation is dominated by the linear potential, wave functions at short\ndistances are very much alike due to the common boundary condition. Thus, the\ndifference in energy due to OGE comes from the energy dependence of the wave\nfunction below the non-perturbative scale. In Table~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:masses-toy')]), ',\nfor the case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ', we show  numerical values of the excited states\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '=0.0,', '\\,', '0.1,', '\\,', '0.2', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '0.3'], []), '. The mass shift ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' M_n =\nM_n-M_0'], []), ' is shown in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:mass-shift-OGE')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c = 0.06 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), '\nand as we can see the OGE effects are rather moderate.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=deltamass_vs_als_color.eps,height=6.5cm,width=7cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Mass shift (in MeV) as a function of the strong coupling\n  constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s'], []), ' when the short distance cut-off is removed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c\n  ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ' for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(2S)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(3S)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(4S)'], []), ' relative to the\n  ground ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(1S)'], []), ' state.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:mass-shift-OGE')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '=0.0'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '=0.1'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '=0.2'], []), ' ', '& &\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '=0.3'], []), ' ', '[', '2ex', ']', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3615'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3630'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3638'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3640'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4039'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4060'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4070'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4073'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4414'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4439'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4449'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4452'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4756'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4783'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4795'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4798'], []), ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ccccccccc')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:masses-toy')]), ' Masses in MeV of S-wave charmonium states\nfor several values of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), ' coupling constant and keeping always the\nground state mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('0'), '=3096.916', '\\,', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('MeV')])], []), '.')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t!')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Coupled channel solutions: Mixing S and D states')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:toy-coupled')]), '\n', '\nIn this section we include the spin dependent potential contributions\ncoming from the OGE interaction to the simple Cornell potential discussed in\nSection~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:toy')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Potential')]), '\n', '\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')]), 'q'], []), ' interaction can be written as \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nV (', TexCmd('vec'), ' r)  = ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r + V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' OGE'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('vec'), ' r ),\n'], []), '\nwhere now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' OGE'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), ')'], []), ' contains central, the coulomb interaction, and\nnon-central, tensor and spin-orbit, contributions \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV_', BraceGroup('OGE'), '^', BraceGroup('C'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), ') &=&-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('3')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r')]), ',  \nV_', BraceGroup('OGE'), '^', BraceGroup('T'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), ') &=& ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('3')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('m^2')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^3')]), ' S_', BraceGroup('12'), ', \nV_', BraceGroup('OGE'), '^', BraceGroup('SO'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), ') &=& ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('m^2')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('3'))]), '  ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('L')]), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('S')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ,  \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:OGE_unreg')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), ' is the strong coupling constant, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' is the equal\nquark and antiquark mass,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('12'), '=3', '\\,', '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '_', BraceGroup('1'), TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('r')]), ')(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '_', BraceGroup('2'), '\n', TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('r')]), ' ', ')-', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '_', BraceGroup('2')], []), ' is the quark\ntensor operator, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('S')]), ' '], []), ' the total spin operator and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('L')]), ' '], []), ' is\nthe relative orbital angular momentum operator.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The coupled S-D equations')]), '\n', '\nOur previous discussion of renormalization was undertaken without\ntaking into account the role played by the tensor and spin-orbit\nforces. In the case of charmonium, these states are a combination of S\nand D-wave components due to the tensor force contribution. As we will\nsee below, this tensor force is small enough to have almost pure S and\nD orbital state components. The interesting aspect of our discussion\nbelow is that using just one renormalization condition we can predict\nall S and D-wave mesons, i.e. we reduce the number of renormalization\nconditions.  \n\nThe radial Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('3'), '\\!', 'S_', BraceGroup('1'), '-', '\\,', '^', BraceGroup('3'), '\\!', 'D_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' coupled\nchannel reads \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', "& -u''(r)+U_", BraceGroup('S'), '(r)u(r)+U_', BraceGroup('SD'), '(r)w(r)= ', TexCmd('kappa'), "^2 u(r), \n& -w''(r)+U_", BraceGroup('SD'), '(r)u(r)+', '[', 'U_', BraceGroup('D'), '(r)+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('6'), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('2'))]), ']', 'w(r)= ', TexCmd('kappa'), '^2 w(r),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ref:CE')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), '^2 =m_c (M- 2 m_c)'], []), '. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U_', BraceGroup('S')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U_', BraceGroup('D')], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U_', BraceGroup('SD')], []), ' are the different contributions of the reduced potential,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U(r)=2', TexCmd('mu'), ' V(r)'], []), ', where the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('3'), '\\!', 'S_', BraceGroup('1'), '-', '\\,', '^', BraceGroup('3'), '\\!', 'D_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' coupled\nchannel potential is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '&\nV_', BraceGroup('S'), '(r)=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('3r')]), '+', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r, \n&\nV_', BraceGroup('D'), '(r)=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('3r')]), '+', TexCmd('sigma'), '\nr-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('20'), BraceGroup('3')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('c'), '^', BraceGroup('2'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('3'))]), ', \n&\nV_', BraceGroup('SD'), '(r)=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')])), BraceGroup('3')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')), BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('c'), '^', BraceGroup('2'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('3'))]), ',\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nin which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), ' is the strong coupling constant, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is the string\ntension and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ' is the quark mass. Obviously, in order to describe a bound\nstate we seek for normalizable solutions\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('infty', [BracketGroup(' u(r)^2+w(r)^2')]), '=1, \n'], []), '\nwhich impose conditions on the wave functions both at infinity as well as\nat the origin.\n\nThe set of equations~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:CE')]), ') must be accompanied by asymptotic conditions\nat infinity. As in previous sections, we have a linear potential at large\ndistances for both channels and therefore the wave function is a linear\ncombination of regular and irregular Airy functions. Once we have discard the\nirregular function at long  distances, Bi(z), the wave functions at\ninfinity have the following behaviour\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu(r) &arrow& A_', BraceGroup('S'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('Ai')]), '(z), ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nw(r) &arrow& A_', BraceGroup('D'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('Ai')]), '(z),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ref:ABC')]), '\n'], []), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' defined in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:z_def')]), ') and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('S')], []), ' is the normalization\nfactor and the asymptotic D/S ratio parameter is defined by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '=A_', BraceGroup('D'), '/A_', BraceGroup('S')], []), '.  Ideally, one would integrate the Schr', '\\"', 'odinger\nequation taking its solutions at infinity, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:ABC')]), '), which\ndepend on the bound energy and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), '. The singular structure of the\nproblem at short distances requires a specific analysis of the coupled\nequations as it has been done extensively\nelsewhere~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Cordon:2009pj')]), ' and we adapt in \nAppendix~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:shortdistances')]), ' for our particular case. The result\namounts to integrate from infinity for the physical value of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('J/', TexCmd('psi'))], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), '. Generally, the solutions diverge strongly at\nthe origin, so that the normalization of the state is\nprecluded. However, there is a particular value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' which\nguarantees that the wave function becomes normalizable.  Then, if one\nimposes the regularity condition at the origin one will determine\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' and therefore the wave function of the bound state. In\npractice, however, the converging solution is rather elusive since\nintegrated-in solutions quickly run into diverging solution due to the\nround-off errors and dominate over the converging solution.\n\nAccording to Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Cordon:2009pj')]), ' one may proceed as follows.\nOne can impose different auxiliary short distance boundary conditions\ncorresponding to a choice of regular solutions at the origin\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')=0 & ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('(BC1)')]), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), " \nu'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')=0 & ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('(BC2)')]), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nw(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')=0 & ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('(BC3)')]), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), " \nw'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')=0 & ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('(BC4)')]), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nu(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), 'w(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')=0 & ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('(BC5)')]), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), " \nu'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), "w'(r_", BraceGroup('c'), ')=0 & ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('(BC6)')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ref:BC')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nAll these boundary conditions must predict the same value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' at\nsome value of the cut-off radius, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ', the precise convergence\nvalue corresponds to the particular choice.  As in other\nRefs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PavonValderrama:2005gu')]), ' we find convergence for the\nboundary conditions BC5 and BC6 for larger cut-off radii, which\nimproves the numerical results.\n\nTo calculate the D/S asymptotic ratio, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ', it is convenient to use\nthe superposition principle of boundary\nconditions~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PavonValderrama:2005gu')]), ' to write\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '& u(r)=u_', BraceGroup('S'), '(r)+', TexCmd('eta'), ' u_', BraceGroup('D'), '(r), \n& w(r)=w_', BraceGroup('S'), '(r)+', TexCmd('eta'), ' w_', BraceGroup('D'), '(r), \n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(u_', BraceGroup('S'), ',w_', BraceGroup('S'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(u_', BraceGroup('D'), ',w_', BraceGroup('D'), ')'], []), ' correspond to the boundary\nconditions at infinity, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:ABC')]), ') with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('S'), '=1'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('D'), '=0'], []), ' and with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('S'), '=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('D'), '=1'], []), ', respectively. Through that\ndecomposition the boundary conditions, BC1-BC6, can be rewritten as\nalgebraic expressions for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), '. For instance, if we use the BC6\nboundary condition we get \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('eta'), '=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("u'_", BraceGroup('S'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', "w'_", BraceGroup('S'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup("u'_", BraceGroup('D'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', "w'_", BraceGroup('D\n'), ' ', '(r_ ', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), '.\n'], []), '\nOnce ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' has been calculated, the wave function of the bound state\nis completely determined by the normalization factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('S')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu(r) &=& A_', BraceGroup('S'), '(u_', BraceGroup('S'), '+', TexCmd('eta'), '\\,', 'u_', BraceGroup('D'), '), ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \nw(r) &=& A_', BraceGroup('S'), '(w_', BraceGroup('S'), '+', TexCmd('eta'), '\\,', 'w_', BraceGroup('D'), '),\n'], []), '\nin which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('S')], []), ' is obtained normalizing the wave function to one\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nA_', BraceGroup('S'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), '[', '(u_', BraceGroup('S'), '+', TexCmd('eta'), '\\,', 'u_', BraceGroup('D'), ')^', BraceGroup('2'), '+(w_', BraceGroup('S'), '+', TexCmd('eta'), '\\,', 'w_', BraceGroup('D'), ')^', BraceGroup('2'), ']', 'dr=1.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe above procedure can be undertaken for the ground state of the\nsystem if its energy is known. Now, if we want to calculate the\nexcited states of the system we must impose the orthogonality\ncondition between wave functions of states with different energy\ntogether with the regularity condition at the origin.\n\nFor a regular potential the orthogonality between wave functions of\nstates with different energy is a property of the solutions of the\nSchr', '\\"', 'odinger equation and it always holds. However, if the potential\ncontains some attractive singular contribution we have to impose\nexplicitly the orthogonality between wave functions.\n\nThus, given the ground state and one excited state, the orthogonality\ncondition can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), 'dr ', '[', 'u_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r)u_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r)+w_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r)w_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r)', ']', '=0,\n'], []), '\nwhere it is useful to rewrite the above expression through a Lagrange identity\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('Big|_', [BraceGroup('0')]), '^', BraceGroup('\n', TexCmd('infty')), '=0.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ref:OC')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup("u'_", BraceGroup('0'), 'u_', BraceGroup('m'), '-u_', BraceGroup('0'), "u'_", BraceGroup('m'), "+w'_", BraceGroup('0'), 'w_', BraceGroup('m'), '-w_', BraceGroup('0'), "w'_", BraceGroup('m'))]), '\nNote that any individual term in the integrand is actually divergent,\nbecause of the dominance of the singular solutions at the origin.  At\nvery short distances, the orthogonality between wave functions and the\nregularity condition of them have been imposed at a certain cut-off\nradius, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), '. Of course, we always check that the numerical\ncalculation is stable against suitable changes of the short distance\ncut-off so that the range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.01 - 0.3 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), ' is\nsufficient. In that situation, the orthogonality condition,\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:OC')]), '), can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', "&u'_", BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')u_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ")+w'_", BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')w_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')  \n&\n=u_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ")u'_", BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')+w_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ")w'_", BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), '),\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nand combining this expression with the corresponding one of the\nboundary conditions, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:BC')]), '), we obtain in the case of the\nboundary condition BC6 \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("w'_", BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', 'u_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')+w_', BraceGroup('m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("w'_", BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup('\n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', 'u_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')+w_', BraceGroup('0'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), '.\n'], []), '\nand similarly for all other auxiliary boundary conditions.  Obviously\nin this case the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D/S'], []), ' mixing of the excited state is determined from\nthe requirement of regularity at the origin,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('eta'), '_m=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("u'_", BraceGroup('S,m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', "w'_", BraceGroup('S,m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')'), BraceGroup("u'_", BraceGroup('D,m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2\n')]), '\\,', "w'_", BraceGroup('D,m'), '(r_', BraceGroup('c'), ')')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe will also compute other observables. The results are presented in\nTable~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:toy-coupled')]), '. In the numerical integration\na certain maximum radious has to be selected to imposed the asymptotic\nboundary conditions. Due to the long range coulomb force the values\nof the asymptotic parameters are slowly convergent and we quote the\nvalues for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '=20', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), '.\nThe corresponding wave functions can be\nlooked up in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:reswfTM')]), '.\n\nAs we see the description of the spectrum is not particularly\naccurate, but one should take into account that we are only providing\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' mass as an input, as well as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', for which we take generally accepted values. The present\nanalysis suggests that exploiting these ideas one may find a reduction\nof parameters in quark models. As we will see in later Sections,\nrather than being a mathematical curiosity, these correlations which\nare unveiled by the renormalization approach actually are embodied in\nquark models in a much less transparent way. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('table*', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\nState & M (MeV) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('s')], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(fm^', BraceGroup('-1/2'), ')'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), '.', '\\!', '\\!', '\nr^', BraceGroup('2'), '\\!', '\\!', ' .', TexCmd('rangle'), '^', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(fm)'], []), ' ', '& & \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_', BraceGroup('D')], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['( percent )'], []), ' ', '[', '2ex', ']', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3096.916^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger'))], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-0.0037'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4.01'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.637'], []), ' ', '& & \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.52'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(1D)'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3577.7'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-19,71'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.084'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.93'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['99.91'], []), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(2S)'], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.24'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(2D)'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3995.9'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-17.73'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.104'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.29'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['99.84'], []), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(3S)'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4065.1'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+0.028'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2.66'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.40'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.15'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(3D)'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4368.7'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-15.70'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.12'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.60'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['99.75'], []), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(4S)'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4443.1'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+0.039'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2.44'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.70'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.12'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(4D)'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4710.8'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-14.09'], []), ' ', '& ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4787.4'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+0.048'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2.29'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.98'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.14'], []), ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('lccccccr')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:toy-coupled')]), ' Different observables computed through the\ncoupled toy model and applied to charmonium spectrum.')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t!')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf1S_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf2S_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf3S_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf4S_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), ' \n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf1D_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf2D_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf3D_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=dib_wf4D_color.eps,height=4cm,width=4cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:reswfTM')]), ' S and D-wave functions of the different states of\ncharmonium calculated through the coupled toy model.')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Charmonium with form factors')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:oldmodel')]), '\n', '\nIn the previous sections we have presented how one may incorporate a\ndesirable short distance insensitivity into several simplified models\nfor quarkonium. In this section we give a brief description of the\nspecific charmonium model which fits a wider and successful\nphenomenology (see Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Vijande:2005eu')]), ' for further details)\npaying special attention to the form factors introduced to regulate\nthe unpleasent short distance singularities.  Our intention is to\nre-analyse the model by trading these form factors into a less model\ndependent set of renormalization conditions. While the model furnishes\nunequal quark species we will restrict for illustration purposes to\nthe case of charmonium. \n\n\n\nThe corresponding potentials for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')]), 'q'], []), ' system stem from the\nnon-relativistic reduction of OGE and the confinement component. We\nseparate the central, tensor and spin-orbit pieces, as follows: \n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('0'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ')=', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('r')]), '_', BraceGroup('0'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('nn')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))])], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('g'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ')=', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('r')]), '_', BraceGroup('g'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('nn')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))])], []), ' are short distance regulators\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' stand for the reduced quark mass. The contact term of the\ncentral potential of  one gluon exchange is regularized in a suitable way by\nreplacing the Dirac delta function by a Yukawa form  \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('vec'), ' r ) ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('pi'), ' r_0^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^', BraceGroup('-r/r_0')), BraceGroup('r')]), '.\n'], []), '\nIn table~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:parameters')]), ' we show\nthe model parameters constrained by the light quark phenomenology and also\nappear in the potentials operating in the heavy quark sector.\n\n\nRegarding the confinement interaction~', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Our expressions imply\n  the validity of Casimir scaling both for the perturbative (tree\n  level) as well as the non-perturbative (confinement) contributions\n  to the potential. A recent perturbative calculation to three loops\n  displays violations to this Casimir scaling~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Anzai:2010td')]), ',\n  although nothing is implied for the non-perturbative contribution.')]), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' '], []), ' is a global constant adjusted to fit the origin of\nenergies, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ' are model parameters. At short distances\nthis potential presents a linear behavior with an effective confinement strength\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '=-a_', BraceGroup('c'), '\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('c'), '\\,', '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), '^', BraceGroup('c'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), '^', BraceGroup('c'), '_', BraceGroup('2'), ')'], []), '\nwhile it becomes constant at large distances. This type of potential shows a\nthreshold defined by\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nV_', BraceGroup('thr'), '=', '\\{', '-a_', BraceGroup('c'), '+ ', TexCmd('Delta'), '\\}', '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), '^', BraceGroup('c'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), '^', BraceGroup('c'), '_', BraceGroup('2'), ').\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:thres-conf')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n Quark mass & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ' ', '(MeV) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1763'], []), ' \n ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n Confinement & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ' ', '(MeV) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['507.4'], []), ' \n\t       ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('fm')]), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.576'], []), ' \n\t       ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' ', '(MeV) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['184.432'], []), ' \n\t       ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('s')], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.81'], []), ' \n ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n OGE & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2.118'], []), ' \n     ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('fm')]), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.113'], []), ' \n     ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' ', '(MeV) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['36.976'], []), ' \n     ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('r')]), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' ', '(fm) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.181'], []), ' \n     ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('r')]), '_', BraceGroup('g')], []), ' ', '(fm) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.259'], []), ' \n ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('c|cc')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:parameters')]), ' Quark model parameters.')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t!')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nBy construction, no ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')]), 'q'], []), ' bound states can be found for energies\nhigher than this threshold. Actually, the potential suffers a transition from a\ncolor string configuration between two static color sources into a pair of\nstatic mesons due to the breaking of the color flux-tube and the most\nfavoured subsequent decay into hadrons. In a more general set up, a dynamical\ncoupling to the formed meson pair should be included. \n\nThe wide energy range covered by a consistent description of light, strange and\nheavy mesons requires an effective scale-dependent strong coupling constant that\ncannot be obtained from the usual one-loop expression of the running coupling\nconstant which diverges at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q^', BraceGroup('2'), '=', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('QCD'), '^', BraceGroup('2')], []), '. Following previous\nwork~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Vijande:2005eu')]), ', we use a frozen coupling constant such as \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ')=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('0')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ln'), '( \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '+', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup('2'))]), ' ', ')')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is the reduced mass of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')]), 'q'], []), ' pair and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' are parameters of the model determined by a global\nfit to the hyperfine splitting from the light to the heavy quark sector. In our\ncase this yields a value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s=0.288'], []), '. \n\nWe note that the regulators in the tensor and spin-orbit terms of the one gluon\nexchange potential as well as the smeared ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-function of the central\ncomponent are introduced just because tensor and spin-orbit terms become\nsingular at short distances. As a consequence the collapse of the system which\nwould occur for the pure unregularized ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-function is prevented. The\nprevious model describes successfully the meson\nspectroscopy~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Vijande:2005eu')]), ' and provides a good agreement with the\nexperimental data of different physical observables as the strong and radiative\ndecays of charmonium performed in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Segovia:2008zz')]), '.\n\nAs we have discussed above it is interesting to inquire the real need\nof form factors which, while providing an acceptable phenomenology,\nare introduced ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ad hoc'), ' to avoid the short distance\ndivergences. Indeed, if the short distance regulators are removed,\ni.e. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_0,r_g ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ', the expressions of our potentials become\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:OGE_unreg')]), ') for the OGE piece and the confinement part\nremains the same as in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:Conf_V')]), ') as this latter\ncontribution does not depend on regulators. We will use these\nexpressions for the potentials in the renormalization scheme. Note\nthat we have also discarded the Dirac delta functions. While this may\nseem weird, these are distributions which are not seen in the compact\nsupport test functions implicitly implied by the boundary\ncondition regularization. This also applies to any derivatives of the\nDirac delta function. This result was\nsuggested~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PavonValderrama:2005wv')]), ' and explicitly checked by\nusing a momentum space regularization with so-called\ncounterterms~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Entem:2007jg')]), '.\n\nMoreover, the form factors are naturally adjusted in order to reproduce some\nwell established physical observables, such as the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' mass and its\nleptonic width. What will be shown below is that one can actually treat \nthese observables as suitable renormalization conditions, without any specific\nneed of form factor regulators. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Renormalized charmonium model')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:renormodel')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Masses (uncoupled case)')]), '\n', '\nIn this section we carry out the renormalization, presented previously\nalong the lines described in detail in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:toy')]), ', for the\nunregularized model potential.  While the tensor force induces a\nmixing between S and D-waves we will in a first step neglect such a\nmixing. This implies that both ground states are completely unrelated\nand renormalization is pusued independently.  As expected, the\ncharmonium masses in this scheme depend on the short distance cut-off,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), '.  Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:cut-off-masses')]), ' shows this dependence for the\nfirst radial excitations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), '-wave charmonium states. One\ncan see that at some value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ' the masses do not depend on the\nshort distance cut-off.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsi2Svsrc.eps,height=6.5cm,width=7cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsi2Dvsrc.eps,height=6.5cm,width=7cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Dependence of the mass (in MeV) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^3S_1'], []), ' ', '(upper panel) and\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^3D_1'], []), ' ', '(lower panel) excited charmonium states on the short\n  distance cut-off, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), ' ', '(in fm).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:cut-off-masses')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\nIn Table~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:masses')]), ' the masses predicted by renormalized\ncharmonium model and the standard constituent quark model (with form\nfactors) are displayed. We find a perfect agreement between both\nschemes. This provides confidence on the way the original model took\ninto account the unknown short distance dynamics, on the one hand, and\nalso on the irrelevance of those form factors for excited states as\nlong as the ground state mass is fixed.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\nState & n & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('RSC')], []), ' ', '(MeV) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('CQM')], []), ' ', '(MeV) & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('exp')], []), ' ', '(MeV)\n& Ref. \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('3'), 'S_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' \t', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3096^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger'))], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3096'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3096.916', TexCmd('pm'), '0.011'], []), ' ', '&\n', TexCmd('cite', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3686.093', TexCmd('pm'), '0.034'], []), ' ', '&\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Nakamura:2010zzi')]), ' \n\t\t', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4097'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4097'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4039.6', TexCmd('pm'), '4.3'], []), ' ', '&\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Nakamura:2010zzi')]), ' \n\t\t', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4389'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4389'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4361', TexCmd('pm'), '9', TexCmd('pm'), '9'], []), '\n', '& ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PhysRevLett.99.142002')]), ' \n\t\t', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['5'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4614'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4614'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4634^', BraceGroup('+8+5'), '_', BraceGroup('-7-8')], []), ' ', '&\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PhysRevLett.101.172001')]), ' ', '[', '2ex', ']', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('3'), 'D_', BraceGroup('1')], []), '\t', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3796^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger'))], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3796'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3772.92', TexCmd('pm'), '0.35'], []), ' ', '&\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Nakamura:2010zzi')]), '  \n\t\t', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4153'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4153'], []), ' ', '& '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4641'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4641'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4664', TexCmd('pm'), '11',
