TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:masses')]), ' Predicted charmonium masses (in MeV) within the\nrenormalization scheme (RSC) and potential model with form factors (CQM).')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t!')]), '\n', '\nAs it becomes clear from the expressions of the potential, the perturbative and\nnon-perturbative contributions dominate at short and large distances\nrespectively. Therefore, we want to study now the dependence of the mass with\nrespect to two important model parameters, the strong coupling constant,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), ', and our effective string tension of the confinement potential,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', featuring those short and long distance effects.\n\nThe dependence on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s'], []), ' while fixing the threshold for confinement, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nthr')], []), ' in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:thres-conf')]), '), can be seen in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:masses-vs-als')]), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), '-wave states. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-wave states the mass changes about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['15 ', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nMeV')], []), ' meaning a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.4 percent '], []), ' in the total mass and we see a flattening\nbehaviour along the considered range of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), '. We find a similar trend\nfor the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), '-wave states, although in this case the change in mass is larger than\nin the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-wave states, the picture shows again a rather clear plateau.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsiSvsals.eps,height=6.5cm,width=8cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsiDvsals.eps,height=6.5cm,width=8cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Mass (in MeV) dependence on the strong coupling constant of excited\ncharmonium states.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:masses-vs-als')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\nWe now turn to the mass dependence on the effective string tension of\nour confinement potential. Again and for clarity of presentation we\nfix the threshold for confinement, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' thr')], []), ' in\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:thres-conf')]), ').  Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:masses-vs-sigma')]), ' shows such\na dependence for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), '-wave states. The range for the\neffective string tension is in percentage level equal than the range\nof the strong coupling constant and we can see that the masses change\non the hundreds of MeV. We can conclude that at least the masses of\nexcited states are dominated by the confinement potential as long as\nthe ground state mass is kept to its physical value. In\nAppendix~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:fitting')]), ' we further analyze the sensitivity of the\nrenormalized model parameters.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsiSvssigma.eps,height=6.5cm,width=8cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsiDvssigma.eps,height=6.5cm,width=8cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Dependence of the mass (in MeV) excited charmonium states on the\neffective string tension of our confinement potential, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '=-a_', BraceGroup('c'), '\\,', TexCmd('mu'), ' \n', '_', BraceGroup('c'), '\\,', '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), '^', BraceGroup('c'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), '^', BraceGroup('c'), '_', BraceGroup('j'), ')'], []), ' ', '(in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV'), '^', BraceGroup('2')], []), ').')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:masses-vs-sigma')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Leptonic widths')]), '\n', '\nWe now focus on the leptonic widths. This will illustrate the interesting\nsubject of the wave function renormalization. A complete calculation of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('(vector meson)')]), 'arrow e^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-')], []), ' widths involves radiative and\nrelativistic contributions. In the heavy quark limit one can write the leptonic\ndecay for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-wave states\nas~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Barbieri:1975eu')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(n^', BraceGroup('3'), 'S_', BraceGroup('1'), ' arrow\ne^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-'), ')=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), 'e^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('c'), '|R_', BraceGroup('nS'), '(0)|^2'), BraceGroup('M^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('n'))]), '(1-\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('alpha'), '_s'), BraceGroup('3', TexCmd('pi'))]), '),\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('c'), '=2/3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('n')], []), ' is the mass of the charmonium state. Decay widths \ndepend on the value of the wave function at short distances. Of course while \nthe decay may be triggered by a short distance operator, we may predict decay \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ratios'), ' as \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(n^', BraceGroup('3'), 'S_', BraceGroup('1'), 'arrow \ne^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(1^', BraceGroup('3'), 'S_', BraceGroup('1'), 'arrow e^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-'), ')')]), '= \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|R_', BraceGroup('nS'), '(0)|^2'), BraceGroup('|R_', BraceGroup('1S'), '(0)|^2')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('M^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('1')), BraceGroup('M^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('n'))]), '.\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' R')]), '\nThis corresponds in practice to implement a common wave function renormalization\nwhich factors out in the ratio. \n\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:lepwidth-vs-als')]), '(a) shows the dependence of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' R')], []), ' with\nrespect to the short distance cut-off for the first radial excitation of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-wave states. At some range of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), ', the ratio does not depend on its\nvalue.  Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:lepwidth-vs-als')]), '(b) shows the dependence of the ratio for\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-wave states along the range of strong coupling constant. This range is\nthe same as in the case of studying masses. We find a stronger dependence on the\nstrong coupling constant as expected since the leptonic decay is a short range\nobservable.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsi2Slepwidthvsrc.eps,height=6.5cm,width=8cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=figpsiSlepwidthvsals.eps,height=6.5cm,width=8cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Top picture shows the dependence of the ratio ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' R')], []), ' with respect \nto short distance cut-off, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('c')], []), '. Bottom picture shows the dependence of the\nratio ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' R')], []), ' for the excited S-wave charmonium states on the strong\ncoupling constant, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s')], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:lepwidth-vs-als')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Inclusion of coupled channels')]), '\n', '\nFinally, we take into account the role played by the tensor force which, as\nwe know from previous sections, is the responsible of the mixing between S and\nD-waves in the case of charmonium. The interesting aspect of applying\nrenormalization procedure to S-D coupled case is that using just one\nrenormalization condition, the mass of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ', we can predict all S and\nD-wave mesons.\n\nThe procedure is the same than in Sec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:toy-coupled')]), ' with only\none difference, where our confining interaction is given by\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:Conf_V')]), '), which flattens out at large distances. So in\nthis case  the asymptotic boundary conditions become \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu(r) &arrow& A_', BraceGroup('S'), '\\,', 'e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('kappa'), ' r'), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nw(r) &arrow& A_', BraceGroup('D'), '\\,', '( 1+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'), ' r')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('kappa'), ' r)^2')]), ' ', ')', '\\,', 'e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('kappa'), ' r'), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ref:ABC2')]), '\n'], []), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '= m_', BraceGroup('c'), '(V_', BraceGroup('thr'), '+2m_', BraceGroup('c'), '-M)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup('thr')], []), ' given by\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:thres-conf')]), ').\n\nResults on the mass, the asymptotic D/S ratio parameter and D-wave\nprobability are presented in Table~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:cqm-coupled1')]), '. The\ncomparison between renormalization scheme and constituent quark model\nwith form factors is given in Table~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:cqm-coupled2')]), '. One can\nsee that the agreement is completely satisfactory. Essentially, this\nproves that the form factors only provide the correct mass of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), '. Once this is fixed the rest of the excited states with\neither S- or D- wave character are predicted. This is the main result\nof the present study.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\nState & & M (MeV) & & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_', BraceGroup('D')], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['( percent )'], []), ' ', '[', '2ex', ']', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3095.78^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger'))], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-0.0115'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.146'], []), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(2S)'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3703.19'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+0.0105'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.221'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(1D)'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3795.93'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-12.47'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['99.852'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(3S)'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4097.46'], []), ' ', '& & ', []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+0.0522'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.758'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(3D)'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.11'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4614'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['99.88'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.12'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4614'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4634^', BraceGroup('+8+5'), '_', BraceGroup('-7-8')], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X(4660)'], []), '\t', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['9'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.08'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['98.92'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4640'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.11'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['99.89'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4641'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4664', TexCmd('pm'), '11', TexCmd('pm'), '5'], []), ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('rr|rrc|rrc|c')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:cqm-coupled2')]), ' Comparison of different properties of\ncharmonium between the renormalization scheme and the constituent quark model with form\nfactors, considering coupled channels in both cases.')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t!')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('On the applicability of the renormalization procedure')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:applic')]), '\n', '\nIn most examples shown in this paper, we have always dealt with a\nsituation where it was possible to fix the energy of a bound state, so\nthat there is a mild dependence of excited states on the short\ndistance cut-off. This scaling analysis is carried out in\nAppendix~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:errors')]), " providing an understanding of the features \nfound numerically. \n\nOf course, there is the question when the present renormalization\nprocedure is guaranteed to work, i.e. can we always mock up our\nignorance at short distances by a given renormalization condition? On\nthe other hand it is also important to know if the answer is \naffirmative what does the renormalization tell about the true\nsolution?  \n\nIt is instructive to analyze first the case where renormalization can\nbe carried out at any level of approximation of the ``true''\npotential.  We provide some insight into the renormalization problem\nby analysing in some detail the bosonic string model\n(BSM)~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Alvarez:1981kc,Arvis:1983fp')]), '. Such a model provides an\nalternative approach to the physics of confinement from the point of\nview of large distances (for a review see\ne.g.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lucha:1991vn')]), '). It should be noted that with the constraint\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s = ', TexCmd('pi'), '/16'], []), ', the Cornell potential corresponds to the large\ndistance expansion of the following potential\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV(r)= ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('r^2 - r_0^2')]), ' = ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), ' r_0^2'), BraceGroup('2 r')]), '\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), ' r_0^4'), BraceGroup('8 r^3')]), ' + ', TexCmd('dots'), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:pot-bsm')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), ' r_0^2 = ', TexCmd('pi'), '/6'], []), '. With the standard value for the string\ntension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), ' = 0.420 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV')], []), ' one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_0 ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.3 ', '\\,', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), '. A feature of this potential is that for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r<r_0'], []), ' it becomes\npurely imaginary. Moreover, lattice calculations~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Necco:2001xg')]), '\nyield ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4', TexCmd('alpha'), '_s/3= 0.25(1)'], []), ', extremely close to the BSM choice of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s = ', TexCmd('pi'), '/16'], []), ' when the Cornell potential,\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:pot-cornell')]), '), is taken. It has been\nfound~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Luscher:2002qv')]), ' that the transition from perturbative to\nstring behaviour is evident from the data and takes place at\nsurprisingly small distances~', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('This of course raises the\nquestion on whether the perturbative OGE contribution,', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-4\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '_s(', TexCmd('mu'), ')/3 r'], []), ', should be added on top of the BSM-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/r'], []), ' result or\nit is actually dual to it, in which case a scale of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV')], []), '\nis implied, if one demands ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s(', TexCmd('mu'), ') = ', TexCmd('pi'), ' /16'], []), ' at LO in perturbation theory.')]), '.\n\nThe BSM potential satisfies exact fundamental inequalities for the Wilson\nloop exploiting reflection positivity~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bachas:1985xs,Nussinov:2000kn')]), ', namely\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ["\nV'(r)>0 ", TexCmd('qquad'), " V''(r) ", TexCmd('le'), ' 0.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:concavity')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe latter identity is saturated by the linear potential. This is satisfied \nby  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' any'), ' inverse power series with  negative coefficients, i.e.\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV(r) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r + V_0 + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('n=1'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' c_n /r^n,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:ipower')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_n ', TexCmd('le'), ' 0'], []), '.  However, note that the converse need not\nbe true, namely Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:concavity')]), ') does not necessarily imply\nthat ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' all'), ' coefficients in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:ipower')]), ') are negative. \n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Renormalization of the bosonic string potential')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:bsm')]), '\n', '\n', '\nIn this section we deal with the renormalization of the bosonic-string potential\ngiven by Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:pot-bsm')]), '). Of course, this potential is questionable below\nthe critical radius where it becomes imaginary. On the other hand, if the large\ndistance expansion is truncated to a finite order we have to deal with\nincreasingly singular power divergences. We will illustrate how the\nrenormalization procedure works when the full potential is compared to the\nseries of singular potentials at the origin.\n\nThis example also shows how to treat singular potentials. Indeed, at\nNNLO one encounters a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/r^3'], []), ' short distance divergence. The problem\nwith such a singularity is that the energy becomes unbound from\nbelow. To overcome this situation one can fix, as it was discussed in\nSec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:toy')]), ', the ground state energy and then, using the\northogonality condition, the excited states can be predicted. Of\ncourse, this procedure can also be carried out without a\nsingular potential, but just on the basis that the short distance\nbehaviour of the potential may not be fully reliable.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=potencial_bsm_color.eps,height=5cm,width=5.5cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=energy_bsm_vs_rc_color.eps,height=5cm,width=5.5cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=ratio_vs_rc_color.eps,height=5cm,width=5.5cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Left panel:'), ' The bosonic-string model potential (in GeV) and\n  different terms contributing to the long distance expansion\n  truncated to a given order as a function of the distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' ', '(in\n  fm).  Middle panel: Short distance cut-off ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), ' ', '(in fm) dependence\n  of the S-wave charmonium spectrum masses (in GeV) for the different\n  approximations to the potential. ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Right panel:'), ' Relative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n^3S_1 ', TexCmd('to'), '\n  e^+ e^-'], []), ' decay ratios with respect the leptonic width of the ground state,\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+e^-'], []), '. The bands indicate the corresponding experimental\n  number.  In all cases the vertical line marks the critical radius below which\n  the full potential becomes imaginary. Solid line: Full BSM. Thick\n  dotted: LO approximation. Dotted: NLO. Dotted-dashed: NNLO.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:bsm')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\nOur numerical results are displayed in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:bsm')]), '. There we\nshow the BSM potential compared to the linear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' LO'), '(r) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), '\nr'], []), ' ', '(LO), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' NLO'), '(r) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r + c_1/r'], []), ' ', '(NLO) as well as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' NNLO'), '(r) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' r + c_1/r+ c_3/r^3'], []), ' ', '(NNLO)\napproximations. Actually, for the typical value of the string tension\nthe difference between the potentials is at most about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['50 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nMeV')], []), '. Applying the renormalization procedure we see that when the\nshort distance cut-off coincides with the critical distance the\ndifference among the different masses become much smaller. This is\njust a manifestation of the short distance insensitivity embodied by\nthe renormalization. While in the exact BSM we are forced to stop at\nthe critical radius, the LO, NLO, NNLO, ... truncations to such a\npotential allow to remove the cut-off completely. However, as we see\nfrom the figure this provides in our view an estimate on the\nsystematic error inherent to the BSM model; the mass shift generated\nby the different truncations is about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['50', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV')], []), '. Of course, there\nis no point in going beyond such an accuracy before other important\neffects (like e.g. relativistic corrections) are taken into account.\n\n\nActually, there are hints~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lambiase:1995st,Nesterenko:1997hw')]), '\nthat for the Nambu-Goto string the critical radius moves about a factor\nof two down (in our case it means ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm ')], []), ' ', ') when quark\nmasses become comparable to the string tension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_q / ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '\n', TexCmd('sim'), ' 1'], []), ' ', '(in our case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c / ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), ' =2.85'], []), ')~', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('We also note a\nrecent effective string theory approach~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('PerezNadal:2008vm')]), ',\nwhere these finite mass effects are evaluated regardless on the\nspecific string dynamics, yielding a potential, up to a constant term, of\nthe form \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV(r)=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('m'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('g^', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('4')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('kappa'))]), TexCmd('log'), '(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))]), '\\,', '\nr)')]), ',\n'], []), '\nhence they obtain the nontrivial result that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/m'], []), ' potential must grow\nlogarithmically at large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' and it has to connect with the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/r^', BraceGroup('2')], []), ' behaviour\nat short distances of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/m'], []), ' contribution calculated by perturbation\ntheory. The comparison of the lattice data is done through the next potential\nform\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fit'), '(r)= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('m'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("-c'"), BraceGroup('r^2')]), " + d' ", TexCmd('ln'), '\n', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('r_0')]), ')\n')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere once a fit to the lattice data is done~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koma:2006si,Koma:2006fw')]), '\nyields ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["c'=0.0027 ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV'), '^2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["d'=0.0075 ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' GeV'), '^2'], []), '.')]), '\n', '\n', '\nWe depict the relative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n^3S_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+ e^-'], []), ' decay ratios\nwith respect the ground state ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' J/', TexCmd('psi'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+ e^-'], []), ' decay. As we\nhave emphasized above the advantage of such a comparison is that purely\nperturbative and state independent corrections in the van Royen-Weisskopf\nformula are factorized out. However, note that the very use of this formula\nassumes a regular potential. Thus we take naturally the wave function at the\nshortest cut-off radius, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), '. As we can see there are somewhat large\ndifferences for the simple linear potential (LO) approximation as compared to\nNLO, NNLO or the full BSM results which agree among them, displaying a\nconvergent pattern at any value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), '. Differences between NLO and NNLO\nstart being noticeable below cut-off radius of about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.15 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' fm')], []), ' for the\nfirst excited state, although the value seems slightly displaced to larger\nnumbers for the next excited states, as one might expect from their stronger\nshort distance sensitivity. Also interesting is the fully converged result at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ', a fact which follows analytically by a detailed study of the short\ndistance wave functions (see Appendix~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:shortdistances')]), ').\n\nThese features reinforce the value of renormalization as a way to study the\neffect of improving on the long distance components of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')]), 'q'], []), '\npotential. Indeed, even though the NNLO potential strongly diverges at short\ndistances the effects on the short distance wave function are not out of\ncontrol; the relevant scale is provided by the binding energy of the bound\nstate.\n\nOf course, while the outcoming decay ratios seem to reproduce the experimental\nnumbers above the critical radius, it is not completely obvious whether\nfixing the short distance cut-off radius is fully justified, as the decay\nformula corresponds to the strict infinite mass and point-like limit of the\nrelated electromagnetic matrix element ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' q ', TexCmd('bar'), ' q '], []), '. Actually, the\nmomentum dependence and recoil effects due to the incoming virtual photon have\nbeen dealt with in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Leinweber:1987hi')]), ' where the corresponding\nmodification to the standard decay formula decreases its value substantially. In\nappendix ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:recoil')]), ' we collect some relevant formulas. In our case we see\nthat, as expected, there is an increasing suppression for excited states,\nalthough in the ratio this effect is negligible as can be seen from\nTable~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:van-royen')]), '.\n\nIn summary, the analysis shows that even if one can apply the\nrenormalization to any long distance approximation to the BSM\npotential, due to the existence of the scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_0'], []), ', one should not\ntake ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ', but rather to keep ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c ', TexCmd('sim'), ' r_0'], []), ' to comply with the\ndynamics. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\nState & & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' R'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Weisskopf')], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' R'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Leinweber')], []), ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.00'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.00'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(2S)'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.58'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.58'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(3S)'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.41'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.42'], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(4S)'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.31'], []), ' ', '& & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.32'], []), ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ccccc')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:van-royen')]), ' Relative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n^3S_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+ e^-'], []), ' decay ratios with\nrespect the ground state ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+ e^-'], []), ' decay calculated through the van\nRoyen-Weisskopf formula and taking into account momentum dependence and recoil\neffects according to Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Leinweber:1987hi')]), '.')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Singular repulsive interactions')]), '\n', '\nTo analyze a situation where renormalization conditions cannot be\napplied let us consider the case where in the power series expansion\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:ipower')]), ') one term happened to be singular and repulsive\nat short distances, say for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=3'], []), ' ', '(unlike the BSM discussed above).\nThen the solution would be of the form\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nu(r) ', TexCmd('to'), ' r^', BraceGroup('3/4'), '[', ' C_', BraceGroup('1R'), ' ', '\\,', ' e^', BraceGroup('2(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R'), BraceGroup('r')]), ')^', BraceGroup('1/2')), ' + C_', BraceGroup('2R'), '\n', '\\,', ' e^', BraceGroup('-2(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R'), BraceGroup('r')]), ')^', BraceGroup('1/2')), '  ', ']', ',\n'], []), '\nwhere we have a converging and a diverging exponential at the origin. \n\nClearly, if we impose normalizability of the bound state, the regular\nsolution must be chosen.  In such a case the bound state energy is\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' predicted'), ' as it usually happens for the standard non-singular\nquantum mechanical potentials.  Conversely, if the bound state energy\nis chosen ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' arbitrarily'), ' then the wave function is non-normalizable\nat short distances. In this sense, the rigorous results given by\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:concavity')]), '), valid in the infinite mass limit, which\nimply that ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' all'), ' inverse powers are attractive singularities are\nmost welcome, because this would imply that the problem of a repulsive\nsingularity of a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' truncated'), ' potential is related to the\ntruncation itself. As we have mentioned, these violations of the\nconditions featured by Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:concavity')]), ') are also observed in\nperturbation theory (see e.g.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Laschka:2011zr')]), '). \n\nFinally, it is not obvious what might be the situation for\nrelativistic corrections which on purely dimensional grounds are of\nthe general form\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV(r ) ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('m^n')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p^k'), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('k+n+1'))]), '  \n'], []), '\nOf course, Weyl ordering should be applied to make sure that\nthe operator is hermitian~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Brambilla:1993zw')]), '. However, as shown in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Brambilla:2000gk,Brambilla:2001xk')]), ' one can eliminate the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' dependence in\nterms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' dependence at the expense of reshuffling the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/m'], []), ' expansion.\nUltimately, we end up with singular problems which generally depend on the\nangular momentum, showing that one must possibly use a different renormalization\ncondition for each partial wave. However, note that for this to happen one must\nhave a singular attractive singularity.  This interesting topic deserves further investigation. \n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conclusions')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:conclusions')]), '\n', '\nWe have reanalyzed the calculation of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1^', BraceGroup('--')], []), ' charmonium spectrum in a\nconstituent quark model using a renormalization boundary condition scheme. This \napproach avoids explicitly the introduction of phenomenological form factors \nused in the past which are usually fine-tuned to low-lying mesonic observables. \n\nThe renormalization viewpoint actually uses these low-lying properties\nas input parameters and sidesteps the fine tuning, as illustrated in\nseveral examples.  For the phenomenologically successful model of\nRef.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Vijande:2005eu')]), ' where ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ad hoc'), ' form factors are\nintroduced as regulators, we find an almost perfect agreement with the\nrenormalization approach.  This result provides confidence on the way\nthe original model took into account the unknown short distance\ndynamics. The use of the renormalization scheme allows us to further\nstudy the dependence of the states on the model parameters in a\ncleaner way since the regulator dependence has been removed.\n\n\nWe find that the mass of the excited states strongly depends on the\nstring tension parameter as one would naturally expect. Further, there\nis also a remarkable insensitivity to the strong coupling constant\nentering the one gluon exchange contribution of the potential. This\navoids a great deal of unphysical fine tuning which suggested taking\nfor this parameter unnaturally large values ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '=0.3-0.4'], []), '. In\ncontrast, the leptonic decay widths present a marked dependence on the\nstrong coupling constant, as expected likewise because these are short\nrange observables. Of course, a more complete description of\ncharmonium systems should also take explicitly into account the\ncontribution to the open charm channels which will provide mass shifts\nand widths for unstable quark-antiquark bound states. In summary, the\nrenormalization approach traces quite naturally and explicitly the\nlong and short distance dependence of hadronic properties.\n\n\n', TexCmd('appendix'), ' \n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Renormalization conditions and Error estimates')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:errors')]), '\n', '\nThe boundary condition allows to connect the bound state to the excited states\nby the matching condition. Here we estimate what is the error in the excited\nmass as a function of the the cut-off radius. This means that we start\nwith the ground state energy, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_0'], []), ', which is fixed throughout and compute the\nlogarithmic derivative at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), '. Then, we perform a calculation of the\nbound state energy, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_n (r_c)'], []), ', which obviously depends on the cut-off radius.\nLet us denote ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_n(r,r_c)'], []), ' the excited wave function where the dependence on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), ' is explicitly shown. Under an infinitesimal change, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c ', TexCmd('to'), ' r_c +\n', TexCmd('Delta'), ' r_c'], []), ' we get\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-', TexCmd('Delta'), " u_n'' + U ", TexCmd('Delta'), ' u_n = ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' E_n u_n + E_n ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' u_n,\n'], []), '\nNote that the variation is defined for a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' fixed'), ' value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ',  \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('Delta'), ' u_n (r,r_c) = u_n (r,r_c + ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' r_c)- u_n (r,r_c ),\n'], []), '\nand hence \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('Delta'), " u_n' (r,r_c) = u_n' (r,r_c + ", TexCmd('Delta'), " r_c)- u_n' (r,r_c ),\n"], []), '\nwhere here, the prime denotes derivative with respect to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '\nvariable.  Therefore, if we use the boundary condition\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ["\nu_n' (r_c,r_c) = L_n (r_c) u_n (r_c, r_c),\n"], []), '\nwe get \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', TexCmd('Delta'), " u_n' (r,r_c) ", TexCmd('Big|_', [BraceGroup('r=r_', BraceGroup('c'))]), ' =& ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', '(L_n (r_c) u_n (r_c, r_c) ) \n& -\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), " u_n' (r,r_c)"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' r_c')]), ' ', TexCmd('Big|_', [BraceGroup('r=', BraceGroup('r_c'))]), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' r_c.\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nFrom here we obtain \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', "(L_n'+ L_n^2 - U + E_n) u_n = - ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), " u_n'"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' r_c')]), ' + L_n \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' u_n'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' r_c')]), ',\n'], []), '\nand multiplying this equation by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_n'], []), ' and subtracting the original\nequation multiplied by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' u_n'], []), ' we get\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-', TexCmd('Delta'), " u_n'' u_n + u_n'' ", TexCmd('Delta'), ' u_n  = ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' E_n u_n^2,\n'], []), '\nwhich integrating from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), ' and infinity and using that for a bound state\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_n (r,r_c) ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ' at large distances we get\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-', TexCmd('Delta'), " u_n' u_n + u_n' ", TexCmd('Delta'), ' u_n  = ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' E_n ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('r_c'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' u_n^2.\n'], []), '\n', '\nOn the other hand, since the ground state energy is fixed, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' E_0=0'], []), ', we\nget\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-', TexCmd('Delta'), " u_0' u_0 + u_0' ", TexCmd('Delta'), ' u_0  = 0,\n'], []), '\nand taking into account \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('Delta'), " E_n = (L_n'+ L_n^2 - U + E_n)\n", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_n(r_c)^2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('r_c'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' u_n (r)^2 dr ')]), ',\n'], []), '\nso that using ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_n = L_0'], []), ' we arrive  at \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', '(E_n-E_0)  = (E_n- E_0) ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_n(r_c)^2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('r_c'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' u_n (r)^2\n  dr ')]), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' r_c.\n'], []), '\nActually, integrating we get \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('r_c'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', '\\,', ' dr ', '\\,', ' u_n (r)^2 = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' const.'), ' \n'], [BracketGroup(' E_n(r_c)-E_0 ')]), '\nFor a normalized state we have for small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_c'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nE_n(r_c)- E_0 =  (E_n - E_0) ', '[', ' 1 + r_c u_n(r_c)^2 + ', TexCmd('dots'), ' ', ']', ' \n'], []), '\n', '\nTherefore for a regular potential with a non-trivial boundary\ncondition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_n (0) ', TexCmd('neq'), ' 0'], []), ' the error is at least linear. For a\nsingular and attractive potential, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/r^n'], []), ', the error is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '\n', '(r_c^', BraceGroup('1+n/2'), ')'], []), ' up to some oscillations. As we see, the convergence is\nfrom above and proportional to the energy difference as well. This\nmeans that the effect of putting a finite cut-off fixing the ground\nstate energy is repulsive and increases with the excitation energy.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Momentum dependence and recoil effects as corrections to leptonic\nwidths')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:recoil')]), '\n', '\nMomentum dependent effects could reveal significant corrections to the\ntheoretical leptonic width. The expression for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-')], []), ' decay\nwidth of S-wave states in the center-of-mass frame of the meson and\ntaking into account those effects can be written\nas~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Leinweber:1987hi')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '&', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(e^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-'), ')=16', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), 'e_', BraceGroup('q'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('q'), '^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('M^', BraceGroup('4'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('k')]), '|\n'), BraceGroup('E_', BraceGroup('e'))]), '(3E_', BraceGroup('e'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '-|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('k')]), '|^', BraceGroup('2'), ')', TexCmd('times'), ' \n', '&\n', TexCmd('times', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_', BraceGroup('q'), '+m_', BraceGroup('q')), BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('q'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('E_', BraceGroup('\nq'))]), '(1+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('3(E_', BraceGroup('q'), '+m_', BraceGroup('q'), ')^', BraceGroup('2'))]), ')', TexCmd('psi'), '(|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|)d|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '\n|')]), '^', BraceGroup('2'), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ref:eqee')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('q')], []), ' is the quark charge in units of the charge of the electron, M is the mass of the meson and\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '&\nE_', BraceGroup('q'), '=(|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|^', BraceGroup('2'), '+m_', BraceGroup('q'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), ')^', BraceGroup('1/2'), ', \n&\nE_', BraceGroup('e'), '=(|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('k')]), '|^', BraceGroup('2'), '+m_', BraceGroup('e'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), ')^', BraceGroup('1/2'), ',\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nare the quark and lepton energies respectively. \n\nThe static limit of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:eqee')]), ') may be obtained by considering the nonrelativistic limit\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('q'), '^', BraceGroup('2'))]), TexCmd('ll'), '1\n'], []), '\nand in this case the integral in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:eqee')]), ') reduces to\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('q'), 'M^', BraceGroup('2'))]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('psi'), '(|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|)|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|^', BraceGroup('2'), 'd|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ref:eqI')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nRecalling the Fourier transform\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('phi'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), ')=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(2', TexCmd('pi'), ')^', BraceGroup('3/2'))]), TexCmd('int'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')])), TexCmd('psi'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', ')d', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\n'], []), '\nand evaluating at the origin, we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('phi'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '=0)=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(2', TexCmd('pi'), ')^', BraceGroup('3/2'))]), TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('psi'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', ')d', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]))]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), '|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|^', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('psi'), '(|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|)d|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|,\n'], []), '\nso the integral above, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:eqI')]), '), becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('q'), 'M^', BraceGroup('2'))]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('psi'), '(|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|)|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|^', BraceGroup('2'), 'd|', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\\,', '|=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(2', TexCmd('pi'), ')^', BraceGroup('1/2')), BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup('q'), 'M^', BraceGroup('2'))]), '|', TexCmd('phi'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '=0)|^', BraceGroup('2'), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWith the kinematic relationships, the static limit of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ref:eqee')]), ') is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(e^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-'), ')', TexCmd('Big|_', [BraceGroup('static')]), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), 'Q^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('M^', BraceGroup('2'))]), '|', TexCmd('phi'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '\n=0)|^', BraceGroup('2'), ',\n'], []), '\nwhich is the well-known van Royen-Weisskopf formula.\n\nFigure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:leinweber')]), ' shows the comparison of the relative\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n^', BraceGroup('3'), 'S_', BraceGroup('1'), TexCmd('to'), ' e^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-')], []), ' decay ratios with respect the leptonic width of the\nground state, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+e^-'], []), '. The ratios are calculated by van\nRoyen-Weisskopf and Leinweber formulas. Left, middle and right panels of the\nfigure show the results for the different terms contributing to the long\ndistance expansion of the bosonic string model truncated to a given order (LO,\nNLO and NNLO).\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=ratio3_term1_vs_rc_color.eps,height=5cm,width=5.5cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=ratio3_term2_vs_rc_color.eps,height=5cm,width=5.5cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=ratio3_term3_vs_rc_color.eps,height=5cm,width=5.5cm')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Relative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n^', BraceGroup('3'), 'S_', BraceGroup('1'), TexCmd('to'), ' e^', BraceGroup('+'), 'e^', BraceGroup('-')], []), ' decay ratios with respect the\n  leptonic width of the ground state, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J/', TexCmd('psi'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e^+e^-'], []), ' which are\n  calculated by van Royen-Weisskopf (solid line) and Leinweber (dashed line)\n  formulas. ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Left panel:'), '  LO. ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Middle panel:'), ' NLO. ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Right panel:'), '\n  NNLO.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:leinweber')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('ttt')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Short distance analysis of wave functions')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:shortdistances')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Single channel case')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:shortdistances_single')]), '\n', '\nIn this appendix we summarize a few interesting facts concerning the\nshort distance behaviour of wave functions. In the OGE case an\nattractive Coulomb like behaviour holds, so that at short distances the reduced \npotential reads\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nU(r) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 2 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' V(r)  ', TexCmd('to'), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('R r')]), ',\n'], []), '\nso that for the nS state we have short distance behaviour \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu_n(r) ', TexCmd('to'), ' A_n ', '[', ' 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3r'), BraceGroup('2R')]), '- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R')]), ' ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(\n  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R')]), ' ', ') ', ']', ' + B_n r,\n'], []), '\nwhich is a linear combination of the regular wave function and the\nsingular one. Note that since the ground state has a given energy the\nirregular component does not vanish. On the other hand, the\northogonality condition,  Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:bc')]), '), implies \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_n/B_n=A_0/B_0'], []), ' so that \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_n(r_c)'), BraceGroup('u_0(r_c)')]), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('A_n'), BraceGroup('A_0')]), ',\n '], []), '\nwhich shows that the ratio between wave functions becomes finite as\nthe cut-off is removed, as can be seen at the right panel in\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:bsm')]), '.\n\nFor a power-like short distance singular potential we may keep the\nstrongest singularity\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nV(r) ', TexCmd('to'), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('C_n'), BraceGroup('r^n')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:sing_U')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe solution of the Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation requires the reduced potential \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nU(r) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 2 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' V(r)  ', TexCmd('to'), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('R^2')]), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R'), BraceGroup('r')]), ' ', ')^n,\n'], []), '\nwhere for convenience the variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R = (2', TexCmd('mu'), ' C_n)^', BraceGroup('1/4')], []), ' with length\nscale dimensions has been introduced. At short distances the reduced\nde Broglie wavelength is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '(r) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('U(r)')]))]), ' = R (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R')]), '\n', ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('2')])), ',\n'], []), '\nwhich fulfills \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '(r)'), BraceGroup('d r')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R')]), '\n', ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('2')]), '-1'), ' ', TexCmd('ll'), ' 1,\n'], []), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r ', TexCmd('ll'), ' R'], []), '. In such a case the WKB method can be\napplied~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Frank:1971xx')]), ' yielding\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nu(r) &&', TexCmd('to'), ' u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' WKB'), ' ', '(r)= ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  ', '&&= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('A'), BraceGroup('[', '-U(r)', ']', '^', BraceGroup('1/4'))]), '\n', TexCmd('sin', [BracketGroup(' ', TexCmd('int'), ' dr ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('-U(r)')]), '+ ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ')]), ',\n '], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi')], []), ' are undetermined amplitude and phase which may be\nobtained by matching to the exact solution in the region ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r ', TexCmd('sim'), '\nR'], []), '. In the case of the singular potential given by\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:sing_U')]), ') we have for the m-state \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nu_m(r)', TexCmd('to'), ' A_m (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R')]), ' ', ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('4')])), '\n', TexCmd('sin', [BracketGroup(' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('n-2')]), '\n', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R')]), ' ', ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('2')]), '-1'), '\n+ ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_m ')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nHowever, the orthogonality condition, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:bc')]), '), imply\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_m=', TexCmd('varphi'), '_0'], []), '. Thus we obtain \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_m(r_c)'), BraceGroup('u_0(r_c)')]), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('A_m'), BraceGroup('A_0')]), ',\n '], []), '\nwhich shows that the ratio between wave functions becomes finite as\nthe cut-off is removed. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=3'], []), ' this is seen at the right panel in\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:bsm')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Coupled channel case')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:shortdistances_coupled')]), '\n', '\nHere we undertake the short distance analysis of the spin-orbit and tensor\ninteractions. At short distances one may neglect all terms and just keep the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/r^3'], []), ' singular contribution yielding\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', [" -u''(r)  -w''(r) "], []), '\n', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R'), BraceGroup('r^3')]), TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', [' 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')])), BraceGroup('3')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')])), BraceGroup('3')]), '  ', '& -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('20'), BraceGroup('3')]), '  '], []), ' ', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', [' u(r)\n   w (r) '], []), ' =0 ', '\\,', ' . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:sch_coupled-dip')]), ' \n'], []), '\n', '\nThis system can be diagonalized by going to the rotated basis \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', [' v_', BraceGroup('1'), '(r)\n   v_', BraceGroup('2'), ' ', '(r) '], []), '\n ', '&=& ', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ['  ', TexCmd('cos'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '  ', '&  ', TexCmd('sin'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '   \n-', TexCmd('sin'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '&  ', TexCmd('cos'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' \n'], []), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', [' u(r)\n   w(r) '], []), ',\n'], []), ' \nwhere the new functions satisfy \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n-v_', BraceGroup('1'), " '' (r) + ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R_1'), BraceGroup('r^3')]), ' v_', BraceGroup('1'), ' ', '(r) &=& 0, ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \n-v_', BraceGroup('2'), " '' (r) - ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R_2'), BraceGroup('r^3')]), ' v_', BraceGroup('2'), ' ', '(r) &=& 0,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:decoup')]), '\n'], []), '\nand the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-R_2'], []), ' are the corresponding eigenvalues \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nR_1 &=& -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('10'), BraceGroup('3')]), ' + 2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('3')]), ' > 0, ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \n-R_2 &=& -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('10'), BraceGroup('3')]), ' - 2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('3')]), ' < 0,\n'], []), '\nand the mixing angle is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), ' = 1.1^0'], []), ', a rather small value. At short\ndistances the solutions of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:decoup')]), ') could be analyzed via the WKB\nmethod as we have done in the previous section, but for\nthis case we can undertake the analysis in terms of Bessel functions,\nwhich short distance is analytically known. Actually, the solutions of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [" -y''(x) - y(x)/x^3=0"], []), ' are\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x')]), ' J_1 ( 2 /', TexCmd('sqrt', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^', TexCmd('frac'), '34'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]))]), ' \n', TexCmd('cos'), '(', TexCmd('pi'), '/4-2 /', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x')]), ') + ', TexCmd('dots'), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n'], []), '\nwhereas the  solutions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [" -y''(x) + y(x)/x^3=0"], []), ' are\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', &=& ', TexCmd('frac'), '1', BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), ' ')])), ' x^', TexCmd('frac'), '34 e^', BraceGroup('2/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x')])), '\n+ ', TexCmd('dots'), ', \n'], []), '\n', '\nAll this amounts to write the solutions in the suitable form\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nv_', BraceGroup('1'), ' ', '(r) &', TexCmd('to'), ' ', '& (', ' \n', TexCmd('sin', [BracketGroup(' 2 ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' R_2'), BraceGroup('r')]))]), ' +  ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:short_bc_r3')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe four constants appearing here, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('1R')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('2R')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('A')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi')], []), '\nreflect that the total order of the system is four. The last equation also shows\nthat generally solutions will diverge as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('R_1/r')]))], []), ' at the origin,\nhence preventing the bound state normalization condition, unless ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('1R'), '=0'], []), '. In\nsuch a case the normalizable solution may be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '&\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nu(r) ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('cos'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' C_A ', '\\,', ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R_2')]), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac'), '34'), ' \n', TexCmd('sin', [BracketGroup(' 2 ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' R_2'), BraceGroup('r')]))]), ' +  ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ')]), ' \n', '&\n-', TexCmd('sin'), TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('\nR_2'), BraceGroup('r')]))])), ',\n'], []), ' \n', '&\n\n&\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nw(r) ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('sin'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' C_A ', '\\,', ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R_2')]), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac'), '34'), ' \n', TexCmd('sin', [BracketGroup(' 2 ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' R_2'), BraceGroup('r')]))]), ' +  ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ')]), ' \n', '&\n+', TexCmd('cos'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' C_', BraceGroup('2R'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('R_2')]), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac'), '34'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-2\n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' R_2'), BraceGroup('r')]))])), '.\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe three independent constants appearing here for the regular solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_A'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('2R')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi')], []), ' correspond to fix the energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('J/', TexCmd('psi'))], []), ', the asymptotic\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D/S'], []), ' ratio ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ', and the normalization condition. Note that when integrating\nfrom large distances to short distances with a given bound state energy and an\narbitrary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' we would always have a contribution from the exponentially\ndiverging solution since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('1R'), ' ', TexCmd('neq'), ' 0'], []), '. Thus, the condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('1R'), '=0'], []), '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' predicts'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' from the bound state energy. The foregoing analysis shows\nthat for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/r^3'], []), ' singularity appearing here the solution is ambiguous and\nthe bound state energy for a given state has to be treated as an ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' input'), '. Of\ncourse, the orthogonality requirement between different states implies that if\none state, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(u_n,w_n)'], []), ', has a short distance phase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_n'], []), ' and another\nstate, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(u_m,w_m)'], []), ', has a short distance phase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_m'], []), ', one has\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n0 &=& 2 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(M_n - M_m)  ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', '\\,', ' dr ', '\\,', ' ', '(u_n u_m + w_n w_m) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&=& \n', '[', 'u_', BraceGroup('n'), "' u_", BraceGroup('m'), '  - u_', BraceGroup('n'), ' u_', BraceGroup('m'), "'  + w_", BraceGroup('n'), "' w_", BraceGroup('m'), '  - w_', BraceGroup('n'), ' w_', BraceGroup('m'), "' ", ']', TexCmd('Big|_'), '0^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \n', '&=& ', TexCmd('frac'), '1', BraceGroup('R_2'), ' C_', BraceGroup('A,n'), ' C_', BraceGroup('A,m'), ' \n', TexCmd('sin'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_n - ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_m) \n'], []), '\nwhence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_n=', TexCmd('varphi'), '_m'], []), ' is obtained. This shows that all states are linked\nthrough the spin-dependent splitting provided the ground state energy is given.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Fitting parameters of the renormalized model')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:fitting')]), '\n', '\nIt is interesting to see what is the renormalized model sensitivity to\nthe parameters. Of course, at this level one should envisage the\npossibly non-negligible contribution of the missing mesonic thresholds\nand the induced mass shift.  To this end we fit the model parameters\nfrom the experimental masses of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1^', BraceGroup('--')], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('c')])], []), '\nstates~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Nakamura:2010zzi')]), ' and estimate their theoretical\nuncertainties as well as an educated mass shift guess.  The way to\nperform the first task is of course debatable.  This requires some\ncompromise as to what are the errors attached to the masses within the\npresent framework. Naively one would just take the quoted PDG errors\non the experimental masses. However, as we have mentioned above, the\npresent model incorporates thresholds but no explicit coupling to\nmeson-meson channels. This affects more significantly\nthe higher excited states via a subthreshold induced mass shift, which\nwe take as a systematic error of the model.\n\nWe decide to make a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '^2'], []), ' fit using as fitting parameters the quark mass,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_c'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_c'], []), ' related with the confinement strength and the strong\ncoupling constant, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s'], []), '. We define the\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('chi'), '^2(', TexCmd('vec'), ' p) = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_i ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(M_', BraceGroup('exp'), '(i)-M_', BraceGroup('teo'), '(i,', TexCmd('vec'), '\np))^2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('exp'), '(i)^2')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec'), ' p'], []), ' represents our model parameters and the experimental data are taken as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'), '(2S)'), ' = 3686.093 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 0.143 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'), '(3S)'), ' =\n4039.6 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 42.25 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'), '(4S)'), ' = 4361 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 37 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV')], []), ',\nwhere as explain previously the errors are taken as the half-width of the state. \nBy minimizing the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '^2'], []), ' function we\nobtain the theoretical uncertainties from the corresponding covariance matrix at\nthe minimum. The outcoming values for the parameters are\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nm_c &=& 1862', TexCmd('pm'), '12.6 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', '(0.68', '\\,', ' percent ),\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \na_c &=& 524  ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 43  ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), '   ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', '(8.2 ', '\\,', ' percent ),\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('mu'), '_c &=& 88', TexCmd('pm'), '7.2 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', '(8.2 ', '\\,', ' percent ),\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('alpha'), '_s &=& 0.41', TexCmd('pm'), '0.14       ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', '(34', '\\,', ' percent ),\n'], []), '\nwhere we put in parenthesis the relative uncertainties in percentage.\nHere we clearly see that the highest uncertainty corresponds to the\nvalue of the strong coupling constant. This rather large insensitivity\nto the otherwise too large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s'], []), ' is a rewarding feature of the\nrenormalization approach. Actually, quite natural values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_s'], []), '\nare obtained. The spectrum at the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '^2-'], []), 'minimum is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('psi'), '(2S) &=& 3687 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 80  ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), ',\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('psi'), '(3S) &=& 4108 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 79  ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), ',\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('psi'), '(4S) &=& 4348 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 80  ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), ',\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('psi'), '(5S) &=& 4586 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 66  ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' MeV'), ',\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nren-charm Bibliography file not found \n', TexCmd('bibliography', [BraceGroup('ren-charm')]), '\n', '\n'], []), ' \n', '\n']
