[BraceGroup(TexCmd('baselinestretch')), BraceGroup('#1')]), TexCmd('large'), TexCmd('normalsize'))]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('Isospectral surfaces with distinct covering spectra via Cayley Graphs')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BracketGroup('B. de Smit'), BraceGroup('Bart de Smit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('ast')], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('address', [BraceGroup('Universiteit LeidenMathematisch InstituutPostbus 9512 2300 RA\nLeiden')]), ' ', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('desmit@math.leidenuniv.nl')]), '\n', TexCmd('thanks', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' Funded in part by the European Commission under contract\nMRTN-CT-2006-035495')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BracketGroup('R. Gornet'), BraceGroup('Ruth Gornet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('dagger')], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('address', [BraceGroup('University of Texas  Department of Mathematics  Arlington, TX\n76019 ')]), ' ', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('rgornet@uta.edu')]), '\n', TexCmd('thanks', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('dagger')], []), ' Research partially supported by NSF grant DMS-0204648')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BracketGroup('C. J. Sutton'), BraceGroup('Craig J. Sutton', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('sharp')], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('address', [BraceGroup('Dartmouth College Department of Mathematics  Hanover, NH 03755')]), '\n', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('craig.j.sutton@dartmouth.edu')]), '\n', TexCmd('thanks', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('sharp')], []), ' Research partially supported by NSF grant DMS-0605247 and a \nCareer Enhancement Fellowship from the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('keywords', [BraceGroup('Laplace spectrum, length spectrum, marked\nlength spectrum, covering spectrum, Gassmann-Sunada triples')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nThe covering spectrum is a geometric invariant of a Riemannian manifold, \nmore generally of a metric space, that measures the size of its one-dimensional \nholes by isolating a portion of the length spectrum.\nIn a previous paper we demonstrated that the covering spectrum \nis not a spectral invariant of a manifold in dimensions three and higher.\nIn this article we give an example of two isospectral Cayley graphs that \nadmit length space structures with distinct covering spectra.\nFrom this we deduce the existence of infinitely many pairs of \nSunada-isospectral surfaces with unequal covering spectra.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nThe covering spectrum of a complete length space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a geometric invariant\nintroduced by Sormani and Wei ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SW')]), ' \nthat measures the size of one dimensional holes in \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' by isolating the lengths of certain closed geodesics that \nare minimal in their free homotopy class. \nMore specifically, the covering spectrum can be computed by \nconsidering a certain family ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '\\{', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta')), '\\}', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), ' >0')], []), ' of regular coverings of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'))], []), ' covers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), "'")], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), "' > ", TexCmd('delta')], []), '. \nThe covering spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' then consists of those values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' where\nthe isomorphism type of the cover changes.\nThat is, the covering spectrum is the collection of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), "'s \nwhere there is a ``jump'' in the step function ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'))], []), ". \nOne can see that a ``jump'' at time ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), " corresponds \nto the appearance of a ``hole'' of circumference ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2 ', TexCmd('delta')], []), ' or, in the case of manifolds, a \nnon-trivial free homotopy class whose shortest geodesic is of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('delta')], []), ' \n', '(cf. Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Prop:NewGeo')]), ').\n\nAs an example, we follow ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Example 2.5'), BraceGroup('SW')]), ' and consider the flat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2 ', TexCmd('times'), ' 3'], []), ' torus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X= S^1(2) ', TexCmd('times'), ' S^1(3)'], []), ', \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1(c)'], []), ' denotes the circle of circumference ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '. \nOne can see through the covering spectrum algorithm \n(see ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('CSA')]), ') that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-covers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' are given by \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R', TexCmd('delta'), ' = ^2'], []), ' ', '(for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 < ', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), '),\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R = S^1(2) ', TexCmd('times'), ' '], []), ' ', '(for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1< ', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')])], []), ' ', ') \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' = X'], []), ' ', '(for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' > ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')])], []), ').\nHence, the covering spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is given by \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '1, ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', '\\}'], []), ".\nEach of these numbers is the circumference of a ``hole'' in this torus and \nalso half the length of the minimal closed geodesics\nin the free homotopy classes associated to the standard generators \n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1,0)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(0,1)'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Z_1(X) = ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Z ', TexCmd('times'), ' '], []), '.  \n\nAs there is a long-standing interest in the relationship \nbetween the Laplace spectrum of a manifold and its length spectrum\n(i.e., the collection of lengths of closed geodesics), \nit is natural to wonder about the mutual influences between the Laplace spectrum \nand the covering spectrum. Specifically, one would like to know if the \ncovering spectrum is a spectral invariant. \nIn ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Ex.~10.5'), BraceGroup('SW')]), ", Sormani and Wei demonstrated that certain isospectral manifolds \narising through Sunada's method ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Sunada')]), ' share the same covering spectrum, suggesting that \nthe covering spectrum might at least be an invariant of this technique.\nHowever, through an analysis of the group theory and geometry underlying the covering spectrum we \nconstructed Sunada-isospectral manifolds with distinct covering spectra \nin dimensions three and higher ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Sec. 8'), BraceGroup('DGS')]), ', thus showing that \nthe covering spectrum is not a spectral invariant. \n\nIndeed, we recall that a triple of finite groups ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(G, H_1, H_2)'], []), ', where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2'], []), ' are subgroups of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', is said to be a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Gassmann-Sunada')]), ' triple \nif for any conjugacy class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C ', TexCmd('subset'), ' G'], []), ' the sets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C ', TexCmd('cap'), ' H_1'], []), ' \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C ', TexCmd('cap'), ' H_2'], []), ' are of the same order.\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(G, H_1, H_2)'], []), ' is a Gassmann-Sunada triple where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' acts \nfreely and isometrically on a Riemannian manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ", \nthen Sunada's theorem (Theorem~", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Thm:SunadaPesce')]), ')  \ntells us that the quotient Riemannian manifolds ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('backslashH'), '_1  M'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('backslashH'), '_2 M'], []), ' are isospectral,\nand the isospectral pairs arising in this manner are said to be ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Sunada-isospectral')]), ".\nSunada's theorem provided the first systematic method for constructing isospectral manifolds \nand---along with its numerous variants---accounts for many of the \nisospectral pairs in the literature (see ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Gordon')]), " for a \nretrospective on Sunada's method).\nIn ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DGS')]), ' we discovered an analogous algebraic condition and theorem concerning \nthe covering spectrum. Specifically, we showed the following.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thm', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Thm:DGS')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(G, H_1, H_2)'], []), ' be a triple of finite groups, where \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2'], []), ' are subgroups of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', and suppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' acts freely \non a closed manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is \nsimply-connected and of dimension at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ', then \nthe following are equivalent:\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DGS')]), ' Theorem 2.2')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nWe then went on to produce examples of Gassmann-Sunada triples that \nare not jump triples. As a consequence we were able to construct \nSunada-isospectral manifolds \nwith distinct covering spectra in all dimensions greater than or equal to three.\nHowever, our method for building such examples appears to fail in dimension two \nas the arguments underlying Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Thm:DGS')]), ' depend in part on the fact that \nall free homotopy classes in dimension \nthree and higher can be represented by simple closed curves.\n\nIn this article we take a different approach in order to establish the \nfollowing theorem showing that \nthe covering spectrum is not a spectral invariant of a surface.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thm', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Thm:Main')]), '\nFor each integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('ge'), '1'], []), ' there exist pairs of closed connected\nSunada-isospectral surfaces of genus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['7n+1'], []), ' with distinct covering spectra.\n'], []), '\n', '\nTo prove the result above we construct certain Cayley graphs \nassociated to a well-known Gassmann-Sunada \ntriple ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Ex.~11.4.7.'), BraceGroup('Buser')]), ',\nand endow them with suitably chosen edge lengths\nso that the resulting length spaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' \nhave distinct covering spectra. \nWe then build continuous families of Riemannian \nmanifolds ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '(M_1, g_1^', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'), ' > 0')], []), ' \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '(M_2, g_2^', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'), ' > 0')], []), ' that are pairwise \nSunada-isospectral for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), ' > 0'], []), ' and \nsuch that for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i = 1,2'], []), ' the family ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(M_i, g_i^', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ' \nconverges with respect to the Gromov-Hausdorff metric to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' tends to zero.\nThen, since the covering spectrum is continuous under \nGromov-Hausdorff convergence ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Corollary 8.5'), BraceGroup('SW')]), ',\nit follows that for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' sufficiently small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(M_1, g_1^', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ' \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(M_2, g_2^', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ' are Sunada-isospectral manifolds with distinct \ncovering spectra.\n\nCurrently, it is not clear to us whether any of the aforementioned pairs \nconsist of Riemann surfaces. \nIt would appear to be an interesting problem to \ndetermine whether the covering spectrum is a spectral invariant \namong such spaces.\n\nThe outline of this article is as follows. In Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sec:Covering')]), ' we \nwill formulate the precise definition of the covering spectrum, \npresent a useful algorithm for computing it, and discuss its \nbehavior under Gromov-Hausdorff convergence. \nIn Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sec:Cayley')]), ' we recall the notion of a Cayley graph, we\nproduce the length spaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' mentioned above, and show their covering spectra are distinct.\nIn Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sec:Surfaces')]), ' we review how the Cayley graphs relate\nto the isospectral problem, and we finish the proof of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Thm:Main')]), '\nas outlined.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The Covering Spectrum')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Sec:Covering')]), '\n', '\nIn this section we will recall the definition of the covering spectrum as given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SW')]), '.\nSince the primary focus of this paper will be the covering spectra of compact\nsemi-locally simply-connected length spaces we will only formulate our definition \nin this setting. However, we note that in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DGS')]), ' we \nextended this definition of the covering spectrum to arbitrary metric spaces. \n\nWe will begin by recalling the notion of a filtration of a group.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('dfn', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a group. A ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('filtration')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('bullet'), ' G'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is \na family ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '\\{', '^', BraceGroup('i'), ' G', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup('i ', TexCmd('in'), ' I')], []), ' of subgroups of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' ranges \nover an ordered index set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ', such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^i G ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^j G'], []), ' whenever ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i < j'], []), '.\nThe ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('jump set')]), ' of the filtration is the subset of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ' given by\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Jump')]), TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), TexCmd('bullet'), ' G) = ', '\\{', ' i ', TexCmd('in'), ' I : ^i G ', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', '^j G ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' for all ')]), ' j > i ', '\\}', '.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('exa', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Exa:Filtration')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a group and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m: G ', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), TexCmd('to'), ' '], []), ' a class function; i.e., \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' is constant on the conjugacy classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' induces \na filtration ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), TexCmd('bullet'), '_m G = ', '\\{', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta')), '_', BraceGroup('m'), ' G ', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), ' > 0')], []), ', where\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), '_m G := ', TexCmd('langle'), ' g ', TexCmd('in'), ' G : m(g) < ', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('rangle'), '.'], []), '\nSuch filtrations will prove to be useful in our discussion of the covering spectrum.\n'], [BracketGroup('Filtrations Induced by Class Functions')]), '\n', '\nWe now observe that given a connected and compact semi-locally \nsimply-connected length space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X,d)'], []), ' its metric structure induces \na natural filtration (indexed by the positive reals) on \nits fundamental group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), '. Indeed, for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' > 0'], []), ' \nlet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('U')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'))], []), ' be the open cover of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' consisting of all the \nopen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-balls in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X,d)'], []), '. Then let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), ' \nbe the subgroup of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), ' generated by classes \nof the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('alpha'), ' * ', TexCmd('beta'), ' * ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ']'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), ' : ', '[', '0, 1', ']', ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' X'], []), ' \nis a loop that is completely contained in some open ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-ball, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' is a path from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_0'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '(0)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), '(t) = ', TexCmd('alpha'), '(1-t)'], []), ' \nis its reverse. \nThe subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), '  is normal in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), ' and \nthe conjugacy classes of the generators ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('alpha'), ' * ', TexCmd('beta'), ' * ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ']'], []), ' \nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), ' represent the free homotopy classes \nof loops that have representatives completely contained in a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-ball. In this fashion we obtain \na filtration ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('bullet'), TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0) = ', '\\{', ' ', '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0) ', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), ' > 0')], []), ' \nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('dfn', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X,d)'], []), ' be a connected and compact semi-locally simply-connected length space. \nWe then define the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('covering spectrum')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X,d)'], []), ' to be the set \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('CovSpec')]), TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Jump')]), TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '(X,d) =  (^', TexCmd('bullet'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)).'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nNow, since each subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), ' of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X, x_0)'], []), ' is normal, the Galois theory of covering spaces ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Theorem 2.5.13'), BraceGroup('Spanier')]), ' tells us \nthat we may associate to each subgroup a connected regular covering \nspace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' X'], []), ' known as the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-cover')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '. \nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-cover has the property that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y ', TexCmd('to'), ' X'], []), ' is any covering space \nthat evenly covers every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '-ball of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', TexCmd('delta')], []), ' is a covering space of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ' ', '(cf. ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 2.5.11'), BraceGroup('Spanier')]), ').\nHence, we obtain a tower ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '\\{', '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), ' > 0')], []), ' of regular covers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' \nand the covering spectrum detects when we have a change in the isomorphism \ntype of the cover. That is, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('CovSpec')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(X,d)'], []), ' if and only if for \nall ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), ' > ', TexCmd('delta')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '^', TexCmd('delta')], []), ' are non-isomorphic as\ncovering spaces. In the event that we are considering a \ncompact Riemannian manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(M,g)'], []), ' we see that the covering spectrum \nalso contains information about the length spectrum.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Prop:NewGeo')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(M,g)'], []), ' be a closed Riemannian manifold. Then \n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DGS')]), ' Corollary 4.5')]), '\n', '\nIn order to compute the length spectrum it will be useful \nto introduce the minimum marked length map.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('dfn', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X,d)'], []), ' be a connected and compact semi-locally \nsimply-connected length space with fundamental group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)'], []), ' and\nsimply-connected universal cover ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), '(, ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('d')]), ')'], []), '. \nThen the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('minimum marked length map')]), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m: ', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), '_1(X) ', TexCmd('to'), ' '], []), ' is given by \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['m(', '[', TexCmd('gamma'), ']', ') ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('inf'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('x')]), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('d')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('x')]), ', ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('x')]), '),'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)'], []), ' acts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('X')])], []), ' via deck transformations.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nThe minimum marked length map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m: ', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), '_1(X) ', TexCmd('to'), ' '], []), ' assigns \nto each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('gamma'), ']', ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)'], []), '\nthe length of the shortest closed geodesic in the free \nhomotopy class determined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('gamma'), ']'], []), '.\nSince free homotopy classes correspond to conjugacy classes \nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)'], []), ' we see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' is a class function.\nHence, by Example~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Exa:Filtration')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' induces the \nfiltration ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '^', TexCmd('bullet'), '_m ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)'], []), ' and we have the following.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prop:filter')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X,d)'], []), ' be a connected and compact semi-locally \nsimply-connected length space with minimum marked length \nmap ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m : ', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), '_1(X) ', TexCmd('to'), ' '], []), '. Then \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('CovSpec')]), '(X,d) = ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Jump')]), TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', '( ^', TexCmd('bullet'), '_m ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)).'], []), ' \n'], [BracketGroup('cf. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DGS')]), ' Proposition 2.5')]), '\n', '\nThe above leads to the \nfollowing algorithm for computing the covering spectrum of \na compact semi-locally simply-connected length space as found in ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('p. 54'), BraceGroup('SW')]), ' and \n', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('4.6'), BraceGroup('DGS')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('csa', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('CSA')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(X,d)'], []), ' be a compact semi-locally \nsimply-connected length space with minimum marked length map\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m: ', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), '_1(X) ', TexCmd('to'), ' '], []), '. Then let\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), '_1=', TexCmd('inf'), '\\{', 'm(', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', TexCmd('colon'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X), ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('ne'), ' 1', '\\}', ' > 0 \n', TexCmd('delta'), '_2=', TexCmd('inf'), '\\{', 'm(', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', TexCmd('colon'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X), ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('not'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), '  ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X) ', TexCmd('colon'), '\\;', '\nm(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('delta'), '_1', TexCmd('rangle'), ' ', '\\}', ' > ', TexCmd('delta'), '_1 \n', TexCmd('delta'), '_3=', TexCmd('inf'), '\\{', 'm(', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', TexCmd('colon'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X), ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('not'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), '  ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X) ', TexCmd('colon'), '\\;', '\nm(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('delta'), '_2', TexCmd('rangle'), ' ', '\\}', ' > ', TexCmd('delta'), '_2 \n', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('l')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere we continue until ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), '  ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X) ', TexCmd('colon'), '\\;', ' m(', TexCmd('sigma'), ') ', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '_r ', TexCmd('rangle'), ' = ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)'], []), '.\nNow since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a compact length space we know by ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 4.6'), BraceGroup('SW')]), ' \nthat the image of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' is closed and discrete. It then follows from the fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X)'], []), ' \nis finitely generated that the above process stops in finitely many steps at some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_r'], []), ', \nand by the previous proposition we see\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('CovSpec')]), '(X,d) = ', '\\{', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '_1 , ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' , ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('delta'), '_r ', '\\}', '.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('rem', ['\nFor an application of the covering spectrum algorithm to the case of flat tori the reader is encouraged to see ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Example 4.7'), BraceGroup('DGS')]), '.\nIn particular, this example shows that for a flat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '-torus, the covering spectrum need not be equal to the \nsuccessive minima of the corresponding lattice ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')])], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R^n'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe conclude this section by recalling that in Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Prop:NewGeo')]), '\nwe observed that for any compact length space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' we have \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('CovSpec')]), '2', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Spec_L')]), '(X) ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '(X)'], []), ', \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Spec_L')]), '(X)'], []), ' denotes the length spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '.\nNow, it is well known that the length spectrum does not \nbehave well under Gromov-Hausdorff \nconvergence: lengths may disappear or \nsuddenly appear in the limit (cf. ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Examples 8.1-8.3'), BraceGroup('SW')]), ').\nHowever, in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sec:Cayley')]), ' we will use the fact that, in contrast, \nthe covering spectrum is continuous under Gromov-Hausdorff convergence.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Prop:GHConv')]), '\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i'], []), ' is a sequence of compact length spaces converging to a compact length \nspace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ' in the Gromov-Hausdorff sense, then the covering spectra converge in the \nHausdorff sense as subsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'], []), '. That is, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i ', TexCmd('stackrel', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm', [BraceGroup('GH')])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('longrightarrow'))]), 'Y'], []), ', then \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('i ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('CovSpec')]), ' d_', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('CovSpec'), BraceGroup('H')]), '( (X_i) ', TexCmd('cup'), ' ', '\\{', '0', '\\}', ', (Y)', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', '0', '\\}', ' ', ') = 0,'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_H'], []), ' denotes the Hausdorff distance between subsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'], []), '.\n'], [BracketGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SW')]), ' Corollary 8.5')]), ' \n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nHence, twice the covering spectrum determines a part of the length \nspectrum of a compact length space that behaves well \nunder Gromov-Hausdorff convergence.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('rem', ['\nWe refer the reader to Sections 7 and 8 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SW')]), ' for \nthe relevant details on Gromov-Hausdorff convergence and the proof of the \nproposition above. \n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Cayley Graphs associated to the Fano plane')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Sec:Cayley')]), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\n', '\nIn this section we will introduce certain Cayley graphs and associated length\nspaces. In the next section we will use these examples to construct\nisospectral surfaces with distinct covering spectra.\n\nBy a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('graph')]), ' we will mean a quadruple ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(V,E, o,t)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' are\nthe sets of vertices and edges (respectively), and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['o'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' are maps from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), '\nassociating to each edge its origin and target.  \nIn other words, we consider directed graphs with possible self-edges and\nmultiple edges between the same vertices.  \nA morphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' from a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(V,E,o,t)'], []), ' to a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["(V',E',o',t')"], []), ' is a pair of\nmaps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_v', TexCmd('colon'), '\\;', 'V', TexCmd('to'), " V'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_e', TexCmd('colon'), '\\;', 'E', TexCmd('to'), " E'"], []), ' for which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["o'", TexCmd('circ'), ' f_e=\nf_v', TexCmd('circ'), ' o'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["t'", TexCmd('circ'), ' f_e= f_v', TexCmd('circ'), ' t'], []), '.\n\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a group acting ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('on the right')]), ' on a set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S', TexCmd('subset'), ' G'], []), ' is\na subset, then we can consider the (', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('generalized')]), ') ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Cayley graph')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V', '[', 'S', ']', '=(V,E,o,t)'], []), ' associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ', where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E=V', TexCmd('times'), ' S'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['o(v,s)=v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t(v,s)=vs'], []), '.  Note that we can label the\nedges by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' according to their second coordinate---this will be referred to \nas the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('color')]), ' or ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('type')]), ' of the edge---and that for every\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), ' S'], []), ' every vertex has a single incoming and outgoing edge of type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), '.\n\nIf for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' we take a finitely generated group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '-action by right multiplication\nand we let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' be a set of generators of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ',\nthen we obtain the usual Cayley graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G', '[', 'S', ']'], []), ' of the group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' ', '(cf. ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Chp. 4'), BraceGroup('Harpe')]), ').  The group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' then has a left-action\nby graph automorphisms on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G', '[', 'S', ']'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' acts on the vertices by left\nmultiplication. The action preserves the labeling of the edges by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '.\nFor any subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' the quotient graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H', TexCmd('backslash'), '\n', '(G', '[', 'S', ']', ')'], []), ' is then naturally isomorphic to the generalized Cayley graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(H', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G)', '[', 'S', ']'], []), '.\nThe graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(H', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G)', '[', 'S', ']'], []), ' is also known as the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Schreier graph')]), ' associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H ', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' ', '(cf. ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Chp. 4'), BraceGroup('Harpe')]), ').\n\nIn our application, the group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' will be the group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Gl')]), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' FG=_3(_2)'], []), ', which we\nwill consider with its right action on the Fano plane, the projective plane\nover the field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' F_2'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' elements.\nThe set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_1'], []), ' of points of the Fano plane is labeled by non-zero\nrow vectors of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' F_2'], []), ', which are multiplied on the right by\nmatrices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \nA second set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2'], []), ' with right ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '-action that we will consider is the\nset of lines in the Fano plane. We can label ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2'], []), ' by the same set\nof non-zero vectors in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' F_2^3'], []), '\nwhere the line through two distinct points ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1,v_2', TexCmd('in'), ' V_1'], []), ' is labeled by the\nunique nonzero vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w', TexCmd('mathbb'), ' F', TexCmd('in'), '_2^3'], []), ' so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), ' v_1, w', TexCmd('rangle'), ' =', TexCmd('langle'), '\nv_2,w', TexCmd('rangle'), '=0'], []), ' under the standard inner product \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('cdot'), ',', TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' F_2^3'], []), '; see\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Fano')]), '. \nBy computing the stabilizer in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' of the element represented by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['100'], []), ' \nin each of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2'], []), ' we \nsee that we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '-set isomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_1', TexCmd('cong'), ' H_1', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2', TexCmd('cong'), ' H_2', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G'], []), ', where\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nH_1 =\n(', TexNamedEnv('array', ['1 & 0 & 0  * & * & *  * & * & *'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), ') \n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '\nH_2 =\n(', TexNamedEnv('array', [' 1 & * & * 0 & * & * 0 & * & *'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), ').\n'], []), ' \n', '\nLet us now consider the subset ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S = ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Gl')]), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' F', '\\{', 'A, B', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' G=_3(_2)'], []), ' consisting of the two matrices\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nA= ( ', TexNamedEnv('array', [' 1&1&0 0&0&1 0&1&0 '], [BraceGroup('rrr')]), ' ', '), ', TexCmd('qquad'), '\nB= ( ', TexNamedEnv('array', [' 0&1&0 0&0&1 1&0&0 '], [BraceGroup('rrr')]), ' ', ').'], []), '\nThe action of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' on the Fano plane is given by dotted arrows in Figure\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Fano')]), ', while the action of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' is rotation by 120 degrees\ncounterclockwise.  By rearranging the vertices we see that the\nCayley graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_1', '[', 'A,B', ']'], []), ' is the graph in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Graph1')]), '\nwhere the dotted arrows indicate edges associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and\nthe solid arrows indicate edges associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '.\nBy tracking the action of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' on the lines of the Fano plane\n(or on the three points each line contains) we construct the Cayley graph \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2', '[', 'A,B', ']'], []), ' as in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Graph2')]), '.\nThese graphs are also given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Ex.~11.4.7'), BraceGroup('Buser')]), ' and ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Brooks')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tikzpicture', ['\n', TexCmd('node', [BracketGroup('below left,inner [BracketGroup("->,>=stealth',shorten >=1pt,auto,node distance=3cm,\n                    semithick,inner sep=2pt")]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The Cayley graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2', '[', 'A,B', ']', '=H_2', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G', '[', 'A,B', ']'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' acting on the lines in the Fano plane.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:Graph2')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('geometric realization')]), ' of a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(V,E,o,t)'], []), ' is the topological\nspace that one obtains by glueing closed intervals onto the\nset ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' as follows: for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', TexCmd('in'), ' E'], []), ' one adds an interval\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '0,1', ']'], []), ' identifying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['o(e)', TexCmd('in'), ' V'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t(e)', TexCmd('in'), ' V'], []), '.\nIf one designates a positive real number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_e'], []), ' as the\nlength of an edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' then one can give the interval assocated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' \nlength ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_e'], []), ' and in this way one obtains a length space.\n\nFor our Cayley graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G', '[', 'A,B', ']'], []), ' we will assign a length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_A>0'], []), ' to all edges\nassociated with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_B>0'], []), ' to all edges associated with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ', and we\nthus obtain a length space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X(l_A,l_B)'], []), '. The group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' acts by isometries on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X(l_A,l_B)'], []), ' and it acts freely, i.e., no non-trivial element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' has a\nfixed point on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X(l_A,l_B)'], []), '. The quotient length space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1', TexCmd('backslash'), '\nX(l_A,l_B)'], []), ' is the length space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_1', '[', 'A,B', ']'], []), ' and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2', TexCmd('backslash'), '\nX(l_A,l_B)'], []), ' is the length space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2', '[', 'A,B', ']'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Prop:distinct')]), '\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<l_A <l_B < ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' l_A'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_A+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'l_B'], []), ' lies in the covering spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1=H_1', TexCmd('backslash'), ' X(l_A,l_B)'], []), ' but not in \nthe covering spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2=H_2', TexCmd('backslash'), ' X(l_A,l_B)'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nWe see from the assumption \nthat \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['l_A < l_B < 2l_A < l_A + l_B < 2l_', BraceGroup('B'), ' < 3l_', BraceGroup('A'), ' < 2l_', BraceGroup('A'), ' + l_', BraceGroup('B')], []), '\nrepresent the lengths of the non-trivial minimal loops of length \nbelow ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_', BraceGroup('A'), ' + 2l_', BraceGroup('B')], []), '. These lengths form\nthe first column of the table in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:table')]), '.\n\nThe second and third column in the table lists closed loops in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' of the given lengths.\nIn this table ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('001')], []), ' denotes the path along the\nedge associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' leaving from the vertex with label ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['001'], []), '.\nOne has to inspect the appropriate graph to see what the endpoint\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('001')], []), ' is: in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' it is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['010'], []), ' and in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' it is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['110'], []), '.\nPaths are composed according to the following convention: if the endpoint of a path ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' is the starting\npoint of a path ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), ' then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p*q'], []), ' runs through ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' at double speed on the interval\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '0,1/2', ']'], []), ' and then through ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '1/2,1', ']'], []), '. \n\nBy inspecting the graphs in Figures ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Graph1')]), ' and ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Graph2')]), ' one \ndeduces that every closed loop in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' that is of length\nbelow ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_A+2l_B'], []), ', is freely homotopic to either a\nconstant loop, or to a loop in the table, or to the inverse of a loop in the\ntable in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:table')]), '. \nNote also that the lengths of the loops in the table are minimal within\ntheir free homotopy class.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', [' ', TexCmd('hline'), '\nlength   &  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1=H_1', TexCmd('backslash'), ' X(l_A,l_B)'], []), '  ', '&  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2=H_2', TexCmd('backslash'), ' X(l_A,l_B)'], []), '  ', TexCmd('hline'), ' ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_A'], []), ' ', '&  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_1 = A_', BraceGroup('110')], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_1 = A_', BraceGroup('100')], []), '  ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_B'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_2 = B_', BraceGroup('111')], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_2 = B_', BraceGroup('111')], []), '  ', TexCmd('hline'), ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2 l_A + l_B'], []), ' ', '&\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_6 = B_', BraceGroup('011'), '*A_', BraceGroup('101'), '*A_', BraceGroup('100')], []), ' ', '&\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_2*', TexCmd('tau'), '_3'], []), '  \n', '&', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('7'), ' = B_', BraceGroup('011'), '*A_', BraceGroup('111'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '*A_', BraceGroup('011'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '&\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_2*', TexCmd('tau'), '_3^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '  \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('| l || c | c |')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The minimal loops in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' of length below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_A+2l_B'], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:ShortGeodesics')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:table')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nDenoting the minimum marked length map for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), ' by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), '\none sees that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '_m^', BraceGroup('2l_A+l_B'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X_2))'], []), ' is the normal\nsubgroup of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X_2)'], []), ' generated by all homotopy classes of loops that are\nfreely homotopic to one of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '_1, ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ,', TexCmd('tau'), '_5'], []), ', which is also\nequal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '_m^', BraceGroup('2l_A+l_B+', TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X_2))'], []), ' for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<', TexCmd('epsilon'), TexCmd('le'), ' l_B - l_A'], []), '.  \nWe deduce that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2l_A+l_B'], []), ' is not a jump of the filtration ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Fil')]), '_m^', TexCmd('bullet'), TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X_2)'], []), ',\nso that by Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop:filter')]), ' the number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_A+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'l_B'], []), ' is not in the\ncovering spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_2'], []), '.\n\nTo complete the proof we will show that the class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X_1,x_0)'], []), ' \nof any loop in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), ' based at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_0'], []), ', that is freely homotopic\nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_6'], []), ', does not lie in the normal subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X_1,x_0)'], []), ' generated by the classes of all loops based at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_0'], []), '\nthat are freely homotopic to one of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), '_5'], []), '.\nTo see this, consider the topological quotient space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), '\nthat one obtains by contracting the loops ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), '_5'], []), ' to a\npoint. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' lies in the kernel of the induced group homomorphism\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1(X_1)', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1(K)'], []), ', but one sees from the graph in Figure\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Graph1')]), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), ' does not map to the trivial class.  Since\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_6'], []), ' has length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2l_A+l_B'], []), ', and this length is minimal in its free\nhomotopy class, it follows with Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop:filter')]), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_A+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'l_B'], []), ' lies in the covering spectrum of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_1'], []), '.  \n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('From Cayley graphs to isospectral surfaces')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Sec:Surfaces')]), '\n', '\n', '\nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a group and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' is a subset of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\nFor any set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' with a right action of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' we defined the Cayley graph\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V', '[', 'S', ']'], []), ' with vertex set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' and edge set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' consisting of an edge from \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['xs'], []), ' for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), ' S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x ', TexCmd('in'), ' V'], []), '.\nWe can construct a surface out of this graph as follows (cf. ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Chapter 11'), BraceGroup('Buser')]), ').\n\nSuppose that we have a compact connected surface of genus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '.\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=', '\\#', 'S'], []), ', then we add ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' handles to the surface,\nand on this surface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' we choose a Riemannian metric.\nWe now cut open the handles to obtain a compact surface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2n'], []), ' border components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'B_s, ', TexCmd('overline'), ' B_s', TexCmd('colon'), '\\;', ' s', TexCmd('in'), ' S', '\\}'], []), ',\nwhere for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), ' B'], []), ' a homeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_s', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('overline'), ' B_s'], []), '\nis given so that identifying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_s'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline'), ' B_s'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), ' S'], []), '\ngives us ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  In Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Genus2')]), ' this is illustrated for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=0'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=2'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width = 2.5in'), BraceGroup('TwoHoled2')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Cutting a surface of genus two along two curves')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:Genus2')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nWith this building block we can now make a surface as follows.  Take the\nsurface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'", TexCmd('times'), ' V'], []), ' and for every edge from an element ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), ' V'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['xs', TexCmd('in'), ' V'], []), '\nof color ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), ' S'], []), ' we identify ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_s', TexCmd('times'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline'), '\nB_s', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '\\{', 'xs', '\\}'], []), ' using the homeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_s', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('overline'), ' B_s'], []), '.  We will\ndenote this quotient by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'V;S', ']'], []), '. It is a compact surface,\nand it is not hard to see that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V', '[', 'S', ']'], []), ' is connected, then \nthe genus of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'V;S', ']'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1+(g+n-1)', '\\#', 'V'], []), '.\n\nA Riemannian metric on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' then gives rise to a Riemannian metric on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'V;S', ']'], []), ' and it follows that any color-preserving graph automorphism of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V', '[', 'S', ']'], []), ' induces an isometry\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'V;S', ']'], []), '. Thus, for any subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' we find that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' acts freely and by isometries on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'G;S', ']'], []), ' and the manifolds\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H', TexCmd('backslash'), ' M', '[', 'G;S', ']'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'H', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G;S', ']'], []), " are isometric.\n\nThis set-up allows us to produce isospectral manifolds\nby Sunada's method.\nWe recall that a triple of groups ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(G, H_1, H_2)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1, H_2 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' G'], []), ' is\nsaid to be a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Gassmann-Sunada triple')]), ' if for any conjugacy class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C\n', TexCmd('subset'), ' G'], []), ' we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\#', '(C ', TexCmd('cap'), ' H_1) = ', '\\#', '(C ', TexCmd('cap'), ' H_2)'], []), '.  \nThis group theoretic notion identifies the configurations of isospectral\nmanifolds in the sense of the following theorem.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thm', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Thm:SunadaPesce')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a finite group acting freely on a closed connected manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2'], []), ' \nbe subgroups of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. Then the following are equivalent.\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Sunada, Pesce2')]))]), ' \n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nThe fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1)'], []), ' implies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(2)'], []), ' is the well-known theorem of Sunada ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Sunada')]), ' \nand the reverse implication follows from the work of Pesce ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Pesce2')]), ". \n\nTo apply Sunada's method to our manifolds associated to Cayley graphs, suppose\nthat ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2'], []), ' are two subgroups of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(G,H_1,H_2)'], []), ' is a\nGassmann-Sunada triple.  The theorem above then implies\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'H_1', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G;S', ']'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', '[', 'H_1', TexCmd('backslash'), ' G;S', ']'], []), ' are isospectral. \nWe can now finish the proof of our main result.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nThe group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('Gl')]), TexCmd('mathbb'), ' FG=_3(_2)'], []), ' and the subgroups ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_2'], []), ' of the previous\nsection form a Gassmann-Sunada triple. metric on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '. \nFor each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '> 0'], []), ' we choose a metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g^', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(M', '[', 'V_2;S', ']', ',g_2^', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ' are isospectral for\nevery~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), '.
