Groot')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('Rotational Doppler beaming in eclipsing binaries')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('Paul J. Groot', TexCmd('altaffilmark', [BraceGroup('1,2')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('affil', [BraceGroup('Cahill Center for Astronomy and Astrophysics, California\n  Institute of Technology, 1200 East California Boulevard, Pasadena, CA 91125')]), '\n', TexCmd('affil', [BraceGroup('Department of Astrophysics/IMAPP, Radboud University Nijmegen,\n  P.O.Box 9010, 6500 GL, Nijmegen, The Netherlands')]), ' \n', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('pgroot@astro.ru.nl')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nIn eclipsing binaries the stellar rotation of the two components will\ncause a rotational Doppler beaming during eclipse ingress and egress\nwhen only part of the eclipsed component is covered. For eclipsing\nbinaries with fast spinning components this photometric analogue of\nthe well-known spectroscopic Rossiter-McLaughlin effect can exceed the\nstrength of the orbital effect. Example light curves are shown for a\ndetached double white dwarf binary, a massive O-star binary and a\ntransiting exoplanet case, similar to WASP-33b. Inclusion of the\nrotational Doppler beaming in eclipsing systems is a prerequisite for\nderiving the correct stellar parameters from fitting high quality\nphotometric light curves and can be used to determine stellar\nobliquities as well as e.g. an independent measure of the rotational\nvelocity in those systems that may be expected to be fully\nsynchronized. \n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('keywords', [BraceGroup('binaries: eclipsing --- methods: observational --- stars: rotation ---\n  white dwarfs --- techniques: photometric')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nDoppler beaming in stellar binaries was first discussed, in the\ncontext of stellar rotation, by Hills ', '\\&', ' Dale (1974), after which it\nled a dormant life until it was rediscussed in the context of orbital\nmotion by Maxted, Marsh ', '\\&', ' North (2000). The general theory was\nextensively discussed in Loeb ', '\\&', ' Gaudi (2003) and Zucker, Mazeh ', '\\&', '\nAlexander (2007) for stellar binaries and star-planet cases in the\ncontext of to the orbital motion of the components in a\nbinary. Because the flux density, F', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ',0')], []), ' at a frequency ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is\nnot a Lorentz-invariant quantity by itself, a brightening or dimming\nof the observed flux occurs depending on the radial velocity of the\nobject.\n\nIn short, for non-relativistic velocities the\nbeamed flux, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' at frequency ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' depends on the radial velocity\n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_r'], []), ') and spectral slope (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ') as (Eq. 2 from Loeb ', '\\&', ' Gaudi,\n2003):\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nF_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = F_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ',0'), '[', ' 1+ (3-', TexCmd('alpha'), ')', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v_r'), BraceGroup('c')]), ']', ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' F_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ',0'), ' B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ',v_r'), ', ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:beaming')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ',0')], []), ' is the unbeamed signal and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' depends on the\nobserving frequency and spectral slope of the object. Eq. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:beaming')]), ' defines the beaming factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ',v_r')], []), '. \nFor blackbodies\nat a temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' eff')], []), ' one can approximate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' with Eq. 3\nfrom Loeb ', '\\&', ' Gaudi (2003) or Zucker et al. (2007):\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '(', TexCmd('nu'), ') = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^x(3-x)-3'), BraceGroup('e^x-1')]), ' = 3 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x e^x'), BraceGroup('e^x-1')]), ',  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:alpha')]), '\n'], []), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' h ', TexCmd('nu'), '/kT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' eff')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), " Planck's and\n  Boltzmann's constants, respectively. \n\nObservationally, Doppler beaming has been detected in a small number\nof binaries so far. Van Kerkwijk et al. (2010) used the excellent\nphotometric quality of the ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' Kepler'), ' satellite to demonstrate the\nexistence of Doppler beaming in two binary systems consisting of an\nA-type star and a white dwarf orbiting each other in 5.2 days and 23.9\ndays, respectively. Subsequently the same effect has been found in a\nsubdwarf B - white dwarf binary with a 9.6 hour orbital period by\nBloemen et al. (2010), also using ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' Kepler'), ' data, in the transiting\nmassive Jupiter/low-mass brown dwarf plus F3-type main sequence star\nsystem CoroT-3b, with a 4.3 day orbital period by Mazeh ', '\\&', ' Faigler (2010),\nand in the eclipsing, detached double white dwarf systems NLTT', '\\,', '11748\nand SDSS', '\\,', 'J0651+38 in ground-based photometric data by Shporer et\nal. (2010) and Brown et al. (2011). \n\nApart from the Doppler beaming due to the orbital motion of the two\nstars in a binary, the same effect will also occur due to the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), '\n  rotational'), ' velocity of the stars. This was the original, but\nincomplete, context of Hills ', '\\&', ' Dale (1974) and it has also been\nmentioned briefly by Van Kerkwijk et al. (2010).  As the star spins on\nits rotational axis half of the star will be moving towards the\nobserver and half of it will be moving away from the observer. In\nnon-eclipse conditions and for axisymmetric stars the combined beaming\neffect of these two halves exactly cancels. However, during eclipse\ningress and egress the partial coverage of the eclipsed component in\nthe binary will break the symmetry and a net beaming will be the\nresult. The amplitude of the beaming is set by the flux-weighted\neffect of the non-eclipsed part of the star and will be simulated in\nSection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:simu')]), ' for three cases. A fourth case, of solar-type\nbinaries, has subsequently been discussed by Shporer et al. (2011). \n\nIn radial velocity studies, the related shift in the observed radial\nvelocity of spectral lines during ingress and egress is well known as\nthe Rossiter-McLaughlin effect, as first shown by Rossiter (1924) and\nMcLaughlin (1924). The shape, amplitude and asymmetry of the\nRossiter-McLaughlin effect can be used to derive the projected\nrotational velocity of the star, prograde or retrograde rotation and\nthe obliquity of the binary orbit with respect to the stellar\ncomponents. A detection of the rotational Doppler beaming (or\nphotometric Rossiter-McLaughlin effect) may open up a photometric way\nof determining these same parameters in eclipsing binaries,\nsubstituting high spectral resolution studies with high\nsignal-to-noise photometric time series. For very short period\nbinaries such as the recently reported 12 minute orbital period\ndetached white dwarf binary SDSS', '\\,', 'J0651+28 (Brown et al., 2011) the\neffect can, in principle, also be used for an independent\ndetermination of the spin-orbit coupling of the components to the\norbit.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Rotational Doppler beaming')]), '\n', '\nFor a spherical star with radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' the radial component ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(v_r)'], []), ' of\nthe rotational velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot')], []), ' simply scales as \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nv_r = v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x'), BraceGroup('R')]), ') ', TexCmd('sin'), ' i,\n'], []), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x,y,z'], []), ' a right-handed coordinate system with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ',', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' defining\nthe orbital plane, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' in the direction of orbital angular\nmomentum for an edge-on system. In our sign convention prograde\nrotation of the stars with respect to the orbit results in positive\nrotational velocities. The orbital inclination with respect to the\nplane of the sky, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ', is defined, as usual, to be 0', TexCmd('degr'), ' for a\nface-on orbit and 90', TexCmd('degr'), ' for an edge-on orbit.\n\nThe maximum rotational velocity of a star is set by its break-up\nvelocity, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' break'), ' = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('MG'), BraceGroup('R')]))])], []), ', and its minimum\nvelocity is in principle unbounded, but, in short-period systems where\ntidal forces are strong enough to synchronize the system, will be set\nby the synchronisation velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sync'), '= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' R'), BraceGroup('P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\n    orb'))])], []), '. In wide binaries where tidal synchronization is\nineffective, there is no hard lower limit to the rotational velocity\nof each of the components.  In these equations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is the mass of one\nof the components of the binary, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' the radius of this component,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' orb')], []), ' the binary orbital period and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), " Newton's gravitational\nconstant. For main-sequence stars maximum rotational velocities are\nreached for early-type stars and can exceed 300 km s", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. After the\nonset of the magnetic dynamo around spectral type F1V, when stars\ndevelop a convective outer layer, the rotational velocity drops very\nquickly due to magnetic braking (see e.g. Groot, Piters ', '\\&', ' Van\nParadijs, 1996). In white dwarfs very high rotational velocities can\nbe reached. Using the Eggleton mass-radius relation for fully\ndegenerate white dwarfs as reported by Verbunt ', '\\&', ' Rappaport (1988), a\n1.2 M', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', TexCmd('odot')], []), ' white dwarf can have a break-up velocity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['>'], []), '6', '\\,', '000 km\ns', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('angle=-90,width=14cm'), BraceGroup('f1.ps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Simulated eclipses (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' bottom'), ') and the photometric\n  Doppler beaming factor (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' B', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ', v_r')], []), ', top'), ') for three eclipsing\n  binary systems: a detached double degenerate system (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), '\n    left'), '), a massive O-type binary (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' middle'), ') and a planet\n  around an A-star (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' right'), '). Inserts show close-ups of the light\n  curve and beaming profile during the eclipses. Thick lines are for\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot'), ' = 0.5v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' break')], []), ' and thin lines are for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\n    rot'), ' = v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sync')], []), ', except for the star-planet case where the\n  thin line is for v', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot')], []), ' = 86.5 km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]))]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('System parameters used in the simulations shown in\n  Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:system')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('tableline'), TexCmd('tableline'), '\nParameter & double degenerate & O/B star & A-star+planet\n\n', TexCmd('tableline'), '\nM', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_1'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', TexCmd('odot')], []), ')   &0.43  & 80  & 1.495 \nM', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', TexCmd('odot')], []), ')   &0.17  & 20  & 0.00392 \nR', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_1'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', TexCmd('odot')], []), ')   &0.0148  & 14 & 1.44 \nR', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', TexCmd('odot')], []), ')   &0.0214  & 6.1 &0.153  \nT', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_1'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ')          &10', '\\,', '000 &47', '\\,', '800 &6', '\\,', '440 \nT', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ')          &16', '\\,', '485 &34', '\\,', '200 &1', '\\,', '657 \nP', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' orb')], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ')    &0.0027  &10.00  &1.22  \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('degr')], []), ')& 90.0     & 90.0 & 90.0 \nK', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_1'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['km', '\\,', ' s^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ')  &218.8  &9.2  & 0.5 \nK', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['km', '\\,', ' s^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ')  &553.5  &36.7  &185.9  \nv', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot,1')], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['km', '\\,', ' s^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ') &1', '\\,', '148.8 ', '\\&', ' 27.7  & 510.0 ', '\\&', ' 70.9  & 217.4 ', '\\&', ' 86.4  \nv', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot,2')], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['km', '\\,', ' s^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ') & 601.3 ', '\\&', ' 40.0  & 386.3 ', '\\&', ' 30.9  &  34.1 ', '\\&', ' 6.4 \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_1'], []), ' ', '& 0.36 &1.72 &--0.81 \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_2'], []), ' ', '& 1.10 &1.61 &--11.47 \n', TexCmd('tableline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('llll')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Simulations')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:simu')]), "\n To illustrate the rotational beaming effect we used Kepler's laws,\n the white dwarf mass-radius relation mentioned above, a massive star\n main-sequence mass-radius relation (at solar metallicity) from Pols\n et al.  (1998), stars with no limb darkening (but, see\n Sect. ", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:limbdarkening')]), ') and Eqs. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:beaming')]), ' ', '\\&', '\n ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:alpha')]), '. The two stars are denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_2'], []), ' with\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_1'], []), ' the more massive object, and the mass ratio ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q = M_2/M_1 <\n 1'], []), '. Each star is given a blackbody spectrum characterized by the\n effective temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' eff')], []), '. The orbital Doppler beaming has\n been included in the simulations, but, for clarity and simplicity,\n additional effects such as ellipsoidal variations, the reflection\n effect and gravitational lensing have not been included. For\n illustration purposes all binaries are assumed to be seen exactly\n edge-on (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), '=90', TexCmd('degr'), ').  Three types of binaries have been simulated\n and an overview of system parameters is given in\n Table ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:system')]), ': a detached white dwarf - white dwarf binary\n similar to the one recently reported recently by Kilic et al. (2011)\n at an orbital period of 39 minutes; a massive O-star binary\n consisting of two main sequence stars of 20 M', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', TexCmd('odot')], []), ' and 80\n M', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', TexCmd('odot')], []), ' in a 10 day period orbit; and a transiting exoplanet around\n a fast rotating A-type star, similar to the WASP-33b system (Collier\n Cameron et al., 2010).  For each system the effect is shown for an\n effective wavelength of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), '=6000 ', TexCmd('AA'), ', which, together with the\n effective temperature, determines the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' factor in\n Eq. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:alpha')]), '. In all three systems the rotational velocity of\n both components is varied between break-up and synchronization. For\n the WASP-33b-like exoplanet case, the measured rotational velocity of\n the A-star (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot'), TexCmd('sin'), ' i = 86.5'], []), ' km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ') was also\n simulated. The orbital phase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is defined with respect to\n superior conjunction of the secondary. The projected surface area of\n the components has been divided in a 2', '\\,', '000', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '2', '\\,', '000 grid with\n dimensions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2R ', TexCmd('times'), ' 2R'], []), ', where positive values for the flux and\n rotational velocity were assigned for all values within a radius\n equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ', and all points outside ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' were set to zero. Fluxes\n were assigned as relative to the other component in the binary, with\n the flux of the secondary component set to unity. The position of the\n two components along the orbit was calculated for 4', '\\,', '000 phase\n bins. At each phase bin the projected areal overlap between the two\n components has been calculated and the flux from the eclipsed\n component adjusted accordingly. A flux-weighted mean rotational\n velocity of the star is calculated, and checked to be consistent with\n zero (within the numerical noise and finite grid width) for all\n phases outside of the primary or secondary eclipse.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('angle=-90,width=8.4cm'), BraceGroup('f2.ps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Beaming factors for a detached double degenerate system as\n  in Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), ', but now with both components obliquely\n  rotating with respect to the orbital plane at an angle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ', as\n  indicated in the four sub panels. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:oblique')]))]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), ' shows the results for the three binaries in\neach of the three panels. The top panels shows the total Doppler\nbeaming factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ', v_r')], []), ' for both components in the\nbinary. For clarity both the orbital effect (the slow sinusoidal\nvariation with a period equal to the orbital period) as well as the\nrotational effect (the excursions on top of the orbital variations\nduring eclipse ingress and egress) are shown. In each\nfigure the thick line indicates both components rotating at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\n  rot'), ' = 0.5 v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' break')], []), ' and the thin line has both\ncomponents rotating at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot'), ' = v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sync')], []), ' with the exception\nof the panel on the transiting planet, where the star has been set to\nrotate at the measured rotational velocity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' rot'), ' = 86.5'], []), ' km\ns', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), ' shows that for substantial rotational\nvelocity of the luminous component in the binary, the rotational\nDoppler beaming effect can be as large or larger than the orbital\nvariation, similar to the spectroscopic Rossiter-McLaughlin effect\n(Gaudi ', '\\&', ' Winn, 2007). It is also clear from Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), ' that a correct\ninclusion of the rotational Doppler beaming is a prerequisite is to\nderive the correct parameters of the components in the binary from\neclipse light curve fitting when very high quality data on a promising\nsystem is available.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('angle=-90,width=8.4cm'), BraceGroup('f3.ps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Beaming factors for a transiting extrasolar planet as in\n  Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), ',\n  not-including any limb-darkening ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' ', '(left)'), ' and realistic limb\n  darkening using a quadratic limb darkening law with coefficients\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_a'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_b'], []), ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' ', '(right)'), '. Rotational velocities of the A-star\n  primary are as given in Tab. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:system')]), ': 217.4 km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '\n  ', '(thick line) and 86.4 km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' ', '(thin line).  \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:limb')]))]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Obliquity and limb darkening')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:limbdarkening')]), '\n', '\nThe shape and amplitude of the rotational Doppler beaming effect not\nonly depends on the rotational velocity. Various other effects will\nplay a role in determining the exact shape: the inclination of the\norbit and the obliquity of the rotational axis, oblateness and axial\nsymmetry of the stars, limb-darkening and/or limb-brightnening, and\ndifferential rotation. In non-eclipsing, but highly distorted systems,\nwhere, e.g. one of the components is (nearly) filling its Roche lobe\nand is for instance irradiated asymmetrically by an accretion disk hot\nspot, the asymmetric distribution of light on the distorted star can\neven lead to ellipsoidal terms on the orbital signal. For the moment,\nhowever, these highly distorted systems will not be considered and\nonly an illustration of the obliquity and limb darkening will be\ngiven.\n\nThe  same double  degenerate  binary as  in  Sect. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:simu')]), '  is\ntaken, but  now the obliqueness,  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ', of the rotational  axis of\nthe  two stars with  respect to  the orbital  plane is  varied between\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), '   =  30', TexCmd('degr'), ',  45', TexCmd('degr'), ',   90', TexCmd('degr'), '\\,', '  ', '(oblique   rotator)  and\n180', TexCmd('degr'), '\\,', '   ', '(retrograde  rotator).   As  expected,   the   effect  of\nobliqueness  of the  rotational  axis is  to  decrease and  eventually\nreverse the  amplitude of the  beaming. If a  star is precessing  in a\nbinary  this  will  present  itself  as a  changing  obliqueness  with\ntime.  An  observational  detection  through  the  rotational  Doppler\nbeaming  would allow e.g.  a determination  of the  spin-orbit angular\nmomentum coupling in close binaries and/or hierarchical triples.\n\nLimb darkening is a fundamental property of stellar atmospheres which\nis reasonably well understood in main-sequence stars, but not so much\nin white dwarf atmospheres. In helium dominated, high density white\ndwarf atmospheres limb darkening could even be largely absent due to\ninternal refraction within the atmosphere (Kowalski ', '\\&', ' Saumon, 2004).\n\nUsing a quadratic limb darkening law, \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nF_', TexCmd('nu'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ') = F_0 ', '[', '1 - u_a(1-', TexCmd('mu'), ') - u_b(1-', TexCmd('mu'), ')^2', ']', ', ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:limb')]), '\n'], []), ' \nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('cos'), TexCmd('xi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), ' the angle between the normal to the\nsurface and the line of sight of the observer to describe the limb\ndarkening, Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:limb')]), ' shows the effect for the transiting\nplanet case (Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), '), for limb darkening coefficients of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_a'], []), '=0.29 and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_b'], []), '=0.31, appropriate for a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' eff')], []), ' = 6', '\\,', '440 K\nstar in the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' Kepler'), " pass band (Sing 2010). The general effect of\nlimb darkening is to `soften' the edges of a star, from which it is\nconceptually easy to deduce that it will impact the height of the\nrotational Doppler beaming, in the same way that it affects the\nRossiter-McLaughlin effect. The contribution to the total light from\nthe most extremely beamed parts of the stars is lessened for a positive\nlimb darkening. Fig. ", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:limb')]), ' shows that indeed not\nonly the amplitude of the Doppler beaming is supressed, but also the\nskewness of the profile is significantly reduced. It is clear from\nthis figure that a realistic modeling of transiting planet light\ncurves where the Doppler beaming is included, needs to include a limb\ndarkening term as well. However, if indeed, in high density, helium\ndominated white dwarf atmospheres the limb darkening coefficient is\nclose to zero, the resulting rotational Doppler beaming should hardly\nbe affected and may still show the sharp edges displayed in\nFig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Detectability')]), '\n', '\nThe ultimate goal of these investigations would of course be to first\ndetect and subsequently use the rotational Doppler beaming to\ndetermine and constrain stellar and binary parameters. As can be seen\nfrom Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), ' even in the best of cases, such as the\ndouble degenerates, this detection is going to be challenging. The\nfractional amplitude of the rotational beaming varies between 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('mathrel', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rlap', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lower'), '.55ex ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim')], []))]))]), '\n                   ', TexCmd('kern'), '-.3em ', TexCmd('raise'), '.4ex ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<'], []))]))])), BraceGroup('-3')]), TexCmd('mathrel', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rlap', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lower'), '.55ex ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim')], []))]))]), '\n                   ', TexCmd('kern'), '-.3em ', TexCmd('raise'), '.4ex ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<'], []))]))]))]), '\n B_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ', v_r'), '  10^', BraceGroup('-6')], []), '. To firmly establish the shape\nand amplitude the photometric accuracy needed would be a factor 10\nsmaller than this amplitude at least. The ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' Kepler'), ' light curves\nshow precisions in the 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-4')], []), ' - 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-5')], []), ' range, and it should\ntherefore be possible to detect the effect. In fact, a close look at\nFig.', '\\,', " 3 in Bloemen et al. (2010) appears to show a residual effect in\nthe primary eclipse profile, by comparing their `R.+E.+L.+Beaming'\npanel with the inset in the left panel of Fig. ", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), ' in\nSect. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:simu')]), ". However, this `by eye' residual, does not\nclearly show up in the `Residuals' panel in Fig.", '\\,', ' 3 in Bloemen et\nal. (2010).\n\nIn general the detectability is a combination of source flux, eclipse\nduration, instrument stability and intrinsic amplitude. Source flux\ncan be optimized using a bigger telescope, eclipse duration is\nunfortunately a given for an individual source, instrument stability\nis in the design of the instrument and tends to be highest for space\nmissions, even though modern photometers on the ground now achieve\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' Kepler'), '-like precision (e.g. de Mooij et al., 2011). For a more\nformal derivation of detectability I refer to Shporer et al. (2011),\nbut the recently detected, eclipsing 12 minute orbital period binary\nSDSS', '\\,', 'J0651+28 (Brown et al., 2011) makes for an illustrative\nexample. Using the stellar parameters listed in Brown et al. (2011)\nand assuming a fully edge-on, aligned and synchronized system (but see\nPiro 2011), the fractional amplitude of the Doppler beaming would be\n1.3', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), '. The best way to determine the rotational beaming\nsignal is to determine the light curve shape during primary\nmid-eclipse (inset of Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:simu')]), '), which for SDSS', '\\,', 'J0651+28\nlasts for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim')], []), '0.05P', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' orb')], []), '. As a rule of thumb I will use a\nminimum of 10 samples per eclipse and a photometric precision of a\ntenth of the amplitude to be a minimum for a positive detection of the\neffect, i.e. for SDSS', '\\,', 'J0651+28 a precision of 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-4')], []), ' in the\nphotometry needs to be obtained in 4 seconds on a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=19.06'], []), ' magnitude\nobject. Assuming only Poisson statistics as a noise-contributor one\ntherefore needs to collect 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('8')], []), ' photons per 4 seconds interval,\nrequiring the equivalent of a 180-meter telescope, even far out of\nreach in the ELT era', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Here I have used a photon flux of 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^6'], []), '\n  photons s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' cm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' for a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), "=0 object at the top of the\n  Earth's atmosphere")]), '. Of course, assuming perfect stability in the\nsource, one can stack an arbitrary number of orbits to achieve the\nsame precision. Even on a 10-meter class telescope this would require\nthe stacking of more than a thousand orbits, which is unfeasible in\nthe short run, unless we find a system that is 5-6 magnitudes brighter\nin the sky than SDSS', '\\,', 'J0651+28.\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), '\nA much more promising case is presented by the O-type binaries, where\nthe orbital period is much longer (10 days in our example), and,\nalthough mid-eclipse lasts for a shorter part of the orbital period,\nroughly 0.025P', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' orb')], []), ", the `tenth of mid-eclipse' requirement\ntranslates into 36 minutes during which to collect the signal. The\nfractional amplitude is now only ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup('-4')], []), ', requiring a precision at the\n10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-5')], []), ' level, but ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sl'), ' Kepler'), ' has shown this to be\nfeasible. We now need to collect the photons at a rate of\n4.5', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('6')], []), ' per second.  If our hypothetical binary were to\nbe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '=14.0, this is achievable on a 4-m class telescope by stacking a\nmodest number of orbits (order 10), again assuming perfect source and\ninstrument stability. In practice of course, atmospheric and\nelectronic (detector) stability may very well be the limiting factor. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Discussion and conclusion')]), '\n', "\nFor very high quality data on eclipsing systems inclusion of the\neffect of rotational Doppler beaming in light curve fitting procedures\nis necessary to derive the correct parameters of the binary. Since\nDoppler beaming is a geometrical effect, not including it will lead\nto a systematic error in the parameter derivation. The sign and\nmagnitude of the error depends very much on the system properties of\nthe binary. In prograde rotating binaries the extra `dimming' of the\nbinary at ingress and the extra `brightnening' during egress will\ncause an asymmetric eclipse profile that will skew a timing solution\nto a mid-eclipse phase that is too early. For retrograde rotation the\neffect on the timing will be the opposite.\n\nFrom the simulations shown here it is clear that the detection of\nrotational Doppler beaming should be a mere matter of time and depends\non the availability of suitable systems more than on the accuracy of\ncurrent photometric systems. The most promising case would be a\nnon-synchronously rotating eclipsing double degenerate system, if it\nis bright enough (", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V<15'], []), '). Currently none of these are known.\nObservationally there is a strong bias to find eclipsing double\ndegenerates in short-period systems where the ratio of the white dwarf\nradius over the orbital separation is smallest and the system will be\nobserved to be eclipsing over a wider range of inclinations.\nUnfortunately short-period double-detached binaries also have the\nhighest probability of (nearly) synchronous rotation since they are the product\nof two episodes of common-envelope evolution (e.g. Nelemans et al.,\n2001). This assumption does, however, depend strongly on the\nrotational coupling of the core of a red giant to its outer envelope\n(Sweigart ', '\\&', ' Mengel, 1979), and on the time scale of the\ncommon-envelope phase itself compared to the synchronisation time\nscale (see e.g. Taam ', '\\&', " Sandquist, 2000).  Since the common-envelope\nphase is expected to be relatively short, a decoupled core may remain\nunsynchronized. Prime targets should therefore be young, hot, white\ndwarfs, or even cores of planetary nuclei, in short period systems\nwith another white dwarf, i.e. just after the `birth' of the second\nwhite dwarf in the system. It is unfortunate that the central binaries\nin the nova - planetary nebula system V458 Vul (Wesson et al., 2009;\nRodr", BraceGroup("\\'", TexCmd('i')), 'guez-Gil et al., 2010) and the planetary nebula system Hen\n2--248 (Santander-Garc', BraceGroup("\\'", TexCmd('i')), 'a et al., 2010) do not appear to be\neclipsing as these would have been almost ideal systems. The eclipsing\ndouble degenerate system NLT', '\\,', ' 11448 (Steinfadt et al. 2010) is also\nan obvious candidate for detection of rotational Doppler\nbeaming. Although promising at first we have shown that the faintness\nadn short period of SDSS', '\\,', 'J0651+28 makes it a much harder target. \n\nAlthough the expected effect is a factor 10 smaller than in double\ndegenerate systems, eclipsing O/B stars are perhaps an even more\npromising class of candidates. In general the orbital periods will be\nmuch longer (days instead of hours), which causes the eclipse ingress\nand egress to last much longer, and therefore also allows for the\naccumulation of very high signal-to-noise ratio data. Since accurate\nphotometry requires the presence of many comparison stars to obtain\nhigh precision differential light curves, slightly fainter, far-away\nand/or reddened O/B binaries in the magnitude range 10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<V<'], []), '15 may be\nmore attractive candidates than very bright (V', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<'], []), '10) nearby systems.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BracketGroup('Bloemen et al. (2010)'), BraceGroup('bloemen2010')]), ' Bloemen, S., Marsh, T.R.,\n  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('O')), 'stensen, R.H., Charpinet, S., Fontaine, G., Degroote, P.,\n    Heber, U, et al., 2010, ', TexCmd('mnras'), ', 410, 1787\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BracketGroup('Brown et al. (2011)'), BraceGroup('brown2011')]), ' Brown, W.R., Kilic, M.,\n  Hermes, J.J., Allende Prieto, C., Kenyon, S., Winget, D.E., 2011,\n  ApJ 737, L23\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BracketGroup('Collier Cameron et al. (2010)'), BraceGroup('collier2010')]), ' Collier Cameron\n  A., G', '\\"', 'unther, E., Smalley, B., McDonald, I., Hebb, L., Andersen,\n  J., Augusteijn, Th., et al., 2010, ', TexCmd('mnras'), ', 407, 507\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BracketGroup('Gaudi ', '\\&', ' Winn (2007))')]), ' Gaudi, B.S. Its exponential decay is apparent for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x > 8'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('vskip'), ' .5cm \n'], []), '\n', '\nLet us see how the numerical DMRG would actually proceed for the chain\nof coupled harmonic oscillators (see also Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CaMou')]), '). \nSince the Hilbert space for a single\noscillator already has infinite dimension, one must begin by\ntruncating the initial Hilbert space to a finite and rather small\nnumber of states ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' per site'), ', '], []), 'n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' say.  \nThen one obtains the ground state, with energy\n'], []), '(1/2)', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('-N'), '^', BraceGroup('N'), TexCmd('omega'), '_k', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', '], []), TexCmd('omega'), '_k', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' being the frequencies of the\n'], []), 'N', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' normal modes '], []), 'a_k', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '(of ordinary canonical quantization). \nFrom the ground state, one derives the corresponding density\nmatrix of half of the chain. This can be done numerically, but\nanalytically as well, since the integral for the density matrix is\nGaussian ', '[', 'see Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('DM0')]), ')', ']', ".\nIn White's original algorithm ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('White')]), ', one begins\nwith only one site, which is reflected on the origin, to compute the\ntwo-site ground state and the one-site density matrix. \nNext, one discards its smallest eigenvalues and iterates: one adds one\nsite at the center with their '], []), 'n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' new states, reflects, etc.  In the\npresent case, the one-site density matrix is Gaussian and therefore \nequivalent to the thermal matrix of one single oscillator, \nwith a temperature \nincreasing with the coupling strength. Thus it has the form \n'], []), TexCmd('exp'), '(-2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('H'), ')', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', where '], []), '2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('H'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is '], []), TexCmd('beta'), '\\,', 'H', TexMathModeEnv('$', [" for \nthe ``equivalent thermal oscillator'' ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Pes')]), '. \n\nFor even '], []), 'N', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', the integral (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('DM0')]), ') is an ordinary integral in '], []), 'N/2', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nvariables. It yields the exponential of a quadratic form, '], []), 'u_R^', BraceGroup('T'), ' A\nu_R+', BraceGroup("u'_R"), '^', BraceGroup('T'), " A u'_R + ", BraceGroup('u_R'), '^', BraceGroup('T'), " B u'_R + ", BraceGroup("u'_R"), '^', BraceGroup('T'), ' B u_R', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', where\n'], []), 'A', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and '], []), 'B', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' are '], []), 'N/2 ', TexCmd('times'), ' N/2', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' symmetric matrices, the former being\npositive definite.  One can then perform a two-step diagonalization of\nthis quadratic form ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Gold')]), ': If we write '], []), 'A = M', '\\,', 'M^T', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', with '], []), 'M', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' a\n'], []), 'N/2 ', TexCmd('times'), ' N/2', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' nonsingular real matrix \n(which is always possible ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('GrRy')]), '), the\ntransformation '], []), 'v = M^Tu', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' puts the first part in canonical form, while\nchanging '], []), 'B arrow M^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'B(', BraceGroup('M^', BraceGroup('-1')), ')^T', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. This matrix can be\ndiagonalized by an orthogonal transformation '], []), TexCmd('O'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [', without altering\nthe canonical form of the other part. The result is that the density\nmatrix becomes the product of density matrices of independent modes.\nConsequently, it adopts the form '], []), TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '(-2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('H'), ')', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', with '], []), '2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('H'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nbeing the sum of the operators '], []), TexCmd('beta'), '\\,', 'H', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' for those modes\n(the equivalent thermal oscillators).\nFurthermore, the total transformation matrix '], []), TexCmd('O'), '^T M^T', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is the discrete\nversion of the functions '], []), 'K_', BraceGroup('i', '\\,', TexCmd('ell')), '(m', '\\,', 'x)', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', such that the first\nindex corresponds to '], []), TexCmd('ell'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' while the second corresponds to '], []), 'x', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. It can be seen that they are a discrete version of functions of the\ntype of that in Fig.~1, although with fewer oscillations. The\nfollowing file vectors correspond to higher '], []), TexCmd('ell'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [', and hence to more\nrapidly oscillating functions, but the discreteness interferes in such\na manner that these oscillations are difficult to perceive.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n  ', TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=8cm ', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('vec2.eps')]), ' \n  ', TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=8cm ', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('vec3.eps'), BraceGroup('Fig.~2. Plots of the second and third line vectors of\n  the matrix of transformation to normal mode variables.')]), '  \n'], []), '\n', '\nThe inclusion of weak anharmonic terms in the action should not\nsubstantially modify the picture above. \nAs mentioned before, in real space the important coupling is actually\nthe kinetic term, which couples \nneighboring points. As regards to calculation, anharmonic terms \nprevent us from obtaining analytic expressions for the angular states \nor performing the functional integrals, which are no longer Gaussian. \nHowever, the effect of those terms amounts to a\nmode-mode coupling, which can be treated perturbatively. \nCanonical methods for perturbation theory in Rindler space \nare exposed in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Un')]), '. On the other hand, it is easy to \nsee how to evaluate the functional integral for the density matrix, \nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('DM0')]), '), in perturbation theory: One must first introduce \nthe coupling to an external current, as usual, and express \nthe interaction term, '], []), 'V(u) = ', TexCmd('lambda'), '\\,', 'u^4', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' say, as a derivative with respect \nto the external current; then, the Gaussian integral can be performed\nand the perturbation series constructed. \nAt any rate, although these perturbative corrections \nmodify the ground and excited-state energies, the\nqualitative properties of the spectrum of '], []), TexCmd('H'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' must remain the same.\n\nWe must remark that, in\nquantum field theory in '], []), '1 + 1', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' dimensions, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), '\nnon-perturbative'), ' phenomena may occur and one must\nhave an idea about the type of spectrum of collective excitations\nbefore applying a perturbative approach, since these effects can turn a \nbosonic spectrum into a fermionic one (or viceversa) ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Abda')]), '.\nIf the collective\nexcitations are bosons, the formulas above would constitute the basis\nfor perturbation theory and the conclusions should not be modified.\nOn the other hand, it should not be difficult to reach analogous\nconclusions for a fermionic spectrum such as, for example, the\nspectrum of the Ising model in a transverse field, which has been the\nsubject of many tests for the DMRG. The field-theory forms of '], []), 'H', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and\n'], []), TexCmd('H'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' given by Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('H')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('L')]), '), respectively, still\nhold. Their particular expressions for the free fermion field are easy\nto obtain.  The form of the angular wavefunctions would be similar to \nthe bosonic ones, already studied.\n\nMoreover, regarding the generality of our conclusions, one can argue\nthat the essence of the DMRG, as concerns the effect of boundary\nconditions, is independent of the type of spectrum or the details of\nperturbation theory.  In a general 1D many-body system that is\nhomogeneous in the continuum limit, such as a system defined on a\nchain with uniform site-to-site coupling, we can always express the\nenergy by the integral (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('H')]), ') and, therefore, the generator of\nrotations as '], []), TexCmd('H'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), ' dx', '\\,', 'x', '\\,', TexCmd('epsilon'), '(x),', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' where '], []), TexCmd('epsilon'), ' :=\nT_', BraceGroup('00'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' does not depend explicitly on '], []), 'x', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.  Suppose that we divide the\nchain into equal-size blocks, with coordinate '], []), 'x_j', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', such that, for\nsufficiently large blocks, we can approximately write '], []), TexCmd('H'), ' = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_j\nx_j', '\\,', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_j', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', except for a small inter-block potential.  If we\nwant to discard eigenvalues of the density matrix '], []), TexCmd('exp'), '(-2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('H'), ')', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nsmaller than certain value, then we are to set an upper cutoff for the\n'], []), TexCmd('H'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' eigenvalues, which then implies a cutoff for every '], []), TexCmd('epsilon'), '_j', TexMathModeEnv('$', [',\nbut depending inversely on '], []), 'j', TexMathModeEnv('$', [': for small '], []), 'j', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', that is, close to the\nboundary, an extensive range of values is included, accounting for the\nprogressive uncertainty in their value as the boundary is approached,\nwhereas for large '], []), 'j', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' only the lowest energy states are allowed.  In\nconclusion, one necessarily has a concentration of quantum states at\nthe boundary, due merely to the existence of this boundary, as in the\ndifferent physics of black holes.\n\nFinally, let us mention that, for a class of integrable models, one can go\nbeyond perturbation theory and, actually, calculate the correlation\nfunctions from the two-body '], []), 'S', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-matrix.  Owing to its relation with \nthe corner transfer matrix, the\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' form-factor'), ' method to calculate the correlation functions for\nthese models is deeply related with angular quantization\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BraLuk')]), '.  In this context, it would be very interesting to\ncompare the results of the DMRG for these models with those of the\nform-factor approach.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('Un')]), ' N.D. A\ngood part of this interest has been devoted to studying the influence\nthat the boundary has on the spectrum of conformal field theories in\n1+1 dimensions, which is known on the whole plane, or to its influence\non integrability properties ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('bound')]), '.  The introduction of a\nboundary has deep effects on the quantization of a statistical model,\nand the conditions at the boundary can actually represent some\nphysical property, for example, an impurity, as in the Kondo model\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Aff')]), '.\n\n\nConsidering a quantum field theory on a segment of a line has an\nadditional utility: the length of the segment is a scale that can be used\nas a renormalization group parameter. \nMore generally, a field theory on any space with an intrinsic scale,\nwhich can be associated to boundaries or to the curvature, possess a\nnatural renormalization group parameter. For example, this is the case of\nhomogeneous surfaces other than the plane.  Furthermore, one can then\ndefine a sort of ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' geometric entropy'), ', which exhibits interesting\nproperties with respect to that renormalization group (RG) ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('I')]), '.\n\nThe above comments hint to a deep relation between certain space-times\n(in particular, those with horizons), density matrices and entropy, on\nthe one side, and scaling and the RG, on the other side. In our case, the particle is a quantized mode, which\ntravels as a wave a distance from the origin proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ' and\nthen vanishes exponentially from the turning-point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x = ', TexCmd('ell'), '/m'], []), ' rightwards\n(see the example in Fig.~1). \n\nFurthermore, at certain distance from the origin this influence vanishes\nexponentially.
