Just finished parsing: ['[', 'E_', BraceGroup('1'), '\\,', ' , +', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', ') .\n', TexCmd('end', [BraceGroup('equation')]), '\nFor energies above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' the two parts overlap and eigenvalues of\nthe discrete spectrum are embedded in the continuum spectrum.\nHowever, the two sub-spectra remain well distinct since the system\nHamiltonian is separable in a transverse (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' plane) and a\nlongitudinal (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' direction) component.  In fact, if a given energy\ncorresponds to a discrete level and, at the same time, it lies inside\nthe continuum, the corresponding state will be degenerate, with the\ndifferent eigenfunctions having a different transverse state.  In\nterms of quantum transport along the QW, the above system does not mix\ndifferent transmission channels or propagating states with bound ones.\n\nLet us now introduce a local twist in the QW. As we will show, this\ncouples different transverse modes, mixing their spectra, and shifts\nthe energy of the discrete states.  The deformation adopted, also\nillustrated in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig1')]), ', is a rotation of the rectangular\ncross-section around its center when moving along the QW axis.  A\npoint of coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(x,y,z)'], []), ' of the straight QW is transformed\naccording\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq5')]), "\nx' &=& x ,  ", TexCmd('nonumber'), " \ny' &=& y", TexCmd('cos', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '(x)')]), '\n+z', TexCmd('sin', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '(x)')]), ",\n   \nz' &=& z", TexCmd('cos', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '(x)')]), '\n-y', TexCmd('sin', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('varphi'), '(x)')]), ' ,\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq6')]), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '(x) = \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Phi')), BraceGroup('2'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('erf')]), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), ')+1')]), '\n'], []), '\nis the rotation angle as a function of the longitudinal position ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '.\nHere, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('erf')])], []), ' is the error function, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi')], []), ' is the total\nrotation angle, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' is a parameter that sets the length of\nthe twisted region. In particular, the QW twist can be considered\neffective in a length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4 ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' around the origin. Outside the\nlatter region, the QW is essentially straight.\n\nFor our simulations, we use GaAs effective electron mass\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m=0.067', '\\,', 'm_e'], []), ' and adopt the following set of geometric parameters:\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_', BraceGroup('y'), '=20'], []), '~nm, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_', BraceGroup('z'), '=10'], []), '~nm, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '=17.5'], []), '~nm (i.e. the twisted\nregion is about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['70'], []), '~nm), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('Phi'), TexCmd('leq'), ' 3', TexCmd('pi')], []), '.  Two attractive\npotentials, as given in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq2')]), '), have been used, both with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_', BraceGroup('p'), '=10'], []), '~nm (i.e. effective on a length of about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['60'], []), '~nm around the\norigin).  They differ by their depth: in the first case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=2.95'], []), '\n', '(corresponding to a minimum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-66.262'], []), '~meV), in the second case\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3.95'], []), ' ', '(corresponding to a minimum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-111.186'], []), '~meV). The\nrelative positions of relevant energy levels are reported in\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), ', for the two cases.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=.7', TexCmd('linewidth')), BraceGroup('fig2.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\nSchematic representation of the relevant energies of the system\nwithout twist for two different magnitudes of the quantum well\ndescribed by Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq2')]), ').  The thresholds of the transport\nchannels, i.e. the transverse modes, are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1=70.155'], []), '~meV,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2=112.248'], []), '~meV, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_3=182.403'], []), '~meV (not shown).  The energy of a\nbound state of the straight QW is indicated with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('n,j')], []), ',\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' indicating the transverse mode, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' the bound state of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' in the longitudinal direction.  While the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_n'], []), "'s are fixed, the\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('n,j')], []), "'s are increased by the twist.  ")]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), '\n'], []), '\nFor brevity, the energies of the discrete states are indicated by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('n,j'), '=E_', BraceGroup('n,0'), '+', TexCmd('mu'), '_j'], []), ' in the following.\nWe stress that the transverse energies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_n'], []), ' are fixed, since the\ncross-section is constant, although rotated. Contrary, the position of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('n,j')], []), ' depends upon the twist, as we will analyze in\ndetail in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec4')]), '. In fact, they are the resonant energies\nthat correspond to a local maximum (Breit-Wigner) or a zero (Fano) in\nthe transmission spectra.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Numerical approach')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec3')]), '\n', '\nTo obtain the transmission amplitudes of the twisted QW we solve the\n3D Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation with open boundaries through the quantum\ntransmitting boundary method~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('lent90')]), ' ', '(QTBM).  Electrons\nare injected from the left lead (see Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig1')]), ') in a given\ntransverse mode, and can be either reflected or transmitted to the\nright lead.  With this boundary condition, the differential\nequation of motion is solved in the internal points of the domain,\nleading to complex transmission/reflection amplitudes for every\nchannel of the right/left leads.\nWe adopt a curved coordinate system naturally defined by the twist\nfunction of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq5')]), ') ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('r')]), '=(x,y,z) ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup("r'")]), "=(x',y',z')"], []), ".  This new coordinate system follows the QW twist and\n``sees'' a straight QW.  However, also the equation of motion must be\ntransformed according to the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('r')]), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup("r'")])], []), ' relation.\nIn order to do so, we need the metric tensor of the system\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('G')]), '(', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('r')]), ')'], []), ' with components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('ij'), '(', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('r')]), ') =\n(', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup("r'")]), ') ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('j'), TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup("r'")]), ')'], []), ', together\nwith its inverse ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('G')]), '^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' with components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '. Here, we\nused the definitions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), '=', TexCmd('partial'), ' / ', TexCmd('partial'), ' x^', BraceGroup('i')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(x,y,z)=(x^', BraceGroup('1'), ',x^', BraceGroup('2'), ',x^', BraceGroup('3'), ')'], []), '.  In the curved coordinate system the\nHamiltonian reads~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('dacosta82,ferrari08')]), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&&', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '(', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('r')]), ') = -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), '^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('2m')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i,j=1'), '^', BraceGroup('3'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('i')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('G')]))]), '\n', '(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('G')]), 'G^', BraceGroup('ij'), TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('j'), ' ', ')              ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&& = -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), '^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('2m')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i,j=1'), '^', BraceGroup('3'), '[', 'G^', BraceGroup('ij'), TexCmd('partial'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), '\n- ( ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k,l=1'), '^', BraceGroup('3'), ' G^', BraceGroup('kl'), TexCmd('partial'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('kl'), '\n', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup("r'")]), TexCmd('cdot'), ' G^', BraceGroup('ij'), TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup("r'")]), ' ', ')\n', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('j'), '   ', ']', ' ,                              ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G>0'], []), ' is the determinant of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), '=', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('j')], []), '.  Now it is easy to\ndefine a rectangular mesh following the QW in the new coordinate\nsystem, and discretize ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' through a finite-difference\nscheme. The corresponding Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('psi'), '=E', TexCmd('psi')], []), ' is then solved, with open boundary conditions\nat the two edges of the QW, as described above.  The QTBM takes as an\ninput the kinetic energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E-E_n>0'], []), ' of the incoming electron and the\nwave function of the transverse mode ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ', and gives as an output the\ntransmission/reflection amplitudes in the different\nchannels~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('cuoghi09')]), '.  For this reason, a new calculation must be\nperformed for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' in a chosen set over the range of interest,\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E>E_n'], []), '.\n\nActually, in order to find the resonances we also used a\ncomplementary technique: the complex scaling approach described in\nAppendix~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('kovarik07')]), '.  This method leads to a complex-eigenvalue\nproblem that allows one to identify in a straightforward way the\nresonances originated by the bound states of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), '.  Moreover, it gives\nthe energy levels of bound states below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), ', not achievable with the\nQTBM.  In fact, the QTBM gives the transmission amplitude of the\ndifferent transverse modes as a function of the carrier energy, and\nthe position of transport resonances must be detected subsequently, as\na relevant peak or dip in the transmission probability and as a\ncontinuum (abrupt) phase shift for a Breit-Wigner (Fano)\nresonance. However, the complex scaling method results to be very\ndemanding from the computational point of view and we used its results\nonly as a reference for specific cases. We leave the comparison of the\ntwo methods to a subsequent work.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Transmission spectra')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec4')]), '\n', '\nAs anticipated in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec2')]), ' the transmission spectra of the\nstraight QW can be obtained from a one-dimensional equation of motion\nwith the potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), '.  In order to mix transmission channels, the\ntransverse/longitudinal separability must be lifted.  However, a\ngeneric deformation of the QW section along the wire, not only couples\ndifferent transverse modes, but also introduces additional resonant\nenergies, as in the case of a closed cavity attached at a\nside~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('price92,porod92')]), '.  This can make difficult to expose the sole\neffect of the coupling between the continuum and discrete spectra.\nFor this reason, as well\nas for technological relevance, we choose a kind of deformation that\ndoes not alter the shape of the QW cross section, but only its\norientation, and does not introduce further resonances.  In fact, the\nQW twist has only two effects: first, it couples the transmission\nchannels so that the transmission probability for a carrier injected in a given\ntransverse mode also has traces of quasi-bound states of different\nmodes; second, it increases the energies of quasi-bound states.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.9', TexCmd('linewidth')), BraceGroup('fig3.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\nTop panel: position of transmission resonances in the ground-mode\nspectrum as a function of the twist angle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi')], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=2.95'], []), '.  The\nresonant energies correspond to the real part of the complex-scaled\neigenvalues.  The threshold energies of the ground and first-excited\ntransverse modes are indicated by the two horizontal lines labeled as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ', respectively. The three curves correspond to the\nquasi-bound states ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' ', '(dotted line), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), '\n', '(dashed line), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ' ', '(solid line). Bottom panel: Imaginary\npart of the complex-scaled eigenvalues, corresponding to the half\nwidth of the resonance peaks or dips. While the two Fano resonances\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), ' ', '(see also Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), ')\ndisappear as they reach ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ' is still present in\nthe spectrum at energies exceeding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ' in the form of a broad and\nshallow dip (see also Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig5')]), ').  ')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), '\n'], []), '\nThese effects can be seen from the two panels of\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), ', where we report the position (top panel) and width\n(bottom panel) of the resonances in the transmission spectrum of the\nground transverse channel, as a function of the twist angle.  In\nparticular, for each angle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi')], []), ' we inject a carrier in the ground\ntransverse mode (with energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), ') and with several longitudinal\nkinetic energies, from zero to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2-E_1'], []), '.  From the curves of\ntransmission amplitude vs. total energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' ', '(see e.g. Figs.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), ' and\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig5')]), ') we determine the position of the resonances and\nobtain the imaginary part of the eigenvalue as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/2'], []), ', where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' is the peak or dip width.  Note that the above complex\neigenvalues correspond to quasi-bound states with a mean lifetime\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hbar'), '/', TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' of the order of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['100'], []), '~ps.\n\nBy comparing Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), ' with the levels of the straight QW given\nin Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), ', the origin of the two resonances at higher energy\n(dotted and dashed lines in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), ') is clear.  In fact, for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), TexCmd('sim'), ' 0'], []), ' only two quasi-bound levels lie between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ',\nnamely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), '.  They both belong to\nchannel ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' so that at zero twist, they do not appear in the\ntransmission spectrum, as it can be gathered from the vanishing\nimaginary part of their eigenvalue in the bottom panel of\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), '.  As the twist is introduced, the two levels above\nappear as slightly asymmetric Fano dips in the transmission\nprobability, as reported in the top panels of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), ' for the\ncase of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi'), '/2'], []), '.  However, the Fano character of the resonances\nis better revealed by the abrupt jump of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' in the transmission\nphase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ', as shown in the bottom panels of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.9', TexCmd('linewidth')), BraceGroup('fig4.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(' Ground-mode transmission probability (upper panels)\nand phase (lower panels) around the resonances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), ' ', '(left\npanels) and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' ', '(right panels) for a twist angle\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi'), '/2'], []), '. In both cases, the phase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' shows the typical\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' discontinuity of Fano resonances.  ')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe third resonance of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), ' ', '(solid line) appears around\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.85 ', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' from the low-energy threshold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), '.  It is\nagain a Fano resonance, as can be gathered from the left panels of\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig5')]), ', showing the transmission probability and phase at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi')], []), '. This is confirmed by results of the complex-scaling\napproach, ascribing the resonance to the quasi-bound level\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.9', TexCmd('linewidth')), BraceGroup('fig5.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(' Ground-mode transmission probability (upper panels)\nand phase (lower panels) around the resonance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ' for two\ndifferent twist angles, namely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' ', '(left panels) and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=2.25', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' ', '(right panels, solid line).  In the first case\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1'), '<E_2'], []), ', and a sharp Fano dip is found. In the second\ncase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1'), '>E_2'], []), ', and its position is only indicated by a\nvery shallow dip. In the latter case, also the transmission spectrum\nof the first-excited mode is reported (dashed line), revealing a\npronounced Breit-Wigner resonance.  \n')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig5')]), '\n'], []), '\nIn fact, as the twist increases from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ', both levels\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('1,3')], []), ' reach the threshold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), '. However,\nwhile the former shows up as a resonance in the transmission spectrum,\nthe latter disappears as it enters the traveling-states region, with its\nimaginary part going to zero.  Again, this behavior can be traced by the\ncomplex scaling method alone, since the lower energy accessible with\nthe QTBM is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), '.\nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ' enters the energy range of first-mode traveling\nstates, it appears as a Fano resonance since it is a second-mode\nquasi-bound state.  Moreover, contrary to the other two resonances, it\nappears with a significant width (bottom panel of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), ')\nfrom the beginning, since at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.85 ', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' the coupling\nbetween the modes is already strong.\n\nWhen the twist increases from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' the three quasi-bound\nlevels described above also increase their energy. However, as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' approach the threshold of the\nsecond channel, their width decreases and they finally disappear, with\nthe width going to zero, when their energy reaches ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), '. The behavior\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ' is different.  In fact, its resonance width is\nalways of the order of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' eV'], []), ' until the energy reaches ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ',\nwhere the width increases by order of magnitudes.  This is\nshown in the right panels of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig5')]), ', where the transmission\nprobability (top) and phase (bottom) are shown, for a twist\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=2.25', TexCmd('pi')], []), '. Here, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1'), '>E_2'], []), ', and the second\ntransmission channel becomes available. The solid line is the\nfirst-channel to first-channel transmission, and shows a tiny dip at\nthe quasi-bound state position, reminiscent of the prominent Fano dip\nof the single-channel case.  \nThe dashed line is the second-channel to\nsecond-channel transmission, showing a clear Breit-Wigner resonance\nwith the corresponding continuous phase lapse of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('nota1')]), '\nThis is not surprising, since in this case the quasi-bound state has\nthe same transverse mode of the transmission channel.\n\nThe case with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3.95'], []), ', with a deeper potential well ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' in the\ntwisted region, presents additional effects. In fact, at zero twist\nthe energy range between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ', where only the ground\nchannel is open, contains bound states of two different transverse\nmodes, namely the first excited (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,4')], []), ') and the second excited (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('3,1')], []), '), as shown\nin Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), '.  As the wire is twisted, the energy of the above\nthree quasi-bound states increases, as illustrated in the top panel of\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig6')]), '.  \n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.9', TexCmd('linewidth')), BraceGroup('fig6.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\nSame as Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig3')]), ', but for a deeper potential well, with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3.95'], []), '.  Here, four quasi-bound states with a first-excited\ntransverse mode are present: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ' ', '(solid line, with filled\ncircles), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), ' ', '(dashed line), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' ', '(dotted\nline), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,4')], []), ' ', '(dot-dashed line), together with a quasi-bound\nstate with a second-excited transverse mode: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('3,1')], []), ' ', '(solid\nline with empty squares). The two resonances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('3,1')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,4')], []), ', with different transverse modes, cross around\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' with a repulsion of their imaginary components.  All the\nresonances in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'E_1,E_2', ']'], []), ' range are of Fano type.  \n')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig6')]), '\n'], []), '\nHowever, the level ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('3,1')], []), ' ', '(solid line with empty squares)\nincreases faster than the other two, it crosses ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,4')], []), '\naround ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' and goes beyond ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), '.  First of all we note again\nthat, in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'E_1,E_2', ']'], []), ' range, the transport resonances corresponding\nto the above quasi-bound states are Fano resonances, in agreement with\nthe fact that they originate from a transverse mode different from\nthat of the transport channel.  This is shown in the left panels of\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig7')]), ', reporting the transmission probability and phase of\nthe ground channel at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi')], []), ', just after the crossing.  At the\ncrossing, we also find a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' repulsion'), ' of the imaginary component of\nthe eigenvalues, visible in the bottom panel of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig6')]), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.9', TexCmd('linewidth')), BraceGroup('fig7.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\nGround-mode transmission probability (upper panels) and phase (lower\npanels) showing the resonance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('3,1')], []), ' just after the\ncrossing with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,4')], []), ' ', '(at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=', TexCmd('pi')], []), ', left panels) and above\nthe second mode threshold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ' ', '(at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=1.25', TexCmd('pi')], []), ', right panels).  In\nthe first case the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' discontinuities of the transmission phase\nevidence the Fano character of the resonances. In the second case a\nthird channel is available, and the resonance does not present either\nFano or Breit-Wigner character.  \n')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig7')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('3,1'), '>E_2'], []), ', i.e. it enters the energy region with two\ntransport channels, it does not disappear, as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,4')], []), ' do at larger twist, but simply changes its\ncharacters. Now the minimum of the dip does not reach zero, and the\nphase does not present the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' discontinuity (Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig7')]), ', right\npanels). Here in fact, a third transmission channel is available, this\nlifting the rigid zero-transmission properties of a two-channel case\nFano resonance.\n\nAs already mentioned, the two resonances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,4')], []), ', present in the spectrum since small twist angles,\ndisappear as they reach ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ', with their width going to zero.  Two\nadditional resonances enter the ground-mode region at larger twists:\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,1')], []), ', represented in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig6')]), '\nby a dashed line and a solid line, respectively. They are also Fano\nresonances, but after reaching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ' they do not vanish. In fact,\ntheir width increases and their minimum does not reach zero, as shown\nin Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig8')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), '. Obviously, in this region\nthey are also present in the transmission spectrum of the\nfirst-excited channel as Breit-Wigner resonances (dashed line in\nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig8')]), '), since their transverse mode is the first-excited one\nas well. Correspondingly, their transmission phase presents a smooth\nevolution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.9', TexCmd('linewidth')), BraceGroup('fig8.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\nTransmission probability (upper panels)\nand phase (lower panels) around the resonance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2')], []), ' for \nthe system with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3.95'], []), '.\nTwo different twist angles are considered, with the resonance\nclose to the second-channel threshold: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=2.875', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' ', '(left panels),\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2'), '<E_2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=3.125', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' ', '(right panels), where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('2,2'), '>E_2'], []), '. In the second case, both the ground mode\n(solid line) and first-excited mode (dashed line) transmission probabilities\nare reported.\nAs for the case of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig7')]), ', after the\ncrossing of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ' the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' discontinuity of the\nphase is lost, due to the availability of a third transmission channel.\nThe broad peak in the first-excited channel is a Breit-Wigner resonance.\n  ')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig8')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conclusions')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec5')]), '\n', '\nBy solving the open-boundary Schr', '\\"', 'odinger equation through the QTBM\nwe obtained the transmission spectra of the twisted QW.  The effect of\nthe twist can be summarized in the following points. \n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('First')]), ', the twist is able to mix different transmission channels\nin spite of the fact that the transverse QW section is not altered\n(but only rotated). Furthermore, bound states of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' are coupled to\ntraveling states and appear as resonance peaks/dips in the transmission\nspectra. No additional resonances are introduced.\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Second')]), ', the character of the resonance depends upon the transverse\nmode of the original bound state.\nIn fact, when the latter is equal to the transverse mode of the transmission\nchannel, we find a Breit-Wigner resonance, otherwise we find a Fano resonance.\nIn case more than two channels are available, we do not find the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' discontinuity of the transmission phase typical of Fano\nresonances.\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Third')]), ', the twist increases the energy of quasi-bound levels.\nThe higher the transverse mode of the quasi-bound state, the faster\nits energy is increased. However, the change of resonance width is\nnon-monotonic with the twist. In general, it increases from zero \nwhen the energy of the bound state is already in the transport\nregion in the straight QW, and decreases as the above energy reaches\nthe threshold of the transmission channel with the same transverse\nmode as the quasi-bound state.\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('Forth')]), ', resonances that are present from the beginning in the\nfirst-channel region disappear as they reach ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ', while resonances\nthat enter the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_1'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_2'], []), ' region at a finite twist, persist in the\nmulti-channel region.\nThe strict behavior described above could help in anticipating the\ncharacters of transmission spectra of QW locally twisted once the\nspectra of the straight wire is known. Furthermore, it supports the\nidea that the twist can reduce the effects of localized states on\nquantum conductance, since it shifts their levels towards higher\nenergies, possibly beyond Fermi level of the quasi-1D nanostructure.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('acknowledgments', ['\nWe thank P.~Bordone, G.~Ferrari and H.~Kova', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('r')]), "\\'", BraceGroup('i'), 'k\nfor most helpful discussions.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('APPENDIX: COMPLEX SCALING METHOD')]), '\n', "\nSo far we have identified resonant energies with singular points of\nthe reflection/transmission coefficient. In the framework of the\ncomplex scaling method, introduced in the '70 by Aguilar, Baslev and\nCombes ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('aguilar71, balslev71')]), ' ', '(for a review see also\nRef.~', TexCmd('onlinecite', [BraceGroup('CFKS')]), '), resonances are identified with the complex\neigenvalues of a non-symmetric linear operator obtained from the\noriginal one by analytic complex deformation. The real part of such\ncomplex-valued eigenvalues coincides with the usual resonance energy\nlevel, while the imaginary part is associated with the resonant state\nlifetime. The complex scaling method has been employed in\nRef.~', TexCmd('onlinecite', [BraceGroup('kovarik07')]), ' to twisted QW in order to prove\nthe existence of resonances and here we briefly resume it.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), ' =  ', '[', '- ', TexCmd('frac'), ' 12 L_y , + ', TexCmd('frac'), ' 12 L_y  ', ']', ' ', TexCmd('times', [BracketGroup('- ', TexCmd('frac'), ' 12 L_z , + ', TexCmd('frac'), ' 12 L_z  ')]), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' R^2'], []), ' be the\nrectangular cross section of our QW.  For a given ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), ' R '], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(y,z)', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('omega')], []), ' we define the mapping given in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq5')]), ')\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', '(x) = ', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '(x)'], []), ' and where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ':R ', TexCmd('to'), ' R '], []), '\nis a differentiable function which represent the twisting and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), TexCmd('ge'), ' 0'], []), ' is a real-valued parameter which represents the\nstrength of the twisting.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')))], []), ' be the twisted\nQW and let\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), '^2'), BraceGroup('2m')]), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' +V(x) \n'], [BraceGroup('H')]), '\nbe the time independent Schr', BraceGroup('\\"', 'o'), 'dinger operator on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')))], []), ', that is the wave function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi')], []), ' belongs to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L^2(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'))), ')'], []), ' with Dirichlet boundary conditions at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')))], []), '.  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' represents the external potential\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq2')]), '), depending only on the longitudinal variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '.  In\nthe following, for the sake of definiteness, let us assume the units\nchoice such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), '^2'), BraceGroup('2m')]), ' =1'], []), '.\n\nIn order to analyze the operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('H'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'))], []), ' we go back to the\nuntwisted tube ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega')], []), '.  The operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' then takes the\nform ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nK_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' = - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('yy'), '^2- ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('zz'), '^2-\n', '[', TexCmd('partial'), '_x+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "' (x)", '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau')), ']', '^2+ V(x) =K_0 +\nU_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '\\,', ' ,\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\n', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('tau'), ' = y ', TexCmd('partial'), '_z - z ', TexCmd('partial'), '_y\n'], []), '\nand\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nK_0  = -  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('xx'), '^2 -  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('yy'), '^2- ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('zz'), '^2 +V(x)\n'], []), '\nand\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nU_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '&=& -  ', '[', TexCmd('partial'), '_x+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "' (x)", '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau')), ']', '^2 \n+ ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('xx'), '^2  \n&=&  - 2', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '\\,', '  ', TexCmd('alpha'), "' ( x) ", TexCmd('partial'), '^2_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('tau')), ' \n- ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "'' ( x)", '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau')), ' -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '^2 \n', '[', ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), " ' ( x) ", ']', '^2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('tau')), '^2 ', '\\,', ' . \n'], []), '\n', '\nThe operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'))], []), ' is a symmetric operator on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L^2 (', TexCmd('Omega'), ')'], []), '\nwith Dirichlet boundary conditions at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega')], []), '.  The\nspectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_0'], []), ' is given by Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq4')]), '),\nthat is, the spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_0'], []), ' admits\nembedded eigenvalues in the continuous spectrum.  In\nRef.~', TexCmd('onlinecite', [BraceGroup('kovarik07')]), ' it has been proved that such embedded\neigenvalues become resonances when we add the perturbation\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U_', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_0'], []), '.  Resonances are defined by employing the\nmethod of exterior complex scaling to the operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'))], []), ',\nprovided that the potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' is a bounded potential which extends\nto an analytic function with respect to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' in some sector, and the\ntwisting function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '(x)'], []), ' extends to analytic function with\nrespect to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' in a suitable complex set.  The exterior complex\nscaling method consists in introducing the mapping ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', TexCmd('theta')], []), ', which\nacts as a complex dilation in the longitudinal variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\n', '(S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), TexCmd('psi'), ')(x,y,z) = e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'), '/2'), TexCmd('psi'), '(e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), ' x,y,z)', '\\,', ' , ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' C , ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Im'), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' >0 .\n'], []), '\nThe transformed operator is not a symmetric operator and it takes the form\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nK_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ') = S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), ' K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' S^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), ' \n= K_0 (', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ') + U_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ')', '\\,', ' ,\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nK_0 (', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ') = S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), ' K_', BraceGroup('0'), ' S^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), ' = -e^', BraceGroup('-2', TexCmd('theta')), ' ', '\\,', ' \n', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('xx'), '^2 - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('yy'), '^2-', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('zz'), '^2 +V(e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), 'x) ', '\\,', '\n'], []), '\nand\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nU_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ') &=& S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), ' U_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'))), ' S^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta')), ' \n', '\n', '&=& - 2', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '\\,', ' e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('theta')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "'( e^", TexCmd('theta'), ' x) ', TexCmd('partial'), '^2_', BraceGroup('x ', TexCmd('tau')), ' \n- ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "'' ( e^", TexCmd('theta'), ' x)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau')), ' \n', '\n', '&& -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '^2 \n', '[', ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), "'( e^", TexCmd('theta'), ' x) ', ']', '^2 ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('tau')), '^2 ', '\\,', ' .\n'], []), '\n', '\nThen, the essential spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ')'], []), ' consists of\nthe sequence of the half-lines (Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig9')]), ') ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('n'), ' +\ne^', BraceGroup('-2i', TexCmd('Im'), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' '), ' R ^+ '], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n =1,2,', TexCmd('ldots'), ' '], []), ', and, by a\nstandard argument, it turns out that the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '\n', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ')'], []), ' are analytic functions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ', they are in fact\nindependent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), '. These non-real eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), '\n', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ')'], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Im'), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' >0'], []), ', are identified\nwith the resonances of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'))], []), ' ', '(and hence with the resonances\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ') ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CFKS')]), '.  \n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('height=2cm,width=8cm'), BraceGroup('fig9app.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The essential spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ')'], []), ' is given\nby the half-lines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('n'), ' + e^', BraceGroup('-2i', TexCmd('Im'), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' '), ' R^+'], []), ' ', '(full\nlines). The eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ')'], []), ' ', '(denoted by open\ncircle) with strictly negative imaginary part are the \n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('resonances')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'))], []), '; for energies below the threshold \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', ')'], []), '\n', '(denoted by full circle) are purely real valued and they are\neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), '.')]), '  \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig9')]), ' \n'], []), ' \n'], [BracketGroup('h')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('providecommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('noopsort')), BracketGroup('1'), BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('providecommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('singleletter')), BracketGroup('1'), BraceGroup('#1')]), TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', [TexCmd('makeatletter'), '\n', TexCmd('providecommand'), ' ', '\\@', 'ifxundefined ', '[', '1', ']', BraceGroup(' ', '\\@', 'ifx', BraceGroup('#1', TexCmd('undefined')), '\n'), TexCmd('providecommand'), ' ', '\\@', 'ifnum ', '[', '1', ']', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('ifnum'), ' ', '#1', TexCmd('expandafter'), ' ', '\\@', 'firstoftwo\n ', TexCmd('else'), ' ', TexCmd('expandafter'), ' ', '\\@', 'secondoftwo\n ', TexCmd('fi'), '\n'), TexCmd('providecommand'), ' ', '\\@', 'ifx ', '[', '1', ']', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('ifx'), ' ', '#1', TexCmd('expandafter'), ' ', '\\@', 'firstoftwo\n ', TexCmd('else'), ' ', TexCmd('expandafter'), ' ', '\\@', 'secondoftwo\n ', TexCmd('fi'), '\n'), TexCmd('providecommand'), ' ', TexCmd('natexlab', [BracketGroup('1'), Just finished parsing: ['{', '\\}', BraceGroup('thefootnote'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('fnsymbol', [BraceGroup('footnote')])), TexCmd('footnote', [BracketGroup('2'), BraceGroup('Presented at OPT 2008 Optimization for Machine Learning Workshop, Neural Information Processing Systems, 2008')]), TexCmd('endgroup'), '\n  CBLL-TR-2008-12-01\n\n', TexCmd('end', [BraceGroup('center')]), '\n', TexCmd('bigskip', [BraceGroup()]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\n  Adaptive sparse coding methods learn a possibly overcomplete set of\n  basis functions, such that natural image patches can be\n  reconstructed by linearly combining a small subset of these\n  bases. The applicability of these methods to visual object\n  recognition tasks has been limited because of the prohibitive cost\n  of the optimization algorithms required to compute the sparse\n  representation.  In this work we propose a simple and efficient\n  algorithm to learn basis functions. After training, this model also\n  provides a fast and smooth approximator to the optimal\n  representation, achieving even better accuracy than exact sparse\n  coding algorithms on visual object recognition tasks.\n'], []), 'bibli\n  ', TexCmd('setlength', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('parskip')), BraceGroup('0pt')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('setlength', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('parsep')), BraceGroup('0pt')]), '\n', '\n', '\nintroduction.tex Input file not found \n', TexCmd('input', [BraceGroup('introduction.tex')]), '\nalgorithm.tex Input file not found \n', TexCmd('input', [BraceGroup('algorithm.tex')]), '\nexperiments.tex Input file not found \n', TexCmd('input', [BraceGroup('experiments.tex')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Summary and Future Work')]), '\nSparse coding algorithms can be used as pre-processor in many vision\napplications and, in particular, to extract features in object\nrecognition systems. To the best of our knowledge, no sparse coding\nalgorithm is computationally efficient because inference involves some\nsort of iterative optimization.  We showed that sparse codes can\nactually be approximated by a feed-forward regressor without\ncompromising the recognition accuracy, but making the recognition\nprocess very fast and suitable for use in real-time systems. We\nproposed a very simple algorithm to train such a regressor.\n\nIn the future, we plan to train the model convolutionally in order to\nmake the sparse representation more efficient, and to build\nhierarchical deep models by sequentially replicating the model on the\nrepresentation produced by the previous stage as successfully proposed\nin~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hinton-DeepAutoencoder')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('newenvironment', [BraceGroup('bibli'), BraceGroup('\n  ', TexCmd('setlength', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('parskip')), BraceGroup('0pt')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('setlength', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('parsep')), BraceGroup('0pt')]), '\n')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('end', [BraceGroup('document')]), '\n']
