4196 ***Failed to finish PorodPASCAS2010.tex: [Line: 0, Offset 166] Malformed argument. First and last elements must match a valid argument format. In this case, TexSoup could not find matching punctuation for: {.
Just finished parsing: ['{', '\\}', BraceGroup('e'), '6', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('E(6)')])], []), ' '), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nn')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('nonumber'))]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('LHC phenomenology of supersymmetric models beyond the MSSM')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('Werner Porod', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('a,b')], []))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('address', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('a')], []), ' Institut f', '\\"', 'ur Theoretische Physik und Astrophysik, \nUniversit', '\\"', 'at W', '\\"', 'urzburg,\nD-97074  W', '\\"', 'urzburg, Germany\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('b')], []), ' AHEP Group, Instituto de F', "\\'", 'isica Corpuscular - C.S.I.C., \nUniversitat de Val', '\\`', 'encia, E-46071 Val', '\\`', 'encia, Spain')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('ead', [BraceGroup('porod@physik.uni-wuerzburg.de')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nWe discuss various phenomenological aspects of supersymmetric models\nbeyond the MSSM. A particular focus is on models which can correctly\nexplain neutrino data and the possiblities of LHC to identify the underlying\nscenario.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nSupersymmetric extensions of the standard model (SM) are promising\ncandidates for new physics at the TeV scale ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Nilles:1983ge,Haber:1984rc')]), ' \nas the solve several\nshort-comings of the Standard Model (SM). The Minimal Supersymmetric\nStandard Model (MSSM) solves the hierarchy problem of the SM\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Witten:1981nf')]), ', leads to a unification of the gauge\ncouplings ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Dimopoulos:1981yj,Ibanez:1981yh')]), ' and introduces several candidates\nfor dark matter depending on how SUSY is broken\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ellis:1983ew,Steffen:2008qp')]), '. Its phenomenology with respect to\npresent and future colliders has been\nwidely explored, see e.g.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Weiglein:2004hn,Nath:2010zj')]), '. \n\n\nHowever, similarly as the SM it needs additional ingredients to explain\nneutrino data, e.g.~by either incooperating heavy new particles giving\nrise to tiny neutrino masses via the seesaw mechanism ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Minkowski:1977sc')]), ' or\nvia the braking of R-parity ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hall:1984id')]), '. Moreover,  a new\nproblem arises in the MSSM not present in the SM: the superpotential contains a parameter\nwith dimension mass, namely the so called ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' parameter which gives masses to\nthe Higgs bosons and higgsinos. From a purely theoretical point of view, the\nvalue of this parameter is expected to be either of the order of the GUT/Planck scale or\nexactly zero, if it is protected by a symmetry. For phenomenological\naspects, however, it has to be  of the\norder of the scale of electroweak symmetry breaking (EWSB) and it has to\nbe non-zero to be consistent with experimental data. This\ndiscrepancy is the so called ', TexMathEnv('math', [TexCmd('mu')], []), '-problem of the MSSM\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kim:1983dt')]), '.\n\nIn this paper we discuss various supersymmetric models addressing at least\none of these two topics focusing on features of their phenomenology which can\nbe tested at the LHC and which differ from the usual MSSM phenomenology. \nWe will take as main guideline the requirement that neutrino data are correctly\nexplained.\nWe will first discuss briefly the case of Dirac neutrinos\nand afterwards discuss models leading to Majorana neutrinos, both in the\ncontext of conserved R-parity. In the third part we cover models with broken\nR-parity and their phenomenology at the LHC. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Dirac neutrinos')]), '\n', '\nTechnically the easiest way to obtain masses for neutrinos is by introducing\na new Yukawa coupling similar to the ones for the SM fermions. In this case\nthe MSSM has to be extended by additional right handed neutrinos, which\nare gauge singlets with respect to the SM gauge group, and the superpotential\nof the MSSM\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nW_', BraceGroup('MSSM'), ' = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H'), '_d ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' L'), ' Y_', BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' E'), '^c \n         + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H'), '_d ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' Q'), ' Y_', BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' D'), '^c \n         + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H'), '_u ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' Q'), ' Y_', BraceGroup('u'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' U'), '^c  ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n         - ', TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H')]), '_d ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H'), '_u\n'], []), '\nhas to be extended by the term\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nW_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^c'), ' =     ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H'), '_u ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' L'), ' Y_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '^c  ', '\\,', '.\n'], []), '\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H'), '_d'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' H'), '_u'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' Q')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' D'), '^c'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), '\nU'), '^c'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' L')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' E'), '^c'], []), ' are the MSSM superfields containing\nthe Higgs bosons, quarks, leptons and their supersymmetric\npartners. In addition the superfield ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '^c'], []), ' for the\nright-handed neutrino and the right-sneutrino has been introduced.\nThe corresponding Yukawa coupling ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' has to be tiny, of\nthe order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup('-12')], []), ' and smaller, to explain correctly neutrino masses\nin the sub-eV range as required by data\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Schwetz:2008er')]), '. \nThis in turn implies that one is essentially left with the usual\nMSSM phenomenology, except for the case where the right-sneutrino is\nthe lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP): in this case all decays\nare as in the MSSM down to the next to lightest supersymmetric\nparticle (NLSP) which eventually decays into the LSP. The\ncorresponding width of the last step is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Y_', TexCmd('nu'), '|^2'], []), '\nand thus rather small implying at the LHC decay lengths ranging from\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(cm)'], []), ' up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(km)'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deGouvea:2006wd')]), '. Consequently the signal\nof such a scenario is very two long-lived particles in each event\nwhich can even appear as stable particles in a typical detector of\nhigh energy collider experiments. Detailed studies have been performed\nfor the cases of a stau ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Gupta:2007ui')]), ' NLSP and a stop\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Choudhury:2008gb')]), ' NLSP demonstrating that LHC should be able to\nidentity such scenarios.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Majorana neutrinos via the seesaw mechanism')]), '\n', '\nA possibility to obtain tiny neutrino masses while having at the same time\nsizable Yukawa couplings are seesaw scenarios  where very heavy new particles\nare postulated inducing the so-called Weinberg operator \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Weinberg:1979sa,Weinberg:1980bf')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:dim5')]), '\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'))]), ' ', '(H_u L_', TexCmd('alpha'), ') (H_u L_', TexCmd('beta'), ')\n ', TexCmd('Rightarrow'), '  ', '(m^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ')_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' v^2_u'), BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('Lambda'))]), '\n'], []), '\nwhen integrating out the heavy degrees of freedom. Here ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' is a measure of the\nscale for these new particles and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta'))], []), ' is usually a combination of \ndifferent Yukawa couplings. One can show, that\nat tree-level only three possibilities exist to realize such scenarios\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ma:1998dn')]), '. Type-I is the well-known case of the exchange of \na heavy fermionic singlet usually denoted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '_R'], []), '\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Minkowski:1977sc,yanagida:1979,gell-mann:1980vs,mohapatra:1979ia')]), '. \nType-II corresponds to the exchange of a scalar ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(2)'], []), ' triplet \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Schechter:1980gr,Cheng:1980qt')]), '. In seesaw type-III \none adds (at least two) fermionic ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(2)'], []), ' triplets to the field content of \nthe SM ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Foot:1988aq')]), '.  \nIn the last two models particles charged under the SM gauge\ngroup are added and which correspond to incomplete ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), ' representations.\nAs they would destroy \nthe nice feature of gauge coupling unification  one often adds at the\nseesaw scale(s) additional particles to obtain complete ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), ' representations\nto maintain the feature of gauge coupling unification.\n A  detailed discussion including the embedding in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), '\nmodels can be found in e.g.~in  ref. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Borzumati:2009hu')]), '. \n\nBelow\nwe present only the various superpotential for briefness. \nIn addition there will also be\nthe corresponding soft SUSY terms which, however, reduce at the electroweak\nscale to the MSSM ones once the states with masses at the seesaw scale(s)\nare integrated out and, thus, are not discussed further. \nThese additional\nterms only contribute to threshold corrections at the seesaw scale(s) and their\neffect is negligible if one requires universal boundary conditions for all soft terms\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kang:2010zd')]), '.\nHere we will assume common soft SUSY breaking at the GUT-scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_G'], []), '\nto specify the spectrum at the electroweak scale: a common gaugino\nmass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ', a common scalar mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), ' and the trilinear coupling\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0'], []), ' which gets multiplied by the corresponding Yukawa couplings to\nobtain the trilinear couplings in the soft SUSY breaking\nLagrangian. In addition the sign of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' parameter is fixed as\nwell as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), ' =v_u/v_d'], []), ' at the electroweak scale where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_d'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_u'], []), ' are the the vacuum expectation values (vevs) of the neutral\ncomponent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_d'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_u'], []), ', respectively.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Supersymmetric seesaw type-I')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:modelI')]), '\n', '\nIn this class of models one postulates very heavy right-handed neutrinos\nyielding the following superpotential below the GUT-scale:\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nW_', BraceGroup('I'), ' ', '&=& W_', BraceGroup('MSSM'), ' + W_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^c'), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))]), '^c M_R  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '^c\n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:superpotI')]), ' \n'], []), '\nFor the neutrino mass matrix one obtains the well-known formula\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nm_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^2_u'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' Y^T_', TexCmd('nu'), ' M^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_R Y_', TexCmd('nu'), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:mnuI')]), '\n'], []), '\nBeing complex symmetric, the light Majorana neutrino mass matrix\n  in eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:mnuI')]), ') is diagonalized by a unitary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3', TexCmd('times'), ' 3'], []), ' matrix\n  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Schechter:1980gr')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('diagmeff'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')))]), ' = U^T ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' U .\n'], []), '\nInverting the seesaw equation eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:mnuI')]), ') allows to express \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' as ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Casas:2001sr')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Ynu')]), '\nY_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' =', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('v_u')]), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' M_R')]), TexCmd('cdot'), ' R ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), '\n    m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))))]), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' U^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger')), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat'), ' m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat'), ' M_R'], []), ' are  diagonal matrices containing the\ncorresponding eigenvalues. \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' is  in general a complex orthogonal matrix. We assume\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R=1'], []), ' implying that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), " contains only ``diagonal'' products\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('M_im_', BraceGroup('i'))])], []), '. \n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Supersymmetric seesaw type-II')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:modelII')]), '\n', '\nIn seesaw models of type II one adds a scalar ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(2)'], []), ' triplet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' to generate\nneutrino masses. As this triplet carries also hypercharge one has to embed\nit in a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['15'], []), '-plet of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), ' which has under\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(3)', TexCmd('times'), ' SU_L(2) ', TexCmd('times'), ' U(1)_Y'], []), ' the following decomposition ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rossi:2002zb')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:15'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 15')]), ' ', '& = &  S + T + Z  ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nS & ', TexCmd('sim'), '  ', '& (6,1,-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('3')]), '), ', TexCmd('hskip'), '10mm\nT ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', '(1,3,1), ', TexCmd('hskip'), '10mm\nZ ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', '(3,2,', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('6')]), ').\n'], []), '\nIn supersymmetric models one  adds a pair  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['15'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('15')])], []), ' to avoid\nanomalies below the GUT-scale.\nBelow the GUT scale in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), '-broken \nphase the superpotential reads\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:broken')]), '\nW_', BraceGroup('II'), ' ', '& = & W_', BraceGroup('MSSM'), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]))]), '(Y_T ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('L')]), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_1  ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('L')]), ' \n+  Y_S ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('D')]), '^c ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_1 ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('D')]), '^c) \n+ Y_Z ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('D')]), '^c ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('Z')]), '_1 ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('L')]), '   ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '& + & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]))]), '(', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat'), ' H'), '_d ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_1  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat'), ' H'), '_d \n+', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat'), ' H'), '_u ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat'), ' H'), '_u) \n+ M_T ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_1 ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_2 \n+ M_Z ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('Z')]), '_1 ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('Z')]), '_2 + M_S ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_1 ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_2\n'], []), '\nwhere the states with index 1 (2) belong the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['15'], []), '-plet (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('15')])], []), '-plet).\nThe second term in eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:broken')]), ') is responsible for the generation \nof the neutrino masses yielding \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:ssII')]), '\nm_', TexCmd('nu'), '=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v_2^2'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_2'), BraceGroup('M_T')]), 'Y_T.\n'], []), '\nNote that \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('diagYT'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' Y')]), '_T = U^T ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' Y_T ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' U\n'], []), '\ni.e. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_T'], []), ' is diagonalized by the same matrix as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), '. \n\n\nIn addition there are the couplings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_Z'], []), ', which in  \nprinciple  are not determined by any low-energy data. In the calculation \nof lepton flavour violating \nobservables both Yukawa couplings, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_T'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_Z'], []), ', contribute. Having a GUT model in mind we require for\nthe numerical discussion later the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), ' boundary conditions\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_T=Y_S=Y_Z'], []), ' at the GUT scale.  \nAs long as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_Z ', TexCmd('sim'), ' M_S ', TexCmd('sim'), ' M_T ', TexCmd('sim'), ' M_', BraceGroup('15')], []), ' gauge coupling unification \nwill be maintained. The equality need not be exact for a successful unification. \nIn our numerical studies we have taken into account the different running\nof these mass parameters but we decouple them all at the scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_T(M_T)'], []), '\nbecause the differences are small.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Supersymmetric seesaw type-III')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:modelIII')]), '\n', '\nIn the case of a seesaw model type III one needs new fermions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' \nat the high\nscale being in the adjoint representation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(2)'], []), '. They have to be \nembedded in a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['24'], []), '-plet  to obtain a complete ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), '  representation\nwhich decomposes under  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(3)', TexCmd('times'), ' SU_L(2) ', TexCmd('times'), ' U_Y(1)'], []), ' as \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:def24')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n24_M & = &(1,1,0) + (8,1,0) + (1,3,0) + (3,2,-5/6) + (3^*,2,5/6)  \n   & = & ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_M + ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_M + ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_M + ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_M + ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' X')]), '_M \n'], []), '\nThe fermionic components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1,1,0)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1,3,0)'], []), ' have exactly \nthe same quantum numbers as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '^c'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '. Thus, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['24_M'], []), ' \nalways produces a combination of the type-I and type-III seesaw. \nIn the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SU(5)'], []), ' broken phase the superpotential reads\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:spotIII')]), '\n W_', BraceGroup('III'), ' ', '& = &  W_', BraceGroup('MSSM'), '\n +  ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_u(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_M Y_N - ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('10')]))]), ' \n               ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_M Y_B) ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('L')]), '\n + ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_u ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' X')]), '_M Y_X ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('D')]), '^c ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n         ', '& & + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_M M_', BraceGroup('B'), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_M \n         + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_M M_', BraceGroup('G'), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_M \n          + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_M M_', BraceGroup('W'), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_M \n          + ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_M M_', BraceGroup('X'), ' ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' X')]), '_M \n'], []), '\nAs above we use at the GUT scale the boundary condition\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_N = Y_B = Y_X'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_B = M_G=M_W=M_X'], []), '. Integrating out the heavy fields\nyields the following formula for the neutrino masses at the low scale:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nm_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = - v^2_u ( ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('10')]), ' Y^T_B M^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_B Y_B + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' Y^T_W M^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_W Y_W ). \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:mnu_seesawIII')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe boundary conditions at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_G'], []), ' imply that at the seesaw scale(s) one still has\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_B ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' M_W'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_B ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' Y_W'], []), ' so that one can write in a good approximation\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nm_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = - v^2_u  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4'), BraceGroup('5')]), ' Y^T_W M^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_W Y_W \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:mnu_seesawIIIa')]), '\n'], []), '\nand one can use the corresponding  decomposition for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_W'], []), ' as discussed in section\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec:modelI')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Effect of the heavy particles on the MSSM spectrum')]), '\n', '\nThe appearance of charged particles at scales between the electroweak\nscale and the GUT scale leads to changes in the beta functions\nof the gauge couplings ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rossi:2002zb,Buckley:2006nv')]), '.\nIn the MSSM the corresponding values at 1-loop level are\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(b_1,b_2,b_3)=(33/5,1,-3)'], []), '. In case of one ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['15'], []), '-plet the additional\ncontribution is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' b_i=7/2'], []), ' whereas in case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['24'], []), '-plet\nit is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' b_i=5'], []), '. This  results in case of type II in \na total shift of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' b_i=7'], []), ' for the minimal model and\nin case of type III in  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' b_i=15'], []), '  assuming 3 generations\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['24'], []), '-plets. This does not only change the evolution\nof the gauge couplings but also the evolution of the gaugino\nand scalar mass parameters with profound implications on\nthe spectrum ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Buckley:2006nv,Hirsch:2008gh')]), '. Additional\neffects on the spectrum of the scalars can be present if some of the Yukawa \ncouplings get large\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2008gh,Calibbi:2009wk,Biggio:2010me')]), '.\nIn figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:mass1000')]), ' we exemplify this by showing the values\nof selected mass parameters at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q=1'], []), ' TeV versus the seesaw scale for\nfixed high scale parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0= M_', BraceGroup('1/2'), ' = 1'], []), ' TeV, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), '=10'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=0'], []), '\n where we have assumed that\nthe\nadditional Yukawa couplings are small. As expected, the effects in case\nof models of type II and III are larger the smaller the corresponding\nseesaw-scale is. The scalar mass parameters shown are of the first \ngeneration and, thus, the results are nearly independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta')], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0'], []), '. \n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n  ', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.45', TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('figs/M1M2M3-SeesawScale-m01000-m121000.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('0.08', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.45', TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('figs/MQMLME-SeesawScale-m01000-m121000.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Mass parameters at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q=1'], []), ' TeV versus the seesaw scale for fixed\nhigh scale parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0= M_', BraceGroup('1/2'), ' = 1'], []), ' TeV, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), '=10'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '>0'], []), '. \nThe full lines correspond to seesaw type I, the dashed ones to type II and the\ndash-dotted ones to type III. In all cases a degenerate spectrum of the seesaw\nparticles has been assumed.')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:mass1000')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('height=60mm,width=70mm'), BraceGroup('figs/CompAllInvScd.ps')]), '\n', TexCmd('vskip'), '0mm\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup("Four different ``invariant'' combinations of soft masses \nversus the mass of the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 15')], []), '-plet ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' or'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 24')], []), '-plet, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('15'), '=M_', BraceGroup('24')], []), '. The calculation is at 1-loop order in the leading-log \napproximation. The lines running faster up towards smaller ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' are \nfor type-III seesaw, the lower ones are for type-II seesaw.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:ana')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('0.47', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('0.04', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('height=75mm,width=80mm'), BraceGroup('figs/BrStaus-SPS3-m1-0eV-DegMR.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:seesawIb')]), ' Flavour violating decays of the heavier stau for degenerate\nright-handed neutrinos, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_0=90'], []), '~GeV, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2'), ' = 400'], []), '~GeV,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=0'], []), '~GeV, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), '=10'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' >0'], []), '), from ref. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2008dy')]))]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('0.47', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), ' \n'], [BracketGroup('h')]), '\n', '\n', '\nNote that in all three model types the ratio of the gaugino mass\nparameters is nearly the same as in the usual mSUGRA scenarios but the\nratios and differences of the sfermion mass parameters change\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Buckley:2006nv,Hirsch:2008gh')]), ". One can form four 'invariants' where at\nleast at the 1-loop level the dependence on ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), ' is\nrather weak, e.g. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' L'), ' - m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' E'), ')/M^2_1'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' Q'), ' - m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' E'), ')/M^2_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' D'), ' -\nm^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' L'), ')/M^2_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' Q'), ' - m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' U'), ')/M^2_1'], []), '.\nHere one could replace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_1'], []), ' by any of the other two gaugino masses\nwhich simply would amount in an overall rescaling.\nIn figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:ana')]), " we show these 'invariants' in the leading-log\napproximation at 1-loop order to demonstrate the principal behaviour\nfor seesaw type II with a pair of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 15')], []), '-plets and seesaw type III\nwith three ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 24')], []), '-plets. Due to the larger change in the\nbeta-coefficient the effect is more pronounced in case of type III\nmodels. From this one concludes that in principle one has a handle to\nget information on the seesaw scale for given assumptions on the\nunderlying neutrino mass model and assuming universal boundary\nconditions at the GUT scale.  For the type-I, i.e. singlets only, of\ncourse ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' b_i=0'], []), ' and no change with respect to mSUGRA are\nexpected. A detailed discussion can be found e.g. in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2008gh')]), '.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Lepton flavour violation in the slepton sector and signals at the LHC')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec:model_LFV')]), '\n', '\nAdditional effects beside the ones on the spectrum discussed above can \noccur due to lepton flavour mixing entries in the sleptons mass matrix\nwhich are induced due to RGE effects by the additional Yukawa couplings. \nFrom a one-step integration of the RGEs one gets, assuming mSUGRA boundary\nconditions, a first rough\nestimate for the lepton flavour violating entries in the slepton\nmass parameters:\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nm^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' L,ij'), ' ', '&', TexCmd('simeq'), '& -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('a_k'), BraceGroup('8 ', TexCmd('pi'), '^2 ')]), ' \n ', '( 3 m^2_0 +  A^2_0 ) \n (Y^', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('dagger')), ' L Y^', BraceGroup('k'), ')_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' \nA_', BraceGroup('l,ij'), ' ', '&', TexCmd('simeq'), '& - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3 a_k'), BraceGroup(' 16 ', TexCmd('pi'), '^2 ')]), '   A_0 \n (Y_E Y^', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('dagger')), ' L Y^', BraceGroup('k'), '_N)_', BraceGroup('ij'), '\n'], []), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('ne'), ' j'], []), ' in the basis where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_E'], []), ' is diagonal and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = ', TexCmd('log'), '(M_G/M_i)', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '.\nThe corresponding coefficient ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_k'], []), ' for seesaw type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' are: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_I=1'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('II'), ' = 6'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('III'), '=9/5'], []), '.   \nAll models have in common that the predict negligible flavour violation for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), '-sleptons\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' E,ij'), ' ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0'], []), '. Sizable entries for the these parameters would be a \nclear hint for a left-right symmetric extension of the MSSM ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Vicente:2010wa')]), '.\n\nThese flavour mixing entries induce on the one hand rare lepton decays, e.g.\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' e ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ', and on the other hand lepton flavour violating decays\nof sleptons and neutralinos. As a typical example we show in fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:seesawIb')]), '\nthe flavour violating decays of the heavier stau in a seesaw I scenario. One sees\nthat branching ratios of at most a few per-cent can be reached close to the region\nexcluded by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('to'), ' e', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' gets sizable. Also in case of seesaw type\nII one obtains similar results ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2008gh')]), '. At the LHC however one will not\nbe able to identify the individual branching ratios but one has to consider the\ncomplete cascade starting from the production and taking into account all steps\nof the various decays, e.g. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), ' q_L ', TexCmd('to'), ' q ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '^0_2 ', TexCmd('to'), ' q l_i^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' l'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mp')), '_j ', TexCmd('to'), ' q l_i^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), ' l_k^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mp')), TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '^0_1'], []), '. As typical examples we\ndisplay in fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:seesawIc')]), ' the obtainable cross section containing a\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '^', TexCmd('mp')], []), ' pair in the final state in case of\n seesaw models of type I and II for various values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), '\nas a function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), '. Here the signal has been maximized by choosing the\nYukawa couplings such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['BR(', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('to'), ' e ', TexCmd('gamma'), ') = 10^', BraceGroup('-12')], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Esteves:2009vg')]), '.\nOne sees that one gets at most signals up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(20-30)'], []), ' fb\nwhich clearly requires a large luminosity to be detected.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.47', TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('figs/plot-sigmaLOfbBR-m12_-_4m0.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('4mm')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.47', TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('figs/plot-sigmaLOfbBR-m12_-_4m0_-_II.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:seesawIc')]), ' Cross section ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(p p ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '^0_2) \n', TexCmd('times'), ' BR(', TexCmd('chi'), '^0_2 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i,j'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' l_i l_j \n    ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '^', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '^', TexCmd('mp'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '^0_1)'], []), ' as a function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ' for various\nvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), '=10'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' >0'], []), '. Left side, seesaw type I with degenerate\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '_R'], []), ', right side seesaw type II with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_1=0.02'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_2=0.5'], []), ';\nfrom ref. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Esteves:2009vg')]), '.')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('R-parity violation')]), '\n', '\nWe now turn to the  possibility that low-energy supersymmetry\nitself may provide the origin of neutrino\nmass~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ross:1984yg,Hall:1984id')]), ',\nfor a review see Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2004he')]), '.  Usually one\nassumes that R-parity, defined as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-1)^', BraceGroup('3B+L+2S')], []), ', is an exact\nsymmetry under which all superpartners are odd and SM particles even.\nHowever the terms that break R-parity are allowed by supersymmetry as\nwell as the SM gauge invariance. Expressed as superfields, they\nhave the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat'), ' L ', TexCmd('hat'), ' H_u'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat'), ' L ', TexCmd('hat'), ' L ', TexCmd('hat'), ' E^c'], []), ', \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat'), ' Q ', TexCmd('hat'), ' L ', TexCmd('hat'), ' D^c'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat'), ' U^c ', TexCmd('hat'), ' D^c ', TexCmd('hat'), ' d^c'], []), '. If all four\nterms are present proton decay becomes very rapid. This problem is\ncircumvented by simply forbidding the last term, e.g. by using baryon\ntriality or a similar symmetry ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Dreiner:1997uz,Dreiner:2005rd')]), '.\nThe remaining three terms  break lepton\nnumber explicitly implying that a  combination of tree and loop\ndiagrams in these models can lead to realistic neutrino masses and\nmixings.  From\nthe point of view of collider physics, there is an important\nimplication of LSP decay as at least some of its decay\nproperties are correlated to neutrino physics\n since the same couplings governing neutrino physics also\nlead to visible decays of the LSP.\n\nWe will exemplify this by focusing on bilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_P'], []), ' breaking, for discussion of\ntri-linear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' see for example\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('allanach:1999bf,Barbier:2004ez')]), ' and for the so-called\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')], []), 'SSM see for example ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bartl:2009an')]), '. The absence of tri-linear terms\ncould be explained, for example, if bilinear R-parity breaking is the\neffective low-energy limit of some spontaneous ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' model, see\nbelow.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Explicit bilinear R-parity violation')]), '\n', '\nThe superpotential of the bilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' model can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('spot'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' W')]), ' =  W_', BraceGroup('MSSM'), ' + ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_i ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' L_i ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' H_u .\n'], []), '\nIn addition, one must include bilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' soft supersymmetry\nbreaking terms\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('vsoft')]), '\nV_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' soft'), ' = ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_i B_i ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' L'), '_i H_u + V_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' soft'), '^', BraceGroup('MSSM'), '.\n'], []), '\nThese terms induce mixings between the MSSM Higgs\nbosons and the left scalar neutrinos which in consequence also obtain\nvevs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_i'], []), ' once electro-weak symmetry\nis broken.\nUsually one trades the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_i'], []), ' by the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_i'], []), ' \n using the corresponding tad-pole equations  which are a consequence\nof  eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('vsoft')]), ') as the connections to neutrino physics become more \napparent.  \n\nThe effective\nneutrino mass matrix at tree-level can then be cast into a very simple\nform\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nm_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ',ij'), ' = -\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'))), BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('det')]), '(M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'), '^0'), ')')]), ' ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_i ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_j\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:eff')]), '\n'], []), "\nThe ``photino'' mass parameter is defined as ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma')), " = g^2M_1\n+g'^2 M_2"], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['det(M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'), '^0'), ')'], []), ' is the determinant of the (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4,4'], []), ')\nneutralino mass matrix and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), '\n', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), 'v_d+v_', BraceGroup('i'), TexCmd('mu')], []), " are the ``alignment\nparameters''.\n\nDue to the projective nature of eq.~(", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq:eff')]), ') the other two\nneutrino masses are generated only at 1-loop order.  Generally the\nmost important contributions come from loops with sbottoms \nand staus ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2000ef,Diaz:2003as')]), '. However, there exist also\nparameter regions in the general ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' MSSM where the\nsneutrino-anti-neutrino loop gives a sizeable contribution\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Grossman:2000ex,Dedes:2006ni,Dedes:2007ef')]), '.  \nOne finds that in order to explain the\nobserved neutrino mixing angles one requires certain relations among\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' parameters to be satisfied~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2000ef')]), ', e.g.\nthe maximal atmospheric angles requires ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), TexCmd('simeq'), '\n', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'))], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=67mm,height=50mm'), BraceGroup('figs/atmcorrelationi.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Ratio of semi-leptonic branching ratios, BR', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('chi'), '^0_1', TexCmd('to'), '\n', TexCmd('mu'), "\n  q'", BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q'), ')'], []), ' over Br', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('chi'), '^0_1', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), " q'", BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' q'), ')'], []), ' as a function of\n  the atmospheric neutrino angle calculated within bilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rpv')], []), '\n  SUSY, see ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Porod:2000hv')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:ntrl')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('0.47', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('0.04', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=75mm,height=60mm'), BraceGroup('figs/VisBrmueJ_Om1.ps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Branching ratio BR(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('to'), ' eJ'], []), ') versus visible lightest\nneutralino decay. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('to'), ' eJ'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '^0_1', TexCmd('to'), ' J ', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' are correlated,\nsee ref. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2009ee')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:VisMuEJ')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('0.47', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), ' \n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\nOnce R-parity is broken the LSP decays. The decays of a neutralino LSP\nhave been studied in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('mukhopadhyaya:1998xj,Porod:2000hv')]), '. Decay\nlengths for the neutralino are approximately fixed once the neutrino\nmasses are fitted to experimental data. Typical lengths range from\ntens of cm for very light neutralinos to sub-millimeter for\nneutralinos of several hundred GeV ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Porod:2000hv')]), '.  One of the\nmost exciting aspects of bilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ', however, is the fact that\nonce neutrino angles are fitted to the values\nrequired~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Schwetz:2008er')]), ' by the neutrino\noscillation data, the ratios of LSP decay branching ratios are fixed\nand correlate with the observed neutrino mixing angles, as illustrated\nfor example in fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:ntrl')]), '.  Measurements at the LHC should\nallow to test this prediction, if signals of SUSY are found ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DeCampos:2010yu')]), '.\n\nWithin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' SUSY any supersymmetric particle can be the LSP.  It has been shown that\nwithin bilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' correlations between the measured neutrino\nangles and ratios of LSP decays can be found for all LSP candidates\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2002ys,Restrepo:2001me,Hirsch:2003fe')]), '. Thus, it is \npossible to exclude the\nminimal bilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_p ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-1.0em')]), '/', '\\;', '\\:'], []), ' model experimentally at the LHC.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Spontaneous R-parity violation')]), '\n', '\nIn spontaneous R-parity violation\nmodels~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Aulakh:1982yn,Ross:1984yg,santamaria:1989ic')]), ' R-parity\nviolation results from the minimization of the Higgs potential through\nnonzero sneutrino vacuum expectation values. If lepton number is\nungauged this implies the existence of a\nNambu-Goldstone boson - the majoron. However, a doublet majoron is\nruled out  by LEP measurements of the Z\nwidth~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Amsler:2008zzb')]), '. Hence, viable spontaneous R-parity\nbreaking models must be characterized by two types of sneutrino vevs,\nthose of right and left sneutrinos, singlets and doublets under\n', '\\3', '21\nrespectively~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('masiero:1990uj,romao:1992vu')]), ". These\nobey the ``vev-seesaw'' relation ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_L v_R ', TexCmd('sim'), ' Y_', TexCmd('nu'), ' m_W^2'], []), ' where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is the small Yukawa coupling that governs the strength of\nR--parity violation~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('masiero:1990uj,romao:1992vu')]), '.\n\nIn this case the majoron is so weakly coupled that bounds from LEP and\nastrophysics~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Raffelt:1996wa')]), ' are easily satisfied.  For example,\nthe superpotential of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('masiero:1990uj')]), ' can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [' W &=& ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' H_u ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' Q Y_u  ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' U\n          +  ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' H_d ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' Q Y_d', TexCmd('widehat'), ' D\n          +  ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' H_d ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' L Y_e ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' E \n          + ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' H_u ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' L Y_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), '^c\n          - h_0 ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' H_d ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' H_u ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('Phi'), '\n          + h ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('Phi'), ' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '^c', TexCmd('widehat'), ' S +\n          ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup('3!')]), ' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('Phi'), '^3 . \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:Wsuppot')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe first three terms are the usual MSSM Yukawa terms. The terms\ncoupling the lepton doublets to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '^c'], []), ' fix lepton number.\nThe coupling of the field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('Phi')], []), ' with the Higgs doublets\ngenerates an effective ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), '-term a l', "\\'", 'a the Next to Minimal\nSupersymmetric Standard Model (NMSSM)\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Barbieri:1982eh,Nilles:1982dy,Chamseddine:1982jx')]), '.  \nNote, that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_R = ', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), '^c ', TexCmd('rangle'), ' ', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), ' \ngenerates effective bilinear terms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_i\n= Y_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('i'), ' v_', BraceGroup('R'), ' '], []), ' and that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_R'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup('L_i')], []), ' violate\nlepton number and R-parity spontaneously. \nNeutrino oscillation data enforce\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup('L_i'), '^2 ', TexCmd('ll'), ' v_R^2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup('L_i'), '^2 ', TexCmd('ll'), ' v_d^2+v_u^2'], []), ' implying\n the majoron is mainly a singlet in this model ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2004rw,Hirsch:2005wd')]), '.\n\nThe existence of the majoron affects the phenomenology at colliders mainly in\ntwo ways: (i)  the lightest Higgs\ncan decay invisibly into two majorons ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2004rw,Hirsch:2005wd')]), '. \n(ii) Also the decays of the\nlightest neutralino are affected, since the new decay channel\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '^0_1', TexCmd('to'), ' J ', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is invisible at colliders. In ref.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2006di,Hirsch:2008ur')]), ' it has been shown that this mode can be close\nto 100 percent  for certain parameter combinations implying that a large\nluminosity at the LHC might be required to detect R-parity violation. \nHowever,\nas can be seen in fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:VisMuEJ')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['chi^0_1', TexCmd('to'), ' J ', TexCmd('nu')], []), '  is\ncorrelated with the decay ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('to'), ' J e'], []), ', thus allowing to probe\nfor a complementary part of parameter space ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hirsch:2009ee')]), ' with low\nenergy experiments.\n\n\nSpontaneous ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), '-parity violation can also be obtained by enlarging the\ngauge group \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kuchimanchi:1993jg,Huitu:1994zm,Huitu:1997qu,\nFileviezPerez:2008sx,Everett:2009vy,Barger:2008wn,Ji:2008cq')]), '. In this\ncase the majoron would be the longitudinal component of an additional\nneutral heavy vector boson which can be produced in s-channel processes\nat the LHC.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('LHC studies')]), '\n', '\nIn the following we mainly focus on mSUGRA models which are augmented\nby bilinear R-parity breaking parameters at the electroweak scale implying that\none has  eleven free parameters, namely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta')], []), ',\nsign', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_i'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_i'], []), '.\nIn order to fit current neutrino oscillation data, the effective\nstrength of R-parity violation must be small.\nThis implies that supersymmetric particle spectra are expected to be\nthe same as in the conventional R-parity conserving model, and that processes\ninvolving single production of SUSY states~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('nogueira:1990wz')]), ' are\nnegligible at the LHC and that\nthe only differences occur due to the decays of the LSP.\n\n\nIn these scenarios the lightest neutralino is the LSP and its\n main decay channels  are\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), '^+ ', TexCmd('ell'), '^-'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' =e'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('ell')], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '^+ ', TexCmd('tau'), '^-'], []), ', called ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('tau')], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), '  ', TexCmd('ell')], []), ', called ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('ell')], []), '.\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' q ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' denoted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['jj'], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' q^', TexCmd('prime'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ', called ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), ' jj'], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), ' q^', TexCmd('prime'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ', called ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), ' jj'], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' b ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('b')])], []), ', which we denote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['bb'], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' b ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('b')])], []), ', which we denote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['bb'], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\n\nIn ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deCampos:2007bn')]), ' a comparison has been performed between\nthe reach of LHC for R-parity violating SUSY using the same cuts as\nfor R-parity conserving models ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Baer:2000bs')]), '.\nThe main topologies are: Inclusive jets and missing transverse\nmomentum; zero lepton, jets and missing transverse momentum; one\nlepton, jets and missing transverse momentum; opposite sign lepton\npair, jets and missing transverse momentum; same sign lepton pair,\njets and missing transverse momentum; tri-leptons, jets and missing\ntransverse momentum; multi-leptons, jets and missing transverse\nmomentum.  Due to the reduced missing energy the all-inclusive channel\nwill have a reduced reach in the parameter space. However, the decays\nof the neutralino increase the multiplicities of the multi-lepton\nchannel. As an example we display in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:di:3lep100')]), ' the LHC\nreach in the three-- and multi--lepton channels with/without R--parity\nconservation for an integrated luminosity of 100 fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. These\nconstitute the best standard channels for the discovery of bilinear\nR-parity violation.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n ', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.46', TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('figs/trilep100.eps')]), '\n ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('0.06', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), '\n ', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.46', TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('figs/muitos100.eps')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('LHC discovery potential in the three lepton channel (top\n    panel) and the multi-lepton one (bottom panel) for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=-100'], []), '~GeV,\n    ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), '=10'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' >0'], []), ' and an integrated luminosity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['100'], []), '\n    fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ',  from\n    ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deCampos:2007bn')]), '. ')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:di:3lep100')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', '\nThe sizable decay length of the neutralino is quite useful as\nthis topology has little, if any, background expected at the LHC. This\nfeature has been exploited in\nref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deCampos:2007bn,deCampos:2008re')]), ', where a comparison has\nbeen performed between the reach of LHC for R-parity violating SUSY\nincluding explicitly the displaced vertex topologies.\nIn figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:ms')]), ' we present the displaced vertex reach in\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('0')], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ' plane for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), ' = 10'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' > 0'], []), ',\n    ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=-100'], []), ' GeV.  As one\ncan see form this figure, the LHC will be able to look for the\ndisplaced vertex signal up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('1/2'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' '], []), '800 (1000) GeV\n for a large range of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), '\nvalues and an integrated luminosity of 10 (100) fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. Notice that\nthe reach in this channel is rather independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), '.\nHowever, this signal  disappears in the region where\nthe stau is the LSP due to its rather short lifetime.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n  ', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=7.5cm'), BraceGroup('figs/disp10X100.eps')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Discovery reach for displaced vertices channel in the\n    ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('0')], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ' plane for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), ' = 10'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' > 0'], []), ',\n    ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=-100'], []), ' GeV. The stars (squares) stand for points where there\n    are more than 5 displaced vertex signal events for an integrated\n    luminosity of 10 (100) fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '.  The marked grey (green) area on\n    the left upper corner is the region where the stau is the LSP,  from\n    ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deCampos:2007bn')]), '. ')]), '\n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:ms')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('0.47', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('0.04', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=7cm'), BraceGroup('figs/reach_higgs.eps')]), '\n  ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('LHC reach for Higgs search  in the', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('0')], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), '  plane  for\n    ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tan'), TexCmd('beta'), ' = 10'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0=-100'], []), ' GeV, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' > 0'], []), '. The yellow stars\n    (blue squares) show the reach for an integrated luminosity of\n    10 (100) fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' and the hatched region  the\n    reach of LHCb for an integrated luminosity of 10\n    fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '.  The (yellow) shaded region in the bottom is\n    excluded by direct LEP searches, while the (red)\n    upper--left area represents the region with a stau as\n    LSP; the black lines delimit different regimes of LSP\n    decay length,  from ref. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deCampos:2008ic')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:reach')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('0.47', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), ' \n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', '\nNext we discuss a tantalizing possibility, namely a double discovery\nat the LHC: (i) find evidence for supersymmetry, and (ii) uncover the\nHiggs boson.\nThere are regions in parameter space where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '_1^0'], []), ' may have a sizeable branching ratio up to\n22 percent  into the channel ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), ' h^0'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h^0'], []), ' is the lightest Higgs boson\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deCampos:2008ic')]), '.\nThis would lead to displaced vertices containing two b-jets as a\ncharacteristic signature for Higgs production at the\nLHC~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('deCampos:2008ic')]), '.\nThe displaced vertex signal implies that also LHCb will have good\nsensitivity for such scenarios in particular in case of final states\ncontaining muons such as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '^+ ', TexCmd('mu'), '^-'], []), '.Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:reach')]), ' demonstrates that the ATLAS and CMS experiments\nwill be able to look for the signal up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1/2'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 700'], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(900)'], []), '\nGeV for a LHC integrated luminosity of 10 (100) fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '.\nThe hatched region in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:reach')]), ' indicates the LHCb reach\nfor 10 fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. Due to the strong cut on the pseudo--rapidity\nrequired by this experiment the reach for 2 fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' is severely\ndepleted and only a small region of the parameter space is covered.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Trilinear R-parity breaking')]), '\n', '\n', '\nBilinear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), '-parity violation is essentially equivalent to tri-linear\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), '-parity breaking with the superpotential\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nW_', BraceGroup('tri'), ' = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('textstyle'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')])), '\n ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('ijk'), '  ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' L_i  ', TexCmd('widehat'), ' L_j', TexCmd('widehat'), ' E_k\n + ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('ijk'), "' ", TexCmd('widehat'), ' L_i', TexCmd('widehat'), ' Q_j', TexCmd('widehat'), ' D_k\n'], []), '\nwhere the tri-linear couplings have the following structures\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('ijk'), ' ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'), '_i'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), ' Y^', BraceGroup('jk'), '_e ', '\\,', '\\,', ',', '\\,', '\\,', '\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('ijk'), "' ", TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'), '_i'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), ' Y^', BraceGroup('jk'), '_d\n'], []), '\nObviously the phenomenology will be very similar if tri-linear\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), '-parity violation is close to this structure. In the case of\nsignificant deviations from this structure is realized, one\ngets new interesting signatures. For example there exists light\nstau LSP scenarios where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '_1'], []), ' decays dominantly  via\n4-body decays such as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '^- ', TexCmd('mu'), '^- u ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('d')])], []), '\nwith long lifetimes leading to displaced vertices ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Dreiner:2008rv')]), '.\nAnother interesting signals are the resonant production of sleptons\nas discussed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Dreiner:2000vf,Moreau:2000bs')]), ' or\nassociated production of single sleptons with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), '-quarks\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bernhardt:2008mz')]), '.\n\nAn interesting question is to which extent one can measure deviations\nfrom the hierarchical structure above, e.g.~the coupling ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('211'), "'"], []), '\ncan still be of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.1'], []), '. It has been shown in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Choudhury:2002av')]), '\nthat in such a case one LHC will be able to measure such couplings of such\na strength with an accuracy of about 10 percent .\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Summary')]), '\n', '\nWe have discussed aspects of various extensions of the MSSM taking the\nexplanation of neutrino data as guide-line. As a first model the case\nhas been considered where one adds a Dirac mass term for the neutrinos\nwith tiny Yukawa couplings. In this case one obtains the usual MSSM\nphenomenology except for the case where the right-sneutrino is the LSP\nbecause in this case the NLSP will be very long-lived and one gets as\nsignature quasi-stable particles at the LHC.\n\nIn case of seesaw models one finds that in case of type II and type\nIII models the spectrum can be quite different when compared to the\nusual mSUGRA scenarios as a consequence of additional charged\nparticles between the seesaw scale(s) and the GUT scale. These\ndifferences are the larger the lower the seesaw scale and affect in\nparticular the masses of the sfermions.  One can study four ratios at\nthe LHC which can give information on the GUT scale if one assumes\nuniversal boundary conditions for the soft SUSY breaking parameters at\nthe GUT scale. Moreover, there are parameter regions in all seesaw\nmodels where lepton flavour violating signals can be found in SUSY\ncascade decays. However, for this in general a rather high luminosity\nin the order of 100 ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['fb^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' or higher is required.\n\nSupersymmetric models also offer the possibility to explain neutrino\ndata via R-parity violation. Here we have mainly focused on models\nwhere R-parity is broken by bilinear terms as this is sufficient to\nexplain neutrino data and to explore the relevant LHC\nphenomenology. Moreover, this class of models can be obtained as\neffective model in case of spontaneous R-parity breaking. Bilinear\nR-parity breaking implies correlations between neutrino data and\ndecays properties of the LSP, e.g.~in case of an neutralino LSP the\nratio ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['BR(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' W^- ', TexCmd('tau'), '^+)/BR(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '^0_1 ', TexCmd('to'), ' W^- ', TexCmd('mu'), '^+)\n', TexCmd('simeq'), '\n', TexCmd('tan'), '^2', TexCmd('theta'), '_', BraceGroup('atm')], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), '_', BraceGroup('atm')], []), ' is the mixing angle related to the\nthe atmospheric neutrino sector.\nIn addition one finds very often that the LSP life time is\nsufficiently small to produce a displaced vertex in a typical collider\nexperiments.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgments')]), '\nThis work has been supported by  the DFG, project number PO-1337/1-1,\n the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation and\nthe Spanish grant FPA2008-00319/FPA. \n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('References')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', TexCmd('expandafter'), TexCmd('ifx'), TexCmd('csname'), ' url', TexCmd('endcsname'), TexCmd('relax'), '\n  ', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('url')), BracketGroup('1'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('tt'), ' ', '#1'))]), TexCmd('fi'), '\n', TexCmd('expandafter'), TexCmd('ifx'), TexCmd('csname'), ' urlprefix', TexCmd('endcsname'), TexCmd('relax'), TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('urlprefix')), BraceGroup('URL ')]), TexCmd('fi'), '\n', TexCmd('providecommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('eprint')), BracketGroup('2'), BracketGroup(), BraceGroup(TexCmd('url', [BraceGroup('#2')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('Nilles:1983ge')]), '\nNilles H~P 1984 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' Phys. Just finished parsing: ['{', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('chen')]), ') separately obtained \nthe oxygen abundances of a large\nsample of disk stars, both showed that ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', '   \ndecreases \nwith increasing metallicity in Galactic disk stars. \nFor halo stars, however, available observations exhibit an apparent contradiction,\nnamely,\nthe ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', ' values of metal-poor giants derived from the ', '[', TexCmd('ion', [BraceGroup('O'), BraceGroup('i')]), ']', ' forbidden \nline (+0.4) \nare lower\nthan those of dwarfs from the ', TexCmd('ion', [BraceGroup('O'), BraceGroup('i')]), ' triplet at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), '\\,', '7770 ', TexCmd('AA'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['~'], []), 'and OH lines \n(+1.0) (see Fig. 11).\nAnd using the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), '\\,', '6300 ', TexCmd('AA'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['~'], []), 'forbidden line, similar abundance values to the giants \nhave been obtained for some metal-poor dwarfs, \nthough the line \nis very weak in these stars (Nissen et al. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('NPA20')]), ').\n\nThe difference can be understood from two aspects.\nIn the first aspect, we believe that oxygen has a similar behavior to other \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' elements (Mg, Si, S, Ca), that is, \nwe believe that the lower ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', ' in metal-poor region\nis true, and the relatively higher ratio derived from the ', TexCmd('ion', [BraceGroup('O'), BraceGroup('i')]), ' triplet or OH line is wrong.\nThe reasons are as follows.\nThe ', TexCmd('ion', [BraceGroup('O'), BraceGroup('i')]), '\ntriplet has a very high excitation feature (9.15 eV) and is quite sensitive to the\ntemperature structure of the adopted model atmosphere, and NLTE effects\ncause the higher O abundance derived from it.\nAnd the OH lines in the UV are \nvery sensitive to the temperature structure of the stellar atmosphere and/or\nto NLTE effects too.  \nAccording to this argument,\nthere should be no obvious change in the O abundance \nas the dwarfs evolve to the giants. \n\nOn the other hand, if we believe that the higher ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', ' derived \nfrom the ', TexCmd('ion', [BraceGroup('O'), BraceGroup('i')]), ' triplet and OH line reflects the true O abundance, \nthen we have to reconsider the abundance evolution\nof oxygen, hence the GCE result. \nMaybe the top-heavy IMF is true, which favours the formation of \nmassive stars in the early Galactic stage,\nhence a high O abundance.\nThis assumption would imply a corresponding high ', '[', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), '/Fe', ']', ' in metal-poor dwarfs, which is not found in \npresent available data.\nCould the difference between ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', ' and ', '[', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), '/Fe', ']', '\nmean that their behaviors are ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' not', '\\/'), ' similar?\nPerhaps NLTE effects can revise the present ', '[', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), '/Fe', ']', ' value.\nRecently, Zhao ', '\\&', ' Gehren (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ZG20')]), ') reported that NLTE\neffects can increase the ', '[', 'Mg/Fe', ']', ' abundance, and the corrections are larger \nfor the lower metallicities of the metal-poor stars. \nThus, maybe NLTE corrections can also \nincrease the abundances of other ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' elements at the early Galactic stage. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('input'), ' epsf\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('0cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=8.8cm ', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('h2126f11.ps')]), '\n ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The observed ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', ' vs. ', '[', 'Fe/H', ']', ' data.  \n        Oxygen abundances derived from ', '[', 'O I', ']', ' 6300 ', TexCmd('AA'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['~'], []), 'forbidden line\n        are indicated by triangles, from O I triplet by pluses, \n        and from OH lines in UV region by diamonds.')]), ' \n'], []), '\n', '\nGoswami ', '\\&', ' Prantzos (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('GP20')]), ') pointed out three reasons for the higher ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', '\nvalue\nin low metallicity region: (1) The Fe produced by SN', '\\,', 'Ia explosions \nentered the galactic\nscene as early as ', '[', 'Fe/H', ']', ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' -3'], []), ', instead of ', '[', 'Fe/H', ']', ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' -1'], []), ' in the ``standard"\nscenario; (2) the O yields from massive stars are, for some reasons, metallicity dependent;\n(3) there is the possibility of  \nthe yields of Fe and all elements heavier than oxygen being metallicity-dependent.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup(' Conclusions')]), '\n', '\nUsing the standard GCE model, we have attempted an exploration of  \nthe questions of the sources of carbon\nand the abundance evolution of CNO elements.\nBecause the yield of stellar nucleosynthesis is a very important parameter\nof the GCE model, and different yields give different evolutionary\nbehaviors of the elements, we chose the recently published different \nnucleosynthesis yields: \nthe yields given by RV, VG, MBC and M2K for intermediate-,\nlow-mass single stars; the results of the classical W7 model of \nNomoto et al. (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('nomoto2')]), ') for binary stars through SN', '\\,', 'Ia explosions; the \nyields given by WW, N97, M92 and PCB for massive single stars.\nThen we set up 8 specific models for the combinations, VG+WW, VG+N97, VG+M92, RV+WW, RV+N97, RV+M92, \nMBC+PCB and M2K+PCB.\n\nOur results show that, after fitting the predicted age-metallicity relation, \nmetallicity distribution of G dwarfs and ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', ' vs. ', '[', 'Fe/H', ']', ' relation\nto the observations,  very different ', '[', 'C/Fe', ']', ' vs. ', '[', 'Fe/H', ']', ' relations \nare given by the different models with different yield combinations.\n\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('12')], []), 'C', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('alpha'), ',', TexCmd('gamma'), ')^', BraceGroup('16')], []), 'O reaction rate is very important to \nstellar nucleosynthesis calculations. Hence, it affects the results of the GCE calculations.\nA higher rate of this reaction \nwill produce less carbon, and a lower rate, more.  \nA suitable choice is between the values given by CFHZ and CF.\n\nGenerally speaking, in the early stage\nof our Galaxy, massive stars are the main contributor of carbon.\nAs our Galaxy evolves to the \nlate stage, the long lifetime ILMS begins to play an important role\nin the enrichment of the ISM.  \nAt the same time, \nthe high metallicity W-R stars eject significant amounts of\ncarbon into the ISM \nby radiative-driven stellar wind; the metallicity influences the outer\nopacities and therefore the mass loss rate by stellar winds in massive stars.\nHowever, on the present published nucleosynthesis yields, \nour results still cannot distinguish the source of carbon in metal-rich Galactic stage. It may be that \njust the massive stars (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M>8M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ') \nare sufficient to account for the observed ', '[', 'C/Fe', ']', ' values (see Figs. 3e, 6e); or it may be just the ILMS and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', TexCmd('leq'), ' 40M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ' massive stars without the W-R stars \nare enough to explain the observed carbon in metal-rich stars\n(see Figs. 1b, 7f).\n\nHowever, we can at least distinguish the different contributions of \nILMS and massive stars to carbon from our calculations.\nHaving comparing the GCE results shown in Sect. 5.1', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-'], []), '5.8,\nand considered the undetermined characters of stellar wind  mass loss \nof massive stars,\nand assuming the actual \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('12')], []), 'C', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('alpha'), ',', TexCmd('gamma'), ')^', BraceGroup('16')], []), 'O reaction rate to be between CFHZ and CF, we calculated \nthe respective contributions to carbon from massive stars and ILMS in the model WW+VG.\nFig. 9 shows that, \nin the early stage, almost all carbon is produced by massive stars;\nwith increase of the Galactic age, the contribution from ILMS becomes  more and more and eventually exceeds that of the massive stars. \nThe latter contribution is increased when the contribution from W-R stars is included.\n\nHenry et al. (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('henry20')]), ') gave an excellent analysis on the source of C and N. \nBut they only gave \ndetailed results for the yields of VG for ILMS and M92 \nfor massive stars. And they increased the yields of M92 in their calculations\n(see their Table 3), which increased the contribution of carbon\nfrom massive stars. \n\nCarigi (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('cari20')]), ') compared different set of yield, and suggested that massive stars\nwith stellar wind are the main source of carbon.\nCompared to their work, we use the abundances of a large sample of dwarf stars as \none of the most important observational constraints  \nrather than just the stellar age. The reason is that \nfew halo stars have determined\nages, while the results reported by Edvardsson et al. (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('E93')]), '), Gustafsson\net al. (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Gus99')]), ') and Chen et al. (', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('chen')]), ') \nare only for disk stars,\nso the element abundance in the early stage of the Galaxy cannot be tested by observations.\nIn addition, we divided the massive stars into two ranges, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', TexCmd('leq'), ' 40M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M>40M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ', so that we can compare the carbon contributions \ngiven by W-R stars and ILMS more clearly.\nAnd we use the new set of nucleosynthesis yields of \nM2K, which contain important information \non low metallicity ILMS.\n\nOur results confirm that most of nitrogen is produced by ILMS, especially\nby intermediate mass stars. And the present yields given by massive stars\ncannot supply the needed primary N source. \nMassive stars produce the main part of oxygen in the universe.\nBut the observed O abundances derived from different atomic \nlines lead to \nobvious differences in the ', '[', 'O/Fe', ']', ' determination in metal-poor stars. \nMaybe we should check the procedure and many corresponding \nparameters to obtain abundance of oxygen. \nAlso, perhaps this difference\nhints at some new information on Galactic chemical evolution, especially, \nit is necessary to understand the evolution of our Galaxy in the early stage \ncarefully.\n\n  ', TexNamedEnv('acknowledgements', ['\n  We thank Dr. B.
