Just finished parsing: ['{', 'helical undulator acting as a FEL, to produce photons of high intensity,\nhigh polarisation and high energy (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' 10 ', TexCmd('MeV')], []), '). \nThese hit a \ntarget to produce ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^+ e^-'], []), '-pairs, see Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:eandpsource')]), '.\nTo avoid damage to the target, it is designed as a rotating wheel.\nThe electron beam must have an energy of at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['150 ~', TexCmd('GeV')], []), ': at lower energies\nthe positron yield becomes so low that the positron bunches are not filled\nto full capacity, and the over-all\nluminosity will decrease.\n\nLike the electrons,\nthe positrons are then collected,\npre-accelerated and sent to the damping system.\nThe electrons used to produce the photons are the same as those that\nwill be delivered to the detectors.\nDue to the effect of the helical undulator, the electron beam\nwill therefore obtain an additional energy dispersion.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Damping system')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.45'), BraceGroup('psource-image')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.45'), BraceGroup('esource-image')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Electron (left) and positron (right) sources. From~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('RDR')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:eandpsource')]), '\n'], []), '\nWhen emerging from the sources, the dispersion both in angle and\nenergy of both beams are far to large to be accelerated and delivered\nto the detectors.\nThis dispersion is reduced by\nsending the beams (now at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim')], []), ' 5 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ') to rings where they pass\nwigglers which make them cool off by synchrotron radiation.\nThe particle bunches in the damping ring are kicked out,  one-by-one,\nevery\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim')], []), ' 100 ns to make a bunch train comprising \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(1000)'], []), ' bunches (2625 in the RDR design).\nThe bunches in the damping-rings are separated by a few ns, given\nby the ratio of the circumference of the damping ring to the number of bunches.\nTherefore the kickers must be able to switch on or off in a few ns, which\nis at the limit of current technology.\nThis procedure (cooling and bunch-train assembly) must be completed \nin the 200 ms between bunch trains.\nThe damping rings are at the centre of the complex, so it is needed\nto transport the trains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim')], []), ' 15 km to the start of the\nmain linac after damping.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Main linac')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('wrapfigure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.45'), BraceGroup('rdr-linac-layout-image')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('A section of the main linac. From~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('RDR')]), '.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:mainlinac')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('0.5', TexCmd('columnwidth'))]), '\nThe main linac is made of supra-conducting RF cavities each containing \n9 accelerating\ncells.\nThe accelerating gradient is 31.5 MV/m,\nwhich is the foreseeable limit of this technology.\nOne RF unit contains three cryo-units, two of which contain 9 cavities, \nand one which contains 8\ncavities and a focusing quadrupole.\nThere are 278 RF units in the positron linac, and 282 in the electron one.\nThere are more in the latter, because the energy lost in the undulator\nmust be compensated for.\nHow many particles one can get at the experiment per \ntime-unit depends on how much power is fed into the cavities,\nwhich in turn depends on how many klystrons are installed\nalong the accelerator. How these system are arranged in the RDR \ntwo-tunnel design\ncan be seen in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:mainlinac')]), '.\nIn the RDR design, the positron source is placed at the point\nwhere the electron beam reaches 150 ~', TexCmd('GeV'), ', about 6 km from the\nIP, and  electrons can be delivered \nto the experiment at any energy between 50 and 250 ~', TexCmd('GeV'), ',\nby  appropriately accelerating or decelerating them in the\nremaining\npart of the main linac.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('BDS and final focus')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.4'), BraceGroup('bds-scheme-image')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.4'), BraceGroup('finalfocus-layout-image')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Beam delivery system (left) and Final focus (right). From~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('RDR')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:BDSandfinalfocus')]), '\n'], []), "\nThe last two km of the accelerator is the Beam Delivery System (the BDS).\nIt's purpose is multiple. It should monitor and measure the beam-properties, \nand clean the beam from halo particles.\nIt should also protect the detectors,\nsince anything the beam hits at this location will give secondaries\n- E", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('beam')], []), '\ncould be up to 500 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '~ - that might hit and\ndamage the detectors. A schematic of the BDS is shown to the left in \nFigure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:BDSandfinalfocus')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('wrapfigure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.28'), BraceGroup('rdr-nom')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Beam-strahlung particles in ILD.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:pairsrdrnom')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('0.5', TexCmd('columnwidth'))]), '\nThe final focus system (Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:BDSandfinalfocus')]), ', right) is \nthe last 20 m before the detectors. It\nfocuses the beams to few 100 nm horizontally, and \nfew nm vertically at the centre of the detector.\nThere are several limiting factors on how strongly the beams\ncan be focused, both from fundamental optics, from beam-beam\ninteractions and from stability against ground-motion.\nIn addition, stronger focusing inevitably induces more\nbackground in the detectors. \n\n \n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Beam-strahlung')]), '\n', '\n Due to the very strongly focused beams, both the electric\nand magnetic fields induced by one beam\nhave a large bending power on the other one.\nAs a consequence\nthe primary beam is focused by the other beam,\nand will emit a large amount of \nsynchrotron radiation~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('beambeam')]), TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('schulte')]), '. \nThe emission of synchrotron\nradiation widens the distribution of the\nprimary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'))], []), ' energy.\nIn addition, the synchrotron photons \ncan undergo Compton back-scattering, which in turn\nhas several consequences:\nIt yields a photon component of beam, \nand a long tail to lower\n energies for the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'))], []), ' beam.\nThe resulting relative energy-loss due to beam-strahlung is given by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('BS'), ' ', TexCmd('propto'), ' ', '(E_', BraceGroup('cm'), '/', TexCmd('sigma'), '_z)', TexCmd('times'), '(n^2/(', TexCmd('sigma'), '_x + ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_y)^2)'], []), ',\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('x,y,z')], []), ' are the sizes of the beam in the x,y or z direction,\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' is the number of particles in each bunch~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('beambeam')]), '. \nFurthermore, the synchrotron photons can interact with photons (synchrotron ones,\n or virtual ones) in the other beam,  yielding  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'))], []), '-pairs.\nNecessarily, one of the particles in the\npair will have a charge \n ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' opposite'), ' to that of its parent beam.\nThese particles gets ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' de-focused'), ' rather than focused \nby the other beam, and is the origin of the pair background. \nOf these wrong-sign ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'))], []), ':s, the ones at the outer edge of the beam\nwill encounter the largest bending force.\nThe force is independent of the (longitudinal) momentum\nof the particle, which means that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('T')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' anti-correlates for the pair background, \nand that it accumulates at a quite sharp edge in the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('T')], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' plane.\nTo study the effect of the pair background on the detector, \nit is useful to also draw the detector in these\ncoordinates: \n Place each detector element at  the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('T')], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' \n corresponding to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('T')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' a particle should \n have to turn back at \n the radius and z of the element.\nAs an example, Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:pairsrdrnom')]), ' shows the distribution\nof the beam-strahlung pairs in ILD in these coordinates, \nfor RDR design with nominal \nbeam-parameters. The pairs were generated\nwith GuineaPig~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('schulte')]), ', and the simulation shows \nthat there are some 124000 particles \ncreated per bunch-crossing.\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Luminosity')]), '\nThe Luminosity(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ')  is defined as the\ndensity of particles that pass each other per time-unit,\nie. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L=N^2/(t ', TexCmd('times'), ' A)'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is the transverse area of the\nbeam at the interaction point.\nThe number of interactions per time unit is therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' multiplied by\nthe cross-section for the considered physics process.\nFor the number of particles passing each other (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ') per time-unit, one has that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N^2/t = n^2 N_', BraceGroup('bunch'), ' f_', BraceGroup('rep')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' is the number of particles in the bunch,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' N_', BraceGroup('bunch')], []), ' is the number of bunches \nin the train, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('rep')], []), ' is the number of trains per second.\nOne can note that RF-power (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_', BraceGroup('RF')], []), ') needed also depends\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n, N_', BraceGroup('bunch'), ','], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('rep')], []), ' :  \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' P_', BraceGroup('RF'), '= E_', BraceGroup('cm'), ' ', '(n N_', BraceGroup('bunch'), ' f_', BraceGroup('rep'), ') ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('eta'), ' '], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' is\nthe efficiency of the transfer from the RF-system to the beam.\nHence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L ', TexCmd('propto'), ' P_', BraceGroup('RF'), 'n/AE_', BraceGroup('cm')], []), '. \nFurthermore, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ', the cross-section of beams at the IP,\none has that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A ', TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_x ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_y'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_x'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_y'], []), '\nare the horizontal and vertical sizes of the beam, respectively.\nThese sizes are given by the final focus system, the damping system\nand the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' factor of the beams (proportional to the beam energy):\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))]), ' = \n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('norm'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' / ', TexCmd('gamma'))]), ' '], []), '.\nHere\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' is the emittance, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup('norm')], []), ' is the normalised \nemittance - which\nis the figure of merit of  the\ndamping system - and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ', the focusing-power of the final focus system.\nIt therefore follows that to get high ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ', \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_x ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_y'], []), ' should be small. \nHowever, as mentioned above, the relative energy-loss due to beam-strahlung \nis inversely proportional to  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_x + ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_y'], []), ',\nso to reduce it, this sum should be large.\nThe way to achieve small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_x ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_y'], []), ' and\nlarge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_x + ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_y'], []), ' at the same time is to make\nthe  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_x'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_y'], []), ' as different as possible, \nie. to have a flat beam.\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_y << ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_x'], []), ', one has\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n/', TexCmd('sigma'), '_x ', TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('BS'), TexCmd('sigma'), '_z/E_', BraceGroup('cm'))]), ' '], []), '.\nTherefore one can write a number of scaling-laws for\nthe luminosity, that puts emphasis on different design-parameters:\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate*', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('RDR and SB2009')]), '\nThe aim of SB2009 proposal~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SB2009')]), ' is to save cost, while \nstill full-filling the ILC scope document~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('scope')]), ".\n\nThe main changes wrt. the RDR design is to house the\nmain linac and it's support systems in a single tunnel \n(meaning a re-design of the RF-system),\nhalf the beam power (meaning half as many \nbunches in the train, which apart from reducing the\nneed for klystrons and cooling by two, would allow to make the\ndamping rings smaller),\nwhile keeping the same total luminosity by stronger final focusing, and\nto move the positron source to end of the linac \n(easier logistics and higher positron yield).\n\n", TexNamedEnv('wrapfigure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.29'), BraceGroup('psource-sb09-espread-image2')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Energy-spread of incoming electron beam. Blue: RDR, \nGreen: SB2009 with 5 Hz rep-rate, Red: SB2009 with 2.5 Hz rep-rate. \nFrom~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SB2009')]), '.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:Espread')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('0.5', TexCmd('columnwidth'))]), '\nFor the performance of the machine,\nthis design has a number of issues:\nThe decrease of the beam-size will increase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('BS')], []), ',\nmeaning that the luminosity within 1  percent  of nominal \nreduced from 0.83 to 0.72 at 500 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '.\nIt also gives more overlaid tracks in the detector,\nand twice as much energy in the low angle calorimeter\n(the BeamCal).\nThe halving of the number of\nbunches at constant total luminosity \nwill double the luminosity per bunch-crossing,\nand hence the probability to have a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' event\nin the same bunch-crossing as a physics event.\nThe move of the positron source will give lower\nluminosity below 300 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', since - as described above -\nonce the electron beam is below 150 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', the positron\nbunches will not be full. Since the source is\nat the end of the linac, the option to decelerate the beam after\nthe undulator no longer exists. At 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', the luminosity\nwould only be third of the RDR value.\nIn addition, at 500 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', the electron beam energy-spread\nwill\nincrease from  0.16  percent  to 0.21  percent  and the positron polarisation \nwill \ndecrease from 33  percent  to 22 percent , as can be seen in\nFigures~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:Espread')]), ' and~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:polandyield')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('wrapfigure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.5'), BraceGroup('psource-sb09-yield-pol-image')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Positron yield and polarisation. From~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SB2009')]), '.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:polandyield')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('0.5', TexCmd('columnwidth'))]), '\nIt should be noted that the total luminosity \nwould be unchanged wrt. RDR only if a novel focusing\nscheme - the Travelling Focus (TF) scheme~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('TF')]), '- can be made\npractical. If not, the SB2009 proposal would yield\na total luminosity 25  percent  lower than the RDR design\nalready at 500 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '.\n\n\n\n\nAs mentioned above, the increase of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('BS')], []), '\nincreases the number of beam-strahlung pairs per bunch-crossing\nby\napproximately a factor two. The detector-elements for which this\nis most likely to pose a problem is the vertex-detector,\nand the BeamCal. In ILD, the vertex detector integrates\nover a fixed time-window, which is much longer than the\nintra-bunch separation, so given the fact that\nthe number of bunches per train is reduced by a factor\ntwo in the SB2009 design, the number of hits in each\ntime window will be approximately the same for the two\ndesigns~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SB2009vtx')]), '. \nThe BeamCal, on the other hand, has a read-out fast enough\nto read single bunch-crossings.\nAs can be seen in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:bcalnumberanddensity')]), ', showing hit\nand energy densities for the two designs, the SB2009 would give\na doubling of the background levels.\nThe plots show only the GuineaPig simulation, not\nthe full detector simulation, but does include effects of\nthe crossing-angle and compensating magnetic field (the anti-DID  field).\nThe issue is whether  one still can detect a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('approx')], []), ' 250 GeV\n       electron from a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' process over the increased\npair-background.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.32'), BraceGroup('talk_p10')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.32'), BraceGroup('talk_p14')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Hits (left) and energy-density (right) in\nthe ILD BeamCal. Solid red: SB2009, Dashed blue: RDR.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:bcalnumberanddensity')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('SB2009 and physics')]), '\n', '\nTwo examples will be used to show the impact on the performance\nof the different designs: \nThe analysis of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stau')], []), " in the SUSY \nbenchmark point SPS1a'~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('sps1ap')]), ', which is sensitive to background\nand polarisation,\nand the measurement of the mass of a light SM Higgs with the recoil mass\nmethod~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('higgsrecoil')]), ',\nwhich is sensitive to the luminosity at lower ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), ".\n\nThese two examples are not chosen at random. They both represent\ncorner-stone physics cases for the ILC in their own right.\nThis is even more so in view of the LHC program up to\n2012: On one hand, the (probable) non-observation of the\nHiggs in first LHC run would further strengthen the \nhypothesis that the Higgs is indeed SM-like and has a mass\nclose to the LEP exclusion limit. \nOn the other hand, the current best fit of SUSY as an explanation\nto all lower energy and cosmological observations, both those\nthat show no tension between the SM and the observations, and\nthose that do (eg. the muon g-2 or the cosmological evidence\nfor the existence of dark matter) is quite close to SPS1a'~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ewfit')]), '.\nIf this type of model turns out to be realised in nature,\nthe SUSY spectrum, including the squarks and the gluino, would\nbe light enough that there is a good chance that LHC will\ndiscover SUSY in the first run~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LHC')]), '.\nHence, and due to the time it would require to modify accelerator\ndesigns and to carry out a complete physics analysis,\nit is prudent that the ILC community already now is\nprepared to demonstrate that the ILC is right machine\nfor the future,\nwould any of these observations be done by the time of the\n2012 summer conferences.\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('SB2009 and physics: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stau')], []), " in SPS1a'")]), '\nThe ILD analysis of the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stau')], []), " in SPS1a' is described\nin detail elsewhere~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LOI')]), TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('staupaper')]), TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('peterthesis')]), ",\nand only a few remarks are added here.\n\n\nSPS1a' is a a pure mSUGRA model that \npredicts SUSY particles just outside what is \nexcluded by LEP and low-energy\nobservations. \nIt is compatible with the observations of WMAP, with the \nlightest SUSY particle as the Dark Matter candidate.\nThe LSP is the lightest neutralino, ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('XN', [BraceGroup('1')])], []), '.\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS'), '=500 ~', TexCmd('GeV')], []), ', all sleptons are [BraceGroup('1')]), ' ', TexCmd('XN', [BraceGroup('3')])], []), ')\nwould also be observable. There are a total of 13 distinct channels\nthat would be observable below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), '=500 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ", a fact that demonstrates\nthe great advantage of a machine that can deliver high luminosities\nat a large range of centre-of-mass energies. \n\nIn SPS1a', the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stone')], []), ' is the Next to Lightest SUSY Particle, the  NLSP,\nand has a mass only 10 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ' ', '~above the LSP mass ( \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mstone'), ' = 107.9~', TexCmd('GeV'), ' ,  ', TexCmd('msttwo'), ' = polarisation, and\n100  percent  left electron polarisation (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('P')]), '_', BraceGroup('beam'), '=(1,-1)'], []), '), the cross-sections\nfor ', [BraceGroup('P')]), '_', BraceGroup('beam'), '=(-1,1)'], []), ', these cross-sections almost vanish.\nTherefore, the degree of polarisation of both beams is a very powerful\ntool to ameliorate the signal to background ratio.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('wrapfigure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.27'), BraceGroup('durham-delphi')]))]), '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ', ', TexCmd('genfrac', [BraceGroup(), BraceGroup(), BraceGroup('0pt'), BraceGroup(), BraceGroup('min'), BraceGroup('(max)')])), TexCmd('approx'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('s')])), BraceGroup('4')]), '(1-(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('MXN', [BraceGroup('1')])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mstau'))]), ')^2)\n(1 ', TexCmd('genfrac', [BraceGroup(), BraceGroup(), BraceGroup('0pt'), BraceGroup(), BraceGroup('-'), BraceGroup('(+)')]), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('mstau'), '^2'), BraceGroup('s')]))]), ')'], []), '\n', '(neglecting the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' mass).\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stone')], []), ' decays the resulting spectrum of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ':s has\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',min'), ' = 2.6~', TexCmd('GeV'), ' , E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',max'), ' = 42.5~', TexCmd('GeV')], []), ',\nhence much of the signal will be hidden in the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma')], []), '\nbackground. \nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sttwo')], []), ' one finds that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',min'), ' = 35.0~', TexCmd('GeV'), ' , E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',max'), ' = 152.2~', TexCmd('GeV')], []), '.\nFor such a spectrum, the background from\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W W arrow l', TexCmd('nu'), ' l', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' will be an issue, while\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' background is expected to be small.\nTo determine the ', TexCmd('stau'), ' ', '~mass \nfrom the spectrum, one needs to accurately\nmeasure the end-point of the spectrum of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' decay\nproducts, which is equal to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',max')], []), '.\nIn principle, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' decay spectrum has a kink\nat  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',min')], []), ', but - at least for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stone')], []), ' - this\nregion is completely hidden in the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' background.\nTherefore, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('MXN', [BraceGroup('1')])], []), ' must be found from other channels, to be able\nto determine the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stau')], []), ' mass from the measurement of the end-point.\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stau')], []), ' production cross-section is given by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('stau')), ' = A(', TexCmd('theta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('stau')), ',', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('P')]), '_', BraceGroup('beam'), ') ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '^3/s'], []), ', so\nthat a measurement of this cross-section can be used to determine\nthe mass by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mstau'), ' = E_', BraceGroup('beam'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-(', TexCmd('sigma'), ' s/A)^', BraceGroup('2/3'))])], []), ', which does not\ndepend on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('MXN', [BraceGroup('1')])], []), '.\n\n\nFor the ILD LOI~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LOI')]), ", all SM processes were fully simulated, as was the\nfull SPS1a' model. The\nbeam-background was estimated by generating 1000 bunch-crossings \nwith GuineaPig, simulating the detector response, and reconstructing \nthese with the full ILD reconstruction procedure, to create a pool of\nbunch-crossings. For each physics event,\none bunch-crossing from the pool was randomly chosen and overlaid\nbefore the event was analysed.\n\nThe properties of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stau')], []), ' events are:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize*', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nA set of cuts were found to select such events,\nand to suppress the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' background\nfurther cuts were applied, among which was the requirement that\nthere should be no significant activity in the BeamCal,\nsee~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('staupaper')]), '\nfor details. \nIt should be noted that to get an acceptably low\nbackground, it is paramount to have good ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ':s only, ie.\nto have no extra or missing charged tracks.\nIn particular in the presence of beam-background, general jet-finders\nperform poorly when used to find ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ':s.\nTherefore the DELPHI ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), '-finder~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('delphimssm')]), ' was adopted.\nIt was found to perform better than the Durham algorithm forced to two jets \n(the ILD default) already without\nbackground, see Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:taujetfinding')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('st1mass_epj_log')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('st2mass_epj_lin')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('End-point fit for ', TexCmd('stone'), ' ', '(left) and ', TexCmd('sttwo'), ' ', '(right).\nLight grey (yellow) histogram: signal, grey (red) : SM background, \ndark grey (green): SUSY background. The fit to\nthe background in blue. \nFit to total sample: Solid (red) line.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:endpointfit')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nAs has been emphasised above, only the upper end-point is relevant\nfor the determination of the mass from the spectrum.\nThe remaining background in this region needs to\nbe subtracted from the observed distribution,\nand due to the difference in the amount of poorly known\nSUSY background, this is done differently for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stone')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sttwo')], []), '.\nIn the case of ', TexCmd('stone'), ', a substantial amount of SUSY background remain\nnear the end-point,\nwhich can be estimated from the data, by the\nobservation that the region above 45 ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('GeV')], []), ' is signal-free. \nAn exponential distribution was fitted to the data in this\nregion, and was extrapolated to lower jet energies.\nFor ', TexCmd('sttwo'), ', on the contrary, there is hardly any SUSY processes other than the signal\nthat gives jets\nabove 45 ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('GeV')], []), ', so the background\ncan be estimated from SM-only simulation.\nIn both cases, the upper tail of the signal spectrum was\nthe obtained by fitting a line to the observed spectrum after\nsubtracting the fitted background. The spectra with signal and\nbackground fits are shown in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:endpointfit')]), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('eps-st1')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('eps-st2')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Events selected for the cross-section measurement for\n', TexCmd('stone'), ' ', '(left) and ', TexCmd('sttwo'), ' ', '(right). The selected events are\nthose with jet-energies in the indicated windows.\nLegend as in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:endpointfit')]), '.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:crosssection')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', '\nThe poorly known SUSY background is the most\nimportant contribution to uncertainty of the cross-section\nmeasurement, so efforts need to be made to\nselect region where is is as low as possible. The finally selected\nevents are shown in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:crosssection')]), '.\n\nThe potential effects of the modified machine properties\nfor the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stau')], []), ' analysis include:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize*', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), ' \n     ', '& ', TexCmd('multicolumn', [BraceGroup('6'), BraceGroup('c|'), BraceGroup('Events for end-point analysis')]), ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\ncase & ', TexCmd('multicolumn', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('c|'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('stone'))]), ' ', '&  ', TexCmd('multicolumn', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('c|'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sttwo'))]), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n           ', '&  SM    &     SUSY     &  signal &    SM    &    SUSY  & signal \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n RDR       & 317    &     998      &   10466 &   1518   &    241   &  1983  \n SB09(TF)  & 814    &     956      &    8410 &   1346   &    223   &  1555  \n SB09(noTF) & 611    & ' \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n     ', '& ', TexCmd('multicolumn', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('c|'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('stone'))]), ' ', '&  ', TexCmd('multicolumn', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('c|'),  2377 &   1362   &    33.7  &  1775  \n SB09(TF)  & 17.6   &     45.7     &    1784 &   1194   &    32.4  &  1366  \n SB09(noTF) & 13.2   &     34.3     &    1337 &    895   &    24.3  &  1025  \n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Events after cuts in the ', TexCmd('stau'), ' ', '~analysis for \ndifferent designs (RDR, SB2009 with of without travelling focus).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:events')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('b')]), '\n', '\nThe procedure to modify the fully simulated RDR sample\nto represent the SB2009 design was as follows:\nOur studies of the BeamCal indicates\nthat the energy density in either SB2009 design (with or without\nTF) is about twice the RDR value at all radii.\nFor the LOI studies, the energy density from the beam-strahlung pairs\n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_E'], []), ') was mapped out over the surface of the BeamCal,\nusing the simulation \nwith the RDR beam-parameters.\nThe probability ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p(E_e , ', TexCmd('rho'), '_E)'], []), '\nto detect an electron \nof energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_e'], []), ' in the BeamCal over a local \nenergy density \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_E'], []), ' was then determined and parametrised.\nHence, the procedure factorises between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_E'], []), ', which depends on\nthe beam-parameters, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p(E_e , ', TexCmd('rho'), '_E)'], []), ", which doesn't.\nTherefore, the SB2009 sensitivity for high-energy beam-remnants could be\nestimated simply by scaling up ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_E'], []), " from it's RDR value by a factor\ndetermined to be 2.33,\nand using the previously determined probability  ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p(E_e , ', TexCmd('rho'), '_E)'], []), '.\nTo estimate how many tracks the beam-background would\ncreate in the tracking system, a pool of fully simulated\nbunch-crossings with SB2009 parameters was created and the\nsame procedure as for the LOI-RDR study (see above) was applied.\nThe different beam-spectrum was treated by using the\nspectra obtained from GuineaPig for both RDR and\nSB2009 to calculate event-by-event weights based on\nthe beam-energies of each individual event.\nFinally, it was straight-forward to account for the \nreduced positron polarisation by correctly adjusting the\nrelative weights of  \nsamples \ngenerated with either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('P')])], []), '=(-1,1) or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('P')])], []), '=(1,-1).\n\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n          ', '&  &  ', TexCmd('multicolumn', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('c'), BraceGroup('end-point (', TexCmd('GeV'), ')')]), '&\n                ', TexCmd('multicolumn', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('|c|'), BraceGroup('cross-section ( percent )')]), ' \ncase      &', '\\#', '&  ', TexCmd('stone'), '   ', '&   ', TexCmd('sttwo'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('stone'), ' ', '&    ', TexCmd('sttwo'), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n RDR      & 1&  0.129    &    1.83  &  2.90  &     4.24\n +SB bck  & 2&  0.144    &    2.02  &  3.03  &     4.72\n +SB ppol & 3&  0.153    &    2.06  &  3.31  &     4.77\n +SB spect& 4&  0.152    &    2.10  &  3.52  &     5.09\n +SB noTF & 5&  0.179    &    2.42  &  3.79  &     5.71\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('|l|l|c|c|c|c|')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Errors on end-point and cross-section for the ', TexCmd('stau'), ' ', "~analysis, with different beam conditions:\n1) RDR, 2) RDR, but with background as with SB2009, 3) as 2) but with SB2009:s reduced\npositron polarisation, 4) Nominal SB2009, with TF, ie. as 3) but with SB2009's beam-spectrum,\n5) SB2009 without TF.")]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:errors')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('sbrdr_rel')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('sbrdr_time')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The effect of beam-parameters for the\nresults of the ', TexCmd('stau'), ' ', '~analysis. The left plot shows\nthe uncertainty wrt. the RDR value, while the right one\nshows the increase in data-taking time needed to achieve\nthe RDR value. Red: cross-section,\n    Blue: end-point,\n    Solid : ', TexCmd('stone'), ' , Dashed: ', TexCmd('sttwo'), '.\nThe numbers on the x-axis are explained in caption of Table~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:errors')]), '. ')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:rdrtosbstau')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\nTable~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:events')]), ' shows the number of events after cuts,  \nfor the end-point and cross-section analyses, \nwhile Table~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:errors')]), ' shows the error on the end-point  \nand cross-section, for different machine\nproperties. In Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:rdrtosbstau')]), ', these numbers\nare plotted both as the ratio of uncertainties with respect to the RDR value,\nand as the increase in data-taking time needed to compensate\nfor the weaker performance.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('SB2009 and physics: SM Higgs at 120 ', TexCmd('GeV'))]), '\nThe potential effect on the measurement of the mass of a \nlight (120 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ') SM Higgs due to SB2009 modifications of\nthe ILC is the\nfactor 3 to 4 decrease of luminosity at optimal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('approx')], []), ' 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ').\nThis reduced luminosity is, as has been explained\nabove, due to move of positron source.\nOther aspects of SB2009 should pose no problems:\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS'), '='], []), ' 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', the \nundulator works at the same working-point for RDR and SB2009,\nso no differences in incoming beam-spread nor positron polarisation\nare expected.\nThe Higgs recoil-mass analysis, described in detail in~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LOI')]), ' and~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ILDhiggs')]), ', \nonly depends on the\nprecise measurement of the decay of the Z to high momentum muon or\nelectron pairs.\nHence, it is not sensitive to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('gamma')], []), '\nbackground, nor to overlaid background tracks.\n\nIt has been suggested to do the analysis at 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', where luminosity\nloss is much \nless important(20-40  percent ). \nHowever, the cross-section is sizably lower at this energy,\nand since the lepton-pairs will have higher momenta,\nthe experimental resolution will be worse.\nSince this channel was not studied\nat 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ' ', '~for the LOI,\na fast simulation was set up to bring the\nexperience gained from full simulation at 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ' ', '~to\nan estimate of the performance at 350~', TexCmd('GeV'), ', both for the RDR and SB2009\ndesigns~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('hengnefast')]), '.\nThe fast simulation has been verified with respect to the full simulation at 250~', TexCmd('GeV'), ', \nwith RDR parameters, and  excellent agreement was found.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('cmp_rdr_250_350')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('cmp_sb_250b_350')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Recoil Mass for the RDR design (left) and the SB2009, without \nTF (right) for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), '=250 and 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'))]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:higgsrdrsn-250-350')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('b')]), '\nOne could then compare the recoil-mass peak obtainable with the\nsame running-time at 250 or 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', for RDR and SB2009.\nTwo observations can be done in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:higgsrdrsn-250-350')]), ':\nAs expected, there is a much larger loss of events going from\n350 to 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ' ', '~in the SB2009 design, than what is observed for the RDR\ndesign.\nFurthermore, for both designs, the peak is broader at 350 ~', TexCmd('GeV'), ',\nwhich, as can be seen in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:higgsgen-sim')]), ', is due to the deterioration\nof the momentum resolution at higher track moments.\nTable~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tab:higgserrors')]), ' shows the details of the deterioration of\nthe measurement wrt. the LOI design.\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup('    ', TexNamedEnv('tabular', [' \n    ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n    Beam Par & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' int'))])], []), ' ', '(fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ') & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' ', '& S/B & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '(M_', BraceGroup('H'), ')'], []), ' ', '(GeV)& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('sigma'), '/', TexCmd('sigma')], []), '  \n    ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n    RDR 250 &\t\t188\t& 55 percent  & 62 percent  & 0.043 & 3.9 percent  \n    RDR 350 &\t\t300\t& 51 percent  & 92 percent  & 0.084 & 4.0 percent  \n    SB2 TF 250b &\t68\t& 55 percent  & 62 percent  & 0.071 & 6.4 percent  \n    SB  TF 350 &\t250\t& 51 percent  & 92 percent  & 0.092 & 4.3 percent  \n    SB2 noTF 250b &\t55\t& 55 percent  & 62 percent  & 0.079 & 7.2 percent  \n    SB Wolf 350 &\t175\t& 51 percent  & 92 percent  & 0.110 & 5.2 percent  \n    ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n    '], [BraceGroup('|l|c|c|c|c|c|')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Performance of the Higgs recoil mass analysis for different beam conditions.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:higgserrors')]), '\n'], []), ' \n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('wrapfigure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.3'), BraceGroup('cmp_mc_fs')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Generated and simulated Recoil Mass for the RDR design,\nat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), '=250 and 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'))]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig:higgsgen-sim')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('0.5', TexCmd('columnwidth'))]), '\nOne can note that for the RDR design, the 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '~result \nis best both for cross-section and mass measurements,\nwhile for the SB2009 (TF), the  250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '~result is best for the mass \nmeasurement, while the 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '~is the best for the cross-section measurement.\nHence, for SB2009, one must choose which running scheme to use:\neither the mass-measurement will worse by 110  percent , \nbut the cross-section only by 10  percent  with respect to the RDR design,\nor the mass-measurement will be worse by a more modest 70  percent , \nat the expense that the cross-section will be worse by 65  percent .\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conclusions and outlook')]), '\n', '\n', '\nIn section 1, the ILC was briefly described, and it was \npointed out that depending on what \nis built in to the machine design (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_', BraceGroup('RF')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('rep')], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup('bunch')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('BS')], []), ' ...), luminosity scales differently\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('cm')], []), ',\nand that different machine setups give\ndifferent luminosity scaling, different polarisation scaling,\ndifferent energy within 1  percent  to nominal, and different spread \nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('beam')], []), '.\nThe key issues for performance were pointed out, and\nhow they relate to technological challenges for the accelerator\ndesign.\n\nFrom studying the effect of the transition from\nthe RDR to the SB2008 designs on the ', TexCmd('stau'), ' ', "~analysis it was seen\nthat for such ``fragile'' signals, beam-background influences signal \ndirectly.\nIt was also seen that for any ``low ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '(m)'], []), "'' (", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['< 10'], []), ' GeV) signal, \nbeam-background should\nbe taken into \nconsideration when estimating ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' background.\nIt was found that effect of replacing the RDR \nbeam-parameters by the SB2009 ones, the measurement quality\ndegrades by 15-20  percent , both for\nthe end-point and cross-section measurements, and both for the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('stone')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sttwo')], []), ' channels. \nOf this degradation, half comes from the modifications\nof the positron source, namely the larger spread in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), ', \nand the reduction in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('P')]), '(e^+)'], []), ". \nIt was also shown that the degradation increases to 20-40  percent ,\nif the travelling focus concept would turn out to be unfeasible.\nIt was pointed out that degradation can be compensated for\nby increasing the data-taking period by 40  percent  (or 80  percent \nin the no travelling focus case).\nIt was also pointed out that for a low-mass SUSY scenario like SPS1a',\nmany thresholds are expected below ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), '=500 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ',\nemphasising the importance of having an accelerator tunable in\nenergy.\n\nBy studying the effects of the transition on the SM Higgs\nrecoil-mass analysis, it was observed\nthat \nthe results will not scale with cross-section\nif the analysis is done a different ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), ', since the\ndetector resolution depends on energy. At ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), ' = 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ',\nthe influence on the error on the Higgs mass from the detector\nresolution is quite small compared to the spread of the\nbeam energy, but already at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS')], []), ' = 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ',\ndetector effects dominate the error.\nIt was found that  replacing the RDR design by the SB2009 one\ndegrades the quality of the mass measurement by 110 percent , and the\ncross-section measurement by 10  percent  (if the analysis is done\nat 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '), or by 70  percent  and 65  percent  (if it is done at 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ').\nWithout travelling focus, the numbers are 160  percent  and 30  percent  (at 350 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ')\nor 80  percent  and 85  percent  (at 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), '). To compensate\nfor these losses in precision by longer data-taking\nis difficult: at least three times more time need\nto be spent at an energy where the Higgs channel\nis likely to be the only channel to study.\nThe loss in performance is in this case completely \ndriven by loss of luminosity at 250 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ', which is entirely\ndue to move of positron source. \n\nHence, both these studies arrive at the conclusion that the\nmove of the positron source has a disproportionally large effect\non the performance, while the increased background has\nless of an impact.\n\nSince the presentation of the SB2009 proposal in December 2009,\nit has been reviewed by the AAP~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('aap')]), ' and the PAC~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('pac')]), ", \nand a committee\n(the ``Brau committee'') has been set up to review the performance\nissues the proposal gave rise to. In particular, the effect\nof the move of the positron source has received much attention.\nThe GDE has subsequently set up a series of work-shops aiming to solve\nthis and other issues by mid-2011, and defined a formal \n``change control process'' for the baseline design of the ILC.\n\nThere are no significant financial savings from placing\nthe positron source at the end of the linac. \nHowever, from the \noperational point of view,\nit is strongly preferred to have it at that location, \nsince this would  keep the main linac tunnel free\nof a potentially delicate sub-system,\nand rather concentrate it with all other sub-systems (the electron source,\nthe damping rings, BDS, etc.)\nto a central campus, where access and maintenance would be eased.\nSeveral promising schemes are investigated\nto avoid the large loss of luminosity below ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('CMS'), '='], []), '300 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ',\nwhile still placing the source at the end of the linac.\nThe most probable solution is to use the fact that at lower\nbeam-energies, there is enough spare RF-power to\nincrease the repetition rate to 10 Hz. One would then accelerate  every other\nelectron bunch-train to 150 ', TexCmd('GeV'), ' ', '~to produce positrons,\nand every other, at a lower energy, would be sent to the\ndetector.\nThe feasibility of this scheme is under study, in particular\nwith respect to which modifications would be needed to the\ndamping system to accommodate a higher repetition rate.\n\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('footnotesize', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('RDR')]), " ILC GDE and WWS, Editors N. ~Phinney, N.~Toge, and N.~Walker,\n``International Linear Collider Reference \nDesign Report - Vol. 3: Accelerator'', (2007).\n", TexCmd('url', [BraceGroup('http://ilcdoc.linearcollider.org/getfile.py?docid=182&name=ILC_RDR_Volume_3-Accelerator&format=pdf')]), '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('SB2009')]), "\nILC GDE, Editors M.~Ross, N.~Walker, and A.~Yamamoto,\n``SB2009 Proposal Document'', (2009).\n", TexCmd('url', [BraceGroup('http://lcdev.kek.jp/SB2009/SB20091217B.pdf')]), '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('beambeam')]), "K.~Yokoya and P.~Chen, ``Frontiers of Particle Beams: Intensity Limitations'', \nedited by M.~Month and S.~Turner, Lecture Notes in Physics Vol. 400 (Springer-Verlag, Berlin), (1990) 415.\n", TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('schulte')]), 'D.~Schulte, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' PhD Thesis'), ', DESY/Universit', '\\"', 'at Hamburg, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' DESY-TESLA-97-08'), ', (1997).\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('scope')]), "R.~Heuer (chair) ``ICFA -
