[BraceGroup(TexCmd('goodbreak'))]), '\n'], []), '\nUnder Assumptions (AL2), (AT1), (AT2), (AK) and (AH) we derive\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('psibound')]), '\n', '\\|', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '-', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('L_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), '(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ',w)'), '=O_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('a.s')]), '.'), TexCmd('Biggl'), '( ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('log'), '^', BraceGroup('3+', TexCmd('varepsilon')), '\nn'), BraceGroup('n')]))]), TexCmd('Biggr'), ')\n'], []), '\nwith a weighting function\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\nw(u)=', TexCmd('biggl', [BracketGroup(' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup('u'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1+|', TexCmd('psi'), "'_", BraceGroup('k'), '(v)|'), BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), "'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'), '\n'), '(-', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '(v))|')]), ' ', '\\,', 'dv ', TexCmd('biggr'))]), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '.\n'], []), '\nNow let us define an estimate for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), ' '], []), ' as a\nsolution of the following optimization problem\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lest')]), '\n', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), '=', TexCmd('arg'), TexCmd('inf'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))), TexCmd('sup'), '_', BraceGroup('u', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])), TexCmd('bigl'), '\\{', ' w(u)', TexCmd('bigl'), '| ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(-', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '(u))-', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('phi'), TexCmd('bigl'), '(u^', BraceGroup('(k)'), TexCmd('bigr'), ') ', TexCmd('bigr'), '| ', TexCmd('bigr'), '\\}', ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), ' '], []), ' is the set of completely monotone\nfunctions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), ' '], []), ' satisfying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(0)=1 '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), "'(0)=-", TexCmd('Delta')], []), '. Simple calculations and the bound (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('psibound')]), ') yield\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lbound')]), '\n', TexCmd('sup'), '_', BraceGroup('u', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])), '\\{', ' w(u)| ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'), '\n'), '(-', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '(u))-', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), '(-', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '(u)) |\n', '\\}', '\n=O_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('a.s')]), '.'), TexCmd('Biggl'), '( ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('log'), '^', BraceGroup('3+', TexCmd('varepsilon')), ' n'), BraceGroup('n')]))]), TexCmd('Biggr'), ').\n'], []), '\nSince any function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), ' '], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), ' '], []), '\nhas a representation\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(u)=', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), 'e^', BraceGroup('-u x'), '\\,', 'dF(x)\n'], []), '\nwith some distribution function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' F '], []), ' satisfying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('int'), ' x\n', '\\,', 'dF(x)=', TexCmd('Delta'), '\n'], []), ', we can replace the optimization\nover ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('M')]), ' '], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lest')]), ') by the optimization over the\ncorresponding set of distribution functions. The advantage of the\nlatter approach is that herewith we can directly get an estimate for\nthe distribution function of the r.v. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '(', TexCmd('Delta'), ')'], []), '. A\npractical implementation of the estimate (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lest')]), ') is still to be\nworked out, as the optimization over the set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), ' '], []), "\nis not feasible and should be replaced by the optimization over\nsuitable approximation classes (sieves). Moreover, the ``optimal''\nweights in (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lest')]), ') depend on the unknown~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')])], []), '. However, it turns out that it is possible to use any\nweighting function which is dominated by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' w(u)'], []), ', that is, one needs only\nsome lower bounds for~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), "'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('rem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('compfuncbounds')]), '\nIt is interesting to compare (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('psibound')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lbound')]), ') with\nTheorem~3.2 in\n', TexCmd('citet', [BraceGroup('HM')]), ". At first sight it may seem strange that, while the\nrates of convergence for our ``link'' function ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), ' '], []), "\nand the ``components'' ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), ' '], []), ' depend on\nthe tail behavior of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), "'"], []), ', the rates in\n', TexCmd('citet', [BraceGroup('HM')]), ' rely only on the smoothness of\nthe link function and the components. The main reason for this is that\nthe derivative of the link function in the above paper is assumed to be\nuniformly bounded from below ', '[', 'assumption (A8)', ']', ', a restriction that can\nbe hardly justifiable in our setting. The convergence analysis in the\nunbounded case is, in our opinion, an important contribution of this\npaper to the problem of estimating composite functions that can be\ncarried over to other setups and settings.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Discussion')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('DISC')]), '\nAs can be seen, the estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), ' '], []), ' can exhibit various\nasymptotic behavior\ndepending on the underlying L', "\\'", 'evy process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' and the\ntime-change ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '(t)'], []), '.\nIn particular, if the Laplace transform ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('t'), '(z) '], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' '], []), ' dies off at exponential rate as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('Ree'), ' z', TexCmd('to'), '+', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '=0 '], []), ', then the rates of convergence of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), ' '], []), '\nare logarithmic and depend on the Blumenthal--Geetor index of\nthe L', "\\'", 'evy process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t')], []), '. The larger is the Blumenthal--Geetor\nindex, the slower are the rates and\nthe more difficult the estimation problem becomes. For the polynomially\ndecaying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('t'), '(z) '], []), ' one gets polynomial convergence rates\nthat also depend on the Blumenthal--Geetor index of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), '.\nLet us also note that the uniform rates of convergence are usually\nrather slow, since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('beta'), '<1-', TexCmd('gamma')], []), '\nin most situations. The pointwise convergence rates for points\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' x_', BraceGroup('0'), TexCmd('neq'), '0 '], []), ' can, on the contrary, be very fast.\nThe rates obtained turn out to be optimal up to a logarithmic factor in\nthe minimax sense over the classes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('cap'), '\n', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma')), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '(x_', BraceGroup('0'), ',', TexCmd('delta'), ',D)', TexCmd('cap'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'))], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Simulation study')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('SIM')]), '\nIn our simulation study, we consider two models based on time-changed\nnormal inverse Gaussian (NIG) L', "\\'", 'evy processes.\nThe NIG L', "\\'", 'evy processes is a relatively new\nclass of processes introduced in ', TexCmd('citet', [BraceGroup('BN')]), ' as a model for log\nreturns of stock prices.\nThe processes of this type are characterized by the property that their\nincrements have NIG distribution. ', TexCmd('citet', [BraceGroup('BN')]), ' considered classes of\nnormal variance--mean\nmixtures and defined the NIG distribution as the case when the\nmixing distribution is inverse Gaussian.\nShortly after its introduction, it was shown that the NIG\ndistribution fits very well the log returns on German stock market\ndata, making the NIG L', "\\'", 'evy processes of great interest for\npractioneers. A NIG distribution has in general four parameters: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', BraceGroup('+')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('varkappa'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', BraceGroup('+'), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ' '], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n|', TexCmd('varkappa'), '\n|<', TexCmd('alpha')], []), '. Each parameter in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('NIG')]), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), ', ', TexCmd('varkappa'), ',\n', TexCmd('delta'), ',', TexCmd('mu'), ') '], []), ' distribution can be interpreted\nas having a different effect on the shape of the distribution: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('alpha'), '\n'], []), ' is responsible for the tail heaviness of steepness, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('varkappa')], []), ' has\nto do with symmetry, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('delta')], []), ' scales the distribution and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mu')], []), '\ndetermines its mean value. The NIG distribution is infinitely divisible\nwith c.f.\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('phi'), '(u)=', TexCmd('exp'), TexCmd('bigl'), '\\{', ' ', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('bigl'), '( ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '-', TexCmd('varkappa'), '\n', '^', BraceGroup('2'))]), '-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '-(', TexCmd('varkappa'), '+', TexCmd('ii'), ' u)^', BraceGroup('2'))]), '+', TexCmd('ii'), TexCmd('mu'), ' u ', TexCmd('bigr'), ') ', TexCmd('bigr'), '\\}', '.\n'], []), '\nTherefore, one can define the NIG L', "\\'", 'evy process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '(L_', BraceGroup('t'), ')_', BraceGroup('t', TexCmd('geq'), '0'), ' '], []), ' which\nstarts at zero and has independent and stationary increments such that\neach increment ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t+', TexCmd('Delta')), '-L_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('NIG')]), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), ',\n', TexCmd('varkappa'), ', ', TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('delta'), ',', TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('mu'), ') '], []), ' distribution.\nThe NIG process has no diffusion component making it a pure jump\nprocess with the L', "\\'", 'evy density\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('NIGNU')]), '\n', TexCmd('nu'), '(x)=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('delta')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('exp'), '(', TexCmd('varkappa'), '\nx)K_', BraceGroup('1'), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), '|x|)'), BraceGroup('|x|')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), '(z) '], []), ' is the modified Bessel function of the third\nkind. Taking into account the asymptotic relations\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\nK_', BraceGroup('1'), '(z)', TexCmd('asymp'), '2/z,', TexCmd('qquad'), ' z', TexCmd('to'), '+0,', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('and')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' K_', BraceGroup('1'), '(z)', TexCmd('asymp'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), BraceGroup('2z')]))]), ' e^', BraceGroup('-z'), ',', TexCmd('qquad'), ' z', TexCmd('to'), '+', TexCmd('infty'), ',\n'], []), '\nwe conclude that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('B')]), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_', BraceGroup('s'), '(x_', BraceGroup('0'), ',', TexCmd('delta'), ',D) '], []), ' for arbitrary large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' s>0 '], []), ' and some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '\n>0, D>0'], []), ', if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' x_', BraceGroup('0'), TexCmd('neq'), '0'], []), '. Moreover,  assumption (AL2) is\nfulfilled for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' p>0'], []), '.\nFurthermore, the identity\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d^', BraceGroup('2')), BraceGroup('du^', BraceGroup('2'))]), ' ', TexCmd('log'), TexCmd('phi'), '(u)=-', TexCmd('alpha'), '^2/', TexCmd('bigl'), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), '\n', '^', BraceGroup('2'), '-(', TexCmd('varkappa'), '\n+', TexCmd('ii'), ' u)^', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('bigr'), ')^', BraceGroup('3/2'), '\n'], []), '\nimplies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('2-', TexCmd('delta')), ' '], []), ' for arbitrary small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), '\n>0'], []), '. In the next sections are going to study two time-changed NIG\nprocesses: one uses the Gamma process as a~time change and another\nemploys the integrated CIR processes to model~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' '], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Time change via a Gamma process')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('TCGamma')]), '\nGamma process is a L', "\\'", 'evy process such that its increments have Gamma\ndistribution, so that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' '], []), ' is a pure-jump increasing L', "\\'", 'evy process with the L', "\\'", '\nevy density\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')])), '(x)=', TexCmd('theta'), ' x^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('exp'), '(-', TexCmd('lambda'), ' x),', TexCmd('qquad'), ' x', TexCmd('geq'), '0,\n'], []), '\nwhere the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('theta')], []), ' controls the rate of jump arrivals and\nthe scaling parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' inversely controls the jump size.\nThe Laplace transform of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' '], []), ' is of the form\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('t'), '(z)=(1+z/', TexCmd('lambda'), ')^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('theta'), ' t'), ',', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('Ree'), ' z', TexCmd('geq'), '0.\n'], []), '\nIt follows from the properties of the Gamma and the corresponding\ninverse Gamma distributions that  assumptions (AT1) and (AT2) are\nfulfilled for the Gamma process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ',\nprovided ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('Delta'), '>2/', TexCmd('gamma')], []), '.\nConsider now the time-changed L', "\\'", 'evy process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Y_', BraceGroup('t'), '=L_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '(t)'), '\n'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t'), '=(L^', BraceGroup('1'), '_', BraceGroup('t'), ',L^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('t'), ',L^', BraceGroup('3'), '_', BraceGroup('t'), ') '], []), ' is a\nthree-dimensional L', "\\'", 'evy process with independent NIG components and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' '], []), ' is a Gamma process. Note that the process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Y_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' is a\nmultidimensional L', "\\'", 'evy process since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' '], []), ' was itself the\nL', "\\'", '\nevy process. Let us be more specific and take the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('Delta'), '\n'], []), '-increments of the L', "\\'", 'evy processes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L^', BraceGroup('1'), '_', BraceGroup('t')], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L^', BraceGroup('2'), '_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L^', BraceGroup('3'), '_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' to have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('NIG')]), '(1, -0.05,\n1,-0.5)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('NIG')]), '(3, -0.05, 1,-1) '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('operatorname', [BraceGroup('NIG')]), '(1, -0.03, 1, 2) '], []), ' distributions, respectively. Take also ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('theta'), '\n=1 '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('lambda'), '=1 '], []), ' for the parameters of the Gamma process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), '. Next, fix an equidistant grid on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '[', '0,10', ']', ' '], []), ' of the\nlength ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n=1', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(',')]), '000 '], []), ' and simulate a discretized trajectory of the process\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Y_', BraceGroup('t')], []), '.\nLet us stress that the dependence structure between the components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nY_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' is rather flexible (although they are uncorrelated) and can be\nefficiently controlled by the parameters of the corresponding Gamma\nprocess ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), '.\nNext, we construct an estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' as described in\nSection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ALG')]), '.\nWe first estimate the derivatives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('2')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('11'), '\n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('12'), ' '], []), ' by means of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('PhiDeriv1Est')]), ') and~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('PhiDeriv2Est')]), '). Then we estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('psi'), "''_", BraceGroup('1'), '(u) '], []), ' using the formula\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('PsiDeriv2Est1')]), ') with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' k=1 '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' l=2'], []), '. Finally, we get ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('NUEST')]), ') where the kernel ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('K')]), ' '], []), '\nis chosen to be the so-called flat-top kernel of the form\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('K')]), '(x)=\n', TexCmd('cases', [BraceGroup('\n1, &', TexCmd('quad'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|x|', TexCmd('leq'), '0.05'], []), ', ', TexCmd('vspace*', [BraceGroup('2pt')]), TexCmd('cr'), '\n', TexCmd('displaystyle'), ' ', TexCmd('exp'), TexCmd('biggl'), '( -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^', BraceGroup('-1/(|x|-0.05)')), BraceGroup('1-|x|')]), ' ', TexCmd('biggr'), '), &', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.05<|x|<1'], []), ',', TexCmd('cr'), '\n0, &', TexCmd('quad'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|x|', TexCmd('geq'), '1'], []), '.')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe flat-top kernels obviously satisfy  assumption (AK).\nThus, all assumptions of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('UpperBounds')]), ' are fulfilled and\nCorollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('UPPERCOR2')]), ' leads to the following convergence rates for\nthe estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' of the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '\n', '_', BraceGroup('1'), '(x)=x^', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('nu'), '(x) '], []), ':\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', '\\|', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '-', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('L_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ',w)'), '\n=O_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('a.s')]), '.'), '\n', TexCmd('bigl'), '(n^', BraceGroup('-(', BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('delta'), "'"), ')/', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('Delta'), '+5/2)')), TexCmd('log'), '^', BraceGroup('(', BraceGroup('3+', TexCmd('epsilon'), "\n'"), ')/', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('Delta'), '+5/2)')), '(n) ', TexCmd('bigr'), '),', TexCmd('qquad'), ' n', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty'), ',\n'], []), '\nwith arbitrary small positive numbers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('delta'), "' "], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('epsilon'), "'"], []), ',\nprovided the sequence\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' h_', BraceGroup('n'), ' '], []), ' is chosen as in Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('UPPERCOR2')]), '.\nLet us turn to the finite sample performance of the estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widehat'), '\n', TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), '.\nIt turns out that the choice of the sequence\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' h_', BraceGroup('n'), ' '], []), ' is crucial for a good performance of~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ". For this choice,\nwe adopt the so called ``quasi-optimality'' approach proposed in\n", TexCmd('citet', [BraceGroup('BR')]), ". This approach is aimed to perform a model selection in\ninverse problems without taking into account the noise level.\nAlthough one can prove the optimality of this criterion on average\nonly, it leads in many situations to quite reasonable results. In order\nto implement the ``quasi-optimality'' algorithm in our situation, we\nfirst fix a sequence of bandwidths ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [' h_', BraceGroup('1'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ', h_', BraceGroup('L'), ' '], []), ' and\nconstruct the estimates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('nu'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ', ', TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup('(L)'), ' '], []), ' using\nthe formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('NUEST')]), ') with bandwidths\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' h_', BraceGroup('1'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ', h_', BraceGroup('L')], []), ', respectively. Then one finds\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' l^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star')), '=', TexCmd('argmin'), '_', BraceGroup('l'), ' f(l) '], []), ' with\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\nf(l)=', TexCmd('bigl'), '\\|', ' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup('(l+1)'), '- ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup('(l)'), ' ', TexCmd('bigr'), '\\|', '\n', '_', BraceGroup('L_', BraceGroup('1'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ')'), ',', TexCmd('qquad'), ' l=1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',L.\n'], []), '\nDenote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '=', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '^', BraceGroup('l^', BraceGroup('*')), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' a new\nadaptive estimate for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ". In our implementation of the\n``quasi-optimality'' approach, we take ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [' h_', BraceGroup('l'), '=0.5+0.1', TexCmd('times'), ' l'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nl=1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ', 40'], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('901f01.eps')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Left-hand side: objective function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' f(l)'], []), " for\n``quasi-optimality'' approach versus the corresponding bandwidths ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nh_', BraceGroup('l')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l=1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ', 40 '], []), '. Right-hand side: adaptive estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' ', '(dashed line) together with the true function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' ', '(solid line).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('NIGGammaNUEst')])], [BracketGroup('b')]), '\nIn Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('NIGGammaNUEst')]), ', the sequence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' f(l)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l=1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',\n40'], []), ', is plotted. On the right-hand side of\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('NIGGammaNUEst')]), ', we show the resulting estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' together with the true function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), '.\nBased on the estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ', one can estimate some\nfunctionals of~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), '. For example, we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('int'), '\n', TexCmd('widetilde'), '\n', TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '(x) ', '\\,', 'dx=1.049053 '], []), ' ', '[', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '(x) ', '\\,', 'dx=1.015189 '], []), ']', '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Time change via an integrated CIR process')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec52')]), '\nAnother possibility to construct a time-changed L', "\\'", 'evy process from the\nNIG L', "\\'", 'evy process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), '\nis to use a time change of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('TCProcess')]), ') with some rate\nprocess ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('rho'), '(t)'], []), '. A possible candidate for the rate of the time\nchange is given by the Cox--Ingersoll--Ross process (CIR process). The\nCIR process is defined as a solution of the following SDE:\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\ndZ_', BraceGroup('t'), ' = ', TexCmd('kappa'), '(', TexCmd('eta'), '-Z_', BraceGroup('t'), ') ', '\\,', 'dt + ', TexCmd('zeta'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('Z_', BraceGroup('t'))]), ' ', '\\,', 'dW_', BraceGroup('t'), ',', TexCmd('qquad'), '\nZ_', BraceGroup('0'), '=1,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' W_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' is a Wiener process.\nThis process is mean reverting with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('kappa'), '>0 '], []), ' being the speed of\nmean reversion, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('eta'), '>0 '], []), ' being the long-run mean rate and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('zeta'), '>0 '], []), '\ncontrolling the volatility of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Z_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), '. Additionally, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' 2', TexCmd('kappa'), '\n', TexCmd('eta'), '\n>', TexCmd('zeta'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Z_', BraceGroup('0'), ' '], []), ' has Gamma distribution, then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Z_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' is\nstationary and exponentially ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('alpha')], []), '-mixing ', '[', 'see, e.g., ', TexCmd('citet', [BraceGroup('MH')]), ']', '.\nThe time change ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' '], []), ' is then defined as\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '(t)=', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('0'), '^', BraceGroup('t'), 'Z_', BraceGroup('t'), ' ', '\\,', 'dt.\n'], []), '\nSimple calculations show that the Laplace transform of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '(t)\n'], []), ' is given by\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('t'), '(z)=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('exp'), '(', TexCmd('kappa'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('eta'), ' t/', TexCmd('zeta'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), ')', TexCmd('exp'), '\n', '(-2z/(', TexCmd('kappa'), '+', TexCmd('gamma'), '(z)', TexCmd('coth'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), '(z)t/2)))'), BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('cosh'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), '\n', '(z)t/2)+', TexCmd('kappa'), TexCmd('sinh'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), '(z)t/2)/', TexCmd('gamma'), '(z) )^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('kappa'), TexCmd('eta'), '/ ', TexCmd('zeta'), '\n', '^', BraceGroup('2'), ' '))]), '\n'], []), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('gamma'), '(z)=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), '+2', TexCmd('zeta'), '^', BraceGroup('2'), 'z')])], []), '. It is easy to see\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('t'), '(z)', TexCmd('asymp'), TexCmd('exp'), '( -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2z')])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('zeta'), '\n'), BracketGroup('1+t', TexCmd('kappa'), TexCmd('eta'))]), ' ', ') '], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' |z|', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('Ree'), ' z ', TexCmd('geq'), '0'], []), '.\nMoreover, it can be shown that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('E'), '|', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '(t)|^', BraceGroup('p'), '<', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' for\nany ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' p', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), '.\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' be again a three-dimensional NIG L', "\\'", 'evy process with\nindependent components distributed as in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('TCGamma')]), '.\nConstruct the time-changed process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Y_', BraceGroup('t'), '=L_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('T')]), '(t)')], []), '. Note\nthat the process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Y_', BraceGroup('t'), ' '], []), ' is not any longer a~L', "\\'", 'evy process and has\nin general dependent increments. Let us estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ', the\ntransformed L', "\\'", 'evy density of the first component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('t')], []), '. First,\nnote that according to Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('UpperBounds')]), ', the estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' constructed as described in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ALG')]), ', has\nthe following logarithmic convergence rates\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', '\\|', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '-', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('L_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ',w)'), '\n=O_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('a.s')]), '.'), '\n', TexCmd('bigl'), '(', TexCmd('log'), '^', BraceGroup('-2(2-', TexCmd('delta'), ')'), ' ', '(n) ', TexCmd('bigr'), '),', TexCmd('qquad'), ' n', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty'), ',\n'], []), '\nfor arbitrary small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('delta'), '>0'], []), ', provided the bandwidth sequence is\nchosen in the optimal way. Finite sample performance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '\n', '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' with the choice of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' h_', BraceGroup('n'), ' '], []), " based on the ``quasi-optimality''\napproach is illustrated in\nFigure ", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('NIGCIRNUEst')]), ' where the sequence of estimates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widehat'), '\n', TexCmd('nu'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ', ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('nu'), '^', BraceGroup('(L)'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), ' was constructed from the\ntime series ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' Y_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ', Y_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('Delta')), ' '], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n=5', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(',')]), '000 '], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('Delta'), '=0.1'], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('901f02.eps')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Left-hand side: objective function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' f(l)'], []), " for the\n``quasi-optimality'' approach versus the corresponding bandwidths ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nh_', BraceGroup('l'), ' '], []), '. Right-hand side: adaptive estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), ' '], []), '\n', '(dashed line) together with the true function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' ', '(solid line).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('NIGCIRNUEst')])], []), '\nThe parameters of the used CIR process are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('kappa'), '=1 '], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('eta'), '=1 '], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('zeta'), '=0.1'], []), '. Again we can compute some functionals of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('widetilde'), '\n', TexCmd('nu'), '\n', '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), '. We have, for example, following estimates for the integral and\nfor the mean of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1')], []), ':\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '(x) ', '\\,', 'dx=1.081376 '], []), ' ', '[', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '(x)\n', '\\,', 'dx=1.015189 '], []), ']', ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('int'), ' x', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '(x) ', '\\,', 'dx=-0.4772505 '], []), ' ', '[', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), ' x', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '(x) ', '\\,', 'dx=-0.3057733 '], []), ']', '.\n\nLet us now test the performance of estimation algorithm in the case of\na time-changed NIG process (parameters are the same as before), where\nthe time change is again given by the integrated CIR process with the\nparameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('eta'), '=1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zeta'), '=0.1 '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('kappa'), TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '0.05,0.1,0.5,1', '\\}'], []), '.\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('boxplots')]), '(left) shows the boxplots of the resulting error ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', '\\|', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '-', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('L_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ',w)'), ' '], []), '\ncomputed using ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' 100 '], []), ' trajectories each of the length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n=5', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(',')]), '000'], []), ',\nwhere the time span between observation is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('Delta'), '=0.1'], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BraceGroup('901f03.eps')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Boxplots of the error\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\|', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '-', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('L_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ',w)'), ' '], []), ' for\ndifferent values of the mean reversion speed parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('kappa')], []), ' and\ndifferent numbers of observations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n'], []), '. ')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('boxplots')]), '\n'], []), '\nNote that if our time units are days, then we get about two years of\nobservations with about one mean reversion per month in the case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('kappa'), '=0.05'], []), '. As one can see, the performance of the algorithm remains\nreasonable for the whole range of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('kappa')], []), '.\nIn Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('boxplots')]), '(right), we present the boxplots of the error ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', '\\|', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '-', TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nu'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '\\|', '_', BraceGroup('L_', TexCmd('infty'), '(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), ',w)'), ' '], []), '\nin the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('eta'), '=1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zeta'), '=0.1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('kappa'), '=1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '500,\n1', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(',')]), '000, 3', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(',')]), '000, 5', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(',')]), '000 ', '\\}'], []), '. As one can expect, the performance of the\nalgorithm becomes worse as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n '], []), ' decreases. However,\nthe quality of the estimation remains reasonable even for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n=500'], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Proofs of the main results')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('texorpdfstring', [BraceGroup('Proof of Theorem ', TexCmd('protect'), TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('UpperBounds')])), BraceGroup('Proof of Theorem 4.4')]))]), '\nFor simplicity, let consider the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l'), '>0 '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '\n', '_', BraceGroup('k'), '=0'], []), '. By Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ExpBounds'), BracketGroup('take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' G_', BraceGroup('n'), '(u,z)=', TexCmd('exp'), '(', TexCmd('ii'), ' u z)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' L_', BraceGroup('n'), '=', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), '=', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), '=1\n'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' a=0, b=1 '], []))]), '\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('P')]), TexCmd('bigl'), '(|', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('l'), '(', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('0')]), ')|', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('kappa'), '/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('n')]), '\n', TexCmd('bigr'), ')', TexCmd('geq'), '\n', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('P')]), TexCmd('bigl'), '(|', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('l'), '(', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('0')]), ')-', TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('l'), '(', TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('0')]), ')|> ', TexCmd('mu'), '\n', '_', BraceGroup('l'), TexCmd('bigr'), ')', TexCmd('leq'), ' B n^', BraceGroup('-1-', TexCmd('delta')), '\n'], []), '\nfor some constants ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('delta'), '>0, B>0 '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' n '], []), ' large enough.\nFurthermore, simple calculations lead to the following representation:\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('psirepr')]), '\n', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), TexCmd('prime')), '(u)-', TexCmd('widehat',
