Just finished parsing: ['{', '\\}', BraceGroup('mpc'), '3h', BraceGroup('\\,', 'h^', BraceGroup('3'), '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Mpc^', BraceGroup('-3'))), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nWe investigate the properties of clusters of galaxies in the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), 'CDM models with a steplike initial power spectrum. We examine\nthe mass function, the peculiar velocities and the power spectrum of\nclusters in models with different values of the density parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ',\nthe normalized Hubble constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' and the spectral parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', which\ndescribes the shape of the initial power spectrum. The results are\ncompared with observations. We also investigate \nthe rms bulk velocity in the models, where the properties of clusters\nare consistent with the observed data. We find that the power spectrum of \nclusters is in good agreement with the observed power spectrum of the Abell-ACO\nclusters, if the spectral parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' is in the range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.6-0.8'], []), '. The\npower spectrum and the rms peculiar velocity of clusters are consistent\nwith observations only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0<0.4'], []), '. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models are \nconsistent with the observed properties of clusters, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.50-0.63'], []), '.\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', we find that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.20 -0.27'], []), '. \n\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('keywords', ['\ncosmology: theory -- large-scale structure of Universe,\ncosmology: theory -- dark matter, galaxies: clusters\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('sec', [BraceGroup('INTRODUCTION')]), '\n', '\nThe theory of galaxy formation based on gravitational instability \ndescribes how primordially generated fluctuations grow into galaxies \nand clusters of galaxies due to self-gravity of matter. The initial field \nof density fluctuations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' x'), ',t)'], []), ' \ncan be decomposed into its Fourier components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' k'), '(t)'], []), ' and \nexpressed in terms of the power spectrum \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(k)=', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('vert'), TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' k'), ' ', TexCmd('vert'), '^2', TexCmd('rangle')], []), '.\n\nAs the study of the large-scale structure in the Universe has pushed to ever \nlarger scales, several data samples have suggested the presence of a peak \nin the power spectrum at the wavenumber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.05h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' ', '(or at the \nwavelength ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 120 - 130 h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc). \nEinasto et al. (1997) and Retzlaff et al. (1998) studied the\nspatial distribution of the Abell-ACO clusters and found that the power\nspectrum of the clusters has a well-defined peak at the \nwavenumber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=0.052h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. A similar peak in the one-dimensional \npower spectrum of a deep pencil-beam survey was detected by \nBroadhurst et al. (1990), and in the two-dimensional power spectrum of \nthe Las Campanas redshift survey by Landy et al. (1996). \nThe power spectrum of the spatial distribution of APM galaxies also has\na feature on the same scale (Caztanaga and Baugh 1998).\nIndependent\nevidence for the presence of a preferred scale in the Universe at about\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['130h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc comes from an analysis of high-redshift galaxies.\nBroadhurst and Jaffe (1999) studied the distribution of the Lyman-break\ngalaxies at redshift ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 3'], []), ' and found a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['5', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' excess of pairs\nseparated by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' z=0.22 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 0.02'], []), ', equivalent to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['130h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc for\nflat universe with the density parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.4 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 0.1'], []), '.\n\nThe power spectrum of density fluctuations depends on\nthe physical processes in the early universe. The peak in the power\nspectrum of clusters at the wavenumber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.05h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' may\nbe generated during the era of radiation domination or earlier.\nStandard cosmological models based on collisionless dark matter \n', '[', 'e.g. cold dark matter (CDM)', ']', ' and adiabatic fluctuations, when combined \nwith power-law initial power spectra, predict smooth power spectra of \ndensity fluctuations at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z', TexCmd('sim'), ' 10^3'], []), '. The baryonic acoustic oscillations \nin adiabatic models may explain the observed power spectrum only if \ncurrently favored determinations of\ncosmological parameters are in substantial error (e.g., if the density\nparameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0<0.2h'], []), '; Eisenstein et al. 1998). \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('picture', ['(300,350)\n', TexCmd('special', [BraceGroup("psfile='fig1.ps' angle=-90 voffset=370 hoffset=-200\nvscale=75 hscale=75")]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S(k,p)/p^2'], []), ' for different values of the \nparameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. For the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p<1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>1'], []), ', the step parameter \nwas chosen to be ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0=0.016h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0=0.03h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', \nrespectively.')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nOne possible explanation for the observed power spectrum of clusters is an \ninflationary model with a scalar field whose potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('varphi'), ')'], []), ' has a \nlocal steplike feature in the first derivative. This feature can be produced \nby a fast phase transition in a physical field different from the inflaton \nfield. An exact analytical expression for the scalar (density) perturbations \ngenerated in this inflationary model was found by Starobinsky (1992). \nThe initial power spectrum of density fluctuations in this model can be \nexpressed as\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nP_', BraceGroup('in'), '(k) ', TexCmd('propto', [BraceGroup('k ', '\\,', ' S(k,p) ', TexCmd('over'), ' p^2')]), ' ,\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(1)\n'], []), '\nwhere the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S(k,p)'], []), ' can be written as\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nS(k,p) = 1 -\n', BraceGroup('3 (p-1) ', TexCmd('over'), ' y'), '[', 'f_1(y)', TexCmd('sin', [BraceGroup('2y')]), ' + ', BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' y'), ' ', TexCmd('cos', [BraceGroup('2y')]), ']', ' +\n'], []), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n+', BraceGroup('9 ', '\\,', ' ', '(p-1)^2 ', '\\,', ' f_2(y) ', TexCmd('over'), ' 2 ', '\\,', ' y^2'), '[', 'f_2(y)+f_1(y)', TexCmd('cos', [BraceGroup('2y')]), ' - ', BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' y'), ' ', TexCmd('sin', [BraceGroup('2y')]), ' ', ']', ' ', '\\,', ' .\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(2)\n'], []), '\nHere, the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y=k/k_0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_1(y)=1-y^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_2(y)=1+y^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), '.\nThe initial power spectrum in this model depends on two \nparameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. The parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0'], []), ' determines the location of \nthe step and the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' - the shape of the initial spectrum.\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1'], []), ", we recover the scale-invariant Harrison-Zel'dovich\nspectrum (", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S(k,1) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 1'], []), '). At present, the initial spectrum (1,2)\nis probably the only example of an initial power spectrum with the\ndesired properties, for which a closed analytical form exists.\n\nFig.~1 shows the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S(k,p)/p^2'], []), ' for different values of\nthe parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. For the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p<1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>1'], []), ', the step parameter\nwas chosen to be ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0=0.016h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0=0.03h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', \nrespectively. In this case, in the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p<1'], []), ', the power spectrum \nhas a well-defined maximum at the wavenumber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.05h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' \nand a second maximum at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.1h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. In the models with \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>1'], []), ', the picture is inverted. The power spectrum has a flat upper \nplateau at the wavenumbers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k<0.05h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', a sharp decrease on smaller \nscales (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=0.05-0.1h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ') and a secondary maximum at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.15h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. \n\nLesgourgues, Polarski ', '\\&', ' Starobinsky (1998, hereafter LPS) compared the \nCDM models with a steplike initial spectrum (1,2) with \nobservational data. They studied the rms mass fluctuation on an \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['8h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc scale, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8'], []), '; the rms bulk velocity of galaxies and the \ncosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies on different angular scales. \nIn this paper we continue this research and investigate the properties of \ngalaxy clusters in these models. We examine the mass function, the peculiar \nvelocities and the power spectrum of clusters \nfor different values of the density parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ',\nthe normalized Hubble constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' and the spectral parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '.\nThe results are compared with observations. We also \ninvestigate the rms bulk velocity and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8'], []), ' in the \nmodels, where the mass function, the peculiar velocities and the power\nspectrum of clusters are consistent with the observed data. \n\nIn their study LPS assumed that the parameter\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8'], []), ' lies in the interval \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8=(0.57 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 0.06) ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0^', BraceGroup('-0.56')], []), '. This interval was derived by\nWhite, Efstathiou ', '\\&', ' Frenk (1993) by analysing the mass function of\nclusters. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' this gives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8=1.0-1.25'], []), '. In this\npaper we examine the observed values of the mass function of galaxy\nclusters in more detail and obtain lower values for the parameter\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8'], []), '. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' we find that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8=0.8-1.05'], []), '. \nTherefore, the allowed values for the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' in the \n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ') plane that we obtain are different from those \nfound by LPS.\n\nWe examine flat cosmological models with the density parameter \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.2-0.5'], []), ' and the normalized Hubble constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.5-0.8'], []), '.\nThese parameters are in agreement with measurements of the density \nparameter (e.g. Bahcall et al. 1999) and with measurements of the Hubble \nconstant using various various distance indicators (e.g. Tammann 1998). \nTo restore the spatial flatness in the low-density models, we assume a \ncontribution from a cosmological constant: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda')), '=1-', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), '.\nThe Hubble constant is written as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_0=100h'], []), ' km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), 'Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. \nThe transfer function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T(k)'], []), ' is computed with \nthe fast Boltzmann code CMBFAST developed by Seljak ', '\\&', ' Zaldarriaga (1996).\nThe models are normalized using the COBE normalization derived by Bunn\n', '\\&', ' White (1997). We assume that the initial density fluctuation field\nin the Universe is a Gaussian field. In this case, the power spectrum\nprovides a complete statistical description of the field.\n\nThis paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we study the mass\nfunction of clusters of galaxies and compare the\nresults with observations. In Section 3 we examine the peculiar velocities \nof galaxy clusters. In Section 4 we investigate the power \nspectrum of clusters. Discussion and summary are presented in Section 5.\n\n\n', TexCmd('sec', [BraceGroup('THE MASS FUNCTION OF CLUSTERS OF GALAXIES')]), '\n', '\nTo study the mass function of clusters we use the Press-Schechter \n(1974, PS) approximation. The PS mass function has been compared with\nN-body simulations (Efstathiou et al. 1988; White, Efstathiou ', '\\&', ' Frenk \n1993; Lacey ', '\\&', ' Cole 1994; Eke, Cole ', '\\&', ' Frenk 1996; Borgani et al. 1997a) \nand has been shown to provide an accurate description of the abundance \nof virialized cluster-size halos. In the PS approximation the number \ndensity of clusters with the mass between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M+dM'], []), ' is given by\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nn(M) dM = - ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'))), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '_b ', TexCmd('over'), ' M'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '_t ', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2(M)'), BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('sigma'), '(M)', TexCmd('over'), ' dM')]), '  \n', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '_t^2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' 2', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2(M)'))]), '  dM .  \n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(3)\n'], []), '\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_b'], []), ' is the mean background density and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_t'], []), ' is the \nlinear theory overdensity for a uniform spherical fluctuation which is\nnow collapsing; ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_t=1.686'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=1'], []), ', with a weak dependence\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ' for flat and open models (Eke et al. 1996; Kitayama ', '\\&', '\nSuto 1996). In this paper we will use values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_t'], []), ' found by Eke\net al. (1996) for flat models.\nThe function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(M)'], []), ' is the rms linear density fluctuation at the\nmass scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '. We will use the top-hat window function to describe halos.\nFor the top-hat window, the mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is related to the window radius\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M=4', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('rho'), '_b R^3/3'], []), '. In this case, the number density of clusters \nof mass larger than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' can be expressed as\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nn_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(>M) = ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('int'), '_M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty'))), " n(M') dM' = \n"], []), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [' \n= - ', BraceGroup('3 ', TexCmd('over'), ' ', '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ')^', BraceGroup('3/2')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('int'), '_R^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty'))), BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('delta'), '_t ', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2(r)'), BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('sigma'), '(r)', TexCmd('over'), ' dr'), ' ', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '_t^2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' 2', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2(r)')), BraceGroup('dr ', TexCmd('over'), ' r^3')]), '  .   \n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(4)\n'], []), '\n', '\nFig.~2 shows the cluster mass function in the flat models with \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), '. The threshold density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '_t=1.675'], []), '. We \ninvestigated the cluster masses within a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.5h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc radius sphere \naround the cluster center. This mass \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1.5')], []), ', is related to the window radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' as \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nR=8.43 ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0^', BraceGroup('0.2', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('over'), ' 3-', TexCmd('alpha')), '[', BraceGroup('M_', BraceGroup('1.5'), ' ', TexCmd('over'), ' 6.99\n', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('14'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0 h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))), ']', '\n', '^', BraceGroup('1 ', TexCmd('over'), ' 3-', TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '(h^', BraceGroup('-1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Mpc'), ')  .\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(5)\n'], []), '\nHere the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' describes the cluster mass profile, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M(r) ', TexCmd('sim'), ' r^', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ', at radii ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r', TexCmd('sim'), ' 1.5h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc. Numerical \nsimulations and observations of clusters indicate that the parameter \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 0.6-0.7'], []), ' for most of clusters  (Navarro, Frenk ', '\\&', ' \nWhite 1995; Carlberg, Yee ', '\\&', ' Ellingson 1997). In this paper we use a \nvalue ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '=0.65'], []), '. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('picture', ['(300,350)\n', TexCmd('special', [BraceGroup("psfile='fig2.ps' angle=-90 voffset=370 hoffset=-200\nvscale=75 hscale=75")]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The cluster mass function in the models with \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1.0'], []), ' ', '(solid line) and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.79'], []), ' ', '(dashed line).  \nOpen circles and squares show the mass function of galaxy clusters \nderived by Bahcall and Cen (1993) and by Girardi et al. (1998), \nrespectively. The open triangle is the result obtained by White, \nEfstathiou ', '\\&', ' Frenk (1993).')]), '\n'], []), ' \n', '\nFig.~2 shows also the mass function of clusters of galaxies derived\nby Bahcall and Cen (1993, BC) and by Girardi et al. (1998, G98). BC \nused both optical and X-ray observed properties of clusters to determine \nthe mass function of clusters. The function was extended towards the faint \nend using small groups of galaxies. G98 determined the mass function \nof clusters by using virial mass estimates for 152 nearby \nAbell-ACO clusters including the ENACS data (Katgert et al. 1998). The \nmass function derived by G98 is somewhat larger than the mass function \nderived by BC, the difference being larger at larger masses (see Fig.~2). \n\nLet us consider the amplitude of the mass function of galaxy clusters at \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1.5'), ' = 4', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('14'), ' h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), '. For this mass, the cluster \nabundances derived by BC and G98 are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n(>M)=(2.0 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1.1)', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-6'), ' \nh^3'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n(>M)=(6.3', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1.2)', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-6'), ' h^3'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), ', \nrespectively. By analysing X-ray properties of clusters, White, Efstathiou \n', '\\&', ' Frenk (1993) found that the number density of clusters with the mass \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1.5'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 4.2 ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('14'), ' h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ' is \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n(>M)=4 ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-6'), ' h^3'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), '. \n\nWe derived the limits for the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', assuming that the mass function \nof galaxy clusters at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1.5'), ' = 4', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('14'), ' h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ' is in \nthe range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(2-6.5) ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-6'), ' h^3'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), '. Fig.~3a shows the \nresults for the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ' for different ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ' and Fig.~3b \nfor the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' for different ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), '. For the model with \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', we find that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.79-1.0'], []), '. Fig.~2 demonstrates the mass function of clusters in \nthis model for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.79'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1.0'], []), '.\n\nLPS used high values of the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8'], []), ' and found that \none of the best-fit models is the model with parameters \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.7'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.8'], []), '. We find that the number density of\nclusters in this model is substantially higher than \nobserved; for the mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1.5'), ' = 4', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('14'), ' h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ',\nthe cluster abundance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n(>M)=9.8 ', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-6'), ' h^3'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), '. For \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.7'], []), ', the mass function of clusters is consistent \nwith the observed data, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.88-1.13'], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('picture', ['(300,490)\n', TexCmd('special', [BraceGroup("psfile='fig3a.ps' angle=-90 voffset=490 hoffset=-100\nvscale=50 hscale=50")]), '\n', TexCmd('special', [BraceGroup("psfile='fig3b.ps' angle=-90 voffset=260 hoffset=-100\nvscale=50 hscale=50")]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The limits for p in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), 'CDM models with a steplike \ninitial power spectrum. Solid lines show the constraints obtained from \nthe mass function of clusters and dashed lines show the \nconstraints obtained by analysing the peculiar velocities of clusters. \n(a) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), '. (b) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), '. In the region studied peculiar \nvelocities are larger than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['329'], []), ' km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '.')]), '\n'], []), ' \n', '\n', TexCmd('sec', [BraceGroup('PECULIAR VELOCITIES OF CLUSTERS OF GALAXIES')]), '\n', '\nThe observed rms peculiar velocity of galaxy clusters has been studied \nin several papers (e.g. Bahcall, Gramann ', '\\&', ' Cen 1994, \nBahcall and Oh 1996, Borgani et al. 1997b, Watkins 1997). In this paper\nwe use the results obtained by Watkins (1997). He developed a\nlikelihood method for estimating the rms peculiar velocity of clusters\nfrom line-of-sight velocity measurements and their associated errors.\nThis method was applied to two observed samples of cluster peculiar \nvelocities: a sample known as the SCI sample (Giovanelli et al. 1997) and \na subsample of the Mark III catalog (Willick et al. 1997).  Watkins (1997) \nfound that the rms one-dimensional cluster peculiar velocity is \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['265^', BraceGroup('+106'), '_', BraceGroup('-75')], []), ' km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', which\ncorresponds to the three-dimensional rms velocity  \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['459^', BraceGroup('+184'), '_', BraceGroup('-130')], []), ' km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '.\n\nTo investigate the peculiar velocities of clusters in our models,\nwe use the linear theory predictions for peculiar \nvelocities of peaks in the Gaussian field. The linear rms velocity \nfluctuation on a given scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' at the present epoch can be expressed \nas ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_v(R)=H_0 f(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0) ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', '(R),\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(6)\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0) ', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0^', BraceGroup('0.56')], []), ' is the linear\nvelocity growth factor in the flat models and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_j'], []), ' is defined for \nany integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' by \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_j^2=', BraceGroup('1 ', TexCmd('over'), ' 2', TexCmd('pi'), '^2'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), ' P(k) W^2(kR) k^', BraceGroup('2j+2'), ' dk.\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(7)\n'], []), '\nBardeen et al. (1986) showed that \nthe rms peculiar velocity at peaks of the smoothed density field differs \nsystematically from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_v(R)'], []), ', and can be expressed as\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_p(R)=', TexCmd('sigma'), '_v(R) ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1 - ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_0^4/', TexCmd('sigma'), '_1^2 ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('-1'), '^2')]), ' .\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(8)\n'], []), '\n', '\nSuhhonenko ', '\\&', ' Gramann (1999) examined the linear theory predictions \nfor the peculiar velocities of peaks and compared these to the peculiar\nvelocities of clusters in N-body simulations. The N-body clusters were \ndetermined as peaks of the density field smoothed on the scale \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 1.5h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc. The numerical results\nshowed that the rms peculiar velocity of small clusters is similar to\nthe linear theory expectations, while the rms peculiar velocity of rich\nclusters is higher than that predicted in the linear theory.\nThe rms peculiar velocity of clusters with a mean cluster separation \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('cl'), ' = 30h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc was ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' 18'], []), ' per cent higher than that predicted \nby the linear theory. We assume that the observed cluster sample studied by \nWatkins (1997) corresponds to the model clusters with a separation \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('cl'), TexCmd('sim'), ' 30h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup('cl'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 3.7 ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-5'), ' h^3'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), ')\nand determine the rms peculiar velocity of the \nclusters, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup('cl')], []), ', as\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nv_', BraceGroup('cl'), '=1.18 ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_p(R),\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(9)\n'], []), '\nwhere the radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R=1.5h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc.  \n\nFig.~3 shows the limits for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' in different models obtained on the basis\nof Watkins (1997) results. Fig.~3a shows the results in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ' models \nfor different ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ' and Fig.~3b in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models for\ndifferent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), '. In the region studied in Fig.~3b, the rms\npeculiar velocity is larger than 329 km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. For the model with \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', we find that the initial parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>0.87'], []), '. \n\nFor high values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ', peculiar velocities are\nlarger than observed for any values of the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. \nThe velocities are sensitive to the amplitude of the large-scale\nfluctuations at wavenumbers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k<0.1h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. By increasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', if \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>1'], []), ', the power spectrum on these wavenumbers and, therefore, the \nvelocities remain almost unchanged (see Fig.~1). Fig.~3a shows that\nin the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ' models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0>0.35'], []), ', the peculiar velocities are \nnot consistent with observations. For the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.4'], []), ' model with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.5'], []), ' \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.6'], []), ', we find that peculiar velocities are consistent with \nobservations, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>0.86'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>1.26'], []), ', respectively.\n\nIf we compare the observational constraints obtained by studying\nthe mass function and peculiar velocities of clusters of galaxies, we\nsee from Fig.~3 that the mass function and the peculiar velocities of clusters \nare consistent with the observed data only in a small interval of the \nparameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. For the model with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', we find \nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.87-1.0'], []), '. For the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.5'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.6'], []), ', we find that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.57-0.64'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.76-0.88'], []), ', respectively. \n \n', TexCmd('sec', [BraceGroup('THE POWER SPECTRUM OF CLUSTERS OF GALAXIES')]), '\n', '\nLet us now consider the power spectrum of clusters in these models where\nboth the mass function and the peculiar velocities are consistent with\nobservations. To investigate the power spectrum of clusters,\nwe can also use the PS approach. The power spectrum of clusters for a given \nnumber density in the PS approximation can be expressed as (Gramann ', '\\&', '\nSuhhonenko 1999, hereafter GS)\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nP_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(k)=b_', BraceGroup('cl'), '^2 ', '\\,', ' P(k),\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(9)\n'], []), '\nwhere the cluster bias parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b_', BraceGroup('cl')], []), ' is\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nb_', BraceGroup('cl'), ' = 1 - ', BraceGroup('3 ', TexCmd('over'), ' ', '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ')^', BraceGroup('3/2'), 'n_', BraceGroup('cl')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('int'), '_R^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty'))), BraceGroup(' 1 ', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2(r)'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('sigma'), '(r)', TexCmd('over'), ' dr'), '\n', '(y^2 -1) ', TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '(-y^2) ', BraceGroup('dr ', TexCmd('over'), ' r^3'), ' .\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(10)\n'], []), '\nHere, the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y=', TexCmd('delta'), '_t/ ', TexCmd('sigma'), '(r)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(r)'], []), ' is the rms\nlinear density fluctuation at the radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '. \nThe cluster bias parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b_', BraceGroup('cl')], []), ' depends on the minimal mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' ', '(or\nthe window radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ') of clusters and on the power spectrum of density\nfluctuations, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(k)'], []), ', which determines the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(r)'], []), '. For\nfixed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(k)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup('cl')], []), ', the minimal mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' ', '(or scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ') can be\ndetermined by inverting equation (4). \n\nObservations provide the distribution of clusters in redshift\nspace, which is distorted due to peculiar velocities of clusters. On\nlarge scales, where linear theory applies, the power spectrum of matter\ndensity fluctuations in redshift space is given by (Kaiser 1987):\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nP^s(k)=', '[', '1 + ', BraceGroup('2 f(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0) ', TexCmd('over'), ' 3'), ' + ', BraceGroup('f^2(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0)\n', TexCmd('over'), ' 5'), ' ', ']', ' P(k).\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(11)\n'], []), '\nUsing the PS approximation (10), relation (11)\ntakes the form\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nP^s_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(k)=\n', '[', '1 + ', BraceGroup('2 f(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0) ', TexCmd('over'), ' 3 b_', BraceGroup('cl')), ' + ', BraceGroup('f^2(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0) ', TexCmd('over'), '\n5 b_', BraceGroup('cl'), '^2'), ' ', ']', ' b_', BraceGroup('cl'), '^2 ', '\\,', ' P(k).\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(12)\n'], []), '\nEquation (12) determines the power spectrum of clusters\nfor a given ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup('cl')], []), ' in redshift space.\n\nGS examined the power spectrum of clusters in the PS theory and in N-body \nsimulations. They determined the power spectrum of clusters for mean \nseparations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('cl'), '=30-40h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc. The numerical results showed that at\nwavenumbers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k<0.1h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc, the power spectrum of clusters in the\nsimulations is linearly enhanced with respect to the power spectrum of\nthe matter distribution. However, the amplitude of the spectrum of\nclusters was somewhat lower than predicted by the approximation \n(12). It is possible that the linear approximation \n(12) overestimates the power spectrum of clusters due to dynamical\neffects that are not taken into account in this approximation. \nThe power spectrum of clusters can be expressed as\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nP^s_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(k)= \n', '\\,', ' F ', '\\,', '[', '1 + ', BraceGroup('2 f(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0) ', TexCmd('over'), ' 3 b_', BraceGroup('cl')), ' + ', BraceGroup('f^2(', TexCmd('Omega'), '_0) ', TexCmd('over'), '\n5 b_', BraceGroup('cl'), '^2'), ' ', ']', ' b_', BraceGroup('cl'), '^2 ', '\\,', ' P(k),\n', TexCmd('eqno'), '(13)\n'], []), '\nwhere the factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F=0.7-0.8'], []), '. The factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' depends slightly on the\nmodel. GS examined the distribution of clusters in two cosmological\nmodels which start from the observed power spectra of the distribution\nof galaxies and clusters of galaxies. In the model (1), the initial\nlinear power spectrum of density fluctuations was chosen in the form\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(k) ', TexCmd('propto'), ' k^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' at wavelengths ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '<120h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc. In the\nmodel (2), GS assumed that the initial power spectrum contains a\nprimordial feature at the wavelengths ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 30-60h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc.\nThey found that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F=0.8'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F=0.7'], []), ' in the model (1) and model (2), \nrespectively. In this paper we use a value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F=0.75'], []), '.\n\nFig.~4 shows the redshift-space power spectrum of the model clusters \nwith a mean separation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('cl'), '=34h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc. For comparison, we show\nthe power spectrum of the Abell-ACO clusters determined by Einasto et\nal. (1999). This spectrum represents the weighted mean of the power\nspectra determined by Einasto et al. (1997) and Retzlaff et al. (1998).\nEinasto et al. (1997) determined the power spectrum of the Abell-ACO\nclusters from the correlation function of clusters, while Retzlaff et\nal. (1998) estimated the power spectrum directly (see Einasto et al.\n1999 for details). The power spectrum of the distribution of the\nAbell-ACO clusters peaks at the wavenumber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=0.052h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. The\nmean intercluster separation of the Abell-ACO clusters is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('cl'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), '\n34h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup('cl'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 2.5 ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-5'), ' h^3'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-3')], []), ')\n(Einasto et al. 1997, Retzlaff et al. 1998). \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('picture', ['(300,350)\n', TexCmd('special', [BraceGroup("psfile='fig4.ps' angle=-90 voffset=370 hoffset=-200\nvscale=75 hscale=75")]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The power spectrum of the model clusters and the Abell-ACO\nclusters (open circles) with a separation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('cl'), '=34h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc. \nThe heavy lines show the power spectra of clusters determined by\napproximation (13) and the light lines the corresponding linear power\nspectra of matter fluctuations. We have shown the spectra for the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.5'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.6'], []), ' ', '(dot-dashed lines), \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.6'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.8'], []), ' ', '(solid lines), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.95'], []), ' ', '(dotted lines) and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.7'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1.05'], []), ' ', '(dashed lines).')]), '\n'], []), ' \n', '\nFig.~4 shows the power spectrum of clusters predicted in the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models with (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.5'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.6'], []), '), (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.6'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.8'], []), '), \n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.95'], []), ') and (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.7'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1.05'], []), '). For these models, the \nmass function and the peculiar velocities are consistent with the\nobserved data (see Fig.~3b). The models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.6'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.8'], []), '  \nare in good agreement with the observed power spectrum, while\nthe models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.95'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1.05'], []), ' are not consistent with the\nobserved data. In the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>0.95'], []), ', we do not see a peak in the \npower spectrum at the wavenumber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k', TexCmd('simeq'), ' 0.05h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. \n\nWe used also the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '^2'], []), ' test to calculate the probability that the\nmodels fit the observed power spectrum. The observed power spectrum\nrepresents the weighted mean of the power spectra determined by Einasto\net al. (1997) and Retzlaff et al. (1998) and it is not clear how many\npoints of the power spectrum are independent. As a first step we\nused all the data points in Fig.~4. The models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.6'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.8'], []), ' \nare consistent with the observed power spectrum at a confindence level \nhigher than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['90'], []), ' percent . For the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.95'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1.05'], []), ', the \nprobability that the models fit the observed power spectrum is less than \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['30'], []), ' percent . \n\nWe studied also the power spectrum of clusters in other models \nwith different values of (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ') and found similar results. The \npower spectrum of clusters is in good agreement with the observed power \nspectrum of the Abell-ACO clusters, if the initial parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' is in \nthe range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.6-0.8'], []), '. In the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', the allowed values \nfor the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' are in this range, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.20-0.27'], []), ' \n', '(see Fig.~3a). Similarly, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models are consistent \nwith the observed mass function, peculiar velocities and the power spectrum\nof clusters, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.50-0.63'], []), ' ', '(Fig.~3b). \n\nIn the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.4'], []), ' model with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.5'], []), ', the peculiar velocities are larger \nthan observed, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p<0.86'], []), '. For higher values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ', this limit for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' increases. Therefore, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0 ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0.4'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0.5'], []), ', the observed power spectrum and peculiar velocities of clusters \nare not consistent with each other. Either the observed peculiar velocities \nare underestimated, or the observed peak in the power spectrum of clusters \nis overestimated. The peculiar velocities and \nthe power spectrum of clusters are consistent with observations only if \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0<0.4'], []), '.   \n\n', TexCmd('sec', [BraceGroup('DISCUSSION AND SUMMARY')]), '\n', '\nIn this paper, we have examined the properties of clusters of galaxies\nin the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), 'CDM models with a steplike initial power spectrum (1,2)\nthat depends on two parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. The parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0'], []), '\ndetermines the location of the step and the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' - the shape\nof the initial spectrum. For the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p<1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p>1'], []), ', the step\nparameter was chosen to be ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0=0.016h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0=0.03h'], []), ' Mpc', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', respectively.  We investigated the mass function, \npeculiar velocities and the power spectrum of clusters in models with \ndifferent values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. \n\nWe found that the mass function and the peculiar velocities of clusters \nare consistent with the observed data only in a small interval of the \nparameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '. For the model with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', we find \nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.87-1.0'], []), '. For the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.5'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.6'], []), ', we find that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.57-0.64'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.76-0.88'], []), ', respectively. \n\nThe power spectrum of clusters in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), 'CDM models with a\nsteplike initial power spectrum is in good agreement with the observed \npower spectrum of the Abell-ACO clusters, if the initial parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' is \nin the range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0.6-0.8'], []), '. In the models with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.65'], []), ', the allowed values \nfor the parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' are in this range if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.20-0.27'], []), '. \nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0=0.3'], []), ' models are consistent with the observed mass function, \npeculiar velocities and the power spectrum of clusters, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=0.50-0.63'], []), '.\nThe peculiar velocities and the power spectrum of clusters are consistent \nwith observations only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_0<0.4'], []), '.   \n\nWe also studied the rms bulk velocity in the\nmodels, where the mass function, the peculiar velocities and the power \nspectrum of clusters are consistent with observations. We choosed three \nmodels in the allowed parameter space and studied these models in more detail. \nTabel~1 lists the parameters of the models studied. We have determined the\nnumber density of clusters with mass \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('1.5'), ' = 4', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('14'), ' h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot'))], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup('cl')], []), ';\nthe rms mass fluctuation on an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['8h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc scale, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_8'], []), '; \nthe rms peculiar velocity of clusters, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup('cl')], []), ', and the rms bulk\nvelocity for a radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=50h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup('50')], []), '. The rms bulk velocity\nwas determined by using eq. (6). The observed\nbulk velocities are determined in a sphere centered on the Local Group\nand represent a single measurement of the bulk flow on large scales.\nThe observed bulk velocity derived from the Mark III catalog of peculiar\nvelocities for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=50h^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' Mpc is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['375 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 135'], []), ' km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' ', '(Kolatt ', '\\&', '\nDekel 1997). In the models studied, the rms bulk velocity is \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' 270-285'], []), ' km s', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', which is consistent\nwith the observed data. \n\nTherefore, in many aspects the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), 'CDM models with a steplike\ninitial spectrum fit the observed data. Further work is needed to study \nthe properties of galaxies and clusters of galaxies in these models in \nmore detail.\n\n', TexCmd('sec*', [BraceGroup('ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS')]), '\n', '\nWe thank A. '.\nWe can write\n', TexCmd('be'), '\n', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|A_x|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=0'), '^', BraceGroup('k+1'),
