'_0|P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), '|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle')), '\n', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), '|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), '|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n/', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), '|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' is a normalized positive\nlinear functional,\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pap')]), '\n', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|A_x|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_j', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '(j)', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), '|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), ' ,\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '(j)'], []), ' is the maximum eigenvalue of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_x'], []), ' restricted\nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('x,j')], []), '. Now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '(j)'], []), ' was computed by DLS:\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('lamj')]), '\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '(j)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '2'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('j(k+1-j)')]), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe DLS-bound (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dls')]), ') corresponds to the maximum of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('lamj')]), ').\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h(t)'], []), ' be obtained by linear interpolation through the\npoints ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(j,', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '(j))'], []), ':\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ht')]), '\nh(t)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '2'), '\\{', '(', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' t', TexCmd('rfloor'), '+1-t)\n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lfloor'), ' t', TexCmd('rfloor'), '(k+1-', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' t', TexCmd('rfloor'), ')')]), '\n+(t-', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' t', TexCmd('rfloor'), ')', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' t', TexCmd('rfloor'), '+1)(k-', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' t', TexCmd('rfloor'), ')')]), '\\}', ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h(t)'], []), ' is a concave function, and the right\nmember of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('pap')]), ') can be written as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('int'), ' h(t)d', TexCmd('nu'), '(t)'], []), ' with a probability\nmeasure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' concentrated on the integers from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k+1'], []), ", by Jensen's\ninequality\n", TexCmd('be'), '\n|e_0|', TexCmd('leq'), ' h(', TexCmd('int'), ' td', TexCmd('nu'), '(t))=h(\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=0'), '^', BraceGroup('k+1'), 'j', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), '|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n', ') .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe expectation value in the argument of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' can be evaluated and yields\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k+1)', TexCmd('rho')], []), '. Indeed, using the translation invariance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '_0'], []), ', after a\nsimple algebra we find\n', TexCmd('be'), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=0'), '^', BraceGroup('k+1'), 'j', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|P_', BraceGroup('x,j'), '|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n=', TexCmd('sum'), '_X a_X^2', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('vol')), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda')), '|X', TexCmd('cap'), TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x| .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_X'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x')], []), ' denote the characteristic functions of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x'], []), ', respectively. Then\n', TexCmd('be'), '\n|X', TexCmd('cap'), TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x|=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda')), TexCmd('chi'), '_X(y)', TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x'), '(y)\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nand therefore\n', TexCmd('be'), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda')), '|X', TexCmd('cap'), TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x|=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda')), TexCmd('chi'), '_X(y)\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda')), TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x'), '(y)=|X|', TexCmd('cdot'), '|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_x|=N(k+1) .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nHence, we obtain\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('hkr')]), '\n|e_0|', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('min'), '\\{', 'h((k+1)', TexCmd('rho'), '),k', TexCmd('rho'), '\\}', TexCmd('leq', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '2')]), '(k+1)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(1-', TexCmd('rho'), ')')]), '\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nwhere the last member results from majorizing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h(t)'], []), ' by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '2'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('t(k+1-t)')])], []), '.\nTaking the minimum in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('hkr')]), ') is not superfluous. For\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '<', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' k+1')], []), ' we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h((k+1)', TexCmd('rho'), ')=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('k')]), '(k+1)', TexCmd('rho')], []), '.\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '/|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|=k', TexCmd('rho')], []), ' is smaller\nfor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', the trivial bound is better\nfor small densities. Actually the trivial bound provides the\nright asymptotics at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '=0'], []), '\nbecause ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_0=-k', TexCmd('rho'), '+O(', TexCmd('rho'), '^2)'], []), ' near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '=0'], []), ', as one can see by comparing\nthe trivial upper and lower bounds, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-M/', TexCmd('vol')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), '/', TexCmd('vol')], []), '.\n\nNumerical works on the spin-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'], []), ' XY model in the square lattice yield\nan approximate formula,\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('MCFS')]), '\ne_0(', TexCmd('rho'), ')=-1.09766+4.835(0.5-', TexCmd('rho'), ')^2-1.99232(0.5-', TexCmd('rho'), ')^4+0.85952(0.5-', TexCmd('rho'), ')^6 .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe first two terms come respectively from a Monte Carlo\n(Zhang and Runge 1992)\nand a finite-size scaling (Hamer ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al'), ' 1999) study, to which\nwe have added the fourth and the sixth order terms to obtain\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_0(0)=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["e_0'(0)=-4"], []), '.\nIn Figure 1 we have plotted the\ntrivial upper bound ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-4', TexCmd('rho'), '(1-', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), ',\nthe formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MCFS')]), ') and the lower bound\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('min'), '\\{', 'h((k+1)', TexCmd('rho'), '),k', TexCmd('rho'), '\\}'], []), '. We have also shown numerical points for\na ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['5', TexCmd('times'), ' 5'], []), ' lattice from Table 1 of Hamer ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al'), ' 1999. They nicely\nfollow the curve (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MCFS')]), ').\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n ', TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=9 truecm\n ', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('epsffile', [BraceGroup('newboseplot.ps')]))]), '\n ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Approximations of the ground state energy per site as a function of\nthe density in the square lattice.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig1')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nUsing the formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MCFS')]), ') we can compute the lower and upper bounds (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('lowup')]), ')\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_a^2/D^2'], []), '. Both of them increase monotonically as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' varies between\n0 and 0.5: the lower bound from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.66'], []), ' to 0.90234 and the upper bound\nfrom 1 to 1.09766, their difference decreasing monotonically at the same time.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Off-diagonal order and the final form of the ground state')]), '\n', '\nOff-diagonal long-range order in the ground state is characterized by\n(cf. Appendix)\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('odlro')]), '\n', TexCmd('omega'), '_0', TexCmd('equiv'), TexCmd('lim', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' |', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|^2')]), TexCmd('sum'), '_X a_X', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('in'), ' X'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('y', TexCmd('notin'), ' X'), '\na_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'y', '\\}', TexCmd('setminus'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'), '>0\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nwhere lim means the thermodynamic limit\n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vol')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' going to infinity and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N/', TexCmd('vol')], []), ' going to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ').\nIn (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('odlro')]), ') ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), ' a_X^2=1'], []), ' is supposed.\n\nLet us see, what would we obtain if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X'], []), ' did not fluctuate within\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'], []), ', i.e. if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X=', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bndl'))], []), '. This and\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('alen')]), ') would imply another large-deviation principle in the approximate\nform\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ldp^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'), 'a_X^2 =', TexCmd('alpha'), '_n^2 |', TexCmd('Omega'), '_n|\n', TexCmd('sim'), '\n', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('-', BraceGroup('(n-', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2)^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D_', BraceGroup('a^2'), '^2'))]), '\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nwith\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('m2d2')]), '\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2=', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1+D_a^2', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_1-M', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D^2-D_a^2'), TexCmd('qquad'), '\nD_', BraceGroup('a^2'), '^2=', BraceGroup('D^2D_a^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D^2-D_a^2'), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe mean value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_2'], []), ' is larger than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_1'], []), ' because\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('da2/d2'), BraceGroup('D_a^2', TexCmd('over'), ' D^2')]), TexCmd('leq', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_1', TexCmd('over'), ' M')]), '<', TexCmd('min'), '\\{', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '1-', TexCmd('rho')), ' ,\n', BraceGroup('k+1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2k', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(1-', TexCmd('rho'), ')')])), '\\}', '<2 ,\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nsee Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('hkr')]), ').\nAs\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('partial')]), '\n||', TexCmd('partial'), '(X', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'y', '\\}', TexCmd('setminus'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}', ')|-', TexCmd('bndl'), '|', TexCmd('leq'), ' 2k ,\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'y', '\\}', TexCmd('setminus'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'), TexCmd('geq'), TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bndl'), '-2k')], []), ' we would\nfind\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nofluc')]), '\n', TexCmd('omega'), '_0', TexCmd('geq'), TexCmd('rho'), '(1-', TexCmd('rho'), ')', TexCmd('lim'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-', BraceGroup('2k(', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1-M)', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D^2-D_a^2')), '>0 .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe argument above, together with the conclusion (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nofluc')]), ') may be\nright in high enough dimensions\nbut it is known to be incorrect in one dimension.\nFluctuations have to be taken into account.\n\nA way to prove (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('odlro')]), ') would be to show\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), '\na_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'y', '\\}', TexCmd('setminus'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'), TexCmd('geq'), ' c a_X\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nfor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' with a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c>0'], []), ' independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '.\nIf (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ') did hold true, we would find\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_0', TexCmd('geq'), ' c', TexCmd('rho'), '(1-', TexCmd('rho'), ')>0'], []), '. In the complete graph (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ')\nis verified with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=1'], []), ' and equality sign.\nHowever, we know already from the considerations following Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eigen')]), ')\nthat in finite dimensional lattices (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ') cannot hold indeed for all\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ': e.g., in the case when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bndl'), TexCmd('propto'), ' N^', BraceGroup('1-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' d'))], []), ', (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ')\ncan be satisfied only with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c', TexCmd('propto'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' d'))], []), '. Also, we should not\nbe able to prove (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ') in one dimension. Below we present an\nargument which takes into account\nfluctuations and distinguishes between one, two and higher dimensions.\n\nFirst, we note that we need (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ') only for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' in a subset ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ',N)'], []), ' such that the sum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X^2'], []), ' over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '\nis non-vanishing in the thermodynamic limit.\nLet us introduce a function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), ' by setting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X=', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bndl')), 'e^', BraceGroup('R(X)')], []), '.\nThen\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('RX')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'), 'e^', BraceGroup('R(X)'), '=|', TexCmd('Omega'), '_n|', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'), 'e^', BraceGroup('2R(X)'), TexCmd('leq'), ' |', TexCmd('Omega'), '_n|^2 ,\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nso we can define an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), ' and\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('epsfirst')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'), 'e^', BraceGroup('2R(X)'), '=|', TexCmd('Omega'), '_n|^', BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n'), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nUsing this and Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('alen')]), ') we find\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('aepsn')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'), 'a_X^2=', TexCmd('alpha'), '_n^2 |', TexCmd('Omega'), '_n|^', BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n'), '\n', TexCmd('sim'), TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('-', BraceGroup('(n-M_n)^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D_n^2'))]), '\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nwith\n', TexCmd('be'), '\nM_n=', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1+', BraceGroup('(1-', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n)D_a^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D^2-(1-', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n)D_a^2'), '(', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1-M)', TexCmd('qquad'), '\nD_n^2=', BraceGroup('D^2D_a^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D^2-(1-', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n)D_a^2'), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nBecause of the possible ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '-dependence of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_n'], []), ', Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('aepsn')]), ')\nmay not describe a large deviation principle. However,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_n'], []), ' satisfy the inequalities\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_1', TexCmd('leq'), ' M_n', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_a/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('leq'), ' D_n', TexCmd('leq'), ' D_', BraceGroup('a^2')], []), ' and, hence, for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '>0'], []), '\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('epslast')]), '\n', TexCmd('lim'), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(1-', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ')', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('bndl'), TexCmd('leq'), '(1+', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ')', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2'), 'a_X^2=1 .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' we can take the set of summation with any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), '.\n\nNext, we observe that by using Eqs.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nonbipar')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('bipar')]), ')\nwe can write\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ratio'), BraceGroup('a_X', TexCmd('over'), ' a_Y')]), '\n=', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('marrow', TexCmd('infty')), BraceGroup('W_m(X)', TexCmd('over'), ' W_m(Y)'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' or')]), TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('marrow', TexCmd('infty')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_1W_m(X)+W_', BraceGroup('m+1'), '(X)\n', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1W_m(Y)+W_', BraceGroup('m+1'), '(Y)'), '\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nfor non-bipartite or bipartite lattices, respectively.\nThe convergence in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ratio')]), ') is usually slow.\nHowever, we expect that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bndl')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('partial'), ' Y|'], []), ' do not differ too much then,\nat least up to the order of magnitude, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X/a_Y'], []), ' can be approximated\nby the ratio of the number of walks whose length is the\ndistance between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), '. Thus,\nwe conjecture that for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bndl'), '=c_1 N'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['||', TexCmd('partial'), ' Y|-', TexCmd('bndl'), '|', TexCmd('leq'), ' c_2'], []), '\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('conj')]), '\n|', TexCmd('ln', [BraceGroup('a_X', TexCmd('over'), ' a_Y')]), '-', TexCmd('ln', [BraceGroup('W_', BraceGroup('d_G(X,Y)'), '(X)', TexCmd('over'), ' W_', BraceGroup('d_G(X,Y)'), '(Y)')]), '|\n', TexCmd('leq'), ' c_3\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_3'], []), ' may depend on the constants\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_2'], []), ' but not on the size of the system.\nIn what follows, we examine the consequences of this hypothesis.\n\nIf the aspect ratios of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' are kept bounded,\nits diameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' is of order\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|^', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' d')], []), ' and the diameter of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is of order\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L^', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), '. Over such a distance (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('conj')]), ') allows a gigantic change of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X'], []), '.\nHowever, the distance to be considered\nfor (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ') is much smaller. If the symmetric difference of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'x,y', '\\}'], []), ', it is easily seen that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_G(X,Y)=d(x,y)', TexCmd('leq'), ' L'], []), '.\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bndl'), '=n', TexCmd('propto'), ' N'], []), '.\nAbove one dimension we apply the inequalities (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Wnineq')]), ')\nto obtain\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('W/W'), BraceGroup('W_', BraceGroup('d_G(X,Y)'), '(X)', TexCmd('over'), ' W_', BraceGroup('d_G(X,Y)'), '(Y)')]), TexCmd('leq'), '\n', '(', BraceGroup('1+2(k-1)L/n', TexCmd('over'), ' 1-', '[', '2(k-1)L+2', ']', '/n'), ')^', BraceGroup('L'), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nIn the thermodynamic limit the upper bound remains finite\nin two dimensions and converges to 1 in higher dimensions,\nso we get the necessary estimate (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ageqa')]), ').\nIn one dimension there exists no convergent upper bound.\nThus, we find ODLRO in the ground state in two and higher dimensions\nbut not in one dimension.\n\nThe difference between\n2 and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2+', TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), ' dimensions in the convergence of the right-hand side of\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W/W')]), ')\nindicates that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d=2'], []), ' is the critical dimension above which\nthe deviations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X'], []), ' from the average ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bndl'))], []), '\nare irrelevant. This remark can be made quantitative if we observe\nan interesting consequence of the hypothesis (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('conj')]), ') on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), '.\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bndl'), TexCmd('propto'), ' N'], []), ' then inside a sphere of radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')])], []), ', centred\nat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ', for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['||', TexCmd('partial'), ' Y|-', TexCmd('bndl'), '|'], []), ' is bounded by some constant\nof the order of unity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|R(Y)-R(X)|'], []), ' also remains below another constant of order~1.\nComparing the scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')])], []), ' with the diameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' N^', BraceGroup('1+1/d')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\nwe conclude that\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('maxrx')]), '\n|R(X)|', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('max'), ' R(Y)-', TexCmd('min'), ' R(Y)<', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' const'), TexCmd('times'), ' N^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '+', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' d')), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe maximum and the minimum are taken over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bndl'))], []), '.\nThe first inequality holds because for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' the average of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), ' over\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'], []), ' is negative, but ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), ' cannot be negative for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '.\n\nAccording to Equation~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('maxrx')]), '),\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('afinal')]), '\na_X=', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('F(', TexCmd('bndl'), ')+R(X)')]), '=\n', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('F(', TexCmd('bndl'), ')+O(N^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '2'), '+', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' d')), ')')]), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nTherefore, in one dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), '\ncan dominate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(', TexCmd('bndl'), ')'], []), ', in two dimensions it can vary on the same\nscale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), ' N'], []), ',\nand above two dimensions the variation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), ' is\nnegligible compared with that of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(', TexCmd('bndl'), ')'], []), '. Apart from an additive\nconstant necessary for normalization, the approximate form of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(n)=', TexCmd('ln'), TexCmd('alpha'), '_n'], []), ' can be read off from Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('alen')]), ').\n\nThe upper bound in the right-hand member of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('maxrx')]), ') could, of course,\noverestimate the order of magnitude of the maximum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|R(X)|'], []), '. However,\nbecause it seems to correctly distinguish between one, two and higher\ndimensions, it is probably sharp.\nThis implies also that on the scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')])], []), ' the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), ' can\nbe considered as describing a ballistic motion over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' rather than a\nrandom fluctuation about a negative average,\nwhich would lead to a smaller bound. Accepting\nballisticity on smaller scales as well, one can\nfind the order of magnitude of local variations\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), '. We distinguish between two cases.\n\n(a) If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' is bipartite with sublattices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_2'], []), ' then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is also\nbipartite with sublattices\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_1=', '\\{', 'X:|X', TexCmd('cap'), ' V_1| ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('is even')]), '\\}'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_2=', '\\{', 'X:|X', TexCmd('cap'), ' V_1| ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('is odd')]), '\\}'], []), '. Along each path in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' the subsequent\nterms belong to alternating sublattices. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), '\\,', '^2 X'], []), ' denotes the set\nof second neighbours of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' then\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cons1')]), '\n|R(X)-R(Y)|<', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' const'), TexCmd('times'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1/2'), TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('partial'), '\\,', '^2X'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('partial'), ' Y|=', TexCmd('bndl')], []))]), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\n', '\n', '(b) If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' is not bipartite, neither is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', and no systematic\ncompensation of terms of different signs is possible. In this case\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cons2')]), '\n|R(X)-R(Y)|<', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' const'), TexCmd('times'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1/2'), TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bnd')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('partial'), ' Y|=', TexCmd('bndl')], []))]), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe result on ODLRO could be obtained from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cons1')]), '), (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cons2')]), ') as well.\n\nAs the two-dimensional case is marginal, some subtle logarithmic corrections,\nthat we do not see, may modify our conclusions.\n\nAbove two dimensions we also find, as a further consequence\nof Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('maxrx')]), '), that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_n'], []), '\nidentically vanishes in the thermodynamic limit. Thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_n/', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2arrow 1'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_n/D_', BraceGroup('a^2'), 'arrow 1'], []), ', Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('aepsn')]), ') asymptotically coincides\nwith Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ldp^2')]), '), Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nofluc')]), ') provides a valid lower bound\non the order parameter, and Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('epslast')]), ') can be replaced by\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eps22')]), '\n', TexCmd('lim'), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(1-', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ')', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('bndl'), TexCmd('leq'), '(1+', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ')', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2'), 'a_X^2=1\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nfor any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '>0'], []), '. This property makes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X^2'], []), ' similar to a thermal\nGibbs state for a classical lattice gas. The classical Hamiltonian\n(with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/k_B T'], []), ' incorporated) is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Heff'), '(X)=-2F(', TexCmd('bndl'), ')-2R(X)'], []), ', and there is\nasymptotic equivalence between the canonical distribution and a microcanonical one\nconcentrated on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), "'s with ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Heff'), '(X)'], []), ' in an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['o(N)'], []), ' neighbourhood of the\ncanonical expectation value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Heff')], []), '. This holds in spite of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Heff')], []), '\ncontaining long-range interactions. Indeed, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-F'], []), ' is a sum of\nnearest neighbour repulsive two-body interactions, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_x'], []), ', and, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_a', TexCmd('neq'), ' D'], []), ',\nproperly normalized\nlong-range four-body interactions, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_xf_y'], []), ', see Eqs.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fx')]), '),\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('DeltaX')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('alen')]), '), the whole yielding a global repulsion\nwhich tends to maximize ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bndl')], []), '. Now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' may also include up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' body\ninteractions but because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)=o(N)'], []), ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' and because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X^2'], []), ' corresponds\nto a high-temperature Gibbs state'), ', it can be neglected: The fact that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' may partly split the ground state degeneracy of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-F'], []), ' is irrelevant at high\ntemperatures.\n\nWe have no rigorous proof that the limiting effective Gibbs state is a\npure (in particular, a high-tem', '\\-', 'per', '\\-', 'ature)\nstate. For this we should show that for all densities and all relevant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2F(n)/n<K_c'], []), ', the critical coupling\nof the Ising model on the same lattice. Even if we knew ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_1'], []), ' exactly,\nour bounds (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('lowup')]), ') on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_a/D'], []), ' are not good enough to obtain this\ninformation. For example, in the case of the square lattice we can use\nthe numerical fit (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('MCFS')]), '). If we assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_a', TexCmd('geq'), ' D'], []), ', we get\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2F(n)/n', TexCmd('leq'), ' 2(', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1-M)/D^2'], []), ' where the upper bound increases with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), '\nand its maximum at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '=0.5'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.3906<K_c=0.4407'], []), '. On the other hand,\nif we use the lower bound for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_a'], []), ', at half filling we find for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('geq'), TexCmd('lambda'), '_1'], []), '\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2F(n)/n', TexCmd('leq'), ' 0.628>K_c'], []), '. An indication to\nthe high-temperature character can be found in the variational estimates,\ncf. the final remark\nof section 5.1. In the light of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('afinal')]), '), trial functions of the\nform (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('trial')]), ') acquire a particular importance: For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d>2'], []), ' one could find\nwith them the exact ground state energy per site, and the optimal exponential\nansatz may not be far from the true ground state. The variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' appearing in\nthe formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('av*av')]), ') corresponds to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), TexCmd('beta'), ' J'], []), ' of the Ising model.\nThe estimates we have done predict a value well below the critical one in\nany dimension: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), ' J< 0.2'], []), ' for all densities at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=3'], []), ', and decreases with\nincreasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', reaching 0 in the complete graph.\n\nNow the fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X^2'], []), ' is equivalent to a high-temperature Gibbs state means that there\nis no classical (diagonal) order in the ground state, coexisting with\nthe purely quantum-mechanical (off-diagonal) one.\nDiagonal order is characterized by an order\nparameter operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O'], []), ' which is diagonal in the basis (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('basis')]), ')\nand for which the ground state expectation value\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vol'), '^', BraceGroup('-2'), TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|O^*O|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), '=', TexCmd('vol'), '^', BraceGroup('-2'), TexCmd('sum'), ' a_X^2 |O(X)|^2'], []), ' has a\nnon-vanishing thermodynamic limit. A typical example is\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O_q=', TexCmd('sum'), '_x e^', BraceGroup('i(q,x)'), 'n_x'], []), ',\nassociated with a periodic order with a wave vector~', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), '. Due to the\ncorrespondence with a Gibbs state, diagonal order in the ground\nstate of the Bose gas is equivalent to low-temperature order in\nthe associated classical lattice gas.\nThe ground state of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-F'], []), ' is exponentially degenerate for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '<1/2'], []), '.\nHowever, it is only two-fold degenerate on bipartite lattices at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '=1/2'], []), ',\nand the degeneracy is not split by the translation invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(X)'], []), '.\nApparently, there is no\nqualitative argument against a crystalline order at half filling\nin the ground state of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d>2'], []), ' dimensional purely hard-core Bose gas.\nThe nearest neighbour repulsion in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-F'], []), ' is simply not strong enough,\nreflecting the fact that a purely on-site repulsion in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_0'], []), ',\neven though infinite, cannot induce such an order.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Extensions and concluding remarks')]), '\n', '\nThe nonuniformity of the ground state we have found in a\npurely hard-core gas seems to be a general property of\nfinite-range Hamiltonians. The extension to more complicated\nhard-core Hamiltonians is immediate. Let\n', TexCmd('bea'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Hgen')]), '\nH&=&-', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('langle'), ' xy', TexCmd('rangle')), '(b_x^*b_y+b_y^*b_x)+', TexCmd('sum'), ' V_x n_x\n-J', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('langle'), ' xy', TexCmd('rangle')), '(n_x-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')(n_y-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')\n+K(', '\\{', 'n_x', '\\}', ')', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('equiv'), '& H_0+V+', BraceGroup('J', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), '(2', TexCmd('Delta'), '-|E', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|)+K\n', TexCmd('eea'), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' is the diagonal\npart of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_0^2'], []), ', cf. Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '), and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' may contain further\ninteractions of a bounded range.\nBecause the terms additional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_0'], []), ' are diagonal in the\nbasis (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('basis')]), '), the Perron-Frobenius theorem still applies and\nthe ground state wave vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X>0'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is the matrix of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-H'], []), ' then\nkeeping the definition (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W')]), ') we still have (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('EaWn')]), '), and the\ninequalities of section 2 also hold with suitable modifications.\nIn particular, in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('parxy')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('w1s-w2')]), ') ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2(k-1)'], []), ' is to be replaced\nby ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), '=|2-J|(k-1)+', TexCmd('delta'), ' V+', TexCmd('delta'), ' K'], []), ' where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' V=', TexCmd('max'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('langle'), ' xy', TexCmd('rangle')), '|V_x-V_y|'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' K=', TexCmd('max'), '_', BraceGroup('X,Y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bnd')), '|K(Y)-K(X)|'], []), '\nare of the order of unity, and in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Da')]), ')-(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Ch2')]), ') we have\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('bndl'), TexCmd('rangle'), '_a'], []), ' instead of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2(k-1)', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1'], []), '. Now\n', TexCmd('be'), '\nW_1(X)=A_', BraceGroup('XX'), '+', TexCmd('bndl'), '=(1-', BraceGroup('J', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')', TexCmd('bndl'), '-V(X)-K(X)\n+', BraceGroup('J', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), '|E', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nmay not be positive and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), ' W_1', TexCmd('rangle'), '_a=', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1=-E_0'], []), ' may not be of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '.\nTherefore, there may not be a large deviation principle for the pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(W_1,a)'], []), '.\nHowever, if we replace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H^c=H+cI'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ' is the identity operator, the\nground state vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' will not change. The corresponding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_1'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_1^c(X)=W_1(X)-c'], []), ',\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_a^2(W_1^c)'], []), ' is also independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '. Let us choose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=', TexCmd('langle'), ' A_', BraceGroup('XX'), TexCmd('rangle'), '_a'], []), ',\nthen\n', TexCmd('be'), '\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1+c', TexCmd('equiv'), TexCmd('lambda'), '_1^c=', TexCmd('langle'), ' W_1^c', TexCmd('rangle'), '_a=', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('bndl'), TexCmd('rangle'), '_a\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nand, thus, we have a large deviation principle for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(W_1^c,a)'], []), ' in the same form as\nfor the purely hard-core interaction.\n\nWhat really counts for the non-uniformity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' is not the large deviation\nprinciple for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(W_1,a)'], []), ' but the variation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_1(X)'], []), ' over the set of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-point\nconfigurations. The ground state is nonuniform if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('max'), ' W_1(X)-', TexCmd('min'), ' W_1(X)', ']', '/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')])], []), '\ngoes to infinity with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '. As an example, let us consider the nearest neighbour\nanisotropic Heisenberg model (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V=K=0'], []), '). At ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J=2'], []), ', when it is isotropic,\nfor any fixed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' we have\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_1(X)', TexCmd('equiv'), ' |E', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|/2'], []), ' and hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_1=|E', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|/2'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X'], []), ' is constant.\nAway from the isotropy point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' W_1'], []), ' is of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' is nonuniform.\n\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_n=', '\\{', 'X: W_1(X)=w_n', '\\}'], []), ',\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_1<w_2<', TexCmd('ldots')], []), ' are the possible values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_1'], []), ', one can write\ndown an approximate formula similar to Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('qan')]), '), namely\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q(n)', TexCmd('sim'), TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('-(w_n-', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('W_1')]), ')^2/2D^2(W_1)')]), '(w_', BraceGroup('n+1'), '-w_n)'], []), '.\nInterpreting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_n'], []), ' as the average of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X'], []), ' over the newly defined\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), '_n'], []), ', we have also the analogue of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('alen')]), ').\n\nAs earlier, we can write\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X=', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('F(W_1(X))+R(X)')])], []), ', and Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('RX')]), ') remains valid.\nThe approximate form of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' is\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('F')]), '\nF(W_1(X))', TexCmd('approx', [BraceGroup('(W_1(X)-', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('W_1')]), ')^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D(W_1)^2')]), '-\n', BraceGroup('(W_1(X)+E_0)^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2D_a(W_1)^2'), '+', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' const'), '\n .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\n', '\nOne can replace the infinite on-site repulsion by a finite one\nprovided that stability is assured, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H>-', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' const'), TexCmd('times'), ' N'], []), '.\nThe dimension of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-particle subspace will increase\nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vol'), '+N-1', TexCmd('choose'), ' N'], []), '. A\nconfiguration ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' becomes a list of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' elements containing vertices\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' with possible repetitions that we can write as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X=', '\\{', 'x^', BraceGroup('n_x'), '\\}', '_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda'))], []), '. The neighbourhood relation\nremains the same: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bnd')], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ' can be obtained\nfrom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' by moving a single particle along an edge of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ', say,\nfrom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), '. The corresponding matrix element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-H'], []), ' is then\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('XY'), '=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('n_x(X)n_y(Y)')])], []), '. Now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('Y', TexCmd('neq'), ' X'), 'A_', BraceGroup('XY')], []), '\ncan vary between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), 'kN'], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bndl')], []), ' varies\nbetween ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['kN'], []), '. However, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('XX')], []), ' can be of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N^2'], []), ' and\nits change between neighbours of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '. Therefore, we miss\na pointwise bound like (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('parxy')]), ') and cannot repeat the argument of\nsection 2. Nevertheless, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-W_1(X)=', TexCmd('sum'), '_Y', TexCmd('langle'), ' Y|H|X', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' is still the\nenergy of a classical lattice\ngas in which the equivalence of the canonical and microcanonical\nensembles implies the analogue of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('qan')]), ") and, via the\nargument of section 4, the nonuniformity of the ground state.\n\nThe real novelty introduced by the additional interactions is the possible\ncoexistence of classical long-range order with the off-diagonal one. A\nthorough discussion of this question, concluding negatively, can be found\nalready in Penrose and Onsager's 1956 paper. Nevertheless, a controversy\nhas remained until recently, when reliable quantum Monte Carlo computations\non square lattice models have shown such a coexistence (Batrouni ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al'), ' 1995,\nScalettar ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al'), ' 1995).\nWe hope that the ideas developed in this paper\ncan contribute in the future to further elucidate this interesting problem.\n\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('2mm')]), '\n', '\nThis work was supported by the Hungarian Scientific Research Fund (OTKA)\nunder Grant No. T 30543.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Appendix. A digression on ODLRO')]), '\n', '\nFollowing the standard\ndefinition (Penrose and Onsager 1956, PO), we give below the expression\nof the ODLRO parameter in terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(a_X)'], []), ', valid for any Bose gas whose\nHamiltonian contains a hard-core repulsion and conserves the number of particles.\nThe density operator in the ground state ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '_0'], []), ' ', '(supposed\nto be normalized) is\nthe orthogonal projection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|'], []), '. The density\nmatrix in the basis (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('basis')]), ') is therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(a_Xa_Y)'], []), '.\nFrom here the one-particle reduced density matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '=(', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), ')'], []), '\nis obtained by taking a partial trace over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N-1'], []), ' particle positions,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('onepart')]), '\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup("X'"), 'a_', BraceGroup("X'", TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'), 'a_', BraceGroup("X'", TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'y', '\\}'), ' .\n'], []), '\nIn the above sum ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["X'"], []), ' runs over the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N-1'], []), '-point subsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), '\nnot containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), '. The matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is real symmetric, positive\nsemidefinite (in fact, positive definite for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N>2'], []), '), its trace is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' and\nall its elements are positive.\nA possible choice for the order parameter, according to PO, is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('omega')]), '\n', TexCmd('omega'), '=|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|^', BraceGroup('-2'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x,y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), ' .\n'], []), '\nAnother definition of PO for the order parameter is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|'], []), '\ntimes the largest eigenvalue of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' is a shift-invariant set (which\nsupposes periodic boundary conditions), the ground state is translation\ninvariant and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '=', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('x-y')], []), '.\nApplying the Perron-Frobenius theorem to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' we find that its largest\neigenvalue\nis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_y', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('x-y'), '=|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|', TexCmd('omega')], []), ',\nso that the above two definitions coincide.\nThe order parameter\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' also has an interpretation as the density of the\nBose-Einstein condensate. This holds because the operator\nassociated with the density of the condensate is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('condop')]), '\n|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'b^*_', BraceGroup('k=0'), 'b_', BraceGroup('k=0'), '=|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|^', BraceGroup('-2'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x,y', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Lambda')), 'b_x^*b_y\n'], []), '\nand because\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sigmaxy')]), '\n', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_0|b_x^*b_y|', TexCmd('Psi'), '_0', TexCmd('rangle'), '=', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), ' .\n'], []), '\nInserting (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('onepart')]), ') into (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('omega')]), ') we obtain\n', TexCmd('be'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup("om'")]), '\n', TexCmd('omega'), '=', TexCmd('omega'), "'+", BraceGroup('N', TexCmd('over'), '|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|^2'), TexCmd('qquad'), '\n', TexCmd('omega'), "'=", BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|^2'), TexCmd('sum'), '_X a_X ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('in'), ' X'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('y', TexCmd('notin'), ' X'), '\na_', BraceGroup('X', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'y', '\\}', TexCmd('setminus'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'), ' .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nThe maximum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), "'"], []), ' under the condition of normalization is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(1-', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), ',\nattained with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_X'], []), ' constant. It is realized by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_0'], []), ' on complete graphs and\nby the ferromagnetic Heisenberg model on arbitrary graphs.\nOur ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), "'"], []), ' is one fourth of the order parameter usually used in the\nspin-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'], []), ' XY model, cf. Fujiki and Betts 1986, Hamer ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al'), ' 1999.\nThere is ODLRO for a density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' or, equivalently,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), "'"], []), ' has a\nnonvanishing limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_0>0'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|'], []), ' go to infinity while\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N/|', TexCmd('Lambda'), '|'], []), ' goes to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), '. When this occurs, conservation\nof the particle number\nis spontaneously broken and there appears (at least) a\none-parameter continuum of ground states in infinite volume. The order\nparameter operator, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), ' b_x^*'], []), ', is nondiagonal in the natural basis\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('basis')]), ') (whence the name ODLRO).\nThe ground states\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('alpha'), '<2', TexCmd('pi')], []), ', are symmetry-related. For any local\noperator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '\n', TexCmd('be'), '\n', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), '(B)=', TexCmd('gamma'), '_0(', TexCmd('prod'), '_x e^', BraceGroup('-i', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n_x'), 'B\n', TexCmd('prod'), '_x e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n_x'), ') .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\nIn particular,\n', TexCmd('be'), '\n', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), '(b_x^*)=e^', BraceGroup('-i', TexCmd('alpha')), TexCmd('gamma'), '_0(b_x^*)', TexCmd('neq'), ' 0 .\n', TexCmd('ee'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('newpage'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('BSZK')]), '\nBatrouni G G, Scalettar R T, Zimanyi G T and Kampf A P 1995\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' Phys. Nucl. Sci.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('The ', TexCmd('d'), '0 Run II Detector and Physics Prospects')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('Neeti Parashar')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('address', [BraceGroup('111 Dana Research Center,Northeastern University, 360 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115, USA\nE-mail: neeti@fnal.gov\nFOR THE ', TexCmd('d'), '0 COLLABORATION')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('abstracts', [BraceGroup('\nThe ', TexCmd('d'), '0 Detector at Fermilab is currently undergoing an extensive upgrade to\nparticipate in the Run II data taking which shall begin on March 1, 2001. The\ndesign of the detector meets the requirements of the high luminosity\nenvironment provided by the accelerator. This paper describes the\nupgraded detector subsystems and gives a brief outline of the physics prospects\nassociated with the upgrade. ')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nThe ', TexCmd('d'), '0 detector\nwas designed to study\ncollisions between protons and anti-protons in the Tevatron collider at\nFermilab.\n', TexCmd('d'), '0 took its first data run in the period 1992-1996, called Run I.\nThe successes of Run 1, including the discovery of the top quark, and the\nphysics potential of high-luminosity running at the Tevatron have additionally motivated the\n present upgrade of the detector. We would now like to pursue a detailed top\nquark physics study, search for the Higgs boson and for supersymmetry,\ninvestigate b-physics, and look for physics beyond the Standard Model (SM).\n\nIn order to enhance the physics reach of these processes in Run II, the Tevatron also\nhad to undergo two major upgrades. First, the Tevatron for Run II is\ndesigned to achieve a luminosity of 5x10', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('32')], []), ' cm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), 's', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', which is a factor of\n10 more than in Run I. The second upgrade involves a decrease in the bunch\ncrossing time, which for Run I was 3.5 ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' s'], []), ', while Run II will begin with 396 ns\n and eventually reach 132 ns as the number of bunches is increased.\nThere is also an increase in the center-of-mass (CM) energy from 1.8 TeV to 2.0\nTeV. To take full advantage of the new physics opportunities and to contend\nwith the high radiation environment and shorter bunch crossing times, an\nextensive upgrade of the ', TexCmd('d'), '0 detector was undertaken, which is now in its final\nstages.\n\n Figure 1 shows an elevation view of the upgraded detector.\n The upgrade consists of an addition of a solenoid, a tracker\n with silicon and fiber detectors, muon scintillation trigger\n counters, new forward muon system, preshower detectors, readout\n electronics and new trigger and data acquisition systems.\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=28pc ', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('d0upgrade.eps')]), ' ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Elevation view of the upgraded ', TexCmd('d'), '0 detector for Run II. ')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('p')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Tracking')]), '\nThe upgraded tracking system (Figure 2) consists of an inner silicon vertex\ndetector,\nsurrounded by eight superlayers of scintillating fiber tracker. These detectors\n are located inside a 2 Tesla superconducting solenoid, which is surrounded by\n a scintillator based preshower detector. The upgraded tracking system has\nbeen designed to meet several goals:\nmomentum measurement by the introduction of a solenoidal field; good\nelectron identification and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e/', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' rejection; tracking over a large\nrange in pseudo-rapidity (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('approx')], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm')], []), '3); secondary vertex\nmeasurement for identification of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), '-jets from Higgs and top decays\nand for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), '-physics; first level tracking trigger; fast detector\nresponse to enable operation with a bunch crossing time of 132~ns; and\nradiation hardness.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Silicon Microstrip Tracker (SMT)')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('subsec:wpp')]), '\nThe silicon tracker is the first set of detectors encountered by particles\nemerging from the collision. The detector design consists of interspersed disks\nand barrels, based on single and double-sided silicon microstrip detectors,\nwith a total of 793,000 channels and is radiation hard up to about 2 Mrad.\nThe SVX IIe chip is\nused for readout~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('svx2e')]), '. The combination of\nsmall-angle and large-angle stereo provides good pattern recognition\nand allows good separation of primary vertices in multiple interaction\nevents. The expected hit position resolution in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r', TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is 10~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ' m'], []), '.\n\nA silicon track trigger preprocessor is being built which will allow the\nuse of SMT information in the Level 2 trigger.  This will add the capability for\ntriggering on tracks displaced from the primary vertex, as well as\nsharpening the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_T'], []), ' threshold of the Level 2 track trigger and of the\nelectron and jet triggers at Level 3.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=27pc ', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('run2_tracker_annotated2.eps')]), ' ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r-z'], []), ' view of the ', TexCmd('d'), '0 tracking system. ')]), '\n', '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Central Fiber Tracker (CFT)')]), '\nThe detector just outside the SMT is the 8-layered CFT, which is based on\nscintillating fiber ribbon doublets with visible light photon counter (VLPC)\nreadout~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('vlpc')]), '. Each layer contains 2 fiber doublets in a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['zu'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['zv'], []), ' configuration (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' = axial\nfibers and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u,v = ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 3^', TexCmd('circ')], []), ' stereo fibers). Each doublet\nconsists of two layers of 830~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), 'm diameter fibers with 870~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), 'm\nspacing, offset by half the fiber spacing. This configuration provides very\ngood efficiency\nand pattern recognition and results in a position resolution of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('approx')], []), '~100~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), 'm in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r ', TexCmd('phi')], []), '. There are a total of 77,000 channels.\n\nThe CFT serves two main functions. First, with the SMT it enables track reconstruction\nand momentum measurement for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<'], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm')], []), '1.7, second it provides fast Level 1 triggering on charged track momentum.\n\n\nThe fibers are up to 2.5~m long and the light is piped out by clear\nfibers of length 7-11~m to the VLPCs situated in cryostats outside the\ntracking volume, which are maintained at 9', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('circ')], []), 'K.  The VLPCs are\nsolid state devices with a pixel size of 1~mm, matched to the fiber\ndiameter. The fast risetime, high gain and excellent quantum\nefficiency of these devices make them ideally suited to this\napplication.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Superconducting Solenoid')]), '\n', '\n', '\nThe momenta of the charged particles will be determined from their curvature\nin the 2T magnetic field provided by a 2.8 m long, 1.42 m in diameter and 1.1\n radiation length thick solenoid magnet. From the value of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sin'), TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('int'), ' B_z dl'], []), ' and the space point precision provided\nby the silicon and fiber tracking\nsystem (located inside the solenoid) a momentum resolution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' p_T / p_T = 0.002 p_T'], []), ', (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_T'], []), ' in GeV) is\n expected.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Preshower detectors')]), '\nThe central and forward preshower detectors (CPS and FPS) are based on a\nsimilar technology, using triangular scintillator strips (axial and 20', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('circ')], []), '\n ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('stereo')]), ') with wavelength\nshifter readout. These detectors provide fast energy and position measurements\nfor the electron trigger and facilitate offline electromagnetic identification.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Muon Detectors')]), '\n', '\nThe higher event rates in Run II have led us to add new muon trigger detectors\n covering full pseudorapidity range and the harsh radiation environment has\nprompted us to replace the forward proportional drift tubes(PDTs) with\nmini-drift tubes (MDTs). In the central region, the Run I PDTs are used\n and the front-end electronics have been replaced to ensure\ndead-timeless operation.\n\nThe scintillation counters provide the time information and match\nthe muon tracks in the fiber tracker, and consists of three layers\nto reduce hit combinatorics. The drift tubes provide enhanced muon\nmomentum resolution and pattern recognition. The design of the muon\nsystem reduces backgrounds and trigger rates with additional shielding\nand we have the ability to trigger on inclusive single muons with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_T > 7'], []), ' GeV and dimuons with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_T > 2'], []), ' GeV.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Trigger and Data Acquisition')]), '\nThe ', TexCmd('d'), '0 trigger and DAQ systems have been completely restructured to\nhandle the shorter bunch spacing and new detector subsystems in\nRun~II.  The Level 1 and 2 triggers utilize information from the\ncalorimeter, preshower detectors, central fiber tracker, and muon\ndetectors. The Level 1 trigger reduces the event rate from 7.5~MHz to\n10~KHz and has a latency of 4~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), 'sec. The trigger information is\nrefined at Level 2 using calorimeter clustering and detailed matching\nof objects from different subdetectors. The Level 2 trigger has an\noutput rate of 1~KHz and a latency of 100~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), 'sec. Level 3,\nconsisting of an array of PC processors, partially reconstructs event\ndata within 50~msec to reduce the rate to 50~Hz. Events are then\nwritten to tape.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfxsize'), '=27pc ', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('higgs_reach_runII.eps')]), ' ', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Integrated luminosity required as a function of Higgs mass for a 95 percent  C.L.\nexclusion, 3', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' evidence and 5', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' discovery.')]), '\n', '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Run II Physics Prospects - Some Highlights')]), '\nWe have seen that the design of the Run II ', TexCmd('d'), '0 detector makes important\nadditions to the ', TexCmd('d'), '0 physics capabilities, namely: energy/momentum matching for electron identification, improved muon momentum resolution, charged sign and momentum determination, calorimeter calibration and displaced vertex identification (b-tags).\n\nOne of the crucial physics goals of Run II is to search for the Higgs boson.\nIn Run II the reach for Higgs at the Tevatron suggests a possibility of\ndiscovering light Higgs, given sufficient integrated luminosity from both\nexperiments (', TexCmd('d'), '0 and Collider Detector at Fermilab, CDF)\nat the collider~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('run2_higgs')]), '. The dominant decays can be classified into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_ ', BraceGroup('Higgs'), ' < 135~GeV'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('Higgs'), ' > 135~GeV'], []), '. The light mass range is of great interest, since minimal\nsupersymmetric versions of SM always predict a light Higgs boson lying in this region. If there is no SM Higgs, 95 percent  confidence level exclusion limits can be set up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('approx')], []), '120 GeV mass with 2~fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. However if there is a Higgs, discovery at the 5', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' level can be obtained with 20~fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' up to similar mass. This sensitivity is shown in ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('Figure 3')]), '.\n\n\n\nA detailed study of the top quark is another important physics interest.\n Since the CM energy is expected to increase from\n1.8~TeV to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('approx')], []), '2.0~TeV, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('bar'), ' t'], []), ' production cross section will\nincrease by about 38 percent  (the production is dominated by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q ', TexCmd('bar'), ' q ', TexCmd('to'), ' t\n', TexCmd('bar'), ' t'], []), '). For single top production the increase will be about 22 percent \nfor the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), '-channel (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q ', TexCmd('bar'), ' q ', TexCmd('to'), ' t ', TexCmd('bar'), ' b'], []), '), and about 44 percent  for the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), '-gluon fusion process (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['qg ', TexCmd('to'), ' q t ', TexCmd('bar'), ' b'], []), '). The expected\nuncertainty in the top quark mass measurement is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' m_t ', TexCmd('simeq'), '\n2'], []), '~GeV, and we should also be able to observe single top production for the first time.\n\nSM has been very successful so far and in the electroweak sector, the goal is to make more precise tests of the SM and search for deviations that may signal the presence of new physics. A prime measurement is of the W mass, which\nin Run II would be done with a precision of ~30 MeV from both ', TexCmd('d'), '0 and CDF~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('run2_mw')]), '. Within SM, the mass of the top quark and the W boson set constraints on the mass of the Higgs boson.\n\nIn physics beyond the SM, there is potential for observing supersymmetry. For example, the supersymmetric  gaugino pair production in the trilepton\ndecay modes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('bar'), ' p ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), ' ', '_1^', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '_1^', TexCmd('mp'), ',\n', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), ' ', '_1^', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '_2^0 ', TexCmd('to'), ' 3', TexCmd('ell'), ' + X'], []), ', can be discovered with a mass reach of 220\nGeV. Supersymmetric squark/gluino production in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('jets')]), TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), TexCmd('kern'), '-0.6em', TexCmd('lower'), '-.1ex', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('/')]))])), '_T'], []))]), ' + '], []), '\nchannel is expected to probe masses up to about 400~GeV for\n2~fb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. Other interesting searches include a wide range of topics, namely,\nleptoquarks, new gauge bosons (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W^', TexCmd('prime')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z^', TexCmd('prime')], []), '), topcolor, compositeness, technicolor and\nextra dimensions. In Run II there is an excellent chance to discover new physics or exclude significant regions of parameter space.\n\nA wide range of b-physics and QCD physics will also be pursued, but their details are beyond the scope of this article. Details of the ', TexCmd('d'), '0 detector and its upgrade can be found elsewhere~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('upgrade_details')]), '.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgments')]), '\nI would like to thank the Lake Louise Winter Institute for arranging a ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('stimulating')]), ' set of talks and for their warm hospitality. I would also like to thank Darien Wood for careful reading of this paper.\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('svx2e')]), 'T.~Zimmerman ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al'), ', ', TexCmd('Journal', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('IEEE')), BraceGroup('42'), BraceGroup('803'), BraceGroup('1995')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('vlpc')]), 'M.D. Petroff and M.G. [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Im')), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Im'), '~')]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nh')), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' non-hermitean matrix'))]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('det')), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' det'), '~')]), '\n', TexCmd('renewcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('thesection')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('arabic', [BraceGroup('section')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('renewcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theequation')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('thesection'), '.', TexCmd('arabic', [BraceGroup('equation')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('itp', [BraceGroup('01'), BraceGroup('24')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('vspace*', [BraceGroup('.0in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('center', [], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('large'), TexCmd('bf'), ' ``SINGLE RING THEOREM" AND THE DISK-ANNULUS PHASE \nTRANSITION')]), '\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('-.2in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Joshua Feinberg', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('a *')], []), ', R. Scalettar', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('b *')], []), ' ', '\\&', ' A. \nZee', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('c ')], []), TexCmd('fnote', [BraceGroup('*'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' e-mail addresses: joshua@physics.technion.ac.il, \nrst@solid.ucdavis.edu, zee@itp.ucsb.edu'))]))]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('a)')], []), BraceGroup('Physics Department,'), '\n', BraceGroup('University of Haifa at Oranim, Tivon 36006, Israel', TexCmd('fnote', [BraceGroup('**'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' permanent address'))])), '\n', BraceGroup('and'), '\n', BraceGroup('Physics Department,'), '\n', BraceGroup('Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('b)')], []), BraceGroup('Physics Department,'), '\n', BraceGroup('University of California, Davis, CA 95616, USA'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('c)')], []), BraceGroup('Institute for Theoretical Physics'), '\n', BraceGroup('University of California Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA'), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n'], [BraceGroup('6.1in'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('abstract'), '\nRecently, an analytic method was developed to study \nin the large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), " limit non-hermitean random matrices that are drawn from a \nlarge class of circularly symmetric non-Gaussian probability distributions, \nthus extending the existing Gaussian non-hermitean literature. One \nobtains an explicit algebraic equation for the integrated density of \neigenvalues from which the Green's function and averaged density of \neigenvalues could be calculated in a simple manner. Thus, that formalism may \nbe thought of as the non-hermitean analog of the method due to Br", "\\'", 'ezin, \nItzykson, Parisi and Zuber for analyzing hermitean non-Gaussian random \nmatrices. A somewhat surprising result is the so called \n``Single Ring" theorem, namely, that the domain of the eigenvalue \ndistribution in the complex plane is either a disk or an annulus. \nIn this paper we extend previous results and provide simple new explicit \nexpressions for the radii of the eigenvalue \ndistiobution and for the value of the eigenvalue density at the edges of \nthe eigenvalue distribution of the non-hermitean matrix in terms of moments of the eigenvalue \ndistribution of the associated hermitean matrix. We then present several numerical verifications of the \npreviously obtained analytic results for the quartic ensemble and its phase transition from a \ndisk shaped eigenvalue distribution to an annular distribution. Finally, \nwe demonstrate numerically the ``Single Ring" theorem for the sextic potential, namely, \nthe potential of lowest degree for which the ``Single Ring" theorem has non-trivial consequences.')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('10pt')]), '\n', TexCmd('vfill'), '\n', TexCmd('pagebreak'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('page'), BraceGroup('1')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\nThere has been considerable interest in random non-hermitean matrices \nin recent years. Possible applications range over several areas of\nphysics', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('nonherm, stony, fz, fz1')]), '. For some recent reviews \nsee', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('reviews')]), '.\nOne difficulty is that the eigenvalues of non-hermitean matrices invade the \ncomplex plane, and consequently, various methods developed over the years to \ndeal with random hermitean matrices are no longer applicable, as these methods\ntypically all involve exploiting the powerful constraints of analytic function\ntheory. (See in particular the paper by Br', "\\'", 'ezin, Itzykson, Parisi, and Zuber\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BIPZ')]), '.) In ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz')]), ', two of us proposed a ``method of hermitization", \nwhereby a problem involving random non-hermitean matrices can \nbe reduced to a problem involving random hermitean matrices, to which various \nstandard methods (such as the diagrammatic method', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('bzw')]), ', or the \n``renormalization group" method', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('french, rg, daz, rectangles')]), ') can be \napplied. An idea similar to the ``method of hermitization" was expressed \nindependently in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('stony')]), '.\n\nTo our knowledge, the literature on random non-hermitean \nmatrices', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('nonherm, stony')]), ' has focussed \nexclusively on Gaussian randomness. For instance, it has been known for over \nthirty years, from the work of Ginibre', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ginibre')]), ', that for the Gaussian \nprobability distribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('phi'), ') =(1/Z) ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' exp'), '~(-N', TexCmd('rmtr'), TexCmd('phi'), '^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' \n', '(here, as in the rest of this paper, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' denotes an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N', TexCmd('times'), ' N'], []), ' complex \nrandom \nmatrix with the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Narrow', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' understood), the density of \neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is uniformly distributed over a disk of radius 1 in the \ncomplex plane. \n\nAnalytic determination of the density of eigenvalues of a \nnon-Gaussian probability distribution of the form \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prob')]), '\nP(', TexCmd('phi'), ') = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' Z'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-N', TexCmd('rmtr'), ' V(', TexCmd('phi'), '^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('phi'), ')'), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '  \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' is an arbitrary polynomial of its argument, was given for the first\ntime in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '. Based on the method of hermitization, it was shown in \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' that by a simple trick, the desired density of \neigenvalues could be obtained with a minimal amount of work, by judiciously \nexploiting the existing literature on random hermitean matrices. \n\nDue to the symmetry of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ' under the transformation \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('phiarrow'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('alpha')), TexCmd('phi')], []), ', the density of eigenvalues is obviously \nrotational invariant. It was shown in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' that the class of \nprobability distributions of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ') exhibits a universal \nbehavior in the sense that whatever the polynomial ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' was, the shape of \nthe eigenvalue distribution in the complex plane was always either a disk \nor an annulus. This result was referred to in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' as the ``Single \nRing Theorem". \n\nIn a certain sense, the formalism developed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' may be \nthought of as the analog of the work of Br', "\\'", 'ezin et al. for random hermitean \nmatrices ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BIPZ')]), '; they showed how the density of eigenvalues of hermitean \nmatrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi')], []), ' taken from the probability distribution \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('varphi'), ') = (1/Z)', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' exp'), '[', '-N', TexCmd('rmtr'), ' V(', TexCmd('varphi'), ')', ']'], []), ' \nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' an arbitrary polynomial can be determined, and not \njust for the Gaussian case studied by Wigner and others', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('wigner')]), ', in which\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V=(1/2)', TexCmd('rmtr'), TexCmd('varphi'), '^2'], []), '. An important simplifying feature of the analysis in \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BIPZ')]), ' is that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('varphi'), ')'], []), ' depends only on the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi')], []), ',\nand not on the unitary matrix that diagonalizes it. In contrast, the \nprobability distribution (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ') for non-hermitean matrices depends \nexplicitly on the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['GL(N)'], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' used to diagonalize ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '=S^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', TexCmd('Lambda'), ' \nS'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' does not decouple. Remarkably however, for the Gaussian ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), ',\nGinibre ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ginibre')]), ' managed to integrate over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' explicitly and derived an\nexplicit expression for the probability distribution of the eigenvalues of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), '. Unfortunately, it is not clear how to integrate over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and derive \nthe expression for the eigenvalue probability distribution for non-Gaussian \ndistributions of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), '). In ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' this difficulty \nwas circumvented by using the method of hermitization.\n\nAs an explicit example, the case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')=2m^2', TexCmd('pdgp'), ' + g (', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^2'], []), ' \nwas studied in detail in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '.
