As should perhaps be expected in \nadvance, the following behavior in the parameter space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2, g>0'], []), ' was found: \nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2'], []), " positive, the eigenvalue distribution was disk-like (and \nnon-uniform), generalizing Ginibre's work, \nbut as ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2', TexCmd('equiv'), ' -', TexCmd('mu'), '^2'], []), ' was made more and more negative, a phase transition \nat the critical value ', TexCmd('beqast'), '\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2 = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')]), '\n', TexCmd('eeqast'), '     \noccured, after which the disk fragmented into an annulus. \nThe density of eigenvalues was calculated in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' in \ndetail.\n\nThe paper is organized as follows: In Section 2 we summarize the \n``method of hermitization" ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz')]), '. We present (without derivation) the \ngeneral algorithm for finding the density of eigenvalues associated \nwith (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ') which was developed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ', and also add some new\ninsight into the mechanism behind the ``Single Ring" theorem. We then \nformulate a novel simple criterion on the couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), " to \ndecide whether the shape of the eigenvalue distribution is a disk or an \nannulus. Finally, we discuss some generic features of the disk-annulus phase \ntransition. In particular, we prove that the Green's function associated with \nthe hermitean matrix ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' ', "(which plays an important role in the \n``hermitization algorithm'' just mentioned) is continuous through the \ndisk-annulus phase transition.\n\n\nIn Section 3 we provide simple new expressions for the outer radius ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out')], []), ' and for the inner radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in')], []), '\n', '(in the annular phase) of the eigenvalue distribution of the non-hermitean matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ', and for the corresponding boundary values \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')'], []), ' of its eigenvalue density, in terms of the moments \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [' <', TexCmd('si'), '^k> = ', TexCmd('int'), ' d', TexCmd('si'), ' ', TexCmd('si'), '^k ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad'), ' ', '(k=0, ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1, ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', ')'], []), '\nof the eigenvalue distribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ' of the hermitean matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '. Thus, we find that \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 = <', TexCmd('si'), '> '], []), '\nand \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')  = ', BraceGroup('2R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^2> - <', TexCmd('si'), '>^2'), '\\,', '.'], []), '\nWe see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2'], []), ' is simply the average of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si')], []), ', and the density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ' is inversely proportional to the \nvariance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si')], []), '. \n\n\nSimilarly, we find that in the annular phase, \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' R^2_', BraceGroup('in')), ' = ', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'))]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' '], []), '\nand \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')  = ', BraceGroup('2R_', BraceGroup('in'), '^', BraceGroup('-6'), TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-2'), '> - <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '>^2'), '\\,', '.'], []), '\nThus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R^', BraceGroup('-2'), '_', BraceGroup('in')], []), ' is simply the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' moment of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ', and the density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ' is \ninversely proportional to the variance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '.\n\n\n\nIn Section 4 we verify that the explicit analytic expressions in \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' concerning the quartic ensemble \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')=2m^2', TexCmd('pdgp'), ' + g(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^2'], []), ' are \nconsistent with the results of Section 3. We also compare these analytic \npredictions with results of Monte-Carlo simulations of the quartic ensemble \nfor various values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '. The numerical results we obtained for \nthe eigenvalue distribution in the disk phase and in the \nannular phase, as well as some quantitative features of the disk-annulus \ntransition are in good agreement with the analytic predictions in \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '. \n\n\nThe ``Single Ring Theorem" may seem surprising at first \nsight. Our explanation of why the single ring theorem is not that surprising  \nrests upon the simple argument that fragmentation of the \neigenvalue distribution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '  into several disjoint segments does not \nnecessarily imply that the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' trace out annuli \nobtained, loosely speaking, by revolving the segments of the eigenvalue \ndistribution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' into the complex plane (see the discussion in \nSection 2). In Section 5 we carry a numerical check of the ``Single Ring" \ntheorem for the sextic potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')=m^2', TexCmd('pdgp'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^2 + ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' 3'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^3 '], []), ',\nwhich is the potential of lowest degree for which the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' may split into more than a single \nsegment (in this case, two segments at the most). We generated numerically an ensemble in which the spectrum of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' is split into two separated segments, yet we found that the spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is a disk, and not a configuration\nof a disk encircled by a concentric annulus, as one would perhaps naively expect by rotating the two-segment spectrum\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' in the complex plane. \n\n\nIn the Appendix we briefly review the multi-cut phase structure of matrix \nensembles with generic ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ', and then specialize to the phase \nstructure of the sextic potential ensemble.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('pagebreak'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The Method of Hermitization and Non-Gaussian Ensembles')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\nHere we very briefly summarize the ``method of \nhermitization" ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz, fz1')]), ' in the form of an algorithm, followed by a \ngeneral discussion of the phase structure of the eigenvalue\ndistribution. \n\n\nLet us first introduce some notations and definitions. The averaged \ndensity of eigenvalues \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rho1')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(x,y) =', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N')]), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_i ', TexCmd('delta'), '(x-', TexCmd('Re'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_i)~ ', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '(y- ', TexCmd('Im'), '\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_i)', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nof the non-hermitean matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ", may be determined from the \nthe Green's function associated with ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ', namely\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('greens')]), '\nG(z,z^*)=', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N')]), ' ', TexCmd('rmtr', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' z-', TexCmd('phi'))]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' =\n', TexCmd('int'), " d^2 x'~", BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), "(x', y')", TexCmd('over'), " z-z'"), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nin terms of which', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('We use the following notational conventions:\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z=x+iy'], []), ' we define ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pa'), TexCmd('equiv', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), ' z')]), ' = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '\n', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), ' x'), ' -i', BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), ' y'), ')'], []), '\nso that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), ' z=1'], []), '. Similarly, we define\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pa'), '^', BraceGroup('*'), TexCmd('equiv', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pa'), TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('pa'), ' z^*')]), ' = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pa'), TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('pa'), ' x'), ' +\ni', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pa'), TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('pa'), ' y'), ')'], []), ', so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pa'), '^', BraceGroup('*'), 'z^*=1'], []), ' and also\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pa'), '^*(1/z)=', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '(z)'], []), '. Finally, we denote ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|z|=r'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rho11')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '(x,y) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('pi')), ' ', TexCmd('pa'), '^', BraceGroup('*'), '~G(z, z^*)', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\nThe probability distributions (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ') studied in this paper are invariant\nunder ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phiarrow'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('alpha')), TexCmd('phi')], []), ', rendering \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('radrho')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '(x,y)', TexCmd('equiv'), TexCmd('rho'), '(r)/2', TexCmd('pi'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\ncircularly invariant. Rotational invariance thus leads to a simpler form of \nthe defining formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('greens')]), ') for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G(z, z^*)'], []), ' which reads\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('circular')]), '\n', TexCmd('gam'), '(r) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' zG(z,z^*)=', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), "_0^r r'd r'~", TexCmd('rho'), "(r')", '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhence\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhocirc')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '(r) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' r'), BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('gam'), TexCmd('over'), ' dr'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nClearly, the quantity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ', which can be thought of as the integrated eigenvalue density, \nis a positive monotonically increasing function,\nwhich satisfies the obvious ``sum-rules" \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sumrules')]), '\n', TexCmd('gam'), '(0)=0 ', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('gam'), '(', TexCmd('infty'), ')=1', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nIn particular, observe that the first condition in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sumrules')]), ') insures\nthat no ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(x)', TexCmd('delta'), '(y)'], []), ' spike arises in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(x,y)'], []), ' when calculating it \nfrom (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rho11')]), ') with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G(z, z^*)'], []), ' given by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('circular')]), '), as it should be. \n\n\nIt was shown in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), " that by applying a simple trick, the desired\nGreen's function of a non-hermitean random matrix ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' could be \nobtained with a minimal amount of work, by\njudiciously exploiting the existing literature on random hermitean matrices.\nThe algorithm, according to ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ", for finding the Green's function and \nthe averaged eigenvalue density of a non-hermitean random matrix ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' \ndrawn from a non-Gaussian ensemble ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('phi'), ') = (1/Z) e^', BraceGroup('-N', TexCmd('rmtr'), ' \nV(', TexCmd('phi'), '^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('phi'), ')')], []), ' ', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ")) is as follows:\n\nStart with the Green's function", TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Of course, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' is already \nknown in the literature on chiral and rectangular block random hermitean\nmatrices for the Gaussian distribution', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('rectangles, bhz, \nbhznpb, rectangles1')]), ', as well as for non-Gaussian probability \ndistributions of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ') with an arbitrary polynomial \npotential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('cicuta, ambjorn, periwal')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('FF')]), '\nF(w) = ', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N')]), ' ', TexCmd('trn', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' w -', TexCmd('pdgp'))]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '\n', TexCmd('limits'), '_0^', TexCmd('infty', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ') d', TexCmd('si'), TexCmd('over'), ' w-', TexCmd('si'))]), ' ', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhere \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dos')]), '\n', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ') = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('trn'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mu'), ' -', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nis the averaged eigenvalue density of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '. \nThen, the desired equation for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), ' ', '(r)', TexCmd('equiv'), ' zG(z,z^*)'], []), ' is \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('final')]), '\n', TexCmd('gam', [BracketGroup('r^2~F(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gam'), '~r^2', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('gam'), ' -1'), ') -', TexCmd('gam'), ' +1')]), ' = 0', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThus, given ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' one can solve for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ' using this master equation.\n\n \nEq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('final')]), ') is an algebraic equation for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ' and thus may have \nseveral ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' dependent solutions. In constructing the \nactual ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ' one may have to match these solutions smoothly into a \nsingle function which increases monotonically from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(0)=0'], []), ' to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(', TexCmd('infty'), ')=1'], []), '. An explicit non-trivial example of such a procedure is \nthe construction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ' in the disk phase of the quartic \nensemble', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '. \n\n\nA remarkable property of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('final')]), ') is that it has only two\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '-independent solutions: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), ' =1'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '.\nSince the actual ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ' increases monotonically from \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(0)=0'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(', TexCmd('infty'), ')=1'], []), ', we immediately conclude from \nthis observation that there can be no more than a single void \nin the eigenvalue distribution. Thus, in the class of models  governed by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('phi'), ') = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' Z'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-N', TexCmd('rmtr'), ' V(', TexCmd('phi'), '^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('phi'), ')')], []), '\n', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ')), the shape of the eigenvalue \ndistribution is either a disk or an annulus, whatever \npolynomial the potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' is. This result is the ``Single Ring Theorem" of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '. \n\n\nThe ``Single Ring Theorem" may appear counter-intuitive at \nfirst sight. Indeed, consider a potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' with \nseveral wells or minima. For deep enough wells, we expect the \neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' to ``fall into \nthe wells". Thus, one might suppose that the eigenvalue \ndistribution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' to be bounded by a set of concentric \ncircles of radii ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leq'), ' r_1 < r_2 < ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' < r_', BraceGroup('n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'))], []), ', \nseparating annular regions on which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)>0'], []), ' from voids \n(annuli in which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)=0'], []), '.) A priori, it is natural to \nassume that the maximal number of such circular boundaries \nshould grow with the degree of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ', because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' may then have \nmany deep minima. Remarkably, however, according to the \n``Single Ring Theorem" the number of these \nboundaries is two at the most. \n\n\nTo reconcile this conclusion \nwith the a priori expectation just mentioned, note that while the eigenvalues \nof the hermitean matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' may split into several disjoint segments \nalong the positive real axis, this does not necessarily constrain the \neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' itself to condense into annuli. Indeed, the hermitean \nmatrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' can always be diagonalized ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp'), '=U^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('La'), '^2 U'], []), ' by a unitary \nmatrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('La'), '^2=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' diag'), '(', TexCmd('la'), '_1^2, ', TexCmd('la'), '_2^2,', TexCmd('cdots'), ',', TexCmd('la'), '_N^2),'], []), ' where \nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('la'), '_i'], []), ' are all real. This implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '=V^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('La'), ' U'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' a \nunitary matrix as well. Thus, the complex eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' are given by \nthe roots of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' det'), ' ', '(z-', TexCmd('La'), ' W)=0'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W=UV^', TexCmd('dgg')], []), '. Evidently, as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), ' \nranges over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U(N)'], []), ' ', '(which is what we expect to happen in the generic case), \nthe eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('La'), ' W'], []), ' could be smeared (in the sense that they would \nnot span narrow annuli around the circles ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|z|=|', TexCmd('la'), '_i|'], []), '.) \n\nThe last argument in favor of the ``Single Ring Theorem" \nclearly breaks down when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), ' fails to range over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U(N)'], []), ', which occurs \nwhen the unitary matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' are correlated. For example, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), '   \nmay be such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W=UV^', TexCmd('dgg')], []), ' is block diagonal, with the upper diagonal block \nbeing a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K', TexCmd('times'), ' K'], []), ' unitary diagonal matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' diag'), '(e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om'), '_1'), ', \n', TexCmd('cdots'), ' , e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om'), '_K'), ')'], []), ' ', '(and with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' a finite fraction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '). In the extreme \ncase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=N'], []), ', in which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), ' is completely diagonal, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W', TexCmd('equiv'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om')), ' = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' diag'), '(e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om'), '_1'), ', ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' , e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om'), '_N'), ')'], []), ', we see that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), ' = U^', TexCmd('dgg'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om')), TexCmd('Lambda'), ' U'], []), ' is a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' normal'), ' matrix,', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('That is,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('phi'), ', ', TexCmd('phi'), '^', TexCmd('dgg'), ']', '=0'], []), '.')]), ' with eigenvalues ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' diag'), '(e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om'), '_1'), TexCmd('la'), '_1, ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ,\ne^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('om'), '_N'), TexCmd('la'), '_N ).'], []), ' Thus, normal matrices, or partially normal matrices \n(i.e., the case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K<N'], []), "), evade the ``Single Ring'' theorem: if the \nfirst ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' eigenvalues ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('la'), '_1^2, ', TexCmd('la'), '_2^2,', TexCmd('cdots'), ',', TexCmd('la'), '_K^2'], []), ' of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' split into several disjoint segments along the positive real axis, \nthe corresponding eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' will split into concentric annuli in \nthe complex plane obtained by revolving those ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('la')], []), "-segments. Normal, \nor partially normal matrices are, of course, extremely rare in the \nensembles of non-hermitean matrices studied in this paper, and do not \naffect the ``Single Ring'' behavior of the bulk of matrices in the ensemble.\n\n\nWe end this section by showing how simple features of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' indicate \nwhether the domain of the eigenvalue distribution is a disk or an \nannulus.\nAs is well known ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('rectangles, ambjorn, periwal')]), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' a \npolynomial of degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ", the Green's function\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' is given by', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Here we assume for simplicity that the\neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' condense into a single segment ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'a,b', ']'], []), '. Discussion\nof condensation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' eigenvalues into more segments appears in\nthe Appendix.')]), ' \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('FFF')]), ' F(w)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), "V'(w)-P(w)", TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(w-a)(w-b)')]), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), ' \nwhere \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('P')]), ' P(w) = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k=-1'), '^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ' c_k~w^k', '\\,', '. ', TexCmd('eeq'), ' \nThe real \nconstants ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' a < b'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_k'], []), ' are then determined completely by the\nrequirement that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)arrow ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' w')], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' tends to infinity,\nand by the condition that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' has at most an integrable singularity as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['warrow 0'], []), '. Thus, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a>0'], []), ', inevitably ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1'), ' = 0'], []), '. However, if\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=0'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' will be determined by the asymptotic behavior for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' large. \n\nAccording to the ``Single Ring" theorem ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ', the \neigenvalue distribution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is either a disk or an annulus. \nThe behavior of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0'], []), ' turns out to be an indicator \nas to which phase of the two the system is in, as we now show:\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' A. Disk Phase:'), '~~~In the disk phase we expect that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(0)>0'], []), ", as in Ginibre's case. \nThus, from (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhocirc')]), ') ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r) = (1/r) (d', TexCmd('gam'), '/dr) ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 2 \n(d', TexCmd('gam'), '/dr^2)'], []), ' and from the first sum rule ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(0)=0'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sumrules')]), ') we \nconclude that \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('near0')]), '\n', TexCmd('gam'), '(r)', TexCmd('sim', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2')]), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), '(0) r^2\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nnear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=0'], []), '. \nTherefore, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' small, \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('final')]), ') yields \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('near00')]), '\nF(-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(0) r^4', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ' + ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', ')', TexCmd('sim'), ' - ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' r^2'), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), ' \nnamely, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)', TexCmd('sim'), ' 1/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w')])], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0'], []), ", as we could\nhave anticipated from Ginibre's case.~", TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('In the Gaussian case, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V=', TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ', we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w')]), 'F(w) = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w')]), ' - ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w -4')])], []), ', whence the roots \nof (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('final')]), ') are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '=0, 1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r^2'], []), '. We note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '=0'], []), ' is \nunphysical, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '=r^2'], []), ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' i.e.,'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G=z^*'], []), ") corresponds to Ginibre's \ndisk", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ginibre')]), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '=1'], []), ' is the solution outside the disk.')]), ' This means\nthat in the disk phase we must set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=0'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FFF')]), '). Consequently, in the \ndisk phase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' does not vanish. We can do even better: paying \nattention to the coefficients in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FFF')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('P')]), ') (with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=0'], []), ') we \nimmediately obtain from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('near00')]), ') that \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rho0')]), '\nc_', BraceGroup('-1'), ' = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(0)', TexCmd('over'), ' 2 b')]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' B. Annular Phase:'), ' In the annular phase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ' must clearly  \nvanish identically in the inner void of the annulus.  Thus, \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('final')]), ') implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' cannot have a pole at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=0'], []), ', and therefore from \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FFF')]), ') we must have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('ab')]), '=0'], []), '. Thus, the annulus must \narise for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1'), ' = 0'], []), ' ', '(the other possible solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=0, c_', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('neq'), '\n0'], []), ' leads to a disk configuration with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '=0'], []), ' only at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=0'], []), ', as we just \ndiscussed.)  \n\n\nThus, to summarize, in the disk phase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' has the form \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fdisk')]), '\nF_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(w)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), "V'(w)-(", TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(0)', TexCmd('over'), ' 2b'))]), '\\,', 'w^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' + c_0 + c_1 ~w \n+', TexCmd('cdots'), ' + c_', BraceGroup('p-2'), '~w^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ')', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w(w-b)')]), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhile in the annular phase it has the form\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fannulus')]), '\nF_', BraceGroup('annulus'), '(w)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), "V'(w)-(c_0 + c_1 ~w +", TexCmd('cdots'), ' \n+c_', BraceGroup('p-2'), '~w^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ')', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(w-a)(w-b)')]), '\\,', '. ', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nHaving determined ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' in this way, i.e., having determined the various unknown parameters \nin (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fdisk')]), ') or in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fannulus')]), '), we substitute it into (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('final')]), ') and \nfind ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G(z, z^*)'], []), '. We can thus calculate the density of eigenvalues ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), ' explicitly \nfor an arbitrary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), '. \n\nWe now turn to the disk-annulus phase transition. An important feature of this transition is that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' is continuous\nthrough it. To see this we argue as follows: By tuning the couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ', we can induce a phase transition from the \ndisk phase into the annular phase,\nor vice versa. Note, of course, that we can parametrize any point in the disk phase either by the set of couplings in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' or by the set of parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'c_', BraceGroup('-1'), ', c_0,  ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' c_', BraceGroup('p-2'), '; b', '\\}'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fdisk')]), '). The ``coordinate transformation" between\nthese two sets of parameters is encoded in the asymptotic behavior of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), '. Similarly, \nwe can parametrize any point in the annular phase either by the set of couplings in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' or by the set of parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'c_0, c_1 ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' c_', BraceGroup('p-2'), '; a, b', '\\}'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fannulus')]), '). \nDue to the one-to-one relation (in a given phase, once we have established it is the stable one) between the couplings\nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' and the parameters in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w) - ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), " V'(w)"], []), ' ', '(namely, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_n'], []), "'s and the locations of the branch points of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), '), we can \ndescribe the disk-annulus transition in terms of the latter parameters (instead of the couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), '). Clearly, the \ntransition point is reached from the disk phase when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(0) = 0'], []), ', that is, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fdisk')]), ') vanishes:\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cminus1crit')]), '\nc_', BraceGroup('-1'), '^', BraceGroup('crit'), ' = 0', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nSimilarly, the transition point is reached from the annular phase when the lower branch point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fannulus')]), ') vanishes. \nThus, e.g., in a transition from the disk phase into the annular phase, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(w)'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fdisk')]), ') would cross-over \ncontinuously into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('annulus'), '(w)'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fannulus')]), ') through a critical form \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fcrit')]), '\nF_', BraceGroup('crit'), '(w)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), 'V_', BraceGroup('crit'), "'(w)-(c^", BraceGroup('crit'), '_0 + c^', BraceGroup('crit'), '_1 ~w +', TexCmd('cdots'), ' \n+c^', BraceGroup('crit'), '_', BraceGroup('p-2'), '~w^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ')', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w(w-b^', BraceGroup('crit'), ')')]), '\\,', '.', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\nThe continuity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' through the transition was demonstrated explicitly \nin ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' for the quartic ensemble ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ') = 2m^2 ', TexCmd('pdgp'), ' + g(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^2'], []), ' \n', '(see also Section 4). \n\nThis discussion obviously generalizes to cases when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), '\nhas multiple cuts, which correspond to condensation of the\neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' into many segments. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=0'], []), ' is a branch\npoint of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ', that is, if the lowest cut extends to the\norigin, we are in the disk phase,\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fdisk1')]), '\nF_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(w)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), "V'(w)-(c_", BraceGroup('-1'), 'w^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' + c_0 + c_1 ~w \n+', TexCmd('cdots'), ' + c_', BraceGroup('p-2'), '~w^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ')', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w(w-b_1)', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', '(w-b_n)')]), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0< b_1 < ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' < b_n '], []), '. The relation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rho0')]), ')\nthen generalizes to \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rho00')]), '\nc_', BraceGroup('-1'), ' = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '(0) ', TexCmd('over'), ' 2 (-1)^', BraceGroup('n+1'), ' ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k =1'), '^n b_k'))]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' must be real we conclude that such a configuration\nexists only for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' odd. \n\nIf the lowest branch \npoint in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' is positive, we are in the annular phase with \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fannulus1')]), '\nF_', BraceGroup('annulus'), '(w)=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), "V'(w)-(c_0 + c_1 ~w +", TexCmd('cdots'), ' \n+c_', BraceGroup('p-2'), '~w^', BraceGroup('p-2'), ')', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(w-a)(w-b_1)', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', '(w-b_n)')]), '\\,', '. ', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThe phase transition would occur when the couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' are tuned \nsuch that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(w)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('annulus'), '(w)'], []), ' match continuously, as \nwas described in the previous paragraph.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('pagebreak'), '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Boundaries and Boundary Values')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\nRemarkably, with a minimal amount of effort, and based on the mere\ndefinition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' ', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FF')]), '), which we repeat here for convenience)\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('FFrep')]), '\nF(w) = ', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N')]), ' ', TexCmd('trn', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' w -', TexCmd('pdgp'))]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '\n', TexCmd('limits'), '_0^', TexCmd('infty', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ') d', TexCmd('si'), TexCmd('over'), ' w-', TexCmd('si'))]), ' ', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '     \nwe are able to derive simple expressions for the location of the \nboundaries of the eigenvalue distribution and also for the \nboundary values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), ' in terms of the moments of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ', which, we remind the reader, \nis the density of eigenvalues for a hermitean matrix problem. \n\nTo this end it is useful to rewrite our master formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('final')]), ') for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), ' ', '(r)'], []), ' as \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fin')]), '\nw F(w) = ', TexCmd('gam'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwith \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('w')]), '\nw = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gam'), ' r^2', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('gam'), ' -1'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\nWe start with the outer edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=R_', BraceGroup('out')], []), ' ', '(either in the disk phase or\nin the annular phase.) Near the outer edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamarrow'), ' 1-'], []), ', and thus \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['warrow -', TexCmd('infty')], []), '. We therefore expand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' in powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/w'], []), ' and \nobtain from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FFrep')]), ')-(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('w')]), ')\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('finsum1'), BraceGroup('<', TexCmd('si'), '>', TexCmd('over'), ' r^2')]), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gam'), ' -1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('gam'), ' r^4 '), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^2> + ', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('gam'), ' -1)^2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' \n', TexCmd('gam'), '^2 r^6 '), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^3> + ', TexCmd('cdots'), '  = ', TexCmd('gam'), '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('eeq'), '  \nwhere\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('moments')]), '\n<', TexCmd('si'), '^k> = ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_0^', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ') ', TexCmd('si'), '^k d', TexCmd('si'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nare the moments of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ' ', '(which is of course normalized to 1.)\nFor the class of models we are interested in here, all the \nmoments ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('si'), '^k>,~ k', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ' are clearly finite.', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')\n', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', '(1/', TexCmd('pi'), ')', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Im'), ' F(', TexCmd('si'), ' -i', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ' is supported along a finite segment \n(or segments), and its singularity at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si'), '=0'], []), ' is no worse than \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1/2')], []), '.')]), ' Thus, at the outer edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=R_', BraceGroup('out')], []), ' ', '(where of \ncourse ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ') =1'], []), '), all terms with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('si'), '^k>,', '\\,', '  k', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2'], []), ' drop out of \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('finsum1')]), ') and we obtain\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rout')]), '\nR_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 = <', TexCmd('si'), '> ', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nNamely, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2'], []), ' is simply the first moment of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), '.\n\nWe now calculate the boundary value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), '. Approaching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out')], []), '\nfrom the inside, we substitute ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), ' = 1-f'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r^2 = R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 (1-', TexCmd('delta'), ')'], []), '\n', '(with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f, ', TexCmd('delta'), ' <<1'], []), ') in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('finsum1')]), '). After some work we obtain\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f = ', BraceGroup('<', TexCmd('si'), '>^2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^2> -<', TexCmd('si'), '>^2'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), ' + ', TexCmd('cO'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('delta'), '^2)'], []), ', namely,\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gamf')]), '\n', TexCmd('gam'), ' = 1 - ', BraceGroup('<', TexCmd('si'), '>^2 ', TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^2> -<', TexCmd('si'), '>^2'), '\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('delta'), ' + ', TexCmd('cO'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('delta'), '^2)', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThus, from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r) = 2 (d', TexCmd('gam'), '/dr^2)'], []), ' ', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhocirc')]), ')) and \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rout')]), ') we find \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhoout')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')  = ', BraceGroup('2R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^2> - <', TexCmd('si'), '>^2'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThe density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ' is inversely proportional to the variance\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si')], []), '! \n\nFor the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ' under consideration here, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('si'), '^2>'], []), ', \nand consequently ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ', are always finite. Outside the\nboundary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), ' vanishes identically, of course, and thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), ' \nalways ``falls off a cliff" at the boundary, for all probability \ndistributions of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ') with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' polynomial. \nIt would be thus interesting to study circularly invariant matrix\nensembles ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' such that the eigenvalue distribution \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' has a finite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('si'), '>'], []), ' but an infinite \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('si'), '^2>'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ' would vanish. This would naturally raise \nthe question whether in such situations, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), ' behaves universally \nnear the edge (that is, if near the edge it vanishes like ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ' - \nr)^', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' being some universal exponent). \nWe do not pursue this question further in this paper.\n\nWe now turn to the annular phase, and focus on the inner edge \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=R_', BraceGroup('in')], []), ' of the annulus. According to the discussion at the end of \nSection 2 (see Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fannulus')]), ') and the discussion above it), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a>0'], []), ' in \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FFF')]), '), and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' is analytic in the domain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|w|<a'], []), '. \nExpanding (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FFrep')]), ') in powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ', we obtain from \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fin')]), ') \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fin2'), BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('gam'), TexCmd('over'), ' r^2')]), ' - ', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('si'))]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' = \nw', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('si'), '^2')]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' +\nw^2', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('si'), '^3')]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' + ', TexCmd('cdots'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nA little above the inner radius, into the annulus, \nclearly ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), ' arrow 0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['warrow 0-'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('w')]), '). \nThus, setting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=0'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fin2')]), ') we obtain\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rin'), BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' R^2_', BraceGroup('in'))]), ' = ', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'))]), TexCmd('rangle'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R^', BraceGroup('-2'), '_', BraceGroup('in')], []), ' is simply the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' moment of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), '.\n\nWe can now calculate the boundary value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')'], []), '. Near the inner\nedge we parametrize ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r^2= R^2_', BraceGroup('in'), ' ', '(1+', TexCmd('delta'), ')'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' <<1'], []), ' ', '(and of \ncourse, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), ' << 1'], []), ' to begin with.) Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ' obviously \nvanishes \nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si'), '<a'], []), ', all moments ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-k'), '>'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fin2')]), ') are finite. Thus, \ndropping all terms with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-k'), '>, k', TexCmd('geq'), ' 3'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fin2')]), '), we obtain\nafter some work\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gamin')]), '\n', TexCmd('gam'), ' = R^', BraceGroup('-4'), '_', BraceGroup('in'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-2'), '> - <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '>^2'), ' + ', TexCmd('cO'), ' \n', '(', TexCmd('delta'), '^2)', '\\,', '. ', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nIt then follows from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhocirc')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rin')]), ') that \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhoin')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')  = ', BraceGroup('2R_', BraceGroup('in'), '^', BraceGroup('-6'), TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-2'), '> - <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '>^2'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThe density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ' is inversely proportional to the variance\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\\,', '.'], []), '\n', '\nFrom (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FFF')]), ') (or (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fannulus')]), ') ) we learn that in the annular \nphase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('annulus'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ') ', TexCmd('equiv', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('pi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Im')]), ' F(', TexCmd('si'), '-i', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')\n= ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' polynomial'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('si'), ' - a)(b - ', TexCmd('si'), ')')]), '\\,', ',~0<a<', TexCmd('si'), '<b'], []), ' ', '(and \nvanishes elsewhere.) Thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<1/', TexCmd('si'), '^k> ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('a'), '^', BraceGroup('b'), '\n', '(', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')/', TexCmd('si'), '^k)d', TexCmd('si'), '\\,', ',~k=1,2'], []), ' are finite. Therefore, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('annulus'), '(', TexCmd('si'), ')'], []), ' jumps from zero (in the inner void of the annulus)\nto a finite value at the inner edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in')], []), '. Note, however, \nthat when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['aarrow 0'], []), ', that is, in the annular to disk transition,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<1/', TexCmd('si'), '>'], []), ' remains finite, but ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<1/', TexCmd('si'), '^2>'], []), ' diverges like ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('a')])], []), '. (For a \nparticular example see Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('momentsannQ')]), ').) \nThus, from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rin')]), ') we see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('innner'), ' ', '(a=0)'], []), ', the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' critical'), ' \ninner \nradius, is finite. The annulus starts up with a finite inner radius. Also,\nin this limit, we see from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoin')]), ') that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')'], []), ' vanishes \nlike ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('a')])], []), '. As we approach the annulus-disk transition, the \ndiscontinuity in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), ' at the (finite) inner edge disappears. \n\n\nWe saw at the end of Section 2 (see Eqs. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fdisk')]), ')-(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fcrit')]), ')) that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' is continuous through the disk-annulus phase \ntransition. Thus, our master formula ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['wF(w)=', TexCmd('gam'), ' '], []), ' to determine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gam'), '(r)'], []), ' ', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fin')]), ')) is also continuous through the \ntransition. Consequently, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r) = (1/r) (d', TexCmd('gam'), '/dr)'], []), ' must remain continuous through the disk-annulus transition, and\nhas (at the transition) the universal behavior described in the previous paragraph.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('pagebreak'), '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Phase Transitions in the Quartic Ensemble')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\nThe disk-annulus transition in the quartic ensemble \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('quartic')]), '\nV(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ') = 2 m^2', TexCmd('pdgp'), ' + g (', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^2\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwas studied in detail in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '. The annular eigenvalue \ndistribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('annular'), '(r)'], []), ' and the disk eigenvalue distribution \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(r)'], []), ' for this ensemble were calculated explicitly in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '.\nAccording to the expressions given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ', as the critical point is \napproached from the annular phase, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('annular'), '(r)'], []), ' behaves \nprecisely as described in the paragraph following Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoin')]), ') at the \nend of the previous section (see also Eq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoann')]), ') below, at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=', TexCmd('mu'), '_c'], []), '.) \nAlso according to ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ', as the critical point is approached from the \ndisk phase, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(r)'], []), ' gets completely depleted inside a region of \nradius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), '_c)'], []), ' ', '(remaining continuous at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=R_', BraceGroup('in'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), '_c)'], []), '. \nSee Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhodiskcrit')]), ') below.) Thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), ' for the quartic ensemble \nis continuous through the disk-annulus transition. \n\nIn this section we verify the expressions (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rout')]), '), (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoout')]), '), \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rin')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoin')]), ') for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in')], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')'], []), ' for the quartic ensemble (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('quartic')]), ') against the \nexplicit expressions for these quantities given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ', and also \nprovide ample numerical results concerning the disk phase, the annular \nphase, and the transition between them, in support of the analytical results.\nIn what follows we have omitted many technical details that can be found in \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The Disk Phase')]), '\n', '\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2>-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), ' the density of eigenvalues is a disk.\nAccording to ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' we have\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('FQ')]), '\nF(w)=m^2 + gw - (', BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('over'), ' w'), ' + g)~', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w (w-b)')]), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwith \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('parameters1')]), '\nc = ', BraceGroup('2m^2 +', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('m^4 + 6g')]), TexCmd('over'), ' 3'), ', ', TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '  and')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' b=', BraceGroup('-2m^2 + 2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('m^4 + 6g')]), TexCmd('over'), ' 3g'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\nAccording to Eqs. (5.8) and (5.9) in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ', the eigenvalue density \nin this phase is \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhodisk')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(r) = 2m^2 + 4gr^2 + 2', '[', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sgn'), '~(', BraceGroup('b', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), '-r^2)', ']', ' ', '~\n', BraceGroup('bc^2-(m^2+2gr^2)', '[', '1+2(m^2r^2+gr^4)', ']', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('[', '1+2(m^2r^2+gr^4)', ']', '^2 - 4bc^2r^2')])), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\ninside a disk of radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out')], []), ', where \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('routdisk')]), '\nR_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 = ', BraceGroup('bc^2 - 2m^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2g'), ' = ', BraceGroup('(m^4+6g)^', BraceGroup('3/2'), '-m^2(m^4 + 9g)', TexCmd('over'), ' 27 g^2'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThus, from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhodisk')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('routdisk')]), ') we have ', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('It is \nstraight forward to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sgn'), '~(', BraceGroup('b', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), '-R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2)=-1'], []), ' in\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhodisk')]), '): just substitute ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^4 = A^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' cos'), '^2 ', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['6g = A^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sin'), '^2 ', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' and obtain that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 - ', BraceGroup('b', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), ' = \n(A^3/108g^2) (1-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' cos'), TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', ')^3'], []), '.')]), ' \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhoroutdisk')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ') = ', BraceGroup('4g(bc^2 - 2m^2)', TexCmd('over'), ' 2g - bc^2(bc^2 - 2m^2)'), ' = \n', BraceGroup('4gR_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 1-2R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 ( g R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 + m^2)'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\nThese results should be compared with the predictions of Section 3. \nFrom (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FQ')]), ') we can read-off the density of eigenvalues \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('sigma'), ') = (1/', TexCmd('pi'), ')', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Im'), ' F(', TexCmd('sigma'), ' - i', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' as\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dosQ')]), '\n', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', ') = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('pi')), ' ', '(', BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('sigma')), ' + g)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '\n', '(b-', TexCmd('sigma'), ')')]), TexCmd('eeq'), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('leq'), ' b'], []), ', and zero elsewhere. We can readily check that \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dosQ')]), ') is properly normalized to 1. \n\nThe first two moments of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dosQ')]), ') are \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('1momentdiskQ')]), '\n<', TexCmd('si'), '> = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(', BraceGroup('b', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')^2 ( c + ', BraceGroup('gb', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ') = \n', BraceGroup('(m^4+6g)^', BraceGroup('3/2'), '-m^2(m^4 + 9g)', TexCmd('over'), ' 27 g^2'), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nand\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('2momentdiskQ')]), '\n<', TexCmd('si'), '^2> = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 8'), '(', BraceGroup('b', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')^4 ( ', BraceGroup('8c', TexCmd('over'), ' b'), ' + 5g) =\n', BraceGroup('27g^2 + 18gm^4 + 2m^8 -2m^2 (6g + m^4)^', BraceGroup('3/2'), TexCmd('over'), ' 54g^3'), ' ', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\nThus, \n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('variance')]), '\n', '&&<', TexCmd('si'), '^2> - <', TexCmd('si'), ' >^2 = -', BraceGroup('b^3', TexCmd('over'), ' 256'), '[', '4 b c^2  + bg (b^2 g - 10) + 4 c ( b^2 g -4)', ']', TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n ', '&=& ', BraceGroup('297g^3 + 108 g^2 m^4 -18 g m^8 -4m^', BraceGroup('12'), ' -2m^2(9g -2m^4)(6g + m^4)^', BraceGroup('3/2'), TexCmd('over'), ' 1458 g^4'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\n', '\nComparing (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('routdisk')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('1momentdiskQ')]), ') we immediately verify \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rout')]), '), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R^2_', BraceGroup('out'), ' = <', TexCmd('si'), '>'], []), '. After some additional work, using \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('variance')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('routdisk')]), ') in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoout')]), '), we can see that \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoout')]), '), namely, that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ') = 2 R^2_', BraceGroup('out'), '/(<', TexCmd('si'), '^2>-<', TexCmd('si'), '>^2)'], []), ', coincides with (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoroutdisk')]), '). \n\n\n', TexCmd('subsubsection', [BraceGroup('Numerical Results for the Disk Dhase')]), ' \n', '\n', '\nWe have generated numerically random matrix ensembles corresponding to the \nquartic potential (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('quartic')]), ') in the disk phase, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2=1'], []), ' fixed and \nfor various values of the coupling ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' ', '(and for various sizes of matrices),\nand measured ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(r)'], []), ' for these realizations. \n\n\nThe generation of the matrices was done by a standard Metropolis \nMonte Carlo approach.  A random change had been suggested in the real and \nimaginary parts of one of the elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' and then the change in \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('phi'), ')'], []), " was evaluated.  This ``move'' was accepted unconditionally if \n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' were decreased, and with probability ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('Delta'), ' V')], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' were \nincreased.  \nGeneral theorems on Monte Carlo then guaranteed that the resulting \nprobability distribution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' was the desired one.  After the \nmatrices were generated, their eigenvalues were determined with a standard \nsolver from the LAPACK library.  We tuned the size of the suggested\nchanges in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' so that the acceptance rate was about one--half, and\nmonitored the equilibration and autocorrelation times to ensure our\nstarting configuration had evolved properly and error bars have were \naccurate. In particular, the local changes in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' made the matrices \ncorrelated over some number of random changes, however, local changes \nalso allowed one to employ various tricks to evaluate the change in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' \nrapidly.\n\n\nIn Figure 1 we display our numerical results for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('disk'), ' ', '(r)'], []), ' for \n128x128 dimensional matrices, and compare them to the analytical large-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' \nresult (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhodisk')]), ') of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '. (As a trivial check of our numerical \ncode, we also included in this figure the results for the gaussian (Ginibre) \nensemble.)\n\n\nEvidently, the agreement between the numerical and the analytical \nresults is good. Note the finite-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' effects near the edge of the disk. \n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The Annular Phase')]), '\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2 <-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), ', the stable eigenvalue distribution is annular. \nFor convenience, let us switch notations according to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2=-', TexCmd('mu'), '^2'], []), ', and also \nwrite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), '.\n\nAccording to ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ' we have \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('FANN')]), '\nF(w)=m^2 + gw - g~', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(w-a) (w-b)')]), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwith \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('parameters2')]), '\na=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'), ' -', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'))]), ', ', TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '  and')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' \nb=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'), ' +', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'))]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nWe see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a= (2/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4)(', TexCmd('mu'), '^2-', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2)'], []), ' which is positive for \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2>', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2'], []), ', as it should be, by definition.\n\n\nAccording to Eqs. (5.16) - (5.19) in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), ', the eigenvalue density in \nthis phase is \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhoann')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('annulus'), ' ', '(r) = 8g(r^2 -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2g'), ')= \n8g(r^2 -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4'), ')\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\ninside an annulus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in'), TexCmd('leq'), ' r', TexCmd('leq'), ' R_', BraceGroup('out')], []), ', where\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ranin')]), '\nR_', BraceGroup('in'), '^2=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2 + ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4-2g')]), TexCmd('over'), ' 2g'), ' = \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2 + ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4-', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4')]), TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '^4_c'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nand \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ranout')]), '\nR_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'), ' = ', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('mu'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThus, we see immediately that \n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhoannbound')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ') &=& 4', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4-', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4')]), TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ') &=& 4', TexCmd('mu'), '^2', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\nNote that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')=0'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=', TexCmd('mu'), '_c'], []), ', as expected. Also note that \nthe critical annulus has a finite inner radius: \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in'), '^2 (', TexCmd('mu'), '_c) = 1/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2 > 0 '], []), '. \n\nWe now compare these results with the predictions of Section 3. From \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FANN')]), ') we read-off the density of eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ': \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dosQFANN')]), '\n', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', ') = ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('pi')), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('sigma'), ' -a ) (b-', TexCmd('sigma'), ')')]), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a', TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('leq'), ' b'], []), ', and zero elsewhere. We can check that \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dosQFANN')]), ') is properly normalized to 1. \n\nThe relevant moments of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dosQFANN')]), ') are \n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('momentsannQ')]), '\n<', TexCmd('si'), '> &=& ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(', BraceGroup('a+b', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')(', BraceGroup('b-a', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')^2 = \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'), TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n<', TexCmd('si'), '^2> &=& ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(', BraceGroup('b-a', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ')^4 ', '[', '(', BraceGroup('b+a', TexCmd('over'), ' b-a'), ')^2 + ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), ']', ' = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4', TexCmd('over'), ' g^2'), ' + ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2g'), TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n<', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('si')), '> &=& ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('b')]), '-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('a')]), ')^2 = ', TexCmd('mu'), '^2 - ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4 - 2g')]), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and ')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n<', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('si'), '^2'), '> &=& ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('b')]), '-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('a')]), ')^2', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('ab')])), ' = \ng', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^2 - ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4 - 2g')]), TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4 - 2g')])), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\n', '\nComparing (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ranin')]), '), (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ranout')]), ') and the first and third equations in \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('momentsannQ')]), '), we verify (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rout')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rin')]), ') straightforwardly. \n\nFurther, we find from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('momentsannQ')]), ') that \n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('variances')]), '\n<', TexCmd('si'), '^2> - <', TexCmd('si'), '>^2 &=& ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2g'), TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('hfill'), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n<', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('si'), '^2'), '> - <', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('si')), ' >^2 &=& g-2', TexCmd('mu'), '^4 +', TexCmd('mu'), '^2 ', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('mu'), '^4-3g', TexCmd('over'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4-2g')])), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\nThus, comparing with (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoannbound')]), ') we find that \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [' ', BraceGroup('2R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2', TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^2> - <', TexCmd('si'), '>^2'), ' = 4', TexCmd('mu'), '^2 = ', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('out'), ')'], []), ' \nand \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [BraceGroup('2R_', BraceGroup('in'), '^', BraceGroup('-6'), TexCmd('over'), ' <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-2'), '> - <', TexCmd('si'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '>^2'), ' = 4', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4-', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4')]), ' = \n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(R_', BraceGroup('in'), ')', '\\,', ','], []), ' \nand verify (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoout')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoin')]), ') for the annular phase.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsubsection', [BraceGroup('Numerical Results for the Annular Phase')]), '\n', '\nIn Figures 2.a-2.c we display our numerical results for \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('annulus'), ' ', '(r)'], []), ' for matrices of various sizes, \nand compare them to the analytical large-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' result (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoann')]), ') of \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '. In these figures we hold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2=0.5'], []), ' fixed, and increase ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' \nfrom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.025'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.1'], []), TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Here we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2= 0.5 = \n', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2/2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), '. Thus increasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' as indicated in the text brings us \ncloser to the disk-annulus phase transition.')]), '.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The Disk-Annulus Phase Transition')]), '\n', '\nThe phase boundary separating the disk phase and the annular phase \nin the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2-g'], []), ' plane is the curve ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2 = -', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), '. \n\nConsider approaching this boundary from within the disk phase by setting \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2=-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')]), ' + ', TexCmd('delta')], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' positive and small. Then, \nusing (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('parameters1')]), '), we find to first order in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=', TexCmd('delta'), '/2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b=2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(2/g)')]), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '/g'], []), '.\nIn particular, at the phase boundary itself ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=0'], []), ', \nin accordance with (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cminus1crit')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fcrit')]), '). It was shown in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fz1')]), '\nthat as one approaches the critical point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2 = -', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), ' from the disk \nphase, the density of eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' approches the particularly simple \ncritical configuration \n\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rhodiskcrit')]), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('crit'), ' ', '(r) = ', '\\{', TexNamedEnv('array', [' 0', TexCmd('quad'), ' ,', TexCmd('quad'), ' r^2<1/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')]), '\\,', '\\,', '\n', BraceGroup(), '\n8g (r^2 - ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])), ') ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ,', TexCmd('quad'), ' 1/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')]), '<r^2<', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2/g')]), '\\,', ',\n'], [BraceGroup('c')]), '\n.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThus, as we decrease \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' to zero, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('disk'), '(r)'], []), ' ', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhodisk')]), ')) becomes increasingly \ndepleted inside the disk ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r^2< b(', TexCmd('delta'), ')/4'], []), ', reaching complete depletion at \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '=0'], []), ', at \nwhich point the disk breaks into an annulus. We also note that at the phase \nboundary (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FQ')]), ') reads \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('FQcrit')]), '\nF(w)=-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')]), ' + gw - g~', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w (w-2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'))]), ')')]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nConsider now approaching the phase boundary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2 = -', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), ' from within the \nannular phase.  Thus, we set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')]), ' + ', TexCmd('delta')], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '\npositive and small. Then, since all the expressions in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('parameters2')]), ') are\nlinear in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2'], []), ', we find that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=', TexCmd('delta'), '/g'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b=2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(2/g)')]), ' + ', TexCmd('delta'), '/g'], []), '.\nIn particular, at the phase boundary itself ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a=0'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b=1/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), '. \nTherefore, at the phase boundary (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FANN')]), ') reads \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [' F(w)=-', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')]), ' + gw - g~', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w (w-2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('over'), ' g'))]), ')')]), '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhich coincides with (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FQcrit')]), '). Thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' ', '(and consequently, the \neigenvalue density of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('phi')], []), ') is also continuous at the transition,\nin accordance with (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fcrit')]), ').\n\nNote from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ranin')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ranout')]), ') that at the transition \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in'), '^2=1/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2=1/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), ' is ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' finite'), ', and coincides \nwith the radius (squared) of the depleted region in the disk configuration \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhodiskcrit')]), '). Right at the transition, the disk breaks into an annulus with a finite hole! Note also that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 = 2/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2 = \n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2/g')])], []), ", which coincides with the disk's ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2'], []), '  \nat the phase boundary. Thus, at the phase boundary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2=', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2'], []), ' \n', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhoann')]), ') coincides with (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rhodiskcrit')]), '), namely, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(r)'], []), '\nis continuous at the transition from the disk phase to the annular phase.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsubsection', [BraceGroup('Numerical Simulation of the Disk-Annulus Phase Transition')]), '\n', '\nWe have measured the density of eigenvalues \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(r)'], []), ' of matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' of size 128x128, taken from the \nthe quartic ensemble with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2=0.5'], []), ' and for \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g = 0.025, 0.05, 0.1, 0.125, 0.15'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.175'], []), '. The results are \ndisplayed on Figure 3. \n\nFor these values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ', we start in the annular phase \nat the lowest value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '. For our set of parameters we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2= 0.5 = \n', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2/2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), '. Thus, increasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' ', '(while keeping ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^2'], []), ' fixed at \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.5'], []), ') brings us closer to the disk-annulus phase transition, which occurs \n(at large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ') at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_c=0.125'], []), '. Increasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' \nbeyond that, puts us into the disk phase.  \n\nThe first three profiles on the right in Figure 3 belong to the annular phase. \nTheir behavior is consistent with our discussion in Section 4.2 of the \nannular phase. Indeed, as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' increases towards the transition point at \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_c=0.125'], []), ', these three graphs exhibit the expected decrease of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R^2_', BraceGroup('in'), ' = (', TexCmd('mu'), '^2 + ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '^4-', TexCmd('mu'), '^4_c')]), ')/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4'], []), ' ', '\\,', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ranin')]), '), \nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_c^2=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2g')])], []), ') and the decrease of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^2 = 2', TexCmd('mu'), '^2/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c^4'], []), ' ', '\\,', '(Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ranout')]), ')).\n\n\nThe critical density profile, corresponding to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_c=0.125'], []), ', is the fourth profile (from the right). For our choice of \nparameters, the theoretical boundary radii of the critical annulus, i.e., at \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=0.125'], []), ', are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('in'), '^', BraceGroup('crit'), ' = 1/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')])], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('out'), '^', BraceGroup('crit'), '=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '/', TexCmd('mu'), '_c=2'], []), '.
