These boundary values fit nicely with \nthe features of the critical profile in Figure 3.\n\nFinally, the last two profiles in Figure 3 have pronounced tails extending \nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=0'], []), ' and thus belong to the disk phase.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('pagebreak'), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Phase Transitions in the Sixth Order Potential and the ``Single Ring" Theorem')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\nThe sextic potential \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), '\nV(', TexCmd('phi'), '^', TexCmd('dgg'), TexCmd('phi'), ') = m^2 ', TexCmd('pdgp'), ' +', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^2 + ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' 3'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')^3', '\\,', '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nis the potential of lowest degree in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prob')]), ') for which the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' may split into more then a single \nsegment. In fact, it is easy to see that there can be at most two eigenvalue segments in the spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '.\n\n\nThe qualitative features of the support of the eigenvalue density \nassociated with (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), ') can be deduced by moving the cubic \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(x) = m^2 x + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ' x^2 + ', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('over'), ' 3'), ' x^3'], []), '\naround in the plane (i.e., by varying its couplings, fixing, say ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=1'], []), '), \nand concentrating on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), '. It is obvious from such considerations that there are three \nqualitatively different phases in the spectrum\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '. In two of the phases the eigenvalues ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_i'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' live in a single segment. In one of these single \nsegment phases, the segment includes the origin (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('leq'), ' s', TexCmd('leq'), ' a'], []), '), but in the other it does not (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<a', TexCmd('leq'), ' s ', TexCmd('leq'), ' b'], []), '). \nFollowing the general discussion in the last part of Section 2, we would \nexpect that the spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' itself is a disk in the first case, and an \nannulus in the second case. \n\n\nIn the third phase of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ', there are two \nsegments, one of which hits the origin (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '0', TexCmd('leq'), ' s ', TexCmd('leq'), ' a', '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('bigcup'), '\\{', 'b', TexCmd('leq'), ' s ', TexCmd('leq'), ' c', '\\}', ').'], []), ' ', '(There is no two-segment phase of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' which \ndoes not include the origin.) Thus, according to the discussion in the \nlast part of Section 2, the non-hermitean matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is expected to be in \nthe disk phase in this case (rather than having its eigenvalue fill in a disk \nsurrounded by a concentric annulus), in accordance with the ``Single Ring" \ntheorem. \n\n\nIn this short section we limit our discussion to the two-segment phase of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '. (A rather detailed sketch of the analytical conditions that \ndetermine the whole phase structure of the sextic ensemble (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), ") is \ngiven in the Appendix.) Our purpose here is to demonstrate numerically \nthe ``Single Ring'' Theorem for the eigenvalue distribution of matrices \n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' taken from the sextic ensemble (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), ').  To this end, we have \nto identify points well within the phase in which the eigenvalues of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' split into two segments. \n\n\n\nWe used the formalism of the Appendix to choose two ensembles in the \ntwo-segment phase of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ', for which we verified that the \neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' formed a disk. The results for these ensembles are \ndisplayed in Figures 4 and 5. \n\n\nFigure 4 shows the scatter plot of the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' together with \nthe density of eigenvalues ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' for (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), ') with \ncouplings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2=7.372, ', TexCmd('lambda'), '=-6.116 '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=1.372'], []), '. As can be seen on the \nright part of Figure 4, for these couplings, the eigenvalues of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' live in two separated segments: \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '0', TexCmd('leq'), ' s ', TexCmd('leq'), ' a=1', '\\}', TexCmd('bigcup'), '\\{', 'b=2', TexCmd('leq'), ' s ', TexCmd('leq'), ' c=3', '\\}'], []), '. The solid line there is \nthe large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' theoretical curve, which was plotted \naccording to the analysis we have described in the Appendix (see the \ndiscussion following (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('2cutdisk')]), ')). Evidently, the spectrum of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' is a disk, despite the split support of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)'], []), ", in accordance \nwith the ``Single Ring'' Theorem.\n\n\n\n\n\nFigure 5 is similar to Figure 4, but for (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), ') with \ncouplings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2=6.403, ', TexCmd('lambda'), '=4.184'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=0.713'], []), ', for which the \neigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' live in the segments ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '0', TexCmd('leq'), ' s ', TexCmd('leq'), ' a=1', '\\}', TexCmd('bigcup'), '\n', '\\{', 'b=3', TexCmd('leq'), ' s ', TexCmd('leq'), ' c=4', '\\}', '.'], []), ' The spectrum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' remains a disk, \neven though the two segments of the support of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)'], []), ' are more \nseparated than in Figure 4. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('newpage'), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('section'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', TexCmd('renewcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theequation')), BraceGroup('A.', TexCmd('arabic', [BraceGroup('equation')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('renewcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('thesection')), BraceGroup('Appendix A')]), '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The Phase Diagram of a Generic ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('vskip'), ' 5mm\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('section'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', TexCmd('renewcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('thesection')), BraceGroup('A')]), '\nIn this Appendix we briefly review the necessary theoretical aspects of \nmulti-cut phases of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '. The first part of our discussion will \napply for a generic polynomial ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), '. Then, in the second part of the \nAppendix, we will specialize to the sextic potential (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), '). \n\nFor practical reasons, we eliminate some (or all) of the couplings in \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' in terms of the end-points of the segments containing the \neigenvalue distribution of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ', and use the latter as (part of) the coordinates in the phase diagram.\nIn this way we can find rather easily which couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' are needed\nto generate an eigenvalue distribution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' with a prescribed set of \nsupport segments.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('A generic potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []))]), ' \n', '\n', '\n', '\nThe saddle-point equation governing the Dyson gas of eigenvalues of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' is ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ambjorn, periwal')]), '\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dyson'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Re')]), ' F(s-i', TexCmd('epsilon'), ') = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), " V'(s)", '\\,', '. \n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nBy definition (see Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('FF')]), '))\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fw')]), '\nF(w) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('trn', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' w-', TexCmd('pdgp'))]), ' ', TexCmd('rangle'), ' = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^N ', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' w-s_i')]), TexCmd('rangle'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\n', '(where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_i'], []), ' are the eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '). Thus, as usual, \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('realax')]), '\nF(s-i', TexCmd('epsilon'), ') = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' P.P.'), BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^N ', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' s-s_j')]), TexCmd('rangle'), ' + i', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(s)', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)'], []), ' \nis the density of eigenvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), '.\n\nIn order to study multi-cut configurations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)'], []), ', we also need the auxiliary function ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('david')]), ' \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gs')]), '\nG(s) = ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('a_1>0'), '^s d', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', "( V'(", TexCmd('mu'), ') - 2F(', TexCmd('mu'), '-i', TexCmd('epsilon'), '))', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nIn the last equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1'], []), ' is the lowest branch point of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), '.\nThus, from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('realax')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dyson')]), '), we see that for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' real and in the support of eigenvalues,\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sreal')]), '\nG(s) = - 2', TexCmd('pi'), ' i ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('a_1'), '^s ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ') d', TexCmd('mu'), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nis pure imaginary. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('Im'), ' G(s) = 2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)'], []), ' is then positive and monotonically increasing (and reaches ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' hits \nthe largest branch point).\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' Stability of multi-cut distributions'), ' ', '~~~ How do we know that a given distribution of eigenvalues is stable against migration\nof eigenvalues from one place to another? To answer this question, consider the Dyson gas energy functional \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dysongas')]), '\n', TexCmd('sef'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s) V(s) ds - ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s) ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ') \n', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(s-', TexCmd('mu'), ')^2 ~ds d', TexCmd('mu'), '\n', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nA general variation of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dysongas')]), ') under ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)arrow', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s) +', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s) '], []), ' is \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('variation')]), '\n', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('sef'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), ' V(s) ', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s) ds - ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ') ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(s-', TexCmd('mu'), ')^2 ', TexCmd('delta'), '\n', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s) ~ds d', TexCmd('mu'), '\n', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nMoving an eigenvalue from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_i'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_f'], []), ' corresponds to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s) = (1/N)', '[', TexCmd('delta'), '(s-s_f) - ', TexCmd('delta'), '(s-s_i)', ']'], []), '. Thus, from \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('variation')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gs')]), ') (and after some work) we can show that such a move costs \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cost')]), '\n', TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('sef'), ' = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' N'), '[', 'G(s_f) - G(s_i)', ']', '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nin energy ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('david')]), '. Such a rearrangement of eigenvalues costs energy only if \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cost1')]), '\n', TexCmd('Re'), TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('sef'), ' >0', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nand therefore (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cost1')]), ') is the stability condition against such a rearrangement. Thus, a multi-cut ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ',\nwhere the eigenvalues coalesce into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' segments ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['[', 'a_1, a_2', ']', TexCmd('bigcup', [BracketGroup('a_3, a_4')]), TexCmd('bigcup'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', TexCmd('bigcup', [BracketGroup('a_', BraceGroup('2n-1'), ', a_', BraceGroup('2n'))]), ','], []), ' would be stable \nagainst migration of eigenvalues between neighboring cuts if and only if (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cost1')]), ') would hold for all neighboring pairs\nof cuts, and in both directions. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G(s)'], []), ' is real on the segments on the real axis\nthat connect the cuts, this stability condition means \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('global')]), '\nG(a_3) = G(a_2),', '\\,', ' G(a_5) = G(a_4), ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' G(a_', BraceGroup('2n-1'), ') = G(a_', BraceGroup('2n-2'), ')', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nIn addition, of course, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Re'), ' G(s)<0'], []), ' cannot happen anywhere for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), '. \nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n-1'], []), ' equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), ') comprise the desired stability condition for such an eigenvalue distribution. \nIn addition to these conditions, we have to make sure that along the cuts themselves ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('Im'), ' G(s)>0'], []), ', which is just the \ncondition that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(s)'], []), ' be positive. \n\n\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n-1'], []), ' equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), '), together with the obvious analytic properties of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' and its asymptotic behavior \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('asymptotic')]), '\nF(w)', TexCmd('sim', [BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' w')]), '\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['warrow', TexCmd('infty')], []), ', determine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' uniquely. Indeed, as is well known, for a \ngeneric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ', in view of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dyson')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('asymptotic')]), ') (and as we discussed at the end of Section 2), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' \n', '(with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' cuts) must be of the form\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fansatz')]), '\nF(w) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), " V'(w) - P(w) ", TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('l=1'), '^', BraceGroup('2n'), '(w-a_l)')]), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhere \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('p')]), '\nP(w) = ', BraceGroup('c_', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('over'), ' w'), ' + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('l=0'), '^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), '\\,', 'V -n-1'), ' c_l w^l', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1<a_2', TexCmd('cdots'), ' <a_', BraceGroup('2n')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('neq'), ' 0'], []), ' only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1=0'], []), ' ', '(see Section 2). If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1>0'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1'), ' = 0'], []), ', and thus in such a \ncase, there are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [" 2n (a's) + (", BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), '\\,', "V -n ) (c's) = n + ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), '\\,', 'V '], []), ' \nindependent parameters in the expression (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fansatz')]), ') for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), '. On the other hand, there are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), '\\,', 'V +1 '], []), ' conditions \nfrom the asymptotic behavior (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('asymptotic')]), ') plus additional ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n-1'], []), ' conditions from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), '), which comprise a total of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), '\\,', 'V + n'], []), ' conditions, equal to the number of unknown paramters. This balance remains if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' appears in the game\nas an unknown parameter, because then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1=0'], []), ', so that the number of parameters does not change. Finally, we have to remember to \nimpose the positivity constraint \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('positivity')]), '\n', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(x) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('pi')), TexCmd('Im'), ' F(x - i', TexCmd('epsilon'), ') ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhich translates into a set of inequalities among the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["a'"], []), 's and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["c'"], []), 's.\n\n  \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' A convenient local parametrization of the phase diagram'), '~~~\nRecall, that the phases of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pdgp')], []), ' are specified by the number of segments in the support\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '(s)'], []), ', i.e., the number of cuts in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' ', '(and whether these cuts have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=0'], []), ' as a branch point or not.)\nThus, instead of the usual description of the phase structure in terms of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), 'V'], []), ' couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ', our strategy is \nto use ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), 'V'], []), ' parameters out of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2n'], []), ' branch-points ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1, ', TexCmd('cdots'), ', a_', BraceGroup('2n')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' and the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), ' P'], []), ' \ncoefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_k'], []), ' ', '(with the total number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' deg'), ' V'], []), ' first saturated by the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), "'s in ascending order), which we refer to as \n``", BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' phase coordinates'), '", to express (in a given phase) the couplings appearing in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' ', '(such as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2, ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' g'], []), ' in \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), ')), as well the as the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_k'], []), "'s and ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_k'], []), "'s complementary to the phase coordinate parameter set. \n(See our discussion of the sextic potential below for concrete examples of this paramtrization.) \n\n\nWe have to be careful in giving the expressions for, say, the couplings of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ', in terms of the phase coordinates. This because \nfor a given configuration of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ', the equations from which we are to eliminate the couplings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' ', '(such as the \ntriad  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2, ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' '], []), ' and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), ')) as functions of the phase coordinates may have several \nsolutions (in other words, the  couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' are generally multivalued functions of the phase coordinates in a given phase).\nThus, in a given phase, we must of course choose the parametrization of couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' which yields the \nminimal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sef')], []), ' appropriate for that phase. \n\n\n\nThis alternative \nparametrization is more convenient for our purposes in Section 5. Indeed, \nonce we are successful in expressing the couplings \nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' as functions of the phase coordinates, it will be very easy \nfor us to tune the couplings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(', TexCmd('pdgp'), ')'], []), ' to a generic point in a given phase and also to approach the phase \nboundaries in a controlled manner. In particular, phase transitions appear here, for example, when \nbranch points collide and become equal (at some common real positive value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), "). This process removes 2 a's and thus closes \none cut ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(narrow n-1)'], []), ' but adds an additional term to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(w)'], []), '. The number of unknown parameters drops by 1, but so does the number of \nstability conditions (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), '). In the other dircetion, we can obviously reach the same coexistence point, by \ntuning the parameters of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(w)'], []), ' to a point where it develops a linear factor \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(w-a) = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(w-a)^2')])], []), ' ', '(with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), '). \nObviously, when these alternative phase coordinates approach a point on the coexistence surface from two different sides of the \npahse transition, the respective sets of couplings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ', expressed as sets of functions of the two phase coordinate patches, coincide. \nThus, they lead to the same ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sef')], []), ', which means that such a point is indeed a point on the phase boundary. \n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Results for the sextic potential')]), '\nFrom (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fansatz')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sextic')]), '), the general form of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(w)'], []), ' is \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fsextic')]), '\nF(w) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(m^2  +', TexCmd('lambda'), ' w + g w^2) -P(w)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' polynomial'))]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' A. single cut, disk phase')]), ': ~~~\nHere\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('1cutdisk')]), '\nF(w) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(m^2  +', TexCmd('lambda'), ' w + g w^2) -\n(', BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('over'), ' w'), ' + t + uw)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w(w-a)')]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nThere is a single cut, so (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), ') is trivial in this case, and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('positivity')]), ') holds manifestly. We need only impose\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('asymptotic')]), '). In the end, we find\n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('parameters1cutdisk')]), '\n', '&& u= ', BraceGroup('16 - 8as -2a^2 t', TexCmd('over'), ' a^3'), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& g = 2u', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' = 2t - au = ', BraceGroup('4a^2t + 8as -16', TexCmd('over'), ' a^2'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& m^2 = 2s - at - ', BraceGroup('a^2u', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), ' = ', BraceGroup('8as -a^2t -8', TexCmd('over'), ' 2a'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\nThe phase coordinates are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a, t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), '.\n\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' B. single cut, annular phase'), ': ~~~\nWe have \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('1cutannulus')]), '\nF(w) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(m^2  +', TexCmd('lambda'), ' w + g w^2) -\n( t + uw)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('(w-a)(w-b)')]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<a<b'], []), '. Again, there is a single cut, so (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), ') is trivial in this case too, and also (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('positivity')]), ') holds manifestly.\nWe need \nonly impose (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('asymptotic')]), '). In the end, we find\n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('parameters1cutannulus')]), '\n', '&& u= ', BraceGroup('16 -2t(a-b)^2', TexCmd('over'), ' ', '(a+b)(a-b)^2'), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& g = 2u', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' = 2t - u(a+b)  = 4t -', BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('over'), ' ', '(a-b)^2'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& m^2 = -', BraceGroup('(a-b)^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), 'u - t(a+b) = -', BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('over'), ' a+b'), ' -\nt ', BraceGroup(' a^2 + 6ab + b^2', TexCmd('over'), ' 2(a+b)'), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\nThe phase coordinates are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a, b'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), '.  \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' C. two cuts, disk phase'), ': ~~~\nWe have\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('2cutdisk')]), '\nF(w) = ', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), '(m^2  +', TexCmd('lambda'), ' w + g w^2) -\n( ', BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('over'), ' w'), ' + t )', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('w(w-a)(w-b)(w-c)')]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<a<b<c'], []), '. Note that in this case we can trade the three couplings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2, ', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' for the \nthree branch points ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a,b'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '. In this case there are two cuts, so for the first \ntime (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), ') is not trivial. We first impose (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('asymptotic')]), '). We find\n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('parameters2cutdisk')]), '\n', '&& s= ', BraceGroup('8', TexCmd('over'), ' a^2 + b^2 + c^2 -2(ab + ac + bc)'), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&-&', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 2'), BraceGroup('a^3 + b^3 + c^3 - a^2(b+c) - b^2(a+c) - c^2(a+b) + 2abc', TexCmd('over'), ' a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - 2(ab+ac+bc)'), 't', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& g = 2t', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' = 2s - t(a+b+c)', TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& m^2 = -(a+b+c)s - ', BraceGroup('a^2 + b^2 + c^2 -2(ab+ac+bc)', TexCmd('over'), ' 4'), 't', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\nWe have yet to impose (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), '), which is why ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' was not eliminated yet. \nBefore doing that, we impose (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('positivity')]), '). \nOur conventions are always to take each cut from the appropriate branch point to the \nleft on the real axis. Thus, after some work, we find from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('2cutdisk')]), ') \n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('density')]), '\n', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('rho'), '(x) &=& ', TexCmd('Im'), ' F(x-i', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')=', TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&', '\\{', TexNamedEnv('array', [' \n-(', BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('over'), ' x'), ' + t)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x(a-x)(b-x)(c-x)')]), TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad'), ' 0<x<a', BraceGroup(), '\n+(', BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('over'), ' x'), ' + t)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x(x-a)(x-b)(c-x)')]), TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad'), ' b<x<c', BraceGroup(), '\n0', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' otherwise')]), '\\,', '.'], [BraceGroup('c')]), '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\nWe have to impose (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('positivity')]), ') on (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('density')]), '). This means \n', TexCmd('beqast', [BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('over'), ' x')]), ' + t <0', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for ')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' 0<x<a', TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and'), BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('over'), ' x')]), ' + t >0', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for ')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' b<x<c', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqast'), '\nThus, we must have', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('It is straightforward to check that the \nfollowing inequalities hold for the ensembles corresponding to \nFigures 4 and 5 in Section 5.')]), '  \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('inequalities')]), '\nt>0', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('quad'), ' -bt', TexCmd('leq'), ' s', TexCmd('leq'), ' -at<0', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' is given in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('parameters2cutdisk')]), ').\nWe are now ready to impose (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('global')]), '). Here it simply means ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G(a)=G(b)'], []), ', namely,\n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('globaldisk')]), '\n', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_a^b (', BraceGroup('s', TexCmd('over'), ' x'), ' + t)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x(x-a)(b-x)(c-x)')]), '\\,', 'dx = 0', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nNote from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('inequalities')]), ') that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-b<s/t<-a'], []), ', and thus the factor multiplying the square root in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('globaldisk')]), ') flips its sign in \nthe integration domain, so that the integral on the LHS of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('globaldisk')]), ') may vanish. The latter equation may be expressed in terms\nof the elliptic integrals \n', TexCmd('beqra'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('elliptic')]), '\nI(a,b,c) &=& ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_a^b ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x(x-a)(x-b)(x-c)')]), ' dx ', TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nJ(a,b,c) &=& ', TexCmd('int'), TexCmd('limits'), '_a^b ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x(x-a)(x-b)(x-c)'), BraceGroup('dx', TexCmd('over'), ' x')]), '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('eeqra'), '\nFollowing the usual procedure, we may express ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J'], []), ' in terms \nof complete elliptic integrals in a \nstraightforward manner. (We do not bother to write these expressions here, \nsince for our purposes in Section 5 we evaluated ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J'], []), ' numerically.)\n\nFinally, substituting these expressions in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('globaldisk')]), ') we obtain \n', TexCmd('beq'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('t')]), '\ns(t,a,b,c)J(a,b,c)+tI(a,b,c)=0\n', TexCmd('eeq'), '\nwhich we solve for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' ', '(recall from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('parameters2cutdisk')]), ') that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' is merely \nlinear in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ', and also that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t>0'], []), ', in view of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('inequalities')]), ').) \nOnce ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t(a,b,c)'], []), ' is known, we can go back to (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('parameters2cutdisk')]), ') and evaluate\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^2(a,b,c), ', TexCmd('lambda'), '(a,b,c)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g(a,b,c)'], []), ' explicitly.  Our phase coordinates in this case are thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a, b'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('vskip'), ' 20mm\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS')]), "\nWe thanks H. We summarise here the main \narguments on the complementary role of the LC compared to the Higgs boson \npicture that may be obtained on the basis of the LHC data, as anticipated by\nthe present studies, and compare the LC reach to that of a muon collider.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('vspace*', [BraceGroup('-0.75cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('file=Higgs_cms_lc.eps,width=11.5cm,height=9.0cm,clip=')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Comparison of the MSSM Higgs sector discovery potential at the \nLHC and at the LC. BraceGroup('HWW'))])], []), ' ', '& 120 & 0.070 & 0.023  \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('g_', BraceGroup('HZZ')), BraceGroup('g_', BraceGroup('HWW'))])], []), ' ', '& 160 & 0.050 & 0.022   ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('tot')], []), ' ', '& 120-140 &   -     & 0.04 - 0.06  ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('HHH')], []), ' ', '& 120 & - & 0.22  ', TexCmd('hline'), ' \n'], [BraceGroup('|l|c|c|c|')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tab:lhc1')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('h!')]), '\nBeyond discovery, measuring the Higgs properties in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['pp'], []), ' collisions is \ndifficult due to the limited signal statistics, large backgrounds and \nsystematic uncertainties arising, for example from the limited precision of the\nparton densities in the proton. Still, the LHC data can provide ratios of some\nof the Higgs branching ratios and couplings, as listed in \nTable~4 for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_H = 120'], []), ' GeV, while the precision measurements of the absolute \nbranching ratios and couplings remain an experimental program which can only be\naddressed at a high luminosity lepton collider. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('vspace*', [BraceGroup('-0.75cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('file=hfitter3.eps,width=10.0cm,height=8.5cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Accuracy in the determination of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('Htt')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('HWW')], []), ' \nHiggs boson couplings at the LHC and at the LC compared to the \npredictions from MSSM for different values of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_A'], []), ' mass.')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig:lhclcgh')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('h!')]), '\nFurther perspectives for measurements of the total Higgs \nboson width and of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('HWW')], []), ' coupling with a precision of 10--20 percent  have \nbeen recently suggested for the LHC~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('zeppenfeld')]), ' but are still awaiting \nto be confirmed experimentally, accounting for the backgrounds and the \ndetector response. Since over a large range of the parameter space, only one \nHiggs boson is observable at the LHC, the distinction of the SM or SUSY nature \nof the Higgs sector can only be addressed at a lepton collider, while the \nLHC may discover supersymmetry by directly observing sparticle decays.\n\nThe complementarity of the linear collider data to the picture of the Higgs \nsector as it will have been outlined by the LHC is therefore threefold: \ni) the accuracy of those measurements, which are possible at the LHC, can be \nsignificantly increased, ii) the absolute measurements of all the relevant \nHiggs boson couplings, including the Higgs self coupling, will be possible \nonly at the lepton collider and iii) extended Higgs sector scenarios (e.g. \ninvisible Higgs boson decays or 2HDM) can be observed at the linear collider \nclosing the loopholes of a possible non-discovery at the LHC.\n\nIf the considerable technical challenges presented by a muon collider project \ncan be properly addressed, a first muon collider (FMC)~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fmc,cernfmc')]), ' \ncould be operated at the centre-of-mass energy corresponding to a light Higgs \nboson mass. Such a machine would provide with the unique feature of s-channel \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^+', TexCmd('mu'), '^- arrow H'], []), ' production with a beam energy spread comparable to \nthe natural width of a light SM Higgs boson. However such a small energy \nspread may only be achieved at a luminosity of about \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup('31')], []), '~cm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), 's', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', corresponding to the production of a few thousand \nHiggs particles/year. \nBy an energy scan of the Higgs resonance, the FMC can determine its mass and \nwidth to an accuracy of better than 1~MeV. The measurement of the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^+', TexCmd('mu'), '^- arrow H arrow b ', TexCmd('bar'), ' b'], []), ' cross section would offer \nsensitivity to the Higgs couplings to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' quark. This measurement can thus \nbe used, together with those of the Higgs width and mass for a test the Higgs \nboson nature, similarly to that discussed above for the case of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^+e^-'], []), '\ncollider. A comparable sensitivity to the MSSM Higgs nature can be obtained \nwith 200~pb', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', while a significant extension towards larger values of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_A'], []), ' would require an order of magnitude higher luminosity~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('cernfmc')]), '. \nConsidering the different maturity of the LC and FMC projects, the LC appears \nat present as the most attractive option for a detailed investigation of the \nHiggs sector, complementing the data from the Tevatron and the LHC, at the turn\nof the first decade of this new century. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Summary')]), '\n', '\nThe search for the Higgs boson and the study of its properties is one of the \nmain goals of present research in particle physics. The central role of a\nlinear collider in the understanding of the mechanism of electro-weak symmetry \nbreaking, complementing the data delivered by LEP and those to be acquired \nat the Tevatron and at the LHC, has been clearly outlined by the studies \ncarried out world-wide, reported at this Conference and summarised in this \nreview.    \n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgements')]), '\n', '\nWe are grateful to the organisers of the LCWS-2000 Conference for their\ninvitation and the inspiring atmosphere. 4389 **SUCCESS CombAndNpSection.tex

4390 ***Failed to finish last-preprint.tex: [Line: 0, Offset 1314] Malformed argument. First and last elements must match a valid argument format. In this case, TexSoup could not find matching punctuation for: {.
Just finished parsing: ['{', '\\}', BraceGroup('U'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Upsilon')), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nn')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('nonumber'))]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ds')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('displaystyle'))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('What happens to Lattice Fermion near Continuum Limit?')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('Minoru Koseki, Hiroto So and Naoya Ukita \n Department of Physics, Niigata University\n  Ikarashi 2-8050, Niigata 950-2181, Japan\n  E-mail: ', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('koseki@muse.hep.sc.niigata-u.ac.jp')]), ',\n            ', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('so@muse.hep.sc.niigata-u.ac.jp')]), ',\n            ', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('ukita@muse.hep.sc.niigata-u.ac.jp')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('abstract', [BraceGroup('A Ginsparg-Wilson Relation (GWR) is obtained in the presence\nof chiral symmetry breaking terms.  It leads to the PCAC relation as\nwell as an anomaly relation on the lattice.  For general fermions, the\ndeviation from the exact GWR is getting small when the block-spin\ntransformations are performed iteratively.  Based on a simple\ngeometrical interpretation of the Dirac operator satisfying the GWR, we\nfind some physical properties shared by the lattice fermions near the\ncontinuum limit.  In two-dimensions, we explicitly construct the GW\nDirac operator by using a conformal mapping.')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('keywords', [BraceGroup('Lattice Quantum Field Theory, Renormalization Regularization\nand Renormalons, Anomalies in Fields and String Theories')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('preprint', [BraceGroup('NIIG-DP-00-2')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('footnote'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('newpage'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('large', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 1.~ Introduction')]))]), '\n', '\nThe chiral symmetry on the lattice has been found by L', '\\"', 'uscher ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('lu')]), '\n based on the Ginsparg-Wilson Relation (GWR) ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('gw')]), '.  He has opened a\n new era in the study of the regularized theory of chiral fermion.  His\n formalism has been applied to chiral gauge theories, numerical calculations\n of chiral dynamics and supersymmetry on the lattice ', '[', '3-17', ']', '.\n\nThe purpose of this paper is to investigate the realization of the\nchiral symmetry near the continuum limit. The related problem was\ndiscussed by Hasenfratz based on his idea of the perfect action\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('hf')]), ': he obtained the relation equivalent to the GWR using the\nblock-spin transformation(BST).  However, his discussion was restricted\nto the behaviors of lattice fermions on the renormalized trajectory.\n\nWe first consider a BST for chiral non-invariant fermion from a\nfine-lattice to coarse-lattice, and derive a GWR with symmetry breaking\nterms. Since the chiral limit can be taken independently of the\ncontinuum limit, it is possible to obtain the PCAC relation on the\nlattice. We also find an anomaly relation between the fermions on the\nfine-lattice and the coarse-lattice.  We next show that the Dirac\noperator satisfying the conventional GWR can be regarded as a mapping\nfrom a torus to a sphere. Based on this identification, it can be\nunderstood that a massless state corresponds to the South Pole of the\nsphere and massive states (doublers) appear at the North Pole.  We want\nto emphasize that massless and massive states can have different charges\nunder a L', '\\"', "uscher's chiral transformation.  That is the reason why the\nGW fermion escapes from the no-go theorem.  We discuss the BSTs of the\nlattice fermions such as the Wilson fermion and the Domain Wall fermion.\nIt is shown that they must satisfy the GWR as approaching the\nultraviolet fixed point (FP). They share the following physical\nproperties near the continuum limit: (i) All doublers have the same mass\nwith order ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(a^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '). This is compatible with the chiral symmetry\nproposed by L', '\\"', "uscher. (ii) Restoration of the ``rotational symmetry''.\nSo, the GW fermion has more symmetries than other lattice fermions.\n\n\n  The present paper is organized as follows.  In section 2, we derive\n the GWR with a breaking term, chiral anomaly term and BST for Dirac\n operator.  Section 3 is devoted to properties of GWR.  We analyze\n block-spin transformed lattice fermion in section 4.  In section 5, we\n explicitly construct, for two dimensional case, the Dirac operator near\n the continuum limit using a conformal mapping.\n \n", TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n ', TexCmd('large', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 2.~GWR, Anomaly and BST '))]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn order to investigate the continuum limit which corresponds to a FP,\nwe will use the BST from a microscopic theory to a macroscopic\n(effective) theory. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_c'], []), ' be an action of the high frequency modes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('psi'), '_n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '_n'], []), ' with fine lattice index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' be the\naction of the low frequency modes', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('Psi'), '_N'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), '_N'], []), ' with\ncoarse-lattice index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '. We assume that the action ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_c'], []), ' is bi-linear\nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('psi'), '_n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '_n'], []), '. The chiral transformation for the fine\nlattice variables is given by\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), ' = -i', TexCmd('g'), '_5', TexCmd('psi'), ',\n~~~', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ' = ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ' ', '(-i', TexCmd('g'), '_5).\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:chiral')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nunder which the action transforms as\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' A_0(', TexCmd('psi'), ', ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ') =  A_0(', TexCmd('psi'), ' + ', TexCmd('delta'), '  ', TexCmd('psi'), ', ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ' + ', TexCmd('delta'), '  \n', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ') -A_0(', TexCmd('psi'), ', ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ').\n'], []), '\n', '\nThere are two kinds of chiral breaking for which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' A_0 ', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), ': (i)\n The breaking due to the lattice regularization.  For example, the\n actions for the Wilson fermion and the Domain Wall fermion are not\n invariant under eq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:chiral')]), ').  (ii) Explicit breaking such as\n the mass term.\n\nWe derive a general GWR for the coarse-lattice action ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' in the\npresence of the chiral breaking terms. The action is defined as\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nA ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' - ', TexCmd('ln'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ',', TexCmd('psi')), '    \nK ', TexCmd('exp'), '( - A_0 ', '[', TexCmd('psi'), ', ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ']', ') = ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), 'D ', TexCmd('Psi'), ' .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('macro_a')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nThe block spin kernel, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ', takes of the form \n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nK ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '(- (', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), ' - ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), 'f^*)', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('Psi'), ' - f', TexCmd('psi'), ')),\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nwhere the functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f\n(f^*)'], []), ' specify the BST and normalized as  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('Nn'), ' f^*_', BraceGroup('nM'), ' = ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('NM'), ', ~~\nf^*_', BraceGroup('nN'), ' f_', BraceGroup('Nm'), ' = ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('nm')], []), '. \nWe take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha')), '_', BraceGroup('MN'), ' = ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), ' so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' becomes local.\nThe following formula for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' is useful:\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '^l'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('Psi'))]), ' \n', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', '\\{', TexCmd('alpha'), ',', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5', '\\}', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '^l'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]))]), ' K\n = (', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), ' - ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), 'f^*)', '\\{', TexCmd('alpha'), ' , ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5', '\\}', ' ', '(', TexCmd('Psi'), ' - f', TexCmd('psi'), ')K.\n'], []), '\nWe obtain the general GWR,\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5 D + D ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5)', TexCmd('Psi'), ' = \n', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), 'D ', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\\{', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ,', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5', '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' D ', TexCmd('Psi'), ' - i \n<', TexCmd('delta'), ' A_0>|_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), TexCmd('Psi')), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:GW1')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('cdots'), '>'], []), ' is defined as \n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n<', TexCmd('cdots'), '> = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ',', TexCmd('psi')), ' ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' \n K ', TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '( - A_0 ', '[', TexCmd('psi'), ', ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ']', ') /\n  ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ',', TexCmd('psi')), ' K ', TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '( - A_0 ', '[', TexCmd('psi'), ', ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ']', '),\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), TexCmd('Psi'))], []), ' implies the component of\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), TexCmd('Psi')], []), '.  In section 4, we discuss the symmetry breaking term corresponding to the contribution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('delta'), ' A_0>|_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), TexCmd('Psi'))], []), ' for the Wilson fermions.\n\n\nNext we consider a massive fermion on the fine lattice whose action\ntakes the bilinear form, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_0 = ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '(D_0 + m)', TexCmd('psi')], []), '.  Then, the\ngeneral GWR becomes\n \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5 D + D ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5)', TexCmd('Psi'), ' = \n', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), 'D ', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\\{', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ,', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5', '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' D ', TexCmd('Psi'), ' + \n2m ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), TexCmd('alpha'), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), ' + m + fD_0f^*)^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\n', TexCmd('gamma'), '_5 (', TexCmd('alpha'), ' + m + fD_0f^*)^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('Psi'), '. \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:mgw')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nPerforming the Gaussian integral eq.(3), we find the relation between  the Dirac operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), '\nfor the coarse-lattice variables and the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_0'], []), ' for fine-lattice variables\n \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nD^', TexCmd('alpha', [BraceGroup('-1')]), ' ', '&=& ^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' + f (D_', BraceGroup('0'), ' + m)^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'f^*.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('blockspin')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nThis leads to the general GWR with the mass breaking term:\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nD', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_5 + ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_5D = 2m (1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ')', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_5,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:pcac')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_5 ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('g'), '_5 (1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('a'))]), ')'], []), ".  It corresponds to the\n``PCAC'' relation for the coarse-lattice fermions.  ", BraceGroup(), "From this ``PCAC''\nrelation on the coarse-lattice, we can consider the chiral symmetry\nbreaking, e.g. the pion mass.  In eq.(", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:pcac')]), '), we observe that\nthe effective fermion mass on the coarse lattice should be regarded as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m (1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ')'], []), '.  Note that the l.h.s. of eq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:pcac')]), ')\nis written entirely with quantities defined for the coarse lattice,\nwhile the r.h.s. contains also the microscopic information (microscopic\nmass, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ').\n\nThe general GWR eq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:pcac')]), ') is obtained from the\neq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:mgw')]), ') which is bi-linear in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))])], []), '. For\nthe field-independent relation, we obtain\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' J  = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tr')]), TexCmd('gamma'), '_5', '\\{', 'D- m(1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ')', '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:anomaly')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), ' \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' J'], []), ' means the shift of path integral measure under \nthe chiral transformation eq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:chiral')]), ') and the l.h.s corresponds to \n chiral anomaly generated by fine-lattice fermion. \n This  equality implies the anomaly generated  by microscopic fields \n is saturated with  coarse-lattice (macroscopic) fields.\n Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), ' includes a mass term, we have to eliminate the apparent effect\nof the mass. \n From ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D-m(1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ') ', TexCmd('to'), ' D'], []), ', \nthe apparent mass dependence of the l.h.s \n  is  vanished after redefinition of the Dirac operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), '.\n\n\n\nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m=0'], []), ',\nthere is a remnant of chiral symmetry which is called L', '\\"', "uscher's symmetry\n", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('lu')]), ',\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('Gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('Psi'), ' = -i_5', TexCmd('Gamma'), TexCmd('Psi'), ',\n~~~', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), ' = ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), ' ', '(-i_5).\n'], []), '\nEq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:anomaly')]), ') implies the relation between microscopic and\nmacroscopic anomalies, since r.h.s of eq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:anomaly')]), ') is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nTr'), '\\{', '2', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_5', '\\}'], []), '.  It is noted that the transformation of the low\nfrequency modes is given by ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iis')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('Psi'), ' = <', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '>,\n~~~', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))]), ' = <', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '>.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nThis gives another interpretation of the  L', '\\"', "uscher's symmetry. \nHere we note that ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('psi'), '>'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '>'], []), ' do not vanish\n because of the presence of the external fermions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'))])], []), '.  \n\n\nIn the proceeding  sections, we find the properties of fermions with GWR\n  and carry out   BST explicitly for Wilson fermions.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n ', TexCmd('large', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 3.~GW fermion'))]), '\n', '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nIn this section we investigate  general properties of the free Dirac\noperator satisfying the GWR. They are useful for discussing in \nsection 4 that Dirac operators are gradually satisfying the GWR by \nBSTs,  and for constructing a Ginsparg-Wilson (GW) \nDirac operator in section 5. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 3.1.~Properties of the GWR solutions')]), '\nIn a momentum space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\}', ',', TexCmd('mu'), '=1', TexCmd('sim'), ' d'], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(d=even)'], []), ', the parity-even \nfree GW Dirac operator can be written as \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n D=i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '(p)+A(p),  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:1')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))], []), ' denote the hermitian gamma matrices, and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '(p), A(p)'], []), ' are appropriate functions of momentum ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))], []), '.\nUsing the above expression, the GWR can be expressed as \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '+(A-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), ')^2=\n(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), ')^2.  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:2')]), '\n'], []), '\nIt represents a d-dimensional\nspherical surface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^d'], []), ' with a radius of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' /2'], []), ' in a\n(d+1)-dimensional space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',A', '\\}'], []), '. Since the momentum\nspace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\}'], []), ' is equivalent to a d-dimensional torus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^d'], []), ', we \nfind that the GW Dirac operator is a mapping from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^d'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^d'], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n D ', '\\,', ':', '\\,', ' T^d ', TexCmd('longmapsto'), ' S^d.\n'], []), '\nIt is noted that eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:2')]), ') has a rotational symmetry in a\nsubspace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\}'], []), '. Although this is only a fake symmetry and not a\nrotational one in the momentum space', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\}'], []), ', it is expected to\nbecome a real rotational symmetry in the continuum limit.\n\nEach point on the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^d'], []), ' corresponds to each mode of the\npropagator.  For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A=0'], []), ', a massless mode appears at the South Pole\n(SP), and for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A=', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ', massive modes do at the North Pole (NP) in\nFig.', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '.  Both Poles are fixed points under the fake rotational\nsymmetry.  \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=fig1.ai,scale=0.5')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('A massless mode (SP) and massive mode (NP) in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', ' S_1 ,S_2 ,A ', '\\}'], []))]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nAs an example, consider the Dirac operator \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)'], []), ' given by Neuberger ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('neu')]), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n D_', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)=i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)+A_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p), ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:17')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '\n ', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n   S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)=', TexCmd('sin'), TexCmd('displaystyle'), TexCmd('displaystyle'), ' p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ' ', '(H^2(p))^', BraceGroup('-1/2'), ', \n \n\n '], [BraceGroup('l')]), '\n.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' 0<M<2'], []), '.\n', BraceGroup(), 'From a simple calculation, it is found that this Dirac operator satisfies\nthe equation of the d-dimensional sphere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^d'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '+(A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '-1)^2=1'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '=2'], []), ' and has the\nrotational symmetry in a subspace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '\\}'], []), '. Fig.', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' represents\nthis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^', BraceGroup('d=2')], []), ' parameterized by momentum ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))], []), '.\n\nThe GW Dirac operator defines a smooth mapping from torus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^d'], []), ' to\nsphere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^d'], []), '.  However, since they are different in topology, the\nmapping is not one-to-one and several points on the torus may be mapped\nto a point on the sphere.  For example, we observe in Fig.1 the North\nPole is realized for several values of momentum.  Fig.', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' represents the\nmomentum dependence of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A(p)'], []), ", which shows the massless mode and the\ndegenerate massive modes.  From this figure we learn that the North Pole\nis actually realized three times for this two dimensional example,\ncorresponding to the number of doublers.  In section 5, we will observe\nthe same feature in our new GW Dirac operator, different from the\nNeuberger's one.\n\n", TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=fig2.ai,scale=0.5')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup("Neuberger's Dirac operator in ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', ' p_1 , p_2 , A ', '\\}'], []), '.  \nThree doublers appear in association with three maxima indicated by dots.')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nNext, we consider the L', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ddot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' u')])], []), "scher's chiral transformation of the\nmassless mode ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '=0,A=0)'], []), ' and the massive modes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '=0,A=', TexCmd('alpha'), ')'], []), '.\nSince the transformation is given by \n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '\\{', '\n ', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n ', TexCmd('psi'), ' ', '& arrow & ', '[', '1 +i', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), '\n                      ', '(1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ')', ']', TexCmd('psi'), ', \n ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), ' ', '& arrow & \n   ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi')), BracketGroup('1 +\n    i', TexCmd('theta'), '(1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), ')', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'))]), ',\n '], [BraceGroup('lll')]), '\n . '], []), '\n'], []), '  \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' is an infinitesimal parameter, one obtains for the massless\nmode (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D=0'], []), ')\n ', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '\\{', '\n ', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('massless'), ' ', '& arrow &(1+i', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), ')\n                   ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('massless'), ', \n ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '_', BraceGroup('massless'), ' ', '& arrow & \n   ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '_', BraceGroup('massless'), '(1+i', TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), '),\n  '], [BraceGroup('lll')]), '\n . '], []), '\n'], []), '\nand for the massive modes (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D=', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ')\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '\\{', '\n ', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('massive'), ' ', '& arrow & ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('massive'), ', \n ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '_', BraceGroup('massive'), ' ', '& arrow & \n   ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('psi'))]), '_', BraceGroup('massive'), '.\n '], [BraceGroup('lll')]), '\n . '], []), '\n'], []), '\nIt should be emphasized that the L', '\\"', "uscher's chiral transformation\nallows the mass for the doublers.  This fact looks incompatible with the\nno-go theorem.  However, it is not the case, since the L", '\\"', "uscher's\nchiral symmetry does not satisfy one of the assumptions for the\nno-go theorem, the locality of the chiral charge.\n\nIn the presence of interactions, the Dirac operator may not take the free\nfields form ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D=i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '(p)+A(p)'], []), ', and cannot be interpreted\nas a d-dimensional sphere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^d'], []), '.  Nevertheless, the GW Dirac operator\nalways can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n D=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), '(1-U),\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' is a unitary operator. So the eigenvalues ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' are given\nas \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' =', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), '(1-e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('theta')), ') ', '\\,', ',', '\\,', '(-', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('theta'), '<', TexCmd('pi'), ').\n'], []), '\nThey distribute on a circle in a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'Im(', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ,Re(', TexCmd('lambda'), ')', '\\}'], []), 'space\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('bh,bicudo,wb')]), '.  For free field case, it is further possible to\nconsider the Dirac operator in terms of the modes of the propagator.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 3.2.~The number of free parameters of the GW Dirac operator')]), '\nNext, we will discuss the number of free parameters of the GW Dirac\noperator. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('GW')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('GW'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'))], []), " be two GW Dirac\noperators. In order for them to describe the same physics, they should\nhave the same ``fermion determinant'' and the same ``anomaly''. \nIntroducing two hermite matrices, ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H=', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), 'D_', BraceGroup('GW'), ',\nH^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), '=', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), 'D_', BraceGroup('GW'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'))], []), ', we may express the unitary\nequivalence conditions as  \n\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\\,', 'H&=&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Det'), '\\,', ' H^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:7'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tr')]), '\\,', 'H&=&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tr'), '\\,', 'H^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:8'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tr')]), '\\,', '[', 'H', ']', '^', BraceGroup('n'), '&=&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tr'), '\\,', '[', 'H^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ']', '^', BraceGroup('n'), '   \n  ', '\\,', ',', '\\,', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:9')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Det')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('leq'), ' n ', TexCmd('leq'), ' N-1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' denotes the total number of color,\nflavor, spinor indices and lattice points. The equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:7')]), ')\nand (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:8')]), ") are the ``fermion determinant'' and the `` anomaly''\nconditions.  Thus, the number of free parameters of the GW Dirac\noperator is ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N-2'], []), ', which is the number of\nconditions of eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:9')]), ').  \nThis implies that there are many\nsolutions of the GWR.\nActually, in section 5 we will construct another\nGW Dirac operator which differs from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('neu')], []), '.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n ', TexCmd('large', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 4.~BST of Lattice Fermions '))]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn this section, we consider the Dirac operators which do not satisfy\nthe GWR, and show that the iterative use of BST makes them satisfy the\nGWR approximately.  The Dirac operators gradually get the properties of\nthe GW fermion:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '\\{', '\n ', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n  ', TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(i) & ', TexCmd('rm'), ' d-dimensional', '\\,', '\\,', ' sphere', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' S^d'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', 'in', '\\,', '\\,', 'the', '\\,', '\\,', ' \n             ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), '\\{', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',A', '\\}'), 'space \n  ', TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(ii) &', TexCmd('rm'), ' rotational', '\\,', '\\,', ' symmetry', '\\,', '\\,', ' in', '\\,', '\\,', 'the', '\\,', '\\,', ' \n                   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), '\\{', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\}'), 'subspace \n  ', TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(iii) &', TexCmd('rm'), '  degenerate', '\\,', '\\,', ' doubler', '\\,', '\\,', ' masses.\n '], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '\n.\n'], []), '\nFor comparison, we also consider a BST of the GW fermion.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 4.1.~Properties of the Wilson fermion')]), '\nAs a simple example, consider the 2D free Wilson Dirac operator\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('W'), '(p)'], []), ' given by  \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n D_', BraceGroup('W'), '(p)=i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('W'), '(p)+A^', BraceGroup('W'), '(p), ', Now verify analytically\nthem. [BracketGroup('A^W')]), '\nwhere\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), '=(0,N', TexCmd('pi'), ')', '\\,', ',', '\\,', 'p_',
