the FP the doubler masses (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('neq'), ' 0'], []), ') become degenerate. \nOn the other hand, from eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:20')]), ') \nwe can obtain the mass correction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup('(N)'), 'm'], []), ' by the N-th BST,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['_', BraceGroup('N'), ' = ', '[', 'A^', BraceGroup('W'), ']', '_', BraceGroup('N-1'), ' + ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup('(N)'), 'm ,\n'], [BracketGroup('A^', BraceGroup('W'))]), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n  ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup('(N)'), 'm = ', '[', 'A^', BraceGroup('W'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '-A^', BraceGroup('W')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '+A^', BraceGroup('W'))]), ']', '_', BraceGroup('N-1'), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:mc')]), '\n'], []), '\nThis implies that the doubler masses ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('neq'), ' 0)'], []), ' approaches to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), '\nby the BST, and the massless mode is a fixed point of the BST. \nTherefore, as far as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' is finite (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '<', TexCmd('infty')], []), '),\nall doubler masses become the same mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Narrow', TexCmd('infty')], []), '. \nThus it is understood that performing the BST on the fermion, the\nfermion gradually gets the properties of the GW fermion.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 4.3.~BST of the GW fermion')]), '\nFor comparison, consider the BST of the GW fermion. \nThe Neuberger Dirac operator in eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:17')]), ') satisfies the GWR, \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n . S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)\n +(A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), ')^2\n =(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), ')^2|_', BraceGroup('micro'), '.\n'], []), '\nThus, the BST is given as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['_', BraceGroup('MACRO'), '&=&\n  .', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', 'A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')', '\\,', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')'), BraceGroup('[', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')', ']', '^2\n  +4', '[', 'A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')', ']', '^2')]), '|_', BraceGroup('micro'), ', \n ', '[', 'A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)', ']', '_', BraceGroup('MACRO'), '&=&.\n  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('alpha', [BracketGroup('A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')')]), '^2'), BraceGroup('[', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')', ']', '^2\n  +4', '[', 'A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')', ']', '^2')]), '|_', BraceGroup('micro'), ',\n'], [BracketGroup('S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)')]), '\nand one can show that the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)', ']', '_', BraceGroup('MACRO')], []), ' and the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)', ']', '_', BraceGroup('MACRO')], []), '\nsatisfy the GWR also, \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n . S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)\n +(A^', BraceGroup('neu'), '(p)-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), ')^2\n =(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), ')^2|_', BraceGroup('MACRO'), '.\n'], []), '\nAfter all we have obtained the structure of chiral symmetry near the \nFP. That is, the GW fermion flows into the FP keeping the GWR. The\nother fermions flow into the FP getting the properties of the GW fermion \napproximately, and satisfy the GWR at FP at the end. \nThus fermions have at least the approximate GWR near FP. \n\nIn the above discussion, we have considered only about the massless fermion\ncase which had a bare mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('0'), ' = 0'], []), '.\nNow, consider a massive fermion case with a non-zero bare mass\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(m_', BraceGroup('0'), TexCmd('neq'), '0)'], []), '. From the fact that the all modes are massive ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('neq'), ' 0)'], []), '\nand that the mass correction by the BST is given from eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqn:mc')]), '),\nthe mass  will\nbecome  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' at the FP (Fig.', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['6'], []), ').\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('epsfig', [BraceGroup('figure=fig6.ai,scale=0.5')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('BST of massive Wilson fermion. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' is set to 2.')]), '\n'], []), '\nAnd the Dirac operator will satisfy the GWR.', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('\nChandrasekharan introduced a bare mass for the GWR, but \nhis GWR is different from ours', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('sc')]), '.')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 4.4.~The domain wall fermion and massless states')]), '\n', '\nWe consider here fermion masses \nin the domain wall formulation', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('kaplan,shamir,fs')]), ". \nThe domain wall fermion can be interpreted as  \na multi-flavor Wilson fermion with a  negative mass.\nThe number of flavor corresponds to the fifth dimensional size. Its rule\n can be explained in view of the BST or the renormalization group as\n follows: increasing the flavor number or the fifth dimensional size in\n the domain wall fermion corresponds to looking at the behavior of the\n 4-dimensional fermion at larger scale, which would be described\n by an iteration of the BST's.  In the infinite size limit, it is known\n that the 4-dimensional effective fermion satisfies the GWR", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('kn')]), ".\n It just corresponds to the continuum limit.  The degeneracy  of the doublers\n mass and the restoration of the ``rotational invariance'' are\n essentially the same as those of one flavor Wilson fermion near the\n continuum limit.\n\nIn this subsection, we concentrate on \n the massless state in the domain wall fermion \n related with the the fifth dimensional size.\n\nLet ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup('S')], []), ' be the fifth dimensional size for the domain wall fermions\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('kaplan,shamir,fs')]), '. \nDecompose a Dirac spinor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), ')'], []), ' as \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('Psi'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), ') = P_', BraceGroup('L'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_', BraceGroup('L'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), ') \n                      + P_', BraceGroup('R'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_', BraceGroup('R'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), '),\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_', BraceGroup('L,R'), '=(1', TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), ')/2'], []), '. We impose the following\nappropriate boundary condition for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_', BraceGroup('5')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), ')'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('Psi'), '_', BraceGroup('L'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), '+N_', BraceGroup('S'), ') = ', TexCmd('Psi'), '_', BraceGroup('R'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), '),  \n ', TexCmd('Psi'), '_', BraceGroup('R'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), '+N_', BraceGroup('S'), ') = ', TexCmd('Psi'), '_', BraceGroup('L'), '(x_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',x_', BraceGroup('5'), ').\n'], []), '\nThe domain wall Dirac operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('DW'), '(p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')'], []), ' in a\nmomentum space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',p_', BraceGroup('5'), '\\}'], []), ' can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n D_', BraceGroup('DW'), '(p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',p_', BraceGroup('5'), ') = i ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' =1', TexCmd('sim'), ' 4'), TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('DW'), '\n                                ', '(p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ')\n                   +A^', BraceGroup('DW'), '(p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',p_', BraceGroup('5'), '), \n'], []), '\nwhere \n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '\n  ', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n    S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('DW'), '(p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ')=', TexCmd('sin'), ' p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ', \n    A^', BraceGroup('DW'), '(p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ',p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')= - M +(1-', TexCmd('cos'), ' p_', BraceGroup('5'), ' +i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), TexCmd('sin'), ' p_', BraceGroup('5'), ') \n                     +', BraceGroup(TexCmd('displaystyle'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' =1', TexCmd('sim'), ' 4')), '(1-', TexCmd('cos'), ' p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '),\n  '], [BraceGroup('l')]), '\n .'], []), '\n'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<M<2'], []), ' , ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('5'), '= ', TexCmd('pi'), ' n/N_', BraceGroup('S'), ',', '\\,', '\\,', 'n=1', TexCmd('sim'), ' 2N_', BraceGroup('S')], []), '.\nThe lowest mass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_', BraceGroup('eff'), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')'], []), ' which depends on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('5')], []), ' is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n    m_', BraceGroup('eff'), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')=A^', BraceGroup('DW'), '(p_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '=0,p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')\n           = - M +(1-', TexCmd('cos'), ' p_', BraceGroup('5'), ' +i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), TexCmd('sin'), ' p_', BraceGroup('5'), '). \n'], []), '\nFor each case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), '=', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1'], []), ', we denote each mass as \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n    m_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')= - M +(1-', TexCmd('cos'), ' p_', BraceGroup('5'), ' ', TexCmd('pm'), ' i', TexCmd('sin'), ' p_', BraceGroup('5'), ').\n'], []), '\nThis yields a constraint,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n  -M ', TexCmd('leq'), ' Re', '\\{', 'm_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 2-M. \n'], []), '\nIn the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup('S'), ' arrow', TexCmd('infty')], []), ', each\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Re', '\\{', 'm_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')', '\\}'], []), ' has a continuum spectrum with two zeros due\nto the periodicity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('5')], []), '.  Then the number of total zeros are four.\nAccording to the sign of each imaginary part ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Im', '\\{', 'm_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '\\}'], []), ', only\nhalf of four zeros are allowed by causality.  Therefore two allowed\nzeros are regarded as massless modes corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5'), '=', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1'], []), ', \nand we obtain a massless fermion theory.  For a finite\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup('S')], []), ', each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Re', '\\{', 'm_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')', '\\}'], []), ' has a discrete spectrum. Thus\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Re', '\\{', 'm_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')', '\\}'], []), ' does not have zero in general, and \nwe obtain in this case a massive theory.', TexCmd('footnote', [BracketGroup('3'), BraceGroup(' It is possible, however, to make\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Re', '\\{', 'm_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '(p_', BraceGroup('5'), ')', '\\}', '=0'], []), ' for a certain value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', BraceGroup('5')], []), ' by making a\nfine-tuning for  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '. Thus we may \nconstruct a fine-tuned massless fermion theory for finite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup('S')], []), '.')]), '\nAs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup('S')], []), ' increases, the minimum value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|Re', '\\{', 'm_', BraceGroup('eff'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '\\}', '|'], []), '\ndecreases, and finally becomes zero which corresponds to a massless mode.\n\n\n\nThe zero has no mass correction via the BST, that is a fixed point of the\nBST. Thus we can obtain a massless fermion theory which satisfies the\nGWR at the FP of the BST.\n  \n  \n', TexNamedEnv('flushleft', ['\n', TexCmd('large', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 5.~Lattice Fermions near the Continuum Limit')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', "\nIn this section, we show that the Neuberger's Dirac operator is not the\nunique GW Dirac operator, by constructing another free GW Dirac\noperator, ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('GW'), '=i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '+A'], []), ', for two dimensional case.  As\nis shown in eq.(16), the construction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('GW')], []), ' is equivallent to find\na mapping from a 2D torus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^2'], []), ' to a 2D sphere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^2'], []), ' in the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(S_1,S_2,A)'], []), ' space,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n D_', BraceGroup('GW'), '(p) & : & T^2 ', TexCmd('longmapsto'), ' S^2 .\n'], []), '\nWe obtain this mapping by using a combination of conformal mappings.\nBefore going into the details of the construction, let us explain our\nidea.  We divide the torus equally into four regions (see ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' I'), "\nbelow).  Take one of the regions and map it to the Sourthern hemisphere\nconformally. It is important that this conformal mapping is unique\ndue to the Riemann's theorem.  Each of three other regions is similarly\nmapped conformally to the Northern hemisphere.  Our mapping is\nconstructed by continuously connecting the four conformal mappings.\n\nWe will construct such a mapping with the following steps.\n", TexNamedEnv('description', ['\n', TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('I :')]), TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('II :')]), TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('III :')])], []), '\nIn this way we can construct a solution of the GWR, \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('GW'), '=i', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '+A'], []), '. \n\nFirst let us construct the disk ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' as the conformal mapping,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ' ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' V^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ' ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' S^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' denotes \nupper half plane mapped from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), '. The conformal mapping from\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' is defined as \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n V^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k),', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:30')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere sn is an elliptic function with modulus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'))], []), ' is\nthe complete elliptic integral of the first kind with complementary\nmodulus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), '=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-k^2')])], []), '. The elliptic function sn', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(P,k)'], []), ' is a\nperiodic function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4K', '\\,', ',', '\\,', '2iK^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'))], []), '. In our case\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', ',', '\\,', 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), '=', TexCmd('pi')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '-1)^2'], []), '.  Also\nconsidering the conformal mapping from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ', we \nobtain the mapping ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ' ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' S^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n S^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '&=&', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('V^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '-i(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '+1)'), BraceGroup('V^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '+i(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '+1)')]), '\n                ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' i', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '              \n                                      ', '&&', TexCmd('nonumber'), '    \n        ', '&=&', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k)\n               -i(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '+1)'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k)\n               +i(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '+1)')]), TexCmd('cdot'), ' i', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:31')]), '\n'], []), '\nSimilarly, we construct the mapping, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup('(2),(3),(4)'), ' ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' S^', BraceGroup('(2),(3),(4)')], []), ', paying attention to\ncontinuity at boundaries.\nThe mapping, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), ' ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' V^', BraceGroup('(4)')], []), ' is given by \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n V^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '&=&\n   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(-(P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '-2K-iK^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ')\n    +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n       ', '&=&\n   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(-(P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '-iK^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ')\n    +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n       ', '&=&\n   -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(-(P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ')\n     +2iK^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n       ', '&=&\n   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k),\n'], []), '\nwhere we used the properties ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P+2K,k)=-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P,k)'], []), '\\,', ',', '\\,', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P+2iK^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k)=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P,k)'], []), '\\,', ',', '\\,', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(-P,k)=-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P,k)'], []), '.\nThus we obtain the mapping, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), ' ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' S^', BraceGroup('(4)')], []), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n S^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '&=&', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k)\n               -i(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '+1)'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(P^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k)\n               +i(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), '+1)')]), TexCmd('cdot'), ' i', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('2')]), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn:33')]), '\n'], []), '\nAs for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' V^', BraceGroup('(2),(3)')], []), ', it is convenient to take the complex conjugate \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('P')])], []), '.  The mappings,  \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('P^', BraceGroup('(2),(3)'))]), '\\,', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', '\\,', 'V^', BraceGroup('(2),(3)'), '\\,', '\n', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', '\\,', ' S^', BraceGroup('(2),(3)')], []), ' are given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n V^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '&=&\n   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(-', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('(P^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '-2K)')]), '\n    +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n       ', '&=&\n   -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(-', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('P^', BraceGroup('(2)'))]), '\n    +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n       ', '&=&\n   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('(P^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '\n    +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ')')]), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n       ', '&=&\n   ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn')]), '(P^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '\n    +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k),\n'], []), '\nand\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n V^', BraceGroup('(3)'), '&=&\n   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('(P^', BraceGroup('(3)'), '\n    -iK^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ')')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n       ', '&=&\n   ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn'), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('(P^', BraceGroup('(3)'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ')')]), '\n     +2iK^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n  ', '&=&', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn')]), '(P^', BraceGroup('(3)'), '\n        +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime')), ',k).\n'], []), '\nWe find that \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n S^', BraceGroup('(2),(3)'), '&=&', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sn')]), '(P^', For the purpose of our approach, we used \n a bock-spin transformation method.  The analysis lead us to the chiral\n anomaly and the GWR with chiral breaking terms. The breaking measures\n the distance between the fixed point action and the general lattice\n fermions.  It was found that features of the operators are (i) masses of\n doublers are completely degenerate (ii) ``rotational'' symmetry.  When\n we start from a Wilson fermion with a chiral breaking, it acquires these two\n properties after a few block-spin steps.\n \n In the case of multi-flavor Wilson fermions (the domain wall fermion), \n  we found massless modes   as  a fifth dimension size becomes infinite.\n Even if we adopt more general lattice fermion, we could find massless modes\n because the  fifth dimension size essentially  \ncontrols the macroscopic fermion mass as the BST does.  \n\nIn the 2-dimensional case, we constructed a Dirac operator,\n in additon to Neuberger's one,\n which satisfies the GWR using elliptic functions.\n This example  teaches us the unique existence \n of the fixed point action (chiral symmetric lattice fermion),\n if it is possible to exchange  between a massless mode and one of doublers \n because of uniqueness  for conformal mapping by the Riemann's theorem.\n\n We are grateful to Y. The Nambu-Goldstone mode (collective mode  \nin the AF-Q order) scatters electrons in different ways corresponding to the angle \nbetween the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '-axis and the wave vector ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p'), ' of quasiparticles.  \nNamely, the coupling constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' q')), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat'), ' p'), '_', BraceGroup('z'), '\n', '(Q_', BraceGroup('xz,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' q')), '+Q_', BraceGroup('yz,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' q')), '),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('coupling1')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')])), TexCmd('equiv', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')]), '/|', BraceGroup(TexCmd('perp'))], []), ' are coupling constants that are essentially independent of \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' q'), '.  \n\nThis reflects the fact that long-wavelength fluctuations of quadrupolar moment \nbetween two ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('5')], []), ' states around the equilibrium AF-Q order effectively \nscatter electrons travelling in the basal plane. On the other hand, \nthese fluctuations give essentially no influence on electrons travelling \nperpendicular to the basal plane leaving the wave number of electrons intact.  \nThese situations can be understood intuitively from \na picture shown in Fig. 1.  The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), '-linear term in the second term of \neq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coupling1')]), ') represents the fact that the electrons \ncan only be scattered by the difference in the rotation angle (at different lattice \nsites) of the quadrupolar moments from the equilibrium direction.  \nThe absence of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), '-linear term in the first term of eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coupling1')]), ') reflects \nthe fact that even a uniform rotation of quadrupolar moment in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ab'], []), '-plane \ncan scatter the electrons travelling in the plane. \n\nPhysical and microscopic origins of the couplings are primarily the modulation \nof the transfer integral of quasiparticles by the fluctuations of quadrupole in the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ab'], []), '-plane.  Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig:2')]), ' shows how the transfer integral between adjacent \nU-sites along the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), "-axis among which Ru's are located above or below the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ab'], []), "-plane \nincluding U's. It is easily understood that the transfer of quasiparticles \n(consisting mostly of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' electrons) via the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('xz')], []), ' orbital of Ru decreases if the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q_', BraceGroup('xz')], []), ' component of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f^', BraceGroup('1')], []), ' configuration of electrons at U ions increases from \nthat of the original orbital shown by dashed lines.  This implies that \nthe coupling arises between the quadrupole fluctuation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q_', BraceGroup('xz,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' q'))], []), ', of wave vector \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' q')], []), ', and the electron transfer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger')), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p'), '+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' q')), 'c_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')], []), '.  \nThis coupling works even for the uniform variation in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q_', BraceGroup('xz')], []), ' component  at \nall lattice points.  On the other hand, the transfer integral \nalong the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '-axis between two adjacent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ab'], []), '-planes with the same distribution \nof U ions (which is not shown in the figure) does not change at all (in the \nlinear approximation of changes in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q_', BraceGroup('xz')], []), ' component) if the \nchanges in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q_', BraceGroup('xz')], []), ' component are the same at all lattice points. \nThe coupling arises only from the difference in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q_', BraceGroup('xz')], []), ' component change \nbetween the adjacent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ab'], []), '-planes.  Therefore, the coupling is proportional to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q_', BraceGroup('z')], []), ' in the long wavelength limit.  These facts are represented by the \nelectron-quadrupole interaction Hamiltonian ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' e-q')], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '& &H_',
