At low\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' greater than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ', the total response approaches\nthe incoherent one when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' grows. However, both\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc'), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' differ\nfrom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' because the momentum distribution\nat those temperatures noticeably depart from the gaussian shape of the\nclassical ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('k')]), ')'], []), '. When the temperature is risen, the\ndifference between the momentum distribution in the classical and\nquantum quantum cases is reduced and so the high ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' response\nof the free Bose gas approaches the classical limit. Notice however\nthat the difference between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' is still apparent at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '=20'], []), ',\nwhich means that the classical limit is only well recovered at rather\nhigh temperatures.\n\nThe evolution with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' of the different responses can also be\nanalyzed from the sum rules they satisfy. Sum rules are defined as the\ndifferent energy--weighted moments of the responses\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc,coh'), '^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha'), ')'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ')   ', TexCmd('equiv'), '  \n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('infty')), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc,coh'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ', ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')\n', '\\,', 'd', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber', [BracketGroup('2mm')]), '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha'), ')'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ') ', TexCmd('equiv'), '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc'), '^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha'), ')'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ')   +  \n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('coh'), '^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha'), ')'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ') =\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('infty')), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ', ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') ', '\\,', 'd', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sr-b1')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe first lower orders sum rules can be easily deduced and yield the\nfollowing results\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') & = & \nn_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') ', '[', '\n2', '\\,', 'n(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ') + 1 ', ']', ' +\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') \n= ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sr-c1a')]), '  ', '[', '2mm', ']', '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') & = & \nn_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') + ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc,nc'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') = 1\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sr-c1b')]), '  ', '[', '2mm', ']', '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_', BraceGroup('coh'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') & = & \n2 n_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')', '\\,', 'n(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ') +\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('coh,nc'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') =\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')-1\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sr-c1c')]), '  ', '[', '2mm', ']', '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') & = & \nn_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '^2 +\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') = ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '^2\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sr-c1d')]), '  ', '[', '2mm', ']', '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('inc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') & = & \nn_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '^2 +\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc,nc'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') = ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '^2\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sr-c1e')]), '  ', '[', '2mm', ']', '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('coh'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') & = & \n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('coh,nc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') = 0  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sr-c1f')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha'), ')'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ')'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha'), ')'), '_', BraceGroup('(inc,coh),nc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ')'], []), ' refer to the\ncontribution to the sum rules coming from the integral of the\nnon--condensate parts of the different responses.\n\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sr-c1a')]), ') yields the values of the static structure factor\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' as obtained from the direct\nintegration of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sqwb1')]), '). Two different contributions appear\nat temperatures below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), '. The first one results from the\ncondensate term in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ', ', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' and\nso is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), '. The contribution of this term\nto the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' sum rule grows as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '/', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '^2)'], []), ' at low momentum\ntransfer because at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '<', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ' the low ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' states\nclose to the condensate are populated according to a\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '/', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '^2'], []), ' law. Notice that this is an entirely coherent\neffect as can be seen from Eqs.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sr-c1b')]), ') and~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sr-c1c')]), ').\nThis behavour can be smeared out when particle interactions are\nallowed to take place as happens in liquid ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^4'], []), 'He at low\ntemperatures. Also, as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '^', BraceGroup('-1/2'), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ',\n', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') = ', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' is a\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), '--independent function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ', the zero order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), '--weighted moment of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ' yields an universal curve from where both the\nevolution with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' and the evolution with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c)'], []), ' can be\nextracted. According to the previous definitions\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup('(n)'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q)=', TexCmd('int'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), '^n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') d', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '^', BraceGroup('n+3/2'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '^', BraceGroup('(n)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('Y')]), ')'], []), '.\n\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q)'], []), ' is depicted in the upper plot of\nFigure~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-e')]), ').  At low ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), ', that is, at low momenta compared to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '^', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ', the divergences appearing in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ' at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=', TexCmd('pm'), ' Q^2'], []), ' take most of the strength and as a result\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q)'], []), ' increases. However, the singularities in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=', TexCmd('pm'), ' Q^2'], []), ' are of the logarithmic type and thus\ntheir ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), '--weighted integrals of the response give always finite\nresults consistent with Eqs.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sr-c1d')]), ')--(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sr-c1f')]), '). On the\nother hand, in the large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), ' limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q)'], []), ' approaches the\nconstant value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c^', BraceGroup('-3/2'), TexCmd('approx'), ' 0.058'], []), ', a result that is\nconsistent with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ',', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' going to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1-n_0(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' and the temperature dependence of the condensate\nfraction value reported in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sqwc1b')]), '). When this value is\nreached the total ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ',', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' equals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '.  The\nhigh ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), ' limit can be reached either rising ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' at fixed\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' or lowering ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' at fixed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), '. Therefore,\nno matter what the value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' is, at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '\\!', TexCmd('to'), '\\!', '0'], []), ' the\nstatic structure factor goes to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ', a fact that is consistent with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ',', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '=0)'], []), ' being completely\nincoherent and equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '-', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '^2)'], []), '.\nWhen the temperature is risen, the total response receives\ncontributions from the non--condensate terms and thus\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' grows. Finally, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), '\nreaches the transition temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q)'], []), ' equals\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(Q)'], []), ' but its value depends on the the momentum transfer. If\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' is still high compared to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c^', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ', the\nnon--condensate part of the total response does not qualitatively\ndiffer from the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '=0'], []), ' case and thus the the static structure\nfactor remains close to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '. Otherwise, the response enters into the\nlow ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), ' regime as seen in Fig.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-a')]), ') and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ';\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' departs from unity. Taking into account that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')=1'], []), ' and that the coherent response of\nthe free Bose gas is positive defined, the asymptotic value\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')=1'], []), ' is always reached from above.\n\nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' exceeds the Bose--Einstein transition temperature the\ncondensate fraction value decays to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' and the previous sum rules\ncoincide with their non--condensate parts. The evolution with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' is sketched in the\nlower plot of Fig.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-e')]), ').\n\nAs the logarithmic singularities in the dynamic structure function are\nsmeared out at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '>', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ', the limiting value\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '\\!', TexCmd('to'), '\\!', '0; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' now becomes finite. When\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' increases, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' decreases and\nasymptotically approaches ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' from above, thus indicating that the\ntotal response is reaching the incoherent limit in which\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ',', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')', '\\!', '~', TexCmd('approx'), '~', '\\!', '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ',', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('coh'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ',', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '; ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')', '\\!', '~', '\\!', TexCmd('approx'), '~0'], []), '.\nIn the high ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ';\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')', '\\!', TexCmd('approx'), '\\!', '1'], []), ' at all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), "'s and this reveals that the\nclassical limit has almost been reached, as\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' is known to be equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' for\nall ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), '. Moreover this limit is consistently reached when\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '\\!', TexCmd('to'), '\\!', TexCmd('infty')], []), ', as in fact it is straightforwardly seen from\nthe very definition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' that this can be achieved either\nincreasing the temperature at fixed density or reducing the density at\nfixed temperature.\n\nAnother interesting feature of the high momentum transfer behaviour of\nthe response is the  scaling property, as it is well known that\nwhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '\\!', TexCmd('to'), '\\!', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' the dynamic structure function does not\ndepend anymore on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega')], []), ' separately but only\nthrough the West scaling variable\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('y')]), '=(', TexCmd('tilde'), TexCmd('omega'), '/', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '-', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), ')/2'], []), TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('west')]), '.\n\nIn the free Bose gas case scaling may be reached in two different ways\ndepending on the temperature. At ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '\\!', TexCmd('leq'), '\\!', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ' this\ncan be done introducing a Compton profile \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^-_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q,Y;', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' as follows\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^-_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q,Y;', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') = 2 Q', '\\,', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('j-b1')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y=(', TexCmd('nu'), '/Q-Q)/2'], []), '. With this definition,\nthe non--condensate contribution to the incoherent response becomes\ntemperature and momentum independent\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('hat'), ' J^-_', BraceGroup('inc,nc'), '(Y) = -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('8', TexCmd('pi'), '^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('ln', [BracketGroup('1-e^', BraceGroup('-Y^2'), ' ')]), '  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('j-c1')]), '\n'], []), '\nand so becomes an universal function valid for all values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ' as\nlong as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), '. The non--condensate contribution\nto the total response reaches the incoherent limit at high momentum\ntransfers, so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^-_', BraceGroup('nc'), '(Q,Y;', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' approaches\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^-_', BraceGroup('nc,inc'), '(Y)'], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q', '\\!', TexCmd('to'), '\\!', TexCmd('infty')], []), '. This is indeed the\ncase as shown in Fig.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-f')]), '). As can be seen, already at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q=2'], []), '\nthe incoherent limit seems to be almost reached, which means that at\nany temperature below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ' scaling is well recovered when the\ntransferred momentum is larger than\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('q')]), '=2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' T_c')]), '\\!', TexCmd('approx'), '\\!', '5'], []), '.\n\nScaling can also be recovered at temperatures above the Bose--Einstein\ntransition temperature. However in that case the following alternative\ndefinition of the Compton profile may be used\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^+(Q,Y;', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ') = 2Q', '\\,', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '^', BraceGroup('3/2'), ' ', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ';', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('j-d1')]), '\n'], []), '\nWith this definition, the classical response becomes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), '--independent according to the expression\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^+_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(Y) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]))]), '\\,', 'e^', BraceGroup('-Y^2'), '  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('j-d2')]), '\n'], []), '\nand therefore this is the limiting case to which the response of the\nfree Bose gas tends when the temperature is risen. The response\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^+(Q,Y;', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' and the incoherent response\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^+_', BraceGroup('inc'), '(Q,Y;', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ')'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q=1'], []), ' are compared at different\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), "'s with ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '_', BraceGroup('cl'), '^', BraceGroup('+'), '(Y)'], []), ' in Fig.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-g')]), '). Both\nfunctions approach the classical behaviour when the temperature is\nrisen, even though it is remarkable how far should the temperature go\nin order to reach that limit. In any case and as expected, the\nincoherent response approaches faster ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^+_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(Y)'], []), ', a fact that\ncan be understood recalling that the total response contains also\ncoherent contributions that do not scale in the same variables. In\nthis way, the different velocity at which both functions approach\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^+_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(Y)'], []), ' gives a measure of how fast the coherent response\ngoes to zero.  Finally the main reason why the scaling in\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('j-d1')]), ') is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '^', BraceGroup('3/2')], []), ' may be\nunderstood recalling that in the classical regime ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' is proportional\nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '^', BraceGroup('3/2')], []), ', so that in the end both dependencies cancel and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('J')]), '^+_', BraceGroup('cl'), '(Y)'], []), ' becomes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), '--independent. This explains\nwhy the scaling law at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '>', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '\\!', TexCmd('leq'), '\\!', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '_c'], []), ' should be different, as in the latter\ncase the fugacity vanishes and therefore it can not introduce any\nexplicit dependence on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' as happens at high temperatures.\n\nIn summary, the dynamic structure function of the free Bose gas at\nfinite temperatures is shown to contain both coherent and incoherent\ncontributions. At low temperatures compared to the Bose--Einstein\ntransition temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_c'], []), ' , the total response is mainly incoherent\nand tends to the limiting incoherent value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '(', TexCmd('omega'), '-q^2/2m)'], []), '.\nWhen the temperature is risen, coherent contributions presenting\nlogarithmic singularities at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '=', TexCmd('pm'), ' q^2/2m'], []), ' appear, and they\nactually overcome the contribution of the incoherent response when\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T', TexCmd('approx'), ' T_c'], []), '.  When ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is increased above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_c'], []), ', the logarithmic\ndivergences disappear but a visible signature of their presence below\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_c'], []), ' still remain in both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('inc')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('coh')], []), '.  When ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T', TexCmd('gg'), ' T_c'], []), '\nthe coherent response cancels while the incoherent and total responses\napproach the classical limit.\n\nThe incoherent limit is always recovered when the transferred momentum\nis high, while the classical limit is only reached at high ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '. Below\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_c'], []), ', the presence of singularities in the response is also reflected\nin their lowest order energy--weighted sum rules. Finally, in the high\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), ' limit the total response can be written in the form of a Compton\nprofile that scales in the West scaling variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), '. The temperature\ndependence can also be removed from the response by using an\napproppriate redefinition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ', even though the transformation is\ndifferent at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T<T_c'], []), ' and at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T>T_c'], []), ' due to the different temperature\ndependence of the chemical potential.  Despite the simplicity of the\nsystem analyzed and the fact that the excitation spectrum of an\ninteracting bose system will be different the results described in\nthis work are expected to enlight some aspects of the finite\ntemperature response of both weakly and strong interacting Bose\nsystems.\n\n', TexCmd('acknowledgements'), '\n', '\nThis work has been  partially supported by the Austrian Science Fund under\ngrant No. P12832-TPH,   DGICYT (Spain) grant No. PB95-1249 and \nthe program SGR98-11 from ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' Generalitat de Catalunya'), '.\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(' Non-condensate contributions to the total (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ',\nsolid lines), coherent (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('coh'), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ', dashed lines) and\nincoherent (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup('inc'), '(Q,', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ', dotted lines), for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q=0.7,1.5'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ', at any temperature below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), ' T_c'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-a')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', We study nuclear burning, \n  hydrodynamic instabilities and explosion of very massive stars. Use a \n  new radiation-hydrodynamics code, .\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig:PSN-e'), BraceGroup()])), 'Figure~')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('intro')]), '\nThe first stars that formed after the big bang may have had a \ncharacteristic mass scale about hundred times heavier than modern \nstars ', TexCmd('citep', [BraceGroup('abel,bromm')]), '. Stars with initial mass between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ensuremath', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot')))])), '140', '\\,'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ensuremath', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot')))])), '260', '\\,'], []), ' end their lives in a very powerful explosion, a pair-instability \nsupernova (PSN) ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('barkat,bond')]), '. Such supernovae could play an important role \nin the synthesis of the first heavy elements ', TexCmd('citep', [BraceGroup('heger1')]), '. The energy\noutput into their surroundings can affect the structure and evolution \nof the early universe. Current theoretical models \nof PSN are mostly based on one-dimensional calculations ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('heger1')]), '. \nUntil now, multidimensional simulations have been scarce, however. Here we present \n2D simulations that aim to study how fluid instabilities affect the \nnucleosynthesis and energetics of PSN. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Numerical Approach')]), '\n We start our simulations using one-dimensional models \nobtained from the  code ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('weaver')]), ', an implicit spherically symmetric \nLagrangian hydrodynamics code. We follow the 1D stellar evolution until \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10'], []), ' secs before maximum compression. Then we map the resulting\n1D profiles into 2D using a conservative mapping procedure \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ken')]), ' to serve as the initial conditions for a new Eulerian AMR code,  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ann1')]), '. \nWe follow the contraction, burning, and onset of explosion for about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['100'], []), ' secs. During this \nperiod, thermonuclear burning releases almost all \nof the explosion energy.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Results and Discussion')]), '\nThe results presented here are from a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ensuremath', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('M')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('odot')))])), '150', '\\,'], []), ' star for which we simulate one hemisphere \nusing cylindrical symmetry.  shows the oxygen mass \nfraction in the inner ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ensuremath', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('powersep', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ensuremath', [BraceGroup('10^', BraceGroup('10'))]))]))])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ensuremath', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('cm')]))])), '2', '\\,'], []), ' domain at about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['60'], []), ' secs after maximum \ncompression. Later, we expect that these instabilities grow \nfurther after passing of the reverse shock. They could lead to large-scale mixing and affect \nthe observable PSN light curve. TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' be an integral convex polytope, \nthat is, a convex polytope whose vertices have integer coordinates, \nof dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '. We say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')], []), ' is a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' Fano polytope'), ' \nif the origin of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), '^d'], []), ' is a unique integer point in the interior of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')], []), '. \n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nIn particular, smooth Fano polytopes are always terminal, Gorenstein and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Q')], []), '-factorial. \n\nFano polytopes have been studied by many people. \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('O')), 'bro ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Oeb')]), ' constructed the so-called SFP-algorithm which yields \nthe complete classification list of the smooth Fano polytopes of dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' \nfor any given positive integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '. TexCmd('leq'), ' 4'], []), ' by Kreuzer and Skarke ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KS98, KS00')]), '. \nThe study of the classification of Fano polytopes of dimension three was done \nby Kasprzyk ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup('l+1'), '=i_1'], []), '. \nThe length of a cycle is the number of vertices (or edges) forming a cycle. \nFor a cycle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '=(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma')), '^', BraceGroup('(-)'), '=\n', '\\{', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma')), '^', BraceGroup('(-)'), '|'], []), ' \nand ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' homogeneous'), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('Delta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma')), '^', BraceGroup('(+)'), '| = |', TexCmd('Delta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma')), '^', BraceGroup('(-)'), '|'], []), '. \nNote that two arrows ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(j,i)'], []), ' form a nonhomogeneous cycle of length two. \nEvery odd cycle is nonhomogeneous. \n(Here odd (resp. even) cycle is a cycle of odd (resp. even) length.) \nThe following result can be proved by similarly to ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Proposition 1.3'), BraceGroup('OhsugiHibi')]), ' and ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 1.1'), BraceGroup('hamiltonian')]), '. \n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('Proposition', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '\nOne has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dim', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')]), '(_G) = d-1'], []), ' if and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' has a nonhomogeneous cycle. \n'], [BracketGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Proposition 1.3'), BraceGroup('OhsugiHibi')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 1.1'), BraceGroup('hamiltonian')])))]), '\n', '\nWe assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' has at least one nonhomogeneous cycle. \n\nNext, we investigate directed graphs which define Fano polytopes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), '. \nOnce we know that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is a Fano polytope, \none can verify that it is terminal and Gorenstein (', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 1.4 and 1.5'), BraceGroup('HibiH')]), '). \nThe following result can be proved similarly to ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Proposition 4.2'), BraceGroup('MHNOH')]), ' and ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 1.2'), BraceGroup('hamiltonian')]), '. \n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('Proposition', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tGF')]), '\nAn integral convex polytope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), ' is a terminal Gorenstein Fano polytope of dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-1'], []), ' \nif and only if every arrow of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' appears in a directed cycle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', \nwhere a cycle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' is called a directed cycle if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma')), '^', BraceGroup('(-)')], []), ' is empty. \n'], [BracketGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Proposition 4.2'), BraceGroup('MHNOH')]), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Lemma 1.2'), BraceGroup('hamiltonian')])))]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nHereafter, we assume that every arrow of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' appears in a directed cycle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \nNotice that by this condition, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' has a nonhomogeneous cycle since every directed cycle is nonhomogeneous. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('Example', [], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a directed graph on the vertex set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '1,2,3', '\\}'], []), ' \nwith the arrow set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '(1,2),(2,1),(2,3),(3,1)', '\\}'], []), '. Then \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e')]), ')'], []), "'s and ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pc'), '_G'], []), ' are as Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('example1')]), ': \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.4'), BraceGroup('example1.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('example1')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('htb!')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nRemark that the arrows ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1,2),(2,3),(3,1)'], []), ' and the arrows ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1,2),(2,1)'], []), ' form directed cycles. \nIn the picture of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pc'), '_G'], []), ', we ignore the third coordinate of each integer point. \nThen the convex polytope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pc'), '_G'], []), ' of this example becomes \na smooth (in particular, terminal and Gorenstein) Fano polytope of dimension two. \n')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('Remark', [], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' \nIn ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('HibiH')]), ', terminal Gorenstein Fano polytopes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Qc'), '_P'], []), ' arising from \nfinite partially ordered sets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' are introduced. \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P=', '\\{', 'y_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',y_d', '\\}'], []), ' be a partially ordered set \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('P')]), '=P ', TexCmd('union'), ' ', '\\{', 'y_0,y_', BraceGroup('d+1'), '\\}'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y_0=', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('0')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y_', BraceGroup('d+1'), '=', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('1')])], []), '. \nThen we can regard ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('P')])], []), ' as the directed graph on the vertex set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '0,1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',d+1', '\\}'], []), ' \nwith the arrow set ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\\{', '(i,j) : y_j ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' covers ')]), ' y_i ', '\\}', '.'], []), ' \nIdentifying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d+1'], []), ' as the same vertex, we obtain a directed graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_P'], []), ' \non the vertex set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',d+1', '\\}'], []), '. \nThen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Qc'), '_P'], []), ' is nothing but ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pc'), '_', BraceGroup('G_P')], []), '. \nTherefore, terminal Gorenstein Fano polytopes associated with directed graphs \nare a natural generalization of those defined in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('HibiH')]), '. \nWe can study these polytopes in Section 2 in the similar way. \n')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('When is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Pc'), '_G'], []), ' smooth ?')]), '\n', '\nIn this section, we consider the problem of which \ndirected graphs yield smooth Fano polytopes. \n\nFirst, we prove the following \n', TexNamedEnv('Lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('lemma'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(a)')]), ' \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')'], []), ' be a cycle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \nIf there exists a facet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' with \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), '),', TexCmd('ldots', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')]), ',', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' is homogeneous. \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(b)'), ' Suppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j) ', TexCmd('in'), ' A(G)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(j,i) ', TexCmd('in'), ' A(G)'], []), '. \nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '((i,j))'], []), ' is contained in some facet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '((j,i))'], []), ' is not in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), '. \n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n', '(a) Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1x_1+', TexCmd('cdots'), '+a_dx_d=1'], []), ', where each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Q'), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', \ndenote the equation of the supporting hyperplane of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' which defines a facet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), '. \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j=', '\\{', 'i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '\\}'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup('l+1'), '=i_1'], []), '. \nIt then follows that ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^l(a_', BraceGroup('i_j'), '-a_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('j+1')), ') \n=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), '_C^', BraceGroup('(+)')), '(a_', BraceGroup('i_j'), '-a_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('j+1')), ') \n-', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), '_C^', BraceGroup('(-)')), '(a_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('j+1')), '-a_', BraceGroup('i_j'), ')\n=|', TexCmd('Delta'), '_C^', BraceGroup('(+)'), '|-|', TexCmd('Delta'), '_C^', BraceGroup('(-)'), '|=0.'], []), ' \nHence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' must be homogeneous. \n\n(b) We set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1x_1+', TexCmd('cdots'), '+a_dx_d=1'], []), ' as above and suppose that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '((i,j))'], []), ' lies on this supporting hyperplane. Then one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i-a_j=1'], []), '. Thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_j-a_i=-1'], []), '. \nThis implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '((j,i))'], []), ' cannot be contained in the same supporting hyperplane. \n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nNext, we prepare two notions, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_C'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dist'), '_G'], []), '. \n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C = (', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')'], []), ' be a homogeneous cycle of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l'], []), ', \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j=', '\\{', 'i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '\\}'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup('l+1'), '=i_1'], []), '. \nThen there exists a unique function \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_C:', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Z'), '\\{', 'i_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',i_l', '\\}', ' arrow _', BraceGroup(TexCmd('geq'), ' 0')], []), '\nsuch that \n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nFor two distinct vertices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', \nthe ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' distance'), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ', denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i,j)'], []), ', \nis the length of the shortest directed path in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), '. \nIf there exists no directed path from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ', \nthen the distance from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' is defined to be infinity. \n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('Theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('main')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a connected directed graph on the vertex set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',d', '\\}'], []), ' \nsatisfying that every arrow of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' appears in a directed cycle of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \nThen the following conditions are equivalent: \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(i)'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Q')], []), '-factorial; ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(ii)'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is smooth; \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(iii)'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' possesses no homogeneous cycle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')'], []), ' such that \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq1')]), '\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_C(i_a)-', TexCmd('mu'), '_C(i_b) ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_a,i_b)\n'], []), '\nfor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' a,b ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j=', '\\{', 'i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '\\}'], []), ' \nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup('l+1'), '=i_1'], []), '. \n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' \nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' possesses a homogeneous cycle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' satisfying ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq1')]), ' \nand let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')'], []), ' be such cycle, \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j=', '\\{', 'i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '\\}'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '=i_1'], []), '. \nThen one has ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^lq_j', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), ')=(0,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',0),'], []), ' \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q_j=1'], []), ' ', '(resp. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q_j=-1'], []), ') if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), '=(i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), ')'], []), ' \n', '(resp. if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), '=(i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), ',i_j)'], []), ') for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), '. \nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' is homogeneous, one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^lq_j=0'], []), ', which implies that \nthe integer points ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), '),', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')'], []), ' are not affinely independent. \n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_j=', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), '. \nIn order to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is not simplicial, it suffices to find a face of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',v_l'], []), '. \n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',a_d'], []), ' be integers. We write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' for the hyperplane \ndefined by the equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1x_1+', TexCmd('cdots'), '+a_dx_d=1'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup('(+)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' for the closed half space \ndefined by the inequality ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1x_1+', TexCmd('cdots'), '+a_dx_d ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), '. \nWe will show that for suitable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',a_d'], []), ', we make ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H')], []), ' a supporting hyperplane of a face ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' \nsatisfying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'v_1,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F'), TexCmd('ldots'), ',v_l', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('(+)')], []), '. \n\nFirst, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('i_j'), '=', TexCmd('mu'), '_C(i_j)'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), '. \nIt then follows easily that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_j'], []), ' lies on the hyperplane \ndefined by the equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^la_', BraceGroup('i_j'), 'x_', BraceGroup('i_j'), '=1'], []), '. \n\nNext, we determine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_k'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('in'), ' A=', '\\{', '1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',d', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' ', '\\{', 'i_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',i_l', '\\}'], []), '. \nWe set ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['a_k=', TexCmd('max'), '(', '\\{', 'a_', BraceGroup('i_j'), '-', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,k)', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('union'), ' ', '\\{', '0', '\\}', ').'], []), ' \nIn particular, we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_k=0'], []), ' when there is no ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_j'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,k) < ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '. \nHere, we notice that one has \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq2')]), '\na_k ', TexCmd('leq'), " a_k', \n"], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["a_k'=", TexCmd('min'), '(', '\\{', 'a_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup("j'")), '+', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ')', '\\}', ')'], []), '. \nIn fact, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["a_k > a_k'"], []), ', then there are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_j'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup("j'")], []), ' such that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,k) < ', TexCmd('infty'), ', ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ') < ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('i_j'), ' - ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,k) > a_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup("j'")), ' + ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ')'], []), '. \nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,k) + ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ') ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ')'], []), ', one has \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_C(i_j)-', TexCmd('mu'), '_C(i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ')=a_', BraceGroup('i_j'), '-a_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup("j'")), ' \n> ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,k) + ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ') ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ').'], []), ' \nThis contradicts ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq1')]), '. \n\nNow we finish determining the integers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',a_d'], []), '. Since each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_j'], []), ' lies on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H')], []), ', \nin order to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' is defined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H')], []), ', it suffices to show ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('(+)'), '.'], []), ' \n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j) ', TexCmd('in'), ' A(G)'], []), '. When ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', 'i_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',i_l', '\\}'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j ', TexCmd('in'), ' A'], []), ', \nthen one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_j ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('max'), '(', '\\{', 'a_i-1,0', '\\}', ')'], []), ' by the definition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_j'], []), '. Hence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i - a_j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), '. \nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i ', TexCmd('in'), ' A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', 'i_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',i_l', '\\}'], []), ', then one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' a_j + 1'], []), ' by ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq2')]), '. \nHence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i - a_j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), '. \n\nLet ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['B=', '\\{', 'k ', TexCmd('in'), ' A : ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('there is ')]), ' i_j ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' with ')]), ' ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(i_j,k) < ', TexCmd('infty'), '\\}'], []), ' \nand ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['C=', '\\{', 'k ', TexCmd('in'), ' A : ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('there is ')]), ' i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' with ')]), ' ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k,i_', BraceGroup("j'"), ') < ', TexCmd('infty'), '\\}', '.'], []), ' \nAgain, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j) ', TexCmd('in'), ' A(G)'], []), '. In each of the nine cases below, \nby a routine computation, we can easily show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '((i,j))'], []), ' is in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup('(+)')], []), '. \n', TexNamedEnv('align*', ['\n', '&(1) ', '\\;', ' i ', TexCmd('in'), ' B ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' C ', '\\;', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '\\;', ' j ', TexCmd('in'), ' B ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' C; ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' \n', '&(2) ', '\\;', ' i ', TexCmd('in'), ' C ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' B ', '\\;', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '\\;', ' j ', TexCmd('in'), ' C ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' B; \n&(3) ', '\\;', ' i ', TexCmd('in'), ' C ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' B ', '\\;', TexCmd('text', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '\\;', ' j ', TexCmd('not'), TexCmd('in'), ' B ', TexCmd('union'), ' C. \n'], []), '\n', '\nFor example, a routine computation of (1) is as follows. \nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i=0'], []), ', since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_j ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ', one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i-a_j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 0 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), '. \nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i >0'], []), ', since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_j ', TexCmd('geq'), ' a_i -1'], []), ', one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i-a_j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), '. \n\nTherefore, it follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H')], []), ' is \na supporting hyperplane of a face of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' which is not a simplex. \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((iii) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Rightarrow')], []), ' ', '(i))'), ' \nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n > d-1'], []), ', \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_n')])], []), ' the arrows with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_j = ', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' n'], []), '. \nWe write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' for the supporting hyperplane ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_1x_1+', TexCmd('cdots'), '+a_dx_d=1'], []), ' defining ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), '. \nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',v_n'], []), ' are not affinely independent, \nthere is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(r_1,', TexCmd('ldots', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R')]), ',r_n) ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '^n'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(r_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',r_n) ', TexCmd('not'), '= (0,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',0)'], []), ' \nsatisfying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^nr_j=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^nr_jv_j=(0,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',0)'], []), '. \nBy removing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_j'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_j = 0'], []), ', we may assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^', BraceGroup("n'"), 'r_jv_j=(0,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',0)'], []), ', \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_j ', TexCmd('not'), '= 0'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), " n'"], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^', BraceGroup("n'"), 'r_j=0'], []), '. \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_j')]), "=(i_j,i_j')"], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), " i_j,i_j' ", TexCmd('leq'), ' d'], []), ' and \nlet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' denote the subgraph of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with the arrow set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_', BraceGroup("n'"))]), '\\}'], []), '. \nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup("G'"), '(i_j)=1'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup("G'"), "(i_j')=1"], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_j=0'], []), ', a contradiction. \n(For a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and its vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_G(v)'], []), ' denotes the number of edges ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v ', TexCmd('in'), ' e'], []), '.) \nThus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup("G'"), '(i_j) ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), '_', BraceGroup("G'"), "(i_j') ", TexCmd('geq'), ' 2'], []), '. \nBy Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('lemma')]), ' ', '(b), since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), '),', TexCmd('ldots', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')]), ',', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_', BraceGroup("n'"))]), ')', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), ', \nit cannot happen that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j=e_k'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('not'), '= k ', TexCmd('leq'), " n'"], []), '. \nMoreover, since every vertex in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is at least degree 2, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is not a tree. Hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' contains a cycle, which is homogeneous by Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('lemma')]), ' ', '(a). \n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_1')]), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e_l')]), ')'], []), ' be a homogeneous cycle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j=', '\\{', 'i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '\\}'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '=i_1'], []), '. \nOur goal is to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' satisfies the inequality (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq1')]), '). \n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '=(k_0,k_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',k_m)'], []), ' be the directed shortest path in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' \nsuch that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_m'], []), ' belong to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'i_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',i_l', '\\}'], []), '. \nOn the one hand, since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bold'), ' e'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bold'), ' e'), BraceGroup('k_j'), '-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_', BraceGroup('k_', BraceGroup('j+1')), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_G'], []), ', \none has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('k_j'), '-a_', BraceGroup('k_', BraceGroup('j+1')), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' m-1'], []), '. \nHence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('k_0'), '-a_', BraceGroup('k_m'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' m=', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k_0,k_m)'], []), '. \nOn the other hand, we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('k_0'), '-a_', BraceGroup('k_m'), ' = ', TexCmd('mu'), '_C(k_0)-', TexCmd('mu'), '_C(k_m).'], []), ' \nThus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_C(k_0)-', TexCmd('mu'), '_C(k_m) ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('dist'), '_G(k_0,k_m)'], []), '. \nTherefore, the required inequality ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eq1')]), ' holds. \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((i) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Rightarrow')], []), ' ', '(ii))'), ' \nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is simplicial. \nThen there are just ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-1'], []), ' vertices in each facet, which are linearly independent. Let \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '\nbe the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(d-1) ', TexCmd('times'), ' d'], []), ' matrix whose row vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Z'), BraceGroup('d-1'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' are \nthe vertices of a facet of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(d-1) ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(d-1)'], []), ' submatrix of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' \nignoring the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), 'th column of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '. \nFrom the theory of totally unimodular matrices ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Sch')]), ', \nthe determinant of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' is equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), ' 1'], []), ', \nwhich means that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is smooth. \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((ii) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Rightarrow')], []), ' ', '(i))'), ' \nIn general, every smooth Fano polytope is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Q')], []), '-factorial. \n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((i) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Rightarrow')], []), ' ', '(iii))')]), '\n', '\nFor a directed graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', we say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' symmetric'), ' \nif ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(j,i) ', TexCmd('in'), ' A(G)'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j) ', TexCmd('in'), ' A(G)'], []), ', that is, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2|E(G)|=|A(G)|'], []), '. \nNote that when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is symmetric, every arrow of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is contained \nin a directed cycle of length two, \nso ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is always a terminal Gorenstein Fano polytope. \n\nRecall that for a connected graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', we say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' two-connected'), ' \nif the induced subgraph with the vertex set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V(G) ', TexCmd('backslash'), ' ', '\\{', 'i', '\\}'], []), ' \nis still connected for any vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i ', TexCmd('in'), ' V(G)'], []), ', \nand a subgraph of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' two-connected component'), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' \nif it is a maximal two-connected subgraph in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \n\n\nFor symmetric directed graphs, we obtain the following \n', TexNamedEnv('Corollary', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('noeven')]), '\nAssume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a connected symmetric directed graph. \nThen the following conditions are equivalent: \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(i)'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' Q')], []), '-factorial; ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(ii)'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is smooth; \n', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(iii)'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' contains no even cycle; \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(iv)'), ' every two-connected component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is \neither one edge or an odd cycle. \n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' \nThis equivalence follows from Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('main')]), '. \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((i) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Rightarrow')], []), ' ', '(iii))'), ' \nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' possesses an even cycle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2l'], []), '. \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=(e_', BraceGroup('i_1'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',e_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('2l')), ')'], []), ' be a cycle, \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j=', '\\{', 'i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), '\\}'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' 2l'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup('2l+1'), '=i_1'], []), '. \nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is symmetric, there are arrows of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['(i_2,i_1),(i_2,i_3),(i_4,i_3),(i_4,i_5),', TexCmd('ldots'), ',(i_', BraceGroup('2l'), ',i_', BraceGroup('2l-1'), '),(i_', BraceGroup('2l'), ',i_1).'], []), ' \nWe define ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',v_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), BraceGroup('2l'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' by setting \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nv_j=\n', TexNamedEnv('cases', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), '((i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), ',i_j)), ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', '&j=1,3,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',2l-1, \n', TexCmd('rho'), '((i_j,i_', BraceGroup('j+1'), ')), &j=2,4,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',2l. \n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nThen one has ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^lv_', BraceGroup('2j-1'), ' + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^l(-1)v_', BraceGroup('2j'), ' = (0,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',0).'], []), ' \nThus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',v_', BraceGroup('2l')], []), ' are not affinely independent. \nHence, we may show that there is a face ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'v_1,', TexCmd('ldots', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')]), ',v_', BraceGroup('2l'), '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), '. \n\nNow, we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup('2j-1'), '=-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e'), '_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('2j-1')), '+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e'), '_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('2j'))], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_', BraceGroup('2j'), '=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e'), '_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('2j')), '-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e'), '_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('2j+1'))], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' j ', TexCmd('leq'), ' l'], []), '. \nThus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',v_', BraceGroup('2l')], []), ' lie on the hyperplane ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' \ndefined by the equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_', BraceGroup('i_2'), '+x_', BraceGroup('i_4'), '+', TexCmd('cdots'), '+x_', BraceGroup('i_', BraceGroup('2l')), '=1'], []), '. In addition, \nit is clear that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e')]), ')'], []), ' is contained in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup('(+)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' for any arrow ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e')])], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \nHence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H')], []), ' is a supporting hyperplane defining a face ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' \nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'v_1,', TexCmd('ldots', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')]), ',v_', BraceGroup('2l'), '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), '. Therefore, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is not simplicial. \n\n\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((iii) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Rightarrow')], []), ' ', '(iv))'), ' \nWe prove this implication by elementary graph theory. Suppose that there is a two-connected component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' \nwhich is neither one edge nor an odd cycle. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' be such two-connected subgraph of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \nNow, an arbitrary two-connected graph with at least three vertices can be obtained by the following method: \nstarting from a cycle and repeatedly appending an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), '-path to a graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' \nthat has been already constructed. (Consult, e.g., ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Wilson')]), '.) \nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is not one edge, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' has at least three vertices. \nThus, there is one cycle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(m-1)'], []), ' paths ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_2,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_m'], []), ' such that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'=C_1 ", TexCmd('union'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_2 ', TexCmd('union'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', TexCmd('union'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_m'], []), '. \nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'"], []), ' is not an odd cycle, one has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["G'=C_1"], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_1'], []), ' is an even cycle, or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m > 1'], []), '. \nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m>1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_1'], []), ' is an odd cycle. \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' be distinct two vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_1'], []), ' which are intersected with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_2'], []), '. \nThen there are two paths in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_1'], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), '. \nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_1'], []), ' is odd, the parities of the lengths of such two paths are different. \nBy attaching the path ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_2'], []), ' to one or another of such two paths, \nwe can construct an even cycle. Therefore, there exists an even cycle. \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((iv) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Rightarrow')], []), ' ', '(i))'), ' \nSuppose that each two-connected component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is \neither one edge or an odd cycle. \nThen there is no homogeneous cycle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. \nHence, by Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('main')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_G'], []), ' is simplicial. \n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', '((i) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Leftrightarrow')], []), ' ', '(ii))')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The case where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' possesses no even cycle')]), ' \n', '\n', '\n', '\nIn this section, we show that every pseudo symmetric \nsmooth Fano polytope can be obtained from \nsome directed graph with no even cycle. \nThis fact includes the case of centrally symmetric smooth Fano polytopes. \n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), ' \n', '\n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '^d'], []), ' be a Fano polytope. \n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', [' \n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', '\nThere is a well-known fact on the characterization of \ncentrally symmetric or pseudo symmetric smooth Fano polytopes. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('Theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('delPezzo')]), ' \nAny centrally symmetric smooth Fano polytope splits into \ncopies of the closed interval ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '-1,1', ']'], []), ' or a del Pezzo polytope. \n'], [BracketGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('VK')])))]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('Theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pdelPezzo')]), ' \nAny pseudo symmetric smooth Fano polytope splits into \ncopies of the closed interval ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '-1,1', ']'], []), ' or a del Pezzo polytope \nor a pseudo del Pezzo polytope. \n'], [BracketGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ewald, VK')])))]), '\n', '\n', '\nSomewhat surprisingly, we also give the complete characterization of \ncentrally symmetric or pseudo symmetric smooth Fano polytopes \nby means of directed graphs. In fact, \n', TexNamedEnv('Theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('symmetricsmooth'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(a)')]), ' Any centrally symmetric smooth Fano polytope can be obtained \nfrom a symmetric directed graph with no even cycle. \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', '(b)'), ' Any pseudo symmetric smooth Fano polytope can be obtained \nfrom a directed graph with no even cycle. \n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nFirst, we prove (b). \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')], []), ' be an arbitrary pseudo symmetric smooth Fano polytope of dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '. \nBy Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('pdelPezzo')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')], []), ' splits into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_1,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), TexCmd('ldots'), ',_m'], []), ' \nwhich are copies of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '-1,1', ']'], BraceGroup("m'")], []), ' be del Pezzo polytopes, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_', BraceGroup("m'+1"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nBy connecting the above graphs with one vertex, \nwe obtain the directed graph with no even cycle which yields the required smooth Fano polytope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')], []), '. \n\nMoreover, del Pezzo polytopes and the closed interval ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '-1,1', ']'], []), ' are \nconstructed by
