Just finished parsing: ['{', '\\}', BraceGroup('cm'), '2', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['cm^', BraceGroup('-2')], [])), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', TexCmd('title*', [BraceGroup('How to make CMB maps from huge timelines with small computers')]), '\n', TexCmd('toctitle', [BraceGroup('How to make CMB maps from huge timelines with small computers')]), '\n', TexCmd('titlerunning', [BraceGroup('How to make CMB maps...')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('Xavier Dupac\n', TexCmd('and'), ' Martin Giard'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al.'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al.')]), ' \n', TexCmd('authorrunning', [BraceGroup('Dupac ', '\\&', ' Giard')]), '\n', TexCmd('institute', [BraceGroup("Centre d'", "\\'", 'Etude Spatiale des Rayonnements \n9, avenue du Colonel Roche \nBP 4346 \n31028 Toulouse cedex 4 \nFrance')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '              \n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\n', '\nWe present in this article two different ways to make CMB maps in practice,\nfrom large timelines.\nOne is to make a simple destriping, fitting the data and using the scan\nintercepts to remove the low frequency noise (stripes).\nThe second, optimal, is to resolve linearly the map-making problem, which in\ncase of big timelines must be simplified and changed from matrices to vectors\nfor the calculations.\nAssuming few conditions on the noise, it is possible to make fast map-making tools.\n\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nThe last ten and the future ten years provide a large number of CMB (Cosmic\nMicrowave Background) experiments.\nTheir main goal is to estimate the\ncosmological parameters through sky temperature maps.\nThe map-making is therefore a key question of these experiments, moreover with\nthe advent of large time-ordered data (TOD) being currently analysed or simulated.\nThe "brute force" direct inversion of the linear map-making problem is beyond\nthe reach of computing facilities of today.\nThus the data analysers need to find faster methods, which have to be as\noptimal in theory and as efficient in practice as possible.\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Destriping for Planck HFI data')]), '\n', '\nThis is used to clean Planck High Frequency Instrument (Bersanelli  1996) simulated data, to be published in\nGiard  (2000).\nIt uses a simple algorithm to destripe the data and make the map.\nThe scanning strategy assumed to make the timeline is 1 round per minute of\nthe beam on the sky, so that the timeline is a succession of circles on the\nsky.\nThe cleaning algorithm follow the processing described below:\nFirst each circle is adjusted so that the measured signal fits a cosecant law\n(galactic dust), plus dipole emission:\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' et al.'), ' ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nM_', BraceGroup('ik'), ' = r_k (Dipole_', BraceGroup('ik'), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('g_k'), BraceGroup('sin(bII_i)')]), ' + C^0_k)\n'], []), '\n', '\nwhere k is the index of each circle of the data, i the data index along the\ncircle, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_k'], []), ' the detector response.\nThe free parameters are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_k'], []), ' ', '(galactic emission for the circle k) and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C^0_k'], []), '\n', '(constant to be subtracted).\nThen we destripe the data using an algorithm derived from Delabrouille (1998)\nwhich uses the scan intercepts.\nWe adjust the constants to subtract to each circle k by minimising the spread\nbetween the measurements contributing to the same sky pixel.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The optimal method in practice')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The map-making problem')]), '\n', '\nIf we assume the instrument to be linear, the time-ordered data, represented\nby a vector y, is linearly\ndependent on the real sky, represented\nby a vector x.\nWe have thus:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\ny = A x + n\n'], []), '\n', '\nwhere A is the point-spread (convolution) matrix and n the random noise vector\nin the timeline.\nFor CMB experiments, x would represent the pixelised sky map of the CMB temperature.\nThe map-making problem is thus written as this:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nx_', BraceGroup('0'), ' = W y\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('deconv_eq')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_', BraceGroup('0')], []), ' is the vector of the reconstructed sky map, and W the inversion\nmatrix.\nThe inversion matrix W depends on the method used. The simplest\nis the pixel averaging, but\nthe optimal methods for estimating the map are the\nCOBE method (with no prior for x) or the Wiener filter (with gaussian prior\nfor x).\nSee Tegmark (1997) for a set of linear and non-linear map-making methods.\nAs an example, the COBE method is written as this:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nW = ', '[', 'A^', BraceGroup('t'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' A', ']', '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' A^', BraceGroup('t'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cobe')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nwith N the noise covariance matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N = <n n^', BraceGroup('t'), '>'], []), '.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The large timeline problem')]), '\n', '\nThe CMB experiments now in analysis (Boomerang, MAXIMA...) or to come\n(Archeops, MAP, Planck...) provide several megabytes of time-ordered\ndata.\nThe noise covariance matrix, for instance, would be several terabytes of data, which is\nimpossible to handle or even to write.\nHow to solve optimally the map-making problem without writing any matrix\nanywhere ?\n\nAssuming no beam and the stationarity of the noise, it is possible to make the\nmap iteratively handling only vectors.\nUsing the COBE method (eq. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cobe')]), '), the deconvolution equation (eq. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('deconv_eq')]), ') can be written as this:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' x_', BraceGroup('0'), ' = A^', BraceGroup('t'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' y\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqltm')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('A^', BraceGroup('t'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' A')]), '\n', '\nIf the noise is stationary, the matrix multiplication ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' y is equivalent to a convolution by a kernel, i.e. a\nmultiplication in the Fourier space.\nIf the beam is not taken into account, A is making a timeline from a map, and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A^', BraceGroup('t')], []), ' is the pixel averaging of a timeline into a map.\nEq. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqltm')]), ' leads to iterative methods such as:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nx_', BraceGroup('n+1'), ' = x_n + ', TexCmd('eta'), ' A^', BraceGroup('t'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' y - ', TexCmd('eta'), ' A^', BraceGroup('t'), ' N^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' A x_n\n'], []), '\n', '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' is a free parameter of the '\nOne-loop amplitudes contain two pieces referred to as the cut-constructible and rational pieces. \nIn massless gauge theories the cut-constructible part of one-loop amplitudes can be written as a sum over constituent basis integrals,\n', TexCmd('bea'), '\nC_4(', TexCmd('phi'), ',1^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_1'), ',2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_2'), ',3^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_3'), ',4^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '_4'), ')=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('C'), '_', BraceGroup('4;i'), BraceGroup('I'), '_', BraceGroup('4;i'), ' + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('C'), '_', BraceGroup('3;i'), BraceGroup('I'), '_', BraceGroup('3;i'), ' +', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), BraceGroup('C'), '_', BraceGroup('2;i'), BraceGroup('I'), '_', BraceGroup('2;i'), '.\n', TexCmd('eea'), '\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('I'), '_', BraceGroup('j;i')], []), ' represents a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), '-point scalar basis integral, with a coefficient\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('j;i')], []), '. The sum over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' represents the sum over the partitions of the external\nmomenta over the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' legs of the basis integral. \n\nMultiple cuts isolate different integral functions and allow the\nconstruction of a linear system of equations from which the coefficients can be extracted. When\nconsidering quadruple cuts of one-loop amplitudes, one is forced to consider complex momenta in\norder to fulfill the on-shell constraints~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Britto:2004nc')]), '. The four\non-shell constraints are sufficient to isolate each four-point (box) \nconfiguration by freezing the loop momentum, thereby allowing the determination of the corresponding coefficient\nby a purely algebraic operation.\nTo isolate the coefficients of lower-point integrals, one needs to cut fewer than four lines.\nIn this case the loop momenta is no longer completely determined, but, according to the number of cuts, \nsome of its components are free variables. \nIn this case the computation of the three- (triangle) and two-point (bubble) coefficients can also be reduced \nto algebraic procedures by exploiting the singularity structure of amplitudes in the complex-plane ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Forde:intcoeffs')]), '.\nAlternatively one can extract the coefficients of bubble- and triangle-functions by employing \nthe spinor-integration technique ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Britto:sqcd,Britto:ccqcd')]), '.\nThis method has recently inspired a novel technique for evaluating the double-cut phase-space \nintegrals ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' via'), " Stokes' Theorem applied to functions of \ntwo complex-conjugated variables ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Mastrolia:2009dr')]), '. \n\nIn addition to the cut-constructible pieces one-loop QCD amplitudes contain pieces which cannot be reconstructed by four dimensional cuts. As such additional techniques have been used to calculate the one-loop ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' + 4 parton amplitudes. For the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), '-MHV, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), '-all minus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), ' q', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), '\n-MHV and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), ' q', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('q')]), 'Q', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('Q')])], []), ' helicity amplitudes the unitarity bootstrap method was employed ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Berger:genhels')]), '. In this approach one calculates the rational piece of the amplitudes from four-dimensional BCFW recursion relations ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Britto:proof')]), '.  For the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), '-NMHV and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), ' q', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('q')])], []), '-NMHV amplitudes the rational piece was TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phid')], []), ' amplitudes needed to construct a given\none-loop ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('q')]), 'qgg'], []), ' amplitude, together with the references where\nthey can be obtained.  In all cases the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phid')], []), ' amplitudes are\nconstructed from the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), ' amplitudes given in the reference, using\nthe parity operation.')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Haqggrefs')]))]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conclusion')]), '\n', '\nThis report summarises the recent completion of the analytic results for the process ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['pparrow H+2j'], []), '. The results were obtained by using the unitarity method to calcaulte the cut-constructible pieces of the amplitudes. The rational pieces were calculated with various techniques, for the non-NMHV helicity configurations the unitarity-bootstrap technique was used. For the most recent NMHV calculations the rational pieces were obtained from Feynman diagrams. The calculations were performed using an effective Lagrangian which simplifies the full theory in which the top quark loops are \nincluded. The effective theory provides an accurate prescription of the physics provided that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_H < 2m_t'], []), '.  It is hoped that the analytic formulae described here will aid in producing fast phenomenological studies of Higgs physics at hadron colliders. \n\n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgements')]), '\n', '\nI would like to thank my collaborators Simon Badger, John Campbell, Keith Ellis, Nigel Glover and Pierpaolo Mastrolia. BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '^2 #1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', '#2^2')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('Chiral orbital current and anomalous magnetic moment\nin gapped graphene')]), '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('Mikito Koshino')]), '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('\nDepartment of Physics, Tohoku University, \nSendai, 980--8578, Japan')]), '\n', TexCmd('date', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('today'))]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nWe present a low-energy effective-mass theory to describe\nchiral orbital current and anomalous magnetic moment\nin graphenes with band gap and related materials.\nWe explicitly derive a quantum mechanical current distribution\nin general Bloch electron systems,\nwhich describes a chiral current circulation supporting\nthe magnetic moment.\nWe apply the formulation to gapped graphene monolayer, bilayer \nand ABC-stacked multilayers,\nto show that the chiral current is opposite between different valleys,\nand corresponding magnetic moment\naccounts for valley splitting of Landau levels.\nIn gapped bilayer and ABC multilayer graphenes, in particular,\nthe valley-dependent magnetic moment is responsible for\nhuge paramagnetic susceptibility at low energy, which enables\na full valley polarization up to relatively high electron density.\nThe formulation also applies to the gapped surface states\nof three-dimensional topological insulator,\nwhere the anomalous current is related to\nthe magneto-electric response in spatially-modulated potential.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_intr')]), '\n', '\nThe magnetic moment in an electronic system consists of two distinct \nfactors due to spin and orbital motion of electrons.\nIn solids, the spin magnetic moment is enhanced by          \nanomalous factor caused by to the orbital effect,\nresulting in increase of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '-factor. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Yafet_1963,Kittel_1963')]), '\nGraphene ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Novoselov_et_al_2004a,Novoselov_et_al_2005a,Zhang_et_al_2005a')]), '\nhas an intriguing counterpart of spin, which is \nassociated with valley pseudo-spins,\ni.e., degree of freedom corresponding to different points\nin the Brillouin zone called ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_+'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_-'], []), ' valleys.\nSpecifically, when the band gap is opened by an asymmetric potential\nbreaking the sublattice symmetry,\nthe graphene electrons have \nanomalous magnetic moment opposite in different valleys\nsimilarly to real spin.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Xiao_et_al_2007,Yao_et_al_2008,Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\nGenerally the anomalous magnetic moment\nis closely related to the geometric nature of the Bloch band,\nand has been argued in relation to Berry phase.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chang_and_Niu_1996,Thonhauser_et_al_2005,Ceresoli_et_al_2006,Xiao_et_al_2005,Xiao_et_al_2010')]), '\nPreviously we calculated the orbital susceptibility\nin gapped monolayer and bilayer graphenes, and showed that\nthe susceptibility near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' point,\nwhere the dispersion is quadratic,\nis contributed from the Pauli paramagnetism caused by the valley pseudo-spin.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\n', '\nIn this paper, to understand the physical origin of pseudo-spin magnetic moment,\nand also to investigate the pseudo-spin magnetic moment\nin various electronic structures other than quadratic dispersion,\nwe develop a general low-energy effective-mass theory to describe\nanomalous current density supporting the magnetic moment.\nWe explicitly derive a quantum mechanical current distribution\nin general Bloch electron systems,\nwhich describes chiral current circulation\nfor each eigenstate. \nUsing the formula, we actually calculate the valley-dependent chiral current \nin gapped graphene monolayer, \nbilayer ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Novoselov_et_al_2006a,Ohta_et_al_2006a,Castro_et_al_2007b,Oostinga_et_al_2008a')]), ' \nand ABC-stacked multilayers ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lipson_et_al_1942,Haering_1958,McClure_1969')]), '.\nThe valley-dependent magnetic moment \nexactly gives the valley splitting of Landau levels,\ngeneralizing our previous results limited to \nthe quadratic dispersion. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\nIn gapped bilayer ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), ' \nand ABC multilayers, in particular,\nthe valley splitting and diverging density of states at the band bottom \nresult in a huge paramagnetic susceptibility,\nenabling  a full valley polarization \nup to relatively high electron density \nof the order of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup('12')], []), ' cm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), '\nat a magnetic field of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim')], []), ' 1 T.\n\nThe formulation also allows to include the external potential\nfield within the low-energy approximation,\nand thus useful to investigate the chiral current in disordered systems \nand also finite systems bound by potential barrier.\nIt also applies to the gapped surface states\nof the three-dimensional topological insulator,\nwhere the anomalous current describes\nthe magneto-electric response in a spatially-modulated potential.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Qi_et_al_2008,Essin_et_al_2009,Hasan_and_Kane_2010,Qi_and_Zhang_2010')]), '\n', '\nPaper is organized as follows.\nIn Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec_chiral')]), ', we present \nthe general effective mass description of\nthe anomalous current density for Bloch electrons.\nWe apply this to asymmetric monolayer, bilayer and\nABC multilayer graphenes\nin Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec_mono')]), ', Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec_bi')]), ' and Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec_abc')]), ', \nrespectively, to describe the chiral current circulation, \nmagnetic moment and valley splitting of Landau levels.\nIn Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec_pseudo')]), ', we calculate\nthe magnetic susceptibility and argue the role of the \nanomalous magnetic moment.\nWe describe in Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec_hall')]), ' \nthe current distribution in spatially modulated external potential,\nand formulate it in terms of a response function \nanalogous to the Hall conductivity.\nThe conclusion is given in Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec_concl')]), '.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Anomalous orbital current')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_chiral')]), '\n', '\nWe consider \na Bloch electron system described by\nan effective-mass Hamiltonian matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p'), BraceGroup("mm'"), '()'], []), ',\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')], []), ' is the crystal momentum, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["m'"], []), ' are band indeces. \nWe assume that the Hamiltonian is diagonalized at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p'), '=0'], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['_', BraceGroup("mm'"), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(0) = _', BraceGroup('m'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup("mm'"), ',\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '\nand, for simplicity, that there are no degeneracy at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p'), '=0'], []), '.\nIn presense of the external potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), 'V()'], []), ',\nthe effective-mass wavefunction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' F'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '()'], []), '\nobeys the Schr', '\\"', BraceGroup('o'), 'dinger equation\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup("m'"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup("mm'"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') F_', BraceGroup("m'"), '()\n= ', '[', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' - V()', ']', ' F_', BraceGroup('m'), '(),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_schro')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ' = -i ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla')], []), ', \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), ' is the eigen energy.\nWe assume ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|V|', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('ll'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '|^', BraceGroup('0'), '_m - ^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup("m'"), '|'], []), ',\nso that the states of different bands are not strongly mixed.\n\nWe focus on an eigenstate near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = ^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('n')], []), '\nof the particular band ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '.\nThen the wavefunction mainly has its amplitude on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_n'], []), '.\nBy the first-order perturbation, the amplitude at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('m ', TexCmd('neq'), ' n')], []), '\ncan be written in terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_n'], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n F_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup('m'), '() ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), TexCmd('approx'), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('p')])), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), ' - ', TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('m'))]), '\n F_', BraceGroup('n'), '().\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_Fm')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe Schr', '\\"', BraceGroup('o'), 'dinger equation, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_schro')]), '), then becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& ', '[', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), '(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') + V()', ']', ' F_', BraceGroup('n'), '() \n= ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '  F_', BraceGroup('n'), '(),\n'], []), '\nwith the effective Hamiltonian \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), '(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') = \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('nn'), '(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') + \n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('neq'), ' n'), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('nm'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('p')])), ')', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('p')])), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), ' - ', TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('m'))]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_red')]), '\n'], []), '\nCorrespondingly, we can define the effective velocity operator \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '(eff)')])), '_', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '_n(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('p')])), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial', [BraceGroup('p')]), '_', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup('n')]), '  ', '&= &\n,\n'], [BraceGroup('v')]), '\nand the local current density operator\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['_n^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '(eff)')])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R'), ' ', '() &=&\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), ' \n', '\\{', BraceGroup('v'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '(eff)')])), '_n, ', TexCmd('delta'), '(-)', '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-15mm')]), '\n=\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', TexCmd('Biggl', [BracketGroup('\n', '\\{', '\nv^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('nn'), ',\n', TexCmd('delta'), '(', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '-', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('R')]), ')\n', '\\}', '\n+\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('neq'), ' n'), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), ' - ', TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('m'))]), TexCmd('times'), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('-3mm')]), '\n', '\\{', '\n', '(v^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('nm'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('nm'), 'v^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), '),', '\\,', '\n', TexCmd('delta'), '(', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '-', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('R')]), ')\n', '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('Biggr'))]), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_jred')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('j')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'a,b', '\\}', ' = ab + ba'], []), ' is the anti-commutator, and\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '_', BraceGroup("mm'"), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('p')])), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial', [BraceGroup('p')]), '_', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup("mm'")]), '  =\n.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_v')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('v')]), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('j'), '_n^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '(eff)')]))], []), '\nactually covers only a part of the total current density\neven in the low-energy limit.\nThe original current density operator is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['^', TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), ' ', '() =\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), ' \n', '\\{', BraceGroup('v'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ', ', TexCmd('delta'), '(-)', '\\}', ',\n'], [BraceGroup('j')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is a matrix defined by Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_v')]), ').\nThe expectation value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', TexCmd('mu')], []), '\nfor a given state ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' F')], []), ' near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_n'], []), ' is written as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup('j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), ') ', TexCmd('rangle', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), '\n', '&=&\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup("mm'"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), ' \n', TexCmd('int', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), ' d', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), ' F_m^*() ', '[', BraceGroup('j'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '()', ']', '_', BraceGroup("mm'"), '\nF_', BraceGroup("m'"), '()\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('approx'), '&\n', TexCmd('int'), ' d F_n^*() \n', BraceGroup('j'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_n ()\nF_', BraceGroup('n'), '().\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_jav')]), '\n'], []), '\nIn the second equation we used Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_Fm')]), '),\nand defined,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R'), BraceGroup('j'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_n ()\n=\n-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', TexCmd('Biggl', [BracketGroup('\n', '\\{', '\nv^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('nn'), ',\n', TexCmd('delta'), '(', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '-', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('R')]), ')\n', '\\}', '\n+\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('neq'), ' n'), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), ' - ', TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('m'))]), TexCmd('times'), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('Bigl'), '(\n', '\\{', '\nv^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('nm'), ',\n', TexCmd('delta'), '(', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '-', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('R')]), ')\n', '\\}', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), '\n+\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('nm'), '\n', '\\{', 'v^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), ',\n', TexCmd('delta'), '(', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('r')]), '-', TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('R')]), ')\n', '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('Bigr'), ')\n', TexCmd('Biggr'))]), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&=\n ', BraceGroup('j'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')])), '_n ()\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('quad'), ' \n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('neq'), ' n'), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), ' - ', TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('m'))]), '\n', '(\nv^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('nm'), '[', TexCmd('delta'), '(-)\n,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), ']', ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' h.c.'), ').\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_j')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('j'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_n'], []), ' is not equivalent with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', BraceGroup('j'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')])), '_n'], []), '\nsince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('mn')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), '(-)'], []), '\ndo not generally commute. As shown in the following,\nthe second term, called anomalous current\nin the following, is responsible for the chiral current circulation\nin gapped graphenes.\n\nThe similar argument is available for the orbital magnetic moment.\nThe operator of the magnetic moment perpendicular to the layer is defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n m = -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2c')]), '(x v^y - y v^x).\n'], []), '\nSimilarly to Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_jav')]), '),\nthe expectation value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), '\nfor a state of the band ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('langle'), ' m ', TexCmd('rangle', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '&', TexCmd('approx'), '&\n', TexCmd('int'), ' d F_n^*() \nm_n F_', BraceGroup('n'), '(), \n'], []), '\nwhere \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_n'], []), ' is the effective magnetic moment,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nm_n\n&=&\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2c')]), '\n', '(\nx v_n^', BraceGroup('y', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')), '\n-y v_n^', BraceGroup('x', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')), '\n', ')\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('2 c')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('neq'), ' n'), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('i')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^x_', BraceGroup('nm'), 'v^y_', BraceGroup('mn'), ' - v^y_', BraceGroup('nm'), 'v^x_', BraceGroup('mn')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('n'), ' - ', TexCmd('vare'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '_', BraceGroup('m'))]), '\n.\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_m')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe first term is the magnetic moment given by\nthe orbital current ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')])), '_n'], []), '.\nThe second term is the extra magnetic moment coming from the anomalous current,\nand coincides with the expression of magnetic moment\nwhich enhances the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '-factor\nin a conventional semiconductor physics.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Yafet_1963,Kittel_1963')]), '\n', '\nWhile we include a diagonal scalar potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), 'V()'], []), '\nin above argument, an off-diagonal potential is generally possible\nin systems such as graphene with a random vector potential.\nAs long as the potential term enters the Hamiltonian \nin a form of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('mn'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), ' + V_', BraceGroup('mn'), '()'], []), ', as \nin random vector potential for graphene,\nthe expression of the chiral current Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j')]), ')\nis not influenced since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup('mn')], []), ' \ncommutes with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' R')]), '(-)'], []), ',\nand also does not alter the velocity operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('mn')], []), '.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Monolayer graphene')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_mono')]), '\n', '\nGraphene is composed of a honeycomb network of carbon atoms, where a\nunit cell contains a pair of sublattices, denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '.\nLow-energy electronic states are described by the effective Hamiltonian,\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McClure_1956a,Slonczewski_and_Weiss_1958a,DiVincenzo_and_Mele_1984a,Semenoff_1984a,Ando_2005a,Shon_and_Ando_1998a,Zheng_and_Ando_2002a,Gusynin_and_Sharapov_2005a,Peres_et_al_2006a')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') = \n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', [' \n', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', '& v p_-\n v p_+  & -', TexCmd('Delta'), ' \n'], []), ' ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_mono')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '_', TexCmd('pm'), ' = ', TexCmd('xi', [BraceGroup('p')]), '_x ', TexCmd('pm'), ' i', BraceGroup('p'), '_y'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' is the valley index\ncorresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('xi')], []), ' point in the Brillouin zone,\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')], []), ' is the momentum measured from the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('xi')], []), '.\nThe matrix works on two-component \nenvelope wave function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '(F_A(), F_B())'], []), '\nat the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' sublattices, respectively.\nThe diagonal terms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('Delta')], []), ', opening the energy gap at Dirac point,\nis given by the potential asymmetry between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' sites, \nwhich can arise in a certain substrate material for instance. \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Zhou_et_al_2007a,Zhou_et_al_2008b')]), '\nThe band velocity is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 1', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^6'], []), ' m/s. \n\nThe surface states\nof the three-dimensional topological insulator of Bi', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), 'Se', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_3'], []), '\nfamily is also described by a similar Hamiltonian\nto Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_mono')]), '), where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', BraceGroup('p'), '_x,', BraceGroup('p'), '_y)'], []), '\nis rotated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', BraceGroup('p'), '_y,-', BraceGroup('p'), '_x)'], []), '. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hasan_and_Kane_2010,Qi_and_Zhang_2010')]), ' \nThe rotation of vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p'))], []), ' \nis compensated by the spinor rotation\nand does not affect the following argument.\nThere is only single valley index,\nand the diagonal term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' appears\nonly when the time-reversal symmetry is broken,\nfor instance, by attaching a ferromagnetic material. \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Qi_et_al_2008,Essin_et_al_2009')]), ' \n', '\nWe assume ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' > 0'], []), ' and consider a state near the electron band bottom \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '=', TexCmd('Delta')], []), '. The wave amplitude is then mainly \nconcentrated on the first component ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' F_A'], []), '.\nThe reduced Hamiltonian for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' becomes apart from the constant energy,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('p'), '^2'), BraceGroup('2m^*')]), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_mono_red')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '\nwith the effective mass,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n  m^* = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), BraceGroup('v^2')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_eff_mass')]), '\n'], []), '\nApplying Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j')]), '), the local current density is written as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('langle'), ' ', '() ', TexCmd('rangle', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e')]), '&=&  \n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('m^*')]), '\\,', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Im'), '(F^* ', TexCmd('nabla'), ' F)\n- ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('2m^*')]), '\n ', '(-_z ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), ') |F|^2\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_j_mono')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nwhere\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), ' = (', TexCmd('partial'), '/', TexCmd('partial'), ' x, ', TexCmd('partial'), '/', TexCmd('partial'), ' y, 0)'], []), ',\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e'), '_z = (0,0,1)'], []), '.\nThe first term is the usual current density, \ncorresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')], []), '\nof Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j')]), ').\nThe second term is the anomalous component, and denoted as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), '_c'], []), '\nin the following.\nIt flows perpendicularly to the gradient of the density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|F|^2'], []), ',\nand thus it circulates on a closed loop and does not \ncontribute to the electron transport.\nThe direction is opposite between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm')], []), '.\nIt is written in terms of equivalent local\nmagnetic moment ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []))])], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('langle'), ' ', '_c(', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), ') ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), TexCmd('rangle', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e')]), '&=&  \n  c', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(),\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '() &=& - ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('2m^*c')]), '|F|^2 _z.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_mr_mono')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nFor the valence band electron, \na similar calculation shows that \nthe first term of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_mono')]), ')\nflips the sign while the second term remains unchanged.\n\nThe expression of the magnetic moment operator, \nEq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m')]), '), becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', '&& m \n=\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2m^*c')]), '(x', BraceGroup('p'), '_y - y', BraceGroup('p'), '_x) \n-', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('2m^*c')]), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_m_mono')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere the first and second terms corresponds to those \nof Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_mono')]), '), respectively.\nThe second term, now denoted as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), ',\nis the magnetic moment induced by the anomalous current\nand coincides with the integral of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '()'], []), '\nof Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_mr_mono')]), ') over the space.\nIt should be noted that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), ' is constant\nregardless of the detail of the wavefunction.\nThis is analog of spin magnetic moment of bare electron system \nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), ' being the spin index, \nwhile in graphene\nthis is mimicked by the valley-dependent chiral orbital current. \nThe expression agrees with an intrinsic magnetic moment\nin the semi-classical picture,  that attributed to\nthe self-rotation of the wave packet. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Xiao_et_al_2007')]), ' \n', '\nThe valley pseudo-spin magnetic moment ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), '\nproduces the pseudo-spin Zeeman energy in presence of a \nmagnetic field, \nand this accounts for the valley splitting of Landau levels \nin graphene. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\nThis can be checked by\nconsidering the Hamiltonian in a uniform external field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' B')], []), ',\nor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []))])), ')'], []), ' in Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_mono')]), '),\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []))])), TexCmd('equiv', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Vec', [BraceGroup('p')])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' A')]), '+ e/c'], []), '\nwith the vector potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' A')], []), ' giving \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' B'), ' = ', TexCmd('nabla', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' A')]), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' '], []), '.\nNoting the relation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('pi'), '_x,', TexCmd('pi'), '_y', ']', ' =-i', TexCmd('hbar'), ' e B/c'], []), ',\nthe reduced Hamiltonian for the A site \nnear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = ', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' is written as ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []))])), ') \n&', TexCmd('approx'), '& \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^2'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('Delta'))]), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_- ', TexCmd('pi'), '_+\n=', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '_c (', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('n')]), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup('2')]), '),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_mono_red_B')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_c = eB/(m^*c)'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_', TexCmd('pm'), ' = ', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('pi'), '_x ', TexCmd('pm'), ' i ', TexCmd('pi'), '_y'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('n')]), ' = a^', TexCmd('dagger'), ' a'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a = (2', TexCmd('hbar'), ' e B/c)^', BraceGroup('-1/2'), ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), '_x - i', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), '_y)'], []), ' is \nthe annihilation operator of Landau level,\nand we used the relation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), '^2 = (2', TexCmd('hbar'), ' eB/c)(', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('n')]), '+1/2)'], []), '.\nThe term depending on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), ' is the pseudo-spin Zeeman energy,\nand actually coincides with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-m_c ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' B'], []), '.\nIn graphene, the pseudo-spin Zeeman splitting \nis equal with the Landau level spacing,\nso that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '-th Landau level at the valley ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_+'], []), '\nhas the same energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n+1)'], []), '-th level at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_-'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexCmd('leavevmode'), TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('height=0.45', TexCmd('hsize')), BraceGroup('fig_spec.eps')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\n', '(color online)(a) Low energy dispersion of gapped bilayer graphene\ngiven by Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi_red')]), ').\n(b) Landau level spectrum of\nEq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi_red_B')]), ') with some small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), "'s,\nplotted against magnetic field.\nDashed (red) and solid (black) lines represent\nthe valley ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = +'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-'], []), ', respectively.\nNumbers assigned to the curves indicate Landau level index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '.\nA pair of dotted slopes represent \nthe energy of the band bottom shifted by pseudo-spin Zeeman energy,\ni.e., ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('vare'), '_0 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '_0/2'], []), '.\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' = 0.1'], []), ' eV, the characteristic energy scale is\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vare'), '_0 = 13'], []), ' meV and \nthe magnetic field for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_0/', TexCmd('vare'), '_0 = 1'], []), '\nis 7.6T.\n')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig_spec')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nThe two terms in the current distribution of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_mono')]), ')\ncan be distinguished by change in \nthe two-dimensional mirror reflection,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n F (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), ') ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), TexCmd('to'), " F'() ", TexCmd('equiv'), " F('),\n", TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_reflect')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '=(x,y)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), " r'"), '=(-x,y)'], []), '.\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '()'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), "'()"], []), ' be \nthe expectation values of\nthe current density for the wavefunctions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["F'"], []), ', respectively.\nEach current component changes with either of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s=', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' in\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n  ', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ["\n   j'_x(') \n   j'_y(')\n  "], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\n=\ns \n  ', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ['\n   -j_x() \n   j_y()\n  '], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_chiral1')]), '\n'], []), '\nor equivalently,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('times', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '()\n=\n- s ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('times'), '().\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_chiral2')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), " r'"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), " j'"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), " r'"), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nIn Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_mono')]), '), the first term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')], []), '\nyields to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s=+'], []), ', i.e., the current \nmap is just mirror-reflected in the same way as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')], []), '.\nThis is a natural consequence,\nsince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')], []), ' is invariant in the mirror reflection.\n\nThe second term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), '_c'], []), ' has an opposite sign ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s=-'], []), ', \nor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), "'_c"], []), ' goes against\nthe mirror reflection of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), '_c'], []), ',\nand can be called chiral in this sense.\nIn gapped graphene, having this term may look counter-intuitive\nsince the system is originally mirror symmetric\nwith respect to a line containing an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['AB'], []), " bond.\nBut this ``real'' reflection\nexchanges valleys ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' at the same time\nin addition to  Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_reflect')]), '),\nso that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), '_c'], []), ' is then simply mirror-reflected \nas it should. Therefore the chiral term \nis necessarily accompanied by the factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), '.\n\nTwo current components behave also differently in the \neffective time reversal operation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F', TexCmd('to'), ' F^*'], []), '\nwithin single valley.\nThe first term obviously reverses in this operation,\nas a consequence of the effective time-reversal symmetry\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')], []), '.\nThe second term depends only on the absolute value of the wave amplitude\nand thus remains unchanged in the same operation.\nBut it reverses in the real time-reversal operation\nwhich switches ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm')], []), '.\nWe will see that the same argument applies to\nbilayer graphene as well.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Bilayer graphene')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_bi')]), '\nBilayer graphene', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Novoselov_et_al_2006a,Ohta_et_al_2006a,Castro_et_al_2007b,Oostinga_et_al_2008a')]), '\nis a pair of graphene layers arranged in AB (Bernal) stacking and\nincludes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_1'], []), ' atoms on layer 1 and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_2'], []), ' on layer\n2.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McCann_and_Falko_2006a,Guinea_et_al_2006a,Lu_et_al_2006a,Lu_et_al_2006b,McCann_2006a,Koshino_and_Ando_2006a,Nilsson_et_al_2006b,Partoens_and_Peeters_2006a')]), '\nThe states at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_2'], []), ' are coupled by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_1 ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 0.39'], []), ' eV.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Misu_et_al_1979')]), '\nThe low-energy states are described by the Hamiltonian matrix for the\nbasis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(|A_1', TexCmd('rangle'), ',|B_1', TexCmd('rangle'), ',|A_2', TexCmd('rangle'), ',|B_2', TexCmd('rangle'), ')'], []), ',\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McCann_and_Falko_2006a,Guinea_et_al_2006a')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') =\n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', [' \n', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', '& v p_-  & 0 & 0\n\nv p_+ & ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_1 & 0\n\n0 & ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_1  & -', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', '& v p_-\n\n0 & 0   & v p_+ & -', TexCmd('Delta'), '\n'], []), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H')]), '\nwhere \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' describes potential asymmetry between \nlayer 1 and 2 (not ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' sites), \nwhich gives rise to\nan energy gap. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McCann_and_Falko_2006a,Lu_et_al_2006a,Lu_et_al_2006b,Guinea_et_al_2006a,McCann_2006a,Nilsson_et_al_2006b,Ando_and_Koshino_2009a,Ando_and_Koshino_2009b')]), '\nExperimentally the potential asymmetry can be induced \nby applying an electric field perpendicular to the layer,\n ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ohta_et_al_2006a,Castro_et_al_2007b,Oostinga_et_al_2008a,Y_Zhang_et_al_2008, Mak_et_al_2009')]), '\nand the asymmetry as large as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0.1'], []), ' eV was actually observed\nin spectroscopic measurements. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ohta_et_al_2006a,\n Y_Zhang_et_al_2008, Mak_et_al_2009')]), '\nFor simplicity, we neglected the trigonal warping effect\ndue to the extra band parameter. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McCann_and_Falko_2006a,Koshino_and_Ando_2006a')]), '\n', '\nLet us assume ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' > 0'], []), ' in the following.\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p'), '=0'], []), ', the Hamiltonian gives four eigen energies\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^0_1 = -', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2 + ', TexCmd('Delta'), '^2')]), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\n ', '^0_2 = -', TexCmd('Delta'), ',\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ^0_3 = ', TexCmd('Delta'), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n ', '^0_4 = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2 + ', TexCmd('Delta'), '^2')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_basis')]), '\n'], []), '\nWe consider a state near the conduction band bottom \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = ^0_3'], []), ', of which wave amplitude is mostly\nconcentrated on the first component ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('A1'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' F'], []), '.\nThe effective Hamiltonian for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' is ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Guinea_et_al_2006a')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') &', TexCmd('approx'), '&\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('Delta'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^4p^4'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2')]), '\n- 2', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^2p^2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('equiv'), '&\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('p'), '^4'), BraceGroup('4m_0 p_0^2')]), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('p'), '^2'), BraceGroup('2m_0')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi_red')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '\nwhere the energy is measured from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = ', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n m_0 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2'), BraceGroup('4v^2', TexCmd('Delta'))]), ',\n', TexCmd('quad'), ' p_0 = ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' k_0 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('Delta')), BraceGroup('v')]), '.\n'], []), '\nThe term with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^2'], []), ' comes from the off-diagonal elements \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('34')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('31')], []), '\nin the Hamiltonian matrix diagonalized for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0'], []), '.\nTo have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^4'], []), ' term, \nwe need in Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_red')]), ') the higher order term \nfor the off-diagonal matrix element between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j=2'], []), ' and 3;\ni.e.,use instead of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('32')], []), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '_', BraceGroup('32'), ' = \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('32'), ' + \n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m=1,4'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup('3n'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '^0_3-', TexCmd('vare'), '^0_n'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '_', BraceGroup('n2'), '.\n'], []), '\nThe dispersion is plotted in Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_spec')]), '(a).\nIt is non-monotonic function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', and\nthe band minimum appears at off-center momentum ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=p_0'], []), '\nand energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = -_0'], []), ', where \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\n ', '_0 = ', TexCmd('frac', eV\ngives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_0 = 13'], []), ' meV.\nThe density of states is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\nD() = g_sg_v\n', TexCmd('frac',
