'_0')]))]), TexCmd('times'), '\n', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n0\n& (', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' < -_0)\n\n2 & (-_0 <  < 0)\n\n1 & ( > 0),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_dos_bi')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('cl')]), '\n.\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_s=g_v=2'], []), ' is spin and valley degeneracies.\n\nThe local current density of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j')]), ') is written \nin the same level of approximation as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' u')]), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e'), ') ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' u'), TexCmd('rangle'), '\n', '&=&\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Im'), '\\,', '\n+ ', TexCmd('xi'), ' \n', '(-_z ', TexCmd('times', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Re')]), '\\,', ')\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_j_bi')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nwhere the vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' u')], []), ' is \ndefined by \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '&=& \n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('2m_0')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('k_0^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '=x,y'), '[', '\n2(', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' F^*)', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '(', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' F)\n- ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(F^* ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), '^2 F)\n', ']', '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('m_0')]), 'F^*', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' F.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_u')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe second components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), ' ', '() ', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' \nis the chiral current\nand expressed as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['&&  ', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '_c(', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), ') ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e'), TexCmd('rangle'), '\n=  c', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(),\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& () = \n ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', '_z\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('2 m_0c')]), '\n', TexCmd('Bigl'), '\\{', '\n- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('k_0^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('Bigl', [BracketGroup('|', TexCmd('nabla'), ' F|^2 - ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Re'), '(F^* ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 F)', TexCmd('Bigr'))]), '\n+  |F|^2\n', TexCmd('Bigr'), '\\}', '.\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_j_bi_chiral')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nThe equivalent magnetic moment ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '()'], []), ' now depends on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' and its derivative.\nThe magnetization of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m')]), ') becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nm\n&=&\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2c')]), '\n', '(\nx v^', BraceGroup('y', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')), '\n-y v^', BraceGroup('x', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')), '\n', ')\n- ', TexCmd('xi'), ' \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('m_0 c')]), '\n', '(\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('p'), '^2'), BraceGroup('p_0^2')]), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', ').\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_m_bi')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe second term, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), ', is the valley magnetic moment\ninduced by the chiral current.\nThe valley splitting energy at the band bottom\ncan be estimated by inserting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=p_0'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n 2 |m_c(p_0)|', '\\,', ' B = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), ' e B'), BraceGroup('m_0 c')]), '\n', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_0.\n'], []), '\nThe effective ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '-factor for this pseudo-spin splitting\nis given by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g^* = 2m/m_0'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' is the bare electron mass.\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g^*'], []), ' is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), '\nand it approximates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['30'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' = 0.1'], []), 'eV.\n\nWhen the valley splitting exceeds ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_F'], []), ',\nthe system is fully valley-polarized \nwith single kind of chiral particles.\nUsing the density of states of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_dos_bi')]), '),\nthe condition for full valley polarization\nis estimated in low ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '-field limit,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nn < n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' crit'), ' = \ng_s', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), ' v')]), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2eB'), BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('hbar'))]))]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' is the electron density.\nWe have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' crit'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 5', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('11')], []), ' cm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), '\nat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' = 0.1'], []), 'eV and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B=1'], []), 'T.\nFor the gapped monolayer graphene, the condition is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n n < n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' crit'), ' = g_s ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('eB'), BraceGroup('h')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhich is approximately ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['5', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('10')], []), ' cm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B=1'], []), 'T.\nIn bilayer, the critical density is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('B')])], []), ' rather \nthan ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ', and thus the valley polarization\nis achieved in much lower magnetic fields\nthan in monolayer, in a small electron density.\nThis property is owing to\nthe divergence of the density of states at the band bottom.\n\n\nSimilarly to monolayer ,\nthe valley splitting of Landau levels in asymmetric bilayer graphene\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McCann_and_Falko_2006a,Castro_et_al_2007b,Koshino_and_McCann_2009c')]), '\nis correctly given by\nthe pseudo-spin Zeeman energy due to the magnetic moment ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), '.\nThe original Hamiltonian in a magnetic field\nis given by Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi')]), ') \nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')], []), ' replaced by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []))]))], []), '.\nNear ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = ', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ', it is reduced to\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []))])), ') \n ', TexCmd('approx'), ' \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('Delta'))]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(v', TexCmd('pi'), '_-)^2(v', TexCmd('pi'), '_+)^2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^4')]), '\n- 2', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(v', TexCmd('pi'), '_-)(v', TexCmd('pi'), '_+)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& \n=\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_0)^2'), BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('vare'), '_0'), BracketGroup('\n', '(\n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('n')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '+', TexCmd('xi'), '\n', ')^2 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]), '\n')]), '\n- ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '_0 \n(\n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('n')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', '),\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi_red_B')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_0 = eB/(m_0 c)'], []), '.\nThe pseudo-spin Zeeman energy, i.e., half of the energy difference\nbetween ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm')], []), ', is transformed to\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Zeeman'), ' \n', '&=&\n ', TexCmd('xi'), ' \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('m_0c')]), '\n', '(\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), '^2'), BraceGroup('p_0^2')]), ' \n- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', ') B,\n'], []), '\nwhich coincides with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-m_c ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' B'], []), ' in the limit of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B=0'], []), '.\n\nThe first and second terms in Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi_red_B')]), ')\ncorrespond to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^4'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^2'], []), ' terms in the \nzero-field Hamiltonian, respectively, \nand become dominant\nwhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_0 (n+1/2) ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('gg'), ' ', '_0'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ll'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', '_0'], []), ', respectively.\nIn the lower Landau levels where the second term dominates, \nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '-th level at the valley ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_+'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n+1)'], []), '-th level at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_-'], []), ' approximately degenerate.\nIn higher levels where the first term becomes dominant,\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '-th Landau level at the valley ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_+'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n+2)'], []), '-th level of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_-'], []), ' degenerate.\nFig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_spec')]), ' ', '(b) plots the Landau level energy\nof Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi_red_B')]), ') as a function of magnetic field,\nwhere dashed and solid lines represent\nthe valley ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = +'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-'], []), ', respectively.\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' = 0.1'], []), ' eV, for instance, \nthe characteristic the magnetic field corresponding to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_0/_0 = 1'], []), ' is 7.6T.\nA pair of dotted slopes represent \nthe energy of the band bottom shifted by pseudo-spin Zeeman energy,\ni.e., ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '-_0 + ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '_0/2'], []), '.\nIn small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '-field, they actually serve as the envelope curves for \nLandau levels of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm')], []), '.\nFull valley polarization occurs below the upper slope.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure*', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexCmd('leavevmode'), TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('height=0.4', TexCmd('hsize')), BraceGroup('fig_spec_abc.eps')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\n', '(color online)(a) Low energy dispersion of gapped \n3-layer and 4-layer ABC graphene given by Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_abc_red')]), ').\n(b)(c) Corresponding Landau level spectrum of\nEq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_abc_red_B')]), ') with some small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), "'s,\nplotted against magnetic field.\nA pair of dotted slopes represent \n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('vare'), '_0 ', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', '(N-1)', TexCmd('omega'), '_0/2'], []), '.\n')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig_spec_abc')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('ABC multilayer graphenes')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_abc')]), '\n', '\n', '\nFor the structure of bulk graphite, there are two known forms called\nABA (AB, hexagonal, or Bernal) and ABC (rhombohedral) with different\nstacking manners.', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lipson_et_al_1942,Haering_1958,McClure_1969')]), '\nThe ABA phase is thermodynamically stable and common,\nwhile it is known that some portion of natural graphite\ntakes the ABC form. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lipson_et_al_1942')]), '\nThe low-energy band structure of a finite ABC graphene multilayer\nis given by a pair for the surface bands localized \nat outer-most layers, ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Guinea_et_al_2006a,Manes_et_al_2007,Koshino_2010')]), '\nand the interlayer potential asymmetry opens an energy gap between \nthose bands. \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Aoki_and_Amawashi_2007, Lu_et_al_2007,Koshino_and_McCann_2009b,Koshino_2010')]), '\n', '\nNow we attempt to argue the chiral magnetic moment\nof gapped low-energy bands of ABC ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-layered graphene,\nin a parallel way to the bilayer graphene.\nIf the basis is taken as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|A_1', TexCmd('rangle'), ',|B_1', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ';\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|A_2', TexCmd('rangle'), ',|B_2', TexCmd('rangle')], []), '; ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cdots')], []), '; ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|A_N', TexCmd('rangle'), ',|B_N', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ',\nthe low-energy effective Hamiltonian \ncan be written as ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Guinea_et_al_2006a,Manes_et_al_2007,Lu_et_al_2007,Koshino_and_McCann_2009b,Koshino_2010')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ABC'), ' =\n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ['\n H_1 & V  \n V^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger')), ' ', '& H_2 & V  \n & V^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dagger')), ' ', '& H_3 & V \n  &   & ', TexCmd('ddots'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('ddots'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('ddots'), ' ', '& \n'], []), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_abc')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '\nand\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& H_j = \n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ['\n U_j & v p_-  v p_+ & U_j\n'], []), ', \n', TexCmd('quad'), '\nV = \n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ['\n0 & 0  ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_1 & 0\n'], []), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_suppl')]), ' \n'], []), '\nwhere \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U_j'], []), ' is the electrostatic potential at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), 'th layer.\nFor simplicity, we neglected the trigonal warping effect\ndue to the extra band parameter. \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_McCann_2009b')]), '\n', '\nThe potential asymmetry ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U_j'], []), ' can be induced \nby applying an electric field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E')], []), ' perpendicular to the layer.\nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E')], []), ' is uniform, the potential energy \nwith respect to the middle of the stack is\nwritten as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n U_j = (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N+1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' - j ) e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 0.334'], []), ' nm is the interlayer spacing.\nThe bilayer graphene of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi')]), ') is  \na special case of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_abc')]), ')\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd = 2', TexCmd('Delta')], []), '.\nThe actual field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E')], []), ' \ncan be smaller than externally applied electric field\ndue to the screening by the electrons in the graphene. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_2010')]), '\nWe assume ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), ' > 0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|U_j| ', TexCmd('ll'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_1'], []), '\nin the following.\n\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0'], []), ', there are two low-energy eigenenergies \nat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = U_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U_N'], []), ' \noriginating from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|A_1', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|B_N', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ',\nwhile all other states appear near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_1'], []), '\nthrough the dimerization between \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|B_j', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|A_', BraceGroup('j+1'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' for each of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j = 1,', TexCmd('cdots'), ', N-1'], []), '.\nThe effective Hamiltonian \nfor the states near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = U_1'], []), ', \nis derived as \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '(', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')), ') &', TexCmd('approx'), '&\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2'), BraceGroup('(N-1)e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd')]), '\n', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('vp'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1')]), ')^', BraceGroup('2N'), '\n- e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('vp'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1')]), ')^', BraceGroup('2'), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('equiv'), '&\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('N')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p_0^2'), BraceGroup('2m_0')]), ' \n', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('p_0')]), ')^', BraceGroup('2N'), '\n- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup('p'), '^2'), BraceGroup('2m_0')]), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_abc_red')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H')]), '\nwhere the energy is measured from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = U_1'], []), ' and \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n m_0 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2'), BraceGroup('2v^2(e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd)')]), ',\n', TexCmd('quad'), ' p_0 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1'), BraceGroup('v')]), '\n', '(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N-1'), BraceGroup('N')]))]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1')]), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('N-1')])), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_m0_abc')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe term with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^2'], []), ' comes from the direct coupling with \nthe neighboring dimers formed by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|B_1', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|A_', BraceGroup('2'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ',\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^', BraceGroup('2N')], []), ' term is from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-th order coupling with\nthe other low-energy state of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|B_', BraceGroup('N'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), '.\nAll other terms are neglected in low energies\nas long as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['vp_0/', TexCmd('gamma'), '_1 ', TexCmd('ll'), ' 1'], []), '.\nThe band minimum appears at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=p_0'], []), '\nand energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = -_0'], []), ', where \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\n ', '_0 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N-1'), BraceGroup('N')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p_0^2'), BraceGroup('2m_0')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_e0_abc')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe density of states diverges at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = -_0'], []), ' as,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\nD() ', TexCmd('approx'), ' g_sg_v\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('m_0'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('hbar'), '^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2N')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N'), BraceGroup('N-1')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('vare'), '/', TexCmd('vare'), '_0')]))]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_dos_abc')]), '\n'], []), '\nFor example, we show the energy dispersion of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3'], []), ' and 4\nin Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_spec_abc')]), '(a).\nNote that the unit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_0'], []), ' depend on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '.\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd = 0.2'], []), ' eV, for instance,\nthe characteristic energy scale is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_0 = 54'], []), ' meV\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['86'], []), ' meV for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3'], []), ' and 4, respectively. \n\nThe magnetization of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m')]), ') becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nm\n&=&\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2c')]), '\n', '(\nx v^', BraceGroup('y', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')), '\n-y v^', BraceGroup('x', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)')), '\n', ')\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&\n- ', TexCmd('xi'), ' \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup('m_0 c'), BracketGroup('\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('p'), BraceGroup('p_0')]), ')^', BraceGroup('2(N-1)'), ' \n- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n')]), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_m_abc')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere the second term, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c'], []), ', is the valley magnetic moment.\nThe valley splitting energy at the band bottom\ncan be estimated by inserting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=p_0'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n 2 |m_c(p_0)|', '\\,', ' B = (N-1)', TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_0,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_0 = eB/(m_0 c)'], []), '.\nThe splitting is greater for larger ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '\nunder the same electric field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E')], []), '.\nThe condition for full valley polarization\nin low ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '-field limit is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nn < n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' crit'), ' = \ng_s', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('eB'), BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('hbar'))]))]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), ' v')]), '\n', '(\n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N-1'), BraceGroup('N')]))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1')]), '\n', ')^', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('N-1')]), '.\n'], []), '\nIn the small field region ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd ', TexCmd('ll'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_1'], []), ', which is currently assumed, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' crit')], []), ' increases for larger ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ',\ni.e., the valley polarization is achieved \nup to higher electron density in larger stack.\nIn the large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' limit, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' crit')], []), ' approaches\na value independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E')], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nn^', TexCmd('infty'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' crit'), ' =\ng_s', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('eB'), BraceGroup('c', TexCmd('hbar'))]))]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), ' v')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhich approximates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.5', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('12')], []), ' cm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B=1'], []), 'T.\n\nThe low-energy Landau level spectrum near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = U_1'], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' H'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ', '(eff)'), '\n', TexCmd('approx'), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^2'), BraceGroup('(N-1)e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(v', TexCmd('pi'), '_-)^N(v', TexCmd('pi'), '_+)^N'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1^', BraceGroup('2N'))]), '\n- e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v', TexCmd('pi'), '_-'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v', TexCmd('pi'), '_+'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '_1')]), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n= \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(N-1)^', BraceGroup('N-1')), BraceGroup('N^N')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_0)^N'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '_0^', BraceGroup('N-1'))]), '\n', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^', BraceGroup('N'), '[', '\n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('n')]), '+ j-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup('2')]), 'N\n', ']', '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&\n', TexCmd('qquad'), TexCmd('qquad'), TexCmd('qquad'), TexCmd('qquad'), '\n- ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '_0 \n(\n', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('n')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', ').\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_H_abc_red_B')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe valley splitting in the limit of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B=0'], []), '\nis again shown to be equivalent with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-m_c ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' B'], []), ' \nof Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m_abc')]), ').\nIn higher Landau levels where the first term becomes dominant,\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '-th Landau level at the valley ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_+'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n+N)'], []), '-th level of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_-'], []), ' degenerate.\nFig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_spec_abc')]), ' ', '(b) and (c) plot the Landau level spectra\nof Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_abc_red_B')]), ') \nfor the cases of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3'], []), ' and 4, respectively.\nThe Landau levels in small magnetic fields\nare well bound by dotted lines, or\nthe energies of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '-_0 + ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('hbar'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '_0/2'], []), '.\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), 'd = 0.2'], []), ' eV, for instance, \nthe magnetic field corresponding to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_0/_0 = 1'], []), ' is 33T and 52T for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3'], []), ' and 4,\nrespectively.\nAs argued above, we can see that, \nfor greater ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ', the full valley polarization is possible\nup to larger electron density (i.e., more Landau levels)\nat the same magnetic field.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Pseudo-spin paramagnetism')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_pseudo')]), '\n', '\nThe pseudo-spin Zeeman splitting causes the Pauli paramagnetism \nin analogous way to real spin.\nThe magnetic susceptibility was previously calculated\nfor gapped monolayer and bilayer graphenes ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), ', \nand it was shown that the susceptibility \nin the quadratic dispersion near ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' point,\nis expressed as sum of valley pseudo-spin paramagnetism \nand Landau diamagnetism similarly to a bare electron.\nIn monolayer graphene, the pseudo-spin paramagnetism \ndiverges in the zero gap limit, \nleading to a singular orbital susceptibility\nwhere the strong diamagnetism suddenly disappears off the Dirac point.\n ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McClure_1956a,Sharapov_et_al_2004a,Fukuyama_2007a,Nakamura_2007a,Koshino_and_Ando_2007b,Ghosal_et_al_2007a,Koshino_et_al_2009a,Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\n', '\nHere we extend the argument to general electronic structures\nother than quadratic,\nand show that the pseudo-spin splitting always accompanies\nparamagnetic contribution in any part of the dispersion.\nLet us consider a system in a magnetic field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '\nwith the Landau level sequence,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\n', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '&& _', BraceGroup('n'), ' =  (x_n, ', TexCmd('delta'), ') \n', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', '(n=0,1,2,', TexCmd('cdots'), '),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_en')]), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&& x_n = (n+', TexCmd('frac'), ' 1 2 )', TexCmd('delta'), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' = ', TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_c = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), ' e B'), BraceGroup('m^*c')]), ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_x')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' is the Landau level index,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m^*'], []), ' is the effective mass characterizing the system.\nThe second argument ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(x_n, ', TexCmd('delta'), ')'], []), '\nrepresents the dependence on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ', \nwhich are not included in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_n'], []), '.\nFor example \nthe low-energy Landau level of gapped monolayer graphene,\nEq. [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' \nis related to the energy spectrum at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B=0'], []), '.\nWhen the system is isotropic, in particular,\nthe dispersion is given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), ' ', '(x)'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x = p^2/2m^*'], []), '.\nThe first order shift ', TexMathModeEnv('$', (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_chi_form')]), ')\nis regarded as the Pauli paramagnetism induced by \nthe pseudo-spin magnetic moment.\nIt is always positive,\nand purely determined by the density of states \nand the magnetic moment at Fermi energy.\nThe second term is the summation of the second order energy shift\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)')], []), ' over all the states below Fermi level,\nand the third term gives a discrete jump at \nthe energy corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=0'], []), '.\n\nFor the low-energy spectrum of \nthe gapped monolayer graphene, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_e_mono')]), '), \nwe obtain ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& ', TexCmd('chi'), ' = ', TexCmd('chi'), '_P + ', TexCmd('chi'), '_L\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&\n ', TexCmd('chi'), '_P = D ', TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('*2'), '_B,\n', TexCmd('quad'), '  \n ', TexCmd('chi'), '_L = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('3')]), ' D ', TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('*2'), '_B,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_chi_mono')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_P'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_L'], []), ' come from\nthe first and the third terms\nin Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_chi_form')]), '), respectively,\nand the second term is zero.\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D = g_s g_v m/(2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^2) ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('theta'), '()'], []), '\nis the density of states,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^*_B=e', TexCmd('hbar'), '/(2m^*c)'], []), '\nis the effective Bohr magneton.\nObviously ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_P'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_L'], []), ' correspond to conventional \nPauli paramagnetism and Landau diamagnetism, respectively.\nThe susceptibility calculated above is\nthe contribution from the conduction band,\nwhile the valence band gives the exactly opposite jump\nat the valence band top.\nThe total susceptibility is \ndiamagnetic at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), ' = -', TexCmd('chi'), '_P-', TexCmd('chi'), '_L'], []), ' in the gap region,\nand disappears in conduction and valence bands. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\n', '\nFor gapped bilayer graphene, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_e_bi')]), '), we get\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('chi'), '() &=&\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' g_sg_v e^2'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), ' m_0 c^2')]), TexCmd('times'), '\n', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n0\n', TexCmd('quad'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', '( < -_0),\n\n', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('displaystyle'), '\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2+', TexCmd('vare'), '/', TexCmd('vare'), '_0'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('vare'), '/', TexCmd('vare'), '_0')]))]), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\n', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', '(-_0 <  < 0),\n\n', TexCmd('displaystyle'), '\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2+', TexCmd('vare'), '/', TexCmd('vare'), '_0'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('vare'), '/', TexCmd('vare'), '_0')]))]), '\n+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('6')]), '\n', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', '( > 0).\n'], [BraceGroup('l')]), '\n.\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_chi_bi')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe susceptibility diverges at the band bottom,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = -_0'], []), '. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_Ando_2010')]), '\nThe physical meaning of the divergence is obvious,\nsince the Pauli paramagnetism, i.e., the first term\nof Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_chi_form')]), ') is proportional to\nthe density of states, which diverges at the band bottom.\nThe susceptibility of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_chi_bi')]), ')\nis plotted in Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_chi')]), '\ntogether with and the density of states, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_dos_bi')]), ').\n\nThe argument can be extended to ABC ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-layer graphene\nin a straightforward fashion.\nUsing Eqs. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_dos_abc')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m_abc')]), '),\nthe pseudo-spin paramagnetic susceptibility \nabove and near the band bottom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = -_0'], []), '\nis written as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('chi'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '() &', TexCmd('approx'), '&\nD() m_c^2\n=\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('g_sg_v e^2'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), ' m_0 c^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N(N-1)'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2N')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('vare'), '/', TexCmd('vare'), '_0')]))]), ',\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_chi_abc')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_0'], []), ' are defined in\nEqs. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m0_abc')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_e0_abc')]), '),\nrespectively.\nThe paramagnetic divergence is stronger for greater ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexCmd('leavevmode'), TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=1.', TexCmd('hsize')), BraceGroup('fig_chi.eps')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Susceptibility (solid) \nand density of states (dashed)\nnear the band bottom of asymmetric bilayer graphene,\nplotted against the Fermi energy. \n')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig_chi')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Space-dependent Hall conductivity')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_hall')]), '\n', '\nIf the system is modulated by an external scalar potential,\nthe anomalous current term gives a response current \nin analogous way to the Hall effect.\nHere we argue the relation of the associated\nHall conductivity to the anomalous magnetic moment.\nIn graphenes, such the Hall current exactly cancels between two valleys\ndue to the time-reversal symmetry,\nand the real current appears only when the valley populations\nare differentiated, like the Pauli paramagnetism. \nIn odd-valley case such as \nthe surface states of strong topological insulator,\nit directly gives a net current and causes\na magneto-electric response.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Qi_et_al_2008,Essin_et_al_2009')]), ' \n', '\nWe consider a current distribution\nin a finite and isolated system \nmodulated by an external potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), 'V()'], []), '.\nIn the current densities of \ngapped monolayer and bilayer graphenes,\ngiven by Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_mono')]), ') and Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_bi')]), '),\nrespectively, \nthe first term cancels in summation over the occupied states\nbecause it reverses the effective time-reversal operation\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F ', TexCmd('to'), ' F^*'], []), '.\nThen the total current is given by a summation of\nthe chiral term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c', TexCmd('nabla'), TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), TexCmd('times'), '()'], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' M'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), ') &=& \nc ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' M'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), TexCmd('nabla'), ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('boldmath'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], [])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(),\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '() &=& \n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' occupied'), '  ', '().\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_jtot')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' J'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\n', '\nWhen the potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), 'V()'], []), ' \nis weak and slowly-varying, the Thomas-Fermi approximation gives\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n M(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' M_F'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('vare'), '_F'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), ') ', TexCmd('approx'), ' M_F - V(),\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_F'], []), ' is the total magnetization of a uniform system,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n  M_F = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('hbar'), ')^2')]), TexCmd('int', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' p')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' occupied'), ' m_c(p) d^2,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_mf')]), '\n'], []), '\nand \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c(p)'], []), ' being the anomalous magnetic moment at the momentum ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '.\nThen Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_jtot')]), ') becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' M_F'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('vare'), '_F')]), '\n', '() \n&=&\n ce ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' J'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' E'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), ') = - ', TexCmd('nabla'), ' V()/(-e)'], []), ' is\nthe electric field, leading to\na response function\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' M_F'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('vare'), '_F')]), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), ' = -  ce .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_hall')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nBy applying Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_hall')]), ') to the conduction band \nelectrons of gapped monolayer graphene, \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c(p)'], []), ' is given by the second term of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m_mono')]), '),\nwe have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), ' =', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^2'), BraceGroup('2h')]), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_hall_mono')]), '\n'], []), '\nFor gapped ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-layer ABC graphenes including bilayer,\nof which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_c(p)'], []), ' is given by the second term of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m_abc')]), '),\nthe expression approximates in high energies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('gg'), ' ', '_0'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '  ', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('Ne^2'), BraceGroup('2h')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n ', TexCmd('leavevmode'), TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.9', TexCmd('hsize')), BraceGroup('fig_edge.eps')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('\nSingle-valley current distribution \ncontributed by conduction band electrons \nof gapped monolayer (solid) and bilayer graphenes (dashed),\nterminated at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x=0'], []), '.\n')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig_edge')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nWhen the system is confined to a finite space,\nthe above-mentioned Hall current gives \na chiral edge current at the boundary.\nWhen the confining potential is slowly varying in space,\nthe current circulation is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n I = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('e')]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '^', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('varepsilon', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_F')]), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '() d = c M_F,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_edge_current')]), '\n'], []), '\nas a natural consequence.\nThis is equally true in a sharp potential as well, where the current \nis distributed in a range of the Fermi wave length from the boundary.\nFig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_edge')]), ' illustrates the single-valley current distribution\ngiven by the conduction band electrons \nof gapped monolayer and bilayer graphenes.\nThe detail of the derivation is presented in Appendix.\n\nFrom its definition, \nthe Hall conductivity argued here, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_hall')]), '), \nis the long wavelength limit of the static Hall conductivity,\nnamely, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('q', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '(q,', TexCmd('omega'), ')'], []), '.\nFor the original Hamiltonian of monolayer graphene, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_mono')]), '),\nthis is evaluated as ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ludwig_et_al_1994a')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('q', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), ' \n', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), '\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('varepsilon', [BraceGroup('xy')]), '(q,', TexCmd('omega'), ') &=& - ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^2'), BraceGroup('2h')]), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), '(', TexCmd('Delta'), '-|_F|),\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_hall1')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), '(x) = 1 ', '\\,', '(x>0), 0 ', '\\,', '(x<0)'], []), ' is the step function,\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '>0'], []), ' is assumed here.\nThe low-energy result, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_hall_mono')]), '),\ndescribes the contribution from the conduction band electrons,\nand indeed coincides with \nthe discontinuous jump at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' = ', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' in Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_hall1')]), ').\nThe valence band gives an exactly opposite jump at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '=-', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ',\nso that we have the half-integer Hall conductivity inside the gap,\nand zero in the conduction and valance bands.\n\nNote that usual Hall conductivity relevant in the transport\nis given by a different limit,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('q', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '(q,', TexCmd('omega'), ')'], []), '.\nThis is calculated for gapped monolayer graphene as, ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Sinitsyn_et_al_2008')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), '\n ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('q', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), '  \n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '(q,', TexCmd('omega'), ') &=& \n', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('displaystyle'), '\n- ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^2'), BraceGroup('2h')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta')), BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('vare'), '_F|')]), ' ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '& (|_F|>', TexCmd('Delta'), '), \n\n', TexCmd('displaystyle'), '\n- ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^2'), BraceGroup('2h')]), ' ', '& (|_F|<', TexCmd('Delta'), '), \n'], [BraceGroup('lc')]), '\n.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_hall2')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhich differs from Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_hall1')]), ') except for the value inside the gap.\nThe Berry curvature \nis directly related to this transport Hall conductivity. \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Thouless_et_al_1982,Xiao_et_al_2010')]), ' \n', '\n', '\nFrom the relationship between the local current and local magnetic\nmoment, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_jtot')]), '),\nthe spatial-dependent static Hall conductivity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '(q)'], []), ' \ncan be formulated as a magnetization-density correlation function, i.e.,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nM(q) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('e')]), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '(q) V(q).\n'], []), '\nIn the low-energy region of gapped monolayer graphene,\nit becomes a density-density correlation function,\nbecause the pseudospin magnetization Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_m_mono')]), ') is constant \nfor each eigenstate regardless of the detail of the wavefunction.\nThis suggests that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '(q)'], []), '\nis insensitive to the disorder localization effect \nsince the magnetic moment of each eigenstate remains\neven when the wavefunction is localized. \nThis is in contrast to the transport Hall conductivity,\nwhere the localized eigenstates have zero contribution.\n\n\nLastly, we show that Hall conductivity Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_hall')]), ')\nis directly related to\nindex difference ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' n'], []), ' between degenerated Landau levels of two valleys,\nwhich are argued in the previous sections.\nThis is defined by the ratio of pseudo-spin Zeeman splitting to\nLandau level spacing, or\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' n =', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2m_c B'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_c')]), ',\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' S(', TexCmd('vare'), '_F)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('vare'), '_F')]), '\n', '&& ', TexCmd('hbar'), TexCmd('omega'), '_c = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar'), ' eB'), BraceGroup('c')]), '2', TexCmd('pi'), '\n', '()^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\n'], []), '\nand  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilonS'), '(_F)=', TexCmd('pi'), ' p_F^2'], []), ' is the area of the momentum space \nat the Fermi energy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_F'], []), '. \nUsing Eqs. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_mf')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_hall')]), '), we obtain,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n ', TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' M_F'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('vare'), '_F')]), ' n =  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2hc'), BraceGroup('e')]), ' = \n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2h'), BraceGroup('e^2')]), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '.\n'], []), '\nIndeed, we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' n =1'], []), ' for gapped monolayer graphene,\nand  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' n ', TexCmd('approx'), ' N'], []), '  for gapped ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-layer ABC graphene \n(including bilayer graphene) in high energies.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conclusion')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_concl')]), '\n', '\nWe presented systematic analyses \nof anomalous chiral current and magnetic moment\nin gapped graphenes and related materials.\nStarting from the low-energy effective-mass theory,\nwe formulate a description of local current distribution\nsupporting anomalous magnetic moment\nin general Bloch systems.\nIn gapped monolayer, bilayer and ABC multilayer graphenes,\nwe showed that the chiral current circulation accounts for\nthe valley-dependent magnetic moment\nand valley-splitting of Landau levels.\nThe bilayer and ABC multilayer graphenes exhibit \na large paramagnetism\nat the band bottom, and full valley polarization \nis possible in relatively high electron density.\n\nThere have been suggested various mechanisms\nfor valley polarization or valley filtering\nwhich might be used to control electronic devices.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Xiao_et_al_2007,Yao_et_al_2008,Rycerz_et_al_2007,Pereira_et_al_2009,Abergel_and_Chakraborty_2009,Nakanishi_et_al_2010')]), '\nThe possibility of full valley polarization in graphene bilayer\nand ABC multilayers\ninvokes a simple mechanism for valley-dependent transport.\nFor example, if we could locally apply opposite magnetic fields\nto the left and right sides of a gapped bilayer\nor ABC-multilayer strip,\nand achieve different valley polarizations in two regions,\nthen the transport between two regions would be killed,\nas long as the valley flipping is prohibited in the intermediate region,\ni.e., the impurity potential and the spacial magnetic field change \nare smooth compared to the atomic scale.\nOn the contrary, electrons \ncan travel almost \nfreely when the same magnetic field is applied to two regions.\n\nWhile we focus on the family of ABC-stacked multilayer graphenes\nin the present studies, the anomalous magnetic moment arises\nin ABA-stacked multilayer graphenes as well\nwhen the inversion symmetry is broken. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_McCann_2009c')]), '\nIn ABA multilayers with an odd number of layers,\nthe lattice structure originally lacks in the inversion symmetry\nso that the valley splitting intrinsically \nexists even in absence of the external field.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_McCann_2011')]), '\nThe present analysis applies to every subband comprising the \ntotal band structure, each of \nwhich is akin to gapped monolayer or bilayer graphenes. \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Koshino_and_McCann_2011,Koshino_and_Ando_2009_ssc')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Acknowledgment')]), '\n', '\nThis project has been funded by JST-EPSRC\nJapan-UK Cooperative Programme Grant No. EP/H025804/1.\n\n', TexCmd('appendix'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Chiral edge current')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec_app')]), '\n', '\nHere we calculate the edge current distribution\nof gapped monolayer and bilayer graphenes\nbound by a sharp confining potential.\nLet us consider a low-energy Hamiltonian\ngapped monolayer graphene, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_mono_red')]), '),\nbound by a potential barrier, \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n V(x)\n=', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n ', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', '& (x<0)\n\n 0 & (x>0)\n'], [BraceGroup('cl')]), '\n. .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_pot')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe eigenstates are given by\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& F() ', TexCmd('propto'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i k_y y'), ' ', TexCmd('sin'), ' k_x x.\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nThe current density of Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_mono')]), ')\nintegrated over the occupied states is written \nin terms of the Bessel function as,\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nJ_y() &=& \n', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('h')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vare'), '_F'), BraceGroup('x')]), 'J_2(2k_F x).\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nIt oscillates and decays in the length scale of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('pi'), '/k_F'], []), '\nas shown in Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_edge')]), '.\nThe total edge current is\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n I &', TexCmd('equiv'), '& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r'), TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('infty'), ' dx', '\\,', ' \nJ_y() \n= ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('2h')]), ' ', '_F,\n'], []), '\nwhich coincides with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c M_F'], []), '.\n\nThe similar argument is available in bilayer graphene.\nFor simplicity, we \nconsider high energies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), TexCmd('gg'), ' ', '_0'], []), '\nand neglect ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^2'], []), ' term in Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_H_bi_red')]), ').\nThe Schr', '\\"', BraceGroup('o'), 'dinger equation becomes\nthe fourth-order differential equation due to the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('p'), '^4'], []), ' term, and the boundary condition\nbecomes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["F(0)=F'(0)=0"], []), '. The eigenstate then becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&& F() ', TexCmd('propto'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i k_y y'), '[', TexCmd('cos'), ' k_x x + ', TexCmd('sin'), ' k_x x - e^', BraceGroup('-k_x x'), ']', '.\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '\nThe total current density, Eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eq_j_bi_chiral')]), '), \nintegrated over the occupied states\nis numerically calculated and plotted in\nFig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig_edge')]), '.\nThe length scale is again characterized by is Fermi wave length,\nbut it decays more rapidly than in monolayer.\nThe total edge current is shown to be\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n I = ', TexCmd('int', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' r')]), '_0^', TexCmd('infty'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' dx', '\\,', ' \nJ_y() = ', TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e'), BraceGroup('h')]), ' ', '_F,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq_i_bi')]), '\n'], []), "\nwhich is twice as large as monolayer's.\n\n", TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('Yafet_1963')]), '\nY. Yafet, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' Solid State Physics: Advances in Research and Applications'), ',\n(Academic, New York, 1963), Vol. 14.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('Kittel_1963')]), '\nC. TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]))])], []), ', we get:\n', TexCmd('bea'), '\nu_', BraceGroup('min'), '&', TexCmd('sim'), '& f^', BraceGroup('1/3'), 'x_2^', BraceGroup('2/3'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ' G', TexCmd('mu'), ')^', BraceGroup('-1/6'), 't^', BraceGroup('1/6'), TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('1/4'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', BraceGroup('1/4'), ' H_0^', BraceGroup('1/6'), '(1+z)^', BraceGroup('1/4'), TexCmd('Big(1'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('z'), BraceGroup('z_', BraceGroup('eq'))]), TexCmd('Big)^', [BraceGroup('1/12')]), ' \n', TexCmd('nonumber'), '&', TexCmd('sim'), '&10^', BraceGroup('-14'), '10^', BraceGroup('-9.5'), ' x_2^', BraceGroup('2/3'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^', BraceGroup('-1/6'), ' \n', '(G', TexCmd('mu'), ')^', BraceGroup('-5/12'), '(1+z)^', BraceGroup('1/4'), TexCmd('Big(1'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('z'), BraceGroup('z_', BraceGroup('eq'))]), TexCmd('Big)^', [BraceGroup('z'), BraceGroup('z_', BraceGroup('eq'))]), TexCmd('Big)^', [BraceGroup('1/12')]), '\n', TexCmd('eea'), '\nWe see that as long as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_2'], []), ' is not drastically large (i.e. the \nstring is extremely wiggly)  or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' is not significantly \nsmaller than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['50'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('min'), TexCmd('ll'), '1'], []), ' is a valid approximation  \nfor any feasible gravitational wave experiment and none of the other \nparameters in the above expression can compensate for the smallness \nof the size of the cusp segment compared to the size of the loop. \nIndeed, even for very high redshifts up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z', TexCmd('sim'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('12')], []), ' corresponding \nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['100'], []), ' MeV scales, the corrections at most change the result \nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('min')], []), ' by a few orders of magnitude.\n\nWe perform a similar calculation to approximate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('max')], []), ' \nusing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('max'), '=L'], []), ':\n', TexCmd('bea'), '\nu_', BraceGroup('max'), '&', TexCmd('sim'), '&  ', '[', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), BraceGroup('6')]), 'f ', TexCmd('Big(\'), TexCmd('Big)^', [BraceGroup('1/3')]), '(1+z)^', BraceGroup('-1/2'), TexCmd('Big(1'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('z'), BraceGroup('z_', BraceGroup('eq'))]), TexCmd('Big)^', [BraceGroup('-1/6')]), '\n', TexCmd('eea'), '\nwhich suggests that the approximation remains valid at least up \nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z', TexCmd('leq'), ' 10^8'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' MeV scales.
