Gibbs')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('SUPA, School of Physics and Astronomy, University of St Andrews, St Andrews KY16 9SS, United Kingdom')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('A. P. Mackenzie')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('SUPA, School of Physics and Astronomy, University of St Andrews, St Andrews KY16 9SS, United Kingdom')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('R. Moessner')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('Max Planck Institut f', '\\"', 'ur Physik komplexer Systeme,D-01187 Dresden, Germany')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('S. A. Grigera')]), '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('SUPA, School of Physics and Astronomy, University of St Andrews, St Andrews KY16 9SS, United Kingdom')]), '\n', TexCmd('affiliation', [BraceGroup('Instituto de F', "\\'", BraceGroup(TexCmd('i')), 'sica de L', "\\'", BraceGroup(TexCmd('i')), 'quidos y Sistemas Biol', "\\'", 'ogicos, UNLP-CONICET, La Plata 1900, Argentina')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('date', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('today'))]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nWe investigate the non-equilibrium behavior of the spin-ice material Dy', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), 'Ti', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), 'O', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_7'], []), " by studying its magnetization as a function of the rate at which an external field is swept. At temperatures below the enigmatic ``freezing'' temperature ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil'), TexCmd('approx'), '600'], []), '~mK, we find that even the slowest sweeps fail to yield the equilibrium magnetization curve and instead give a smooth, initially much flatter curve. For higher sweep rates, the magnetization develops sharp steps  accompanied by similarly sharp peaks in the temperature of the sample. We ascribe the former behavior to the energy barriers encountered in the magnetization process, which proceeds via flipping of  spins on filaments traced out by the field-driven motion of the gapped, long-range interacting magnetic monopole excitations. In contrast, the peaks in temperature result from the released Zeeman energy  not being carried away efficiently into the bath, with the resulting heating triggering a chain reaction. \n\n\n\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n ', '\nNew phases go along with new excitations, which in turn manifest themselves as new phenomena in experiments. In the case of the magnetic pyrochlore compounds RE', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), 'TM', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2'], []), 'O', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_7'], []), ', where RE = Dy or Ho and TM = Ti or Sn, the new phase, named ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('spin ice')]), ", is peculiar in that it is highly degenerate, with a non-vanishing ``zero-point entropy'' on account of the highly frustrated magnetic couplings ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('gingrev')]), ' and an effective low-energy description provided by a classical emergent gauge field ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('emgauge')]), '.\n\nThe concomitant new excitations are -- unusually for a three-dimensional Ising magnet -- pointlike topological defects. These are charged not only under the emergent gauge field but are also sources of a conventional magnetic field, whence their name magnetic monopoles~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Castelnovo2009')]), '.  \n\nThe experiments we report and analyse here are related to the magnetization processes under an applied magnetic field. This is a fundamentally non-equilibrium phenomenon that has a long and important history in condensed matter physics. It is associated with concepts such as the Barkhausen noise~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('barkhausen')]), ". It is also related to the physics of ``magnetic deflagration'' in the case of simple paramagnets~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('magdeflag')]), ', with links to the physics of explosives, for which detailed analytic theories were proposed~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Garanin2007')]), '. \n\nIn spin ice, we find that there are three fundamentally different types of behavior for the magnetization process. Besides the equilibrium magnetization curve for infinitesimally (at low temperature, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ', unattainably) slow sweep rates, we find smooth behavior for slow sweeps, which gives way to  magnetization jumps accompanied by thermal runaway at faster sweeps.\n\nThis richness of behavior is a consequence of the peculiar nature of the spin ice state, which requires the motion of ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' thermally activated'), ' monopoles to change the magnetization, leading to an exponentially slow response rate at low ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ". The slow-sweep response is special in that it reflects the nucleation of the equilibrium (magnetized) phase as in the case of a supercooled gas, with the crucial distinction that the nucleation happens through one-dimensional filaments (the paths of monopoles), so that the process can occur gradually even in the absence of quenched disorder. The relevant energy barriers arise from the competition of magnetic Coulomb and Zeeman energies involved in creating and separating the monopoles. In contrast, thermal runaway involves physics extrinsic to the spin system, namely a ``phonon bottleneck'', the inability of the heat bath to absorb efficiently the Zeeman energy released by the spin flips.\n\nIn the remainder of this paper, we describe and model these phenomena in detail. Specifically, we study the low temperature magnetization process in response to an external ", '[', '111', ']', ' field which takes place between two states within the ice-rule manifold: the zero field spin ice state (SI) and kagome ice (KI)~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Matsushira2002')]), ', defined below. \n\nThe  pyrochlore lattice consists of a cubic array of corner-sharing\ntetrahedra. In the spin ice systems, the spins -- sitting at the\ncorners of the tetrahedra -- are constrained to point into the center\nof one of the two tetrahedra they belong to. The spin configurations in the low energy ice-rule manifold \nare those in which only two of the four spins of every tetrahedron point towards its center. Positive (negative) magnetic monopoles correspond to tetrahedra with three (one) spins pointing in.\n\nTo understand the transition between the zero field SI and KI states, it is convenient to view the pyrochlore lattice as an alternating stack of two-dimensional kagome and triangular lattice planes, perpendicular to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '111', ']'], []), ' direction. It is possible to polarise all the spins in the triangular layers (more strongly coupled to the magnetic field on account of their local easy axes) while maintaining the ice rules and preserving a reduced but non-vanishing zero-point entropy~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Matsushira2002')]), '; this is the KI state. To further increase the magnetization along the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '111', ']'], []), ' direction requires breaking the ice-rules, with an energy penalty of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '_s', TexCmd('approx'), ' 5.6'], []), '~Kelvin per spin flip. As a result, ', TexCmd('Dy'), '227 exhibits a low-temperature magnetization plateau at the value ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' KI'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 3.3'], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_B'], []), '/Dy for fields up to about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '~Tesla~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Sakakibara2003')]), ". On the other hand, at small fields the system's response is similar to that of an isotropic paramagnet and one expects a linear scaling of the magnetization with ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H/T'], []), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('isakov')]), '. \n\nSingle crystals of ', TexCmd('Dy'), '227 were grown by the floating zone method in\nSt Andrews. The samples were cut into prisms of approx.\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2 ', TexCmd('times'), ' 0.7 ', TexCmd('times'), ' 0.5'], []), '~mm', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^3'], []), ' with the long axis along \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '111', ']'], []), ' to minimize demagnetizing effects.  The magnetization was\nmeasured using a purpose-built plastic Faraday force magnetometer.\nThe sample was mounted flat on a sapphire plate thermally anchored\nto the mixing chamber of a dilution refrigerator. An additional calibrated\nthermometer was attached directly to the sample. The magnetometer was calibrated against a SQUID.\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.85', TexCmd('columnwidth')), BraceGroup('fig1.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('magnetization vs field along the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '111', ']'], []), ' axis, measured at low temperature after zero field cooling, at sweep rate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.1'], []), '~T/min. While above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' 600'], []), '~mK the spin system reaches equilibrium within the experimental measuring time (as shown by a reasonable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i/T'], []), ' scaling for low ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i/T'], []), ', see inset), the lowest ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' curves exhibit quite unusual features. Notably, plateaux are followed by sharp jumps in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '. Eliminating the effect of demagnetizing fields, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['DM'], []), ', gives a crucial piece of information (inset): the field triggers an event that persists even when the actual internal field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i'], []), ' decreases below the triggering value (the negative slope seen here is a consequence of the decrease in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' increases). The details of the curves are remarkably reproducible.')]), ' \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig1')]), '\n'], []), BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' Results --'), ' Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig1')]), ' shows the measured magnetization along ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '111', ']'], []), ' after zero field cooling, as a function of field (with a sweep rate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('upsilon'), ' =  0.1'], []), '~~T/m), for different temperatures. \nAt relatively high temperatures (above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil')], []), ') the magnetization rises linearly from zero as expected and reaches a plateau of approximately ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3.3'], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_B'], []), '/Dy. As the temperature is lowered to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['500'], []), '~mK, contrary to the expected ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H/T'], []), ' scaling, the magnetization rises at a slower rate. Below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['400'], []), '~mK the magnetization at first remains tiny until a finite field is reached, whereupon it  exhibits a steep jump which can hardly be resolved by our instrument, recording ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' point every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sim'), '2'], []), '~s. \nFurther plateaux at intermediate values of the magnetization and subsequent jumps are seen before reaching ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' KI')], []), '. With decreasing temperatures, both the intermediate plateaux and the jumps become sharper and the value of the magnetization at the plateaux changes (from around ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2.4'], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_B'], []), '/Dy to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2.8'], []), '~', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_B'], []), '/Dy). The latter is a strong indication that the plateaux cannot be explained by the formation of an equilibrium intermediate magnetization pattern, in contrast to the case of magnetoelastic coupling~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('cabra')]), '. \n\nFurther information can be obtained by plotting the magnetization as a function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i/T'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i = H-DM'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), ' the calculated demagnetizing factor based on the geometry of the samples (inset of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig1')]), '). As expected, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i/T'], []), ' scaling works only for the high temperature data, where it also agrees with MC simulations of the dipolar spin ice model (not shown). At lower temperatures the curves lie below the equilibrium curve. What is most striking is the fact that the jumps, plotted against the actual internal field, acquire a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' negative'), ' slope. \nThis shows that they correspond to triggered events: once the process has started, it does not stop even though the internal field falls below the triggering value. This represents a magnetic Zeeman equivalent of \ndeflagation of a combustible material set off by a spark.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=0.85', TexCmd('columnwidth')), BraceGroup('fig2.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' vs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i=H-DM'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['200'], []), '~mK, measured for different field sweep rates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('upsilon')], []), '. Jumps only happen above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('upsilon'), ' = 0.025'], []), '~T/min. At slower sweep rates, the data seem to fall onto a single limiting curve. Jumps also occur in field cooling experiments; the inset shows ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' vs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i'], []), ' at 0.1 T/min and 200mK for different starting field cooled states (as indicated in each curve), together with the slow curve (at 0.01 T/min) and the 700 mK curve.  The field-cooled jumps are contained within these two limiting curves, as explained in the text.')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nJumps in the magnetization have been observed indirectly in neutron studies of ', TexCmd('Dy'), '227', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fennell_jumps,f2')]), ' and were absent from the magnetization measurements reported in Ref.~', TexCmd('onlinecite', [BraceGroup('Sakakibara2003')]), '. \nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), ' reconciles this apparent inconsistency as a consequence of the different speeds at which the magnetic field was swept in the two experiments. The figure shows the magnetization curves at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['200'], []), '~mK for sweep rates spanning a factor of about thirty, each step progressing by approximately a factor of two from the previous rate. They can clearly be separated into two groups: those showing one or more jumps, with sweep rates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('upsilon')], []), ' greater or equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.025'], []), '~T/min, and those showing a continuous growth of the magnetization, from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.01'], []), '~T/min to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.003'], []), '~T/min. \nThe changes within each group are very small, despite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('upsilon')], []), ' changing by a factor four: the heights of the jumps are unaltered and so is the slope of the continuous curve. \n\nThe field at which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' jumps can be tuned by preparing the sample into different initial states of magnetization.  Shown\nin the inset of Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' vs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i'], []), ' curves at 0.1 T/min measured after cooling the sample to 200mK\nunder different applied magnetic fields; a slow curve (0.01T/min) at the same temperature and the 700 mK\ncurve are also included. We can see that the magnetization value for each field cooled curve hardly changes until the curve crosses the slow rate trace. Shortly after, the magnetization suddenly jumps up to its equilibrium value at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 700'], []), '~mK. \nThe slow rate curve can thus be considered as an approximate\nlimit for the stability of the out-of-equilibrium magnetization.\n\n\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' Low-temperature behavior')]), ' -- \nFocusing on field values below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.1'], []), '~Tesla, we see that the magnetization at low temperature rises slowly, reaching higher values the smaller the sweep rate. Qualitatively, this behavior can be understood as a consequence of the kinetics of the magnetization process in spin ice, which proceeds via field-driven motion of the magnetic monopoles. \nAs their density and speed of motion is not significantly affected by weak fields, the maximal rate at which the system can respond via this mechanism is independent of the value of the applied field: \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(dM/dt)_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), '_m ', '\\,', ' 10 ', TexCmd('mu'), '_B/', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' ms')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_m'], []), ' denotes the density of thermally activated unbound monopoles,  strongly suppressed at low temperature. Here we assume a typical single spin flip time scale of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '~ms~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Snyder2004,jaubert')]), '. \nEven the slowest experimental sweeps require processes where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' changes much faster than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(dM/dt)_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' max')], []), ' to maintain equilibrium for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T ', TexCmd('ll'), ' T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil')], []), '. As a result, the system enters a strongly out of equilibrium regime where the magnetization remains very small despite the presence of an applied magnetic field.\n\nWhen the sweep rate is sufficiently low, this regime is followed by a smooth, seemingly rate-independent increase in magnetization up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' KI')], []), ' ', '(Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), '). Let us thus consider how monopoles, the agents of magnetization changes, are created out of the SI ground state in presence of a Zeeman field. \nOn one hand, the bare cost of a spin flip, which creates a neighbouring monopole--antimonopole pair, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '_s'], []), ', leads to a tiny density at low ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ', say 100 mK. On the other, a single monopole can change the magnetization by effecting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(L)'], []), ' spin flips as it is swept to the sample surface, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' being the linear size of the system along the field direction.\n\nWe are thus dealing with a nucleation process where a spin flip out of the ground state is the part of an activated process akin to those giving rise to an interface tension between two phases in a first-order transition. The Coulomb attraction experienced by the monopoles as they move apart will then be reflected in the kinetics of the nucleation process.\n\nWe emphasize that -- unlike a supercooled gas, where a nucleated droplet grows to a finite volume fraction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(L^3)'], []), ' -- a spin flip in SI only nucleates a filament of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(L)'], []), ', as mentioned above. In such nucleation processes, the limits of long times and large system sizes do not commute but it is easy to see that there will be a parameter range where the area density of filament creation is low enough for their Zeeman energy release to be absorbed by the rest of the system -- this is our slow-sweep regime~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('footnote')]), '. As we will argue below, the fast-sweep regime corresponds to the situation where this is no longer the case, and thermal runaway is induced.\n\nThe smooth magnetization curve thus provides information about a sequence of energy barriers, which in principle depend on the field direction. In particular, its derivative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['dM/dH'], []), ' at low temperatures is tantamount to a histogram of the distribution of such barriers.\nA plausible origin for these barriers can be found in the Coulomb energy needed to separate a thermally excited monopole pair. Indeed, analytical considerations based on the effective monopole description of spin ice (as well as preliminary numerical simulations) yield energy scales that are in broad agreement with the experimental results for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['dM/dH'], []), ' ', '(not shown). However, a detailed microscopic modelling of this phenomenon is still needed to confirm the origin of the magnetization curve at low sweep rates. \nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '111', ']'], []), ' field direction is particularly complicated as monopoles sweeping through the system can become stuck when their path encounters a spin in a triangular plane already pointing along the field. Such stuck monopoles give rise to local stray fields that  broaden the distribution of energy barriers around them. Moreover, spin flips in triangular and kagome planes have different Zeeman energies in a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '111', ']'], []), ' field. \n\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' Thermal runaway: the fast sweep regime')]), " -- \nWe now turn to the magnetization jumps, the defining distinction between the slow- and fast-sweep regimes. We believe that the increased rate at which Zeeman energy is dumped into the system as the field sweep rate increases overtaxes the ability of the lattice (the phonons) to equilibrate the system with the bath. As a result, the sample heats up locally, leading to the creation of more (and more easily unbound) monopoles. These in turn dump more energy as they move in the field direction and thermal runaway is `ignited' above a critical sweep rate. \n\nTo verify this, we attached an additional thermometer directly to the sample to measure its temperature and magnetization simultaneously. \nIn Fig.~", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), '(a) and~(b), we show this temperature for four different magnetic sweep rates as a function of field, along with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_z ', TexCmd('propto'), ' H_i(t) ', '\\,', ' dM/dt'], []), ', the rate of Zeeman energy release. \nThe sample is strongly coupled to the bath (the dilution refrigerator mixing chamber) and therefore the local temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_l'], []), ' should reflect ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_z'], []), '. Indeed, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_z'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_l'], []), ' trace each other closely. As seen in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), ', for slow sweep rates the energy is dissipated gradually during the whole magnetization process. Once the critical sweep rate is reached (about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.025'], []), '~T/min in this case), the magnetization jumps abruptly, accompanied by a strong spike in the temperature. \n\nThis picture is further supported by the observation that the maximal temperature reached by thermal runaway is approximately independent of the initial temperature over a wide range, pointing at an intrinsic feature of the thermal coupling in the spin-lattice system. This is displayed in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), '(c): at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil'), ' ', TexCmd('approx')], []), ' 600 mK, thermal equilibration is efficient, resulting in a flat temperature trace. \nBy contrast, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T < 500'], []), '~mK temperature spikes appear which, crucially, never surpass ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil')], []), ', where efficient thermal contact is clearly reestablished. This also explains why the magnetization always jumps up to roughly its equilibrium value at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T ', TexCmd('approx'), ' T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil')], []), ' ', '(inset of Fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig2')]), ').\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=', TexCmd('columnwidth')), BraceGroup('fig3.eps')]))]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The temperature of the sample (panel a) follows closely the Zeeman energy release ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dot', [BraceGroup('W')]), '_z'], []), ' due to the motion of monopoles in a magnetic field; the latter is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_i(t) ', '\\,', ' dM/dt'], []), ' ', '(panel b). The temperature reached at each of the thermal runaway episodes is approximately independent of the sample initial temperature (panel c).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig4')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nPrecisely what it is that happens microscopically around ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil')], []), '  is an important open question, which is all the more intriguing because another phenomenon is observed there: spin autocorrelations, as probed in numerical simulations ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' without phonons'), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('jaubert')]), ' and experimentally through AC-susceptibility, show an approximately exponential slowdown below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' equil')], []), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Snyder2004')]), ". \n\nIn conclusion, we have found that the magnetization processes in spin ice exhibit a variety of novel out-of-equilibrium phenomena: nucleation of the equilibrium phase in one-dimensional filaments; thermal runaway following  `supercooling'; a distribution of energy barriers due to long-range interactions and a `speed-limit' on macroscopic equilibrium rearrangements resulting from a paucity of agents to effect such changes. These are exhibited robustly (i.e. without special preparation or a careful choice of parameters). Clearly, further studies of equilibrium and non-equilibrium dynamics and transport -- in particular, thermal transport -- are highly desirable", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('footnote2')]), '. \n\nWe thank the Royal Society and EPSRC (UK), and CONICET and ANPCYT (Argentina) for financial support, and A. G. Green, T. S. Grigera, C. Hooley and S. Sondhi for useful discussions. \n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('gingrev')]), ' For a review, see  M. J. P. Gingras, arXiv:0903.2772.\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('emgauge')]), ' S. V. Isakov, R. Moessner and S. L. It is likely that the nuclear spins act as a buffer in this compound, quickly absorbing the excess local heat released by electronic spin flip processes and transmitting it at a slower rate to the phonon bath. This would have the effect of quenching the runaway process up to much larger sweep rates/lower temperatures.\n'], [BraceGroup()]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('end', [BraceGroup('document')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n']

Schweitzer', TexCmd('footnotemark', [BracketGroup('1')]))]), '  \n', '[', '1.7', TexCmd('baselineskip'), ']', BraceGroup(TexCmd('footnotesize'), TexCmd('itshape'), ' Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Bundesallee 100,\n38116 Braunschweig, Germany'))]), '\n', TexCmd('date', [BraceGroup()]), '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('-.5cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('rule', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('.5pt')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('-.35cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('small'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nThe transition from the quantum Hall state to the insulator is considered \nfor non-interacting electrons in a two-dimensional disordered lattice\nmodel with perpendicular magnetic field. \nUsing ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('correlated')]), ' random disorder potentials the floating up\nof the critical states can be observed in a similar way as in the \ncontinuum model. \nThus, the peculiar behaviour of the lattice models reported previously \noriginates in the special choice of uncorrelated random disorder\npotentials.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('.25cm'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('footnotesize', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('itshape'), ' Keywords:')]), ' Quantum Hall to insulator transition, \nfloating of critical states, correlated random potentials')]), ' \n', '\n', TexCmd('rule', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('textwidth')), BraceGroup('.5pt')]), '\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('.5cm')]), '\n')]), '\n', TexCmd('footnotetext', [BracketGroup('1'), BraceGroup('Corresponding author. Fax: +49', '\\,', '531', '\\,', '5928106; \nemail: Ludwig.Schweitzer@ptb.de.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('normalsize'), '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\nInstead of floating up in energy, as has been proposed ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lau84,Khm84')]), ' \nand shown to exist in continuum models ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('And84,KHA95')]), ', a peculiar \nannihilation of the current carrying states takes place in lattice\nmodels when the quantum Hall to insulator transition is approached. \nAccording to recent investigations \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LXN96,SW98,PBS98,YB99,HIM99')]), ', increasing the disorder causes \nstates associated with a negative Chern number to start moving outwards \nfrom the band centre and to destroy states with corresponding\npositive Chern numbers at the band edges. \nThis behaviour is a special feature of lattice\nmodels which implicitly contain a periodic potential, but is not possible \nin the continuum model without a periodic potential usually considered \nto explain the levitation of the current carrying states.\n\nThe transition from the quantum Hall phase to the insulator is strongly \naffected by the way the critical states disappear. \nWhile in the continuum model the crossover takes place when the last \ncurrent carrying state floats across the Fermi level, \na direct transition to the insulator is possible in the lattice model \nalso from higher Hall plateaus. The latter possibility is not contained \nin the global phase diagram for the quantum Hall effect ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KLZ92')]), '\nsince it was based on the levitation scenario ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lau84,Khm84')]), '.\n  \nUp to now the results of experimental investigations are not conclusive \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SKD93,GJJ95,KMFP95,Hea99c')]), '. Both, direct transitions from \nhigher Hall plateaus to the insulator have been reported as well as\nexperiments that are in accord with the global phase diagram. \nRecently, it has been pointed out that the low field quantum Hall to\ninsulator transition might be unaccessible for the present time\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Huc00')]), ', because the available temperature range and sample sizes  \nrefuse to enter the scaling regime. However, a QH to insulator\ntransition as a function of disorder strength at higher magnetic\nfields is more likely within experimental reach. \n\nIn the present paper we consider the possible origin of both the diverging\nexperimental and theoretical results reported so far. In particular, \nthe fate of the current carrying states is studied when the disorder is\nincreased. We also investigate, how the QH to insulator\ntransition depends on the correlation length of the disorder\npotentials. \n \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Model with correlated disorder potentials')]), '\nA two-dimensional tight binding model describing non-interacting electrons \nmoving in a perpendicular magnetic field and random disorder potentials \nassociated with the lattice sites ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' is given by the Hamiltonian\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nH=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k'), ' w_k |k', TexCmd('rangle'), TexCmd('langle'), ' k| + \n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('<k ', TexCmd('ne'), ' l>'), ' V_', BraceGroup('kl'), ' |k', TexCmd('rangle'), TexCmd('langle'), ' l|.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('AH')]), '\n'], []), ' \nThe transfer terms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup('kl')], []), ' connect only neighbouring sites and\ncontain the magnetic field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B=', TexCmd('alpha'), ' h/e a^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' \nwhich is taken to be commensurate with the lattice. It is expressed as the \nnumber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '=p/q'], []), ' of flux quanta ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h/e'], []), ' per plaquette of area ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a^2'], []), ' and \nenters via the complex phases, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', BraceGroup('kl'), TexCmd('sim'), TexCmd('exp'), '(i2', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' k_x/a)'], []), '. \nWe take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p/q=1/8'], []), ' so that the tight binding band splits into 8 sub-bands.\nThe correlated disorder potentials ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_k'], []), ' are generated \niteratively site by site using a generalisation of the Gibbs\nrepresentation of Markov random chains ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('JS87b')]), '. \n\nThe Gibbs distribution for the configuration of random variables \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nP(', TexCmd('mu'), ')=Z^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('exp'), '(-C', TexCmd('Theta'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ')),\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Theta'), '(', TexCmd('mu'), ')=-', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('<kl>'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_k(', TexCmd('mu'), ')\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_l(', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ' is the Gibbs potential and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' the partition\nfunction. \nHere, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_k(', TexCmd('mu'), ')=', TexCmd('mu'), '_k ', TexCmd('in', [BracketGroup('-1/2,1/2')])], []), ' \nis the value of the random variable on site ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '. \nFor a given configuration ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^0'], []), ' the conditional \nprobability that the new variable on the new site ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' \ntakes a value between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1/2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('le'), ' 1/2'], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nP(', TexCmd('mu'), '_n<', TexCmd('Delta'), '\\,', '|', '\\,', TexCmd('mu'), '^0) = \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'), ' C', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), '_n'), '-e^', BraceGroup('-1/2 C', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), '_n')), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('sinh'), '(1/2 C', TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), '_n)')]), ',\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathit', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), '_n=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('in'), ' N_n'), TexCmd('sigma'), '_i'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_n'], []), ' is the set of\nneighbours of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' already determined. The correlation\nparameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' tunes the strength of the potential correlations. \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=0'], []), ' gives the uncorrelated case.\n\nThe correlated random numbers are then multiplied by the disorder strength \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), ' which results in the set of disorder potentials ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_k'], []), '\nused in Eqn.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('AH')]), ').\nAn example of correlated potentials generated by this method with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=1.3'], []), ' is shown in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('examplecorr')]), ' where a gray-scale plot \nof a 128', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '128 array is displayed. White regions correspond to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_k', TexCmd('approx'), ' +W'], []), ' and black areas to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_k', TexCmd('approx'), ' -W'], []), ' with the gray\nspots for values in between.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=7.5cm'), BraceGroup('crrpot_M128C1p3.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BracketGroup(), BraceGroup('Gray-scale plot for a 128', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '128 array of correlated disorder\npotentials with correlation parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=1.3'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('examplecorr')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nTo further characterise the disorder potentials, we have calculated the \ncorrelation function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(', TexCmd('rho'), ') = ', TexCmd('langle'), ' w_k w_l', TexCmd('rangle'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '=|r_k-r_l|')], []), '\naveraged over all pairs of sites\nwhich are a given distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|r_k-r_l|'], []), ' apart,   \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nK(', TexCmd('rho'), ')  =  \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i,j'), '^', BraceGroup('N'), 'w_i w_j', '\\,', TexCmd('delta'), '(|r_i-r_j|-', TexCmd('rho'), ')'), BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('sum'), '_i^', BraceGroup('N'), ' w_i^', BraceGroup('2'), ' ', ')^', BraceGroup('1/2'), '\n', '(', TexCmd('sum'), '_j^', BraceGroup('N'), ' w_j^', BraceGroup('2'), ' ', ')^', BraceGroup('1/2'))]), '. \n'], []), ' \nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=0.5, 0.7, 1.0, 1.3, 1.7, ', TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), ' 2.0'], []), ',\nwe find an exponential form, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(', TexCmd('rho'), ') ', TexCmd('sim'), '  ', TexCmd('exp'), '(-|r_k-r_l|/', TexCmd('eta'), ')'], []), '. \nThe spatial decay of the correlations is \ngoverned by the correlation length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' which in the range \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.7 ', TexCmd('lesssim'), ' C ', TexCmd('le'), ' 2.5'], []), ' can approximately be fitted by \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '(C) ', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', TexCmd('exp'), '(2C)'], []), '.\nThe results for the correlation function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), ' and the\ncorrelation length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' \ndescribing the decay of the potential correlations are shown \nin Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('corrlength')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=7.5cm'), BraceGroup('corr_results_fin2.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BracketGroup(), BraceGroup('The exponential decay of the correlations in the disorder potentials\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=0.5'], []), ' ', '(+), 0.7 (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '), 1.0 (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ast')], []), '), 1.3\n(', TexCmd('raisebox', [BraceGroup('-.25mm'), BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Box')], []))]), '), 1.7 (', TexCmd('rule', [BraceGroup('1.7mm'), BraceGroup('1.7mm')]), '), \nand 2.0 (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('large'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('circ')], [])), ').')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('corrlength')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Hall conductivity and localisation length')]), '\nThe zero temperature Hall conductivity \n', TexCmd('setlength', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('arraycolsep')), BraceGroup('0.1cm')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '(E,W) & = &\n- ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' arrow 0^+'), TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('L^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rule', [BraceGroup('0mm'), BraceGroup('1.2mm')])), ' \narrow ', TexCmd('infty')), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^2'), BraceGroup('h')]), '\\,', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Omega')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tr')]), '\n', TexCmd('bigg\{'), ' \n ', '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i'), '^', BraceGroup('L'), ' i ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', '(G_', BraceGroup('ii'), '^', BraceGroup('+'), TexCmd('nonumber'), ' ', '&-&  \nG_', BraceGroup('ii'), '^', BraceGroup('-'), ') x_i', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('y')]), '  - 2 ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i,j'), '^', BraceGroup('L'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('varepsilon')), '^2 \nG_', BraceGroup('ij'), '^', BraceGroup('+'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup('y')]), ' ', '\\,', ' G_', BraceGroup('ji'), '^', BraceGroup('-'), ' x_i   \n', TexCmd('bigg\}')], []), '\nand the localisation length \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_M^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(E,W)=-', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('L', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2L')]), '\n', TexCmd('ln'), TexCmd('textnormal', [BraceGroup('Tr')]), '|G_', BraceGroup('1,L'), '|^2\n'], []), '\nare \ncalculated numerically for large disordered two-dimensional systems \nof width ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' and length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' using a recursive Green function method\ndeveloped previously ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Mac85,SKM85')]), '. \nDepending on the\ncorrelation length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' the width is varied between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M/a=32'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M/a=160'], []), '.\nThe length of the system necessary for convergence is typically\nbetween ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^5'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^7'], []), ' in units of the lattice constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), '. \nIn calculating the Hall conductivity one has strictly to observe the \ncorrect order of limits. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=7.7cm'), BraceGroup('E_M48WxpyC0p2_fin.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BracketGroup(), BraceGroup('Normalised localisation length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_M(E,W)/M'], []), '  as a function of\nenergy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' for a system width ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M/a=48'], []), '. The correlation parameter is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=0.2'], []), '. \nThe disorder strength is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W/V=0.5'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Diamond')], []), '), 1.5 (+), 2.0\n(', TexCmd('raisebox', [BraceGroup('-.25mm'), BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Box')], []))]), '), 2.2 (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '), and 2.5 \n(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('triangle')], [])), ').')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('W_M48C0p2_E')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Results and discussion')]), '\nThe Hall conductivity was calculated near filling factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=2'], []), ' as\na function of increasing disorder ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), '. For correlation parameters in the\nrange ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0.0 < C < 1.0'], []), ' a continuous decay from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '=2e^2/h ', TexCmd('to'), '\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '=0'], []), ' is observed. \nAlthough a direct transition is\nseen in the Hall conductivity for these correlation parameters, a \ncloser look at the corresponding localisation length indicates a \ntotally different behaviour of the current carrying states. \nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=0.2'], []), ', which corresponds to a correlation length smaller than the\nmagnetic length, no floating up of the critical state of the lowest\nLandau band can be observed. In fact, as in the\nuncorrelated case it slightly moves downward in energy with increasing\ndisorder strength until it gets annihilated by the corresponding state\nwith negative Chern number moving faster downward from the band centre.\nThis is shown for a system of width ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M/a=48'], []), ' in \nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W_M48C0p2_E')]), ' where the normalised\nlocalisation length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_M/M'], []), ' is plotted versus energy in the \nfilling factor range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0 ', TexCmd('lesssim'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('lesssim'), ' 1.5'], []), ' and\nseveral disorder strength ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), '. The transition to the insulator takes\nplace at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_c/V', TexCmd('approx'), ' 2.5'], []), ' where the Chern and anti-Chern state\ntouch each other.  \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('width=7.6cm'), BraceGroup('W_M48C1p0B8Emxpyfin.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BracketGroup(), BraceGroup('Normalised localisation length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '_M(E,W)/M'], []), ' versus strength \nof the disorder potentials ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), '. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=1.0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M=48', '\\,', 'a'], []), '. \nThe energy parameter is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E/V=-1.2'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Diamond')], []), '), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1.3'], []), ' ', '(+), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1.4'], []), '\n', '(', TexCmd('raisebox', [BraceGroup('-.25mm'), BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Box')], []))]), '), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1.5'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('times')], []), '), \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1.6'], []), ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('triangle')], [])), '), \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1.7'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ast')], []), '), and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1.8'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Diamond')], []), ' dashed line).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('W_M48C1p0_E')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nA completely opposite behaviour is obtained for a larger correlation\nparameter, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=1.0'], []), '. This corresponds to a correlation decay length of\n1.9', '\\,', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' which is almost twice as large as the magnetic length\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_B/a=(2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('alpha'), ')^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), '. While for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=0.2'], []), ' the last current carrying\nstate disappeared at a disorder strength of about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W/V', TexCmd('approx'), ' 2.5'], []), ' two \ncritical states are still observed at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W/V', TexCmd('approx'), ' 3.5'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=1.0'], []), '.\nThis is shown in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W_M48C1p0_E')]), ' where the disorder dependence of \nthe localization length for energies corresponding to filling factors \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1.5 ', TexCmd('lesssim'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('lesssim'), ' 2.5'], []), ' is displayed. \nFig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W_M48C1p0_E')]), ' clearly reveals that there still exist two\ndistinct critical points which move to higher disorder values when the\nfilling factor is increased.  In other words, the current carrying\nstates of the two lowest Landau bands float up in energy and cross the\nFermi energy one by one. Within this energy (filling factor) range the\nshift in disorder is weaker for the critical state of the lowest Landau \nband while it is stronger for the next critical state so that the two\nstates get closer with increasing filling factor. \n\nSince the two critical points are close in disorder the \ncalculated Hall conductivity even for a system of width ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M/a=160'], []), ' \ndoes not reflect the situation of two seperate transitions.\nThe reason for this behaviour is that the \ndivergence of the localization length of the lowest \nand that of the next current carrying state \noverlap because for a given Fermi energy the two critical disorders \nare close (see abscissa in Fig~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W_M48C1p0_E')]), ') so that the Hall steps \ncannot be resolved. \nThis overlap will eventually disappear in the thermodynamic limit and \nsimilarly will the Hall conductivity exhibit the missing Hall plateau at \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('xy'), '=e^2/h'], []), '. \n \nIn conclusion, a lattice model with sufficient correlation in the disorder\npotentials shows similar behaviour as the continuum model. Hence,\na lattice model can perfectly be in agreement with the proposed\nlevitation scenario ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Lau84,Khm84')]), ' and the predictions of the\nglobal phase diagram ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KLZ92')]), '. \n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', [TexCmd('setlength', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('itemsep')), BraceGroup('-3.0pt')]), '\n', TexCmd('footnotesize'), '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('Lau84')]), '\nR.~B. Laughlin, Phys. Rev. Lett ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 52'), ' ', '(1984) 2304.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('Khm84')]), '\nD.~E. Khmelnitskii, Phys. Lett. ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), '\\,', '106A'), ' ', '(1984) 182.\n\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BraceGroup('And84')]), '\nT. (b)', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), ' n_i(8,9)'], []), ' - the 9-th electron is distributed \nalmost uniformly.
