BraceGroup('Theorem')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('prop'), BraceGroup('Proposition')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('lem'), BraceGroup('Lemma')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('corol'), BraceGroup('Corollary')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('A Probability Model for Lifetime of Wireless Sensor Networks')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('authorblockN', [BraceGroup('Moslem Noori and\nMasoud Ardakani')]), ' ', TexCmd('authorblockA', [BraceGroup('Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering,\nUniversity of Alberta, CANADA\nEmail: ', '\\{', 'moslem, ardakani', '\\}', '@ece.ualberta.ca')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nConsidering a wireless sensor network whose nodes are distributed\nrandomly over a given area, a probability model for the network\nlifetime is provided. Using this model and assuming that packet\ngeneration follows a Poisson distribution, an analytical expression\nfor the complementary cumulative density function (ccdf) of the\nlifetime is obtained. Using this ccdf, one can accurately find the\nprobability that the network achieves a given lifetime. It is also\nshown that when the number of sensors, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ', is large, with an error\nexponentially decaying with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ', one can predict whether or not a\ncertain lifetime can be achieved. The results of this work are\nobtained for both multi-hop and single-hop wireless sensor networks\nand are verified with computer simulation. The approaches of this\npaper are shown to be applicable to other packet generation models\nand the effect of the area shape is also investigated.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Section Introduction')]), '\nWireless sensor networks (WSNs) are consisted of a set of cheap and\nusually battery-powered devices, called sensors. Sensor limited\npower usually necessitates a compromise between lifetime and other\nparameters such as the data rate or the quality of the received\nsignal in the sink. It is usually impracticable to replace the\nsensors batteries after their operation period. Hence, estimating\nthe network lifetime according to the initial energy in sensors is\nessential for network design. According to such lifetime estimation,\none can choose the network parameters such as node density, data\nrate and initial energy of the sensors to achieve the desired\nlifetime.\n\nLifetime analysis has been studied in the literature based on\ndifferent definitions such as the number of dead nodes in the\nnetwork, network coverage and network\nconnectivity', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chandr_Upperbound_ICC,Chandr_Upperbound_Role_Infocom,\nAzad_Multipe_Globecom,Santi_Lifetime_cellbased,\nHou_Alpha_lifetime,Rai_Lifetime_Modeling_DATE')]), '. Authors in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chandr_Upperbound_ICC')]), ' derive an upper bound on the network\nlifetime considering the spatial behavior of the data source. To\nachieve this goal, they first consider a simplified version where\nthe data source is a specific point, and the source is connected to\nthe sink with a straight line consisting of relaying sensors. They\nderive the optimum length of a hop and consequently the number of\nhops in the path to minimize the total energy consumed for the data\ndelivery. Then, they remove the assumption of a source concentrated\non a point and assume that the source is distributed over an area.\n\nIn ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chandr_Upperbound_Role_Infocom')]), ', the results of\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chandr_Upperbound_ICC')]), ' are extended to the networks whose\nnodes may perform different tasks of sensing, relaying and\naggregating. The results of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chandr_Upperbound_ICC')]), ' are also\nextended to multiple-sink networks in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Azad_Multipe_Globecom')]), '.\n\nWork reported in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Santi_Lifetime_cellbased')]), ' studies the network\nlifetime for a cell based network. It is assumed that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' nodes are\ndeployed over a hypercube. For the aim of energy conserving, the\narea is divided to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' hypercubes (cells). Using occupancy theory\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kolchin_Random_allocation')]), ', the distribution of the minimum\nnumber of sensors within each cell is investigated when\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N,narrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '. Then, authors study the lifetime for the\ncase when network remains almost surely connected. Using the number\nof sensors in each cell, the network lifetime is lower bounded based\non the given lifetime of each sensor.\n\nA lifetime study based on the area coverage is presented in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hou_Alpha_lifetime')]), '. It is assumed that the nodes have a\ncircular sensing region and are distributed over a squared area.\nUsing the stochastic geometry, theory of coverage process, and\nassuming the size of the area goes to infinity, an expression for\nthe node density is derived to guarantee a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '-coverage in the area.\nIt is shown that using the proposed density, the network lifetime is\nupper bounded by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['kT'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is the given lifetime of each\nsensor. Although the upper bound is derived for an asymptotic\nsituation when the area goes to infinity, it is shown through\nsimulation that the derived bound is also reasonable for networks\nover a finite area.\n\nAuthors in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rai_Lifetime_Modeling_DATE')]), ' divide linear or\ncircular networks to some bins where each bin contains a\ndeterministically assigned number of nodes. The nodes within each\nbin, however, are deployed randomly. Also, the lifetime is defined\nas the time when a hole occurs in the routing scheme (i.e. death of\na bin). Assuming a fixed transmission power for each packet and\nusing the theory of stochastic processes, authors have found the\nprobability distribution function (pdf) of the network lifetime. In\naddition, they propose a method to assign the number of nodes within\neach bin in order to maximize the network lifetime.\n\n\nIt is worthy to note that other studies in the literature are\nperformed on the lifetime, e.g.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DuarteMelo_Hetereogen_Globecom,Ganz_Lifetime_LargNet_Elsevier,Bydere_reliable_IEICE,\nChen_Lifetime_Commletter,Coleri_Automata_WSNA')]), '. However, the most\nrelated ones to this work are those that we discussed earlier.\n\nIn this paper, we find the probability of reaching a certain\nlifetime for randomly distributed networks based on the power\ndissipation model of the sensors. More specifically, unlike\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Santi_Lifetime_cellbased, Hou_Alpha_lifetime')]), ', we do not\nassume that the lifetime of a sensor is given in order to find the\nnetwork lifetime. Instead, we find the lifetime of a sensor (as a\nrandom variable) based on its power dissipation and packet\ngeneration model. Also, our analysis does not assume an infinite\narea and infinite number of sensors. In comparison to\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rai_Lifetime_Modeling_DATE')]), ', we consider totally randomly\ndeployed networks over more variant area shapes. In addition, both\nfixed and adjustable transmission power are studied in this work.\nAlso, the definition of lifetime in our work is more general and can\ninclude the case studied in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rai_Lifetime_Modeling_DATE')]), ' ', '(to be\ndiscussed in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section lifetime pdf multi-hop')]), ').\n\nConsidering the randomness in packet generation and sensor\ndeployment in the area, the lifetime of a network is a random\nvariable. For a lifetime analysis of the network, it is needed to\nhave a knowledge of the lifetime of each individual sensor. In this\nwork, instead of assuming that the lifetime of each sensor is given\nbeforehand, we first perform a lifetime analysis at the sensor\nlevel. To this end, we model the lifetime of a sensor as a random\nvariable and find its distribution based on the traffic model and\nthe power dissipation model in the sensor. Using this probabilistic\nmodel of a sensor lifetime and the distribution of the sensors over\nthe area, the complementary cumulative distribution function (ccdf)\nof the lifetime of a single-hop network is derived. From this ccdf,\nthe probability distribution function (pdf) of the lifetime is also\nobtained. The single-hop analysis will be the base of our further\nextensions.\n\nIn the proposed analysis, no asymptotic assumption is made on the\nnumber of nodes. Nevertheless, an asymptotic analysis is provided,\nwhich---with an error exponentially decaying with the number of\nsensors---predicts whether or not a desired lifetime can be\nachieved.\n\nThe above analysis is then extended to multi-hop networks. Since the\nlifetime of the multi-hop networks is dependent on the routing\nscheme, we study the lifetime ccdf under the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('maximum-lifetime')]), '\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Al-Karaki_Routing_Magazine2004')]), ' routing.\n\nThe methodologies of this work are applicable to more general\nscenarios, some of them are discussed in this paper. For example, we\nextend the results to different traffic models; to the case where\ndifferent sensors may have different initial energy or traffic load;\nand to various area shapes.\n\nThe organization of this paper is as follows. In Section\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Model')]), ' we introduce the system model and provide the\nrequired definitions and assumptions. The lifetime analysis for\nsingle-hop networks is studied in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Prob Model\nSingle Hop')]), '. Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section lifetime pdf multi-hop')]), ' discuses\nthe lifetime analysis of multi-hop networks. Extensions to other\nscenarios are discussed in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Extnesion')]), ' and the\naccuracy of the proposed method is verified through simulations in\nSection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Simulations')]), '. The paper is concluded in Section\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Conclusion')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('System Model')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Section Model')]), '\nIn this section, the components of the system model such as lifetime\ndefinition, energy consumption model and network traffic model are\nintroduced.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Lifetime Definition')]), '\nAs mentioned, lifetime has a great significance in the design of\nWSNs. Conceptually, lifetime means the time duration that the\nnetwork is operational and can perform its assigned task. Since\nthere is no unique measure of the network failure, the definition of\nthe lifetime is application-related.\n\nIn ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Heinzelman_TCOM, Madan_Distributed_Routing_TWireless,\nChang_Energy_Conserving_Infocom')]), " lifetime is stated as the time when\nthe first node dies. Usually the remaining sensors in the network\ncan accomplish the network's assigned task. Therefore, another\ndefinition based on the ratio of dead nodes to the total number of\nnodes in the network is often used (e.g.\n", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DuarteMelo_Hetereogen_Globecom\n,Heinemann_ACM_Mobicom2001,Oym_ICC_2004')]), '). Notice that this\ndefinition includes the definition of lifetime based on the death of\nthe first node and therefore is more general. Other definitions\nbased on the communication connectivity or the coverage of the area\nare also proposed for the lifetime\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hou_Alpha_lifetime,Santi_Lifetime_cellbased')]), '.\n\nIn this study, we consider the network lifetime based on the ratio\nof dead nodes to the total number of nodes, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), '. For multi-hop\nnetworks, where the nodes close to the sink have more traffic load\nthan other nodes and die sooner, we will modify this definition.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Energy Consumption Model')]), '\nThe network lifetime is directly related to the sensors lifetime\nand in other words the energy dissipated in the sensor nodes. The\nconsumed energy in sensors includes the energy required for sensing,\nreceiving, transmitting and processing of data. The total consumed\nenergy is usually dominated by the required energy for data\ntransmission.\n\nTwo cases may be considered for the transmission mode of the nodes\nin the network. In the first case, nodes transmit with a fixed\ntransmission power. This usually results in a fixed transmission\nrange. In the second case, nodes use a mechanism to adjust their\ntransmission power based on their distance to the next hop or the\nsink. Hence, the required energy for a packet transmission in sensor\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' can be modeled as ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hein_Tranmission_model_2000')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\ne(d_i)&= l(e_t d_i ^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), ' + e_o) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&=kd_i^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), '+c  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Power dissipation model')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l'], []), ' represents the packet length in bits, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_i'], []), ' denotes the\ndistance between sensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' and the next hop, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' represents\nthe path loss exponent, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_t'], []), ' shows the loss coefficient related to\n1 bit transmission and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_o'], []), ' is the overhead energy due to the\nsensing, receiving and processing for the same amount of data. Also,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k = le_t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c = le_o'], []), ' represent the loss coefficient and the\noverhead energy for a packet transmission respectively. The path\nloss exponent depends on the local terrain and is determined by\nempirical measurements. The typical value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' for WSNs is\nfrom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Oym_ICC_2004')]), '.\n\nWhile this work is more focused on the transmission model\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Power dissipation model')]), '), fixed transmission power is also\ndiscussed.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Traffic Model')]), '\nThe traffic model of the network depends on the network application\nand the behavior of sensed events. The data reporting process in\nWSNs is usually classified into three categories: event-driven,\ntime-driven and query-driven ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Al-Karaki_Routing_Magazine2004')]), '.\nIn the time-driven case, sensors send their data periodically to the\nsink. Event-driven networks are used when it is desired to inform\nthe data sink about the occurrence of an event. In query-driven\nnetworks, sink sends a request of data gathering when needed. In\nthis paper, our main focus will be on the event-driven networks with\nPoisson model for packet generation.\n\nSuppose that the events are independent (both temporally and\nspatially) and occur with equal probability over the area. In this\ncase, Poisson distribution can be used effectively to model the\ngeneration of data packets ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rai_Lifetime_Modeling_DATE')]), '. When\nthe average rate of packet generation, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ', is known, the\ndistribution of the number of data packets, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', generated by each\nnode, from time 0 to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Packet generation model Poisson')]), '\nP(M=m) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('lambda'), ' T'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('lambda'), ' T)^m'), BraceGroup('m!')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' is a nonnegative integer number. Since the packet\ngeneration distribution obeys the Poisson model, the time duration\nbetween two consequent packet transmissions, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ', has an exponential\ndistribution with mean ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))])], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Packet generation model Exp')]), '\nf_t(x)= ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-x', TexCmd('lambda')), ' u(x)\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u(x)'], []), " denotes the unit step function.\n\nWe will consider the Poisson model for sensor's traffic in this\nstudy. However, the proposed method can be extended to other traffic\ndistributions and data gathering scenarios.\n", TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Lifetime Analysis in Single-hop Networks')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Section Prob Model Single Hop')]), '\nIn this section, we derive the pdf of the lifetime in single-hop\nWSNs. Assuming that nodes directly communicate with the sink, we\nfirst derive the ccdf of the lifetime. Then, the pdf of the lifetime\nis obtained by taking the derivative of the ccdf. The results are\nextended to the case of multi-hop networks in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section\nlifetime pdf multi-hop')]), '.\n\nIt is assumed here that all of the nodes have the same initial\nenergy, same distribution over the area and the same packet\ngeneration model. Other cases like nonuniform energy distribution or\ndifferent packet generation models are studied in Section\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Extnesion')]), '.\n\nFor the ease of presentation, the list of parameters is provided in\nTable ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Parameters')]), '. As mentioned, the lifetime of a single-hop\nWSN is considered as the time when the ratio of dead nodes to the\ntotal number of nodes, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ', passes a threshold, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '& Number of deployed nodes in the area\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), '& Threshold for the ratio of dead nodes to all nodes\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), '& Path loss exponent\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '& Path loss coefficient\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '& Overhead energy\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_i'], []), '& Initial energy in sensors\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' ', '& Lifetime threshold\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), '& Lifetime achieved by sensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), '\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '& Lifetime achieved by the network\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), '& Average rate of packet generation\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_i'], []), '& Distance of sensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' to the next hop\n', TexCmd('hline'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('|l l|')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Parameters of the problem')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Parameters')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!h')]), '\nWe start the network lifetime analysis by considering the lifetime\nof one sensor. Defining ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Pi related to E')]), '\np_i = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_i'), BraceGroup('e(d_i)')]), '\n'], []), '\nfor sensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ', it is clear that the maximum number of packets that\ncan be transmitted by this sensor is equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor')], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('lem'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lemma Sensor lifetime')]), ' If a sensor node with initial\nenergy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_i'], []), ' is randomly placed in the area ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), ', the\nprobability of achieving a lifetime more than a threshold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), '\nwill be\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime')]), '\nP(t_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ') = 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ',', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ')')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '( ', TexCmd('cdot'), ',', TexCmd('cdot'), ')'], []), ' denotes the lower incomplete gamma\nfunction\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lower Inc Gamma')]), '\n', TexCmd('gamma'), '(a,x) = ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^x t^', BraceGroup('a - 1'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-t'), '\\,', 'dt\n'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '(', TexCmd('cdot'), ')'], []), ' represents the gamma function\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(x) = ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' t^', BraceGroup('x - 1'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-t'), '\\,', 'dt.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof:')]), ' The lifetime of sensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), ', depends on the\nmaximum number of packets that can be transmitted by the sensor to\nthe sink. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), ' is the sum of time durations between packet\ntransmissions until the last packet is sent by the sensor, we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('t_i the sum of t_ij')]), '\nt_i = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor')), ' t_', BraceGroup('ij'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' denotes the time duration between transmitting\npackets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j-1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' by sensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_', BraceGroup('i1')], []), ' is defined as the\ntime when the first packet is transmitted. Since a Poisson model is\nassumed for data packet generation, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), "'s obey an exponential\ndistribution indicated in (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Packet generation model Exp')]), '). On\nthe other hand, it is known that the sum of independent identically\ndistributed (i.i.d) exponential random variables has a gamma\ndistribution ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ross_Prob')]), '. It is worthy to note that since the\nnode is deployed randomly in the area, the distance between the node\nand the sink and consequently ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' are a random variables. Hence,\ngiven ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ', the conditional pdf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), ' can be written as follows\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pdf of t_i ineteger')]), '\nf_', BraceGroup('t_i ', TexCmd('vert'), ' p_i'), '(x) = ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ' '), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ' - 1'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('lambda'), ' x')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '  ', '(', TexCmd('lfloor'), '\np_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), '  ', ')')]), '  ', TexCmd('quad'), ' x ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0.\n'], []), '\nNow\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nP(t_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('vert'), ' p_i) & =  1 - ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau')), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lfloor'), '\np_i ', TexCmd('rfloor')), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), '\n-1'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('lambda'), ' x')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '( ', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ')')]), '\\,', 'dx ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '& = 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ',', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ')')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime')]), '.\n'], []), ' ', TexCmd('hfill'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('blacksquare')], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('prop'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('approx floorP by P')]), ' Since the fractional part of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), '\nis usually much smaller than the integer part, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), '\n', TexCmd('simeq'), ' p_i'], []), ' and hence (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime')]), ') can be\nrewritten as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime real')]), '\nP(t_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('vert'), ' p_i) = 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '(p_i,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(p_i)')]), '\n'], []), '\nFor simplicity, we use (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime\nreal')]), ') to analyze the network lifetime in the sequel.\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('square')], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('corol'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Corollary fixed power transmission')]), ' In the case of the\nfixed transmission range, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ', each node lives more than the\nthreshold with probability\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Probability fixed transmission')]), '\nP(t_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ')= 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '(p_f,', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(p_f)')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\np_f = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_i'), BraceGroup('k r ^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), ' + c')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof:')]), ' In this case, all of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), "'s have a\ndeterministic value equal to ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_f'], []), '. Therefore, the value of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(t_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime real')]), ') is unconditional and\nthe proof is completed by replacing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_f'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime real')]), ').', TexCmd('hfill'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('square')], []), '\n', '\nOne can take another approach and approximate the value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P(t_i\n', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' to find a simpler form of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ccdf of sensor lifetime\nreal')]), ').\n\n', TexCmd('prop'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Propositon Q function')]), ' Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('t_i the sum of t_ij')]), ') is the sum of i.i.d.\nrandom variables, central limit theorem (CLT)  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ross_Prob')]), '\nindicates that its pdf tends to Gaussian distribution with mean\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' and variance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), '\n', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), '. Considering ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ' ', TexCmd('approx'), ' p_i'], []), ', we\nhave\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('s_i Q_function')]), '\nP(t_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('vert'), ' p_i) = Q(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ' -\np_i', TexCmd('lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('p_i')]), TexCmd('lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'))]), ').\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q(', TexCmd('cdot'), ')'], []), ' is the ccdf of the normal distribution. ', TexCmd('hfill'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('square')], []), '\n', '\nTo study the lifetime of the network, we consider the lifetime of\nall the nodes in the network which necessitates the knowledge of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' for all of the nodes in the network. When a node is deployed\nrandomly over an area, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' is a random variable with pdf\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('p_i'), '(x)'], []), '. In a random network deployment, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), "'s are usually\ni.i.d. random variables and consequently have the same distribution,\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('p'), '(x)'], []), '. This distribution depends on the shape of the area,\nenergy dissipation model and the pdf of node distribution over the\narea. In the Appendix, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_p(x)'], []), ' is derived for some common area\nshapes assuming a uniform distribution for the node deployment.\n\n', TexCmd('theo'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lifetime theorem')]), ' Assuming ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' equal-energy nodes are\ndistributed independently over the area ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), ', the probability\nthat the network achieves a lifetime more than a given threshold,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ', is equal to\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Probability Formula')]), '\nP(L', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ') = Q (', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1- ', TexCmd('beta'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '\n', ')\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('align', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Mu Integral relation')]), '\n', '&', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), '  ', '(1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(x)')]), ') f_', BraceGroup('p'), '(x)', '\\,', 'dx \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Mu and Sigma relation')]), ' ', '&', TexCmd('sigma'), ' = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), '^2')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof')]), ': To find the number of nodes that live more than the\nlifetime threshold, we define a Bernoulli random variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), '\nindicating the success of achieving the lifetime threshold by sensor\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Bernoulli RV')]), '\nl_i= ', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n1& ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('With probability equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_i'], []))]), ',\n0& ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('With probability equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1- s_i'], []))]), '.\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), ' .\n'], []), '\nThe success probability of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), ', given ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ', is equal to\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('s_i related to gamma function')]), '\ns_i = P(t_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('vert'), ' p_i) = 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '(p_i,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(p_i)')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhich was derived in Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lemma Sensor lifetime')]), '. The number\nof live nodes after time ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' can be found by defining a new\nrandom variable, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ', that denotes the number of successes in the\nBernoulli trials shown by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), "'s\n", TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('W sum of Ki')]), '\nw = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^N l_i.\n'], []), '\nSince nodes packet generations are independent and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), "'s are\ni.i.d., ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_i'], []), "'s and consequently ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), "'s are also i.i.d random\nvariables. In this case, ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' has a binomial distribution\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Nedleman_Bernoulli_Statistician')]), '. Also, when the number of\ntrials is large enough, one can approximate the binomial\ndistribution with a Gaussian distribution. Since the number of nodes\nare usually large enough, CLT can be applied on (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W sum of Ki')]), ').\nHence\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Dist of W')]), '\nf_w(x)= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('sigma'), '_w')]), '\n', TexCmd('exp', [BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(x-', TexCmd('mu'), '_w)^2'), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('sigma'), '_w^2')]))]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_w'], []), ' is the mean and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_w^2'], []), ' denotes the variance of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), '. From (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('W sum of Ki')]), '), it is clear that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Mean of W')]), '\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_w = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^N ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i')], []), ' is the mean of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), "'s are\nindependent random variables\n", TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Var of W')]), '\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_w^2 = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^N ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), '^2\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), '^2'], []), ' is the variance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), '. To find the values\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_w'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_w'], []), ', we need to have the unconditional mean\nand variance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), "'s using the conditional values. Since ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), "'s\nare Bernoulli random variables\n", TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Mean and var k_i Cond')]), '\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i ', TexCmd('vert'), ' p_i'), '= s_i, ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i ', TexCmd('vert'), ' p_i'), '^2 = s_i -\ns_i^2.\n'], []), '\nOn the other hand, for two random variables ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ', the\nunconditional mean and variance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' can be found using the\nconditional mean and variance as follows ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ross_Prob')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '&', TexCmd('mu'), '_x = E', '[', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('x ', TexCmd('vert'), ' z'), ']', ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('mean conditional')]), ' \n', '&', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2_x = E', '[', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2_', BraceGroup('x ', TexCmd('vert'), ' z'), ']', ' + ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Var'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('x ', TexCmd('vert'), ' z'))]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Var conditional')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E', '[', TexCmd('cdot'), ']'], []), ' is the expected value and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Var'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('cdot'))])], []), '\ndenotes the variance of the random variable. Using (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('s_i related\nto gamma function')]), '), (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Mean and var k_i Cond')]), '), (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mean\nconditional')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Var conditional')]), '), it can be shown that\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '&', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), ' = E', '[', 's_i', ']', ' = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), '  ', '(1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '\n', '(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(x)')]), ') f_', BraceGroup('p_i'), '(x)', '\\,', 'dx\n&', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2_', BraceGroup('l_i'), ' = E', '[', 's_i - s_i^2', ']', ' + ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Var'), BracketGroup('s_i')]), ' = E', '[', 's_i', ']', ' -\nE^2', '[', 's_i', ']', ' = ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), '^2_', BraceGroup('l_i'), '.\n'], []), '\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), "'s are i.i.d random variables with pdf ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_p(x)'], []), ', we have\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '&', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), ' = ', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), '  ', '(1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '\n', '(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(x)')]), ') f_', BraceGroup('p'), '(x)', '\\,', 'dx   ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('forall'), ' i \n&', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), ' = ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), '^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('forall'), ' i.\n'], []), '\nThen, using (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Mean of W')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Var of W')]), ')\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('mu and var w ')]), '\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_w = N', TexCmd('mu'), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2_w = N', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2\n'], []), '\n', '\nTo derive the probability of achieving the lifetime threshold by the\nnetwork, we just need to know the probability of achieving the\nlifetime by at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1 - ', TexCmd('beta'), ')N'], []), ' nodes. Hence\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nF_L^c(', TexCmd('tau'), ') = P(L', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ') & = P(w ', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', '(1-', TexCmd('beta'), ')N)', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&= Q(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1- ', TexCmd('beta'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), ' ', ')\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_L^c(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' represents the ccdf of the network lifetime.\n', TexCmd('hfill'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('blacksquare')], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('prop'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Proposition mu Q function')]), ' Using Proposition\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Propositon Q function')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' can also be calculated as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), ' Q(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('thr')])), ' -\nx', TexCmd('lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('-1')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('x')]), TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-1'))]), ') f_', BraceGroup('p'), '(x)', '\\,', 'dx.\n'], []), TexCmd('hfill'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('square')], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('corol'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Corollary lifetime PDF')]), ' Assuming a network with\nparameters given in Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lifetime theorem')]), ', the probability\ndistribution function of the network lifetime is\n', TexNamedEnv('align', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lifetime pdf')]), '\nf_L(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=&', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N')])), BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'))]))]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('mu'), '-', TexCmd('beta'), '( 1\n- 2', TexCmd('mu'), ') '), BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), '^2)^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')])))]), ' c(', TexCmd('tau'), ') e^', BraceGroup('-(', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '\n+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N(1-', TexCmd('beta'), ' -', TexCmd('mu'), ')^2'), BraceGroup('2(', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), '^2)')]), ')'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '& 0', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('infty'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nc(', TexCmd('tau'), ') = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('f_p(x)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(x)')]), '(', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')^', BraceGroup('x-1'), '\\,', 'dx.\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof')]), ': The ccdf of the network lifetime was derived in the\nprevious theorem. Then we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nf_L(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=\n-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d(F^c_L(', TexCmd('tau'), '))'), BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('tau'))]), '=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d(F^c_L(', TexCmd('mu'), '))'), BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('mu'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('tau'))]), '\n'], []), '\nwhich results in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lifetime pdf')]), '). ', TexCmd('hfill'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('blacksquare')], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Lifetime Analysis in Multi-hop Networks')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Section lifetime pdf multi-hop')]), '\nIn multi-hop networks, the network lifetime depends on the way that\nthe routing scheme distributes the traffic load among the sensor\nnodes. The minimum cost routing (minimum required energy or minimum\nnumber of hops) is conventionally used in wireless networks.\nHowever, this routing scheme cannot guarantee the maximum lifetime\nin the network ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Al-Karaki_Routing_Magazine2004')]), '. On the other\nhand, maximum lifetime routing attempts to prolong the network\nlifetime by proper traffic distribution among the nodes. This scheme\nmay not have the minimum overall consumed energy. Since we mainly\nfocus on the lifetime analysis, we just consider the maximum\nlifetime routing. Nevertheless, the proposed approach can be used for other routing schemes knowing how the traffic is distributed among the nodes.\n\nIn multi-hop networks, the whole network traffic passes through the\nnodes in the vicinity of the sink, hence, death of these nodes can\nhave a significant effect on the network performance. Therefore, we\nneed to modify our previous definition of the lifetime.\n\nAssume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' shows the set of nodes that are in the\nvicinity of the sink and directly communicate with it. Since all\nother nodes communicate to the sink through these nodes, they will\nbe out of energy sooner than the other ones. So, we define the\nlifetime based on the ratio of dead nodes within ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vert'), '\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), ' ', TexCmd('vert')], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vert'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('vert')], []), ' denotes the cardinality\nof the set. It is also assumed that the sensors are distributed over\na circle with radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' and the data sink is positioned at the\ncenter of the area. The lifetime of the network over other area\nshapes will be discussed later.\n\nWe assume that the sensors perform transmission with a fixed power\nwhich results in a fixed transmission range ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '. Based on the\nmaximum transmission radius of the sensors and the area radius, the\narea can be divided to a number of rings (Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig Tx\nrings')]), '). The sensors within a ring send their data to the sensors\nwithin the neighboring inner ring. The number of rings, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ', within\nthe area can be simply found as\n', TexNamedEnv('align', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Number of tiers')]), '\nn =  ', TexCmd('lceil'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R'), BraceGroup('r')]), '  ', TexCmd('rceil'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lceil'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('rceil')], []), ' denotes the integer ceiling. For\nsimplicity, it is assumed that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' is an integer multiple of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '.\nThis assumption allows us to focus on methodologies and can be\nremoved if necessary. In addition, since each ring carries the\ntraffic of all outer rings, the average traffic carried by the\nsensors within each ring is different and depends on the distance of\nthe ring to the sink. To study the network lifetime, we consider the\ncase when the routing scheme distributes the network traffic equally\nbetween the nodes within each ring. This scheme prevents the nodes\nfrom being exhausted quickly and prolongs the lifetime.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=.11'), BraceGroup('Multihop_Net.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Rings within a multi-hop network')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig Tx rings')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!h')]), '\n', '\nBased on the assumed routing scheme, the average rate of the packet\ntransmission by each node within ring ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' is equal to\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('lambda of tiers')]), '\n', TexCmd('lambda'), '_i = ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('N - ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^', BraceGroup('i-1'), ' N_j'), BraceGroup('N_i')]), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('forall'), ' i = 1,2,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',n\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_i'], []), ' denotes the number of sensors within ring ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), '. Since\nnodes are assumed to be deployed randomly in the area, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_i'], []), ' is a\nbinomial random variable. If one assumes a uniform deployment for\nthe nodes, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_i'], []), ' will have a binomial distribution with mean ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Nq_i'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('binomial chance for rings')]), '\nq_i = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r^2 (2i - 1)'), BraceGroup('R^2')]), '\n'], []), '\nrepresents the probability of positioning a sensor in the ring ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), '.\nTherefore, the time duration between two consequent transmissions,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ', by a node in the ring ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' obeys an exponential distribution as\nfollows\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('exponential model for rings')]), '\nf_', BraceGroup('t ', TexCmd('vert'), ' N_i'), '(x) = ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_i e^', BraceGroup('-x ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_i'), ' u(x).\n'], []), '\nSince the lifetime is mainly effected by the nodes within the first\ntier, we just consider the probability of achieving the lifetime\nthreshold by the first ring. Nevertheless, the probability of\nachieving ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' by other rings can also be investigated using\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('exponential model for rings')]), '). As discussed earlier,\nprobability of achieving a lifetime threshold depends on the number\nof nodes within the area. Hence, using Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lifetime\ntheorem')]), ' and Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Corollary fixed power transmission')]), ', one\ncan find the conditional probability of achieving ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' by the\nfirst ring\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ccdf for the first ring')]), '\nP(L', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('vert'), ' N_1) = Q (', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('N_1')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1 - ', TexCmd('beta'), ' -\n', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), ')\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '&', TexCmd('mu'), ' = 1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '(p_f,', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(p_f)')]), ' \n', '&', TexCmd('sigma'), ' = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), '^2')]), '.\n'], []), '\nTherefore, by removing the condition on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_1'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ccdf for the\nfirst ring')]), '), we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Unconditioing Ni')]), '\nP(L', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ') = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=0'), '^N P(L', TexCmd('geq'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ' ', TexCmd('vert'), ' N_1) P(N_1 = j)', TexCmd('quad'), '\nn_1 = 1,2,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',N\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['(', TexNamedEnv('array', ['Nn_1'], [BraceGroup('c')]), ')\nP(N_1 = n_1) =  q_1^', BraceGroup('n_1'), ' ', '(1- q_1)^', BraceGroup('N - n_1'), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe given discussion is not restricted to circular areas and can\nalso be applied to other area shapes. To study the lifetime of the\nnetwork in other area shapes, we just need to recalculate the value\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q_1'], []), ' as follows\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('q1 other area shapes')]), '\nq_1 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), ' r^2'), BraceGroup('S')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' is the size of area. Then, ccdf of the lifetime is derived\nby putting this value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q_1'], []), ' into (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Unconditioing Ni')]), ').\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Some Notes')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Section Extnesion')]), '\nIn Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Prob Model Single Hop')]), ', we considered the\nfinite number of nodes in the area. We will study the asymptotic\nanalysis in this section. Also, we earlier studied the case when all\nof the sensors have the same features such as traffic model, initial\nenergy and deployment. In addition, the packet generation model was\nsupposed to be Poisson. Here, we provide some discussions on the\nresults in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Prob Model Single Hop')]), ' and\ngeneralize them for more cases.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Asymptotic Analysis')]), '\nSince the lifetime ccdf in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Probability Formula')]), ') depends on\nthe number of nodes distributed over the area, we can study the\neffect of the node density on the probability of achieving the\nlifetime threshold.\n\n', TexCmd('corol'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Corollary on node density')]), ' The probability of\nachieving a lifetime threshold approaches 0 or 1 by increasing the\nnumber of nodes.\n\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof:')]), ' For large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ', two cases can happen depending on the\nsign of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a = 1 - ', TexCmd('beta'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu')], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), '-function is a decreasing\nfunction, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a\n> 0'], []), ', increasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' causes the probability of hitting the lifetime\nthreshold to tend ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q(', TexCmd('infty'), ') = 0'], []), '. In other words, almost surely the\ngiven lifetime threshold cannot be achieved. Now, considering that\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Salehi_Commsystems')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'))]), 'x')]), '(1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('x^2')]), ')\ne^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^2'), BraceGroup('2')])), ' < Q(x) < ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'))]), 'x')]), '\ne^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^2'), BraceGroup('2')])), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('forall'), ' x', TexCmd('geq'), '  0\n'], []), '\nthe rate of the probability decay is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup('-N')], []), '. In a\nsimilar manner, the probability approaches ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q(-', TexCmd('infty'), ') = 1'], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a\n< 0'], []), '. That is, the network almost surely achieves the lifetime\nthreshold. The error in this prediction also decays exponentially\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '. ', TexCmd('hfill'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('blacksquare')], []), '\n', '\nAn interesting case occurs when one considers the lifetime of the\nnetwork based on the death of the first node. In this case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), ' =\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('N')])], []), ', which approaches 0 when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' increases. Hence,\naccording to the Corollary ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Corollary on node density')]), ', it is\nnecessary to consider just the sign of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 - ', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' in order to predict\nthe asymptotic behavior of the network lifetime (i.e. when\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Narrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '). Assuming ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), ' > 0'], []), ', we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), '  ', '(1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\n', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(x)')]), ') f_', BraceGroup('p'), '(x)', '\\,', 'dx < ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), '\nf_', BraceGroup('p'), '(x)', '\\,', 'dx = 1\n'], []), '\nand consequently ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 - ', TexCmd('mu'), ' > 0'], []), '. Therefore, under this stringent\ndefinition of the lifetime, the probability of achieving the\nlifetime ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' approaches 0 as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' increases.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Different Traffic Models')]), '\nIn Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Prob Model Single Hop')]), ', we considered the\ncase when all of the sensors have the same Poisson model for the\npacket generation. Here, we consider two other cases: 1) The average\nrate of packet generation changes with the position of the sensor,\n2) packet generation obeys another model rather than Poisson. It is\nworthy to note that the assumed model is similar for all of the\nsensors.\n\nIf the average rate of packet generation, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ', varies with the\nposition of the sensor (e.g. due to the spatial correlation of data\nor data aggregation and compression), we have the mean and variance\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), ' conditioned on both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), '. To derive the\nunconditional mean and variance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_i'], []), ', we need to calculate\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('joint lambda P')]), '\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_i'), ' = ', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')])), '  ', '(1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), '\n', '(x,', TexCmd('lambda'), '\ny)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(x)')]), ') f_', BraceGroup('p,', TexCmd('lambda')), '(x,y)', '\\,', 'dx dy\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup('p,', TexCmd('lambda')), '(x,y)'], []), ' denotes the joint pdf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), '. Other parts of the analysis will remain unchanged.\n\nAlso, the proof given for Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lifetime theorem')]), ' can be\napplied to the cases when the traffic model obeys another pattern\nrather than Poisson model. Assume that the pdf of the time duration\nbetween two packet transmissions follows a model with mean ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_t'], []), '\nand variance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_t^2'], []), '. Using CLT, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t_i'], []), ' can be accurately\napproximated by a Gaussian distribution with mean ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i ', TexCmd('mu'), '_t'], []), ' and\nvariance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t^2'], []), '. The remaining part of the proof is\nunchanged.\n\nThe proposed analysis can also be extended to time-driven networks.\nIn this case, the time duration between two consequent transmissions\nis fixed and is equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '. Hence\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sensor lifetime time driven')]), '\nt_i = ', TexCmd('lfloor'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('rfloor'), ' T.\n'], []), '\nThe unconditional values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is found by\nintegration over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), '. Then, the result given in Theorem\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lifetime theorem')]), ' can be applied.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Nonuniform Energy Distribution')]), '\nAssume that the energy is distributed over the network in a\nnonuniform way. As a consequence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_i'], []), "'s in (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('s_i related to\ngamma function')]), ') are not identically distributed. This may also\narise when the sensors generate packets with different rates (i.e.\nnonidentical Poisson distributions). In this situation, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' does not\nhave any standard distribution, however, we can still use CLT to\napproximate the pdf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' with a Gaussian distribution. To this\nend, we will give a brief discussion on the probability of achieving\nthe lifetime threshold by the network.\n', TexCmd('lem'), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Lemma Surprising')]), ' Assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z_i'], []), "'s (", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('leq'), ' i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' m'], []), ')\nare ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' independent random variables such that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^m ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('z_i'), ' = m ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), '.\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('z_i')], []), ' denotes the mean of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z_i'], []), '. Also, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i'], []), "'s (", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('leq'), ' i\n', TexCmd('leq'), ' m'], []), ') are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' Bernoulli trials such that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nP(X_i = 1) = z_i ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('forall'), ' i.\n'], []), '\nNow, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' denotes the sum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X_i'], []), "'s, the variance of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is\nmaximum when\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('z_i'), ' = ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('forall'), ' i=1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',m\n'], []), '\n', '(see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Nedleman_Bernoulli_Statistician')]), ' for the proof).\n\n', TexCmd('corol'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Corollary')]), ' For nonidentical distributed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_i'], []), "'s such\nthat\n", TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mu'), '_w = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^N ', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('l_', BraceGroup('i')), '=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^N E', '[', 's_i', ']', '=N ', TexCmd('mu'), '\n'], []), '\n', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Probability Formula')]), ') is an upper bound for the probability of\nachieving the lifetime when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 - ', TexCmd('beta'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), ' >0'], []), ', otherwise it is a\nlower bound.\n\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof:')]), ' Since we assumed the identical distribution in the\nproof of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lifetime theorem')]), ', Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Lemma\nSurprising')]), ' indicates that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_w'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mu and var w ')]), ') is\nthe maximum possible variance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), '. The proof is completed\nconsidering the decreasing property of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Q'], []), '-function. ', TexCmd('hfill'), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('blacksquare')], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Experimental results')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Section Simulations')]), '\nIn this section, we investigate the accuracy of the proposed\nanalysis through some experiments. We first study the probability of\nachieving a lifetime threshold in single-hop networks. To this end,\nthe simulations are performed over different area shapes with the\nsame area size to investigate the effect of the area shape. In\naddition, the effect of the node density is studied. Moreover,\nsimulations are performed to study the network lifetime in multi-hop\nnetworks. Through these simulations, it will be shown that how the\ntransmission range and consequently the number of hops effect the\nlifetime of the network.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Single-hop Networks')]), '\nThe parameters of model (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Power dissipation model')]), ') depend on\nthe data rate, antenna height, antenna gain, etc. Typical values of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_o'], []), ' are given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Heinzelman_Phd_Thes')]), '. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '\n= 4'], []), ', which we use in our simulations, the values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_o'], []), '\nare respectively 0.0013 pJ/bit/', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^4'], []), ' and 50 nJ/bit for a\n1Mbps data stream. Here, It is assumed that the packets have 1000\nbits length, hence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ='], []), '1.3 pJ/', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^4'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c ='], []), '50 ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), 'J in\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Power dissipation model')]), ').\n\nNetwork has 500 nodes that are deployed uniformly and sink is\npositioned at the center of the area. Also, the packet generation\nmodel obeys the Poisson distribution and each sensor sends its\npackets directly to the sink. All of the sensors have the same\ninitial energy equal to 11 mJ. Assuming that sensors send packet\nwith the average rate of 1 packet/hour, the probability of achieving\nthe lifetime of 100 hours is studied through simulation.\n\nTo investigate the effect of the area shape on the lifetime, the\nsimulations are carried out over areas with the same size equal to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['100 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('m')]), '^2'], []), ' but with different shapes. To decrease the\nfinal result variance and reach the proper confidence interval, the\nsimulation is run 10000 times over each area and the results are\naveraged.\n\nFigure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Beta Diff area shapes')]), ' depicts the probability of\nachieving the lifetime threshold vs. the ratio of dead nodes over\ncircular, hexagonal, squared and triangular areas. As it can be\nseen, the probability of achieving the lifetime threshold in\ncircular, hexagonal and squared areas are very close. Since in a\ntriangle, the distance of the sensors to the sink is more\nnon-uniform and it has the largest circumcircle compared to other\narea shapes, triangle has a smaller probability to achieve the\nlifetime threshold.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=.41'), BraceGroup('REsult_Diff_Area.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Probability of achieving the lifetime threshold vs. the\nratio of dead nodes for single-hop networks deployed over different\narea shapes')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Beta Diff area shapes')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!h')]), '\n', '\nAs discussed through the paper, depending on the value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 - ', TexCmd('mu'), ' -\n', TexCmd('beta')], []), ' and by increasing the number of nodes, it can be almost\nsurely determined whether the network achieves a lifetime threshold\nor not. The effect of the node density on achieving the lifetime\nthreshold is shown in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig Node density effect')]), '. The\nlifetime of the network is considered as the moment when 0.3 of the\nnodes in the network die. In the first case, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_i = 11'], []), ' mJ which\nresults in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 - ', TexCmd('beta'), ' - ', TexCmd('mu'), ' > 0'], []), '. Hence, as discussed in Section\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section Extnesion')]), ', the desired probability decreases by\nincreasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' which is verified by the simulation. In the second\ncase, the initial energy is equal to 11.6 mJ which causes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1 - ', TexCmd('beta'), '\n- ', TexCmd('mu'), ' < 0'], []), '. As shown in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig Node density effect')]), ',\nthe probability of achieving the desired lifetime is an increasing\nfunction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=.41'), BraceGroup('Diff_N_results_fig.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Probability of achieving the lifetime threshold vs. the\nnumber of sensors in a single-hop network')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig Node density\neffect')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!h')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Multi-hop Networks')]), '\nTo study the network lifetime in a multi-hop network, it is assumed\nthat 500 nodes are deployed uniformly over a circle with radius 100 m. All of the nodes have the same initial energy\nequal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_i = 100'], []), ' mJ. The parameters in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Power dissipation\nmodel')]), ') are kept the same as the previous part. A greedy routing\nalgorithm is used to balance the network traffic such that data\npackets are identically distributed between the nodes in the first\nring of the network, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), '. Considering this fact that all of\nthe nodes use a constant transmission power and the traffic is\ndistributed identically between the first-ring nodes, all of the\nnodes within ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' have approximately similar lifetime. As a\nconsequence, they die in time moments very close to each other.\nTherefore, we can say that the desired probability is not\nsignificantly effected by the value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' ', '(Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig Beta\nMultihop')]), ').\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=.41'), BraceGroup('Result_multihop_Beta.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Probability of achieving the lifetime threshold vs. the\nratio of dead nodes in a multi-hop network')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig Beta\nMultihop')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!h')]), '\n', '\nIt is interesting to study the effect of the transmission range and\nconsequently the number of hops on the lifetime. Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Fig\nmultihop Tx range')]), ' depicts the probability of reaching the lifetime\nthreshold vs. the transmission range. The lifetime is considered as\nthe moment when 0.3 nodes within ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' are dead. By\ndecreasing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ', number of nodes within ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' decreases, hence,\nthey carry more packets and will die earlier. Therefore, it is\nexpected that the desired probability decreases by reducing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '.\nIndeed, while the nodes far from the sink still have enough energy\nto send packets, the nodes within ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' cease. To overcome this\ndrawback, nonuniform energy distribution can be applied\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IEEE_Monograph')]), '. Also, the fixed transmission power causes the\nnodes within ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' to die sooner compared to the case where nodes adjust their transmission power.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexCmd('centering'), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=.41'), BraceGroup('Result_multihop.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Probability of achieving the lifetime threshold vs. the\ntransmission range in a multi-hop network')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Fig multihop Tx\nrange')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('!h')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('conclusions')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Section Conclusion')]), '\nIn this paper, we considered the problem of finding the probability\nof achieving a lifetime threshold by the network which is equivalent\nto finding the ccdf of the network lifetime. Using the power\nconsumption model of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Power dissipation model')]), '), the ccdf of\nthe lifetime was derived for the single-hop networks. To this end,\nit was assumed that all of the nodes have identical packet\ngeneration model, initial energy and random deployment in the area.\nThe methodology was also extended to the case when these conditions\nmay not be satisfied. Then, the problem was studied for the\nmulti-hop case. In addition, the asymptotic relation between the\nnumber of nodes and the lifetime was investigated. Through some\nsimulations, the accuracy of our analysis was investigated for the\nnetworks deployed over different area shapes. Using the proposed\nmethod, one can design both node and network parameters (e.g. node\ndensity, data rate, initial energy) according to the desired\nlifetime.\n\n', TexCmd('section*', [BraceGroup('Appendix')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Appendix pdf of p')]), '\nThe pdf of the network lifetime depends on the distribution of the\nmaximum possible number of packet transmissions by each node, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '.\nIn this appendix, we find the pdf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' over some common area\nshapes. The pdf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' over a circle area is required for finding\nthe lifetime pdf of multi-hop networks in Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Section\nlifetime pdf multi-hop')]), '. Also, this pdf over regular polygons is\nuseful for studying the lifetime of a network composed of clusters\ntiling the area.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Network Deployed Over a Circle')]), '\nAssume that the nodes are deployed uniformly over a circle with radius ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), '.\nAlso, assume that the sink is located at the center of the circle.\nSince the nodes are deployed uniformly over the area, the pdf of the\ndistance between the nodes and sink, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ', is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nf_d(x) = ', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2x'), BraceGroup('R^2')]), '  ', '& ', TexCmd('quad'), ' 0 < x ', TexCmd('leq'), ' R\n0 & ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('small', [BraceGroup('Otherwise')]))]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '.\n.\n'], []), '\nNow, using the energy consumption model (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Power dissipation\nmodel')]), '), we have the following expression for the pdf of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('f_p circle')]), '\nf_', BraceGroup('p'), '(x)  = ', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2E_i'), BraceGroup('R^2 k ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' x^2'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_i -\ncx'), BraceGroup('kx')]))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2-', TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))])), '&', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_i'), BraceGroup('kR^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), ' +\nc')]), TexCmd('leq'), ' x < ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_i'), BraceGroup('c')]), '\n0 & ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('small', [BraceGroup('Otherwise')]))]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '. .\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Network Deployed Over a Regular Polygon')]), '\nSuppose that the sensors are deployed over a regular polygon having\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' equal sides with length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), '. Again, we assume that the sink is\nplaced at the center of the area. In this case, we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nf_d(x) = ', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), ' x'), BraceGroup('S')]), ' ', '& 0 < x ', TexCmd('leq'), ' r_i \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), ' x - 2 n x ', TexCmd('cos'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('x')]))), BraceGroup('S')]), ' ', '& r_i < x ', TexCmd('leq'), ' R_c\n0 & ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('small', [BraceGroup('Otherwise')]))]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), ' .\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nr_i = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('cot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), BraceGroup('n')]))]), '\n'], []), '\nis the radius of the inscribed circle of the polygon,\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nR_c = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('sin', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), BraceGroup('n')]))]))]), '\n'], []), '\nrepresents the radius of the circumcircle of the polygon and\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nS = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('n'), BraceGroup('4')]), ' a^2 ', TexCmd('cot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi')), BraceGroup('n')]))]), '\n'], []), '\ndenotes the polygon area. Now, using the relation between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', we have\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nf_p(x) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2 E_i'), BraceGroup('k ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' S x^2'), BracketGroup('\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_i-cx'), BraceGroup('kx')]))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2-', TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))])), '[', TexCmd('pi'), ' - n\n', TexCmd('cos'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup(' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_i Its aim is to eliminate\nthese diagrams for the next sections, as only the non-degenerated faces\nwill need to be taken into account.\nFor the same reason, we shall restrict the study to the configuration\nspaces of subprincipal diagrams, as the faces of other spaces are all degenerated\nthanks to Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('34')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nondeg')]), ' The only faces of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cb')], []), ' which can be non-degenerated\nare:\n\nThe anomalous faces in the connected case (type (a) faces with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), " connected, \nand type (a') faces ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' connected).\n\nThe faces of types (c) and (e).\n\nThe faces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' of type (d) which satisfy the following conditions: each \nedge in ',
