Then\nconsider the two subdiagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '_2'], []), ' whose sets of vertices are\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V-A'], []), ' respectively. \nThen there is a canonical diffeomorphism from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c')], []), ' to an open subset of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_1'), TexCmd('times'), ' C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_2')], []), ', which is \ndelimited by a finite union of subspaces. \n'], []), '\n', "\nThis gives a diffeomorphism between a type (a') face, \nand an open subset of the product of a type (a) face of "], []), 'C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_1'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' with\nthe space '], []), 'C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_2'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [". So it shows that the types (a) and (a') are fundamentally\nthe same.\n\nIt also has the following consequence:\n\n", TexNamedEnv('lemma', ['\nA type (a) face with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), " not connected, or a type (a') face\nwith ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' not connected, is degenerated.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('proof'), '\nWhen '], []), TexCmd('g'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is a disjoint union of two diagrams '], []), TexCmd('g'), '_1', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and '], []), TexCmd('g'), '_2', TexMathModeEnv('$', [',\nthe natural map from '], []), TexCmd('cb'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' to '], []), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_1'))]), TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_2'))]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' \nmaps a type (a) face of '], []), TexCmd('c'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' to a product of type (a) faces of \n'], []), TexCmd('overline'), ' C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_1'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and '], []), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_2'))]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' , which has codimension 2. Thus, as '], []), TexCmd('Psi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [" is \nfactorised through this, the image of its restriction to this face\nalso has codimension at least two.\n\nThis concludes for the type (a), and the generalisation to (a') is immediate. ", TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('btype')]), '\nThe type (b) faces, and the type (d) faces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' such that  \n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('not'), TexCmd('inc'), ' T'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\#', "E'_A>2"], []), ') or (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('inc'), ' T'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\#', "E'_A>4"], []), '), \nare degenerated.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThese are direct consequences of Subsection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dime')]), '. For the type (b),\nthe image of the univalent vertices is a vertex at least trivalent (because\nthe diagram is subprincipal) which must stay at the origin, so that\nthe codimension is at least 3. ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('facedil')]), '\nAny type (d) face such that the vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' of some\nedge in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["E'_A"], []), ' is either in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' or not bivalent in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ', \nis degenerated.\n'], []), '\n', '\nIndeed, in such a face, each preimage of a point by '], []), TexCmd('Psi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is at least \none-dimensional because in the '], []), 'C^A', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' part of this preimage, this \nvertex '], []), 'v', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' can move freely in one direction while the others remain fixed.\nThis direction is the tangent direction of '], []), 'L', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' at '], []), "f'(v)", TexMathModeEnv('$', [' if '], []), 'v', TexCmd('in'), ' U', TexMathModeEnv('$', [',\nor the one of its edge in '], []), 'E_A', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' if '], []), 'v', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is univalent in '], []), 'A', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\nThis move is not eliminated by dilations because '], []), '\\#', 'A>2', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\nThis ends the proof of Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nondeg')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Labelled diagrams and orientations')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Labelled diagrams')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('labd')]), '\n', '\nTo formulate the degree '], []), 'n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' part of '], []), 'Z^0', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' in terms of the degree of the map\n'], []), TexCmd('Psi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' from the glued configuration spaces to a product of spheres, we shall\nneed to fix this product of spheres. Thus, all our edges will be\nlabelled and oriented. We shall call that ``labellings"\nof diagrams.\nWe are going to reformulate the definition of the diagrams so that they\nwill be intrinsically labelled.\n\nLet us fix the degree '], []), 'n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' of the diagrams. Their number of edges \nvaries under STU but we must fix the number '], []), 'N', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' of their labels.\nSo, we shall only work with the diagrams '], []), TexCmd('g'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' which have a number of edges \n'], []), 'e_', TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('leq'), ' N', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', and thus a number of univalent vertices '], []), 'u_', TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('geq'), ' k=3n-N', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', \nand there may be some unused labels which will be called ``absent edges".\n\n', TexNamedEnv('nota', ['If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is a set of sets, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cup'), ' A'], []), ' denote the union of \nelements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('geq'), ' 1, k', TexCmd('leq'), '2n'], []), ' be fixed integers and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3n-k'], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E=', '\\{', 'e_1,', TexCmd('cdots'), ', e_N', '\\}'], []), ' be the set of labelled ``edges" \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_i=', '\\{', '2i-1,2i', '\\}'], []), '.\nThe set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dem'), '=', TexCmd('cup'), ' E=', '\\{', '1,', TexCmd('cdots'), ', 2N', '\\}'], []), ' is called the set of half-edges.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dl')], []), ' denote the set of 4-tuples \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '=(U,T,E^v,', TexCmd('s'), ')'], []), ',\ncalled ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' labelled diagrams'), ', \nwhich respect the following conditions:\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E^v', TexCmd('inc'), ' E'], []), ' is the set of ``visible edges", it labels the edges of \nthe diagram. We let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E^a=E-E^v'], []), ' denote the set of ``absent edges".\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' The set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V=U', TexCmd('cup'), ' T'], []), ' of all ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' is the set of univalent vertices: it is a set of singletons, \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('s')], []), ' is an isotopy class of injections of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' into the interior of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is the set of trivalent vertices, which are subsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dem')], []), ' with \nthree elements belonging to three different edges.\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\#', 'V=2n'], []), ' ', '(which is equivalent to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('g'), '=', '\\#', 'U=', '\\#', 'E^a+k'], []), ').\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' is subprincipal (see Definition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('3con')]), ').\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nThe identity is the only isomorphism of diagrams which preserves \nthe labelling, so we will take the same notion of an isomorphism as before,\nwhich refers to the underlying unlabelled diagrams:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [' An ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), "'")], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nA configuration for a labelled diagram induces a map from '], []), TexCmd('cup'), ' E^v', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' \nto '], []), ['.\n\nAs for the trivalent vertices, let us represent\n'], []), 'o', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' by a family of bijections '], []), '(b_t)_', BraceGroup('t', TexCmd('in'), ' T'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' of '], []), TexCmd('g'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\nIt is reversed when we change the orientation of one vertex or one edge;\nand the isomorphism induced by a permutation of '], []), 'E', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', which preserves the \norientations of edges and vertices, also preserves the orientation of '], []), TexCmd('cc'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. \nSo, this construction is equivalent to\nfirst orienting '], []), TexCmd('c'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' by the same method with edges '], []), 'e_i', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' \n', '('], []), 'i=1,', TexCmd('cdots'), ',', '\\#', 'E^v', TexCmd('sd'), ' ', ')^', BraceGroup('E^v'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\n\nNote that we have '], []), 'I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ',-o)=-I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ',o)', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and that '], []), 'I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ',o)', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is independent \nof the labelling of '], []), TexCmd('g'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [': exchanging two edges preserves both \norientations of '], []), TexCmd('cc'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and '], []), '(', TexCmd('sd'), ' ', ')^E', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', and reversing one edge changes both \norientations (precisely, it changes both the orientation of\n'], []), TexCmd('cc'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and the sign of the form '], []), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Psi'), "'"), '^*', TexCmd('O'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['), because the antipodal \nmap reverses the orientation of '], []), TexCmd('sd'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\n\nSo, the product '], []), 'I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')', '[', TexCmd('g'))]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is well-defined independently \nof '], []), 'o', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\n\nIn all the following, we fix an arbitrary choice of orientations \non the diagrams in '], []), TexCmd('dl'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [', \nwith no consequence on the final results.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Interpretation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' in degree theory')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('degthe')]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('C')), BraceGroup("C'")]), '\n', '\nLet '], []), TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' be a map from '], []), TexCmd('dl'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' to '], []), TexCmd('ank'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nsuch that: \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('somme')]), '\n', TexCmd('qs'), TexCmd('g'), ' ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('principal')]), ',', TexCmd('qua'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), "'", TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dl'), ',', TexCmd('g'), "'", TexCmd('sim'), TexCmd('g')), TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('g'), "')=", BraceGroup('[', TexCmd('g'), ']', TexCmd('over'), ' |', TexCmd('g'), '|'), '\n'], []), '\nThe standard example will be \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('coef')]), '\n', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), ')=', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('projection of '), BraceGroup('(N-e_', TexCmd('g'), ')!', TexCmd('over'), ' N!', '\\;', '2^', BraceGroup('e_', TexCmd('g'))), BracketGroup(TexCmd('g'))]), ' ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(' in ')]), ' ', TexCmd('ank'), '\n'], []), '\nbut we need not restrict to it now.\n\nLet '], []), TexCmd('C'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' be the following formal linear combination of spaces\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('space')]), '\n', TexCmd('C'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('dl')), TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), ') ', TexCmd('cc'), '.'], []), '\nHere, '], []), '-', TexCmd('cc'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' stands for '], []), TexCmd('cc'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' with the opposite orientation.\nLet '], []), TexCmd('xi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' be the almost everywhere defined map with rational values \nin '], []), TexCmd('ank'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [':\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('eqalign', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), ':(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^E&', TexCmd('lra'), TexCmd('ank'), TexCmd('cr'), ' x&', TexCmd('longmapsto'), ' \n', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(' count of ')]), TexCmd('Psi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(x)', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(' in ')]), TexCmd('C'), ' ')]), '\n'], []), '\nAccording to the degree theory, this map can be extended \ninto a locally constant map defined\noutside the union of the '], []), TexCmd('Psi'), '(', TexCmd('del'), TexCmd('cc'), ')', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' for '], []), TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dl'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. When a\nmap is defined on a manifold without boundary, the number of preimages\ncounted with signs is constant and called the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' degree'), " of the map.\nIn this article, we shall use a kind of generalised notion of ``manifold \nwithout boundary'', with a notion of gluing of faces that we shall define\nin the next section, such that\nonly the faces which are not glued are relevant in the notion of a boundary.\nNow, we have ", TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['Z_n^k=', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^E'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('O'), '.'], []), '\nSo, '], []), 'Z_n^k', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is generally not rational because the map '], []), TexCmd('xi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is not \nconstant on '], []), '(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^E', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\nThe aim of the following sections will be to prove Propositions ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('varia')]), ' and\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mult')]), ' in the following way: we shall introduce other configuration spaces to \ncomplete '], []), TexCmd('C'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' \nso that the corresponding '], []), TexCmd('xi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' becomes constant. \n\nThen, each of the expressions '], []), 'Z^0', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' of Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('varia')]), ' and \n'], []), 'Z_n^k', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' of \nProposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mult')]), ' will be equal to the degree of the map '], []), TexCmd('Psi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\ndefined on such a linear combination of configuration spaces which extends '], []), TexCmd('C'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('remark', [' We could generalise these constructions to other maps \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dl')], []), ' to any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Z')], []), '-module. \nThis possibility will be discussed in the Appendix. We shall see that\nin the case of a torsion-free module it gives no more invariants. The\nonly interest is that it can improve the rationality result by means of\nanother map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' which satisfies Formula \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('somme')]), ') and optimised gluing conditions, but not\n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), '). \nHowever, the improvement expressed in Remark ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('improve')]), ' is not based on this method. \n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup("Yang's point of view")]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('yang')]), '\n', '\nYang ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ya')]), ' introduced another interpretation of '], []), 'Z', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' in \nterms of degree theory,\nwhich is sometimes useful to avoid some computations of coefficients. \nLet us keep here Formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), ') for '], []), TexCmd('poids'), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. \n\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gg')), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' G'))]), TexCmd('def', [BraceGroup('\\'), BraceGroup('rp')]), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('sym'), ' RP')), '\nThe idea is to quotient the space '], []), '(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^E', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' by the group '], []), TexCmd('gg'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' of \npermutations and reversals of the edges, to obtain the space \n'], []), 'B_E=(', TexCmd('rp'), '^2)^E/', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_E', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' where '], []), TexCmd('Sigma'), '_E', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is the permutation group of \n'], []), 'E', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. The group '], []), TexCmd('gg'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' also naturally acts on '], []), TexCmd('C'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [', so that '], []), TexCmd('gg'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' \ncommutes with '], []), TexCmd('Psi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' in these actions.\nThus, the map '], []), TexCmd('xi'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is invariant under the action of '], []), TexCmd('gg'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '(for the same reason\nas the fact that '], []), 'I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')', '[', TexCmd('g'))])], []), ' did not depend on orientations) and induces\na map defined on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_E'], []), '.\n\nTo understand the quotient space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), '/', TexCmd('gg')], []), ', first note that the\ngroup of automorphisms of a diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' freely acts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c')], []), '.\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c'), '/|', TexCmd('g'), '|'], []), ' denote the quotient space of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c')], []), " by this action.\nIt is almost everywhere identical to\nthe space of all ``configured diagrams'' isomorphic to ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ', that is, \nunlabelled diagrams where the set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' of vertices is a subset of the \nspace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ' and the univalent vertices belong to the image of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '.\nThen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), '/', TexCmd('gg')], []), ' is topologically the union over all isomorphism \nclasses of degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('geq'), ' k'], []), ', of the product \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c'), '/|', TexCmd('g'), '| ', TexCmd('times'), ' B_', BraceGroup('E^a')], []), '.\n\nNow, the expression ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_n^k'], []), ' can be interpreted as an integral on these quotients,\nbut not of a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2N'], []), '-form because some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' can contribute even when\nthe quotient space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c'), '/|', TexCmd('g'), '|'], []), ' is not orientable (the simplest example is \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '=', TexCmd('th')], []), '). So we must replace the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '^*', TexCmd('O')], []), ' by the density\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Psi'), '^*', TexCmd('O'), TexCmd('cdot'), '('], []), 'local orientation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c'), '))'], []), '. \n\nLet us drop the condition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('geq'), ' k'], []), ' ', '(or equivalently, take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=2'], []), ');\nreplace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' by the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' constructed the same way as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), '/', TexCmd('gg')], []), '\nbut without the absent edges (it is the union of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c'), '/|', TexCmd('g'), '|'], []), ' for all \ndegree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' up to isomorphism). \nThus it is made of parts with different dimensions.\n\nSo, we can say that ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['Z_n=', TexCmd('int'), '_C (', TexCmd('Psi'), '^*', TexCmd('O'), TexCmd('cdot'), '(', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('orientation')]), ')', TexCmd('cdot', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('g'))]), ')_', BraceGroup('local'), '.'], []), '\nThe whole integral ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' itself is defined in the same way with diagrams\nof all degrees.\n\nNote that \nthe rational coefficient disappears in the above integral formula. \nThe advantage of this presentation is that it generally trivialises the problem\nof the handling of the rational coefficients of Formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), '). The bad point is that \nit gives no means to handle the sign of the density involved in\nthe space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Ordinary gluings')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('recol')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Definition of a gluing')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('glu')), BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomor', '\\-', 'phism ')]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('glus')), BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphisms ')]), '\nIn this subsection, we explain in all generality (for any map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), '\nand without restricting to the set of configuration spaces we already defined)\nthe notion of a gluing of a set of faces:\n\nEach face ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' of a configuration space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cc')], []), ' contributes to a \nvariation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' of the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), ' while going across ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(F)'], []), '.\nHere, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(F)'], []), ' is counted with possible multiplicities.\nWe are going to define ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' gluings'), ' for certain sets of faces, \nthat is, objects whose existence ensure that the contributions of these faces\nto the discontinuity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), ' at their images\ncancel. Note that the degenerated faces do not contribute to the discontinuity of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), ', thus no gluing is necessary for them.\n\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('M')), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' M'))]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [' A ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism'), ' between two manifolds ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M'), '_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M'), '_2'], []), ' \nwith maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' from each\nof them to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^N'], []), ', is\na diffeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph')], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M'), '_1'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M'), '_2'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), TexCmd('circ'), ' ', TexCmd('ph'), '=', TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' \non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M'), '_1'], []), '. A ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism is said to be ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' positive'), ' if it preserves their\norientations.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [' A ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' self-gluing'), ' of a face is a negative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-automorphism\nof this face.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe existence of a self-gluing of a face clearly implies that this face does\nnot contribute to the discontinuity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), '. But self-gluings are quite\nexceptional and we shall use them only to eliminate some pathological cases\nof the other gluings.\n\nIn this section, we define gluings in the following way \n(but for the anomalous faces in the next section, \nit will be necessary to cut some faces into pieces).\n\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [' A ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' gluing'), ' of a set of faces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' with coefficients \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' is a partition of this set such that in each class, all \nthe faces  are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphic and verify the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' gluing condition'), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('g'), ',A)', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(' in the class')])), ' ', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), ')=0'], []), '\nwhere the signs in front of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), "')"], []), ' for two given pairs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('g'), "',A')"], []), ' will be equal iff\neach ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), "',A')"], []), ' \npreserves their orientations inherited from the orientations\nof the spaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cc')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["C'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), "'")], []), '. \n'], []), '\n', '\nNote that if there are both a positive and a negative \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism between two faces, then each face in the class is \nglued to itself, so the condition may be deleted. Otherwise, the condition for\nthe signs in the above formula is consistent.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Gluing results for ordinary faces')]), '\n', '\nThe aim of this section is to prove the following proposition. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('glunano')]), '\nFor the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' defined by Formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), '),\nthere exists a gluing of the set of ordinary, non-degenerated\nfaces of the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["C'"], []), ' defined by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('space')]), ').\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('proof'), ' We shall prove the following three lemmas\nin Subsection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('proglu')]), '. They apply to the gluing of a combination ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["C'"], []), ' \nas above but that can come from any map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' defined on the set \nof diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dl')], []), ' with chosen orientations, and seen as extended to \nthe set of the same diagrams with all orientations, \naccording to the AS relation.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rihx')]), " The gluings of the type (c1) faces are ensured\nby the IHX' relations defined as follows: they are all possible relations\nof the following form between six subprincipal labelled diagrams that are \nidentical outside the drawn part:\n", TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('ih')]), '+', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('ib')]), '=', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('hd')]), '+', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('hg')]), '-', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('xd')]), '-', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('xg')])], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rstu')]), " The gluings of the type (c2) faces are ensured\nby the following STU' relation between labelled diagrams that are \nidentical outside the drawn part and such that all three unlabelled diagrams \nof the corresponding STU relation are subprincipal:\n", TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('u')]), '-', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('s')]), '\n=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('in'), ' E^a'), '( ', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('th')]), '+', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('tb')]), ')'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E^a'], []), ' is the set of absent edges of a diagram in the left-hand side \nof the relation (it can be empty).\n'], []), '\n', '\nIf this ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E^a'], []), ' is empty, this relation is verified in the case of Formula \n(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), ') because\nit is deduced from the STU relation and the fact that the missing\ndiagram was forced to cancel in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ank')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('autorel')]), ' There is a gluing of the type (d) faces \nif ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' is a constant on each isomorphism class of diagrams.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe relations stated in the first two lemmas above will be fully used in\nthe proofs to define the gluings, but the proof of the last\nlemma will not make full use of its assumption (that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' is \nconstant on each isomorphism class) but only of a consequence of it, whose\nexpression would be complicated to write and useless here. This possibility\nto weaken the condition can be used to improve the result on the \ndenominators of the integral (see Appendix\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('r2')]), ').\n\nThen, we finish the proof of Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('glunano')]), ' by the remark that\nthe map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' defined by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), ') satisfies the conditions of these\nlemmas.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Gluing methods and orientations')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('let'), TexCmd('eps'), '=', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sign')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Sgn')]))]), '\n', '\nNow we are going to consider a general case of ', TexCmd('glu'), ' between two faces\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), "',A')"], []), ' of a same type ((c) or (d)). The problem will be\nto determine its sign ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eps')], []), '. \n\nWe suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A=', TexCmd('g'), "'/A'"], []), ' ', '(as labelled diagrams), and that the ', TexCmd('glu'), '\npreserves the projection onto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '/A')], []), '. \nSo, the only transformations concern the graphs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A'"], []), ' and the \nspaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('co'), '(A)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('co'), "(A')"], []), ' ', '(Notation ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('notgra')]), '), and if \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('cap'), ' U'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A'", TexCmd('cap'), " U'"], []), ' are nonempty, \nthey are mapped to the same line ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' in the two identified configurations.\n\nMoreover, let us suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_A=E_', BraceGroup("A'")], []), ' ', "(it will be the case for the \ngluings we shall consider except one of the two kinds of gluings for the \nSTU' relation).\nThis implies that ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A'"], []), ' have the same respective\nnumbers of univalent and trivalent vertices.\n', TexCmd('ppar'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('L')), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' L'))]), '\nFor convenience, we are going to label all vertices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' independently\nof the labelling of the edges, starting with\nthe univalent vertices (this means the elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), '), if they exist.\nWe denote them by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_i'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('in'), ' X'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X=', '\\{', '0,', TexCmd('cdots'), ',', '\\#', 'A-1', '\\}'], []), '. \nThus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_0', TexCmd('in'), ' U'], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('cap'), ' U', TexCmd('not'), '=', '\\0'], []), '. By convention,\nwe put the vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_0'], []), ' at the origin of the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_A'], []), '. \nSo ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C^A'], []), ', which contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('co'), '(A)'], []), ', is identified\nwith the space of half lines in the vector space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('rt'), ')^', BraceGroup('X-', '\\{', '0', '\\}')], []), '. \nWe do the same for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), "'"], []), ' ', '(so the univalent vertices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A'"], []), '\nare labelled by the same elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '). \n\nThe neighbourhoods of the faces are locally identified (on open dense\nsubsets, in natural ways with a definite limit near the interior of the face) \nwith the fiber bundle\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ' with base ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '/A')], []), ' and fiber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ce')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ce')], []), ' is the space defined by:\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ce'), '=(', TexCmd('rt'), ')^', BraceGroup('X-', '\\{', '0', '\\}')], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('cap'), ' U=', '\\0'], []), '; and if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('cap'), ' U', TexCmd('not'), '=', '\\0'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ce')], []), ' is the subspace of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('rt'), ')^', BraceGroup('X-', '\\{', '0', '\\}')], []), ' consisting of the configurations \nwhich map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('cap'), ' U'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' is defined by the base point in \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '/A')], []), '.\n\nWe shall suppose that the bijection between the faces is defined \nover each element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '/A')], []), ' by a linear transformation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ce')], []), '.\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('cap'), ' U', TexCmd('not'), '=', '\\0'], []), ', consider the set of vertices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('cap'), ' U'], []), ' \nas a subset of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ': we shall suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' is the identity on the\ncorresponding copies of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l_s'], []), ', and that the orientations of these\nvertices are preserved from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), "'"], []), '.\n\nThen, the bijection between the faces smoothly extends to a bijection of\ntheir neighbourhoods. As the orientation of each face of a space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cb')], []), ' was \ndefined as coming from the orientation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cb')], []), ', the sign ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eps')], []), ' of the \n', TexCmd('glu'), ' between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), "',A')"], []), ' is given by the action on \nthe neighbourhoods of the faces.\n\nThese neighbourhoods are both identified to the same space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ', but \nthe orientation of \nthis space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ' depends on the diagram.\nTherefore, we have ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('eps'), '=', TexCmd('sign'), '(', TexCmd('det'), TexCmd('L'), ')', TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('eps'), "'"], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eps'), "'"], []), ' is\nthe sign of the change of orientation\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ' as orientations of the respective configurations spaces to which\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ' was identified.\n\nThis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eps'), "'"], []), ' can be computed by comparing these\norientations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ' coming from the respective diagrams as defined \nin Subsection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ori')]), '.\nThe local coordinates, first labelled by\nthe vertices, are then labelled by the half-edges. \nThe labelled graphs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A'"], []), ' respectively define two bijections ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["b'"], []), ' \nbetween\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\\{', 'i', TexCmd('in'), ' X', '\\,', '|', '\\,', 'x_i', TexCmd('in'), ' U', '\\}', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', '(i,1),(i,2),(i,3)', '\\,', '|', '\\,', 'i', TexCmd('in'), ' X,x_i', TexCmd('in'), ' T', '\\}'], []), '\nand the set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cup'), ' A', TexCmd('inc'), ' ', TexCmd('dem')], []), ' of half-edges which belong to a vertex in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '.\n\nThen, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eps'), "'"], []), ' is the signature of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('-1'), "b'"], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Proofs for the gluings')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('proglu'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rihx')]))]), '\n', "\nEach term of an IHX' relation corresponds to a type (c1) face\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(', TexCmd('g'), ',e)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' is the labelled diagram of the term, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), " is\nthe edge involved in the relation. \n\nIf some type (c1) face does not fit into such a relation, it is because \none other diagram of the IHX relation is not subprincipal, \nso its faces are degenerated. Since all \nfaces of this unwritten IHX' relation are ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), "-isomorphic, they are\nall degenerated. This is why no relation is necessary for them.\n\nSo we have a partition of at least all non-degenerated type (c1) faces, \nand what we have to check is that this partition is a\ngluing, where the gluing condition is the IHX' relation.\n\nIn the above constructions, we can always take ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L'), '='], []), ' Id, preserve the\ngraph structure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' but just use permutations of the set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["E'_A"], []), '. \nThis provides ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphisms of faces with sign the\nsignature of this permutation (it must be considered\nmodulo the transpositions of two edges attached to the same vertex\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ", because these transpositions induce the identity).\n\nThe verification of the signs in the IHX' relation is now easy. ", TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('autorel')])), '\n', '\nWe consider now the non-degenerated type (d) faces. \n\nAccording to Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nondeg')]), ', each edge in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["E'_A"], []), ' meets\ntwo edges (denoted as pairs of vertices) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1=', '\\{', 'x,y', '\\}'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2=', '\\{', 'x,z', '\\}'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_A'], []), '. Suppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' has\na non-zero label. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' be the map\nwhich maps (the position of) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y+z-x,'], []), ' and preserves the\nother vertices.\nThis transformation has determinant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), '.\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('self.eps')])], []), '\nThen apply the only change of structure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' which fits in with this \ntransformation: it is a mere relabelling, which exchanges ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ' \nand reverses them: if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' goes from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ', then it\ngoes from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A'"], []), '.\nSuppose that these diagrams have the same orientation through this relabelling.\nThis defines an even permutation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cup'), ' A'], []), ', so this ', TexCmd('glu'), ' is negative.\n\nNow, here is a way to give a partition of these faces into pairs, which\nis a gluing as soon as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' is constant on each isomorphism class of\ndiagrams with the same orientation.\n\nConsider an (equivalence) class of pairs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('g'), ',A)'], []), ' ', '(concerned here) \nwhich are isomorphic by isomorphisms whose restriction to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), '\nis the identity (thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), ' is fixed as a labelled diagram).\nThen fix an arbitrary edge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', TexCmd('in'), " E'_A"], []), '. \nBy this choice, the diagrams in this class are grouped in pairs\naccording to the above construction. ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rstu')])), '\n', '\nFirst let us check that for each pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('g'), ', A)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is an edge\nor a pair of consecutive univalent vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ', the face ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('g'), ', A)'], []), ' can be \nidentified with the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["C'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '/A')], []), ':\nindeed, let us distinguish two cases.\n\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_A=', '\\0'], []), ', it comes from the fact that the configuration of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' \non this face in the compactified configuration space, is \ndetermined by the one of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), ' and the tangent map of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '. \n\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_A', TexCmd('not'), '=', '\\0'], []), ', we have\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('not'), TexCmd('inc'), ' U'], []), '. This allows us to put\nthe unique element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_A'], []), " among the absent edges.\n\nTherefore, all faces of a STU' relation (faces of the form ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F(', TexCmd('g'), ', A)'], []), ' \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\#', 'A=2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), ' is identical to a fixed diagram with one \nbivalent vertex ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'A', '\\}'], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ') are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphic,\nthus, they are all degenerated when one is. This is true for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=2'], []), ' when\nall faces of the STU relation are represented, thus, as the codimension does\nnot depend on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' ', "(which determines the number of absent edges), all \nfaces of an STU' relation are degenerated when one \nface of the STU relation with unlabelled diagrams is.\n\nThis proves that aevery non-degenerated type (c2) face \nappears in an STU' relation. \n\nLet us now study the signs of these ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), "-isomorphisms and check\nthat the STU' relations are the gluing conditions.\nThe sign of the ", TexCmd('glu'), " between both left-hand side diagrams comes from the\nsame method as in the IHX' gluing (here the space ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ce')], []), ' has dimension 1, \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('det'), TexCmd('L'), '=1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eps'), "'=-1"], []), ' because of the transposition). \n\nOtherwise, let us study the sign of one ', TexCmd('glu'), ' between two faces corresponding to diagrams with a different number of univalent vertices.\nThis is the exceptional case of sign study, but we shall treat it in a similar\nway to the other cases.\n\nConsider the following diagrams, where each half-edge is marked with the\nname of a component in a local coordinate system of the neighbourhood\nof each face.\nHere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(x,y)'], []), ' stand for the spherical coordinates, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u'], []), ' stands\nfor the radial coordinate (outward normal vector to the sphere, thus \ninward normal vector to the face of the configuration space):\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('dt.eps')]), TexCmd('hskip'), ' 3cm', TexCmd('epsfbox', [BraceGroup('du.eps')])], []), '\nWe see that these two labellings only differ by the transposition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(x,s)'], []), ', \nthanks to the way the standard orientation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd')], []), ' was defined (Subsection\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ori')]), ').\nThis proves that these two diagrams appear in the relation with different\nsigns (or on different sides of the equality). ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Anomaly')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('secano')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The anomaly as a degree of a map')]), '\n', "\nRecall that the non-degenerated types (a) and (a') faces are defined by\na connected component ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A '], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ', whose configurations map all\nunivalent vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' to a line ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' directed \nby a tangent vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '. To study them, we \nneed to introduce a few definitions, where we replace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' \nby the non-compact line ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), '.\nThis does not change the fundamental notions of diagrams and configuration\nspaces (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dk'), '(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), ' is identical to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dk'), '(J)'], []), ' for instance).\n\n', TexNamedEnv('nota', [' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dw')], []), '\nbe the set of connected elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('dk'), '(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), '.\n\nFor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('sd'), ' '], []), ', let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' be the standard map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' us'], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), '\nto the oriented axis of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ' with direction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), '. By an abuse of notation,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' will also mean this oriented axis. \n\nFor any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dw'), '\n'], []), ', let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wx'), '(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' denote the quotient of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', TexCmd('gu'), '(', TexCmd('D'), ')'], []), ' by the \ntranslations and dilations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ' which preserve the axis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), '.\n\nThen, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' denote the union of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wx'), '(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' running\nover ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd'), ' '], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe are going to give these spaces an orientation. First, let us orient\nthe two-dimensional Lie algebra of the group of translations \nand dilations which preserve ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ', by giving it a basis: take \na first vector oriented to the positive translations of the oriented axis\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ', and a second vector oriented to the dilations of ratio greater than one.\n\nNow, since the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', TexCmd('gu'), '(', TexCmd('D'), ')'], []), ' is oriented by the method of \nSubsection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ori')]), ', \nthis orients the quotient space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wx'), '(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ', and therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), '\nusing the standard orientation of the base space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd')], []), '. \nThere is no ambiguity, since all\nconsidered spaces are even-dimensional.\n\nThen we define a map  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '_', TexCmd('gu')], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^', BraceGroup('E^v')], []), ', and a map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), "'_", TexCmd('gu')], []), ' from \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["W'(", TexCmd('gu'), ')=W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^', BraceGroup('E^a')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^', BraceGroup('E')], []), ', exactly as before.\n\nNow we are going to see that these spaces can be glued together according to\nthe same formulas, except that there are no anomalous faces anymore.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('w')]), ' For the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' defined by the same\nformula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), ') on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dw')], []), ', the linear combination of spaces\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['W_', BraceGroup('n,k'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dw'), '\n'), TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('gu'), ") W'(", TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' is completely glued, hence the union ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' of the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), "'_", TexCmd('gu')], []), ' admits a degree on it.\n'], []), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('w')])), '\n', "\nThe method is to use the same proofs as those of Sections 4 and 5 in \nthis new situation, where there are no equivalents of types (a), (a') and (e)\nfaces (for the scale is relative and the diagrams are connected): \nwe just have to check that the map ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' defined on the spaces\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' factorises in the same way\non the faces.\nIt is very easy to do for the faces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F (', TexCmd('gu'), ',A)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('inc'), ' T'], []), ':\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['F (', TexCmd('gu'), ',A)=W(', TexCmd('gu'), '/A)', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('co'), '(A).'], []), '\nThe other faces can also be seen as fibered spaces with bases\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), '/A)'], []), ' and fiber ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(A)'], []), ': over each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y', TexCmd('in'), ' W(', TexCmd('gu'), '/A)'], []), ' we have the fiber\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(A)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y', TexCmd('in'), ' W_s(', TexCmd('gu'), '/A)'], []), ".\n\nThe only new thing to prove is that if an STU' relation involves a \nnon-connected diagram, then the faces are degenerated. This can easily be done\nby projecting the fiber over ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd')], []), ' to the product of the corresponding \nfibers for the connected components: this product has one dimension less,\ncorresponding to the relative dilations between the\nconfigurations of the two subdiagrams.\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ew')], []), ' be the set of connected elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ed'), '(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), '. \nIn other words, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ew')], []), ' is the set of isomorphism classes of diagrams in \nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D^W_', BraceGroup('n,2')], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' runs over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('N')], []), ', \ntogether with a choice of arbitrary orientations.\nFor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('ew')], []), ' we define the \nintegral\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['f_', TexCmd('gu'), '=', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'), TexCmd('Psi'), '_', TexCmd('gu'), '^*', TexCmd('O'), '.'], []), '\nThen we define the anomaly to be \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('ano'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('ew')), BraceGroup('f_', TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('over'), '2|', TexCmd('gu'), '|'), '[', '_n(M)'], []), '.\nMoreover, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ano'), '_1=', BraceGroup('[', TexCmd('th'), ']', TexCmd('over'), ' 2')], []), '. \nWe are going to see that it is also the degree of a map defined on the quotient\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('n,k')], []), ' by a symmetry, with still the same \ncoefficients.\n \n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Symmetry properties of the anomaly')]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bg')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('gu'))]), '\n', '\nFor any labelled oriented diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu')], []), ' with support ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), ', let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bg')], []), '\nbe the diagram obtained by reversing the injection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i:U', TexCmd('lra'), TexCmd('R')], []), ' ', '(by the\ncomposition with the involution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' -u'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), '),\nand transporting the orientations of univalent vertices with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' by this\ninvolution:\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('ssym')])], []), '\nSo the order of the vertices is changed.\nThis defines a linear involution of each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), '\nand an automorphism of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), '.\n\nWe say that a element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), ' is ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), '-even'), ' if it is preserved \nby this involution. It is unknown whether all elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), ' are\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), '-even.\nNow, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('gu')], []), ' denote the labelled diagram obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu')], []), ' by reversing all\nits edges and preserving the vertex orientations. We obviously have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', '-', TexCmd('gu'), ']', '=', '[', TexCmd('gu'), ']'], []), ' \nbecause these diagrams are isomorphic.\n\nWe have the two properties:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sym1')]), ' ', '(i) For all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('sd')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' D^W_', BraceGroup('n,k')], []), ', there is a negative \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('-s'), '(', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), '. \n\n(ii)\nthe anomaly is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), '-even (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), ' ', TexCmd('ano'), '=', TexCmd('ano')], []), ').\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sym2')]), ' ', '(i) For all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('sd')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' D^W_', BraceGroup('n,k')], []), ', \nthere is a \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('-s'), '(-', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' with sign ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-1)^n'], []), '.\n\n(ii) The anomaly cancels at even degrees.'], []), BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), ' ', TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sym1')])), '\n', '\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism that we take from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('-s'), '(', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' is\nthe identity on configurations as maps from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), '. The sign comes\nfrom the fact that we quotient the configurations by the action of the\noriented group of dilations and translations along the axis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' which is\nreversed. Now, this map preserves the orientation between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' because the antipodal map on the base space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd')], []), ' also reverses\nits orientation. Thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', TexCmd('gu'), '=f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bar'), ' ', TexCmd('gu'))], []), '. ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), ' ', TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sym2')])), '\n', '\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism we take between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('-s'), '(-', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' is\nthe central symmetry on configurations. Note that this symmetry transports\nthe orientation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' and the orientations of univalent vertices.\nThus, the orientation changes come from the geometrical symmetry \nfor each trivalent vertex, and the reversal of each edge in the diagram.\nSo, the sign is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-1)^n'], []), ' because of the formula ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\#', 'E-', '\\#', 'T=', TexCmd('deg'), TexCmd('gu'), '=n'], []), '. Finally,\nthe antipodal map on the base space and the isomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('sim'), TexCmd('gu')], []), ' give \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', TexCmd('gu'), '=(-1)^', BraceGroup('n+1'), 'f_', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('gu')), '=(-1)^', BraceGroup('n+1'), 'f_', TexCmd('gu')], []), ': ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', TexCmd('gu')], []), ' cancels for even ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '. \n ', TexCmd('endproof'), TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('dwt')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' D_', BraceGroup('n,k'), '^W')]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ddwt')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' D_N^W')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('nota', [' For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' odd, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism between \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('-s'), '(-', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' defines an orientation-preserving involution of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('n,k')], []), '. \nWe let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wt'), '_', BraceGroup('n,k')], []), ' be the quotient space of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup('n,k')], []), ' \nby this involution, and let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dwt')], []), ' be the quotient of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dw')], []), ' by the involution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('mapsto'), '-', TexCmd('gu')], []), '.\nIt lets no diagram fixed because it changes the half-edge of the first\nunivalent vertex on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), '. Thus, ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('wt'), '_', BraceGroup('n,k'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dwt')), '\n', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('gu'), ") W'(", TexCmd('gu'), ').'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe can note that the image of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ano'), '_n'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n^k(', TexCmd('R'), ')'], []), ' is equal to the degree of the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' defined on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wt'), '_', BraceGroup('n,k')], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The labelled generalised diagrams and their configuration spaces')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gen')]), '\n', '\nNow we are going to define the additional configuration spaces to complete ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["C'"], []), ' in order\nto glue all the faces and define the degree of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' in the case of a link.\n\nFirst, identify ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X', TexCmd('times'), ' S^1'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' is a finite set. \nThen choose a family of smooth maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph'), '_m:', TexCmd('dd'), TexCmd('longrightarrow'), '\n', TexCmd('sd'), ' '], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ' is the disc and each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph'), '_m'], []), ' \ncoincides with the tangent map \nto the link ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' on the boundary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'm', '\\}', TexCmd('times'), ' S^1'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), '.\nHere we equip ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ' with the opposite orientation to \nthe usual one. So, the basis (tangent oriented by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), ', outward\nnormal) is direct.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('note', [' For all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dw')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'], []), ', let \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('wg'), '= ', TexCmd('ph'), '_m^*W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' be the fibered space over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ' which is the union of the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ph'), '_m(x)'), '(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('dd')], []), ', and equip it with the product \norientation.\n\nIn the same way as in Subsection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('labd')]), ', we let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E=', '\\{', 'e_1,', TexCmd('cdots'), ', e_N', '\\}'], []), " be the set of labelled ``edges''\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_i=', '\\{', '2i-1,2i', '\\}'], []), '. We recall the formula ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=3n-N'], []), '. \n\nNow fix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' vary for the sets of diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dw')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dwt')], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ddw')], []), ' denote the union '\nIn fact, these unions concern the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2n-1', TexCmd('leq'), ' N'], []), ', for \nconnected diagrams of higher degrees would have more edges.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gendiag')]), ' \nA ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' labelled generalised diagram'), ' with support ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], '\ntogether with:\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' a labelled diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '_0'], []), ' with support ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' such that its set of We let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_1=Y', TexCmd('cap'), TexCmd('ddw')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_2=Y', TexCmd('cap'), '\n', TexCmd('ddwt')], []), '.\n\nThe ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' degree'), ' of a labelled generalised diagram is the sum of the degrees of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '_0'], []), '\nand all the diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y'], []), '.\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D^g_', BraceGroup('n,3n-N')], []), ' denote the set of these generalised diagrams of degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '.\nAn arbitrary orientation is chosen on each of them.\n'], []), '\n', '\nNote that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dl'), TexCmd('inc'), TexCmd('dg')], []), '. Indeed, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dl')], []), ' is the set of generalised diagrams \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dg')], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y=', '\\0'], []), ', or equivalently ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E^W=', '\\0'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('defin', [' Let the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' configuration space'), ' of a generalised diagram be\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('c'), '=C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_0'), TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y_1'), TexCmd('wgg'), TexCmd('times'), ' \n', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y_2'), 'W(', TexCmd('gu'), ').'], []), '\nwith the product orientation. This is again completed with the help of the\nabsent edges:', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('cc'), '=', TexCmd('c'), TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^', BraceGroup('E^a'), '.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe product orientation is well-defined because all spaces are \neven-dimensional. It is reversed when we change the orientation\nof a single vertex. The canonical map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' extends to the configuration\nspaces of generalised diagrams in the obvious way.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Gluing the anomalous faces')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tot')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' be a fixed map from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Z')], []), '.\nWe extend ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' to generalised diagrams according to the same formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), ') where now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', TexCmd('g'), '=', '\\#', '(E^v', TexCmd('cup'), ' E^W)'], []), ' and the images ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('g'), ']', ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('A'), '(M) '], []), ' of \nthe generalised diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' are defined by\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('clgen'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('g'))]), '=', '[', TexCmd('g'), '_0', ']', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y_1'), '[', TexCmd('gu'), ']', '^', BraceGroup('(m(', TexCmd('gu'), '))'), TexCmd('times'), '\n', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y_2'), 'p_', BraceGroup('m(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'), '[', TexCmd('gu'), ']', '^', BraceGroup('(m(', TexCmd('gu'), '))'), '.'], []), '\nThen, the canonical map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' defined on the linear combination\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dg')), TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), ') ', TexCmd('cc')], []), '\nadmits a degree which belongs to the integral lattice generated by the \nelements ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' in the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ank')], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' runs over the\nprincipal diagrams in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dn')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('proof'), '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), ' ', TexCmd('bf'), ' Ordinary gluings'), '\n', '\nThe ordinary gluings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '_0'], []), ' and all the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y'], []), ' are an immediate\nconsequence of Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('recol')]), ' and Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('w')]), ".\nHere the STU' relation always involves the set ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E^a'], []), ' of absent edges of the\ngeneralised diagram, given in Definition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gendiag')]), '.\n', TexCmd('ppar'), '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), ' ', TexCmd('bf'), ' Anomaly gluings'), '\n', '\nNow we are going to glue together the following two types of faces.\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), " The types (a) and (a') faces for the subdiagram ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '_0'], []), ' of a generalised\ndiagram; \n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' The faces induced by the boundary of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ' on some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wgg')], []), '.\n\nThese faces are glued in pairs in an obvious way, where one face of the first\ntype is glued to a piece of a face of the second type delimited by the \npositions of the univalent vertices of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '_0'], []), ' on the corresponding component\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'm', '\\}', TexCmd('times'), ' S^1'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.\n\nNow we have to check that the two orientations are opposite in any case.\nThe orientation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ' has been defined by the basis (tangent oriented\nby ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), ", outward normal), whereas for the type\n(a) or (a') faces, we must consider the orientation of the Lie algebra\nby which we quotiented, when we defined the orientation of the spaces\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W_s(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ': we took the basis (translations in the sense of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ', growing\ndilations). But ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' represents the generic tangent vector to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '\nwith the positive orientation, whereas the growing dilations point inward\nto the configuration space.\n', TexCmd('ppar'), '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('noindent'), ' ', TexCmd('bf'), ' Generators'), ' \n', '\nBy definition, the degree of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' is equal to the\ncount of preimages of a generic point with coefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), '. So,\nit belongs to the integral lattice generated by the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' runs\nover the generalised diagrams such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(', TexCmd('c'), ')'], []), ' has nonempty interior. \nThese diagrams are principal, as this necessary condition remains true\ngeneralising Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('34')]), ' ', '(but the converse is false: a principle\ndiagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu')], []), ' can give an empty interior for a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ').\nThen, we may keep the only non-generalised diagrams in this list,\nthanks to Formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('clgen')]), ').\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Proofs of Propositions ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('varia')]), ' and ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mult')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('nota', [' For each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'], []), ', define \nthe integral ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['I_m=', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dd')), TexCmd('ph'), '_m^*', TexCmd('om'), '.'], [])], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [' The integrals on the spaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wg')], []), ' obey the identity\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('wg')), TexCmd('Psi'), '_', TexCmd('gu'), '^*', TexCmd('O'), '= I_m f_', TexCmd('gu'), '.'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThis comes from the invariance of the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' and of the volume form\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('O')], []), ' under rotations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd')], []), '.\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('calcul')]), '\nThe expression ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), ' ', TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' of Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tot')]), ' is \nthe projection in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ank')], []), ' of\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['Z ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'), TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '((p_m+2I_m) ', TexCmd('anom'), ').'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe proof of this proposition is just a matter of calculation. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('egn')], []), ' be\nthe set of isomorphism classes of generalised diagrams in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dg')], []), '. It is\nthe set of classes of degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' generalised diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' \nsuch that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('leq'), ' N'], []), '.\n\nWe have\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('eqalign', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('deg'), TexCmd('Psi'), '&=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dg')), BraceGroup('(N-e_', TexCmd('g'), ')!', TexCmd('over'), ' N!', '\\;', '2^', BraceGroup('e_', TexCmd('g'))), '\nI_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')', '[', TexCmd('g'), ']', TexCmd('cr'), '\n', '&=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('egn')), BraceGroup('I_L(', TexCmd('g'), '_0)', '[', TexCmd('g'), '_0', ']', TexCmd('over'), '|', TexCmd('g'), '|'), TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y_1'), ' I_', BraceGroup('m(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'), ' f_', TexCmd('gu', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('gu'))]), '^', BraceGroup('(m(', TexCmd('gu'), '))'), '\n', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), ' Y_2'), 'p_', BraceGroup('m(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'), 'f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu')), '[', TexCmd('gu'), ']', '^', BraceGroup('(m(', TexCmd('gu'), '))'), '.', TexCmd('cr'), '\n')])], []), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bb')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('varepsilon'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), ',m'), '^', TexCmd('g'))]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('etn')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('eta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), ',m'), '^', TexCmd('g'))]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('prodm')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('ew')))]), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'))]), '\nFor any generalised diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('ew')], []), ', let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bb')], []), '\ndenote the number of copies of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu')], []), ' colored by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' in the set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_1'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ', \nand let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('etn')], []), ' denote its number in the set ', '_0|', TexCmd('prodm'), '|', TexCmd('gu'), '|^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bb')), '\n', '(', TexCmd('bb'), ')!', '\\;', '(2|', TexCmd('gu'), '|)^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('etn')), '(', TexCmd('etn'), ')!'], []), '\nSo we have\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('deg'), TexCmd('Psi'), '=', '\\!', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('egn')), BraceGroup('I_L(', TexCmd('g'), '_0)', '[', TexCmd('g'), '_0', ']', TexCmd('over'), '|', TexCmd('g'), '_0|'), '\n', TexCmd('prodm', [BraceGroup('(I_m)^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bb')), TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('bb'), '!')]), '(', BraceGroup('f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu')), '[', TexCmd('gu'), ']', '^', BraceGroup('(m)'), '\n', TexCmd('over'), '|', TexCmd('gu'), '|'), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bb'), '+', TexCmd('etn')), '\\!', '\\!', '\n', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('etn'), '!'), '(', BraceGroup('p_', BraceGroup('m'), TexCmd('over'), '2'), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('etn')), '.\n'], []), '\nThis is the image in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n^k(M)'], []), ' of the degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' part of\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['(', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), '_0', X'), TexCmd('exp'), '(', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('ew')), BraceGroup('f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gu')), '[', TexCmd('gu'), ']', '^', BraceGroup('(m)'), '\n',
