TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'), TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '((p_m+2I_m) ', TexCmd('anom'), ').', TexCmd('eqno', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('qed'))])], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('phiint')]), ' For all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)+2I_m', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Z')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe can restrict ourselves to one fixed component ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', \nthus to the case of a knot.\nApply Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('calcul')]), ' to the case\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=N=1'], []), ': the degree 1 part of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z', TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '((p_m+2I_m) ', TexCmd('ano'), ')'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), ')', BraceGroup('[', TexCmd('th'), ']', TexCmd('over'), '2'), '+(p_m+2I_m) \n', BraceGroup('[', TexCmd('th'), ']', TexCmd('over'), '2')], []), '.\nIt is the degree of a map where the coefficient is \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('th'), ')=', BraceGroup('[', TexCmd('th'), ']', TexCmd('over'), '2')], []), '.\nThus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)+2I_m'], []), ' is an integer. ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('varia')]))]), '\n', '\nThe above constructions work for any map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Z')], []), '. Now, let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_m=-(I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)+2I_m)'], []), '. In an isotopy, we let the maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph'), '_m'], []), ' \nvary continuously, so the integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_m'], []), ' is constant for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), '.\n\nNow let ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['Z^0=Z ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'), TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '((p_m+2I_m) ', TexCmd('anom'), ').'], []), '\nIts part of each degree is the degree of a map, thus it is constant\nin each isotopy class.\nWe have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_m+2I_m=-I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)'], []), '. We conclude that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['Z=Z^0 ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('in'), ' X'), TexCmd('exp'), ' ', '( I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)', TexCmd('anom'), ').', TexCmd('eqno', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('qed'))])], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Proof of Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mult')]))]), ' \n', '\nWe know that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)+2I_m'], []), ' is an integer.\nIf we suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)'], []), ' is an integer, then we can let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_m=-2I_m'], []), '.\nThus, for any fixed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_n^k'], []), ' is equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), TexCmd('Psi')], []), '. The\nconclusion comes from Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tot')]), '.\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('remark', ['\nIt is well-known that for a knot (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_m=I'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('th'), '_m=', TexCmd('th')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph'), '_m=', TexCmd('ph')], []), '), \nthe Gauss integral ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), ')'], []), ' \nis some sort of measure of the framing of the knot, that is, the \nlinking number of the knot with a parallel curve. Now we have \nproved that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), ')+2I'], []), ' is equal to an integer. So one can wonder \nhow to construct geometrically the parallel curve with framing\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), ')+2I'], []), ' from the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph')], []), '. Here is the answer:\n\nConsider the fibre bundle over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ', with fiber over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('dd')], []), '\nthe normal plane to the vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph'), '(x)'], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ' is homotopically\ntrivial, there is a unique trivialisation of this bundle up to homotopy.\nThis gives a homotopy class of trivialisation of the bundle over the boundary\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ', which is the normal bundle to the knot. Thus, \nit gives our parallel curve up to isotopy.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Vanishing of the anomaly in degree 3')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('v3')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\n', '\nIn this section we are going to prove that the degree 3 part of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ano')], []), ' \nvanishes, although\nthe integrals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', TexCmd('gu')], []), ' that occur in its expression do not individually cancel.\n\nIt is easy to see that the degree 3 diagrams in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ew')], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')])], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a2')])], []), ', and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')])], []), '. They have no automorphisms other than the identity. We\nalso easily find, when considering their classes in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '(S^1)'], []), ', that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')]), ']', '=-', '[', TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')]), ']'], []), ' and that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a2')]), ']', '=0'], []), '. So, what we have to prove\nis that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')])), '=f_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')]))], []), '.\n\nPut the following labelling on the diagrams ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')])], []), ':\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('la1')]), TexCmd('qquad'), TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('la3')])], []), '\nNow we are going to describe the regions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')])), ')'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi'), '(C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')])), ')'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^E'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E=', '\\{', 'e_1,', TexCmd('cdots'), ',e_5', '\\}'], []), '. They are\nthe sets of configurations\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd')], []), ' which verify the two conditions: ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('sph')])], []), '\n', '(1)', TexCmd('qua'), ' The points ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), " form a ``square'',\nthat is, they obey the four conditions obtained by circular permutations of\nthis one: the points ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), ' are on the same side of the vector \nplane ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_1, e_2)'], []), ' which contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), '. \n\nIndeed, considering the vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' orienting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' as the north pole, we can\nfind it on the picture up to sign as the intersection of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_1,e_2)'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_3,e_4)'], []), '. We must have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ' on the same meridian \n(half-circle from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), '), and the same for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), '. This gives two of\nthe above four conditions.\nThe two other conditions are equivalent expressions of the fact that, while\nthe information on the sign of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' is given by the orientation of any of these\nmeridians, respectively from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ' and from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ', these\ntwo informations agree.\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', '(2)', TexCmd('qua'), ' The point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' is in the region ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_1'], []), ' in the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')])], []), ', and in\nthe region ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_3'], []), ' in the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')])], []), '.\n\nIndeed, before fixing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ', the values on the sphere of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_i'], []), ' for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('leq'), ' 4'], []), ' determine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' and the shape of each of the two halves\nof the diagram (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'e_1,e_2', '\\}'], []), ' on the one hand, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'e_3,e_4', '\\}'], []), ' on the other hand)\nup to independant translations and dilations preserving ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), '.\n\nThen, in the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_1'], []), ' ', '(image of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')])], []), '), the vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' must be equal to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2+e_3+', TexCmd('lambda'), ' s'], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '>0'], []), ' and where each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_i'], []), ' is determined only up to a\npositive scalar multiplication. Therefore it means that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' is in the region\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_1'], []), '.\n\nThe case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_3'], []), ' ', '(image of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')])], []), ') is defined by the fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ' is above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ' is above ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), '. Therefore, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' is of the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2+e_4-', TexCmd('lambda'), ' s'], []), '\non the one hand, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1+e_3+', TexCmd('lambda'), "' s"], []), ' on the other hand. This gives the\nregion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_3'], []), '.\n\n\nNote that there are two possible orientations for the square \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4)'], []), ', corresponding\nto the two sides of the vector plane ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_1,e_2)'], []), ' where the points ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), ' can be.\nThis splits the configuration spaces into two subsets.\nWe can restrict the study to one of them, since the other one is obtained from it\nby the central\nsymmetry: we know that this symmetry preserves the integral according to Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sym2')]), '.\nOn the interior of each of these subsets, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' is a diffeomorphism. \n\nTo show the equality of the integrals on these two areas, we shall first\nshow the equality of signs, then the equality of absolute values.\n\n\nTo prove the equality of signs, let us see the areas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_3'], []), ' as two regions\nof the biangle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4)'], []), ' with one side containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ',\nand the other side containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), '. Let us extend the map \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), " to a larger ``configuration space'' which contains ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')]))], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')]))], []), ' as open subsets, and in which one can go continuously from one\nto the other. \n\nThis larger configuration space is defined as follows. \nIt is the quotient by dilations and translations of the set \nof maps from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ' such that:\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), '  It is injective on each edge.\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' It is not contained in a plane.\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' All univalent vertices are on a straight line.\n\n', TexCmd('b'), TexCmd('qua'), ' On this line, the respective positions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z_i'], []), ' of the ends of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_i'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('leq'), ' i', TexCmd('leq'), ' 4'], []), ') verify ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(z_2-z_1)(z_4-z_3)>0'], []), '.\n\nIts image by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' is the region of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('sd'), ')^E'], []), ' defined by the conditions \nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_3'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_4'], []), ' form a square, and that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' is inside\nthe biangle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4)'], []), '.\nIt is an imbedding, thus its jacobian keeps its sign on each connected \ncomponent.\n\nSo, as each connected component meets both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')]))], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')]))], []), ', we have the same signs on them.\n\n\nFinally, to prove that the integrals on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a1')]))], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('a3')]))], []), ' have the same absolute value, we are going to show that the\nsystem of inequalities delimiting their image (positions of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_i'], []), '\nsuch that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' is in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_1'], []), ', resp. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_3'], []), ' relatively to the others) are similar.\nTheir similarity comes from this remark:\n\nDenoting for three vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_1,s_2,s_3'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ', \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 's_1,s_2,s_3', ']', '=', TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' sign')]), '(', TexCmd('det'), '(s_1,s_2,s_3))'], []), ', the condition that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4)'], []), ' is a square is expressed\nby', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['[', 'e_1,e_2,e_3', ']', '=', '[', 'e_1,e_2,e_4', ']', '=', '[', 'e_1,e_3,e_4', ']', '=', '[', 'e_2,e_3,e_4', ']', '.'], []), '\nTherefore it is equivalent to saying that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_2,e_3,-e_1,-e_4)'], []), ' is a square.\n\nNow, the system of inequalities for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_3'], []), ' is that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_1,e_2,e_3,e_4)'], []), ' is a square and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' is inside this square, in the\ntriangle limited by the diagonals and one fixed side ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_1,e_2)'], []), '.\n\nThe one for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_1'], []), ' is that \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_2,e_3,-e_1,-e_4)'], []), ' is a square and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_5'], []), ' is inside this \nsquare, in the triangle limited by the diagonals and the side ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_2,e_3)'], []), '.\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z^0'], []), ' is a universal Vassiliev invariant')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('secvassil')]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', TexCmd('newcommand', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('I')), BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' I'))]), '\n', '\nWe are going to see that the invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z^0'], []), ' is\na universal Vassiliev invariant. But there is a little problem:\nwe have to choose between three possible conventions. Either we study ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' as\na Vassiliev invariant of framed links with framings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)'], []), ' ', '(that can\nbe supposed to be integers), or we look at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z^0'], []), ' as an invariant of \nzero-framed links (but it is rather artificial as this framing must \nbe corrected at each \ndesingularisation), or we just consider the common image of all this under\nthe quotient of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '(M)'], []), ' by the ideal generated by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('th')], []), ', as an invariant of\nunframed links. We shall consider here the question in terms of the first \napproach.\n\nLet us recall the defining property of universal Vassiliev invariants. \nA map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('I')], []), ' from the set of isotopy classes of framed links \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L:M', TexCmd('hookrightarrow'), TexCmd('rt')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '(M)'], []), ' is a\nuniversal Vassiliev invariant if: for any\ninteger ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' and any\nsingular oriented link with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' double points, that is, an \nimmersion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ' which is an imbedding except for a set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), '\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' points\nwhich have two preimages, the alternate sum of desingularised links\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('zeta'), ':X', TexCmd('lra'), '\\{', '-1,1', '\\}'), '(', TexCmd('prod'), '_i', TexCmd('zeta'), '(i))\n', TexCmd('I'), '(L_', TexCmd('zeta'), ')'], []), '\nis zero in all degrees ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<n'], []), ', and is equal in degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' to the \nchord diagram defined by the positions of singular points in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.\nHere, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_', TexCmd('zeta')], []), ' is the link obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' by replacing \nthe singularities by the\ncrossings with signs defined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zeta')], []), '.\n\nLet us prove this property of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' where the framings are given by the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), '_m)'], []), ', considering that the movement of desingularisation is \ninfinitesimal.\n\nConsider ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' in terms of configured diagrams as described in Subsection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('yang')]), '.\nThe spaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' of the different desingularised links are in correspondence\nexcept at places where some part of graph connects the two strands\ntogether inside the neighbourhood of a desingularisation.\nThen, the alternate sum cancels all contributions of the parts of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '\nin which there is not the presence of such a part of graph near ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' every'), '\nsingular point.\n\nThe configured diagrams which do contain such a part of \ngraph near every\nsingular point must have degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('geq'), ' n'], []), ': indeed, they must have at least one univalent\nvertex on each strand of the singular points, so globally at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2n'], []), ' univalent vertices.\nThe only degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' diagram which has the above property is precisely the\nexpected chord diagram.\n\nNow, the alternate sum of integrals on these configured chord diagrams\nis easily computed: at every neighbourhood of a singular point, the direction\nof the chord runs through a hemisphere limited by the tangent plane at\nthe singularity for each desingularised diagram. The difference gives the\nsurface of the whole sphere which is equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' \naccording to our definitions.\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('appendix'), TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Appendix: Changing the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('setcounter', [BraceGroup('equation'), BraceGroup('0')]), '\n', '\nIn the Appendix, we study the possibility of choosing a map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' \ndifferent from Formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), '). It is of no usage in the rest of this\narticle.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Weakening the gluing conditions')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('light')]), '\n', '\nFinding other maps instead of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('coef')]), ') that still satisfies a gluing to\nobtain a result like in Proposition ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tot')]), ' is something difficult. We shall not see general solutions\nbut we shall mention some elements of the problem.\n\n\nThe first aspect of the problem is to make a complete list of configuration \nspaces whose image have codimension 0 or 1. \nIt seems unlikely that something more could be done than we did, except for\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), '.\nAs concerns the question of finding possible other configuration spaces\nto complete the list, Dylan Thurston ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('th')]), ' proposed to use spaces\nconstructed in the same way as our ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wg')], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dd')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph')], []), ' are\nreplaced by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', TexCmd('th')], []), ' and the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' defined on it. But such spaces do\nnot need to be introduced because they can always be replaced by a \nsuitable combination\nof the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('wg')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' as we did. I do not know if one\ncan introduce usefully other spaces.\n\n\nThe second aspect of the problem is to determine which faces are degenerated.\nOne can sometimes deduce that a face is degenerated from the fact that\nit is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphic\nto a face of another configuration space with a codimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('geq'), '2'], []), ' image.\n\nWe can generalise Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('facedil')]), '\nto the fact that a type (d) face is degenerated if \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('exists'), ' B', TexCmd('inc'), ' A', TexCmd('cap'), ' T, ', '\\#', "(E'_B", TexCmd('cap'), ' E_A)=1'], []), ', or if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is not connected.\n\nIt should be possible to find more degenerated type (a) faces, for example\nthe case when at least 3 trivalent vertices are related to 2 univalent \nvertices each. (The corresponding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W(', TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' has codimension 1 image).\n\n\nThe third aspect is to make a list of all possible ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphisms between \nnon-degenerated faces, to enlarge the equivalence relation between faces,\nand thus to reduce the number of gluing conditions, so that more maps \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' may satisfy them.\n\nWe now recall the gluing conditions and give possible ways of weakening them:\n\n(1)', TexCmd('qua'), " The STU' relation (Lemma 5.3): no suggestion.\n\n(2)", TexCmd('qua'), " The IHX' relation (Lemma 5.2), that we can replace by the following \nweaker IHX'' relation: a IHX'' relation is the sum of the \nIHX' relations obtained the following way: we fix the labelled diagram\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/e'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', TexCmd('inc'), ' T'], []), ' is the edge involved, and we let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), ' be replaced by each\nabsent edge.\n\n(3)', TexCmd('qua'), ' The real conditions to glue the type (d) faces are far less constraining \nthan to impose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' to be constant on isomorphism classes of diagrams. \nWith one bivalent vertex on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' the weaker condition is easy to write as\nthere is only one way to group in pairs the faces of labelled diagrams for\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphism we wrote. With more bivalent vertices it is more \ncomplicated as the same construction gives many possible ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphisms;\nmoreover, all permutations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["E'_A"], []), ' may be used. \nIn the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('inc'), ' T'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\#', "E'_A=3"], []), ', the position of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' in the diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), ' may be changed.\nBut these weaker conditions are not easy to make explicit. \n\n(4)', TexCmd('qua'), ' As for the anomaly, we could quotient the configuration spaces of\ngeneralised diagrams by all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), '-isomorphisms used in Lemmas \n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sym1')]), ' and ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sym2')]), '. Then, a sufficient condition\nfor the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' defined on ordinary\ndiagrams to be extendable to generalised diagrams in a way which satisfies\nthe resulting gluing conditions \nis that: for all diagrams obtained by inserting a connected \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu')], []), ' into a fixed diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' at different places of a fixed \ncomponent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', the expression ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ',', TexCmd('gu'), ')+(-1)^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('deg'), TexCmd('gu'), '+1'), '\n', TexCmd('poids'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ',-', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('gu'), ')'], []), ' does not depend on the place where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gu')], []), " is inserted.\nIt may not be necessary because some type (a) or (a') faces can be degenerated,\nbut we cannot easily weaken this as other gluings inside ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y_1'], []), ' must be preserved.\n\n\nWe could also wonder if some torsion Vassiliev invariant can be found by this\nmethod, when the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' takes values in a torsion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Z')], []), '-module.\nBut there may also be torsion invariants that cannot be found by this method.\n(This is suggested by the fact that the rationality results we can obtain in\ndegree 2 by this method are not the best ones: see Appendix ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('deg2')]), "). But\nwe won't be interested in this problem here.\n\n", TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Universality of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_n'], []), ' in the case of a free module')]), '\n', '\n', '\nNow we are going to see that if the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids')], []), ' takes values in a free ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Z')], []), '-module \nor in a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), '-vector space, then the corresponding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), TexCmd('xi')], []), ' if it exists, or the \ncorresponding integral, comes from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_n'], []), '.\nThus, the only interest in choosing such other maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' is\nto obtain better rationality results than those of Theorem \n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mult')]), '.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [' If a map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' from the set of principal elements of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dl')], []), ' to some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), '-vector space\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cal'), ' E'], []), " obeys the STU' relation, then the corresponding expression of\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), ' ', TexCmd('Psi')], []), '\nis of the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L'), '(Z_n(K))'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' is a linear map from\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n(M)'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ' which only depends on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('enk')], []), ' be the set of diagrams \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('edm'), ' '], []), ' which are principal and verify\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('geq'), ' k-1'], []), '.\n\nWe shall first define a map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('enk')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), '. Then,\nwe shall prove that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' extends to a linear map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' defined\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n(M)'], []), ', and that this ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' is the solution to our problem.\n\nLet us first define ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('enk')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ee')], []), ' by:\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('qs'), ' ', TexCmd('g'), ',', TexCmd('qua'), TexCmd('ps'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ')=|', TexCmd('g'), '|', TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), "'", TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('dl')))]), TexCmd('limits'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), "'", TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('g')), '\n', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), "')."], []), '\nThe existence of a linear extension of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n(M)'], []), ' will be deduced\nfrom the following facts:\n\n(1)', TexCmd('qua'), " Any STU' relation implies the corresponding STU relation for ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), '.\n\n(2)', TexCmd('qua'), ' This map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' is well-defined on chord diagrams and obeys the\nfour-terms relation.\n\n(3)', TexCmd('qua'), ' The STU relation obtained from (1) allows us to express any diagram \nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('enk')], []), ' as a linear combination of chord diagrams.\n\nIndeed, from (2) we deduce that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' defines a linear map from the space of\ndegree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' chord diagrams with support ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' modulo the four-terms \nrelation. But we know that\nthis space is identified with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n(M)'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('bn')]), ', \nso ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' defines a linear map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('A'), '_n(M)'], []), '.\nThis map coincides with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('enk')], []), ', thanks  to (1) and (3).\n\nNow, to prove the identity\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('enk')), TexCmd('poids'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('g'), ') I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('edm')), BraceGroup('I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')', TexCmd('over'), '|', TexCmd('g'), '|'), ' ', TexCmd('L'), '(', '[', TexCmd('g'), ']', ')'], []), '\nwe have to check that if a diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('edm'), ' '], []), ' is not represented in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('enk')], []), ',\nthen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')=0'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L'), '(', '[', TexCmd('g'), ']', ')=0'], []), '.\nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('g'), ')', TexCmd('not'), '=0'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' is principal, hence\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('g'), '<k-1'], []), '. Thus, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' can be expressed modulo STU \nas a linear combination of diagrams which have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k-1'], []), ' univalent \nvertices and are principal. But since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('L')], []), ' vanishes on them,\nit also vanishes on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), '.\n\n\nNow let us prove the claims (1), (2) and (3).\n', TexCmd('ppar'), '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), '  Proof of (1)'), TexCmd('qua'), " Consider a STU' relation; let ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' be any diagram\nin this relation, and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), " be the pair of vertices involved.\n\n\nNote that this STU' relation is defined by the labelled diagram ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), '.\nWe shall consider the sum of this relation\nover the set of relabellings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), ', in other words, the set of the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Upsilon'), ',', TexCmd('lambda'), ')'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Upsilon')], []), ' is a diagram isomorphic to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' is an isomorphism from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), '/A'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Upsilon')], []), '.\n\nThis sum of relations, when applied to one of the three parts of the relation\n(the one of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), '), \nis a sum over the set of relabellings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ', that is, the set of pairs\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('g'), "',", TexCmd('lambda'), ')'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' is an isomorphism from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g'), "'"], []), '.\nThis set is in one-to-one correspondence with the product of the \nset of automorphisms\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' with the set of diagrams which are isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), '.\nSo, this sum gives precisely the corresponding term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps'), '(', TexCmd('g'), ')'], []), ' of the STU relation.\n\nThis proves (1). ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Proofs of (2) and (3)'), TexCmd('qua'), '\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k', TexCmd('leq'), ' 2n'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ps')], []), ' is well-defined on the chord diagrams, and also\non the diagrams with only one trivalent vertex. Then the four-terms relation\nis a consequence of the STU relation deduced from (1).\n\nThe proof of (3) is easy by induction: we just have to note that when \nwe use a STU relation to express a diagram in terms of two diagrams \nwith one more \nunivalent vertex, then these two diagrams are principal \nprovided that the first one is. ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\nThis can be generalised to the case when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' takes values in any free\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Z')], []), '-module ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M')], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M')], []), ' is canonically imbedded in the real vector\nspace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('M'), TexCmd('otimes'), TexCmd('R')], []), '.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Rationality results in degree 2')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('r2')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('deg2')]), '\n', '\nIn this last part of the Appendix, we shall restrict ourselves to the case when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' is a knot ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '.\n\nTheorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('mult')]), ' gives the same rationality result in degree 2 as the one of \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('le')]), ', that is, a denominator of 48. But the actual denominator is 24,\naccording to the formula\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['Z_2=', BraceGroup('I_K(', TexCmd('th'), ')^2', TexCmd('over'), '8'), '[', TexCmd('th'), ']', '^2+(v_2-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '24'), ')', '[', TexCmd('vep', [BraceGroup('cr')]), ']', '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_2 ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Z')], []), ' is the degree 2 Vassiliev invariant which vanishes\non the unknot ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O'], []), ' and takes the value 1 on the trefoils. This formula\ncomes from the Vassiliev universal property of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), '\n', '(Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('secvassil')]), '), and the computation of \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['I_O', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('p2')]), '=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 8')], []), '\nfirst made in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('gua')]), ' ', '(not very difficult).\n\nThis actual denominator can be obtained in terms of degree theory \nas Polyak and Viro did ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('pv')]), '.\nLet us recall their remarks, and specify the general context for which\nthis improvement in degree two is a particular case.\n\nKeep ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3'], []), ', but\nconsider the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('2,3')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Z')], []), ' defined by:\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('t2')]), '=0, ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('cr')]), '=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '24')], []), '\nindependently of the labelling, and ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('p2')]), '= 0', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(' or ')]), '-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '24')], []), '\naccording to the following rule: the labellings of this diagram are\ndivided into two classes according to the parity of the number\nof edges oriented towards the trivalent vertex. Then give the value\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '24')], []), ' to a class and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' to the other.\nIt is easy to see that the gluing conditions are realised for this\nmap ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), '. Therefore, this induces a degree ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('deg'), ' ', TexCmd('Psi'), '=v_2-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '24'), '.'], []), '\nThe expression of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_2'], []), ' suggests that, to find better denominators, it \nwould be preferable to manage to cancel the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 24')], []), ' term.\nThis will be done by considering the expression ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z(K)', TexCmd('over'), ' Z(O)'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('prop', [' The expression ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['Z(K)', TexCmd('over'), ' Z(O)'], []), ' is equal to the\nexpression defined the same way as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ', with a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' long knot'), ':\ninstead of an imbedding of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), ' into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ', we put the knot in the form\nof an imbedding\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('R')], []), ' into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ' which coincides with \nthe inclusion of a given straight line of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rt')], []), ' outside some compact set.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe shall not prove this result here as it can be directly deduced from\nour next article ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('p2')]), ' on the extension of the configuration space\nintegral to tangles.\n\nWe are only going to show that the result of the integral on this new\nshape of knots is an invariant, while the cyclic order on the\nunivalent vertices of the labelled diagrams is replaced with a total order.\n\nThis is expressed in the following lemma:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', [' The same conditions as those of Subsection ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('light')]), ' but in\nthe case of a long knot, imply that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' admits a degree.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('proof'), '\nLet us first define the compactification of the configuration spaces\nwe use here. We imbed each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('c')], []), ' into the compact space \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('h'), TexCmd('times', [BracketGroup('-', TexCmd('infty'), ', ', '\\1')]), '^U.'], []), '\nThis compactification has the same general properties as in the case of\ncompact knots, except that it has new faces which correspond\nto the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["(f,f')", TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cb')], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["f'(U)"], []), ' meets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('infty')], []), '.\n\n\nThanks to Remark ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('discon')]), ', we can suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('g')], []), ' is connected.\nNow, the fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["f'(U)"], []), ' meets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('infty')], []), ' implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_V'], []), ' maps all \nunivalent vertices to the \nstraight line ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lo')], []), '. \nWe conclude that this face is degenerated by means of the argument of Subsection\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('dime')]), '.\n\nNow, let us glue the anomalous faces. Note that the tangent map\nd', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K: ', '[', '-', TexCmd('infty'), ', ', '\\1', ']', TexCmd('lra'), ' ', TexCmd('sd'), ' '], []), ' verifies\nd', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(-', TexCmd('infty'), ')='], []), ' d', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K(+', TexCmd('infty'), ')'], []), ', so defines a map from\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^1'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sd'), ' '], []), ', which is the boundary of some map\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ph'), ': ', TexCmd('dd'), TexCmd('lra'), ' ', TexCmd('sd'), ' '], []), '. It still has the property that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I_L(', TexCmd('th'), ')+2I'], []), ' is an\ninteger (Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('phiint')]), '). (The only difference is that this\ninteger is now even, whereas it was odd in the case of an ordinary knot.)\n ', TexCmd('endproof'), '\n', '\n', '\nWith this new problem, if we choose a map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' which only depends\non the diagram obtained by closing the total order of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U'], []), ' into a cyclic \norder, then this gives exactly the same rationality result as the one\nwe would obtain with this map from the diagrams with a cyclic\norder, for the compact knot. So, we can obtain a better rationality result \nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z(K)', TexCmd('over'), ' Z(O)'], []), ' than for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z(K)'], []), ', only by looking for maps \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' which do depend on the cut of the cyclic order.\n\n\nIn particular for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3'], []), ', take the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), '\nwhich only depends on the orientations of the edges, such that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('fl2')]), '=', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), ' 6'), ',', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('poids'), ' ', TexCmd('epfb', [BraceGroup('fl3')]), '=-', BraceGroup('1', TexCmd('over'), '6')], []), '\nand which vanishes on any other diagram. It naturally extends to generalised\ndiagrams and satisfies all gluings.\nThe corresponding expression ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('deg'), ' ', TexCmd('Psi')], []), ' is equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_2'], []), '.\n\n(Actually, no better result can be obtained with another \nmap ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('poids'), ' '], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N=3'], []), ').\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('newpage'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BracketGroup('AF'), BraceGroup('af')]), ' D. 4670 ***Failed to finish ggc.tex: [Line: 0, Offset 103877] Malformed argument. First and last elements must match a valid argument format. In this case, TexSoup could not find matching punctuation for: {.
Just finished parsing: ['{', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('}')]), BraceGroup(TexCmd('large'), TexCmd('sc')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('thesection'), '.'), BraceGroup('1em'), BraceGroup(), '   \n', '\n', TexCmd('date', [BraceGroup()]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('pagestyle', [BraceGroup('main')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', ['\nA geometric grid class consists of those permutations that can be drawn on a specified set of line segments of slope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), ' 1'], []), ' arranged in a rectangular pattern governed by a matrix.  Using a mixture of geometric and language theoretic methods, we prove that such classes are specified by finite sets of forbidden permutations, are partially well ordered, and have rational generating functions.  Furthermore, we show that these properties are inherited by the subclasses (under permutation involvement) of such classes, and establish the basic lattice theoretic properties of the collection of all such subclasses.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), '\n', '\nSubsequent to the resolution of the Stanley-Wilf Conjecture, in 2004 by Marcus and Tardos~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('marcus:excluded-permut:')]), ', two major research programs have emerged in the study of permutation classes:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nWith regard to the first program, we point to the work of Kaiser and Klazar~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('kaiser:on-growth-rates:')]), ', who characterised the possible growth rates up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ', and the work of Vatter~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('vatter:small-permutati:')]), ', which extends this characterisation up to the algebraic number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), TexCmd('approx'), ' 2.20557'], []), ', the point at which infinite antichains begin to emerge, and where the transition from countably many to uncountably many permutation classes occurs.  The second programme is illustrated by the work of Albert, Atkinson, and Vatter~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('albert:subclasses-of-t:')]), ', who showed that all subclasses of the separable permutations not containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Av'), '(231)'], []), ' or a symmetry of this class have rational generating functions.\n\nBoth research programs rely on structural descriptions of permutation classes, in particular, the notion of grid classes.  Here we study the enumerative and order-theoretic properties of a certain type of grid classes called geometric grid classes.\n\nWhile we present formal definitions in the next two sections, geometric grid classes may be defined briefly as follows.  Suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix.  The ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('standard figure')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', which we typically denote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ', is the point set in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), ' consisting of:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '(Note that in order to simplify this correspondence, we index matrices first by column, counting left to right, and then by row, counting bottom to top throughout.)  The ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('geometric grid class')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ', is then the set of all permutations that can be drawn on this figure in the following manner.  Choose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' points in the figure, no two on a common horizontal or vertical line.  Then label the points from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' from bottom to top and record these labels reading left to right.\n\nMuch of our perspective and inspiration comes from Steve Waton, who considered two particular geometric grid classes in his thesis~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('waton:on-permutation-:')]), '.  These are the permutations which can be drawn from a circle, later studied by Vatter and Waton~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('vatter:on-points-drawn:')]), ', and the permutations which can be drawn on an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textsf', [BraceGroup('X')])], []), ', later studied by Elizalde~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('elizalde:the-x-class-and:')]), '.  Examples of these two grid classes are shown in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-circle-and-X')]), TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('The drawing on the left of Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-circle-and-X')]), ' has been drawn as a diamond to fit with the general approach of this paper, but by stretching and shrinking the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '- and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), '-axes in the manner formalised in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-geometric-perspective')]), ", it is clear that any permutation that can be ``drawn on a diamond'' can also be ``drawn on a circle''.")]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('xunit=0.017in, yunit=0.017in')]), '\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('linewidth=0.005in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('pspicture', ['(0,0)(80,85)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(0,40)(40,0)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(0,40)(40,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(40,0)(80,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(40,80)(80,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(0,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(40,0)(40,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(80,0)(80,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(80,0)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,40)(80,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,80)(80,80)\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(10,30)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('45')]), '(10,30)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(20,60)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('135')]), '(20,60)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['5'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(30,10)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('45')]), '(30,10)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(50,70)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', '\n'], []), '\n', '&', TexCmd('rule', [BraceGroup('0in'), BraceGroup('0pt')]), '&\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('xunit=0.017in, yunit=0.017in')]), '\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('linewidth=0.005in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('pspicture', ['(0,0)(80,85)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(0,0)(40,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(0,80)(40,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(40,40)(80,0)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(40,40)(80,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(0,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(40,0)(40,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(80,0)(80,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(80,0)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,40)(80,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,80)(80,80)\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(10,10)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('135')]), '(10,10)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(20,60)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('45')]), '(20,60)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['5'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(30,30)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('135')]), '(30,30)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(50,50)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('135')]), '(50,50)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(60,20)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('45')]), '(60,20)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(70,70)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('135')]), '(70,70)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['6'], [])), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BracketGroup('Two geometric grid classes.'), BraceGroup('The permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['351624'], []), ' on the left and the permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['153426'], []), ' on the right lie, respectively, in the geometric grid classes of\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('1&-1-1&1')]), TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('-1&11&-1')]), '.\n'], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-circle-and-X')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nA permutation class is said to be ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('geometrically griddable')]), ' if it is contained in some geometric grid class.  With that final piece of terminology, we can state the main results of this paper.\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-pwo')]), '.')]), TexCmd('item', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-fin-basis')]), '.')]), TexCmd('item', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-reg-lang')]), '.')]), TexCmd('item', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-simple-reg-lang')]), '.')]), TexCmd('item', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-union-atomics')]), '.')])], []), '\n', '\nFor the remainder of the introduction we present the (standard) definitions of permutation classes.  In the next section we formalise the geometric notions of this paper.  Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-forests')]), ' contains a brief discussion of grid classes of forests, while Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-grid-pmm')]), ' introduces partial multiplication matrices.  Sections~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-words-and-encodings')]), '--', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-atomic-decompositions')]), ' introduce a correspondence between permutations in a geometric grid class and words, and utilise this correspondence to establish the main results of the paper.  Finally, in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-concluding-remarks')]), ', we conclude with numerous open problems.\n\nThe permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '1,2,', TexCmd('dots'), ',n', '\\}'], []), ' ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('contains')]), ' or ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('involves')]), ' the permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '1,2,', TexCmd('dots'), ',k', '\\}'], []), ' ', '(written ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('pi')], []), ') if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' has a subsequence of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' which is order isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.  For example, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '=391867452'], []), ' ', '(written in list, or one-line notation) contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '=51342'], []), ', as can be seen by considering the subsequence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '(2)', TexCmd('pi'), '(3)', TexCmd('pi'), '(5)', TexCmd('pi'), '(6)', TexCmd('pi'), '(9)=91672'], []), '.  A ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('permutation class')]), ' is a downset of permutations under this containment ordering; thus if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' is a permutation class, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('pi')], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), '.  \n\nFor any permutation class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' there is a unique (and possibly infinite) antichain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' such that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('C'), '=', TexCmd('Av'), '(B)=', '\\{', TexCmd('pi'), ': ', TexCmd('beta'), TexCmd('not'), TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' for all ')]), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' B', '\\}', '.\n'], []), '\nThis antichain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' is called the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('basis')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), '.  We denote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), '_n'], []), ' ', '(for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('N')])], []), ') the set of permutations in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ', and we refer to\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('n=0'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' |', TexCmd('C'), '_n|x^n=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')), ' x^', BraceGroup('|', TexCmd('pi'), '|'), '\n'], []), '\nas the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('generating function')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), '.\n\nFinally, a permutation class, or indeed any partially ordered set, is said to be ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('partially well ordered (pwo)')]), ' if it contains neither an infinite strictly descending chain nor an infinite antichain.  Of course, permutation classes cannot contain infinite strictly descending chains, so in this context being pwo is equivalent to having no infinite antichain.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The Geometric Perspective')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-geometric-perspective')]), '\n', '\nGeometric ideas play a significant role in this paper, and to start preparing the ground we reintroduce permutations and the involvement relation in a somewhat nonstandard manner.\n\nWe call a subset of the plane a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('figure')]), '.  We say that the figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), ' is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('involved')]), ' in the figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ', denoted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ', if there are subsets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A,B', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), ' and increasing injections ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('opinj'), '_x:A', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('opinj'), '_y:B', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')])], []), ' such that\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), TexCmd('subseteq'), ' A', TexCmd('times'), ' B\n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '\n', TexCmd('opinj'), '(', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), ')\n=\n', '\\{', '(', TexCmd('opinj'), '_x(a), ', TexCmd('opinj'), '_y(b)) ', TexCmd('st'), ' ', '(a,b)', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), '\\}', '\n', TexCmd('subseteq'), '\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('G')]), '.\n'], []), '\nThe involvement relation is a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('preorder')]), ' ', '(it is reflexive and transitive but not necessarily antisymmetric) on the collection of all figures.  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('G')]), TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []), ' then we say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ' are ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('(figure) equivalent')]), ' and write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), TexCmd('equivfig'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), '.  Note that in the case of figures with only finitely many points, two figures are equivalent if and only if one can be transformed to the other by stretching and shrinking the axes.  Three concrete examples are provided below.\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\nTo any permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ', we associate a figure which we call its ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('plot')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '(i, ', TexCmd('pi'), '(i))', '\\}'], []), '.  These figures have the important property that they are ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('independent')]), ', by which we mean that no two points lie on a common horizontal or vertical line.  It is clear that every finite independent figure is equivalent to the plot of a unique permutation, so we could ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('define')]), ' a permutation as an equivalence class of finite independent figures.  Under this identification, the partial order on equivalence classes of finite independent figures is the same as the containment, or involvement, order defined in the introduction.\n\nEvery figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), ' therefore naturally defines a permutation class,\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('Sub'), '(', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), ')\n=\n', '\\{', '\n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('permutations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []))]), '\n', TexCmd('st'), '\n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' is equivalent to a finite independent subset of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []))]), '\n', '\\}', '.\n'], []), '\nFor example:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nA geometric grid class (as defined in the introduction) is precisely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sub'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' denotes the standard figure of the defining matrix.  Permutation classes of the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sub'), '(', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), ')'], []), ' in the special case where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []), ' is the plot of a bijection between two subsets of the real numbers have received some study before; we refer the reader to Atkinson, Murphy, and Ru', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('s')]), 'kuc~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('atkinson:pattern-avoidan:')]), ' and Huczynska and Ru', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('s')]), 'kuc~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('huczynska:pattern-classes:')]), '.\n\nThe lines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'x=k', TexCmd('st'), ' k=0,', TexCmd('dots'), ',t', '\\}'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'y=', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('st'), TexCmd('ell'), '=0,', TexCmd('dots'), ',u', '\\}'], []), ' play a special role for standard figures, as they divide the figure into its cells.  We extend this notion of ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('griddings')]), ' to all figures.  First though, we need to make a technical observation: because the real number line is order isomorphic to any open interval, it follows that every figure is equivalent to a bounded figure, and thus we may restrict our attention to bounded figures.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R=', '[', 'a,b', ']', TexCmd('times', [BracketGroup('c,d')])], []), ' be a rectangle in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), '.  A ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('times'), ' u'], []), '-gridding of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' is a tuple\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nG=(g_0,g_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',g_t; h_0,h_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',h_u)\n'], []), '\nof real numbers satisfying\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\n', '&a = g_0 ', TexCmd('le'), ' g_1', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', TexCmd('le'), ' g_t=b,&\n&c = h_0 ', TexCmd('le'), ' h_1 ', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', TexCmd('le'), ' h_u = d.&\n'], []), '\nThese numbers are identified with the corresponding set of vertical and horizontal lines partitioning ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' into a rectangular collection of cells ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), ' as shown in Figure ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-example-gridding')]), '.  We often identify the gridding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and the collection of cells ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('xunit=0.017in, yunit=0.017in')]), '\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('linewidth=0.005in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('pspicture', ['(-5,-5)(120,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(30,0)(30,20)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(110,0)(110,20)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,20)(30,20)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,70)(30,70)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(30,20)(110,20)(110,70)(30,70)(30,20)\n', TexCmd('psline', BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(85,0)(85,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,50)(120,50)\n', TexCmd('psaxes', [BracketGroup('linewidth=0.01in,ticks=none,showorigin=false,labels=none,arrowscale=2'), BraceGroup('->')]), '(0,0)(0,0)(120,80)\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('c')]), '(40,35)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('11')], [])), '\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('c')]), '(67.5,35)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('21')], [])), '\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('c')]), '(97.5,35)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('31')], [])), '\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('c')]), '(40,60)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('12')], [])), '\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('c')]), '(67.5,60)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('22')], [])), '\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('c')]), '(97.5,60)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('32')], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('270')]), '(30,0)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('270')]), '(50,0)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_1'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('270')]), '(85,0)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_2'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('270')]), '(110,0)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('180')]), '(0,20)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('180')]), '(0,50)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h_1'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('180')]), '(0,70)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], [])), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('A ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'], []), ' gridding of the rectangle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'a,b', ']', TexCmd('times', [BracketGroup('c,d')])], []), ' with the cells ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), ' indicated.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-example-gridding')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nA ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('gridded figure')]), ' is a pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), ',G)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []), ' is a figure and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a gridding containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []), ' in its interior.  To ensure that each point of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []), ' lies in a unique cell, we also require that the grid lines are disjoint from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')])], []), '. By analogy with ungridded figures and permutations, we define the preorder ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('le')], []), ' and the equivalence relation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('equivfig')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('times'), ' u'], []), ' gridded figures.  The additional requirement is that the mapping ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '=(', TexCmd('phi'), '_x,', TexCmd('phi'), '_y)'], []), ' appearing in the original definition maps the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' cell of one gridded figure to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' cell of the other gridded figure.  A ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('gridded permutation')]), ' is the equivalence class of a finite independent gridded figure.\n\nThe connection between finite figures, gridded finite figures, permutations, and gridded permutations can be formalised as follows.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ', respectively, denote the set of all finite independent and finite gridded independent figures in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ', respectively, denote the set of all permutations and all gridded permutations.  The (obvious) mappings connecting these sets are:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nIt is a routine matter to verify that the diagram\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('psmatrix', [BracketGroup('colsep=1cm,rowsep=1cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('Phi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('Phi'), ' \n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '\n', TexCmd('endpsmatrix'), '\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('nodesep=3pt,arrows=->')]), '\n', TexCmd('ncline', [BraceGroup('1,1'), BraceGroup('1,2')]), '\n', TexCmd('taput', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), '\n', TexCmd('ncline', [BraceGroup('2,1'), BraceGroup('2,2')]), '\n', TexCmd('tbput', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'))]), '\n', TexCmd('ncline', [BraceGroup('1,1'), BraceGroup('2,1')]), '\n', TexCmd('tlput', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'))]), '\n', TexCmd('ncline', [BraceGroup('1,2'), BraceGroup('2,2')]), '\n', TexCmd('trput', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'))]), '\n'], []), '\ncommutes.\n\nThe griddings we are interested in restrict the content of cells in a way specified by a matrix.  Given a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', we say that the gridded figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), ',G) '], []), ' is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('compatible')]), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' if the following holds for all relevant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ':\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), TexCmd('cap'), ' C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' is ')]), ' ', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('increasing,')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('if ')]), ' M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), '=1,\n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('decreasing,')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('if ')]), ' M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), '=-1,\n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('empty')]), ', & ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup('if ')]), ' M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), '=0.\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '\n.\n'], []), '\nWe are concerned with the images, under the maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('Delta'), '=', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ', of the set of all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-compatible, finite, independent, gridded figures; we denote these two sets by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)'], []), ', respectively.  We refer to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)'], []), ' as the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('(monotone) grid class')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.\n\nIn this context, the standard figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' ', '(as defined in the introduction) of a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('times'), ' u'], []), ' has ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('standard grid lines')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'x=k', TexCmd('st'), ' k=0,', TexCmd('dots'), ',t', '\\}'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'y=', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('st'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), '=0,', TexCmd('dots'), ',u', '\\}'], []), '.  We refer to the pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ',G)'], []), ' as the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('standard gridded figure')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', and denote it by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), '; note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' is compatible (in the sense above) with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  The set of all gridded permutations contained in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' is denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ', and its image under ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ', as defined in the introduction.  Because the standard gridded figure of a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is compatible with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', we always have\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Grid'), '(M).\n'], []), '\nIn the next section we characterise the matrices for which equality is achieved.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Grid Classes of Forests')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-forests')]), '\n', '\nThe first appearance of grid classes in the literature, in the special case where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), " is a permutation matrix and under the name ``profile classes'', was in Atkinson~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('atkinson:restricted-perm:')]), '.  Atkinson observed that such grid classes have polynomial enumeration.  Huczynska and Vatter~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('huczynska:grid-classes-an:')]), ", who introduced the name ``grid classes'', generalised Atkinson's result to show that grid classes of signed permutation matrices have eventually polynomial enumeration.  This result allowed them to giver a more structural proof of Kaiser and Klazar's ``Fibonacci dichotomy''~", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('kaiser:on-growth-rates:')]), ', which states that for every permutation class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ', either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('C'), '_n|'], []), ' is greater than the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), 'th Fibonacci number for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ', or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|', TexCmd('C'), '_n|'], []), ' is eventually polynomial.\n\nAtkinson, Murphy, and Ru', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('s')]), 'kuc~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('atkinson:partially-well-:')]), ' and Albert, Atkinson, and Ru', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('s')]), 'kuc~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('albert:regular-closed-:')]), ' studied the special case of grid classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' vectors, under the name ``', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), "-classes''.  The former paper proves that such grid classes are pwo and finitely based, while the latter shows that they have rational generating functions.\n\nThe first appearance of grid classes of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrices in full generality was in Murphy and Vatter~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('murphy:profile-classes:')]), ' ', "(again under the name ``profile classes'').  They were interested in the pwo properties of such classes, and to state their result we need a definition.\n\n\n", TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular',
