'\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('A matrix together with its cell graph (centre) and row-column graph (right).')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-graph-grid')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t')]), '\n', '\nThe ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('cell graph')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is the graph on the vertices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ') : M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), TexCmd('neq'), ' 0', '\\}'], []), ' in which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)'], []), ' are adjacent if the corresponding cells of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' share a row or a column and there are no nonzero entries between them in this row or column.  We say that the matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('forest')]), ' if its cell graph is a forest.  Viewing the absolute value of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' as the adjacency matrix of a bipartite graph, we obtain a different graph, its ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('row-column graph')]), TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('In other words, the row-column graph of a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('times'), ' u'], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is the bipartite graph on the vertices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',x_t,y_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',y_u'], []), ' where there is an edge between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y_', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' if and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), TexCmd('neq'), ' 0'], []), '.')]), '.\nIt is not difficult to show that the cell graph of a matrix is a forest if and only if its row-column graph is also a forest.  An example of each of these graphs is shown in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-graph-grid')]), '.  These graphs completely determine the pwo properties of grid classes:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-forest-grids-pwo')]), '\nThe class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)'], []), ' is pwo if and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a forest.\n'], [BracketGroup('Murphy and Vatter~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('murphy:profile-classes:')]), ', later generalised by Brignall~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('brignall:grid-classes-an:')]))]), '\n', '\nIt has long been conjectured that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)'], []), ' has a rational generating function if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a forest', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)'], []), ' can have a nonrational generating function when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is not a forest.  An example of this is given in the conclusion.')]), ';\nfor example, by Huczynska and Vatter~', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Conjecture 2.8'), BraceGroup('huczynska:grid-classes-an:')]), '.  Indeed, this conjecture was the original impetus for the present work.  However, as the work progressed, it became apparent that the geometric paradigm provided a viewpoint which was at once more insightful and more general, and thus our perspective shifted.  The link with the original motivation is provided by the following result.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-forests-are-geoms')]), '\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a forest then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)=', TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ', and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)=', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nThe proof is by induction on the number of nonzero entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  For the case of a single nonzero cell, note that one can place any increasing (resp., decreasing) set of points on a line of slope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' ', '(resp., ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), ') by applying a horizontal transformation.\n\nNow suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' has two or more nonzero entries, denote its standard gridded figure by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_M^', TexCmd('gridded'), '=(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_M,G)'], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' denote a leaf in the cell graph of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  By considering the transpose of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' if necessary, we may assume that there are no other nonzero entries in column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' be an arbitrary gridded permutation in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), '.  We aim to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), '.\n\nDenote by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' the matrix obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' by setting the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' entry equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ', and denote its standard gridded figure by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_N^', TexCmd('gridded'), '=(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_N,G)'], []), '; note that the grid lines of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_N^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_M^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' are identical because the corresponding matrices are the same size.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' denote the gridded permutation obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' by removing all entries in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' cell.  Because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' lies in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(N)'], []), ', which by induction is equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(N)'], []), ', there is a finite independent point set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Lambda'), '_N', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Lambda'), '_M'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(S,G)', TexCmd('equivfig'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), '.  So long as we do not demand that the new points belong to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_M'], []), ', it is clear that we can extend ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' by adding points in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' cell to arrive at a point set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P', TexCmd('supseteq'), ' S'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(P,G)', TexCmd('equivfig'), TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), '.  Then we can apply a horizontal transformation to column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' to move these new points onto the diagonal line segment of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_M'], []), ' in this cell.  This horizontal transformation does not affect the points of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ', because none of those points lie in column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', so we see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Lambda'), '_M'], []), ', and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ', as desired.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('xunit=0.0226666666666in, yunit=0.0226666666666in')]), '\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('linewidth=0.005in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('pspicture', ['(0,0)(60,63.75)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(10.85,20)(55,20)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(20,49.15)(20,5)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(40,10.85)(40,55)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=dashed,linewidth=0.01in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(49.15,40)(5,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(0,60)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(30,0)(30,60)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(60,0)(60,60)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(60,0)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,30)(60,30)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,60)(60,60)\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(10,20)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(20,50)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(40,10)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(50,40)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('270')]), '(10,20)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('180')]), '(20,50)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('0')]), '(40,10)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('90')]), '(50,40)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], [])), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BracketGroup('The permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2413'], []), ' cannot be drawn on an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textsf', [BraceGroup('X')])], []), '.'), BraceGroup('The permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2413'], []), ' lies in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('-1&11&-1')])], []), ' but not ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('-1&11&-1')])], []), '.  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2413'], []), ' did lie in this geometric grid class, then beginning with the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' and moving in a clockwise direction, we see that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ' lies to the right of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' and thus closer to the centre, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' lies closer than the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ' to the centre, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' lies closer than the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3'], []), ' to the centre, and finally, to reach a contradiction, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' must lie even closer to the centre than the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-2413-not-in-X')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nBecause of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-forests-are-geoms')]), ', all of our results about geometric grid classes yield immediate corollaries to grid classes of forests, which we shall generally not mention.  For example, our upcoming Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-pwo')]), ' generalises one direction of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-forest-grids-pwo')]), '.\n\nThe fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)'], []), ' is not pwo when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is not a forest (the other direction of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-forest-grids-pwo')]), '), combined with Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-pwo')]), ' which shows that all geometric grid classes are pwo, implies that the converse to Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-forests-are-geoms')]), ' also holds: if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)=', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a forest.  This fact can also be established by arguments generalising those accompanying Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-2413-not-in-X')]), '.\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Partial Multiplication Matrices')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-grid-pmm')]), '\n', "\nIn this section we consider a particular ``refinement'' operation on matrices, which is central to our later arguments.  Let ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('times'), ' u'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), ' a positive integer.  The ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('refinement')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' q')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['qt', TexCmd('times'), ' qu'], []), ' obtained from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' by replacing each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' by a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q', TexCmd('times'), ' q'], []), ' identity matrix (which, by our conventions, has ones along its southwest-northeast diagonal), each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), ' by a negative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q', TexCmd('times'), ' q'], []), ' anti-identity matrix, and each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' by a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q', TexCmd('times'), ' q'], []), ' zero matrix.  It is easy to see that the standard figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' q')], []), ' is equivalent to the standard figure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' q'), ')=', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), ' ', '(although, of course, the corresponding gridded classes differ).  \n\nThe refinements ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' 2')], []), ' play a special role throughout this paper.  To explain this we first need a definition.  We say that a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('times'), ' u'], []), ' is a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('partial multiplication matrix')]), ' if there are ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('column and row signs')]), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nc_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',c_t,r_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',r_u', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', '1,-1', '\\}', '\n'], []), '\nsuch that every entry ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), ' is equal to either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' or the product ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_kr_', TexCmd('ell')], []), '.\n\n\nAs our next result shows, we are never far from a partial multiplication matrix.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', ['\nFor every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', its refinement ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' 2')], []), ' is a partial multiplication matrix.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nBy construction, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' 2')], []), ' is made up of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'], []), ' blocks equal to\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('0&00&0')]), ',\n', TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('0&11&0')]), ',\n', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), '\n', TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('-1&00&-1')]), '.\n'], []), '\nFrom this it follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), ')_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '0,(-1)^', BraceGroup('k+', TexCmd('ell')), '\\}'], []), '.  Therefore we may take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_k=(-1)^k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', TexCmd('ell'), '=(-1)^', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' as our column and row signs.\n'], []), '\n', '\nBecause ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)=', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), ')'], []), ', we may always assume that the matrices we work with are partial multiplication matrices.  We record this useful fact below.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-pmm')]), '\nEvery geometric grid class is the geometric grid class of a partial multiplication matrix.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Words and Encodings')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-words-and-encodings')]), '\n', '\nFrom the point of view of our goals in this paper, subword-closed languages over a finite alphabet display model behaviour: all such languages are defined by finite sets of forbidden subwords, are pwo under the subword order, and have rational generating functions.  The brunt of our subsequent effort is focused on transferring these favourable properties from words to permutations.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' be a finite alphabet, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' the set of all finite words (i.e., sequences) over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '. This set is partially ordered by means of the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('subword')]), ' or ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('subsequence')]), ' order: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('le'), ' w'], []), ' if one can obtain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' by deleting letters.\n\nSubsets of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' are called ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('languages')]), '.  We say that a language is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('subword-closed')]), ' if it is a downward closed set in the subword order (such languages are also called ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('piecewise testable')]), ' by some, for example, Simon~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('simon:piecewise-testa:')]), ').  To borrow terminology from permutation classes, we say that the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('basis')]), ' of a subword-closed language ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' is the set of minimal words which do not lie in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '.  It follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' consists of precisely those words which do not contain any element of its basis.  Moreover, a special case of a result of Higman~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('higman:ordering-by-div:')]), ' implies that subword-closed languages have finite bases:\n\n', TexCmd('newtheorem*', [BraceGroup('higmans-theorem'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), TexCmd('bf'), " Higman's Theorem")]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('higmans-theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('The set of words over any finite alphabet is pwo under the subword order.')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe following characterisation of subword-closed languages is folkloric, and follows directly from the fact that, for any finite set of forbidden subwords, there exists a finite state automaton accepting words not containing these subwords, which is acyclic except for loops at individual states.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prop-subword-closed-decomp')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' be a finite alphabet.  Every non-empty subword-closed language over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' can be expressed as a finite union of languages of the form\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_1^', TexCmd('ast'), ' ', '\\{', TexCmd('emptyword'), ', a_2', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_3^', TexCmd('ast'), '\\{', TexCmd('emptyword'), ', a_4', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('2q'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), ' ', '\\{', TexCmd('emptyword'), ', a_', BraceGroup('2q'), '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('2q+1'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_2,', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ,a_', BraceGroup('2q'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('2q+1'), TexCmd('subseteq'), ' ', TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThis fact shows that subword-closed languages are ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('regular languages')]), '.  To recall their definition briefly, given a finite alphabet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ', the empty language ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('emptyset')], []), ', the empty word language ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('emptyword'), '\\}'], []), ', and the singleton languages ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'a', '\\}'], []), ' for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' are regular; moreover, given two regular languages ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ', their union ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K', TexCmd('cup'), ' L'], []), ', their concatenation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['KL=', '\\{', 'vw', TexCmd('st'), ' v', TexCmd('in'), ' K', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), 'w', TexCmd('in'), ' L', '\\}'], []), ', and the star ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L^', TexCmd('ast'), '=', '\\{', 'v^', BraceGroup('(1)'), TexCmd('cdots'), ' v^', BraceGroup('(m)'), TexCmd('st'), ' m', TexCmd('ge'), ' 0', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(' and ')]), 'v^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ',', TexCmd('dots'), ',v^', BraceGroup('(m)'), TexCmd('in'), ' L', '\\}'], []), ' are also regular.  Alternatively, one may define regular languages as those accepted by a deterministic finite state automaton.  From this second viewpoint, it is easy to see that given two regular languages ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ', their complement ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K', TexCmd('setminus'), ' L'], []), ' is also regular, a property we use many times.  We say that the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('generating function')]), ' of the language ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), ' x^', BraceGroup('|w|')], []), ' where the sum is taken over all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w', TexCmd('in'), ' L'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|w|'], []), ' denotes the number of letters in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ', i.e., its ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('length')]), '.  We use only the most basic properties of regular languages, for which we refer the reader to Flajolet and Sedgewick~', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Section I.4 and Appendix A.7'), BraceGroup('flajolet:analytic-combin:')]), '.  In particular, the following fact is of central importance throughout the paper.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-reg-lang-rat-gf')]), '\nEvery regular language has a rational generating function.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe now describe the correspondence between permutations in a geometric grid class, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ', and words over an appropriate finite alphabet.  This encoding, essentially introduced by Vatter and Waton~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('vatter:on-partial-well:')]), ', is central to all of our proofs.\n\nBy Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-pmm')]), ', we may assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('times'), ' u'], []), ' partial multiplication matrix with column and row signs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',c_t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',r_u'], []), '.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' denote the standard gridded figure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', and define the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('cell alphabet')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' to be\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('Sigma'), '=', '\\{', TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('k'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'))]), ' ', TexCmd('st'), ' M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), TexCmd('neq'), ' 0', '\\}', '.\n'], []), '\nIntuitively, the letter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('k'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'))])], []), ' represents an instruction to place a point in an appropriate position on the line in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' cell of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), '.  This appropriate position is determined as follows, and the whole process is depicted in Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-vatter-waton-map-example')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('xunit=0.017in, yunit=0.017in')]), '\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('linewidth=0.005in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('pspicture', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_4'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(15,15)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('-45')]), '(15,15)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(75,75)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('275')]), '(75,75)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_7'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('<-c')]), '(-3,1)(-3,39)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(-3,41)(-3,79)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('<-c')]), '(1,-3)(39,-3)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(41,-3)(79,-3)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(81,-3)(119,-3)\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BracketGroup('An example of the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), '.'), BraceGroup('An example of the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' for the matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rrr'), BraceGroup('0&1&11&-1&-1')])], []), ' with row signs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_1=-1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_2=1'], []), ' and column signs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_1=-1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_2=c_3=1'], []), '.  Here we see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(', TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('2')]), ')=1527436'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-vatter-waton-map-example')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe say that the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('base line')]), ' of a column of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' is the grid line to the left (resp., right) of that column if the corresponding column sign is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' ', '(resp., ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), ').  Similarly, the base line of a row of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' is the grid line below (resp., above) that row if the corresponding row sign is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' ', '(resp., ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), ').  We designate the intersection of the two base lines of a cell as its ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('base point')]), '.  Note that the base point is an endpoint of the line segment of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), " lying in this cell.  As this definition indicates, we interpret the column and row signs as specifying the direction in which the columns and rows are ``read''.  Owing to this interpretation, we represent the column and row signs in our figures by arrows, as shown in Figure~", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-vatter-waton-map-example')]), '.\n\nTo every word ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=w_1', TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_n', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' we associate a permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), ' as follows.  First we choose arbitrary distances\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n0<d_1<', TexCmd('cdots'), '<d_n<1.\n'], []), '\nNext, for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ', we let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' be the point on the line segment in cell ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_i=a_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), ', at infinity-norm distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_i'], []), ' from the base point of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), '.  It follows from our choice of distances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',d_n'], []), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',p_n'], []), ' are independent, and we define ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), ' to be the permutation which is equivalent to the set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'p_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',p_n', '\\}'], []), ' of points.\n\nIt is a routine exercise to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), ' does not depend on the particular choice of distances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',d_n'], []), ', showing that the mapping ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), TexCmd('st'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' is well-defined.  Of course there is a gridded counterpart ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), TexCmd('st'), ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ', whereby we retain the grid lines coming from the figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), '.\n\nThe basic properties of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' are described by the following result.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prop-properties-of-bij')]), '\nThe mappings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' are length-preserving, finite-to-one, onto, and order-preserving.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nThat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' is length-preserving is obvious as it maps letters in a word to entries in a permutation, and that it is finite-to-one follows immediately from this.\n\nIn order to prove that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' is onto, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' and choose a finite set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P=', '\\{', 'p_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',p_n', '\\}', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' of points which represent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' ', '(where as usual ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' denotes the standard figure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ').  Suppose that the point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' belongs to the cell ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k_i,', TexCmd('ell'), '_i)'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ', and let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_i'], []), ' denote the infinity-norm distance from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' to the base point of this cell.  The points in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' are independent, because they are equivalent to a permutation.  Therefore, we may move the points of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' independently by small amounts without affecting its (figure) equivalence class, and thus may assume that the distances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_i'], []), ' are distinct.  By reordering the points if necessary, we may also assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_1<', TexCmd('cdots'), '<d_n'], []), '.  It is then clear that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(', TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('k_1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'), '_1')]), TexCmd('cdots'), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('k_n'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'), '_n')]), ')=', TexCmd('pi')], []), ', so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' is indeed onto.\n\nIt remains to show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' is order-preserving.  Suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=v_1', TexCmd('cdots'), ' v_k,w=w_1', TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_n', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' satisfy ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('le'), ' w'], []), '.  Thus there are indices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i_1<', TexCmd('cdots'), '<i_k', TexCmd('le'), ' n'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=w_', BraceGroup('i_1'), TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_', BraceGroup('i_k')], []), '.  Note that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), ' is represented by the point set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'p_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',p_n', '\\}'], []), ' via the sequence of distances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_1<', TexCmd('cdots'), '<d_n'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(v)'], []), ' is represented by the point set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'p_', BraceGroup('i_1'), ',', TexCmd('dots'), ',p_', BraceGroup('i_k'), '\\}'], []), ' via the sequence of distances ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', BraceGroup('i_1'), '<', TexCmd('cdots'), '<d_', BraceGroup('i_k')], []), ', so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(v)', TexCmd('le'), TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), '.\n\nThe proofs for the gridded version ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' are analogous.\n'], []), '\n', '\nUsing this correspondence between words and permutations, one may give an alternative proof of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-forests-are-geoms')]), ', showing that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)=', TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ', and thus that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)=', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a forest.  As Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-properties-of-bij')]), ' shows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' maps onto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ', one only need to show that it also maps onto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a forest.  This is proved directly in Vatter and Waton~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('vatter:on-partial-well:')]), '.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Partial Well Order and Finite Bases')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-geom-fin-basis')]), '\n', '\nWe now use the encoding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), ':', TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('astarrow'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' from the previous section to establish structural properties of geometrically griddable classes, i.e., subclasses of geometric grid classes.  We begin with partial well order.  By Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-forests-are-geoms')]), ", this generalises one direction of Murphy and Vatter's Theorem~", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-forest-grids-pwo')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-pwo')]), '\nEvery geometrically griddable class is partially well ordered.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' be a geometrically griddable class.  By Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-pmm')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' for some partial multiplication matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  As partial well order is inherited by subclasses, it suffices to prove that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' is pwo.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), TexCmd('st'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('astarrow'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' is the cell alphabet of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', be the encoding introduced in Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-words-and-encodings')]), '.  Take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' to be an antichain.  For every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('in'), ' A'], []), ' there is some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(w_', TexCmd('alpha'), ')=', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' is onto (Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-properties-of-bij')]), ').  The set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'w_', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('st'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('in'), ' A', '\\}'], []), ' must be an antichain in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' is order-preserving (Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-properties-of-bij')]), " again).  Higman's Theorem therefore shows that this set, and thus also ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ', is finite, as desired.\n'], []), '\n', '\nOur next goal is the following result.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-fin-basis')]), '\nEvery geometrically griddable class is finitely based.\n'], []), '\n', '\nWe first make an elementary observation.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-griddable-unions')]), '\nThe union of a finite number of geometrically griddable classes is geometrically griddable.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D')], []), ' be geometrically griddable classes.  Thus there are matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D'), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(N)'], []), '.  It follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('D'), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(P)'], []), ' for any matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' which contains copies of both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '.  The result for arbitrary finite unions follows by iteration.\n'], []), '\n', '\nGiven any permutation class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ', we let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), '^', BraceGroup('+1')], []), ' denote the class of ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('one-point extensions')]), ' of elements of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ', that is, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), '^', BraceGroup('+1')], []), ' is the set of all permutations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' which contain an entry whose removal yields a permutation in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), '.  Every basis element of a class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' is necessarily a one-point extension of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ', because the removal of ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('any')]), ' entry of a basis element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' yields a permutation in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), '.  Since bases of permutation classes are necessarily antichains, Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-fin-basis')]), ' will follow from the following result and Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-pwo')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-one-point-extension')]), '\nIf the class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' is geometrically griddable, then the class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), '^', BraceGroup('+1')], []), ' is also geometrically griddable.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nIt suffices to prove the result for geometric grid classes themselves, and by Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-pmm')]), ', we may further restrict our attention to the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a partial multiplication matrix.  Take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)^', BraceGroup('+1')], []), ' to be a one-point extension of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), '.  Letting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '=(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ',G)'], []), ' denote the standard gridded figure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', there is a finite independent set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P', TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(P,G)'], []), ' is equivalent to some gridding of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '.  Now we may add a point, say ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ', to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' to obtain an independent point set which is equivalent to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), '.  By moving ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' without affecting the equivalence class of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'], []), ', we may further assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' lies in the interior of a cell.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' denote, respectively, the horizontal and vertical lines passing through ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ', as shown on the left of Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-gridding-refinements')]), '.  Our goal is to create a new, refined gridding of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' which contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' as grid lines.\n\nThe ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('offset')]), ' of a horizontal (resp., vertical) line is the distance between that line and the base line of the row (resp., column) of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' that it slices through (recall from Section~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sec-words-and-encodings')]), ' that the standard gridded figure of a partial multiplication matrix has designated base lines determined by its column and row signs).  From the definition of a partial multiplication matrix, it follows that if a vertical line of offset ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' slices a nonempty cell of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ', it intersects the line segment in this cell precisely where the horizontal line of offset ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' slices the line segment.\n\nBecause the cells of a standard gridded figure have unit width, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' have offsets strictly between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ', say ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<d_1', TexCmd('le'), ' d_2<1'], []), '.  By possibly moving ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' slightly without affecting the equivalence class of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'], []), ' ', '(which we may do because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'], []), ' is independent), we may assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<d_1<d_2<1'], []), '.  We now define our refined gridding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ', an example of which is shown on the right of Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-gridding-refinements')]), '.  We take ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' to consist of the grid lines of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' together with the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2t'], []), ' vertical lines which pass through each column of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' at the offsets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_2'], []), ', and the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2u'], []), ' horizontal lines which pass through each row of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' at the same two offsets.  It follows from our observations above that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ',H)'], []), ' is equivalent to the standard gridded figure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' 3')], []), ', and in particular consists of a grid containing line segments of slope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), ' 1'], []), ', each of which runs from corner to corner in its cell.  By possibly moving the points slightly, we may assume that no point of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' lies on a grid line in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' ', '(although ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' lies on two such lines).\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('xunit=0.017in, BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(40,0)(40,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(80,0)(80,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(120,0)(120,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(120,0)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,40)(120,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,80)(120,80)\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(45,55)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('-45')]), '(44,55)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('<-c')]), '(-3,1)(-3,39)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(-3,41)(-3,79)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(1,-3)(39,-3)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('<-c')]), '(41,-3)(79,-3)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(81,-3)(119,-3)\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('c')]), '(45,85)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('rput', [BracketGroup('l')]), '(122,55)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], [])), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('On the left is the standard gridded figure of a partial multiplication matrix, together with two additional (dashed) lines intersecting at the point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '.  On the right is the refinement defined in the proof of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-one-point-extension')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-gridding-refinements')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nBy cutting the figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' at the lines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' and moving the four resulting pieces, we can create a new column and row, whose cell of intersection contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '.  (One can also view this as expanding the lines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' into a column and a row, respectively.)  We can then fill this cell of intersection with a line segment of slope ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), ' 1'], []), ' ', '(the choice is immaterial), running from corner to corner; clearly, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' can be shifted onto this line segment without affecting the equivalence class of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P', TexCmd('cup'), '\\{', 'x', '\\}'], []), '.  The resulting gridded figure consists of line segments that run from corner to corner in their cells, and is equivalent to the standard gridded figure of some partial multiplication matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' which is of size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(3t+1)', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(3u+1)'], []), ', from which it follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(N)'], []), '.  As there are only finitely many such matrices, we see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', BraceGroup('+1'), '(M)'], []), ' is contained in a finite union of geometric grid classes, and so is geometrically griddable by Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-griddable-unions')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Gridded Permutations and Trace Monoids')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-gridded-reg-lang')]), '\n', '\nIn the next two sections we show that geometrically griddable classes have rational generating functions.  We divide this task into two stages.  First, using trace monoids, we show that every ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('gridded')]), ' class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' is in bijection with a regular language.  Then, because a permutation may have many valid griddings, the second part of our task, undertaken in the next section, is to remove this multiplicity, allowing us to enumerate the geometric grid class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' and all its subclasses.\n\nTo illustrate the issue we seek to understand in this section, we refer the reader to Figure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-trace-encodings')]), '.  This example shows two different words which map to the same gridded permutation under ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), '.  This happens because the order in which points are consecutively inserted into ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('independent')]), " cells --- i.e., cells which share neither a column nor a row --- is immaterial.  On the language level, this means that letters which correspond to such cells ``commute''.  For example, in Figure~", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-trace-encodings')]), ', the second and third letters of the words can be interchanged without changing the gridded permutation, which corresponds to placing the points ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_3'], []), ' at different distances from their base points.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('xunit=0.017in, yunit=0.017in')]), '\n', TexCmd('psset', [BraceGroup('linewidth=0.005in')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('pspicture', ['(-3,-3)(120,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in')]), '(0,0)(40,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', '(80,40)(120,80)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(0,80)\n', TexCmd('psline',
