[BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,0)(120,0)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,40)(120,40)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=darkgray,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.02in'), BraceGroup('c-c')]), '(0,80)(120,80)\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(115,5)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(10,10)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('-45')]), '(10,10)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_2'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(105,65)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), TexCmd('uput', [BracketGroup('-45')]), '(105,65)', BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_3'], [])), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(60,60)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(95,25)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(90,50)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('pscircle*'), '(35,35)', BraceGroup('0.04in'), '\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(-3,1)(-3,39)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('<-c')]), '(-3,41)(-3,79)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('c->')]), '(1,-3)(39,-3)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('<-c')]), '(41,-3)(79,-3)\n', TexCmd('psline', [BracketGroup('linecolor=black,linestyle=solid,linewidth=0.01in,arrowsize=0.05in'), BraceGroup('<-c')]), '(81,-3)(119,-3)\n'], []), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Two drawings of a particular gridding of the permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2465371'], []), '.  The drawing on the left is encoded as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('1')])], []), ' while the drawing on the right is encoded as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('1')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('cell', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('1')])], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('fig-trace-encodings')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nMore precisely, suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a partial multiplication matrix with cell alphabet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '.  We say that the two words ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v,w', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^*'], []), ' are ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('equivalent')]), ' if one can be obtained from the other by successively interchanging adjacent letters which represent independent cells.  The equivalence classes of this relation therefore form a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('trace monoid')]), ', which can be defined by the presentation\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('Sigma'), ' ', '\\:', '|', '\\:', ' ', TexCmd('mbox', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('ij'), 'a_', BraceGroup('k', TexCmd('ell')), '=a_', BraceGroup('k', TexCmd('ell')), 'a_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' whenever ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('neq'), ' k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('ell')], []))]), TexCmd('rangle'), '.\n'], []), '\nAn element of this monoid (an equivalence class of words in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ') is called a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('trace')]), '; it is an elementary and foundational fact about presentations that two words lie in the same trace if and only if one can be obtained from the other by a finite sequence of applications of the defining relations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('ij'), 'a_', BraceGroup('k', TexCmd('ell')), '=a_', BraceGroup('k', TexCmd('ell')), 'a_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' whenever ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('neq'), ' k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' ', '(Howie~', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Proposition 1.5.9 and Section 1.6'), BraceGroup('howie:fundamentals-of:')]), ').  The theory of trace monoids is understood to considerable depth, see for example Diekert~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('diekert:combinatorics-o:')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prop-gridded-encoding-trace')]), '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' be a partial multiplication matrix with cell alphabet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '.  For words ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v,w', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ', we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)=', TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ' if and only if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' have the same trace in the trace monoid of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nIt is clear from the preceding discussion that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)=', TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ' whenever ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' have the same trace.\n\nNow suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)=', TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), '.  We aim to prove that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' have the same trace in the trace monoid of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  Clearly ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' must have the same length, say ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '.  We prove our assertion by induction on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '.  In the case where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=1'], []), ', note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(a_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), ')'], []), ' consists of a single point in cell ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), ', so if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|v|=|w|=1'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)=', TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ' implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=w'], []), ', and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' are in the same trace trivially.  Thus we assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('ge'), ' 2'], []), ' and that the assertion is true for all words of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n-1'], []), '.  \n\nWrite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=v_1', TexCmd('cdots'), ' v_n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=w_1', TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_n'], []), '.  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1=w_1'], []), ' then from the definition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v_2', TexCmd('cdots'), ' v_n)=', TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w_2', TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_n)'], []), ', and the assertion follows by induction.  Therefore we may assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1', TexCmd('neq'), ' w_1'], []), '.\n\nSuppose that the column and row signs of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',c_t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',r_u'], []), ' and that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1=a_', BraceGroup('k', TexCmd('ell'))], []), '.  While there are four cases depending on the column and row signs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', TexCmd('ell')], []), ', they are essentially identical, so we assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_k=r_', TexCmd('ell'), '=1'], []), '.  This means that among the points created by following the definition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ', the point corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_1'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)'], []), ' is the leftmost point in its column and bottommost point in its row.  Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)=', TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ' as ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('gridded')]), ' permutations, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ' must also contain a point in cell ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), ' which is the leftmost point in its column and bottommost point in its row; suppose this point corresponds to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_i'], []), '.  Because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_k=1'], []), ', the entries in column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' are placed from left to right, so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_i'], []), ' must be the first letter of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' which corresponds to a cell in column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '.  Similarly, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_i'], []), ' must be the first letter of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' which corresponds to a cell in row ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), '.  Therefore all of the letters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',w_', BraceGroup('i-1')], []), ' correspond to cells which are in different rows and columns from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell'))], []), '.  This shows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' lies in the same trace as the word\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ["\nw'=w_i w_1", TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_', BraceGroup('i-1'), ' w_', BraceGroup('i+1'), TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_n=v_1w_1', TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_', BraceGroup('i-1'), ' w_', BraceGroup('i+1'), TexCmd('cdots'), ' w_n.\n'], []), '\nObserve that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), "(w')=", TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ', and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), "(w')=", TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)'], []), '.  Finally, because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["w'"], []), ' have the same first letter, we see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["w'"], []), ' are in the same trace by the first case of this argument, which implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' are in the same trace, proving the proposition.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThis result established, we are reduced to the task of choosing from each trace a unique representative, which is a well-understood problem.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prop-trace-regular')]), '\nIn any trace monoid, it is possible to choose a unique representative from each trace in such a way that the resulting set of representatives forms a regular language.\n'], [BracketGroup('Anisimov and Knuth; see Diekert~', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Corollary 1.2.3'), BraceGroup('diekert:combinatorics-o:')])))]), '\n', '\nWe immediately obtain the following.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('corollary', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cor-geometric-gridded-reg')]), '\nFor every partial multiplication matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', the (gridded) class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' is in bijection with a regular language.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Regular Languages and Rational Generating Functions')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-geom-reg-lang')]), '\n', '\nWe now shift our attention to the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('ungridded')]), ' permutations in a geometrically griddable class.  This is the most technical argument of the paper, and we outline the general approach before delving into the formalisation.\n\nThe crux of the issue relates to the ungridded version of the encoding map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' and arises because it is possible that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(v)=', TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), ' for two words ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v,w', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' even though ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), '.  This happens precisely when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '=', TexCmd('bij'), '(v)=', TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), ' admits two different griddings.  To discuss these different griddings, we say that the gridded permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' is a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' gridding')]), ' of the permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), '.  Since our goal is to establish a bijection between any geometrically griddable class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' and a regular language, if a permutation in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' has multiple ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' griddings we must choose only one.  To do so, we introduce a total order on the set of all such griddings of a fixed permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ', and aim to keep only those which are minimal in this order.\n\nThe problem is thus translated to that of recognising minimal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' griddings: Given a word ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ', how can we determine if the gridded permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ' represents the minimal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' gridding of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '=', TexCmd('bij'), '(w)'], []), '?  If not, then there is a lesser gridding of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ', given by some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)'], []), '.  The fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)'], []), ' is less than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), ' is witnessed by the position of one or more particular entries which lie in different cells in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(v)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)'], []), '.\n\nIn order to discuss these entries, we use the terminology of marked permutations and marked words.  A ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('marked permutation')]), " is a permutation in which the entries are allowed to be marked, which we designate with an overline.  (Thus our marked permutations look like some other authors' signed permutations, although the marking is meant to convey a completely different concept.)  The containment order extends naturally, whereby we make sure that the markings line up.  Formally we say that the marked permutation ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' contains the marked permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' has a subsequence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '(i_1),', TexCmd('pi'), '(i_2),', TexCmd('dots'), ',', TexCmd('pi'), '(i_k)'], []), ' such that:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nFor example, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '=', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('3')]), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('9')]), '1', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('8')]), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('6')]), '7', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('4')]), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('5')]), '2'], []), ' contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '=', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('5')]), '1', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('3')]), '42'], []), ', as can be seen by considering the subsequence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('9')]), '1', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('6')]), '72'], []), '.  A ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('marked permutation class')]), ' is then a set of marked permutations which is closed downward under this containment order.\n\nThe mappings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' can be extended in the obvious manner to order-preserving mappings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bij'))])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bij'))]), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' to the marked version of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ', without and with grid lines, respectively, where here ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))])], []), ' is the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('marked cell alphabet')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), TexCmd('st'), ' a', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '\\}'], []), ', and both mappings send marked letters to marked entries.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-reg-lang')]), '\nEvery geometrically griddable class is in bijection with a regular language, and thus has a rational generating function.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' be a geometrically griddable class.  By Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-pmm')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' for a partial multiplication matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  By Corollary~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cor-geometric-gridded-reg')]), ', there is a regular language, say ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ', such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), TexCmd('st'), ' L^', TexCmd('griddedarrow'), TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' is a bijection.\n\nWe begin by defining a total order on the various griddings of each permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ', and thus also on the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' griddings of permutations in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), '.  Roughly, this order prefers griddings in which the entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' lie in cells as far to the left and bottom as possible, or, in terms of grid lines, the order prefers griddings in which the grid lines lie as far to the right and top as possible.  Suppose we have two different ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' griddings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' given by the grid lines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), '.  Because these griddings are different, there must be a leftmost vertical grid line, or failing that, a bottommost horizontal grid line, which moved.  Note that in the former case, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' will contain a different number of entries in the corresponding column, while in the latter case they will contain a different number of entries in the corresponding row.\n\nFormally, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)'], []), ' contains the same number of entries as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' in each of the leftmost ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k-1'], []), ' columns, but contains more entries than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' in column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', then we write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)', TexCmd('gridlex'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ', and we say that column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('witnesses')]), ' this fact.  Otherwise, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' contain the same number of entries in each column and in each of the bottom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '-1'], []), ' rows, but ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)'], []), ' contains more entries than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' in row ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)', TexCmd('gridlex'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ', and we say that row ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ' ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('witnesses')]), ' this fact.  Given a permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), ', our aim is to choose, from all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' griddings of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ', the minimal one.\n\nGiven a triple ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G,H)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' griddings of some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)', TexCmd('gridlexeq'), '(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ', we mark the entries of the gridded permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' in the following manner.  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)=(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ', then no markings are applied.  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)', TexCmd('gridlex'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' is witnessed by column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' then we mark those entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' which lie in column ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)'], []), ' but not in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), '.  Otherwise, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)', TexCmd('gridlex'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), ' is witnessed by row ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ' then we similarly mark those entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' which lie in row ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G)'], []), ' but not in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('C'))]), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' denote the set of all marked gridded permutations obtained from triples ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('pi'), ',G,H)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), ', in this manner.  Because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' griddings are inherited by subpermutations and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bij'))]), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' is order-preserving, the language\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('J')]), '\n=\n(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bij'))]), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), ')^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('C'))]), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), ')\n'], []), '\nis subword-closed in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast')], []), '.  In particular, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('J')])], []), ' is a regular language.  Loosely speaking, the words in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('J')])], []), ' containing marked letters carry information about all the non-minimal griddings.  Our goal is therefore to recognise these non-minimal griddings in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ', and remove them from the language ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), '.\n\nConsider any word ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w', TexCmd('in'), ' L^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ', which encodes the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), '-gridded permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(w)=(', TexCmd('pi'), ',H)'], []), '.  The gridding given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('not')]), ' the minimal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '(M)'], []), ' gridding of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' precisely if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('J')])], []), ' contains a copy of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' with one or more marked letters.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), ':(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast'), TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' denote the homomorphism which removes markings, i.e., the homomorphism given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a,', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), TexCmd('mapsto'), ' a'], []), '.  The words which represent non-minimal griddings (precisely the words we wish to remove from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ') are therefore the set\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nK=', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(\nJ', TexCmd('cap'), '\n', '((', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast'), TexCmd('setminus'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), ')\n).\n'], []), '\nBy the basic properties of regular languages, it can be seen that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' and hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L=L^', TexCmd('gridded'), TexCmd('setminus'), ' K'], []), ' are regular.  The proof is then complete as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), ':Larrow', TexCmd('C')], []), ' is a bijection.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Indecomposable and Simple Permutations')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-geom-simples')]), '\n', '\nHere we adapt the techniques of the previous section to establish bijections between regular languages and three structurally important subsets of geometrically griddable classes.\n\nAn ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('interval')]), ' in the permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' is a set of contiguous indices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I=', '[', 'a,b', ']'], []), ' such that the set of values ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '(I)=', '\\{', TexCmd('pi'), '(i) : i', TexCmd('in'), ' I', '\\}'], []), ' is also contiguous.  Every permutation of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' has trivial intervals of lengths ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '; the permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' of length at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' is said to be ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('simple')]), ' if it has no other intervals.  The importance of simple permutations in the study of permutation classes has been recognised since Albert and Atkinson~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('albert:simple-permutat:')]), ', whose terminology we follow; we refer to Brignall~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('brignall:a-survey-of-sim:')]), ' for a recent survey.\n\nGiven a permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' and nonempty permutations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',', TexCmd('alpha'), '_m'], []), ', the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('inflation')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',', TexCmd('alpha'), '_m'], []), ' --- denoted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_1,', TexCmd('dots'), ',', TexCmd('alpha'), '_m')])], []), ' --- is the permutation obtained by replacing each entry ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(i)'], []), ' by an interval that is order isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '_i'], []), ' in such a way that the intervals are order isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.  For example,\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n2413', '[', '1,132,321,12', ']', '=4 798 321 56.\n'], []), '\n', '\nTwo particular types of inflations have been given their own names.  These are the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('direct sum')]), ', or simply ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('sum')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('oplus'), TexCmd('sigma'), '=12', '[', TexCmd('pi'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), ']'], []), ' and the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('skew sum')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('ominus'), TexCmd('sigma'), '=21', '[', TexCmd('pi'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), ']'], []), '.  We say that a permutation is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('sum indecomposable')]), ' if it is not the sum of two shorter permutations and ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('skew indecomposable')]), ' if it is not the skew sum of two shorter permutations.\n\nThese notions defined, we are ready to construct regular languages which encode the simple, sum indecomposable, and skew indecomposable permutations in a geometrically griddable class.  Our approach mirrors the proof of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-reg-lang')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-simple-reg-lang')]), '\nThe simple, sum indecomposable, and skew indecomposable permutations in every geometrically griddable class are each in bijection with a regular language, and thus have rational generating functions.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nWe give complete details only for the case of simple permutations; the minor modifications needed to handle sum indecomposable and skew indecomposable permutations are indicated at the end of the proof.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' be a geometrically griddable class.  As usual, Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-pmm')]), ' implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' for a partial multiplication matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.  By Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-reg-lang')]), ', there is a regular language ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), ':L', TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('C')], []), ' is a bijection.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('C'))])], []), ' denote the set of all permutations in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' with all possible markings.  We say that the markings of a marked permutation are ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('interval consistent')]), ' if the marked entries of the permutation form a (possibly trivial) interval.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('I')]))])], []), ' consist of all marked permutations in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('C'))])], []), ' with interval consistent markings.  Because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bij'))])], []), ' is order-preserving, the preimage\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('J')]), '=', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bij'))]), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('I')]))]), ')\n'], []), '\nis subword-closed in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ', and thus is a regular language.\n\nNow consider any permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), '.  This permutation is simple if and only if it does not have a nontrivial interval.  In terms of our markings, therefore, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' is simple if and only if there is no interval consistent marking of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' which contains at least two marked entries and at least one unmarked entry.  On the language level, a word over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' has at least two marked entries and at least one unmarked entry precisely if it lies in\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', '(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', TexCmd('setminus'), '\n', '(\n', TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', TexCmd('cup'), '\n', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', TexCmd('cup'), '\n', TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', ').\n'], []), '\nTherefore the words in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' which represent non-simple permutations in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' are precisely those in the set\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\nK=', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(\n', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('J')]), '\n', TexCmd('cap'), '\n', '(\n(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', TexCmd('setminus'), '\n', '(\n', TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', TexCmd('cup'), '\n', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', TexCmd('cup'), '\n', TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', ')\n)\n),\n'], []), '\nwhere, as in the proof of Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-reg-lang')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), ':(', TexCmd('Sigma'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Sigma'))]), ')^', TexCmd('ast'), TexCmd('to'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), ' denotes the homomorphism which removes markings.  The simple permutations in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' are therefore encoded by the regular language ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L', TexCmd('setminus'), ' K'], []), ', completing the proof of that case.\n\nThis proof can easily be adapted to the case of sum (resp., skew) indecomposable permutations by defining markings to be ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('sum consistent')]), ' ', '(resp., ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('skew consistent')]), ') if the underlying permutation is the sum (resp., skew sum) of its marked entries and its unmarked entries (in either order).\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Atomic Decompositions')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-atomic-decompositions')]), '\n', '\nThe intersection of two geometrically griddable classes is trivially geometrically griddable, and as we observed in Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-griddable-unions')]), ', their union is geometrically griddable as well.  Therefore, within the lattice of permutation classes, the collection of geometrically griddable classes forms a sublattice.  In this section we consider geometrically griddable classes from a lattice-theoretic viewpoint.\n\n\nThe permutation class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('join-irreducible')]), ' ', '(in the usual lattice-theoretic sense) if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), TexCmd('neq'), TexCmd('D'), TexCmd('cup'), TexCmd('E')], []), ' for two proper subclasses ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('D'), ',', TexCmd('E'), TexCmd('subsetneq'), TexCmd('C')], []), '.  In deference to existing literature on permutation classes, we refer to join-irreducible classes as ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('atomic')]), '.  It is not difficult to show that the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' joint embedding property', '\\/'), ' is a necessary and sufficient condition for the permutation class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' to be atomic; this condition states that for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), ', there is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('C')], []), ' containing both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\n\nFra', BraceGroup('\\"', BraceGroup(TexCmd('i'))), 'ss', "\\'", 'e~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fraisse:sur-lextension-:')]), ' studied atomic classes in the more general context of relational structures, and established another necessary and sufficient condition.  Specialised to the context of permutations, given two linearly ordered sets ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' and a bijection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f:Aarrow B'], []), ', every finite subset ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'a_1<', TexCmd('cdots'), '<a_n', '\\}', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' A'], []), ' maps to a finite sequence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(a_1),', TexCmd('dots'), ',f(a_n)', TexCmd('in'), ' B'], []), ' that is order isomorphic to a unique permutation.  We call the set of permutations that arise in this manner the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' age of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), '\\/'), ', denoted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Age'), '(f:Aarrow B)'], []), '.  A proof of the following result in the language of permutations can also be found in Atkinson, Murphy and Ru', TexCmd('v', [BraceGroup('s')]), 'kuc~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('atkinson:pattern-avoidan:')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('atomic-tfae')]), '\nThe following three conditions are equivalent for a permutation class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('enumerate', ['\n', TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('(1)')]), TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('(2)')]), TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('(3)')])], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('Fra', BraceGroup('\\"', BraceGroup(TexCmd('i'))), 'ss', BraceGroup("\\'", 'e'), '~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('fraisse:sur-lextension-:')]), '; see also Hodges~', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Section 7.1'), BraceGroup('hodges:model-theory:')])))]), '\n', '\nThe next proposition is a specialisation of standard lattice-theoretic facts which may be found in more general terms in many sources, such as Birkhoff~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('birkhoff:lattice-theory:')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('proposition', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pwo-atomic-union')]), '\nEvery pwo permutation class can be expressed as a finite union of atomic classes.\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn order to describe the atomic geometrically griddable classes as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' for certain matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', we allow our matrices to contain entries equal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), ', to signify cells in which a permutation may contain at most one point.  We have to be a bit careful here, as it is unclear how one should interpret ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bullet'), '&', TexCmd('bullet'))])], []), '.  We simply forbid such configurations, in the sense formalised by the following definitions.\n\nSuppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrix, meaning that each entry of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' lies in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '0,', TexCmd('bullet'), ',1,-1', '\\}'], []), '.  We say that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), '-isolated if every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), ' entry is the only nonzero entry in its column and row.  Given a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), '-isolated ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', its ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('standard figure')]), ' is the point set in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^2'], []), ' consisting of:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\nWe can then extend the notion of geometric grid classes to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrices in the obvious manner, and we have the following result.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thm-geom-griddable-union-atomics')]), '\nThe atomic geometrically griddable classes are precisely the geometric grid classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), '-isolated ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrices, and every geometrically griddable class can be expressed as a finite union of such classes.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nFirst suppose that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), '-isolated ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrix.  It is clear from the geometric description of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' that given any two permutations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ', there is a permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('ge'), TexCmd('pi'), ',', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', so such classes satisfy the joint embedding property and are thus atomic by Theorem~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('atomic-tfae')]), '.\n\nNext we show that every geometrically griddable class can be expressed as a finite union of classes of the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), '-isolated ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrix.  Note that this will imply that the only atomic geometric griddable classes are of the latter type.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C')], []), ' be a geometrically griddable class.  By Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-geom-pmm')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('C'), TexCmd('subseteq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' for some partial multiplication matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' ', '(note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix) with cell alphabet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '.  Since the encoding map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), TexCmd('st'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('astarrow'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' is order-preserving (Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-properties-of-bij')]), '), the preimage ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', TexCmd('C'), ')'], []), ' is a subword-closed language.  By Proposition~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prop-subword-closed-decomp')]), ', we know that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(', TexCmd('C'), ')'], []), ' is a finite union of languages of the form\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqn-subword-form')]), '\n', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_1^', TexCmd('ast'), ' ', '\\{', TexCmd('emptyword'), ', a_2', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_3^', TexCmd('ast'), '\\{', TexCmd('emptyword'), ', a_4', '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('2q'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), ' ', '\\{', TexCmd('emptyword'), ', a_', BraceGroup('2q'), '\\}', ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('2q+1'), '^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n', TexCmd('tag', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('dagger')], []))]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('Sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('2q+1'), TexCmd('subseteq'), ' ', TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_2,', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ,a_', BraceGroup('2q'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' denote an arbitrary language of the form ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('eqn-subword-form')]), '. We will show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(L)=', TexCmd('Geom'), '(M_L)'], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), '-isolated ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_L'], []), ', from which the result will follow.  We start with the standard gridded figure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded'), '=(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ',G)'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('times'), ' ', '(2q+1)')], []), '.  Recall that each cell of the standard gridded figure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' becomes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(2q+1)^2'], []), ' cells in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' of which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(2q+1)'], []), ' are nonempty; we use this to label the nonempty cells of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('gridded')], []), ' by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup('k,', TexCmd('ell')), '^', BraceGroup('(s)')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('in', [BracketGroup('2q+1')])], []), ', in order of increasing distance from the base point as it would be in the standard gridded figure of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '.\n\nThe permutations in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('fig-atomic-decomp-lang')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bij'), '(L)=', TexCmd('Sub'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_L)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_L', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' ', TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' consists of:\n', TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('(1)')]), TexCmd('item', [BracketGroup('(2)')])], []), '\nFigure~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('fig-atomic-decomp-lang')]), ' shows an example of this construction.  The subfigure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_L'], []), ' is clearly the standard gridded figure of some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zdpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_L'], []), '.  Moreover, as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), ' entries can only arise from case (2) above, it follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_L'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bullet')], []), '-isolated, completing the proof.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Concluding Remarks')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sec-concluding-remarks')]), '\n', '\nWe have provided a comprehensive toolbox of results applicable to geometrically griddable classes, so perhaps the most immediate question is: how can one tell if a permutation class is geometrically griddable?  Huczynska and Vatter~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('huczynska:grid-classes-an:')]), ' have shown that a class is contained in a monotone grid class (i.e., it is ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('griddable')]), ') if and only if it does not contain arbitrarily long sums of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['21'], []), ' or skew sums of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['12'], []), '.  However, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)', TexCmd('neq'), TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), ' when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' is not a forest, so it remains to determine the precise border between griddability and ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('geometric')]), " griddability.\n\nNone of the major proofs in the preceding sections are effective, in as much as they all appeal to the finiteness of certain antichains of words, which follows nonconstructively from Higman's Theorem.  Therefore these proofs do not provide algorithms to accomplish any of the following:\n", TexNamedEnv('itemize', ['\n', TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item'), TexCmd('item')], []), '\n', '\nAn intriguing, and somewhat different, question is the membership problem.  Given a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', how efficiently (as a function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ') can one determine if a permutation of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' lies in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Geom'), '(M)'], []), '?  Because geometric grid classes are finitely based, this problem is guaranteed to be polynomial-time, but it could conceivably be linear-time.  Such a result would extend the parallel between geometric grid classes and subword-closed languages, because the latter (and indeed all regular languages) have linear-time membership problems.  \n\nWhile we believe that geometric grid classes play a special role in the structural theory of permutation classes, their non-geometric counterparts also present many natural questions.  Perhaps the most natural is the finite basis question.  Does the class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Grid'), '(M)'], []), ' have a finite basis for every ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zpm')], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), "?  We feel that the answer should be ``yes'', but have scant evidence.  In his thesis, Waton ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('waton:on-permutation-:')]), ' proves that the grid class\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('Grid'), TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('1&11&1')]), '\n'], []), '\nis finitely based.\n\nAnother example of a finitely based non-geometric grid class appears in one of the earliest papers on permutation patterns, where Stankova ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('stankova:forbidden-subse:')]), ' proves that the class of permutations which can be expressed as the union of an increasing and a decreasing subsequence, called the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('skew-merged permutations')]), ', has the basis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '2143, 3412', '\\}'], []), '.  In our notation, this class is\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('Grid'), TexCmd('fnmatrix', [BraceGroup('rr'), BraceGroup('-1&11&-1')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe class of skew-merged permutations is also notable because it is the only non-geometric grid class with a known generating function,\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-3x'), BraceGroup('(1-2x)', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-4x')]))]), ',\n'], []), '\ndue to Atkinson~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('atkinson:permutations-wh:')]), '.  Could it be the case that all (monotone) grid classes have algebraic generating functions?  A first step in this direction might be a more structural derivation of the generating function for skew-merged permutations.\n\n\n', TexCmd('bibliographystyle', [BraceGroup('acm')]), '\n../refs Bibliography file not found \n', TexCmd('bibliography', [BraceGroup('../refs')]), '\n', '\n'], []), '\n']
