some\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('NXN'), ','], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('zeta'), ')=', TexCmd('xi'), '(', TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('eta'), '))', TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), ')', TexCmd('rho'), '(x)\n ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for every '), ' x', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Hom')]), '\n', '(', TexCmd('zeta'), ',', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('eta'), '),'], []), '\nas in ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Defn. 4.2'), BraceGroup('iz1')]), '. \nThis can be described by a matrix representation \nfor  an orthonormal basis\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'w_', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), ')_i', '\\}'], []), ' of Hom(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ',', TexCmd('rho')], []), '), if we set\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '^p(', TexCmd('xi'), ')_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('eta'), ',i),(', TexCmd('zeta'), ',j)'), ':=\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('xi'), '(w_', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('zeta'), ')_j^', TexCmd('ast'), ')', TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '^p(', TexCmd('xi'), ') w_', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('eta'), ')_i', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Hom')]), '(', TexCmd('eta'), TexCmd('xi'), ', ', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('zeta'), ')', '\\,', ' .', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\nThen the even vertices of the quantum double system are labelled by \ninequivalent half-braidings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '^p'], []), ', and the odd vertices are labelled by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('otimes', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' id')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' opp'), ')', TexCmd('iota')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi')], []), ' running\nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('NXN')], []), '. Finally vertices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('otimes', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nid')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' opp'), ')', TexCmd('iota')], []), ' are joined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ',', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' edges, see\n', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('page 154'), BraceGroup('iz1')]), '. The principal graph of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' B'], []), ' is the\nconnected component containing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' id'), TexCmd('otimes', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' id')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nopp'), ')', TexCmd('iota')], []), '. \n\nIncidentally, the forgetful functor sending the half-braiding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '^p'], []), ' to the representation\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' is an algebra homomorphism, and indeed has a name: it is alpha-induction.\nSee also the discussion at the end of the next subsection.\n\nThe tube algebra is an effective way to compute the modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' of the quantum double.\nIn Section 2 we compare the tube algebras of the Haagerup subfactor and the group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), '. Their \nsimilarity is the first indication of a possible relation between them. \nThe ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('tube algebra')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('NXN')], []), ' is the finite dimensional C', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^*'], []), '-algebra\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['(', TexCmd('NXN'), ')=', TexCmd('bigoplus'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), ',', TexCmd('eta'), ',', TexCmd('zeta'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('NXN')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Hom'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('cdot'), '\n', TexCmd('zeta'), ',', TexCmd('zeta'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('eta'), ')', '\\,', '.\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tube')]), '\nThe simple summands of Tube(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('NXN')], []), ') are labelled by inequivalent half-braidings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cE'), '_', TexCmd('rho'), '^p'], []), '.\nThe modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' is obtained from the half-braidings by (2.8),(2.9) of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ".\n\nLet's consider in more detail the special case of tube algebras of finite groups.\nLet ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' be a finite group with identity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e'], []), '. Given a type III factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ', write\nInt', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(N)'], []), ' for the group of inner automorphisms and\nOut', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(N):=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Aut'), '(N)/', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Int'), '(N)'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('a'), ': G', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('Out')]), '(N)'], []), ' be a homomorphism. We take a \nlift ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('a'), ': G', TexCmd('to', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Aut')]), '(N)'], []), ', as in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('suth')]), '. \n\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('a'), '_g', ']', '[', TexCmd('a'), '_h', ']', '=', '[', TexCmd('a'), '_', BraceGroup('gh'), ']'], []), ' as sectors, there exists a unitary\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('g,h'), TexCmd('in'), ' N'], []), ' satisfying\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('a'), '_g', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('a'), '_h=', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('Ad')]), '(u_', BraceGroup('g,h'), ')', TexCmd('a'), '_', BraceGroup('gh'), '.'], []), '\nIn particular ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('g,h'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), '(', TexCmd('a'), '_', BraceGroup('gh'), ',', TexCmd('a'), '_g', TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('a'), '_h)'], []), '.\nAssociativity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('a'), '_g', TexCmd('a'), '_h)', TexCmd('a'), '_k=', TexCmd('a'), '_g(', TexCmd('a'), '_h', TexCmd('a'), '_k)'], []), ' implies\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('Ad')]), '(u_', BraceGroup('g,h'), ')u_', BraceGroup('gh,k'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('a'), '_', BraceGroup('ghk'), '=\n', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup('Ad')]), '(', TexCmd('a'), '_g(u_', BraceGroup('h,k'), ')u_', BraceGroup('g,hk'), ')', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('a'), '_', BraceGroup('ghk'), '.'], []), '\nThen since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '\nis a factor, there exists a scalar ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(g,h,k)', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbT')], []), ' satisfying\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('g,h'), 'u_', BraceGroup('gh,k'), '=', TexCmd('omega'), '(g,h,k)', TexCmd('a'), '_g(u_', BraceGroup('h,k'), ')u_', BraceGroup('g,hk'), ','], []), '\ni.e. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' is an element in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z^3(B_G;', TexCmd('bbT'), ')'], []), '. Conversely, every element in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z^3(B_G;', TexCmd('bbT'), ')'], []), '\narises as such an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('suth, J2')]), '.'), '\n', '\nSet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(g,h):= u_', BraceGroup('h,g^h'), 'u_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '^', TexCmd('ast')], []), '. The product and *-structure of the tube\nalgebra Tube(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('NXN')], []), ') are:\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(g,h)', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(k,l)=', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('k,g^h'), '\\,', TexCmd('theta'), '_g(h,l)', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(g,hl)', '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ccdelta')]), '&\n&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(g,h)^', TexCmd('ast'), '=', TexCmd('omega'), '(gh,h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ',h)', '\\,', TexCmd('omega'), '(h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ',gh,h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')', '\\,', '\n', TexCmd('omega'), '(h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ',h,g^h)', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(g^h,h^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')&\n'], []), '\n', '(recall (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('theta')]), ')). Consequently, \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(e,g)', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(e,h)=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(e,gh) ', TexCmd('hbox', [BraceGroup(' and '), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c')]), '(e,g)^', TexCmd('ast'), '\n=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(e,g^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')', '\\,', ','], []), '\nand thus the group algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbC', [BracketGroup('G')])], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is a C', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('ast')], []), '-subalgebra of\nTube(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('NXN')], []), ').\nThe identity of the tube algebra is\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('in'), ' G'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' c'), '(g,e)'], []), '.\n\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_g=', '\\{', 'g^h: h', TexCmd('in'), ' G', '\\}'], []), ' denote the conjugacy class of an element\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g', TexCmd('in'), ' G'], []), '.  Then we have the decomposition\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tube'), '(', TexCmd('NXN'), ')=', TexCmd('bigoplus'), '_', BraceGroup('K_u'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tube'), '(K_u)'], []), '\nwhere the sum ranges over the conjugacy classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ',\nand Tube', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K_u)=', TexCmd('bigoplus'), '_', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('in'), ' K_u,l', TexCmd('in'), ' G'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nHom'), '(', TexCmd('a'), '_g', TexCmd('a'), '_l,', TexCmd('a'), '_l', TexCmd('a'), '_', BraceGroup('g^l'), ')'], []), '. Hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbC', [BracketGroup('G')]), '=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tube'), '(K_e)'], []), '.\n\n\n\nThis decomposition can be further refined. Consider first a trivial twist ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EP4')]), '.\nThe outer action ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' gives a subfactor\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N', TexCmd('subset'), '  N', TexCmd('rtimes'), ' G=M'], []), '. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '\nsystem is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('a'), '_g', '\\}', TexCmd('equiv'), ' G'], []), ' whereas the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' system is the irreps\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), '.  ', BraceGroup('The tube algebras  Tube', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(G)', TexCmd('simeq', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\nTube')]), '(', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')]), ')'], []), ' are Morita equivalent'), ' as finite-dimensional\nC', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('ast')], []), '-algebras ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz1')]), ', ', BraceGroup('so their centres, the quantum doubles of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ', are identified'), '.\nThe simple components of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tube'), '(G)'], []), ', equivalently the even vertices of the quantum\ndouble of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ',  are labelled by pairs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), ' where \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Z')]), '_u')])], []), ' are irreps of the centralizers\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'), '_u'], []), ', see e.g.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KY1')]), ' or ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Sect. 4'), BraceGroup('EP')]), '. To every such \npair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), ' is attached the endomorphism\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Sigma'), '(G)'], []), ' defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')'), '=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' dim'), '(', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('h', TexCmd('in'), ' K_u'), TexCmd('a'), '_h', '\\,', '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn the dual system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ',\nthe endomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('hat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'))]), '_', BraceGroup('(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')')], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '(', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')]), ')'], []), ' attached to\nsuch a pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), ' is the Mackey induction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Ind'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'), '_u'), '^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup('G')), TexCmd('pi')], []), '\nfrom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'), '_u'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', decomposed into irreps of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n\n\n The number of inequivalent half-braidings\nassociated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')')], []), ' equals the number of \ninequivalent irreps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('prime'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'), '_u')])], []), ' such that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' dim'), '(', TexCmd('pi'), '^', TexCmd('prime'), ')=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' dim'), '(', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), '. The half-braiding for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '=', TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')')], []), ' ', BraceGroup('\nin its matrix decomposition'), '  is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', BraceGroup('(u^p,i),(u^q,j)'), '=\n', TexCmd('pi'), '_', BraceGroup('ji'), '(p', TexCmd('xi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' q^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' id'), '_N', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('halfbraiding')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' E'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho')), '^', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), ')')]), BraceGroup('for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' p^', BraceGroup('-1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'), '_uq, u^p, u^q ', TexCmd('in'), ' K _u'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j'], []), ' label the basis vectors in\n the representation space of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '.'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nAll this extends to the twisted case.\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), '_a'], []), "'s of (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('theta')]), ') are normalised twisted\ncocycles\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', namely from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ccdelta')]), ') they satisfy\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['\n', TexCmd('theta'), '_a(x,y) ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('theta'), '_a(xy,z) = ', TexCmd('theta'), '_a(x,yz) ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('theta'), '_', BraceGroup('x^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'ax'), '(y,z)', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('forall'), ' x,y,z ', TexCmd('in'), ' G', '\\,', '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cocy')]), '\n'], []), '\nThey thus describe  projective representations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Z')]), '_a'], []), '.\nAs we know ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DW')]), ', the primary fields  in the model twisted by a\ngiven 3-cocycle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' consist of all pairs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K_a,', TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), ' where\nnow ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('theta'), '_a'], []), '-Irr', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('Z')]), '_a)'], []), '.\n\n\nIn the cohomologically trivial case discussed in Section 1.1, this is immediate: we can twist\n the formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('halfbraiding')]), ') for half-braidings by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), '; inserting into (2.8),(2.9)\n of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ' recovers (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('moddataG')]), ').\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The canonical and dual canonical modular invariants')]), '\n', '\nThis subsection contains original material.\n\nSuppose we have a subfactor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N', TexCmd('subset'), ' M'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' system denoted by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '\nsystem ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '. The double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Delta'), '=LR(', TexCmd('Delta'), ')'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' is realised as sectors on a\nfactor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N', TexCmd('otimes'), ' N^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), '=:B'], []), '. Alpha-induction reverses this. That is, if you\ntake the appropriate modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' in the double, and take alpha-induction\nfrom ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ', then the full system is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('otimes'), TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), '. In some sense\nthen, the factor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and the modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' remembers the original system\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '. In fact it is a consequence of Theorem 1 below that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' system is just\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' regarded as a nimrep. \n\nTo get ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ', only the canonical endomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is needed ', BraceGroup(' \n', '(because of Theorem 1 below, \nwe can read ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' off from'), ' the modular invariant), plus the associated Q-system on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), '.\nThat is, all the information about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' and the full system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('otimes'), TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), '\nis carried in the primary fields and modular data of the double, the modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), '\nand its vacuum block ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), '. We suggest this modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' be called the\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('canonical modular invariant')]), '.\n\nDually, there is an inclusion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' M', TexCmd('otimes'), ' M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), '=:B'], []), ', where the dual\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' acts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ', but the same double acts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '. This comes with another\nmodular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]))], []), ', with a corresponding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))])], []), ' which\nregains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), TexCmd('otimes'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' as the full system. Here\n(again from Theorem 1 below) the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' system is just ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '. Again the modular invariant\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]))], []), ' --- the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('dual canonical modular invariant')]), ' --- and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))])], []), ' \n together encode the original system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '.\n \n This means we should regard the double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('cong'), ' ', TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' as equipped\n with two canonical modular invariants ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]))], []), ', from\n which using say alpha-induction one can recover the full system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '  and the nimrep \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' entirely in terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '. In particular the full system is\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('otimes'), TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), TexCmd('otimes'), '\n ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ', depending on the choice of modular invariant\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]))], []), ', and\n the nimrep is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '. \n \n Note that in both cases the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' system here is an algebra. \n For most modular invariants the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' system is only a module, but when the inclusion\n is type I, which implies for instance that the modular invariant\n is a sum of squares, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' system will necessarily be an algebra (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' B'], []), ' is\n type I iff the equivalent conditions of Proposition 3.2 in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BE4')]), ' hold; in the nets of subfactors \n setting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A(I)', TexCmd('subset'), ' B(I)'], []), ', this means the extended net is local). This suggests\nthat both inclusions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' N', TexCmd('otimes'), ' N^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' M', TexCmd('otimes'), ' M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' are type I. In fact more is true:\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Theorem 1.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('The inclusions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' N', TexCmd('otimes'), ' N^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' \nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' M', TexCmd('otimes'), ' M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' are both type I. Moreover, we have \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(Z_', TexCmd('Delta'), ')_', BraceGroup('i,j'), '=(Z_', TexCmd('Delta'), ')_', BraceGroup('i,0'), '(Z_', TexCmd('Delta'), ')_', BraceGroup('j,0'), '\\,'], []), ', i.e.')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta'), '=|', TexCmd('sum'), '_i Z_', BraceGroup('i,0'), 'ch_i|^2'], []), '\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('(similarly for  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]))], []), '). \nThe vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' with entries ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_i=(Z_', TexCmd('Delta'), ')_', BraceGroup('i,0')], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_i=(Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), ')_', BraceGroup('i,0')], []), ' are eigenvectors with eigenvalue 1 of both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof.'), BraceGroup('Corollaries 6.3 and 6.4 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz1')]), ' show that, at the level\nof subfactors, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('BXB'), '^+:=', TexCmd('alpha'), '^+(', TexCmd('BXB'), ')', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('otimes'), ' 1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('BXB'), '^-:=\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '^-(', TexCmd('AXA'), ')\n', TexCmd('subseteq'), ' 1', TexCmd('otimes', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), '. The neutral system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('BXB'), '^0=', TexCmd('BXB'), '^+', TexCmd('cap'), TexCmd('BXB'), '^-'], []), ' is thus contained in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('otimes'), ' 1', TexCmd('cap'), ' 1', TexCmd('otimes'), TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' and hence equals 1.\nBut dim', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('BXB'), '^', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' is computed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Prop.3.1'), BraceGroup('BE4')]), ',  for such a nondegenerate \nsystem like ours, to be \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('0,0'))]), '=', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('i,0')), BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('0,0'))]), 'Z_', BraceGroup('i,0'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('j,0')), BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('0,0'))]), 'Z_', BraceGroup('0,j'), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dimtheta')])], []), '\nwhich matches the dimensions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('otimes'), ' 1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('otimes'), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), '.\nTherefore we get the equalities ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('BXB'), '^+=', TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('otimes'), ' 1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('BXB'), '^-=1', TexCmd('otimes'), '\n', TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), '.\n\nAny canonical endomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' is bounded below by the vacuum sector:\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ',0'), TexCmd('lambda')], []), '. This inequality is a special case of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('theta'), TexCmd('lambda'), ',', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('rangle'), TexCmd('ge'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('alpha'), '^', TexCmd('pm'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ',', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', TexCmd('pm'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' ', '(', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('eq.(37)'), BraceGroup('BEK2')]), '; see also\n', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Thm.3.9'), BraceGroup('BE1')]), '). But dim', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\,', TexCmd('theta')], []), ' is given by\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '\\,', TexCmd('theta'), '=', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('iota'))]), TexCmd('iota'), ')=', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '(', TexCmd('iota'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('iota'))]), ')\n=', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '(', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('otimes'), TexCmd('xi'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), ')=', TexCmd('sum'), '(', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '\\,', TexCmd('xi'), ')^2=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('0,0'))]), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\nagreeing with \n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('dimtheta')]), ', and thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ',0'), TexCmd('lambda')], []), '. By \n', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Prop.3.2'), BraceGroup('BE4')]), ', this implies the inclusion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' B'], []), ' is type I.\n\nBecause of alpha-induction, we know a modular invariant takes the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',', TexCmd('lambda'), ',\n', TexCmd('mu')), 'b^+_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',', TexCmd('lambda')), 'b_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',', TexCmd('mu'))], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' runs over all sectors of the neutral system\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', TexCmd('pm'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ',', TexCmd('lambda')), '=', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ',', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', TexCmd('pm'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' are the branching\ncoefficients. Because this system is type I, we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^+=b^-'], []), '.\nBecause the neutral system is trivial, we have only one ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), '. Thus the modular invariant\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]))], []), ' corresponding to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))])], []), ', take the desired forms. The statements about the vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u,v'], []), ' follow\nfrom modular invariance.')]), '\nQED', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nFrom the theory of alpha-induction, we know that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' ', '(respectively ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ')\nis noncommutative iff some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(Z_', TexCmd('Delta'), ')_', BraceGroup('i,j'), '>1'], []), ' ', '(resp. some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), ')_', BraceGroup('i,j'), '>1'], []), ')\n--- see ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Cor.6.9'), BraceGroup('BEK1')]), ',', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Thm.4.11'), BraceGroup('BEK2')]), '.\nFor type I inclusions, we know from Section 4.1 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BE3')]), ' that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' system\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('AXB')], []), ' is isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('BXB'), '^', TexCmd('pm')], []), '.\n\nWe will call any modular invariant of the type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z=|', TexCmd('sum'), '_i Z_', BraceGroup('i,0'), '\\,', 'ch_i|^2'], []), ' a ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('monomial\nmodular invariant')]), '.\n\n\nOf course all this applies for a system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' of endomorphisms not\nnecessarily coming from a subfactor --- we expect this is relevant for our\ntwisted Haagerup data. Again ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' is recovered from the\ndouble ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and the canonical modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', TexCmd('Delta')], []), ', which again \nis monomial. The only \ndifference is that there is no ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '.\n\nSuppose a finite group  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' acts by outer automorphism on a type III\nfactor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '. Then as mentioned last subsection, by taking a crossed product we have a subfactor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N', TexCmd('subset'), ' M'], []), ' where the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' systems are identified with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), ' respectively.\nTaking the Longo-Rehren inclusion ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' N', TexCmd('otimes'), ' N^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ', the doubled ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '\nsystem can be identified with the untwisted quantum double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' G'], []), '. We will sometimes find it useful to use the\nK-theory language developed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ev,EG1')]), ', which identifies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' G'], []), ' with\nthe equivariant K-group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup('G'), '^0(G) ', TexCmd('cong'), ' K^0_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'), '-', TexCmd('Delta')), '(G', TexCmd('times'), ' G)'], []), ' where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' acts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' by the conjugate action and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '=', TexCmd('Delta'), '(G)', TexCmd('cong'), ' G'], []), ' acts \ndiagonally on the left and right of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G', TexCmd('times'), ' G'], []), '.\nThe neutral system is trivial\n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^0(e,e)= ', TexCmd('bbZ')], []), '), with sigma-restriction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('id')])), '=', TexCmd('theta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cD'), ' G'), TexCmd('cong'), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')])), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '\\,', TexCmd('chi'), '\\,', '(e,', TexCmd('chi'), ')', '\\,'], []), '. The full\nsystem is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), TexCmd('cong'), ' K^0(G ', TexCmd('times'), ' G)'], []), ' with canonical modular invariant\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gpmodinv1')]), '\nZ_', TexCmd('Delta'), '=|', TexCmd('sum'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '(e)', '\\,', 'ch_', BraceGroup('(e,', TexCmd('chi'), ')'), '|^2', '\\,', ','], []), '\nthe sum over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), '.  The dual LR-inclusion is\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' M', TexCmd('otimes'), ' M^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ', where the doubled ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' system is again the quantum\ndouble of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', the full system is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')]), TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), '\n', TexCmd('cong'), ' K^0_', BraceGroup('G ', TexCmd('times'), ' G'), '(G/G ', TexCmd('times'), ' G/G)'], []), ' and the neutral system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^0(G/G ', TexCmd('times'), ' G/G)'], []), ' is trivial. Here\nsigma-restriction is given by  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('id')])), '=', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cD'), ' G'), '\n', TexCmd('cong'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), ' ', '(g,', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('id')]), ')'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' runs over representatives\nof all conjugacy classes, and the dual canonical modular invariant is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gpmodinv2')]), '\n Z_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), '=|\n', TexCmd('sum'), ' ch_', BraceGroup('(a,1)'), '|^2', '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhere the sum runs over representatives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' of all conjugacy classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\n We recover from ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('gpmodinv1')]), ',', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('gpmodinv2')]), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), '=', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('G')])], []), '\nis always commutative, whereas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '=', TexCmd('bbC'), ' G'], []), ' is commutative iff all dimensions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '(e)=1'], []), ',\ni.e. iff ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' is abelian.\n\n\nBy the Galois theory of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz1')]), ', a subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K<G'], []), ' induces an intermediate\nsubfactor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' C', TexCmd('subset'), ' N', TexCmd('otimes'), ' N^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), ' where the doubled ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' system\nis the untwisted quantum double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' K', TexCmd('cong'), ' K^0_', BraceGroup('K'), '(K)', TexCmd('cong'), ' K^0_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'), ' K-\n', TexCmd('Delta'), ' K'), '(K ', TexCmd('times'), ' K)'], []), '.\nThen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('subset'), ' C'], []), ' is a braided subfactor of index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|G/K|'], []), '. The full system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(), '_C', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_C', TexCmd('cong'), ' K^0_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'), ' K\n-', TexCmd('Delta'), ' K'), '(G', TexCmd('times'), ' G)'], []), ' and chiral systems ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(), '_C', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('X')]), '_C^', TexCmd('pm'), '\n', TexCmd('cong', [BraceGroup()]), '_C', TexCmd('cX'), '_A', TexCmd('cong'), ' K^0_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'), ' K-', TexCmd('Delta'), ' G'), '(G ', TexCmd('times'), ' G)'], []), '. The branching coefficients and\nsigma-restriction\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^0_', BraceGroup('K'), '(K)arrow K^0_', BraceGroup('G'), '(G)'], []), ' are given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(g,', TexCmd('pi'), ')arrow ', TexCmd('Sigma'), "(g',\n", TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Ind')]), '^', BraceGroup('Z_g'), '_', BraceGroup('K ', TexCmd('cap'), ' Z_g'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), ', where the summation is over equivalence classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["g'"], []), ' \nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' conjugate to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), '. The trivial example ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=1'], []), ' recovers the canonical modular invariant\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('gpmodinv1')]), '. In the case of the dihedral group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G=D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and its cyclic subgroup\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', in which we are interested,\nthe canonical modular invariant arising from the inclusion is  given in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('modinvDnuZnu')]), '\nbelow.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('VOAs and  vector-valued modular functions')]), '\n', '\nFor the basic theory of VOAs, see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LeLi')]), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ' be a VOA. Write Irr', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('cV'), ')'], []), ' for the set of \nirreducible ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), '-modules ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '. Among other things, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ' and its modules carry a representation\nof the Virasoro algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Vir')]), '=', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Span')]), '\\{', 'L_n,C', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'))], []), ', where the central term\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ' acts as a scalar ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=c(', TexCmd('cV'), ')'], []), ' called the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('central charge')]), '. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), ' also\narose in Section \n2.1, where it was defined only mod 24. The action of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_0', TexCmd('in'), ' Vir'], []), ' on each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), '-module ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' defines a grading (by eigenvalues) on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' into finite-dimensional spaces.\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup()]), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Definition 3.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('A VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ' is called'), BraceGroup('rational')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('if')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('i)')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Irr')]), '(', TexCmd('cV'), ')'], []), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ' is isomorphic to its\ncontragredient as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), '-modules;')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('ii)')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('writing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '=', TexCmd('oplus'), '_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ')), TexCmd('cV'), '_n'], []), ' for the grading by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_0'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ', we have\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '_n=0'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n<0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '_0'], []), ' is 1-dimensional;')]), '\n ', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('iii)')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('every weak ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), '-module is completely reducible.')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', '\n See ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LeLi')]), ' for the details, which play no role in the following. There is no standard \n definition of rationality --- we chose Definition 3 to guarantee the existence of modular data.\n All VOAs considered in this paper are rational in this sense.\n \nRational VOAs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')])], []), ' ', '(or if you prefer, rational CFT) realise\nmodular data as follows. The primaries consist of  the finitely many modules \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Irr')]), '(', TexCmd('cV'), ')=', TexCmd('Phi')], []), ', and the\nvacuum 0 is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ' itself. Define their ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('characters')]), ' \n to be the graded dimensions\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['ch_M(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Tr')]), '_Mq^', BraceGroup('L_0-c/24'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('voachar')])], []), '\nusing the above grading by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L_0'], []), ', where as always we write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q=e^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('i'), TexCmd('tau'))], []), '. These \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_M'], []), ' will be holomorphic throughout the upper half-plane ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')]), '=', '\\{', TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('in'), '\n', TexCmd('bbC'), ':', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Im')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')>0', '\\}'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('zhu')]), '. Collect these \nfinitely many characters into a column vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), '. Then ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('zhu')]), ' showed\nthere is a representation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' of SL', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2(', TexCmd('bbZ'), ')'], []), ' such that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cheq')]), '\n', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('a', TexCmd('tau'), '+b'), BraceGroup('e', TexCmd('tau'), '+d')]), ')=', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['a&b', TexCmd('cr'), ' e&d'], []), ')\n', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('forall'), ' ', '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['a&b', TexCmd('cr'), ' e&d'], []), ')', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('SL')]), '_2(', TexCmd('bbZ'), ')', '\\,', '.\n'], []), '\nThe matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' now defined by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('modrep')]), ') constitute modular data ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hua')]), '. It\nmay or may not be unitary. Unlike braided subfactors, which are naturally associated to modular invariants, \nVOAs see only one chiral half of the rational CFT, and\nso  capture only the notion of modular data.\n\n\nThere is a rational VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(L)'], []), ' corresponding to any even positive-definite lattice ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '\n', '(the central charge equals the dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '), recovering the modular\ndata of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('moddataL')]), '). The character corresponding to coset ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'v', ']', TexCmd('in'), ' L^*/L'], []), ' is\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup('[', 'v', ']'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=', TexCmd('eta'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')^', BraceGroup('-n'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('in', [BracketGroup('v')])), 'q^', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('cdot'), ' x/2')], []), '.\nThere is a rational VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_k)'], []), ' corresponding to\naffine algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), '^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' at positive integral level ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', recovering the modular\ndata of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('kac')]), '. The character ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' corresponding to highest-weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' coincides with\nthe affine algebra character ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ', specialised to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), '.\nAffine algebra and lattice VOAs overlap for the simply-laced ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')])], []), '\nat level 1, corresponding to the root lattices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '. Finite group modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' G'], []), ' is \nrecovered by taking the orbifold\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '^G'], []), ' ', '(i.e. subVOA of fixed-points of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ') of a subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' of automorphisms of a\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('holomorphic')]), ' VOA (i.e. a rational VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ' with Irr', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('cV'), ')=', '\\{', TexCmd('cV'), '\\}'], []), ') --- it has been conjectured that any such ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '^G'], []), '\nwill itself be rational, but a general proof of this still seems far away.   Examples of holomorphic\nVOAs  are the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(L)'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' self-dual --- e.g. for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ' there\nis the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_8'], []), ' root lattice. In this case the orbifold theory is under better control, see e.g.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KacT')]), ", and indeed this is the main one we'll consider. A sexier example of holomorphic VOA \nthough is the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=24'], []), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Moonshine module')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^', TexCmd('natural')], []), '.\n\nIncidentally, Theorem 1 suggests that: ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('a VOA corresponding to\na quantum double should be a conformal subalgebra of a holomorphic VOA')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Definition 4.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' be a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '-dimensional representation of \nSL', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2(', TexCmd('bbZ'), ')'], []), ', with diagonal  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T:=', TexCmd('rho'), '(', BraceGroup('1', '\\,', '1', TexCmd('atop'), ' 0', '\\,', '1'), ')'], []), '. A'), BraceGroup('weakly holomorphic\nvector-valued modular\n function')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' with  multiplier ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' is a holomorphic function\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('H')]), 'arrow', TexCmd('bbC'), '^d'], []), ' satisfying (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cheq')]), '), with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), '-expansion')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('qexp')]), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=q^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('n=0'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '_nq^n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('for some diagonal matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' satisfying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T=e^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('i'), TexCmd('lambda'))], []), ',\nwhere each Fourier coefficient ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '_n', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbC'), '^d'], []), ' is independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cM'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), '\ndenote the space of all such ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')])], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), '.')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nEquation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('qexp')]), ') means ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' is meromorphic at the cusp.\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('zhu')]), ' showed that the character vector of a rational VOA is a vector-valued modular function\nin this sense. These character vectors  will help us study and identify the VOA.\n\nThe characters of rational VOAs also satisfy other conditions.\nFor instance, by definition (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('voachar')]), ') the Fourier coefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '_n'], []), ' in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('qexp')]), ')\nare nonnegative integers. The ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('vacuum')]), ' character \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cV')), '=ch_0'], []), ' begins with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1q^', BraceGroup('-c/24')], []), '. In a unitary VOA,  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' \nin (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('qexp')]), ') can be chosen so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('la'), '_M>-c/24'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M', TexCmd('ne'), ' ', TexCmd('cV')], []), ' in \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Irr')]), '(', TexCmd('cV'), ')'], []), '. \n\n\nRecall charge-conjugation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=S^2'], []), ' from Definition 1. A consequence of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cheq')]), ') is\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '=', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')])], []), '. For convenience we assume in the remainder of this subsection\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=I'], []), ', i.e. we have a representation\nof PSL', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2(', TexCmd('bbZ'), ')'], []), '. This holds for most modular data considered in this paper\n(other than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup('2n+1')], []), '), but at the end of  Section 2.4 we explain\n how to reduce ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C', TexCmd('ne'), ' I'], []), ' to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=I'], []), ' case.\n\nGiven any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '-dimensional PSL', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2(', TexCmd('bbZ'), ')'], []), '-representation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ',  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BG1,BG2')]), ' \ndescribe how to find  all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('cM'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), '. \nIn particular, there is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d', TexCmd('times'), ' d'], []), ' matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' with the\nproperty that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('cM'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), '  iff\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' is of the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('X')]), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=', TexCmd('Xi'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ') ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('P')]), '(J(', TexCmd('tau'), '))'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('P')]), '(x)'], []), ' is any \ncolumn vector whose entries are polynomials in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' is the Hauptmodul \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=q^', BraceGroup('-1'), '+196884q+', TexCmd('cdots')], []), '.  Thus it suffices to find \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), '.  \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' is determined through a differential equation it satisfies. This differential equation \nand the relevant initial condition is determined from two ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d', TexCmd('times'), ' d'], []), ' matrices\nof numbers. One is  a diagonal matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' satisfying among other things the relation \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('i'), TexCmd('Lambda')), '=T'], []), '; the more elusive one is called ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), '. In terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), ', the matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), '  has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), '-expansion\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')=q^', TexCmd('Lambda'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('n=-1'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' q^n', TexCmd('Xi'), '_n=q^', TexCmd('Lambda'), '(Iq^', BraceGroup('-1'), '+', TexCmd('chi'), '+', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('n=1'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' q^n', TexCmd('Xi'), '_n)', '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '_', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' is the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d', TexCmd('times'), ' d'], []), ' identity matrix, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '_0'], []), ' is \nthe matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), ',  and for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n=1,2,3,', TexCmd('ldots')], []), ' the matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '_n'], []), ' is recursively \ndefined by the commutator \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('recurs'), BracketGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), ',', TexCmd('Xi'), '_n')]), '+(n+1)', TexCmd('Xi'), '_n=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('l=-1'), '^', BraceGroup('n-1'), TexCmd('Xi'), '_l(f_', BraceGroup('n-l'), '\n', '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '-I)+g_', BraceGroup('n-1'), '(', TexCmd('chi'), '+', '[', TexCmd('Lambda'), ',', TexCmd('chi'), ']', '))', '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f_n,g_n'], []), ' are defined by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(J-240)', TexCmd('Delta'), '/E_', BraceGroup('10'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), ' f_nq^n'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '/E_', BraceGroup('10'), '=', TexCmd('sum'), ' g_nq^n'], []), ' for the discriminant form\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta'), '=', TexCmd('eta'), '^', BraceGroup('24')], []), ' and Eisenstein series ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('10'), '=E_4E_6'], []), '. That is, the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)'], []), '-entry of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '_n'], []), ' is the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)'], []), '-entry of ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('recurs')]), ', divided by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('ii'), '-', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('jj'), '+n+1'], []), '.\n\nThe following method suffices to find ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ',', TexCmd('chi')], []), ' for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' considered in this paper (though invariably there\nare more elegant methods). First, decompose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' into irreps. What is \nspecial about irreps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' is that their ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cM'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), '  is cyclic (Theorem 4.1 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BG2')]), '): the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cM'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), '\n is a module over the ring  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbC', [BracketGroup('J,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_1,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_2,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_3')])], []), ' of differentiable operators\n ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_1=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_', BraceGroup('10')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_0', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_2=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_8'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), '\n ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_1', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_0', '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_3=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('E_6'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))]), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_2', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_1', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_0\n', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('for')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_k=q', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'q')]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('k'), BraceGroup('6')]), 'E_2', '\\,', ','], []), '\n  and if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' is irreducible, then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cM'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), '\n', '(and hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), ') is generated over that ring by any nonzero ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('ch')]), TexCmd('in'), '\n', TexCmd('cM'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), ')'], []), '.  All irreps occurring in this paper are subrepresentations of the\nmodular data coming from even lattices, and so the desired nonzero modular function can be built\nfrom lattice theta functions. \n\nKnowing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), ' for a given ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' is equivalent to knowing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,', TexCmd('omega'), ' T'], []), ' for any third root of unity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ', but the explicit equivalence \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BG2')]), ' is not easy.  Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '^', BraceGroup('(k)'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' for the matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,', TexCmd('xi'), '_3^kT'], []), ' and assume\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'], []), ' ', '(hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ') is known. Then the columns of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xi')), '^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' are linear combinations over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbC')], []), ' of the columns of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '^', BraceGroup('-16'), 'E_4^2', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xi')), '^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '^', BraceGroup('-16'), '(E_6', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_0', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xi')), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '-E_4^2', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xi')), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '\n', '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '-1))'], []), ', while the columns of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)')], []), ' \nare linear combinations over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbC')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '^', BraceGroup('-8'), 'E_4', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xi')), '^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '^', BraceGroup('-8'), '(', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_1', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_0', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xi')), '^2-E_4', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Xi')), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '-I)(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('7'), BraceGroup('6')]), 'I)\n)', '\\,', '.'], []), '\n', '\nThe contragredient ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('rho'), '^T)^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' is handled\nsimilarly ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BG2')]), ': the columns of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('10'), 'E_', BraceGroup('14'), TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup('-2'), '(', TexCmd('Xi'), '^T)^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ' are linearly\nindependent vectors in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cM'), '((', TexCmd('rho'), '^T)^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')'], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Comparing the Haagerup, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Sym(3)'], []), ' and SO(13)')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The tube algebra of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Sym(3)'], []))]), '\n', '\nRecall the discussion in Section 1.2.\nWrite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3=Sym(3)=', '\\{', 'e,u,u^2,', TexCmd('tau'), ', ', TexCmd('tau'), ' u, ', TexCmd('tau'), ' u^2', '\\}'], []), '.\nThe three conjugacy classes are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_e=', '\\{', 'e', '\\}'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_u=', '\\{', 'u,u^2', '\\}'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('tau'), '=', '\\{', TexCmd('tau'), ', ', TexCmd('tau'), ' u, ', TexCmd('tau'), ' u^2', '\\}'], []), '. Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_3=', '\\{', '1,', TexCmd('epsilon'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), '\\}'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), '\nis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['sgn'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is 2-dimensional. Then each pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K_g,', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('in'), ' \n', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'))]), '_g'], []), ', gives rise  to a simple component of the tube algebra.\n\nThere are two half-braidings for endomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '=e'], []), ' as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_e,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' 1'), ')'), '=', TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_e,', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'), '=e'], []), ', and a third\nattached to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_e,', TexCmd('sigma'), ')'), '=e+e'], []), '. We denote these half-braidings by \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ',e^', BraceGroup('(2)')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2e'], []), ', respectively. \nThe conjugacy class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_u'], []), ' provides an endomorphism \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', BraceGroup('(K_u,', TexCmd('pi'), ')'), '=u+', BraceGroup('u^2')], []), ' for every irrep ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '  of \nthe centraliser ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'), '_u', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ', and hence\nthree half-braidings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(u+ u^2)^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(u+\nu^2)^', BraceGroup('(2)')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(u+ u^2)^', BraceGroup('(3)')], []), '.\nThe conjugacy class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('tau')], []), ' has \ncentraliser ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' Z'), '_', TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), ', so the endomorphism\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '=', TexCmd('tau'), '+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ' u'), '+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), ' u^2')], []), '\nhas two half-braidings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('tau'), '+ ', TexCmd('tau'), ' u+ ', TexCmd('tau'), ' u^2)^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('tau'), '+ ', TexCmd('tau'), ' u+', TexCmd('tau'), ' u^2)^', BraceGroup('(2)')], []), '.\n\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('epsfysize'), '=3in', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('epsffile', [BraceGroup('fig-S3fig7')]))]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('centerline', [BraceGroup('Figure 1. Izumi introduced\nthe following endomorphisms in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '(', TexCmd('Delta'), ')'], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' ', TexCmd('mu'), '=', TexCmd('rho'), '+ ', TexCmd('rho'), ' u+', TexCmd('rho'), ' u^2', '\\,', ',', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_1=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' id'), '+', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('pi'), '_2=2(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' id'), ')+', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '=u+', BraceGroup('u^2'), '+', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\n and proved that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_2'], []), ' have only one half-braiding, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' has\nthree (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)'), ',', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup('(3)'), ')'], []), ', and finally ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' has six  \n(', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('(6)')], []), ') and that these half-braidings exhaust all of them, so that the quantum double \nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' has 12 primaries as in the middle row of Figure 3. The induction-restriction graph of the Longo-Rehren inclusion of the\nsystem ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' is given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Fig. 5'), BraceGroup('iz3')]), ', see also the top of Figure 3. Dual principal graphs for doubles of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '\nfor Haagerup')]), '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nMore subtle is the dual principal graph corresponding to  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ', on the bottom of\n Figure 3, with dual canonical endomorphism\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', '[', TexCmd('theta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), ']', '=  ', '[', '0', ']', '+', '[', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ']', '+', '[', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), ']', '\n+', '[', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_0', ']'], []), ' and modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('11'), ' = |', TexCmd('chi'), '_0 + \n', TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), ' + ', TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')])), ' +', TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_0'), '|^2'], []), ' corresponding\nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('widehat'), TexCmd('Delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), '. \n To our knowledge this appears here for the first time. To derive it, first note that the\n only monomial modular invariants  for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Hg')], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('22'), '=|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+2ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')])), '|^2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('11'), '=|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')])), '+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_0'), '|^2'], []), ',\n and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('33'), '=|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+2ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_0'), '|^2'], []), ' \n', '(Proposition 4 below with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3'], []), '). The number of sectors in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '\n is 4, and the canonical endomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), '=0', TexCmd('otimes'), ' 0^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), '\n +a', TexCmd('otimes'), ' a^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), '+b', TexCmd('otimes'), ' b^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')])), '+c', TexCmd('otimes'), ' c^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('opp')]))], []), '.\n Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), ',', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), TexCmd('rangle'), '=4'], []), ',\n we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))]), ',', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))]), TexCmd('rangle'), '=4'], []), ' by Frobenius reciprocity.\n Thus the canonical modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))])], []), ' satisfies\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_i Z_', BraceGroup('0,i'), '^2=4'], []), ', forcing it to be ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('11')], []), ' and\n fixing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))])], []), '. Hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1^2+1^2+1^2+1^2=4'], []), ' \n irreducible sectors, call them ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_0,e_1,e_2,e_3'], []), ', one of which (say ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_0'], []), ') is the identity \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), '_', BraceGroup('0')], []), '. The proof of the equivalence is easy, e.g. use ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('SNT')]), '. \nA direct derivation is given in Theorem 5 below.\n\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), ' should be compared to the modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), ' for the (untwisted) double of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ', which\ncan be obtained from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('moddataG')]), ') (or see (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('STDk')]), ') below). This will also\nhelp identify a  VOA realisation. In this subsection we focus on the simplest possibility,\ncentral charge ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ' ', '(the smallest possible), although similar results hold for any other\nmultiple of 8.\n\nConsider first the modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), ' for the quantum double of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ', with primaries\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'], []), ' as in Figure 1. Start with the lattice VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(E_8)'], []), ' corresponding to\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_8'], []), ' root lattice. Its automorphism group is the compact Lie group \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_8(', TexCmd('bbR'), ')'], []), '. Then  the VOA realising (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('chS3+08')]), ') is the orbifold \nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(E_8)'], []), ' by some subgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_8(', TexCmd('bbR'), ')'], []), ' isomorphic to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ' \n', '(i.e. is the subVOA of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(E_8)'], []), ' fixed by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '). This is indeed possible (see Theorem\n4.3 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KacT')]), ').\n\nNow turn to the double of the Haagerup, also at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ', with primaries labelled as in Figure 3.\nIts 12-dimensional PSL', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_2(', TexCmd('bbZ'), ')'], []), '-representation  decomposes into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1+1+3+7'], []), ', \nwhere the 1- and 3-dimensional irreps are as before, and the 7-dimensional irrep occurs \nas a subrepresentation of the modular data of the 4-dimensional lattice ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_352_1', '[', '1,1/4', ']'], []), ',\n in the gluing notation of Conway-Sloane ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CS')]), '. From this we quickly obtain \n for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup('24'), ' 8'], []), ' its matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['&', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), '\ndiag'), '(2/3,2/3,2/3,2/3,0,1/3,5/39,20/39,32/39,2/39,8/39,11/39)', '\\,', ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), ' ', '(', TexNamedEnv('array', ['6& 80& 81& 81& 8748& 1215\n& 3549& 273& 13& 5538& 2275& 1378', TexCmd('cr'), ' \n80& 6& 81& 81& character vectors for the Haagerup modular\ndata at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ',  namely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '=0'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '=1'], []), ' in\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', [' ch_0(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', TexCmd('cr'), ' ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', '_0'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', TexCmd('cr'), ' ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_1'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')', TexCmd('cr'), '\nch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', TexCmd('cr'), ' ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_6'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')\n'], []), ')'), '=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['q^', evidence for the\nexistence of the corresponding VOA.\n\n\n\nWe see remarkable similarities between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), ' and \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), '  when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), '. In particular, the corresponding characters \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')])), ',ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_i')], []), ' are \n ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('identical')]), ', as are the sums ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]))], []), '.\nThe remaining characters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_1'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_6')], []), ' of ',
