BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_2')], []), ' of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), ', \nsince the exponents of their ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q'], []), '-expansions are unrelated.\n\nThis suggests that there is a rational VOA \nat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ', call it ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ', which has conformal subalgebras realising  the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), ' modular data (', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('conformal subalgebra')]), ' was defined at the beginning of Section 1).\nThe  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' characters will be ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]))], []), ' ', '(the vacuum character) and\nsome multiples of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')])), ',ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_i')], []), ', for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch'], []), "'s given in (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('chS3+08')]), '). \n\nIndeed, the knowledge of modular invariants says how this should go. We should look for  modular invariants\nof extension type  (i.e. sum of squares)  for both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), ', which start\nwith ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '|^2'], []), '. Both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Hg')], []), '  have one, namely\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Z3S3')]), ' and ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Z3Hg')]), '. \n In the case of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ' we readily identify the corresponding chiral extension: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' \ncorresponds to the quantum double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ' of the cyclic group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '. The modular\ninvariant says two inequivalent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '\n', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '-primaries correspond to each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]))], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_i')], []), '. \n\nSo ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' is the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '-orbifold (i.e. the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '-invariant part)\n of the rational\nVOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(E_', BraceGroup('8'), ')'], []), ', for some choice of order-3 element ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_8(', TexCmd('bbR'), ')'], []), '.  The group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_8(', TexCmd('bbR'), ')'], []), ' contains\nfour inequivalent order 3 elements: orbifolding by any of these would\ngive a VOA with 9 primaries realising modular data associated to a quantum\ndouble of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ". Half the time this double is twisted and half the time it\nisn't. Take one of the order 3 orbifolds corresponding to the untwisted double\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '. To recover the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), 'S_3'], []), ' VOA,\nchoose an order-2 element ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_8(', TexCmd('bbR'), ')'], []), ' for which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['gh=hg^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ': the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), '-orbifold of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' realises ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), 'S_3'], []), ". Unfortunately the Haagerup VOA won't itself be \nan orbifold of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' ', '(see Section 5.1 below), which\n begs Question 3 of Section 1.\n\nTo better identify ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ',\nwe should repeat the analysis for  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '.\nLabel its 9 primaries by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3^2'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(0,0)'], []), ' is the vacuum.\nNote that charge-conjugation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C=S^2'], []), ' is no longer the identity: it sends ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)'], []), '\nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-i,-j)'], []), '. Hence the characters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup('(i,j)')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup('(-i,-j)')], []), ' are equal\nand we should project to the subrepresentation Span', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'ch_', BraceGroup('(0,0)'), ',\n(ch_', BraceGroup('(0,1)'), '+ch_', BraceGroup('(0,2)'), ')/2,(ch_', BraceGroup('(1,0)'), '+ch_', BraceGroup('(2,0)'), ')/2,(ch_', BraceGroup('(1,1)'), '+ch_', BraceGroup('(2,2)'), ')/2,\n(ch_', BraceGroup('(1,2)'), '+ch_', BraceGroup('(2,1)'), ')/2', '\\}'], []), ' on which\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2', TexCmd('cong'), TexCmd('langle'), ' C', TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' acts trivially. This decomposes into\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1+1+3'], []), ', where the 1- and 3-dimensional irreps are as before. Choosing the\nabove basis,\nwe obtain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup('Z3'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('equiv'), ' 8'), '=', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '(2/3,2/3,2/3,0,1/3)'], []), '\nand ', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('chi'), '_', BraceGroup('Z3'), '^', BraceGroup('0,', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 8'), '=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', [' 86 &   162 &  162 &  17496 &  2430', TexCmd('cr'), '\n  81 &   167 &   -81 &   -8748  &  -1215', TexCmd('cr'), ' 81 &   -81 &   167 &   -8748 &   -1215', TexCmd('cr'), '\n  3  &   -3  &   -3  &    -12   &    18', TexCmd('cr'), ' 27 &   -27  &  -27  &   1458  &   -152'], []), ')'), '\\,', '.'], []), '\nIt is immediate that the only character vector possible for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', [' q^', BraceGroup('-1/3'), '(1+86q+1370q^2+11586q^3+', TexCmd('cdots'), ')', TexCmd('cr'), '\nq^', BraceGroup('2/3'), '(81+1377 q + 11583 q^2 +71037q^3+', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', ')  ', TexCmd('cr'), '   \n   3 + 243 q + 2916 q^2+21870q^3+', TexCmd('cdots'), '  ', TexCmd('cr'), '  q^', BraceGroup('1/3'), '(27 + 594 q + 5967 q^2+39852q^3+', TexCmd('cdots'), ')'], []), ')'), '\\,', '.'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['ch_', BraceGroup('(0,0)'), TexCmd('cr'), ' ch_', BraceGroup('(0,1)'), '=ch_', BraceGroup('(0,2)'), '=ch_', BraceGroup('(1,0)'), '=ch_', BraceGroup('(2,0)'), TexCmd('cr'), ' \nch_', BraceGroup('(1,1)'), '=ch_', BraceGroup('(2,2)'), TexCmd('cr'), ' ch_', BraceGroup('(1,2)'), '=ch_', BraceGroup('(2,1)')], []), '\n', ')')]), '    \nWe recognise this as the character vector for the lattice VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(A_2 E_6)'], []), ',\nso this is the VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' containing both the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ' and Haagerup VOAs. This ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8'], []), ' also has, like ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(E_8)'], []), ',  an interpretation as an affine algebra VOA, \nand the containment ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_8', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(E_8)'], []), ' corresponds to the\nconformal embedding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('2,1'), 'E_', BraceGroup('6,1'), TexCmd('subset'), ' E_', BraceGroup('8,1')], []), '. It can also be realised explicitly\nas an orbifold --- see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KacT')]), '. The only\ntask remaining is ', BraceGroup('to'), '  identify the Haagerup VOA as a subalgebra of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '(A_2 E_6)'], []), '.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The Haagerup and SO(13)')]), '\n', '\nThe relationship with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ' concerns the primaries ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_i'], []), ' and\nto a lesser extent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])], []), '. There also is a striking relationship with\nthe affine algebra modular data  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('6,2')], []), ' concerning the primaries ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'], []), ' ', '(and to a\nlesser extent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])], []), ').  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(B_', BraceGroup('6,2'), ')'], []), ' has central charge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=12'], []), ", and \n10 primaries we'll denote\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), '=2', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_1=', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_6'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_2=\n', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_1+', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_6'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_1=', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_5=', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_5,\n', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_6=2', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_6'], []), '. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '-matrix is diag', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-1,-1;-', TexCmd('i'), ',\n', TexCmd('i'), '; -', TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup('13'), '^', BraceGroup('6l^2'), ')'], []), ', while the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-matrix is ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KaWa')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nS=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), ' ', '(', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\ny/2&y/2&3/2&3/2&y&y&y&y&y&y', TexCmd('cr'), '  y/2&y/2&-3/2&-3/2&y&y&y&y&y&y', TexCmd('cr'), '  \n3/2&-3/2&3/2&-3/2&0&0&0&0&0&0', TexCmd('cr'), ' 3/2&-3/2&-3/2&3/2&0&0&0&0&0&0', TexCmd('cr'), '\ny&y&0&0&-c(1)&-c(2)& -c(3)& -c(4)& -c(5)& -c(6)', TexCmd('cr'), '\ny&y&0&0&-c(2)&-c(4)& -c(6)& -c(5)& -c(3)& -c(1)', TexCmd('cr'), ' y&y& 0&0&-c(3)&-c(6)& -c(4)& -c(1)&\n -c(2)& -c(5)', TexCmd('cr'), ' y&y&0&0&-c(4)&-c(5)& -c(1)& -c(3)& -c(6)& -c(2)', TexCmd('cr'), ' y&y&0&0&-c(5)&-c(3)&\n  -c(2)& -c(6)& -c(1)& -c(4)', TexCmd('cr'), ' y&y&0&0&-c(6)&-c(1)& -c(5)& -c(2)& -c(4)& -c(3)\n'], [BraceGroup('cccccccccc')]), ')')]), '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y=3/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('13')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c(j)=-2y', TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ' j/13)'], []), ' as before.\nIgnoring the first 4 primaries, the only difference with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Hg')], []), ' are some signs.\n\nThis strongly suggests relations between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(B_', BraceGroup('6,2'), ')'], []), ' and the (still hypothetical)\nHaagerup VOA involving the Goddard--Kent--Olive coset construction ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('GKO')]), '.\nIn the VOA language, the coset construction was developed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('FrZh')]), '; see also the\nlucid treatment in Section 3.11 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('LeLi')]), '). There are several ways this could go:\ne.g. the Haagerup VOA at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ' could be a coset of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(B_', BraceGroup('6,2'), ')'], []), ' by a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=4'], []), '\n subVOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '_4'], []), '. In this case the characters of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(B_', BraceGroup('6,2'), ')'], []), ' ', '(which can be determined\nby the Weyl-Kac character formula ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Ch.13'), BraceGroup('kac')]), ')  would be built from the characters of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '_4'], []), ' and the Haagerup. \n\nAlthough the possible relation between the Haagerup and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(B_', BraceGroup('6,2'), ')'], []), ', in particular\n those involving the coset construction, seems very intriguing,\nfor reasons of space we limit the discussion in this paper to relations between the Haagerup\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), '. \n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Generalising the modular data of the Haagerup')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Dihedral groups and orthogonal algebras')]), '\n', '\nLast section we observed that the Haagerup modular data is closely related to that of the symmetric\ngroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3=Sym(3)'], []), ' and affine so', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(13)'], []), ' at level 2. More generally, we propose next subsection a two-parameter \ngeneralisation  of the Haagerup, related to the odd dihedral groups and\naffine so', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(2m+1)'], []), ' at level 2. \n \nFirst, we compute the modular data for quantum doubles of \nthe dihedral group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', TexCmd('nu'), '=', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), ',u', '\\,', '|', '\\,', TexCmd('tau'), '^2,u^', TexCmd('nu'), ',', TexCmd('tau'), ' u=u^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=2n+1'], []), '. Of course ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3', TexCmd('cong'), ' D_3'], []), '. The twist group is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H^3(B_', BraceGroup('D_', TexCmd('nu')), ';\n', TexCmd('bbT'), ')=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('nu')), TexCmd('cong'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2', TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '; because the Schur multipliers of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and cyclic groups all\nvanish, the modular data is cohomologically trivial and is given by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('moddataG')]), '). The \nconjugacy classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' have representatives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e,u^h,', TexCmd('tau')], []), ' \nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' h', TexCmd('le'), ' n'], []), ', with centralisers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ',', TexCmd('langle'), ' u', TexCmd('rangle'), ',', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('rangle')], []), ' respectively. There \nare two 1-dimensional\nirreps of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' ', '(call them ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_0=1,', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_1'], []), ') and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' 2-dimensional ones (call them\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_i'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i', TexCmd('le'), ' n'], []), '); denote the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' 1-dimensional irreps of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), ' u', TexCmd('rangle'), TexCmd('cong'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_j'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('le'), ' j< ', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', and the two 1-dimensional irreps of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), TexCmd('rangle'), TexCmd('cong'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), '\nby ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_0,', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_1'], []), ' again. The primaries fall into four classes:', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('1.')]), ' two primaries: the vacuum ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0:=(e,1)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ':=(e,', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_1)'], []), ';\n\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('2.')]), '  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' primaries, labeled ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i:=(e,', TexCmd('sigma'), '_i)'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i', TexCmd('le'), ' n'], []), ';\n\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('3.')]), '  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' primaries, labeled ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,j'), ':=(u^h,', TexCmd('pi'), '_j)'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' h', TexCmd('le'), ' n, 0', TexCmd('le'), ' j< ', TexCmd('nu')], []), ';\n\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('4.')]), ' two primaries, labeled ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l:=(', TexCmd('tau'), ',', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_l)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l=1,2'], []), '.\n\n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), ' Fix a sign ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s=', TexCmd('pm'), ' '], []), ' and integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), '. Corresponding to these 4 classes we have the modular data\n', TexNamedEnv('align', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('STDk')]), '\nT=&', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' diag'), '(1,1;1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',1;', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('i'), '\\,', '(', TexCmd('omega'), ' h^2+', TexCmd('nu'), ' hj)/', TexCmd('nu'), '^2')]), ';t,-t)', '\\,', ',', TexCmd('cr'), '\nS=&', '\\,', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))]), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '&1_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), '&1_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n', TexCmd('nu')), '&', TexCmd('nu'), ' B', TexCmd('cr'), ' 1_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '&2_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), '&D&0_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), TexCmd('cr'), ' 1_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '&D^t&E&\n0_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), TexCmd('cr'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' B^t&0_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), '&0_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n', TexCmd('nu')), '&s', TexCmd('nu'), ' F'], []), ')', '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t=1,', TexCmd('i')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s=1,-1'], []), ' resp., ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k_', BraceGroup('a', TexCmd('times'), ' b')], []), ' for any number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' is the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a', TexCmd('times'), ' b'], []), ' matrix with constant entry ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['B=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['1&1', TexCmd('cr'), ' -1&-1'], []), ') ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' and'), ' F=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['1&-1', TexCmd('cr'), ' -1&1'], []), ')', '\\,', ','], []), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('i,(h,j)'), '=2', TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ' ih/', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ', and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup("(h,j),(h',j')"), '=2', TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', '(2', TexCmd('omega'), " hh'+", TexCmd('nu'), " hj'+", TexCmd('nu'), " h'j)/", TexCmd('nu'), '^2)'], []), ". We'll denote this modular data by\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. The untwisted double is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,0'), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. \nNote that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega'), '+k', TexCmd('nu')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is equivalent for any integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', so the\ntwist does indeed live in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ". \nWe've separated the order 2 from the order ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' twists, for later convenience.\nThe quantum-dimensions (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['='], []), 'statistical dimensions) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('*0'), '/S_', BraceGroup('00')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,\n', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,j'), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'], []), ' are 1, 2, 2, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ', respectively, and the global dimension\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/S_', BraceGroup('0,0')], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.  \n\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' entries live in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('nu'), '^2'))])], []), '. Choose any Galois\nautomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Gal')]), '(', TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('nu'), '^2'))]), '/', TexCmd('bbQ'), ')'], []), ' fixing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('i')], []), ' and define ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), '\n', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2')], []), ' by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2'), '=', TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2'), '^', TexCmd('ell')], []), '. Then applying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', as explained in Section 1.1, yields modular data equivalent to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('ell'), ' ', TexCmd('omega')), '\nD_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. In particular the fusion ring of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' depends only on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), '\nand gcd', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('omega'), ',', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), '. In fact, if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ', then\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('ell'), '^2 ', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' are equivalent.\n\nThe second ingredient going into our generalisation of the Haagerup modular data is the\n affine algebra modular data \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), ', which has central charge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=2m'], []), '. In particular ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('KaWa')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), '\n has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m+4'], []), ' primaries,\nlabelled ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), '=2', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_1=', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_m'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_2=\n', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_1+', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_m'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l=', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_l'], []), ' for \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' l<m'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_m=2', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_m'], []), '. Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=2m+1'], []), '. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '-matrix is \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup('12'), '^', BraceGroup('-m'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '(1,1;', TexCmd('xi'), '_8^m,-', TexCmd('xi'), '_8^m; ', TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('ml^2'), ')'], []), ', while the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '-matrix is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['S=(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x'), BraceGroup('2')]), '_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '&B&x_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' m'), TexCmd('cr'), '  \nB^T&F&0_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' m'), TexCmd('cr'), '  x_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '&0_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '&H'], []), ')', '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x=1/', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))])], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F'], []), ' are as above,  and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup("l,l'"), '=2x', TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), " ll'/", TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), '.\nThe quantum-dimensions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'], []), '  are \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1,', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), ',2'], []), ', respectively, with global dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))])], []), '.\n\nThere is no obvious twist of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), '.\nCuriously ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CGR')]), ',  affine so', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('nu'), '^2)'], []), ' at level 2 coincides with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' for \na specifically chosen twist ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' ', '(this is one of the few overlaps of affine algebra and finite\ngroup modular data ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CGR')]), '), but that fact seems to have no role\nin our story (in particular we are not interested in the values ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m=(', TexCmd('nu'), '^2-1)/2'], []), ').\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Generalising the  Haagerup modular data')]), '\n', '\nSections 2.3, 2.5 and 3.1 suggest a generalisation of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Hg')], []), '.\nWrite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=2n+1'], []), '  for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('ge'), ' 0'], []), ',   and choose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), '  \n as before. Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m=2(n^2+n+1)'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=2m+1=', TexCmd('nu'), '^2+4'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '=(', TexCmd('nu'), '+', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), ')/2'], []), '.\nNote that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' satisfies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '^2=', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta'), '+1'], []), ' and lies in the range\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '<', TexCmd('delta'), '<', TexCmd('nu'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')])], []), '. Again the primaries fall into four classes:', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('1.')]), ' two primaries, denoted 0 and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])], []), ';\n\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('2.')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' primaries, denoted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i'], []), ' for  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i', TexCmd('le'), ' n'], []), ';\n\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('3.')]), primaries, denoted ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' l', TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), ' \nBreaking ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' into 16 blocks, as in the previous subsection, we get\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nT=&', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' diag'), '(1,1;1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',1;', TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('i'), '(', TexCmd('omega'), ' h^2+', TexCmd('nu'), ' hi)/', ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['A&1_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), '&1_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n', TexCmd('nu')), "&B'", TexCmd('cr'), ' \n1_', TexCmd('cdots'), '&1', TexCmd('cr'), ' -1&-1&', TexCmd('cdots'), '&-1'], []), ')'], []), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('over'), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]))], []), '. Denote this modular\ndata by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega')), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', BraceGroup('2n+1')], []), '; we  call ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), '\n', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Haagerup-Izumi modular data')]), '. To our knowledge this modular \ndata is new except when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('le'), ' 1'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' divides ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), '; in particular twisting the Haagerup data was\nunanticipated in the literature. We discuss further generalisations next \nsubsection.\n\nThe quantum dimensions (or statistical dimensions) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('*,0'), '/S_', BraceGroup('0,0')], []), ' for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,j'), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'], []), ' are respectively\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1+', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2+', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2+', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta')], []), '. The global\ndimension is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/S_', BraceGroup('0,0'), '=', TexCmd('nu'), '\\,', '(', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta'), '+2)'], []), '. Note that the submatrix\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('nu'), ' H'], []), ' has exactly half of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '-1'], []), ' rows and columns of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ".\n\nThe fusions can be computed directly using Verlinde's formula ", TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('verl')]), '\n', '(or from Proposition 2 below). As\nmentioned in Section 1.1,\nit suffices to consider all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j,k'], []), ' different from 0. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', \nall of those fusion coefficients are 1 except for\n', TexNamedEnv('align', [' ', '&N_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i'), '=2', '\\,', ', N_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,i'), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,i')), '=2', '\\,', ', N_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'), '=0', '\\,', ', \nN_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_j,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_k'), '=2 ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('if')]), ' k', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), " si+s'j", '\\,', ', \n&', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&N_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,i'), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', \n&', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["s,s'", TexCmd('in'), '\\{', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1', '\\}'], []), ' are arbitrary signs.\n\nAs in Section 3.1, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', BraceGroup('2n+1')], []), ' depends up to equivalence on the\nvalue of the twist ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' mod ', [TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\nThe computation of fusions reduces to the identity \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['8', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('d=1'), '^k', TexCmd('cos'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), ' ad'), BraceGroup('2k+1')]), ')\n', TexCmd('cos'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), ' bd'), BraceGroup('2k+1')]), ')', TexCmd('cos'), '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(s_a,s_b)'], []), ' of signs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), ' 1'], []), ' such\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup('2k+1'), 's_aa+s_bb'], []), '. Modularity reduces to the Gauss sum\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('a=0'), '^', BraceGroup('2k'), TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup('2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('i'), '\\,', 'ca^2/(2k+1)')]), '=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('2k+1')]), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('c'), BraceGroup('2k+1')]), ' ', ')\n', '\\{', TexNamedEnv('matrix', [' 1&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for'), ' k ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' even'), TexCmd('cr'), ' ', TexCmd('i'), '&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' for'), ' k ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' odd'), '\n'], []), '.', '\\,', '.'], []), '\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('equiv'), '_8 5'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' can never be a \nperfect square, and the Jacobi symbol ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('m'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), ' ', ')'], []), ' will always equal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), '.\nSee Proposition 2 below for a more elegant argument.\n\nOf course ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_3'], []), ' recovers the original Haagerup double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Hg')], []), ', given in Section 2.3.\nThe similarity with the modular data  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), ' D_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), '  and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), ' \nis evident\n (ignoring the first 4 primaries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), ', the only difference with \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is that the bottom-right corner of both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' are off by some 6th root of 1). In particular, class 1 runs through the \n2-dimensional irreps of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', while ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' in class 3 parametrise the \nsize-2 conjugacy classes in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and \nthe irreps of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', respectively; class 4 runs through the fundamental \nnonspinorial\nweights of so', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ".  \n\nThe mysterious `13' in ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), ' is thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4+3^2'], []), ', where the 3 here references the normal\nsubgroup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '  of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), '.\nIt is tempting to guess that the 4 is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^2'], []), ", where the `2' is the involution of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), '. This\nsuggests the further generalisation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '\ngiven in the Wildly Optimistic Guess of Section 1.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Further generalisations')]), '\n', '\nThe way in which\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is built from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), ' leads to the notion of ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('grafting')]), ' modular data. \nA simple instance is provided by the following proposition, \nbut it can be massively generalised. For instance it would be interesting to\nextend it to vacuum blocks larger than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'], []), '.\n\nFor simplicity restrict here to ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('unitary')]), ' modular data (recall Section\n1.1) with real matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), '.\nCall modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Phi'), ',0,S,T)'], []), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), '-laminated')]), ' if it can be written in block form\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Phi'), '=(0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Phi')], []), ' is a permutation matrix (see e.g. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Gan2')]), '); in conformal\nfield theory, such a primary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["c,c'"], []), ' agree mod 24). Then the following\ndefines modular data:')]), '\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '=(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', [' x&x&', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup()]), "'\nx&x&", TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&-', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup()]), "' ", TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), '^T&', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), '^T&A&0 ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup()]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), ' T'), '&\n-', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup()]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), ' T'), "&0&D'"], []), ')', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')]), '=', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '(r,r;\n', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('s')]), ';', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('t')]), '\\,', "')", '\\,', '.'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(c)')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Suppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["x>x'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["r=-r'", TexCmd('omega')], []), ' for some 3rd root \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' of 1 (that is, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["c-c'", TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup('8'), '4'], []), '). Define\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_', TexCmd('pm'), '=x', TexCmd('pm'), " x'"], []), '. Then\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), '=(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', [' x_-&x_+&', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), "'\nx_+&x_-&", TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&-', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), "' ", TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), '^T&', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), '^', BraceGroup('T'), '&A&0 ', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), ' T'), '&\n-', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a'), BraceGroup()]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('prime'), ' T'), "&0&-A'"], []), ')', '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')]), '=', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '(r,r;\n', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('s')]), ';-', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('t')]), '\\,', "')", '\\,'], []), '\nsatisfies all conditions of modular data except possibly that the fusion\ncoefficients are nonnegative integers. Its fusion coefficients are all integers\niff ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["4|(M'-M)"], []), ', and both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["L>0,L'>0"], []), '. \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), ',', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' define modular data if in addition\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["N'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_k,", TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_", BraceGroup("k'"), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_", BraceGroup("k''")), TexCmd('le'), ' 8^', BraceGroup("L'"), "/(M'-M)"], []), '.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof.')]), ' Recall ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('galois')]), '. Clearly, any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '\npermutes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), '\\}'], []), ', so the number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' will be fixed by any\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '. But ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), ' is an algebraic integer, being the sum of squares of\ncertain eigenvalues ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('i,0'), '/S_', BraceGroup('0,0')], []), ' of integer matrices. Therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', BraceGroup('-2')], []), '\nis indeed an integer. Computing \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k'), '/\nN_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_j,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k'), '=a_i/a_j'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("k'")), '/\nN_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k'), '=d_', BraceGroup("k'"), '/d_k'], []), ', we see that there are\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), ',', TexCmd('gamma'), '>0'], []), ' for which both vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('a')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('d')])], []), '\nare integral. The gcd condition follows by choosing these \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), ',', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' as small as  possible.\nBecause ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('d')]), '=1/2'], []), ', we know ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '^2', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbQ')], []), '. Because \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_k'), '=2a_id_k^2/x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), ' and each\nquantum-dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_k/x'], []), ' is an algebraic integer, we know ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i/x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), ' and\nhence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('beta'), ' x)^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), '. This gives us (a).\n\nThe proof of (b) and (c) is now straightforward. Most interesting are the\nfusion calculations in (c). Note that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["4x^2x'", BraceGroup(), "^2/(x^2-x'", BraceGroup(), "^2)=1/(M'-M)"], []), ', \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_i/x', TexCmd('in'), ' 2^', BraceGroup('L'), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["a_k'/x'", TexCmd('in'), ' 2^', BraceGroup("L'"), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), '. ', \n', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('N')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_', BraceGroup("i'")), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('a_ia_', BraceGroup("i'")), BraceGroup('x^2', '\\,', "(M'-M)")]), '+', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup("i,i'"), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('N')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_k"), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('N')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_', BraceGroup("i'"), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_', BraceGroup("i''")), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('a_ia_', BraceGroup("i'"), 'a_', BraceGroup("i''")), BraceGroup('2x^3', '\\,', "(M'-M)")]), '+', BraceGroup('N'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_', BraceGroup("i'"), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_', BraceGroup("i''")), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('N')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_', BraceGroup("i'"), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_k"), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('a_ia_', BraceGroup("i'"), "a'_k"), BraceGroup("2x^2x'", '\\,', "(M'-M)")]), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \n', '&&', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('N')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_k,", TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_", BraceGroup("k'")), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("a_ia'_ka'_", BraceGroup("k'")), BraceGroup("2xx'", BraceGroup(), '^2', '\\,', "(M'-M)")]), '\\,', ',\n', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('N')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_k,", TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_", BraceGroup("k'"), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), "'_", BraceGroup("k''")), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("a'_ka'_", BraceGroup("k'"), "a'_", BraceGroup("k''")), BraceGroup("2x'", BraceGroup(), '^3', '\\,', "(M'-M)")]), "-N'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nWe call ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('S')]), ',', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('T')])], []), ' the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('graft')]), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S',T'"], []), ' onto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), '. \nOf course ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is the graft of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), '  onto\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'), ',', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '; here ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'=", TexCmd('mu')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M=', TexCmd('nu'), '^2'], []), ' ', '(so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'-M=4"], []), '), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '=', TexCmd('xi'), '_3^', BraceGroup('n^2+n-2')], []), ', and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["L=L'=2"], []), '. An easy example of (b) is grafting  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,0'), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' onto\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' to form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\nAn easy generalisation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is to replace \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' with any abelian group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' of odd order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), '. Take a trivial twist ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '=0'], []), ', for \nsimplicity. The entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' involving  classes 1 and 4 are identical to\nthose in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('genhS')]), '). The role of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' \nis played by the semi-direct product ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_K=K', TexCmd('sdprod'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2 '], []), ', so the class 2 primaries\nare labelled by the 2-dimensional irreps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_K'], []), ', and the class 3 ones by pairs\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(h,j)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' runs through representatives of the cardinality-2 conjugacy classes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_K'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' runs \nthrough the irreps of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), "-entries for class 2 are again 1's, while those for class 3 are\nthe evaluation ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j(h)'], []), '. The submatrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E'], []), ' are again cosines, namely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('i,(h,j)'), '\n=i(h)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup("(h,j),(h',j')"), '=2', '\\,', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Re')]), "(j'(h)", '\\,', "j(h'))"], []), '.  Although the modular data thus generalises\nnaturally to arbitrary odd order abelian groups, we see in Section 4.1 that the subfactor\nrealisation for noncyclic ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' is more subtle.\n\nIt is tempting to look for additional twists of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ". After all,\nwe've suggested that the generalised Haagerup  is a twin of the dihedral ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', and the latter can be twisted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' and not merely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' twist of both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' affects the class 3 primaries.\nThe independent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), ' twist of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' affects the\nclass 4 primaries, so this suggests one should look for additional twists (by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), '\nor perhaps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ') of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', which sees the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), " primaries of class 4\nand leaves the other classes untouched.\n\nWe haven't gotten this to work. For instance, one\n approach to probing  some of the missing twists would be a\nGalois automorphism acting on ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' entry-by-entry. \nThe entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' lie in \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2', TexCmd('mu')))])], []), ', with Galois group  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2'), '\n', TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), '. The class 3 twists ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' are stable under ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2')], []), ', \nas explained last subsection, so we should consider the effect of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), '\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. \n\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), ' y=', TexCmd('pm'), ' y'], []), ' for some sign. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), ' y=-y'], []), ', then\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' sends ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' to ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('nonunitary')]), ' modular data\nwith exactly the same fusion coefficients: the vacuum\nprimary is still the first one, but the positive column of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), " is the second one. This means this\nmodular data won't have a subfactor realisation (it could perhaps have a planar algebra\ninterpretation, if the requirement of positive-definiteness there is dropped), though it can still have a VOA one.\nThe notion of twist should presumably preserve unitarity, so we won't regard this ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), '\n', TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' as a twist. Nevertheless it may be interesting to search for \nits VOA realisations.\n\nFor this reason we should focus on those\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' for which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), ' y=+y'], []), '. Now,\nit is typical for small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is a prime power (this is true for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '<19'], []), ' except ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=9'], []), ').\nIn this case, any such ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' will send ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' to equivalent modular\ndata. The search for new twists using Galois seems to fail. \n\nHowever when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is not a prime power, this idea bears fruit. Given the prime decomposition\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^k p_i^', BraceGroup('m_i')], []), ', where each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_i>0'], []), ', then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Gal')]), '(', TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2\n', TexCmd('mu')))]), '/', TexCmd('bbQ'), ')', TexCmd('cong'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2', TexCmd('mu')), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' fixes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' iff ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^k (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell')), BraceGroup('p_i')]), '\n', ')=+1'], []), '. We can also require here that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2'), '1'], []), ' ', '(the \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '^2'], []), '-part of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ' merely shuffles\nthe twists ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), '). The automorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' maps ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' to\nequivalent modular data iff ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell')), BraceGroup('p_i')]), ')=+1'], []), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('forall'), ' i'], []), '. Given any set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), '\n', '(possibly empty) containing an even number of distinct prime divisors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ', pick any\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '_P', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2', TexCmd('mu')), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '_P', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2'), '1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell')), BraceGroup('p_i')]), ')=-1'], []), '\niff ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i', TexCmd('in'), ' P'], []), '. By ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), ',P'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' we mean the modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'), '_P'), 'S,\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'), '_P'), 'T'], []), '; up to equivalence it is well-defined, and is inequivalent to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), '\n', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' even though it has the same fusions. Thus as long as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k>1'], []), ',\ni.e. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is not a prime power, this construction yields new modular data.\nIn Section 4.1 we find subfactor realisations for this new Galois twist, at least when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=9'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=19'], []), '.\n\n\nWe learned in Section 2.4 that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), ' also sees ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ', in some ways more\ndirectly than it does ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' has only a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' worth of\ntwists, it is certainly not inconceivable that the correct generic\ntwist group for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is indeed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. \n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Miscellanea involving modular invariants')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Sect. 6'), BraceGroup('EP')]), ' studied the quantum double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ' modular data in detail,\nand similar techniques ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EP4')]), ' can be used for their twists, as noted in \n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('E2')]), '. Using ', TexCmd('cite', [BracketGroup('Theorem 4.3'), BraceGroup('EP3')]), ',', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EP4')]), ' ', '(with the correction to ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EP3')]), ' where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('11')], []), ' was erroneously recorded as being sufferable, when we have now seen in\nSection 2.2 of this paper that it is indeed a dual canonical modular invariant),\n  we can summarize these results in the\nfollowing table (', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('nimless')]), ' means there is no compatible nimrep, while ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('nimble')]), ' means there is; ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('sufferable')]), ' means there is a subfactor realisation):\n\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexNamedEnv('array', [' ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('rm', [BraceGroup('nimless')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('rm', [BraceGroup('nimble, insufferable')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('rm', [BraceGroup('sufferable')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('rm', [BraceGroup('total')]), '\n ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,0'), 'S_3& 14&6&28&48 ', TexCmd('hline'), '\n', TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,1'), 'S_3& 1&0&4&5
