[BraceGroup(TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Table 1.')]), ' Modular invariants for the doubles of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Sym(3)'], []), ' and Haagerup')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', '\nThe commutant of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' of course forms an algebra under matrix multiplication,\nbut the sufferable modular invariants themselves have a fusion structure, in\nthe sense that the product of two of them is always a linear combination over\nnonnegative integers of other sufferable modular invariants. \nThe modular invariants for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', \nincluding this fusion structure, are naturally isomorphic for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), '\n', TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', using ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('cong'), TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ';\nthe same applies to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('omega')), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EP4,E2')]), ' remarked that there is an (injective) homomorphism from the 28 \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), '  modular invariants to the 28 sufferable  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,0'), 'S_3'], []), ' ones.\nWe can define a natural injective homomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('(S_3,s', TexCmd('omega'), ')'), '^', BraceGroup('(S_3,+0)')], []), ' from the sufferable\ntwist ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s,', TexCmd('omega')], []), ' quantum double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), '  modular invariants into the untwisted \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ' ones. We can actually embed the sufferable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), ' into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+1'], []), ' modular \ninvariants, the sufferable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), ' into\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-0'], []), ' modular invariants and the sufferable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-0'], []), ' into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+0'], []), ' modular invariants. \n\nThis can be generalised and understood as follows. As is clear from Sections 3.1 and 3.2,\n primaries for both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('s,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' fall naturally into\n 4 classes, and so their  modular invariants decompose \n naturally into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4', TexCmd('times'), ' 4'], []), ' blocks as did their ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' matrices. Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('[', 'i', ']', ',', '[', 'j', ']'), ',T_', BraceGroup('[', 'i', ']', ',', '[', 'i', ']'), ',M_', BraceGroup('[', 'i', ']', ',', '[', 'j', ']')], []), ' for these blocks.\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Theorem 3.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' for the number of distinct prime \ndivisors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), '. Define  a map\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Hg'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('D ', TexCmd('nu')), ' M=(', TexNamedEnv('array', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '1', ']'), '&M_', BraceGroup('[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '2', ']'), '&M_', BraceGroup('[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '3', ']'), '&0_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '\nM_', BraceGroup('[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '1', ']'), '&M_', BraceGroup('[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '2', ']'), '&M_', BraceGroup('[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '3', ']'), '&0_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), 'M_', BraceGroup('[', '3', ']', ',', '[', '1', ']'), '&M_', BraceGroup('[', '3', ']', ',', '[', '2', ']'), '&M_', BraceGroup('[', '3', ']', ',', '[', '3', ']'), '&0_', BraceGroup('n', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '\n0_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2'), '&0_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n'), '&0_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' n', TexCmd('nu')), '&(a-b)I_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2')], [BraceGroup('cccc')]), ')'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '1', ']'), '=(', TexNamedEnv('array', ['a&b c&d'], [BraceGroup('cc')]), ')'], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Hg'), TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('D', TexCmd('nu'))], []), '\nis a bijection between all modular invariants of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), ', and\nall modular invariants of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), '. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Hg'), TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('D', TexCmd('nu'))], []), '\nis a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^', BraceGroup('k -1')], []), '-to-1 surjection from all modular invariants of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b= 0'], []), ', onto\nall modular invariants of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b= 0'], []), '. Moreover, any modular invariant\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is a modular invariant of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' ', '(but not conversely). \n')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof.')]), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), ' be modular invariants for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', respectively. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' ', '(resp. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S',T'"], []), ') denote the modular data\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' ', '(resp. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '). From ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'T'=T'M'"], []), ' we see that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'_", BraceGroup('[', 'i', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']'), "=0=M'_", BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', 'i', ']')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,2,3'], []), '. We also see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'_", BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']')], []), ' is diagonal.\nRecall ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Mselrule')]), ': we see from the 0-row of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' in classes ', '[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '3', ']', '\nis identically +1 for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2', TexCmd('mu')), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ', while  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_', TexCmd('ell'), '(', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l)\n=(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), ')'], []), ' equals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-1'], []), ' when e.g. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' m'], []), '. Thus also\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', 'i', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']'), '=0=M_', BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', 'i', ']')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,2,3'], []), '.\n\nEvaluating ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['MS=SM'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', '[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']', ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', '[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '1', ']', ')'], []), ', we get two possibilities (identical conclusions\nhold for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'"], []), '):', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(i)')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '1', ']'), '=I'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']')], []), ' is a permutation matrix: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), '\n=', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), " l,l'")], []), ' for some permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' l', TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ';\n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(ii)')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '1', ']', ',', '[', '1', ']'), '=1_', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('times'), ' 2')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']'), '=0'], []), '.', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', '\nLooking at the remaining equations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['MS=SM'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['MT=TM'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'S'=S'M'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'T'=T'M'"], []), ',\nwe see that (in case (i)) the equations involving ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']')], []), ' decouple from the others and reduce to\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('pi'), '(l)', '\\,', TexCmd('pi'), "(l')", TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('pm'), " ll'", '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('pi'), '(l)^2', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' l^2', '\\,', '.', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('m44S')])], []), '\nOn the other hand, the equations for the unknown entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', 'i', ']', ',', '[', 'j', ']')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j', TexCmd('ne'), ' 4'], []), ',\nare identical to the corresponding equations  for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'_", BraceGroup('[', 'i', ']', ',', '[', 'j', ']')], []), '. For example, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(MS)_', BraceGroup('[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']'), '\n=(SM)_', BraceGroup('[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["(M'S')_", BraceGroup('[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']'), "=(S'M')_", BraceGroup('[', '2', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']')], []), ' both reduce to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,0'), '\n=M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]))], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,0'), "=M'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]))], []), '.\nTherefore in case (ii), where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']'), "=0=M'_", BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']')], []), ', this means ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Hg'), TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('D', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is indeed a bijection.\n\nIn case (i), we know ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["M'_", BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']'), '=I'], []), ', so we need to identify the permutation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '.\nWrite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), ' 1=', TexCmd('ell')], []), '. Then ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('m44S')]), ' requires ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '^2', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' 1'], []), ', hence \n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), ' l', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('pm'), ' l ', TexCmd('ell')], []), '. So to any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ' satisfying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '^2', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' 1'], []), ',\ndefine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell')), ' l'], []), ' to be the unique number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell')), 'l', TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ' obeying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell')), 'l', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('pm'), '\nl ', TexCmd('ell')], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'))], []), ' satisfies ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('m44S')]), ' and thus defines the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('[', '4', ']', ',', '[', '4', ']')], []), '-block\nof a case (i) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '  modular invariant. These ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2^', BraceGroup('k-1')], []), ' \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell')], []), ' parametrise the kernel of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Hg'), TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('D', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' in case (i). \n\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is handled identically. QED', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nNote that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Hg'), TexCmd('nu')), '^', BraceGroup('D', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is linear and preserves matrix multiplication. \nIn particular, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is a prime-power (as it is for the original Haagerup ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), ', and\nall ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '<19'], []), ' except ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=9'], []), '), there will be an algebra isomorphism between\nthe span of modular invariants for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', and an (injective but nonsurjective)\nalgebra homomorphism of these into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\nThe relation between the 28 sufferable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,0'), 'S_3'], []), ' modular invariants and\nthe 28 ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_3'], []), ' modular invariants would seem to be a coincidence:\ne.g. at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,0'), 'D_1=', TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,0'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), ' has exactly\n6 modular invariants, all sufferable, while ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_1'], []), ' has exactly 2.\n\nThe dihedral group is only half the story; the other half is the affine algebra data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), '.\nIts modular invariants were classified in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Gorth')]), ':\nwhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is not a perfect square (the situation here), the complete list is\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(d_0,', TexCmd('ell'), '_0)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(d_1,', TexCmd('ell'), '_1;d_2,', TexCmd('ell'), '_2)=B(d_2,', TexCmd('ell'), '_2;d_1,', TexCmd('ell'), '_1)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_i|\n', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '|d_i^2'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), '_i', TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ' obeys ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '_i^2', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup('d_i^2\n/', TexCmd('mu')), '1'], []), '. for matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(d,', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(d_1,', TexCmd('ell'), '_1;d_2,', TexCmd('ell'), '_2)'], []), ' \ndefined in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Gorth')]), '. Those modular invariants which are permutation \nmatrices are the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(', TexCmd('mu'), ',', TexCmd('ell'), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ' satisfying\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), '^2', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' 1'], []), ': their nonzero entries are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(', TexCmd('mu'), ',', TexCmd('ell'), ')_', BraceGroup('z,z'), '=1'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z\n', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i', '\\}'], []), ',\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(', TexCmd('mu'), ',', TexCmd('ell'), ')_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), '=1'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["l'", TexCmd('equiv'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('pm'), ' \n', TexCmd('ell'), ' l'], []), '. We see from this and Theorem 3 that the modular invariants of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' come from those of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('-,', TexCmd('omega')), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('m,2')], []), ' in a very direct sense.\n\nRecall ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ost,Ev')]), ' that the sufferable modular\ninvariants of the double of a finite group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' are parametrised by pairs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(H,', TexCmd('psi')], []), ') where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' is a subgroup of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G', TexCmd('times'), ' G'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), TexCmd('in'), ' H^2(B_H;', TexCmd('bbC'), '^', TexCmd('times'), ')'], []), ' is called\n', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('discrete torsion')]), '. This suggests:\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Question 4.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Find some analogue for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' of\nthis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(H,', TexCmd('psi'), ')'], []), ' parametrisation of\nsufferable modular invariants.')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nThis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(H,', TexCmd('psi'), ')'], []), ' parametrisation belongs most naturally to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' formulation of the double of the group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\nAs mentioned in Section 1.2, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' is also  the double of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '.\nIs there also a parametrisation of the sufferable modular invariants of the double of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '\nwhich is more natural in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' language?\n\nOf special importance (recall Section 1.3) are the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('monomial')]), ' modular invariants\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. Three of these are obvious:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+2', TexCmd('sum'), ' ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i'), '|^2', '\\,', ',\n|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+', TexCmd('sum'), ' ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i'), '+', TexCmd('sum'), ' ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,0')), '|^2', '\\,', ',\n|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+2', TexCmd('sum'), ' ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,0')), '|^2', '\\,', '.', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('monom')])], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Proposition 4.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('When ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=p'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['pq'], []), ' for (not necessarily distinct)  primes\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p,q'], []), ', the only monomial modular invariants are the three in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('monom')]), '.')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof.')]), '  We need to find all eigenvectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' with eigenvalue \n1, with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_0=1'], []), ' and all other ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_x', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '0,1,2,', TexCmd('ldots'), '\\}'], []), ', so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z=|', TexCmd('sum'), '_x u_xch_x|^2'], []), '. We know\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '=1'], []), ' since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '=1'], []), ' for any modular invariant\n(clear from the proof of Theorem 3), hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'), '=0'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l'], []), '. We need to\ndetermine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_i:=u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('h,j'), ':=u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,j'))], []), '.\n\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Tu=u'], []), ' implies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('h,j'), '=0'], []), ' unless ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' divides ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['hj'], []), '. Therefore if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('h,j'), TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), ' we have:\n\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(i)')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' prime, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j'], []), ' must be 0;\n\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(ii)')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=p^2'], []), ', only for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j=0'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p|h'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p|j'], []), ';\n\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(iii)')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=pq'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p', TexCmd('ne'), ' q'], []), '), only for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j=0'], []), ', or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p|h'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q|j'], []), ', or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q|h'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p|j'], []), '.\n\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Su=u'], []), ' implies, for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), " h,h''", TexCmd('le'), ' n'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0', TexCmd('le'), ' i<', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', \n', TexNamedEnv('align', [' ', '&&2+2', TexCmd('sum'), ' u_', BraceGroup('j'), '+2', TexCmd('sum'), ' u_', BraceGroup("h',j"), TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), "\nih'/", TexCmd('nu'), ')=', TexCmd('nu'), ' u_i ', '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sub')]), ' ', '&&2+2', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ' jh/', TexCmd('nu'), ')+2', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), "(\nhj+h'i)/", TexCmd('nu'), ')u_', BraceGroup("h',j"), '=', TexCmd('nu'), ' u_', BraceGroup('h,i'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('succ')]), ' ', '&&', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ' hj/', TexCmd('nu'), ')', '\\,', 'u_', BraceGroup("h'',j"), '=', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), " h''j/", TexCmd('nu'), ')', '\\,', 'u_', BraceGroup('h,j'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('suc')])], []), '\nwhere we sum over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["h',j"], []), ' ', '(', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('suc')]), ' was obtained by hitting  ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('succ')]), ' with cos', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(2', TexCmd('pi'), " h''i/", TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ' and summing over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ').\nIn analysing these equations, it is useful to recall (for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' odd)\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sum'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '_k^', TexCmd('ell'), '=2', TexCmd('sum'), ' ', TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), ' l/k)=', TexCmd('mu'), '(k)', '\\,', ','], []), '\nthe sums taken over the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('le'), ' k'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' l< k/2'], []), ' which are coprime to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '. \nThe M', '\\"', 'obius function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '(k)'], []), ' \n equals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-1)^n'], []), ' if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' is a product of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n', TexCmd('ge'), ' 0'], []), ' distinct primes, and \n0 otherwise.\nThe Galois symmetry ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('ell')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' ', '(recall\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('galsym')]), ') maps \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('ell'), ' i')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,j')], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('ell'), ' h,\n', TexCmd('ell'), ' j')], []), '. Therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_i=u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('gcd')]), '(i,', TexCmd('nu'), ')')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('h,j'), '=u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('gcd')]), '(h,', TexCmd('nu'), '),jh/\n', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('gcd')]), '(h,', TexCmd('nu'), ')')], []), ', so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('h,-j'), '=u_', BraceGroup('h,j')], []), '.\n\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' prime, this means ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_i=u_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('h,j'), '=u_', BraceGroup('1,0'), TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('j,0')], []), '. Plugging this into\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('sub')]), ' gives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_1+u_', BraceGroup('1,0'), '=2'], []), ', which correspond to the three\n solutions ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('monom')]), '.\n\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=p^2'], []), ', we read off from ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('suc')]), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["h=p,h'=1"], []), ' that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('p,jp'), '=u_', BraceGroup('p,0'), '-u_', BraceGroup('1,0')], []), '\nfor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), '. Then comparing ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('sub')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,p'], []), ' gives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2=u_p+u_', BraceGroup('1,0'), '=u_1+u_', BraceGroup('p,0')], []), '.\nWe can now force ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_p=u_1'], []), ' by ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('succ')]), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=p,i=1'], []), ', and again we recover ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('monom')]), '.\n\nFinally, turn to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=pq'], []), '.  ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('suc')]), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["h'=p,q"], []), ' gives respectively\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('p,qj'), '=u_', BraceGroup('p,0'), '-u_', BraceGroup('1,0')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('q,pj'), '=u_', BraceGroup('q,0'), '-u_', BraceGroup('1,0')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), '. Then ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('sub')]), ' at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i=1,p,q'], []), ' gives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_q+u_', BraceGroup('q,0'), '=u_p+u_', BraceGroup('p,0'), '=2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('1,0'), '=2+u_1-u_p-u_q'], []), '. Now\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('succ')]), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=i=p'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h=i=q'], []), ' give ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_1=u_p=u_q'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', BraceGroup('1,0'), '=u_', BraceGroup('p,0'), '=u_', BraceGroup('q,0')], []), "\nand we're done. QED", TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3'], []), ' modular invariants ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Z3S3')]), ',', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Z3Hg')]), ' generalise,\nfor any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm'), ',', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', to\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('modinvDnuZnu')]), '\n|ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '|^2+2', TexCmd('sum'), '|ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i'), '|^2+2', TexCmd('sum'), '|ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,j')), '|^2', '\\,', '.\n'], []), '\nThis corresponds to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' subsystem in\nboth ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', and to the VOA realising ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '\nand containing both  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' VOAs.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Subfactors for Haagerup--Izumi modular data')]), '\n ', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup("Izumi's subfactors and their modular data")]), '\n', '\nIn Section 5 we address the question of realising this generalised Haagerup modular data\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' by\nVOAs. In this section we address their subfactor realisation. \n\nIn Section 7 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ', Izumi suggests associating subfactors to any odd abelian group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' of \norder ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), ',\nusing endomorphisms in the Cuntz algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '+1')], []), ". (Warning: Izumi's ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' is our \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=2n+1'], []), '.)  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ' be the set of all  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('nu')], []), ' complex matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A=(A_', BraceGroup('g,h'), ')'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g,h', TexCmd('in'), ' K'], []), ', satisfying\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&&A_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '=', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('A_', BraceGroup('h,g'))]), '\\,', ', A_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '=A_', BraceGroup('-h,g-h'), '=A_', BraceGroup('h-g,-g'), '\\,', ',\nA_', BraceGroup('g,0'), '=', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('g,0'), '-1/(', TexCmd('delta'), '-1)', '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('7.1')]), ' ', '&&', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('in'), ' K'), 'A_', BraceGroup('g+m,h'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('A_', BraceGroup('m,h'))]), '=', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('g,0'), '\n-', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('h,0'), '/', TexCmd('delta'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('7.4')]), ' ', '&&', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('m', TexCmd('in'), ' K'), 'A_', BraceGroup('m,g+h'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('A_', BraceGroup('m+k,g'), 'A_', BraceGroup('m+l,h'))]), '=\nA_', BraceGroup('g+l,k'), 'A_', BraceGroup('h+k,l'), '-', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('g,0'), TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('h,0'), '/', TexCmd('delta'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('7.5')])], []), '\nfor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g,h,k,l', TexCmd('in'), ' K'], []), ' ', '(recall ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '=(', TexCmd('nu'), '+', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '^2+4')]), ')/2'], []), '). These equations imply ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', '&&|A_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '|=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'))]), '\\,', ',\n&& A_', BraceGroup('g+k,h'), 'A_', BraceGroup('h,k'), '=A_', BraceGroup('-k,g'), 'A_', BraceGroup('g,h-k'), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('7.7')])], []), '\nfor any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g,h,k', TexCmd('in'), ' K'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0,', '\\,', 'h', TexCmd('ne'), ' 0,', '\\,', 'g', TexCmd('ne'), ' h'], []), '.\nIzumi shows that to any matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ', \n there corresponds a (nonbraided) subfactor of index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '+1'], []), ' with principal\ngraph the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), '-star (see the top graphs of Figures 2 and 4). We call these ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('subfactors of\nIzumi type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '.')]), ' Next subsection we\ndetermine much of the data of these subfactors. \nHis Theorem 8.4 identifies the modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' of the\neven part of the quantum double of this subfactor in terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m(', TexCmd('nu'), '^2+1)'], []), ' variables\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l,C^l_', BraceGroup('g,h')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g,h', TexCmd('in'), ' K'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' l', TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ', satisfying the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m(', TexCmd('nu'), '^2+1)'], []), ' equations:\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('g', TexCmd('in'), ' K'), 'C_', BraceGroup('0,g'), '^l=', TexCmd('omega'), '_l-', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '_l')]), '/', TexCmd('delta'), '\\,', ',\n ', TexCmd('omega'), '_lC^l_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '-', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k', TexCmd('in'), ' K'), ' A_', BraceGroup('g+k,2h'), 'C^l_', BraceGroup('h,k'), '= ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('h,0'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '_l')]), '/', TexCmd('delta'), '\\,', '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('8.10')])], []), '\nSome  solutions to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ', occurring when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '^', TexCmd('nu'), '_l=1'], []), ',\n  are redundant (i.e. correspond to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,j')], []), ') and should be \nignored. In particular, \nprecisely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_1(', TexCmd('nu'), ')-1'], []), ' ', '(i.e. the sum of divisors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d>1'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ') \nsolutions to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l= 1'], []), ' are redundant, and \n for any other root of unity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' dividing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ', \nthe number of redundant solutions is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), " d'", TexCmd('phi'), '(', TexCmd('nu'), "/d')/2"], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), " is\nEuler's totient and the sum is over all divisors ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ["d'<d"], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '. The \nentries of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '\nmatrices equal those of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' except possibly for those in the bottom-right\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m', TexCmd('times'), ' m'], []), ' block, which are given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'), '\n=e^', BraceGroup('-2', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('i'), ' c/24'), TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' and \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta'), '+2')]), '(', TexCmd('omega'), '_l', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup("l'"), '\n+', TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('g,h', TexCmd('in'), ' K'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('C^l_', BraceGroup('g,g+h'), 'C^', BraceGroup("l'"), '_', BraceGroup('-g,h'))]), ')', '\\,', '.', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('8.12')])], []), '\nWhen some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' has more than one solution in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ', ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.12')]), " \nis ambiguous as it isn't obvious which solutions to ", TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' to use.\n\nIzumi shows in his Example 7.1 that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3)'], []), ' contains exactly \ntwo matrices, both corresponding to\nthe Haagerup subfactor. In Appendix C he exactly \nsolves ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3)'], []), ', and in this \nway obtains (a complicated expression for) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Hg')], []), '.\n\nIn his Example 7.2, Izumi shows ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_5)'], []), ' contains exactly 4 matrices, \nagain corresponding to a single (new) subfactor.\nIzumi does not solve ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' for them.\nThis analysis of ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.1')]), '-', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.5')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=5'], []), ' is as far as Izumi went (this is what \nwe mean when we call it a ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('hypothetical')]), ' family of subfactors).\n\n\nNevertheless we can push a little further this analysis. The group Aut', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K)'], []), ' acts naturally\non the matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' by shuffling the entries: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Aut')]), '(K)'], []), ' sends ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' to \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A^', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' defined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '=A_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' g,', TexCmd('alpha'), ' h')], []), '. For example, when \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ',\nAut', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K)=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' acts by multiplication. In this way, given any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ', Aut', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(K)'], []), '\nembeds into Aut', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup('A')]), ')'], []), ' and fixes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup('A')])], []), ' is the field generated over\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbQ')], []), ' by all entries ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('g,h')], []), '. Call ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A,A'", TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('equivalent')]), ' if \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["A'=A^", BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))], []), ' for some ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Aut')]), '(K)'], []), '. Equivalent matrices give rise to\nequivalent subfactors and equivalent modular data.\nFor later convenience, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup('A')])], []), ', write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Tr'), '\\,', ' x'], []), ' for the orbit sum ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('y', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), ' x', TexCmd('rangle')), 'y'], []), ' over the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-orbit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), ' x', TexCmd('rangle')], []), '.\n\nIt is very difficult to solve ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' directly (see Appendix C of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ' for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3'], []), '\nargument, which is already quite involved). Our strategy for finding the modular data is\nto reduce it to computer calculations. A key observation is that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S,T'], []), ' are the modular data\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', and if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S',T"], []), ' is a second modular data, with\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Sapprox')]), "\n|S'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), '-S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), '|<', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('18', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]))])], []), '\nfor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), " l,l'", TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ', and all other entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' are equal, then ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('SNT')]), ' implies\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S'=S"], []), ' everywhere.\nMaple 11 (x86 64 Linux) was used in these calculations. It is difficult to rigourously analyse \nthe resulting error, but various consistency checks (e.g. unitarity of the\nnumerically obtained ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S'"], []), ' matrix, or the values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|S'_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), '-\nS_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), '|'], []), ') all indicate it is on the order of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup('-7')], []), ' or better,\nfar more precision than is actually needed. More details are given below.\nComputer calculations were ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('not')]), ' used in the determination of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), '\nin Theorem 5.\n \n\n\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Theorem 5.')]), ' ', '(a) ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('There is a unique\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cA'), '(1)'], []), '. Its modular data is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0\n', TexCmd('Hg'), '_1'], []), '.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), '(b) ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('There are precisely\n2 matrices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3)'], []), '. They are equivalent and realise ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_3'], []), '.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(c)')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('There are precisely 4 matrices  in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_5)'], []), '. \nThey are equivalent and realise ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_5'], []), '.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), '\n', TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(d)')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('There are precisely 6 matrices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_7)'], []), '. \nThey are equivalent and realise ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_7'], []), '.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(e)')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('There are precisely 12 matrices in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_9)'], []), '. They form\n2 equivalence classes and define inequivalent subfactors; one realises the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' matrix of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_9'], []), ', and the other\nrealises the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0,', '\\{', '5,17', '\\}'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_9'], []), ' ', '(defined in Section 3.3).')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), TexCmd('noindent', [BraceGroup('(f)')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3', TexCmd('times'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3)'], []), ' is empty.')]), '\n', '\n ', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof.')]), " Let's begin by identifying ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ' for these groups (done\nin ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3,', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_5'], []), '). It is trivial that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(1)=', '\\{', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '-2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '-1')]), ')\n', '\\}'], []), ', and for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ' and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_5'], []), ' ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.1')]), ' fixes everything in terms of complex numbers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a,b'], []), ',\n respectively:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['A(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3) =', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '-1')]), '(', TexNamedEnv('array', [TexCmd('delta'), '-2&\n-1&-1-1&-1&a-1&', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&-1'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), ')'), ' , \nA(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_5)=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '-1')]), '(', TexNamedEnv('array', [TexCmd('delta'), '-2&-1&-1&-1&-1\n-1&-1&a&b&a-1&', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&-1&b&b-1&', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('b')]), '&', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('b')]), '&-1&a-1&', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&\n', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('b')]), '&', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), '&-1'], [BraceGroup('ccccc')]), ')'), '\\,', '.', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\n For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3'], []), ', ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.5')]), ' forces  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a^2-a+', TexCmd('delta'), '=0'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t:=b+', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('c')]), '+', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('f')])], []), '. There are\n2 choices for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ', 2 for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ', and 3 for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), '. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '^', TexCmd('times'), '_9'], []), ' symmetry accounts\nfor this ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' ambiguity, leaving 2 inequivalent solutions.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Computation of  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3^2)'], []))]), '. \nWrite the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1,0)'], []), '-row of the matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('delta'), '-1)A(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3^2)'], []), '\nas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-1,-1,t,u,v,w,x,y,z)'], []), '. ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.7')]), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=h=(1,0)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=(0,1),(1,1)'], []), ' gives\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('u')]), '=x', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('v')]), '=z', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('w')]), '=:', TexCmd('delta'), ' a'], []), ' for some complex number ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['|a|=1'], []), '. \nFrom ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.7')]), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=(1,1),h=(1,0),k=(1,2)'], []), ' yields ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' t=xyz'], []), ', and applying the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3^2'], []), '-automorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', '(i,-j)'], []), ' to this we get ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' t=uvw'], []), '.\nComparing these gives ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a^3=1'], []), '.\n\nPutting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g=(0,1),h=(1,0)'], []), ' into ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.4')]), ' yields\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('z3z3')]), '\n1-', TexCmd('delta'), '=(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), 'u+a', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('u')]), '-1)(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), 'v+a', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('v')]), '-1)', '\\,', '.'], []), '\nHitting this with the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3^2'], []), '-automorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(i,j)', TexCmd('mapsto'), '(i+j,j)'], []), ' gives\nthe same equation with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' replacing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u'], []), '. Thus ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), 'u+a', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('u')]), '-1=', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('a')]), 'v+\na', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('v')]), '-1'], []), ' and ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('z3z3')]), ' says there is a real number whose square is negative.\nThis impossibility establishes part (f).\n\n', TexCmd('smallskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Determining the modular data.')]), ' Consider first ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ' and fix\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3)'], []), '.  Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l,C_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '^l'], []), ' be some solution to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), '. Then we learn\nfrom the above proof that any automorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Gal')]), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bbQ'))]), '/', TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('delta'))]), ')'], []), ' \ncorresponds to an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ell'), TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' in such a way that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), ' A_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '=A_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'), ' g,\n', TexCmd('ell'), ' h')], []), '.  Certainly ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' sends ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' to some other root of unity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma'))], []), '\nof the same order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ', and moreover ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '_l')]), '=', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma')))])], []), '\n', '(since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' commutes with complex conjugate in cyclotomic fields).\nHence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' sends the solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l,C_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '^l'], []), ' of ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' to\nanother solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma')), ',C^', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma')), '_', BraceGroup('g,h')], []), ' given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(C^l_', BraceGroup('g,h'), ')=\nC^', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ell'), ' g,', TexCmd('ell'), ' h')], []), '. Incidentally, ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.12')]), ' then implies the Galois\nactions \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('sigma'), '(S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'")), ')=S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma')), ',\n', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'", BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')))), '\\,', ', ', TexCmd('sigma'), '(T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup('l')), ')=\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma')), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup('l', BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')))), '\\,', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\n', '(the second equation is simply the statement ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('omega'), '_l=', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup('l^', TexCmd('sigma'))], []), '; to see\nthe first, compute instead ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('S')])], []), ').\nThis is stronger than the usual Galois action ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('galois')]), ' in modular data,\nthough of course it is compatible with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. \n\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '_', TexCmd('mu'))])], []), ', when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is coprime to the order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), '\n any automorphism in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('Gal')]), '(', TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '_d')]), '/', TexCmd('bbQ'), ')'], []), ' will lift to a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' \nfixing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' ', '(when gcd', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(d,', TexCmd('mu'), ')>1'], []), ', only half will).\nSo if ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' can be solved for a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), 'th root of unity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_l'], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '\ncoprime to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ', then it can be solved for ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('all')]), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), 'th roots of 1.\nThat is, we would have at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(d)'], []), ' solutions. As long as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), " doesn't\ndivide ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ', none of these are redundant. But Izumi tells us there are \nprecisely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' nonredundant (independent) solutions to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), '\n', '(corresponding to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' half-braidings, giving rise to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' primaries\nof type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'], []), ').\n\nHence any solution to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' involves ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(d)', TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ' ', '(for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' coprime to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ') or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(d)', TexCmd('le'), ' 2m'], []), ' ', '(otherwise).\nThere is thus a finite number of possibilities for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), '. A little\nthought reduces the number further --- e.g. when gcd', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(d,', TexCmd('mu'), ')=1'], []), ' it suffices\nto consider only ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l=', TexCmd('xi'), '_d'], []), '. We find that (for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3'], []), ')  only\n12 possibilities for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' need be considered, namely ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pm'), ' 1, ', TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('xi'), '_3,', TexCmd('i'), ',', TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('xi'), '_7,', TexCmd('pm'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '_9,\n', TexCmd('pm'), TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup('13'), ',-', TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup('13'), '^6'], []), '. To rule out these\npossibilities,  we compute\ndeterminants. In particular, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l', TexCmd('ne'), ' 1,', TexCmd('xi'), '_3'], []), ', we show that the linear system ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' \nis inconsistent by showing  the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('nu'), '^2+1)', TexCmd('times'), '(', TexCmd('nu'), '^2+1)'], []), ' augmented matrix (formed from \nthe coefficients and constant vector) has nonzero determinant. To show ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l=1'], []), '\n', '(respectively ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l=', TexCmd('xi'), '_3'], []), ') has at most 3 (resp. 1) independent solutions, we \ndeleted 3 (resp. 1) equations and 2 (resp. 0) variables from ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' so that the resulting\nreduced coefficient matrix has nonzero determinant.\nWe evaluated these determinants numerically using Maple. If some\ndeterminant was fairly close to 0, we found some Galois associate of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), '\nwith large determinant (i.e. of order 1 or higher). \n\n\nIn this way we show that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' must be one of the values ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('ml^2')], []), '. We can now\ndetermine the modular data, rigourously identifying it with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', as follows.  Numerically\ncompute the solution to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' and plug it into ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.12')]), ' to obtain \nan estimate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S'"], []), '. We find that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S'"], []), ' matches ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' to within ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-9')], []), ', well within\nthe 0.015 required by ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Sapprox')]), '.\n\nThis argument for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_5'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_7'], []), ' is identical. For them exactly 14 and 22, respectively,\nvalues of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' need to be considered. The error ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["|S'-S|"], []), ' is less than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-9')], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['5', TexCmd('times'), ' 10^', BraceGroup('-8')], []), ' respectively, again well within ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('Sapprox')]), '.\n\nThe modular data calculation for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_9'], []), ' is more complicated for two reasons, both\nrelated to the compositeness of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=5', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 17'], []), '. Fix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_9)'], []), ' ', '(the result for the\nother ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is automatic by Galois considerations). First, an automorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' will\npermute the entries of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' iff ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' fixes both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s=', TexCmd('Tr'), '\\,', 'b'], []), ' ', '(incidentally,\nGal', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup('s')]), '/', TexCmd('bbQ'), ')', TexCmd('cong'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2^2'], []), ', so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' lies in a cyclotomic\nextension of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbQ')], []), '). Hence potentially only 1/4 of Gal', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '_d')]), '/', TexCmd('bbQ'), ')'], []), ' \nlifts to such ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '. This means more possibilities for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l'], []), ' to be\neliminated (218 possibilities is overkill), and we find that the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' matrix for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' exactly matches\nthat of either ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_9'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0,', '\\{', '5,17', '\\}'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_9'], []), '. More significantly, because of equalities \nlike ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_1=', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup('16')], []), ", there won't always be unique solutions to ", TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ',\nand ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.12')]), ' is ambiguous. This means we cannot identify ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' without more work. \nQED', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nThe key difference between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_9'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3^2'], []), ' is the size of their automorphism\ngroups (6 vrs 48). Nonuniqueness for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_9'], []), ' arises because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=85'], []), ' is \ncomposite: more generally, where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k>1'], []), ' is the number of distinct prime divisors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ',\n there will be at least ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', BraceGroup('k', TexCmd('atop'), ' 2'), ')'], []), ' inequivalent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' and indeed\ninequivalent subfactors, realising the inequivalent modular data of type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0,P'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '\ndefined in Section 3.3.\n\n\nThis nonuniqueness of subfactors with identical principal graphs is not a \nsurprise: for a simple example,  the principal graph fails to uniquely\nidentify the subfactor even in index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<4'], []), ' ', BraceGroup('(two subfactors realise each of  the graphs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_6,E_8'], []), ' \nalthough one is the opposite of the other) whilst in index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), ' the affine graphs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('2n-5')], []), ' \nand its orbifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_n'], []), ' both have  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n-2'], []), ' inequivalent subfactors  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IK')]), '.'), '\n', '\n', '\nExact expressions for the matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ' appear in the proof of Theorem 5. \nNumerical estimates for these ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' may also be of interest. A convenient way to express\nthis, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' cyclic, is in terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j_2,j_3,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',j_', BraceGroup('n+1'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbR')], []), ': for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<g<h<', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' we have\n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['A_', BraceGroup('g,h'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'))])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '-1')]), TexCmd('exp', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('i'), '(j_h-j_g-j_', BraceGroup('h-g'), ')')]), '\\,', ','], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j_1=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j_', BraceGroup('n+1+i'), '=j_', BraceGroup('n+1'), '+j_n-j_', BraceGroup('n-i')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' i<n'], []), '\n', '(see Lemma 7.3 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ').\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nj_2^', BraceGroup('(3)'), TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', ' 1.292076', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '(j_2^', BraceGroup('(5)'), ',j_3^', BraceGroup('(5)'), ')', TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '(0.1846862,1.5984702)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '(j_2^', BraceGroup('(7)'), ',j_3^', BraceGroup('(7)'), ',j_4^', BraceGroup('(7)'), ')', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', '&', '\\,', '(2.471228,0.51685555,0.2137724)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '(j_2^', BraceGroup('(9)'), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',j_5^', BraceGroup('(9)'), ')', TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '\n', '(2.396976693,2.079251103,-0.2079168419,-2.508673987)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '(j_2^', BraceGroup('(9)', TexCmd('prime')), ',', TexCmd('ldots'), ',j_5^', BraceGroup('(9)', TexCmd('prime')), ')', TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '\n', '(-2.364737070,1.031057162,1.569692175,0.3383837765)', '\\,', '.', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(9)')], []), ' corresponds to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_9'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(9)', TexCmd('prime'))], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0,', '\\{', '5,17', '\\}'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_9'], []), '.\n\nIt should be possible to identify ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ' for the next couple\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), "'s, using the method of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=9'], []), ' described in the proof. To probe the answer, we\nused Maple to obtain numerical solutions to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.1')]), '-', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.5')]), ". \nWe don't have any proof that these correspond to actual solutions (although the numerics\nare convincing), and we certainly have no proof that there are no other solutions\nfor these ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), '. \nThe inequivalent numerical solutions we obtained for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K=', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['11', TexCmd('le'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('le'), ' 19'], []), ', are: \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nj^', BraceGroup('(11)'), TexCmd('approx'), ' ', '&', '\\,', '(0.9996507,2.7258434,-0.5714203,-1.7797340,\n1.2675985)', '\\,', ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nj^', BraceGroup('(11)', TexCmd('prime')), TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '(-2.6444397,-1.7629598,-2.6444440,\n2.7572657,0.1128260)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nj^', BraceGroup('(13)'), TexCmd('approx'), ' ', '&', '\\,', '( -3.1050384,0.5993399,-0.111708,\n-0.969766,1.336848,1.00483129)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nj^', BraceGroup('(15)'), TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '(-1.0777623,-.7748018,-2.171863,-1.6068402,-.257508,2.092502,.72289565)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nj^', BraceGroup('(17)'), TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '(-1.466074,.291489,3.130735,-2.693185,1.398153,-.611938,-1.667078,-1.754821)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nj^', BraceGroup('(19)'), TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '(-2.677465,1.088972,-.899442,.015448,-1.240928,-.493394,1.839879,', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('qquad'), ' -1.525884,-2.084374)', '\\,', ';', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nj^', BraceGroup('(19)', TexCmd('prime')), TexCmd('approx'), '&', '\\,', '( .896858,-.882585,-2.369855,-1.873294,-1.711620,-.119360,2.972018,', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('qquad'), '-2.460652,.041334)', '\\,', '. ', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\n', '\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=13,15,17'], []), ' respectively, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=173,229,293'], []), ' is prime. In these cases, choosing\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l=', TexCmd('xi'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('ml^2')], []), ' yields a unique solution to ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' ', '(according to Maple)\nand plugging into ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.12')]), ' yields a very close approximation (of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['10^', BraceGroup('-6')], []), ' or so)\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["S'"], []), ' to the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' matrix of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. With high confidence we can expect ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('nu'), ')')], []), '\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=13,15,17'], []), ' to describe a subfactor of Izumi type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' realising the modular\ndata ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=11,19'], []), ' respectively, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=5^3,5', TexCmd('cdot'), ' 73'], []), ' are composite and the situation is\nmore subtle. We find (up to the numerical accuracy of Maple) that for these ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('nu'), ')')], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_l=', TexCmd('xi'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup('ml^2')], []), ' in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.10')]), ' yields the correct multiplicity of solutions, and thus\nthe corresponding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' matrix agrees with that of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. Likewise, the solution\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(19)', TexCmd('prime'))], []), ' corresponds to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0,', '\\{', '5,73', '\\}'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', BraceGroup('19')], []), '. As with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=9'], []), ', the\nexistence of  higher multiplicities means we cannot determine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' unambiguously from\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.12')]), ' for these 3 ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), 's. We expect ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(11)'), ',j^', BraceGroup('(19)'), ',j^', BraceGroup('(19)', TexCmd('prime'))], []), ' to correspond\nto actual solutions of ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.1')]), '-', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('7.5')]), ', hence subfactors of Izumi type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup('11'), ',', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup('19'), ',\n', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup('19')], []), ' respectively, with modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', BraceGroup('11'), ',', TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', BraceGroup('19'), ',', TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0,', '\\{', '5,73', '\\}'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', BraceGroup('19')], []), '\nresp.\n\nThe only unexpected solution here is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(11)', TexCmd('prime'))], []), '. Following the method described in\nthe proof of Theorem 5, we obtain the corresponding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' matrix: for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1', TexCmd('le'), ' l', TexCmd('le'), ' m'], []), ',\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'), '=', '\\{', TexNamedEnv('array', [TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('ml^2'), '& ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('if')]), ' 5|l', TexCmd('cr'), '\n', TexCmd('xi'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup('5ml^2'), '& ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('otherwise')])], [BraceGroup('cc')]), '.', '\\,', '.'], []), '\nAs before, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' is not uniquely determined by ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('8.12')]), '. We do not have a guess for\nwhat this ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' matrix is, though its entries ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_', BraceGroup("l'"))], []), '\nshould lie in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbQ', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('cos'), '(2', TexCmd('pi'), '/25)')])], []), '. Just as extra solutions like ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(9)', TexCmd('prime')), '\n,j^', BraceGroup('(19)', TexCmd('prime'))], []), ' occur whenever ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('distinct')]), ' primes divide ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ', we would expect\nthat solutions like ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(11)', TexCmd('prime'))], []), ' occur whenever a nontrivial prime power \ndivides ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), '.\n\nOn the basis of these observations, it is tempting to make the following conjecture.\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Conjecture 1.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('The modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('0,P'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' for any  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=2n+1'], []), ' and any set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' ', '(possibly empty) consisting of\nan even number of distinct prime divisors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ', is\nrealised by the even part of the quantum double of a subfactor of Izumi type\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. All ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ' should correspond to modular\ndata obeying ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=I'], []), '. ')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nWe expect ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l'), '^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('mu')), '=1'], []), ' for reasons clear from the proof of\nTheorem 5. Existence is accumulating suggesting that (up to equivalence) there is a unique\nmatrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('cA'), '(', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ')'], []), ', and a unique subfactor of Izumi type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', iff\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '=', TexCmd('nu'), '^2+4'], []), ' is prime. It would be interesting to see if  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ' can be\nnonempty when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' is not cyclic.\n\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Question 5.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Interpret the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' twist\nin ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '  in a von Neumann algebra\nformalism.')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), ' We would expect this to be in terms of twisted systems of endomorphisms, or\ntwisted fusion categories, as what happens for twisted doubles of\nfinite groups.\n\n\n \n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Principal graphs, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), "-induction etc for Izumi's subfactors")]), '\n', '\nConsider  a subfactor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N', TexCmd('subset'), ' M'], []), ' of Izumi type ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ', an abelian group of\nodd order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ', defined by some matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('cA'), '(K)'], []), ',  with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' systems ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), '\nrespectively. We argued last subsection that the modular data of\n the double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' is often (always?)\nthe untwisted Haagerup--Izumi modular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' or some \ngeneralisation thereof. Principal graphs for Izumi's ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_5'], []), ' subfactor')]), '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Theorem 6.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N', TexCmd('subset'), ' M'], []), ' be a subfactor of Izumi type\n ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' as above. TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['&&', '[', BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'), ' u_g'), ']', '[', TexCmd('rho'), ' u_h', ']', '=', '[', TexCmd('kappa'), "'", ']', '+', '[', TexCmd('kappa'), ' u_', TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Proof.')]), ' In Lemma 7.1 and Theorem 7.2 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ', we learn that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), '\ncontains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_g'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' u_g'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g', TexCmd('in'), ' K'], []), ', and the fusions\n', [BraceGroup('id')]), ']', '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('rho'), ' u_g')])], []), '.
