We obtain the fusion\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('kappa'), "' u_g", ']', '=', '[', TexCmd('kappa'), "'", ']'], []), ' from the calculation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('kappa'), "' u_g,", TexCmd('kappa'), "'", TexCmd('rangle'), '=\n', TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('kappa'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), '-1)u_g,', TexCmd('kappa'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), '-1)', TexCmd('rangle'), '=', TexCmd('langle'), '(', TexCmd('rho'), '^2-1)u_g,', TexCmd('rho'), '-1', TexCmd('rangle'), '\n=1'], []), '. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))]), ']', '[', TexCmd('kappa'), "'", ']'], []), ' has dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '^2(', TexCmd('delta'), '-1)=', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta')], []), ' so will\nequal the sum of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' sectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('rho'), ' u_g', ']'], []), ', perhaps with multiplicities, but ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-invariance\nnow forces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))]), ']', '[', TexCmd('kappa'), "'", ']', '=', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('rho'), ' u_g')])], []), '. As above we see that the\nonly sectors in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), '(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))]), TexCmd('kappa'), ')^k'], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('rho'), ' u_g', ']', ',', '[', TexCmd('kappa'), "'", ']'], []), ', so we\nhave exhausted all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' sectors, and obtain the given principal graph.\nAll remaining products are now easy to compute. For example, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'), "'")]), TexCmd('kappa'), "'"], []), '\nhas dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda'), '^2(', TexCmd('delta'), '-1)^2=', TexCmd('nu'), '+(', TexCmd('nu'), '-1)', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('delta')], []), ', so by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '-invariance this must\nbe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('u_g')]), '+(', TexCmd('nu'), '-1)', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('rho'), ' u_g')])], []), '.\n\nAt the end of Section 4 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz1')]), ' is explained how to recover the induction-restriction\n(i.e. dual principal) graph between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' sectors, from the structure of\nTube', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('Delta'), ')'], []), '. In particular, we obtain the dual principal graph directly from the half-braidings\nas described in Proposition 8.2 of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('iz3')]), ' --- for instance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' is read off from the \nhalf-braidings containing the identity. From the graph we read off the given alpha-inductions.\nQED', TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\nFrom this the dual principal\ngraph for the double ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' is the obvious analogue of the top graph of Figure 3.\nNote the resemblance between the fusions for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and the group algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbC'), ' D_K'], []), '\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_K=K', TexCmd('sdprod'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2'], []), ' acts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' by inverse. We also see \nthat the sectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'u_g', ']'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('rho'), ' u_g', ']'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('kappa'), ' u_g', ']'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('kappa'), "'", ']'], []), ' have \nstatistical dimensions \n1,  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('delta'), '-1)', TexCmd('lambda')], []), ' respectively. It is far from obvious (though\nof course an immediate  consequence of Theorem 6) that the map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' defined there\nis a ring homomorphism.\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Theorem 7.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('Assume the hypotheses and notation\nof Theorem 6. In addition, assume the fusions of the double system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Delta'), '=\n', '\\{', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('id')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('i,j'), ',', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_l', '\\}'], []), '\nagree with those of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', and that we have the canonical endomorphism\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])), '=1+', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), '+', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), '_i\n+', TexCmd('sum'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_', BraceGroup('h,0')], []), '. Then we can identify \nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), '-', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M'], []), ' system ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('id')]), ',a,b_i,c_i', '\\}', '_', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('in'), " K'")], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_i=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa')), '\nu_i', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))]), TexCmd('cong', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))]), 'u_', BraceGroup('-i'), TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))])], []), '. \nIts sectors obey the fusions  \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['&&', '[', 'a', ']', '^2=', '[', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('id')]), ']', '+', '[', 'a', ']', '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('b_i')]), '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('c_i')]), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('quad', [BracketGroup('a'), BracketGroup('b_i')]), '=', '[', 'a', ']', '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('b_k')]), '-', '[', 'b_i', ']', '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('c_k')]), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' ', '&&', '[', 'a', ']', '[', 'c_i', ']', '=', '[', 'a', ']', '+ ', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('b_k')]), '+ \n', '[', 'c_i', ']', '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('c_k')]), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('quad', [BracketGroup('b_i'), BracketGroup('c_j')]), '=', '[', 'a', ']', '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('b_k')]), '+', TexCmd('sum', [BracketGroup('c_k')]), '\\,', ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&&', '[', 'b_i', ']', '[', 'b_j', ']', '=\n', TexCmd('delta'), '_', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('langle', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('id')]))]), ',', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_0=', TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('L'), BraceGroup()]), '^', BraceGroup('(k)'), '_0=0'], []), '. \nThus (reordering the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'e_k', ']'], []), ' if necessary) \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('A')]), '=(0,s_1', '\\,', '(', TexCmd('nu'), '+t),', TexCmd('ldots'), ',s_', TexCmd('nu'), '\\,', '(', '\\{', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1', '\\}'], []), '  and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ')], []), '. This integer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' \nsatisfies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '^2=t^2+', TexCmd('nu'), '\\,', '(', TexCmd('nu'), '+t)^2'], []), ', so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t=-', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\nThis means that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'a', ']', ':=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), BracketGroup('A')])], []), ', and hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'b_i', ']', ':=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), BracketGroup('B_i')])], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'c_i', ']', ':=\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), BracketGroup('C_i')])], []), ', all being norm 1, are in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ", possibly up to signs. \nThat the signs are indeed all +1's follows by writing say ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('d')]), '_1', ']'], []), ' \nin terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'a', ']', ',', '[', 'b_i', ']', ',', '[', 'c_i', ']'], []), ': the coefficients should be nonnegative. \n\n\nThe fusions in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' now reduce to the fusions in the double. The dual\nprincipal graph and the two remaining products follow by arguments as in\nTheorem 6. QED\n\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), '\nThis guess for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))])], []), ' is the natural one, matching what happens for the\nHaagerup subfactor (recall Section 2.2) and what we know about monomial\nmodular invariants in Proposition 4, which appear to be severely constrained.\nThe only example we know violating the hypothesis on the fusions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('Delta')], []), '\nis the solution ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j^', BraceGroup('(11)', TexCmd('prime'))], []), ' of Section 4.1. \nThe noncommutativity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Delta')], []), ' and commutativity of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' arise because\nof the presence respectively absence of higher multiplicities in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' resp. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))])], []), '. \nThe generalisation of Figure 3  can be read off from the alpha-inductions\nlisted in the Theorem.\nThese imply the statistical dimensions  dim(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a)=', TexCmd('delta')], []), ', dim(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b_i)=', TexCmd('delta'), '-1'], []), ' and dim(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_j)=', TexCmd('delta'), '+1'], []), '.\n\n\nThe dihedral group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('K', TexCmd('sdprod'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2')], []), ' has one nontrivial 1-dimensional irrep and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' 2-dimensional\nirreps. But for the Haagerup considered in Section 2.2, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a'], []), ' corresponded to the  2-dimensional\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' the 1-dimensional irreps, so ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup('K', TexCmd('sdprod'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_2')])], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widehat', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Delta'))])], []), ' here are\nunrelated for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '>3'], []), ', even after projecting away the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_i'], []), "'s. \n\n\n\n\n\n", TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('VOAs for Haagerup-Izumi modular data')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n ', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The Haagerup-dihedral diamond')]), '\n', '\nIn Section 2.4 we saw ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg')], []), '\nas a mutation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' S_3'], []), ' and contained in a conformal subalgebra of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ';\nnow this becomes ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is a mutation of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), ' D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and is contained\nin a conformal subalgebra of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. The branching rules for this embedding\ncan be read off from the modular invariant ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('modinvDnuZnu')]), '.\nIn some ways (e.g. modular data) the Haagerup-Izumi\nclosely resembles its sibling the dihedral group, and in other ways (e.g.  VOA realisations) it more closely\nrelates to its parent the cyclic group.\n\nThe trivial case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_1'], []), ' is already interesting.\nIn ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ', its VOA can be realised as the tensor of the affine algebra VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(G_', BraceGroup('2,1'), ')'], []), ' ', '(which has\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=14/5'], []), '), with the affine algebra VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(F_', BraceGroup('4,1'), ')'], []), ' ', '(which has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=26/5'], []), '). (Hence\nthere is a VOA realisation for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), ' any positive multiple of 8, by tensoring\nby copies of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(E_8)'], []), '.) Call this ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(', TexCmd('Hg'), '_1^0)'], []), '.\nThe VOA corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_1'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ' of course must be ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(E_8)=\n', TexCmd('cV'), '(E_', BraceGroup('8,1'), ')'], []), ', and the containment corresponds to the conformal embedding\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('2,1'), 'F_', BraceGroup('4,1'), TexCmd('subset'), ' E_', BraceGroup('8,1')], []), '. The VOA corresponding to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), ' D_1'], []), ' is\nthe lattice VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(A_1 E_7)'], []), '. Although the latter is an orbifold of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(E_8)'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(G_', BraceGroup('2,1'), 'F_', BraceGroup('4,1'), ')'], []), ' cannot be, since its modular data is not that of\nthe (possibly twisted) quantum double of a finite group. This is an important lesson:\nwe cannot expect the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' VOAs to be orbifolds,\nby some subgroup of automorphisms, of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' VOAs.\nHence Question 3.\n\nAnother important observation from this trivial case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=1'], []), ' is that the intersection of\nthe holomorphic orbifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), ' D_1'], []), ' with the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=1'], []), ' Haagerup-Izumi VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(', TexCmd('Hg'), '_1^0)'], []), '\nis itself a rational VOA. In particular, there are conformal embeddings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(B_', BraceGroup('3,1'), '\nG_', BraceGroup('2,1'), ')', TexCmd('subset'), TexCmd('cV'), '( E_', BraceGroup('7,1'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(A_', BraceGroup('1,1'), 'B_', BraceGroup('3,1'), ')', TexCmd('subset'), TexCmd('cV'), '( F_', BraceGroup('4,1'), ')'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('SchWa')]), ', and so\nboth ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), ' D_1=', TexCmd('cV'), '(A_1 E_7)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(', TexCmd('Hg'), '_1^0)=', TexCmd('cV'), '(G_', BraceGroup('2,1'), 'F_', BraceGroup('4,1'), ')'], []), ' contain  copies\nof the rational VOA ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(A_', BraceGroup('1,1'), ' G_', BraceGroup('2,1'), 'B_', BraceGroup('3,1'), ')'], []), '. Thus in this baby example at\nleast, the dihedral and  Haagerup-Izumi VOAs are commensurable in this sense. \nIt is tempting to guess though that something similar happens for higher ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), '. This is what\nwe mean by the Haagerup-dihedral diamond: at the top is a VOA realising ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ',\nwhich contains as conformal subalgebras ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', BraceGroup('+,', TexCmd('omega')), 'D_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg')], []), ', and these\ncontain a common conformal subalgebra (the analogue of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(A_', BraceGroup('1,1'), ' G_', BraceGroup('2,1'), 'B_', BraceGroup('3,1'), ')'], []), ').\n\n\n', TexCmd('medskip'), TexCmd('noindent'), TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Conjecture 2.')]), ' ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('There is a rational VOA realisation of each\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' for any sufficiently large central charge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), '\na multiple of 8).')]), TexCmd('medskip'), '\n', '\n', '\nAs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' increases, we will not be able to realise all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' --- or even\nthe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' --- as conformal subalgebras of \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(E_', BraceGroup('8'), ')'], []), '. In other words, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c>8'], []), ' will sometimes be necessary.\nThis conjecture is open even for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=3'], []), '. To make it more plausible, and also to aid in the\nconstruction of the VOAs, in the following sections we supply all the information needed\nto identify the possible character vectors. We saw in Section 2.4 that the Haagerup VOA\nwould see the holomorphic orbifold by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ' more directly than that by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_3'], []), ', so for\nthis reason we also supply the relevant data for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), '.\n\nWe should repeat here the suggestion of Section 2.5 that a second approach to constructing \nVOAs realising ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('Hg'), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is to use the affine algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV'), '(B_', BraceGroup('m,2'), ')'], []), " in the\ncoset construction. For reasons of space, we haven't explored this in this paper.\n\n", TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Character vectors for the untwisted  Haagerup double')]), '\n', '\nIn this section we determine the matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('chi')], []), ' for the untwisted Haagerup\nmodular data ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_3'], []), ', at all allowed values of central charge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), ' ', '(i.e. when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['8|c'], []), ').\nAs explained in Section 1.4, from this all possible character vectors can be obtained. We \nillustrate this with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=16'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=24'], []), ' ', '(for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=8'], []), ' see Section 2.4).\n\n', TexCmd('subsubsection', [BraceGroup('Untwisted Haagerup at central charge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup('24'), '16'], []))]), '\n', '\nWe found ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ',', TexCmd('chi')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('Hg'), '_3'], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c', TexCmd('equiv'), '_', BraceGroup('24'), '8'], []), ' in Section 2.4. \nChanging the central charge by a multiple of 8 leaves ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ' unchanged but multiplies ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' by\nsome 3rd root ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' of 1. \nAt the end of Section 1.4 we explain how this affects ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ',', TexCmd('chi')], []), '.\nTaking the primaries in the usual order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')]), ';', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]), ';', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_0,\n', Any weakly\nholomorphic vector-valued modular function equals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Xi'), TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('P')]), '(J)'], []), ' for some polynomial\nvector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('P')])], []), '.\n\nSpecialise now to a VOA character vector at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=16'], []), '. '\n', '\nSince the Fourier coefficients of a VOA character vector are nonnegative\nintegers, we know each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e,g,h,j', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ge'), ' 0')], []), '.\nIn addition the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q^', BraceGroup('1/3')], []), '-coefficient of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]))], []), ' forces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', TexCmd('le'), ' 6'], []), ' and the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q^', BraceGroup('1/3')], []), '-coefficient of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', Other coefficients yield further bounds,\ne.g. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h', TexCmd('le'), ' 2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j', TexCmd('le'), ' 11'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g', TexCmd('le'), ' 16'], []), '.\n\nThere are several other constraints. One is that VOA characters are linear \ncombinations over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('ge'), ' 0')], []), '\nof the Virasoro characters  at that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c'], []), ' for various values of ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('conformal weight')]), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h'], []), ' ', '(because the VOA carries a Virasoro representation). \nAll these characters are well-known: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup('(16,0)'), '=q^', BraceGroup('-2/3'), '(1+\nq^2+q^3+2q^4+', TexCmd('cdots'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_', BraceGroup('(24,h)'), '=q^', BraceGroup('h-2/3'), '(1+q+2q^2+3q^3+5q^4+', TexCmd('cdots'), ')'], []), ' for \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['h>0'], []), ". This isn't so useful here, but it is effective for the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=24'], []), ' case considered next.\n\nMore important,\nDong-Mason ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('DM')]), ' prove that the conformal weight 1 part of a rational VOA\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), ' is a reductive Lie algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('oplus'), '_i', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_i'], []), ' of central charge \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sum'), '_ik_i', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('dim')]), '\\,', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_i/(k_i+h^', TexCmd('vee'), '_i)', TexCmd('le'), ' c'], []), ' and dimension equal to the coefficient of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q^', BraceGroup('1-c/24')], []), ' in\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_0'], []), '. This gives a finite set of possible values for that coefficient, and knowing this\nreductive Lie algebra helps in constructing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), '. Each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), '-module is also a module for the\ncorresponding affine Lie algebra, so the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cV')], []), "-characters are linear combinations of \nthe affine characters. \n\nThis is as far as we'll carry the analysis here.\n\nThe matrices ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ',', TexCmd('chi')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ', with primaries in the order \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(00),(01)=(02),(10)=(20),(11)=(22),(12)=(21)'], []), ' are\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '=', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '(1/3,1/3,1/3,2/3,0)'], []), ' and \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('chi'), '= ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('array', [' 172 & 324&324& 54&1458\n162& 334 & -162 & -27 & -729 \n162 & -162 & 334& -27& -729\n1215& -1215 &-1215 & -76&17496\n 9 & -9 & -9 & 6 & -12'], [BraceGroup('ccccc')]), ')'), '\\,', '.', TexCmd('nonumber')], []), '\nAt ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=16'], []), ' there is only one free parameter, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ': the possible character vectors are\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['=\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('matrix', ['  q^', BraceGroup('-2/3'), '(1+ (172 + 54 d)q + (23258 + 1188 d) q^2 +', TexCmd('cdots'), ')\nq^', BraceGroup('1/3'), '((162 - '+(8748-76f+2430e)q^', BraceGroup('2/3'), '+(1743039-1384f+159408e)q^', BraceGroup('5/3'), '+', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n', TexCmd('cr'), ' g q^', BraceGroup('-7/13'), '+(1716-252g -176i+134k+100l-5h+176j)q^', BraceGroup('6/13'), '+', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n', TexCmd('cr'), ' hq^', BraceGroup('-2/13'), '+(22451+8h+2464j+16556i-385l-96k-980g)q^', BraceGroup('11/13'), '+', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n', TexCmd('cr'), ' iq^', BraceGroup('-11/13'), '+(104+44i-15k+5h-56j+20l)q^', BraceGroup('2/13'), '+', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n', TexCmd('cr'), ' jq^', BraceGroup('-8/13'), '+(910-32j-34l-847i+77g+8h+120k)q^', BraceGroup('5/13'), '+', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n', TexCmd('cr'), ' kq^', BraceGroup('-6/13'), '+(3003+704j-1540i+55l-216k+330g)q^', BraceGroup('7/13'), '+', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n', TexCmd('cr'), ' lq^', BraceGroup('-5/13'), '+(5200-20l+3388i+616g-14h+132k-595j)q^', BraceGroup('8/13'), '+', TexCmd('cdots')], []), ')')], []), '\nfor certain nonnegative integers ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c,d,e,f,g,h,i,j,k,l'], []), '. By the usual arguments we find a\nfinite number of possibilities. \nLikewise the matrices for \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('cD'), '^0', TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '=', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('diag')]), '(0,1,1,1/3,2/3)'], []), ' and \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', [TexCmd('chi'), '= ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('scriptsize'), '(', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n-12&1&1&36&12 65610&0&0&-5832&-243 65610&0&0&-5832&-243 729&0&0&-152&\n54 8748&0&0&2430&-76'], [BraceGroup('ccccc')]), ')')], []), '\nand we find a character vector depending on 4 bounded nonnegative integers. \n\nThe most intriguing possibility is if these Haagerup and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bbZ'), '_3'], []), ' VOAs are \nboth subVOAs of the\nMoonshine module. It is tempting to guess that this is the most natural\nhome of the Haagerup. Then the character ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J'], []), ' of the Moonshine module will\nequal one of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+2ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')]))], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+2ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]))], []), ', or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ch_0+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('b')])), '+ch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('a')])), '+\nch_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('c')]), '_0')], []), ', and we find that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(c,d,f)'], []), ' is either (12,0,0), (0,12,0)\nor (0,0,1), and that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(g,h,j,k,l)'], []), ' is either (1,2,0,0,0), (0,1,1,0,0), (0,2,0,1,0)\nor (0,1,0,0,1), and all other parameters vanish.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Character vectors of the  twisted  Haagerup double')]), '\n', '\n', '\nThe modular group representation for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('ne'), ' 0'], []), ' twist of the Haagerup decomposes into\na sum of 3 irreps: the trivial one, a 4-dimensional one\nwith kernel ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '(9)'], []), ', and a 7-dimensional one with kernel ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '(13)'], []), '.\nOnly the 4-dimensional irrep is new: it is handled by e.g. the root lattice ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_8'], []), '.\nActually, 6 different 4-dimensional irreps arise here, varying with the twist and central\ncharge mod 24, but they are all obtained from the one in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_8'], []), ' by some combination of\n3rd roots of unity and taking the contragredient. The effects on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ',', TexCmd('chi')], []), ' of both of\nthese is discussed at the end of Section 1.4.\n\n', TexCmd('subsubsection', [BraceGroup('The 1-twisted Amer. Math. Soc. ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('9')]), ', 237--302 (1996). \n\n'], []), '\n', '\n'], [BraceGroup('99')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('end', [BraceGroup('document')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\nThe multi-set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Z)'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',d', '\\}'], []), ' occurs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('ii')], []), ' times,\nis called the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('exponent')]), ' of the modular invariant.\n\nDefinition: A ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('nimrep')]), ' is a representation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i', TexCmd('mapsto', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_i'], []), ' of the fusion ring by nonnegative integer matrices:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nimrep'), BraceGroup('G')]), '_i', BraceGroup('G'), '_j=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^d N_', BraceGroup('ij'), '^k', BraceGroup('G'), '_k'], []), '\nIn addition, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('G'), '_1=I'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('G'), '_', BraceGroup('Ci'), '=', BraceGroup('G'), '_i^T'], []), '.\n\nThese matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('G'), '_i'], []), ' will be normal and mutually commute, so therefore can\nbe simultaneously diagonalised:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nimreppsi'), BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup('ia'), '^b=', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('e'), TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('ae'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('ie')), BraceGroup('S_', BraceGroup('1e'))]), TexCmd('psi'), '_', BraceGroup('be'), '^*'], []), '\nfor some unitary matrix ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi')], []), '. The multi-set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(', BraceGroup('G'), ')'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',d', '\\}'], []), ' occurring in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nimreppsi')]), ') is called the ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('exponent')]), ' of the nimrep.\nWe say that modular invariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' and nimrep ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('G')], []), ' are compatible if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(Z)=', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('E')]), '(', BraceGroup('G'), ')'], []), ';\nwe say ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z'], []), ' is ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('nimble')]), ' if there is a nimrep compatible with it,\notherwise we say it is ', TexCmd('textit', [BraceGroup('nimless')]), '.\n\nFor example, the fusion matrices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(N_i)_', BraceGroup('jk'), '=N_', BraceGroup('ij'), '^k'], []), ' define a nimrep with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '=S'], []), ' and\nexponents ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', '1,', TexCmd('ldots'), ',d', '\\}'], []), '; it is compatible with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z=I'], []), '.\n\n-------------\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray*', ['\nZ_1&=&', TexCmd('sum'), '|', TexCmd('chi'), '_i|^2\nZ_2&=&|', TexCmd('chi'), '_0+', TexCmd('chi'), '_1|^2+2|', TexCmd('chi'), '_2|^2+2|', TexCmd('chi'), '_3|^2+2|', TexCmd('chi'), '_4|^2+2|', TexCmd('chi'), '_5|^2\nZ_3&=&|', TexCmd('chi'), '_0+', TexCmd('chi'), '_2|^2+(', TexCmd('chi'), '_1+', TexCmd('chi'), '_2)', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '_7+', TexCmd('chi'), '_7(', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '_1+', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('chi'))]), '_2)+|', TexCmd('chi'), '_6|^2\nZ_4&=&|', TexCmd('chi'), '_0+', TexCmd('chi'), '_2+', TexCmd('chi'), '_7|^2\nZ_5&=&|', TexCmd('chi'), '_0+', TexCmd('chi'), '_2|^2+|', TexCmd('chi'), '_1+', TexCmd('chi'), '_2|^2+|', BraceGroup('lon2'), '.<br>Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' infinite factors. We denote by<br>', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Mor'), '(A,B)'], []), ' the set\n of unital ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('ast')], []), '-homomorphisms from<br>', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Mor'), '(A,B)'], []), ' we d\nefine the statistical<br>dimension ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d_', TexCmd('rho'), '=', '[', 'B:', TexCmd('rho'), '(A)', ']', '^', BraceGroup('1/2')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'B:', TexCmd('rho'), '(A\n)', ']'], []), ' is the<br>minimal index ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('jon,kosa')]), '. A morphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('Mor'), '(A,B)'], []), ' is<b\nr>called irreducible if the subfactor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '(A)', TexCmd('subset'), ' B'], []), ' is<br>irreducible, i.e\n. if the relative commutant<br>', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), "(A)'", TexCmd('cap'), ' B'], []), ' consists only of scalar multip\nles of<br>the identity in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '. For any tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('ab')], []), ' we define the symmetric part ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('(ab)'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', ' ', '(F_', BraceGroup('ab'), ' + F_', BraceGroup('ba'), ') '], []), ' and the anti-symmetric part ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('[', 'ab', ']'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '( F_', BraceGroup('ab'), ' - F_', BraceGroup('ba'), ')'], []), ' respectively. Moreover we indicate with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' D'), ' '], []), ' the velocity projected covariant derivative: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' D'), '  ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), '.\n\nAs mentioned above, the conservation equation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cons-hydr')]), ') can be used to simplify the expression of the first order stress tensor. Useful relations can be derived projecting  the conservation equation, along the velocity field and transversally\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('iden')]), '\nu^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ')_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('ideal')])), ' ', '&=& 0 ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Longrightarrow')), '\\;', '\\;', ' \n', '(', TexCmd('rho'), ' + p)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' + u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ' =0  \n', TexCmd('qquad'), ' P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ')_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('ideal')])), ' ', '&=& 0 ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Longrightarrow')), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', ' P_', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('mu')), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' P + (', TexCmd('rho'), '+p)', '\\,', ' P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '\\,', 'u^', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ' =0  . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n'], []), '\t\nGiven the identities (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('iden')]), ') that we derived, it is possible in the definition of dissipative terms for the stress-tensor to take into account for only symmetric two tensors built from the  velocity gradients. Using  the Landau frame condition, one is able to single out two candidate dissipative terms: \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('Pi'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '_', BraceGroup('(1)'), ' = -2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' - ', TexCmd('zeta'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('theta'), '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  ,\n'], []), '\t\nthat appear associated with two new parameters the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' shear viscosity'), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ', and the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' bulk viscosity'), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zeta')], []), '. \n\nIn the same way, it is possible spoiling the conservation of charge current to simplify the search for new terms. In particular it is possible to use the conservation equations to eliminate the acceleration term, limiting the new contribution to ones which are first order in the derivatives of the thermodynamic variables ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['q_I'], []), ' and also the velocity field. Another potential contribution arises from the  pseudo-vector  \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('ell'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('5.5mm')]), TexCmd('mu')), ' ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('alpha'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^', TexCmd('beta'), ' u^', TexCmd('gamma'), ' .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('elle')]), '\n'], []), '\t\nThis possible term will be responsible for mixing contributions with different parity structure at first order', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('This kind of contribution for charge current appears in fluid dynamics derived from the AdS/CFT correspondence for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' N'), ' =4'], []), ' Super Yang-Mills fluid and is linked to Chern-Simons couplings of the bulk gauge field in the gravitational description ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Erdmenger:2008rm, Banerjee:2008th')]), '.')]), '. \n\nThe new terms, at first order, for the charge current are\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('Upsilon'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('(1)I'), ' = -', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('varkappa'))]), '_', BraceGroup('IJ'), ' ', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' q_J - ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'))]), '_I', '\\,', '  P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ' - ', TexCmd('mho'), '_I', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('ell'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '  , \n'], []), '\t\nwhere  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('varkappa'))]), '_', BraceGroup('IJ')], []), ' is the matrix of charge diffusion coefficients, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'))]), '_I'], []), ' indicates the contribution of the energy density to the charge current, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mho'), '_I'], []), ' which are the pseudo-vector transport coefficients. in terms of the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' and of the chemical potential ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_I'], []), ', the current reads \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('Upsilon'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('(1)I'), ' = -', TexCmd('varkappa'), '_', BraceGroup('IJ'), ' ', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_J'), BraceGroup('T')]), ') - ', TexCmd('mho'), '_I', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('ell'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_I', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '\\,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' T  .\n'], []), '\t\n', '\n', '\nSumming up, the stress tensor and the current of charge for a dissipative fluid at leading order in gradient expansion are\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '&=& ', TexCmd('rho'), '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ' + p', '\\,', '(g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ')  -2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' - ', TexCmd('zeta'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('theta'), '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ,  ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nJ^', TexCmd('mu'), '_I &=& q_I ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' -', TexCmd('varkappa'), '_', BraceGroup('IJ'), ' ', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_J'), BraceGroup('T')]), ') -  ', TexCmd('mho'), '_I', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('ell'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_I', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '\\,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' T  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dissipative fluid')]), '\n'], []), '\t\nwhere the set of transport coefficients ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('eta'), ', ', TexCmd('zeta'), ', ', TexCmd('varkappa'), '_', BraceGroup('IJ'), ', ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_I, ', TexCmd('mho'), '_I', '\\}'], []), " are to be determined to completely specify the relativistic viscous fluid. In principle transport coefficients  can be worked out from the fundamental QFT underlying the fluid dynamic description.\n\n\nThe dissipative fluid's entropy is not conserved, therefore the second law implies that the entropy current should have non-negative divergence, ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' J^', TexCmd('mu'), '_S ', TexCmd('ge'), ' 0  .\n'], []), '\t\n', '\nIn principle,  the discussion can be extended to determine higher order terms in derivative expansion. However, usually these terms are irrelevant in the hydrodynamic regime. Indeed, these terms are less and less important moving towards longer wavelengths and are therefore suppressed in low energy description. On the contrary terms at first order are important since their presence defines a channel for the fluid to relax back to equilibrium after a perturbation.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conformal hydrodynamics')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('confluid')]), '\n', '\n', '\nIn this section we will introduce conformal fluids, that can be thought of as the low energy macroscopic description of field theories which are conformally invariant. We will start by discussing the restriction on first order terms in the derivative expansion of the stress-tensor for a generic dissipative fluid arising from the requirement of conformal invariance. In the next section, we will review the useful Weyl covariant formalism ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Loganayagam:2008is')]), ', before singling out operators at second order that can appear in conformal hydrodynamics. This discussion is motived by the construction of gravitational duals to hydrodynamics that will be the topic of the next chapter.\n\nHaving in mind a relativistic fluid on a background manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' B'), '_d'], []), ' with metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', we can consider a Weyl transformation of the metric \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '\n  g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-2', TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('wtr')]), '\n'], []), '\nRemembering that the velocity field is normalised as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', 'u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' = -1'], []), ', it will scale under a Weyl transformation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('wtr')]), ') as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '  .\n'], []), '\t\nCombining these facts one finds thate the spatial projector also transforms homogeneously\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nP^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '+u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '=e^', BraceGroup('-2', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('P')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nA generic tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_1 ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', TexCmd('mu'), '_n'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), '_1 ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), '_m')], []), ' is said to be conformally invariant if it transforms homogeneously under Weyl rescalings of the metric  (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('wtr')]), ') , i.e., \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' = e^', BraceGroup('-w', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q'))]), '  ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' is called ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' conformal weight of the tensor'), ' and depends on the index positions. To have a proper conformally invariant operator in the theory, it is also necessary that the dynamical equations for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q')], []), ' remain invariant under conformal transformations.\n\nNow we can address the question about additional constraints on the stress tensor, at first order, due to conformal invariance. From the conservation equations for the energy-momentum tensor (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cons-hydr')]), '), one finds that it transforms homogeneously under \nWeyl rescalings of the metric with weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d+2'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-(d+2) ', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' T'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Wtrstrsstensor')]), '\n'], []), '\t\nprovided that its trace is zero ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', TexCmd('mu')), ' = 0'], []), '.\n\nThe null trace condition implies for an ideal fluid that \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', TexCmd('mu'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' =0 ', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('Longrightarrow'), ' ', '\\;', '\\;', ' ', '\\;', '\\;', ' p = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('rho'), '  .\n'], []), '\t\nThis relation between pressure and energy density fixes the speed of sound in conformal fluids as a function of the spacetime dimension: \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['c_s = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('d-1')]))]), ' .'], []), '\n', '\nThe charge current transforms homogeneously with weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' under conformal transformations, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nJ^', TexCmd('mu'), '= e^', BraceGroup('-d ', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' J'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '  . \n'], []), '\t\n', '\nThe last pieces to recollect are the scaling dimensions of the thermodynamic variables. It is possible to see that the temperature  scales under a Weyl transformation with weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT  = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '  ,\n'], []), '\nand this implies from the thermodynamic Gibbs-Duhem relation, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p+', TexCmd('rho'), ' = s', '\\,', ' T + ', TexCmd('mu'), '_I', '\\,', ' q_I'], []), ', that the chemical potentials ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_I'], []), ' also have weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '. Moreover from eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Wtrstrsstensor')]), ') it follows that the energy density transforms under a Weyl transformation as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), '  = e^', BraceGroup('-d ', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'))]), '  .\n'], []), '\t\n', '\nUsing the properties of transformation listed above, one is lead to the following expression for the stress tensor of an ideal fluid\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '(T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ')_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('ideal')])), ' = ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' T^d', '\\,', ' ', '(g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + d ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), '  u^', TexCmd('nu'), ')  , \n'], []), '\t\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' is a dimensionless normalization constant fixed by the underlying microscopic conformal field theory.\n\nThe next step is to discuss dissipative corrections at first order to the ideal fluid stress tensor. The most convenient approach, is to single out all of the operators at order one in the derivative expansion with the right symmetries transforming homogeneously under conformal transformations. With a bit of work, it is possible to show that the covariant derivative of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))], []), ' transforms inhomogeneously, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '=', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '+', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('lambda')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '\\,', ' u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), '\n  =e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', '[', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nabla'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '+', TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), TexCmd('phi'), '- ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('lambda')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('sigma')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), TexCmd('phi'), ']', '  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('covderivtrans')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere it is useful as an intermediate result that the Christoffel symbols transform as \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '= ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), TexCmd('phi'), '+ ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('phi'), '- ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('sigma')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), TexCmd('phi'), ' .\n'], []), '\n', '\nFrom eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('covderivtrans')]), ') it is possible to obtain the transformation laws of fluid dynamical quantities\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '&', TexCmd('theta'), ' = ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '\n  =e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), TexCmd('nabla')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' u'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '+(d-1)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), TexCmd('phi'), ') = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', '(', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('theta'))]), ' + (d-1)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' D'))]), ' ', TexCmd('phi'), ' ', ')  , ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '& a^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '= ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' D'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ' = u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '\n  =e^', BraceGroup('-2', TexCmd('phi')), '(', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('a')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '+', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('P')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('sigma')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), TexCmd('phi'), '), ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '& ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '(', TexCmd('mu')), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ')'), '   - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), ' ', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '\\,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), ' \n= e^', BraceGroup('-3', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '& ', TexCmd('l'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ' =  u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), '\\,', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('mu')), '\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-2 ', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' ', TexCmd('l'), '^', TexCmd('mu')), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('transdyquant')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn the last equation one uses the fact that all epsilon symbols should be treated as tensor densities in curved space', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('It is possible to show ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Weinberg')]), ' that the epsilon symbols scale as metric determinants ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), ',    ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta')), '  ', TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('-g')])], []), ', and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta')), TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('-g')]))])], []), '. Therefore the correct scaling behavior  under conformal transformations will be ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\;', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' ', TexCmd('epsilon')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'))], []), ' and  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-4', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\;', '  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde'), ' ', TexCmd('epsilon')), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta'))], []), '.')]), '.\n\n\nFrom eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('transdyquant')]), ') we can deduce the restrictions that one must impose on a conformal dissipative fluid at first order. Since  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' ', '(and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ') transform  inhomogeneously under Weyl transformations, the bulk viscosity should vanish for a conformal fluid ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zeta'), ' = 0'], []), '. With the same procedure, for the charge current, it turns out that the contribution from the chemical potential and temperature should appear in the combination ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_I/T'], []), '. Moreover since the gradient of the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '\\,', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' T'], []), ' transforms inhomogeneously, the coefficient of the term in which it appears will be zero ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_I = 0'], []), '.\n\nSumming up, one finds that the stress tensor and the charge current, at first order, for a viscous fluid are\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '&=& ', TexCmd('alpha'), '\\,', ' T^d ', '\\,', ' ', '(g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' +d', '\\,', '  u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ')  -2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '  ,  ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nJ^', TexCmd('mu'), '_I &=& q_I ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' -', TexCmd('varkappa'), '_', BraceGroup('IJ'), ' ', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_J'), BraceGroup('T')]), ') -  ', TexCmd('mho'), '_I', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('ell'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '  ,\n'], []), '\t\nwhere we have used the generalized Stefan-Boltzmann expression for the pressure. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Weyl covariant formulation of conformal hydrodynamics')]), '\n', '\nThe Weyl covariant formulation of conformal hydrodynamics is a quite powerful tool to explore second order corrections to the stress tensor ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Loganayagam:2008is')]), '. \n\nOn the conformal class of metrics ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' C')], []), ', defined on  the background manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' B'), '_d'], []), ', it is possible to define a derivative operator that transforms covariantly under Weyl transformations. Let us start by defining a torsionless connection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Weyl')]))], []), ', called the Weyl connection, such that  for every metric in the conformal class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' C')], []), ' there exists a connection one-form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' for which\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Weyl')])), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '  = 2 ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', 'g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('wcmet')]), '\n'], []), '\t\nIt is possible to define a  Weyl covariant derivative  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Weyl')])), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' + w ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('wderiv')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '\nor in a more explicit form\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['_', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('cdots')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots')), ' ', '&', TexCmd('equiv'), '& ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('cdots')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots')), ' + w', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('cdots')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots')), TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&&  +( g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('alpha')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', '\\,', '  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('cdots')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots')), ' + ', TexCmd('cdots'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&&- ( g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('nu')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ') ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('cdots')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots')), ' -', TexCmd('cdots'), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('wderiv2')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '\t\nThe Weyl covariant derivative  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' transforms in a covariant way under conformal transformations, when acting on a conformally invariant tensor. In particular \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('cdots')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots')), ' = \n e^', BraceGroup('-w', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' Q'))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('cdots')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('cdots')), '  ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '\nin other words, the Weyl covariant derivative of a conformally invariant tensor transforms homogeneously with the same weight as the tensor itself.\n\nFrom the definition, it follows that the Weyl connection is  metric compatible \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = 0  ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '\nsince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=-2'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), '.\n\nRequiring that the new derivative of the fluid velocity is transverse and traceless\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nu^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' = 0  .\n'], []), '\t\nthe connection one-form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is uniquely determined as \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', TexCmd('mu'), ' = u^', TexCmd('lambda'), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), '  ', '\\,', ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' \n', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' a_', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' ', '\\,', ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), '    .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('wconn')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A')]), '\t\n', '\nOnce the Weyl covariant derivative has been defined, one is lead to define an associated curvature as the commutator between two covariant derivatives. In this case, the standard procedure, can be followed keeping in mind some subtleties that we are going to describe.  For a given covariant vector field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V_', TexCmd('mu'), '=e^', BraceGroup('-w', TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' '], []), ', it is possible to define a Weyl-invariant Riemann curvature tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexNamedEnv('equation', ['V_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' = w ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('F')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' V_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' - ', TexCmd('mathcal', TexCmd('mu', [BracketGroup(BraceGroup('g'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('nu')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('A')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '  - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), TexCmd('mathcal', BraceGroup('-2', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R'))]), '  .\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R')]), '\n', '\nA general class of tensor that appears in the study of conformal manifolds, are the  the Weyl-covariant tensors that are independent of the background fluid velocity. A relevant example of this class of operators is the Weyl curvature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma'))], []), ', that can be defined as the trace free part of the Riemann tensor. ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' C'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma')), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Weyltensor')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' C')]), '\nwhere we introduced ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' S'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ',  the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' Schouten tensor'), ', defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-2')]), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R'), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))), BraceGroup('2(d-1)')]), ') ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \n', '&= S_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '-(', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' -
