(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Weyltensor')]), ') is a conformal tensor. Moreover, it turns out that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma'))], []), ' has the same symmetry properties as the Riemann Tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma'))], []), ', ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nC_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma')), ' = -C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma')), ' ', '&= -C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('lambda')), '=C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' \nC_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup(), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '& =0  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('proprC')]), '\n'], []), '\nFrom equation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('proprC')]), '), it follows that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', 'u^', TexCmd('alpha'), '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('beta')], []), ' is a symmetric traceless and transverse tensor.\n\nGiven the Schouten and the Weyl curvature tensors, one can recast other curvature tensors in terms of these new tensors:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma')), '&=', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('C')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('sigma')), ' -', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', BraceGroup('[', TexCmd('mu')), 'g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ']', '[', TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), ']'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ', \n ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R'), ' ', '&= 2(d-1)', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup()]), '^', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '&= (d-2) ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup()]), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' R')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Conformal dissipative fluids')]), '\n', '\nNow we can use the Weyl covariant formalism to provide a classification, up to the second order in the derivative expansion, of the operators that could appear in the stress tensor of a conformal dissipative fluid. Second order term will be relevant in the discussion of holographic duals of conformal fluids.\n\nLet us start by writing the conservation equations for the stress tensor in terms of  the new covariant derivative, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&=& ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' +w ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + \n( g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', ') ', '\\,', ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', '\\,', '& +  (g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '^', TexCmd('nu'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('nu'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), '^', TexCmd('nu'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ') ', '\\,', ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&=& ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '+ (w -d -2)', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' - ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '^', TexCmd('nu'), '\\,', ' T^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', TexCmd('mu')), '\n', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&=& ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '    ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '\t\nwhere inhomogeneous terms cancel out, remembering that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', TexCmd('mu')), '=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w=d+2'], []), '. In the presence of a conformal anomaly, that can be present for \nCFTs on curved manifolds in even spacetime dimensions, the dynamical equation for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' spells out\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = \n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A'), '^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', '(T^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', TexCmd('mu')), ' - W ) =0  ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['W'], []), ' is the trace anomaly.\n\nGiven the definition of the Weyl covariant derivative, it is possible also to rewrite the building blocks of the stress tensor at first order in the covariant formulation \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '^', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('mu')), ' u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ')'), '  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' \n', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '^', BraceGroup('[', TexCmd('mu')), ' u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ']'), '  ,\n'], []), '\nwhich have weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w =3'], []), '.\n\nTo introduce second derivative terms, we need to pin down all of the possible two derivative operators that transform homogeneously under conformal transformations.  The fist kind of term we can have are those that involve the squares of the first derivative operators, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('alpha')), '  = e^', BraceGroup('-4', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), ' ', '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('alpha')), '  ,', TexCmd('qquad'), ' \n', TexCmd('omega'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('alpha')), ' =  e^', BraceGroup('-4', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'))]), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('alpha')), '  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' \n', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('alpha')), '\\,', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('alpha')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-4', '\\,', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), ' ', '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('alpha')), '\\,', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'))]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('alpha')), '  .\n'], []), '\t\nMoreover there exist also two derivative terms built from the fluid velocity. The possible terms of this kind are\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ' u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), ' ,\n& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' =  e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  , \n& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega')), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' =e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '   . \n'], []), '\n', '\nAn other kind of second order terms is one which involves the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' and various chemical potentials ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), '_I'], []), '. After some effort, it turns out that all of the possible operators in this group are\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_I'), BraceGroup('T')]), ') = ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '  ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), '_I'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('T')]))]), ')  , \n&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), ' \n', '&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), '_I'), BraceGroup('T')]), ') = ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))]), '_I'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('T')]))]), ') ', '\\,', ' \n', '&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('lambda', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' T = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'))]), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '   .\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn addition to the terms listed above, there is a one last term to consider, obtained by contracting the curvature tensors in the Weyl  tensor (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Weyltensor')]), ') with two velocity vectors\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nC_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', 'u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', 'u^', TexCmd('beta'), '  = ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('C')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', TexCmd('beta'), ' \n'], []), '\t\nthat is a symmetric, traceless and transverse tensor.\n\n\nHaving classified all possible operators that can enter in the construction of dissipative terms for a viscous conformal fluid, it is possible to proceed in isolating the terms that will be useful later on. In particular, for sake of simplicity, we will construct a dissipative generalisation of a conformal fluid with no conserved charges. For this choice, there are five possible symmetric traceless tensors which transform homogeneously under Weyl rescalings at second order:\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_1^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' =2', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ', ', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T')]), '_2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' =C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', 'u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', '\\,', 'u^', TexCmd('beta'), ', \n&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_3^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  =4', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('rangle')), '_', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('alpha')), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_4^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' =  2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('rangle')), '_', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('alpha')), ', \n&', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_5^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=   ', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('rangle')), '_', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('alpha')), ' .\n'], []), '\nWe summarise all the symmetric traceless tensors which transform homogeneously under Weyl rescalings up to the second order in table 2.1.\n\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('toprule'), '\nFirst order:&  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), '  \n', TexCmd('midrule'), '\nSecond order:& ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_1^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' =2', '\\,', ' u^', T'), '_5^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=   ', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('mu')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('omega'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('rangle')), '_', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('alpha')), ' '], []), ' \n', TexCmd('bottomrule'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('table')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup('ll')]), '\n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Symmetric and homogeneous traceless operator for a conformal viscous non-charged fluid up to the second order.')]), '\n'], [BracketGroup('tb')]), '\n', '\nHaving completed the exploration of possible dissipative terms up to the second order, we are finally able to write the correction to the stress tensor for a conformal viscous fluid that, for simplicity, we will assume to have no conserved charge. The general contributions to the stress tensor are:\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nT_', BraceGroup('(0)'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&=& ', TexCmd('alpha'), '\\,', ' T^d ', '\\,', ' ', '(g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' +d', '\\,', '  u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ')  -2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('Pi'), '_', BraceGroup('(1)'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&=& -2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('eta'), '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('Pi'), '_', BraceGroup('(2)'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&=&  ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '\\,', TexCmd('eta'), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '\n', '_1^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('kappa'), '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '\n', '_2^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_1', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '\n', '_3^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_2', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '\n', '_4^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_3', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '\n', '_5^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '   .\n'], []), '\t\nWhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('eta'), ', ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('pi'), ', ', TexCmd('kappa'), ', ', TexCmd('lambda'), '_i', '\\}'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i = ', '\\{', '1,2, 3', '\\}'], []), ' is a set of six transport coefficients characterizing the viscous fluid.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Nonrelativistic limit of fluid dynamics')]), '\n', '\nIn this section we will discuss, following ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ', the non-relativistic scaling limit of the fluid dynamical equations of a non-charged fluid (we will not assume, for the moment, conformal invariance),  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=0  ,\n'], []), '\nwith \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '= ', TexCmd('rho'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p'), ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' -2 ', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('zeta'), ' ', TexCmd('theta'), ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('ldots'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p')], []), ' is the pressure', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('In this section ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p')], []), ' will indicate the relativistic pressure and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' the nonrelativistic one.')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' the energy density, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' the shear viscosity, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('zeta')], []), ' the bulk viscosity of the fluid, to the incompressible non-relativistic Navier-Stokes equations \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('NS')]), ' \n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v')])), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), '+ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v')]), '& = -', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla')), ' p\n+ ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' f'), ' \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla')), ' ', TexCmd('cdot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v')]), '&=0\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v')], []), ' is the fluid velocity, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' the fluid pressure, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' the shear viscosity and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' f')], []), ' an external forcing function.\n\nIn particular, we will discuss the non-relativistic limit \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' x& ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('T ', TexCmd('epsilon'))]), '\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' t&', TexCmd('sim'), '  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('T ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2')]), '\nv^i & ', TexCmd('sim'), '   ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '\n', TexCmd('delta', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('sim'), '  T^d ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2\n', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' x'], []), ' is a spatial length scale, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' t'], []), ' the temporal scale while  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v^i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p')])], []), ' have to be seen as estimates of the magnitude \nof velocity and pressure fluctuations on a configuration of fluid at rest and in equilibrium.\n\nThe meaning of this limit can be understood by remembering that it is necessary to scale to long distances to be in the fluid dynamical regime. Time intervals should scale like spatial intervals squared, as it is easy to realise looking at the dispersion relation for shear waves,  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), ' = i ', TexCmd('nu'), ' k^2'], []), ' .\nThese two scalings determine the scaling law for velocities. Finally the pressure fluctuations are to be scaled such that  they cannot accelerate the fluid velocities outside this scaling limit. \n\nLet us start by considering the flow of a fluid on a spacetime with a metric that can be cast in the form\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nG_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '+H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '  ,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is an arbitrary small fluctuation of a  background metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' that we want to write as', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('This form of the metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' can be seen as a simply a choice of coordinate system, for a large class of metrics.')]), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \ng_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), 'dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), '= -dt^2 + g_', BraceGroup('ij'), 'dx^i dx^j.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe fluid flow on the background space equipped with the metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' can be reinterpreted as a forced flow on the space with metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), '  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ', mapping the velocity field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' u'), '^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' on the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' to a velocity field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), '. In constructing the map the normalisation of the velocity field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^2=', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' u'), '^2 =-1'], []), ' must be maintained. \n\nThe fluid velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' u'), '^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' on the space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['^', TexCmd('mu'), '  = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('V^2')]))]), ' ', '( 1, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' V'), ' ', ')  ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' u')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' V')], []), ' is the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-1'], []), ' spatial vector with components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^i'], []), '. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' component object with components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' V'), ' ', ')'], []), ' and \n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^2'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' V^', TexCmd('mu'), ' V^', TexCmd('nu')], []), '.\n\nA perturbative expansion of the velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' u'), '^', TexCmd('mu')], []), '  at the first order in the small fluctuation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' gives\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['^', TexCmd('mu'), '& = u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' + ', TexCmd('delta'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' + ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  \nu^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '& = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1 - g_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' V^i V^j')]))]), ' ', '( 1, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' V'), ' ', ')\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '& = -u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('beta'), ' H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' u')]), '\nwhere we have expressed the series in terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', the new velocity of the fluid referring to the metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), '. The idea that we want to follow is to consider terms in which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))], []), ' appears as contributions to an effective forcing function in the non-relativistic Navier-Stokes  equation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('NS')]), ').\n\nWe want to consider ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))], []), ' as a small amplitude and long distance fluctuation on a uniform fluid at rest - it is always a solution  to the equations of fluid dynamics on the space with metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), '.  The fluid at rest will be described as a fluid with pressure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p'), '_0'], []), ', energy density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_0'], []), "  on a manifold that is ``close'' to ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), '. We set the components of the fluctuation to\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nH_', BraceGroup('00'), '& = ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 h_', BraceGroup('00'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' x^i, ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 t)', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nH_', BraceGroup('0i'), '& = ', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' A_i (', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' x^i, ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 t)', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nH_', BraceGroup('ij'), '&= ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 h_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' x^i, ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 t) ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n'], []), '\nand we assume consistently that the velocity and pressure satisfy\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nV^i&=', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' v^i(', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' x^i, ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 t)\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p'), '-', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p'), '_0'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rho'), '_0 + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' p'), '_0')]), '&= ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 p(', TexCmd('epsilon'), ' x^i, ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 t) \n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' is a parameter arbitrarily small and one can define a covariant vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v^', TexCmd('mu'), '=(1, v^i)'], []), '. The normalisation of the pressure fluctuations, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_0 + P_0'], []), ', has been introduced for future convenience. Energy density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' and viscosity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' also scale in a similar fashion. \n\nThe conservation equations are expected to reduce to the classical  Navier-Stokes equations in this limit. Let us start by considering the temporal component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', we get\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' 0'), '& = ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2 ', '[', TexCmd('rho'), '_e ( ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i v^i) ', ']', ' +  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4)\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_e&= ', TexCmd('rho'), '_0+p_0\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\ntherefore, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ', this equation reduces to \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i v^i=0 ,\n'], []), ' \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_i'], []), ' is the covariant derivative with respect to the purely spatial metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '. \nSpatial components of the conservation equations, after some manipulation, can be cast in the form\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' i'), ' = ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3  ', '[', ' ', TexCmd('rho'), '_e ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^i p + ', TexCmd('rho'), '_e ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '( v^i v^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', ') .\n.  -2 ', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j  (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^j v^i + ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^i v^j'), BraceGroup('2')]), '-g^', BraceGroup('ij'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nabla'))]), ' ', TexCmd('cdot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v')])), BraceGroup('d-1')]), ' ', ') \n-', TexCmd('zeta'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla')), TexCmd('cdot', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v')]), '  -f^i ', ']', ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^5)  \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('spns')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere the forcing function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' is defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nf^i=', TexCmd('rho'), '_e( ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '_i h_', BraceGroup('00')), BraceGroup('2')]), ' - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_0 A_i  - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '_j (', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('g')]), ' A_i v^j)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('g')]))]), ' + v^j', TexCmd('partial'), '^i A_j )  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe coefficient of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3'], []), ' can be rewritten in a more transparent form. We begin using the expression \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i v^i= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '_i(', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('g')]), ' v^i)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('g')]))]), '=0 ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  ,\n'], []), '\nto get\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^i p + ', TexCmd('partial'), '_0 v^i  + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v'), '. ', TexCmd('nabla'), ' v^i - ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '(  ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 v^i  +   R^i_j v^j  ) \n= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '^i h_', BraceGroup('00')), BraceGroup('2')]), ' - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_0 A^i + F^i_j v^j\n'], []), '\nwhere we defined a field strength ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('ij'), '=', TexCmd('partial'), '_i A_j-', TexCmd('partial'), '_j A_i'], []), ' associated to the vector field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_i'], []), ', and a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' kinematical viscosity'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu'), '=', TexCmd('eta'), '/', TexCmd('rho'), '_e'], []), ' of the fluid. It this then possible to redefine variables, splitting the gauge field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_i'], []), ' into its pure curl and pure divergence parts, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nA_i= a_i +', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i ', TexCmd('chi'), '  ,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_i a^i=0'], []), ', and one finds\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nf_', BraceGroup('ij'), TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i a_j-', TexCmd('partial'), '_j a_i= F_', BraceGroup('ij'), '.\n'], []), '\nIt is also useful to define an effective pressure \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\np_e=p-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '  h_', BraceGroup('00'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dot'), ' ', TexCmd('chi')), '.\n'], []), '\nIn terms of the new variables, equation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('spns')]), ') becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i p_e + ', TexCmd('partial'), '_0 v_i + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec'), ' v'), '. ', TexCmd('nabla'), ' v_i - ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 v_i +  R_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' v^j )   = -', TexCmd('partial'), '_0 a^i- v^j f_', BraceGroup('ji'), '  ,\n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cond-spnv')]), '\n '], []), '\nwhich is indeed  the Navier-Stokes equation with a forcing function generated by an effective background electromagnetic field on the effectively charged fluid.  \n\nIn the case of a charged fluid, the discussion follows the same track, adding the set of conservation equations for conserved charges (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cons-hydr')]), '). It turns out that, in the non-relativistic limit, these equations lead to supplementary conditions under which the fluid velocity is divergence-free.\n\nA point that it is useful to assess regards how Cauchy conditions for the relativistic fluid are transmitted to the non-relativistic fluid. The Cauchy data of the relativistic dynamical equations consist of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' real functions of space: the value of the pressure field and the  value of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-1'], []), ' independent velocity fields defined on an initial timeslice ', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Since the fluid conservation equations are of first order in time, the Cauchy data of the problem does not include the time derivatives of all these fields.')]), '. In the case of the non-relativistic incompressible Navier-Stokes equations, one can observe that the derivative of eq.(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('cond-spnv')]), ') results in the condition\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('press')]), '\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 p_e = -', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i v^j ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j v^i - v^i v^j R_', BraceGroup('ij'), '   + ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i ', '[', ' ', '( -', TexCmd('nu'), ' R^i_j + f^i_j ) v^j ', ']', '  ,\n'], []), '\nthat determines the pressure of the fluid as a function of the fluid velocity. Therefore, the set of independent data necessary to determine the flow of the fluid is given by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-2'], []), ' real functions that parameterize an arbitrary divergence free velocity field. Indeed,  two of the degrees of freedom of the equations of relativistic fluid dynamics are projected away in the scaling limit. One can see that these two degrees of freedom correspond the fluctuations of the pressure and the divergence of the velocity', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('As observed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ', at the linearized level these two degrees of freedom combine together in sound mode fluctuations. Hence the physical fact behind the reduction of Cauchy data in the non-relativistic limit is that sound waves are projected out in the scaling limit')]), '. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Nonrelativistic symmetries for conformal fluids')]), '\n', '\nAs we have discussed in the previous section, the Navier-Stokes equations may be obtained as the scaling limit of any relativistic equations of fluid \ndynamics. For the purpose of our work we are interested in particular in conformal fluids  due to their connection with gravity. Therefore it is interesting to assess in which form the conformal symmetry descends to a symmetry of the Navier-Stokes equations, in the non-relativistic scaling limit we proposed above.\n\nA dilatation consists of a diffeomorphism \n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', "(x')^", TexCmd('mu'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), ", ~~~ T'=T , ~~~ (u')^", TexCmd('mu'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u^', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), " , ~~~ (g')_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=  ', TexCmd('lambda'), '^2 g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ,\n'], []), '\nassociated with a Weyl transformation \n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' x'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), "= (x')^", TexCmd('mu'), ' , ~~~ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' g'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("(g')_", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), '^2')]), ' , ~~~ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' u'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '= ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', "(u')^", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ' , \n~~~ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' T'), '= ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' T  .\n'], []), '\nThe compound action is therefore:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))]), ', ~~~', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '= g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ', ~~~ ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '= u^', TexCmd('mu'), ', ~~~', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('T')]), '=', TexCmd('lambda'), ' T .\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' x')]), '\nThis action is a symmetry of the  equations of conformal relativistic fluid dynamics, but it is not a symmetry of the Navier-Stokes equations. Indeed, kinematical viscosity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), ' in the Navier-Stokes equations, is proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('T')])], []), ', hence it is not invariant under dilatation transformations.  However as was shown in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ", it is possible to modify dilatation transformations into a true symmetry of the Navier-Stokes equations by ``absorbing'' the transformation of ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nu')], []), " into the ``anomalous'' transformations of time and velocity. \n\nLet us start by considering special conformal transformations. The scaling law for the velocity and temperature fields, under a special conformal transformation, may be obtained by combining  a  diffeomorphism with the appropriate Weyl transformation. For an infinitesimal conformal transformation one gets \n", TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('spconf')]), '\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' x^', TexCmd('mu'), '& = -2 c.x x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' +x^2 c^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('delta'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), '&= -2', '[', ' x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' c^', TexCmd('nu'), '-x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' c^', TexCmd('mu'), ']', ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), ' x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' \n', TexCmd('delta'), ' T&= 2 c.x T - ', TexCmd('delta'), ' x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' T . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n'], []), '\nTo verify the covariance of local equations under these symmetry transformations, one has to omit the terms proportional \nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ", using the following expression for the derivative's transformation\n", TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', ') = 2 ', '[', ' c_', TexCmd('beta'), '  x.', TexCmd('partial'), ' -x_', TexCmd('beta'), ' c.', TexCmd('partial'), ' + x.c ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', ']', ' .\n'], []), '\n', '\nUnder transformation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('spconf')]), '), the conformal stress tensor becomes\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '= 2 d (c.x) T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + 2 (x^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' c^', TexCmd('mu'), ' -x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' c^', TexCmd('lambda'), ')  T^', TexCmd('nu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' +  2 (x^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' c^', TexCmd('nu'), ' -x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' c^', TexCmd('lambda'), ')T^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' - ', TexCmd('delta'), ' x^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '  .\n '], []), "\n Therefore, given the derivative's transformation, any identically traceless stress tensor is invariant under special conformal transformations.\n \nSpecial conformal transformations (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('spconf')]), ') give rise to an additive shift in the temperature fluctuation, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' T'], []), ', proportional \nto ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x', TexCmd('cdot'), ' c T_0'], []), '. In order that this shift respects the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2'], []), ' scaling of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' T'], []), ' one has to scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_0 ', TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c_i ', TexCmd('propto'), ' ', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3'], []), '. In this way the transformations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('spconf')]), ') read\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' t & = 0 ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('delta'), ' x^i& = - t^2 c^i  ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('delta'), ' v^i &= -2 c^i t  + t^2  c_j ', TexCmd('partial'), '_j v^i  \n', TexCmd('delta'), ' T&= 2 (-c^0 t + c^i x^i)  T  + t^2 c_j ', TexCmd('partial'), '_j T . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n'], []), '\nTo verify the covariance of the conservation equations under these transformations, one has to omit the terms proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^2 c_j ', TexCmd('partial'), '_j'], []), ' and to supplement their action with the following derivative transformation\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('partial'), '_t ) = 2 t c^i ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i ', '\\,', '  ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  ', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i )  =0  . \n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nThe symmetry generated by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c^0'], []), ' acts trivially. Indeed it does  not act on coordinates or velocities, but merely generates a shift, linear \nin time, of the pressure. On the contrary, the symmetries generated by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c^i'], []), ' act nontrivially. Under this transformation one gets\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n ', TexCmd('delta'), ' p_e= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), ' p'), BraceGroup('d P_0')]), '= 2 c', TexCmd('cdot'), ' x  ,\n '], []), '\nand therefore\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\n', TexCmd('delta'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i p_e= 2 c^i  .\n'], []), ' \nFinally ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), '( ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('dot'), ' v^i'), ' + v', TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('nabla'), ' v^i ) = -2 c^i'], []), '. Hence, the viscous term - which was responsible for the change in Navier-Stokes equations - is unchanged under the redefined transformation. The Navier-Stokes equations are invariant under a conformal symmetry group.\n\nWe can conclude this section, for sake of completeness, by giving few more details on the conformal symmetry group. \n\nThe group generators of this group are the dilatation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), ',  special conformal symmetries ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_i'], []), ', Galilean boosts ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_i'], []), ', the generator \nof time translations (energy) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ', momenta ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_i'], []), ' and spatial rotations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '. The action of these generators on velocity fields is given by \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '&D v^j  = ( -2 t ', TexCmd('partial'), '_t - x^m ', TexCmd('partial'), '_m - 1 ) v^j  \n&K_i v^j= -2 t ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), '  + t^2  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i v^j \n&B_i v^j=  ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' -t ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i v^j\n&H v^j =  - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_t v^j \n&P_i v^j= - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i v^j \n&M_', BraceGroup('ik'), ' v^j= ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' v^k - ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('kj'), ' v^i - (x^k ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i - x^i \n', TexCmd('partial'), '_k) v^j \n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nWhile the following commutation relations among generators hold:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('comrel')]), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', '&', '[', 'D, K_i', ']', '= -3 K_i ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '  ', '[', 'D, B_i', ']', '= -B_i ', TexCmd('qquad', [BracketGroup('D, H')]), '= 2 H\n&', '[', 'D, P_i', ']', '= P_i  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad', [BracketGroup('D, M_', BraceGroup('ij'))]), '=0  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', '[', 'M_', BraceGroup('ij'), ', P_k', ']', '= -', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ik'), ' P_j + ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('jk'), ' P_i \n&', '[', ' M_', BraceGroup('ij'), ', K_k', ']', ' = -', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ik'), ' K_j + ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('jk'), ' K_i ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', '[', 'M_', BraceGroup('ij'), ', B_k', ']', '= -', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ik'), ' B_j + ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('jk'), ' B_i \n&', '[', 'M_', BraceGroup('ij'), ', H', ']', '= 0 ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', '[', 'K_i, P_j', ']', '= 0 ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('qquad', [BracketGroup('K_i, B_j')]), '= 0 \n&', '[', 'K_i, H', ']', '= -2 B_i ', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('qquad', [BracketGroup('H, B_j')]), '= -P_i\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn addition to the relevant symmetries we enumerated above, the Navier-Stokes equations have, as noted before, an infinite dimensional group of trivial symmetries that act as a shift of the pressure by an arbitrary function of time. These are indeed symmetries since only gradients of the pressure \nenter the Navier-Stokes equations and trivial because the pressure is not really an independent variable, as we discussed above. The action of symmetry generators on the pressure is \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nD p_e  =& ( -2 t ', TexCmd('partial'), '_t - x^m ', TexCmd('partial'), '_m - 2 ) p_e  \nK_i p_e =&  2 x^i  + t^2  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i p_e \nB_i p_e = & -t ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i p_e\nH p_e = & - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_t p_e \nP_i p_e =& - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i p_e \nM_', BraceGroup('ik'), ' p_e =& - (x^k ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i - x^i \n', TexCmd('partial'), '_k) p_e . \n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThese generators acting on the pressure do not yield the commutation relations,  indeed they have additional terms. However spatial derivatives of the pressure field correctly transform according to the algebra (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('comrel')]), ').  For this reason, the symmetry algebra (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('comrel')]), ') is not represented on the pressure field  itself, but only on its spatial derivatives. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('chapter', [BraceGroup('Fluid dynamics from gravity')]), '\n', '\nIn this chapter we give a short review of the construction of gravity solutions dual to arbitrary fluid flows proposed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '. A detailed and comprehensive exposition of the subject can be found in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rangamani:2009xk')]), '. As pointed out in the first chapter, the application of  hydrodynamic concepts  to black holes is part of the core intuition of the membrane paradigm ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Thorne:1986iy, Damour:2004kwa')]), ', wherein one modeled the black hole horizon by a membrane equipped with fluid like properties. However, in this approach the connection to fluid dynamics is an analogy, and therefore provides a qualitative understanding of  the physical behaviour of black holes via a simpler fluid model. On the contrary, the fluid-gravity correspondence - an example of the  AdS/CFT correspondence - provides a duality between the hydrodynamic description and the  gravitational dynamics.  Indeed, the  precise quantitative connection allows one to map fluid solutions of the boundary field theory into a black hole solutions in the  bulk geometric description with regular event horizons.\n\nThe AdS/CFT correspondence conjectures a deep connection between quantum field theories and theories of gravity ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Maldacena:1997re,Gubser:1998bc,Witten:1998qj')]), '. The correspondence has proved to be a powerful tool for the large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' limit in which the gravitational theory turns classical,  and in a simultaneous strong `t Hooft coupling limit that suppresses  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), "'"], []), ' corrections to gravitational dynamics.  In this limit the conjecture asserts the equivalence between the effectively classical  large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['N'], []), ' dynamics of the local single trace operators ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_n= N^', BraceGroup('-1'), TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Tr')]), TexCmd('mathbf', [BraceGroup('O_n')])], []), ' of gauge theory and the classical two derivative equations of Einstein gravity interacting with other fields. The  AdS/CFT correspondence provides a one to one map from  the local and relatively simple bulk equations into unfamiliar and extremely nonlocal equations for the boundary trace operators ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_n(x)'], []), '. The authors of  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' proposed a construction which can simplify the extremely complicated equations on the boundary.\n\nTwo derivative bulk theories of gravity, containing AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' M_I'], []), ' as a solution, admit a consistent truncation to the Einstein equations with a negative cosmological constant.The only fluctuating field in this truncation is the Einstein frame graviton; all other bulk fields are simply set to their background AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' M_I'], []), " values. This fact implies the existence of a sector of decoupled and universal dynamics of the stress tensor in the corresponding dual field theories. Indeed, all single trace operators other than the stress tensor may consistently be set to zero as the stress tensor undergoes its dynamics. The dynamics of the stress tensor happens to be universal since it is governed by the same equations of motion in each member of this infinite class of strongly coupled CFTs. \n\nA further simplification in the dynamics of the dual theory can be obtained by considering the regime in which the local stress tensor varies on a length scale that is large, at any point,  compared to a local equilibration length scale - intuitively, a ``mean free path'' - which is set by the ``rest frame'' energy density at the same point. Under this condition, it is expected that boundary configurations should be locally thermalized, and therefore well described by the equations of boundary fluid dynamics. In particular, it has been proven that the complicated nonlocal ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' dynamics reduces to the familiar boundary Navier Stokes equations of fluid dynamics in this long wavelength limit  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '. \n\nIn ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' a perturbative procedure was proposed,  in a boundary derivative expansion, to construct a large class of asymptotically AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_5'], []), " long wavelength solutions to Einstein's equations with a negative cosmological constant. These solutions are parameterized by a four-velocity field ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu'), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), '  and a temperature field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ' that have to obey the four dimensional generalized Navier Stokes equations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=0'], []), ' where the stress tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ' is a local functional of the velocity and the temperature fields. \n\nThe explicit map from the space of solutions of a distinguished set of Navier Stokes equations to the space of long wavelength solutions of asymptotically AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), ' gravity was established up to second order for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d= 4, 5'], []), ' in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' and than generalized and studied in more detail in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008kq, VanRaamsdonk:2008fp, Bhattacharyya:2008xc, Bhattacharyya:2008ji, Dutta:2008gf, Loganayagam:2008is')]), '. In particular, in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008xc')]), ' it was proven that, subject to mild assumptions, these spacetimes have regular event horizons. Successively, the construction was extended to spacetimes of arbitrary dimensionality ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz, Haack:2008cp')]), '.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Black branes in AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []))]), '\n', '\nLet us start by analysing the universal sector of a string background of the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('AdS')]), '_', BraceGroup('d+1'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' X'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['X'], []), " is a compact internal manifold, suitable for obtaining a consistent string vacuum  and whose properties will be irrelevant in the following. Einstein's equation of gravity with a negative cosmological constant ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' follow from the Einstein-Hilbert action\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nS_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('bulk')])), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), '\\,', 'G_N^', BraceGroup('(d+1)'))]), '\\,', TexCmd('int'), '\\,', ' d^', BraceGroup('d+1'), 'x', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('-G')]), ' ', '\\,', '(R - 2', '\\,', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')  .\n'], []), '\t\nChoosing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('AdS'), ' = 1'], []), ", Einstein's equations are given by\n", TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ein')]), ' \n', '&E_', BraceGroup('M N'), '= R_', BraceGroup('M N'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', '\\,', ' G_', BraceGroup('M N'), ' R- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d(d-1)'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', ' G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '=0\n&R_', BraceGroup('M N'), ' + d', '\\,', ' G_', BraceGroup('M N'), '=0, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' R=- d(d+1) , \n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('M, N')], []), ' is the bulk metric, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('M N')], []), ' is the Einstein tensor and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M, N = 1, ', TexCmd('dots'), ' , d+1'], []), TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('We adopt the convention of using upper case Latin indices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'M,N, ', TexCmd('cdots'), '\\}'], []), ' to denote bulk directions, while lower case Greek indices ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', TexCmd('mu'), ' ,', TexCmd('nu'), ', ', TexCmd('cdots'), '\\}'], []), ' refer to field theory or boundary directions. Lower case Latin indices are used, instead, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'i,j,', TexCmd('cdots'), '\\}'], []), ' to denote the spatial directions in the boundary. Therefore we have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M, N = 1, ', TexCmd('dots'), ' , d+1'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ', ', TexCmd('nu'), '=1 ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' d'], []), '.')]), '.\n\nAn obvious solution of these equations is AdS spacetime with unit radius  \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 's^2=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'r^2'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' +r^2 ( ', TexCmd('eta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '), \n'], []), '\nwhere now ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ', ', TexCmd('nu'), '=1 ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' d'], []), ".\n\nA different solution to Einstein's equations is the planar Schwarzschild-", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['AdS_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), ' black brane which in standard coordinates is written as\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('AdSSw')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 's^2 &= -r^2', '\\,', ' f(b', '\\,', 'r) ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 't^2 + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'r^2'), BraceGroup('r^2', '\\,', ' f(b', '\\,', 'r) ')]), '+ r^2', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^i', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^j  ,\nf(r) &= 1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^d')]), '  .\n'], []), '\t\nEq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('AdSSw')]), ') can be seen as one-parameter family of solutions labeled by the horizon size ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_+'], []), ', which sets the temperature of the black hole\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('pi'), '\\,', 'b')]), '   .\n'], []), '\t\n', '\nFrom the black brane solution (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('AdSSw')]), ') one can generate a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' parameter family of  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' boosted black brane'), ' solutions by boosting the solution along the \ntranslationally invariant spatial directions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^i'], []), '. In Schwarzschild like coordinates, the new solution can be written as \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('blackbrane')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 's^2 &=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'r^2'), BraceGroup('r^2 f(r) ')]), ' +r^2 ( -f(r) u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' \n+ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ')  ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' \nf(r) &= 1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(br)^d')]), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('eta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), '=-1, ', TexCmd('nonumber', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&=', TexCmd('eta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '+u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' b=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' T')]), '  , ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nu^v&=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('beta'), '^2')]))]), ' \nu^i&=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('beta'), '_i'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('beta'), '^2')]))]), '  \n'], []), '\nand the velocities ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i'], []), ' are all constants with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^2 = ', TexCmd('beta'), '_j ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '^j'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '= u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ' +', TexCmd('eta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' '], []), '\nis the projector onto spatial directions. The temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '  associated to this solution is constant. The parameters which characterize the bulk solution are now the basic hydrodynamical degrees of freedom, temperature and the velocity of the black hole. \n\nMore generally, one can consider solution of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('blackbrane')]), ') where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is an arbitrary constant boundary metric of signature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(d-1, 1)'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is a generic constant unit normalized ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' velocity, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), '=-1, ', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup('P')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '= g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '+u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ', ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' b=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' T')]), '  .\n'], []), '\nClearly the new metric is quite redundant, since a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d(d+3)/2'], []), ' parameter set of metrics (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('blackbrane')]), ') are all coordinate equivalent. Indeed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' can be sent in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' by an appropriate linear coordinate  transformation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' x^', TexCmd('nu')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' can subsequently be set to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(1, 0 ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' 0)'], []), ' by a boundary Lorentz transformation. Moreover ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' can be set to one by uniform rescaling of boundary coordinates  coupled with a rescaling of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '. \n\nFor our purposes  it is useful, to introduce an even more redundant formulation of solution (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('blackbrane')]), '), obtained with via a transformation  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), TexCmd('to'), ' e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), ' r'], []), ', ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('blackbrane2')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 's^2=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' ', '( ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), ' + ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), '  ', TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ')^2 '), BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), '^2 f(r) ')]), ' +', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), '^2 ( -f(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('b')]), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), ') \n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' \n+ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' P'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ') \n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' are as defined in the previous equation, while \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('weyldef')]), '\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=e^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('phi'), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' \n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' =e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi'), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'), ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), ', ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('b')]), ' = \ne^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi'), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'), ' b, \n'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ' is an arbitrary function. \n\nMetrics of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('blackbrane2')]), ') describe the same bulk geometry but can be interpreted as distinct,  though Weyl equivalent, boundary description by regulating them inequivalently near the boundary. In particular, following the references above, spacetimes described by eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('blackbrane2')]), ') will be regulated on slices of constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' r')], []), ' and consequently seen as states in a conformal field theory on a space with metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde'), ' g'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '(x)'], []), '.\n\nThe non-anomalous part of the boundary stress tensor dual to metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('blackbrane2')]), ') is given by \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('AdS')])), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('b')]), '^d')]), ' ', '(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '+d ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ')  ,\n'], []), '\nwhich corresponds to the stress tensor of an ideal conformal fluid with a pressure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p=1/(16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('AdS')])), ' b^d)'], []), ' \nand without any vorticity or shear strain rate. \n\nIt is useful to observe that the velocity field is the unique time-like eigenvector of the stress tensor\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \nT^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('K'), BraceGroup('b^d')]), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ', ~~~K=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(d-1)'), BraceGroup('16 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' \nG_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('AdS')])))]), '\n'], []), '\nand the inverse temperature field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' is simply related to its eigenvalue.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Zeroth order ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ansatz'), ' for the metric')]), '\n', '\nIn the previous section, we described locally asymptotically AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), " exact solutions to Einstein's equations (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ein')]), ') which have, as a holographic boundary stress tensor, the ideal conformal fluid stress tensor. This is an expected result as the solution is stationary and therefore corresponds to the global thermal equilibrium. \n\nNow, to describe hydrodynamics we should perturb the system away from global equilibrium. The natural way to do this is to consider  thermodynamic variables varying along the boundary directions, that is promoting the parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' viz.'), ' the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '), ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i'], []), ' ', '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' viz.'), ' the velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ') to functions of the boundary coordinates. In particular, we want discuss solutions to Einstein equations  with slowly varying boundary stress tensors on a boundary manifold that has a weakly curved  boundary metric. These solutions should be locally patch-wise equilibrated, therefore corresponding bulk solution should approximately be given by patching together tubes of the uniform black brane solutions, extending from local patches on the boundary into the bulk.\n\nLet us consider a locally asymptotically AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), " solution to Einstein's equations, whose corresponding boundary stress tensor everywhere has a unique time-like eigenvector. Let us promote this eigenvector to a function ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu'), '(x)'], []), '  of the boundary coordinates, and let us, in the same way, define the inverse of the temperature field as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b(x)'], []), ". Now it is useful to define in a precise way in which sense we can consider our solution as ``slowly varying'': denoting by ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' x(y)'], []), ' the smallest length scale of variation of the stress tensor of the corresponding solution at the point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ', we shell consider  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' x (y) ', TexCmd('gg'), '  b(y)'], []), '. Actually ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b(y)'], []), ' may be interpreted as the effective length scale of equilibration of the field theory at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), '. Similarly, we say that the boundary metric is weakly curved if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b(y)^2 R(y) ', TexCmd('ll'), ' 1'], []), ' ', '(where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R(y)'], []), ' is the curvature scalar, or more generally an estimate of the largest curvature scale in the problem.)\n\nAn important issue to address is the shape of the radial curves that tubes - extending from local patches of uniform black brane on the boundary into the bulk - will have. A seeming natural choice is to let tubes follow lines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu'), '= ', TexCmd('rm', [BraceGroup('const.')])], []), ' in the Schwarzschild coordinates, writing the approximate bulk metric as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('wronguess')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 's^2=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('( ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), ' + ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal'), ' A_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ')^2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), '^2 f(r) ')]), ' +', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), '^2 ( -f(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('b')]), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), ') \n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' \n+ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' P')])), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ') \n'], []), '\nThe problem with this choice is that it has been shown that it leads, in general, to a geometry with non-regular future horizon', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Examples of metrics of the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('wronguess')]), ') have been discussed in  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chamblin:1999by,Benincasa:2007tp,Buchel:2008kd')]), '.')]), '. Furthermore, the solution (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('wronguess')]), ') has a relevant issue with causality. Let us consider a variation in the boundary metric at an arbitrary point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', inducing an effective force on the fluid. The future evolution of the fluid is affected only in the  the future boundary light cone of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', that we will denote ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C(y^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('To be precise this would be strictly true only summing all orders in the fluid expansion. Truncation at any finite order could lead to apparent violations of causality over length scales of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/T'], []), '.')]), '. The bulk will be affected by the variation only in the region of the space-time - ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(y^', TexCmd('mu'), '))'], []), ' - that is the union of all the tubes, that originate in the boundary region ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C(y^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), '. The natural requirement for bulk causality is that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(y^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ' must lie entirely within the future bulk light cone of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y^', TexCmd('mu')], []), '. This is not the case in the geometry described by metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('wronguess')]), '), where the tubes run along lines of constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' in Schwarzschild coordinates.\n\n\nThe appropriate choice to deal with issues of causality turns out to be to promote the parameters of a uniform brane solution, rewritten in Eddington Finkelstein coordinates, to slowly varying boundary functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('mu'), '(x)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b(x)'], []), '. In this way one gets the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ansatz'), ' for the metric\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('guess')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 's^2 = -2 u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'r + r ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ') + r^2 g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r^2'), BraceGroup('(br)^d')]), ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathrm', [BraceGroup('d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere as before\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('g')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=e^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('phi')), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '(x), ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '= \ne^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi')), ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), '(x), ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('b')]), ' = e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi')), ' b(x), \n'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '(x)'], []), ' is a weakly curved boundary metric. The reason for switching to Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates, apart from making issues of regularity more transparent, is that for this choice  tubes are chosen to run along ingoing null geodesics and therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B(y^', TexCmd('mu'), ')'], []), ' lies entirely within the future bulk light cone of the generic point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' ', '(fig. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tubes')]), '). \n\n', TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.75'), BraceGroup('fig3.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('hspace', [BraceGroup('1.5cm')]), '\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=0.32'), BraceGroup('fig4.eps')]), ' \n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('(a) Penrose diagram of the uniform black brane where the dashed lines denote the future event horizons. (b) The shaded tube extending from a local patches of uniform black brane on the boundary into the bulk, and running along ingoing null geodesics, indicates the region of spacetime over which the solution (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('guess')]), ') is well approximated by a tube of the uniform black brane. The two figures are taken from Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rangamani:2009xk')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tubes')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nAn important observation is that for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' all constants the metrics (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('wronguess')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('guess')]), ') reduce to equivalent - under a coordinate transformation - descriptions of a uniform brane solution. On the contrary, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ' are functions of the boundaries coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', the geometry described by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('wronguess')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('guess')]), ') are inequivalent and can differ qualitatively. Indeed, under mild assumptions, the metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('guess')]), ") presents a regular future horizon that shields all of the boundary from all future singularities in this space.\n\nTo summarise the general picture, a given boundary patch corresponds to an entire tube of width set by the scale of variation in the boundary. In the  Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates one has to patch together these tubes to obtain a regular solution to Einstein's equations and moreover this patching can be done order by order in boundary derivatives, just as in fluid dynamics. Therefore the metric (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('guess')]), ") will be the first term in a systematic perturbative expansion of a regular solution to Einstein's equations. The perturbative expansion parameter is ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/b ', TexCmd('delta'), ' x'], []), '. The curvature scale in the metric will be assumed to be of the same order as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/', TexCmd('delta'), ' x'], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The perturbative expansion in gravity')]), '\n', '\nThe logic of the perturbative expansion of the metric has been described in detail in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '.
