Let us review the reasoning starting with the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ansatz'), ' for the bulk metric\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nG_', BraceGroup('MN'), ' = G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '+G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '+G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)'), TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^2+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^3)  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pertansatz')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), ' is the parameter of the derivative expansion and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(k)')], []), ' is the correction to the bulk metric at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' that is to be determined with the help of the bulk Einstein equation. It will be shown that perturbative solutions to the gravitation equation  exist only when the velocity and temperature fields obey certain equations of motion that will be determined in a perturbative expansion order by order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('beta'), '_i= ', TexCmd('beta'), '_i^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '+ ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '_i^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '+ ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^2), ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' b=b^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '+ ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', '\\,', ' b^', BraceGroup('(1)'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^2) , \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pertansatz-2')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i^', BraceGroup('(m)')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(n)')], []), ' are all functions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', '\\,', 'x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), '.\n\nIn order to give a precise meaning to the coordinates it is necessary to adopt a choice of gauge. In ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), " the ``background field'' gauge was adopted, ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nG_', BraceGroup('rr'), '= 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' G_', BraceGroup('r ', TexCmd('mu'), ' '), TexCmd('propto'), ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), '  , ', TexCmd('qquad', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' Tr')]), '( (G^', BraceGroup('(0)'), ')^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' G^', BraceGroup('(n)'), ' ', ')=0 ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  ', TexCmd('forall'), ' ', '\\;', ' n  > 0 . \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gaugecond')]), '\n'], []), '\nA more convenient gauge choice was chosen in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nG_', BraceGroup('rr'), '= 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' G_', BraceGroup('r ', TexCmd('mu'), ' '), ' =  u_', TexCmd('mu'), '  . \n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gaugecond2')]), '\n '], []), '\n The meaning of this choice was discussed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008ji')]), ', where it was observed that, under this  gauge fixing, lines of constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' are ingoing null geodesics, with the radial coordinate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' being the affine parameter.\n \nHaving chosen a gauge, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' e. g.'), ' the second one, it is possible to substitute the perturbative ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ansatzs'), ' for the metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('pertansatz')]), ') and for parameters (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('pertansatz-2')]), ') into the bulk Einstein equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ein')]), ') and expand it order by order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), '. It is possible to solve the perturbative equation recursively starting form the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ansatz'), ' for the order zero metric defined in the previous section. Let us suppose that we have solved the perturbation theory to the\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n-1)^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' th'))], []), ' order, that is to have determined ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(m)')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m', TexCmd('leq'), ' n-1'], []), ', and have determined the functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i^', BraceGroup('(m)')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(m)')], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m ', TexCmd('leq'), ' n-2'], []), '. The Einstein equation at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' that must be solved can be written as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' G^', BraceGroup('(n)'), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', ') = s_n  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pertein')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H'), BracketGroup('G^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i, b^', BraceGroup('(0)'), ')')]), '\nwhere we indicated by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H')], []), ' a linear differential operator of second order in the in the variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' alone. An interesting feature of this operator is its ultralocal nature in the field theory directions. This depends on the fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(n)')], []), ' is already of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^n'], []), ', and every boundary derivative appears with an additional power of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), '. Indeed, it turns out that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H')], []), ' is a differential operator only in the variable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' and is independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', that it is independent at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' of the expansion and depends only on the values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), '. Hence it is possible to solve eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('pertein')]), ') point by point on the boundary. What changes order by order is the source term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_n'], []), ' that can be expressed as a local expression of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' th'))], []), ' order in boundary derivatives of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ', as well as of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n-k)^', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' th'))], []), ' order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i^', BraceGroup('(k)')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(k)')], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('leq'), ' n-1'], []), '.\n\nAs observed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008ji')]), ', it is convenient to organize the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(d+1)(d+2)'), BraceGroup('2')])], []), ' equations in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('pertein')]), ') in two classes of equations: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d(d+1)'), BraceGroup('2')])], []), ' equations determining the metric, that we call ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' dynamical equations'), ', and a a second set of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' equations which are essentially ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' constraint equations'), '.\n\nThe ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('em'), ' constraint equations'), ' are those of first order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' derivatives and are obtained  by contracting the equations with the one-form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'r'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nE^', BraceGroup('(c)'), '_M = E_', BraceGroup('MN'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '^N\n'], []), '\t\nwhere for our considerations ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '_N = dr'], []), '. Four of the five constraint equations, those with a free index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu')], []), ' ', '(that is with with legs along the boundary direction), have a simple interpretation: they are the equations of boundary energy momentum conservation:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T_', BraceGroup('(n-1)'), '^ ', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '=0  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eqst')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('(n-1)'), '^ ', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' '], []), ' is the boundary stress tensor dual to the solution expanded up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^', BraceGroup('n-1'), ')'], []), '. Recalling that all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(k)')], []), ' are local functions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), ', it is clear that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('(n-1)'), '^ ', BraceGroup('\\;', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' '], []), ' is also a local function (with at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n-1'], []), ' derivatives) that respects all boundary symmetries.\n\nThe constraint equations can be used to determine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(n-1)')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i^', BraceGroup('(n-1)')], []), ', this amounts to solving the equations of fluid dynamics at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n-1)^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' th')], []), ' order (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('eqst')]), '). There is a non-uniqueness in these solutions given by the zero modes obtained by  linearizing the equations of stress energy conservation at zeroth order. These may be absorbed into a redefinition of the  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i, b^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ', and do not correspond to a physical non-uniqueness. \n\nThe remaining constraints ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup('rr')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['E_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' are dynamical equations useful to determine the correction that should be added to our initial metric to make it a solution of Einstein equations. By exploiting the underlying symmetries of the zeroth order solution, specifically the rotational symmetry in the spatial sections on the boundary, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SO(d-1)'], []), ', it is possible to decouple the system of equations into a set of first order differential operators. Performing this diagonalization of the system of equations one gets a formal solution of the form:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nG^', BraceGroup('(n)'), ' = ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' particular'), '(s_n) + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' homogeneous'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H'), ') .\n'], []), '\t\n', '\nAt this point it is necessary to impose boundary conditions to determine a solution uniquely. A possible choice is to require that the solution is normalizable such that the spacetime is asymptotically AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), ' and also to demand regularity at all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r ', TexCmd('neq'), ' 0'], []), '. In ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' it was proven that it is possible to require that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(n)')], []), ' is appropriately normalizable  at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=', TexCmd('infty')], []), '  and non-singular at all nonzero ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ', for a generic non-singular and normalizable source ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_n'], []), TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('These requirements do not yet completely specify the solution for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(n)')], []), ', since H posses a set of zero modes that satisfy both these requirements. A basis for these zero modes is obtained by differentiating the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' parameters class of solutions (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('blackbrane')]), ') with respect to parameters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b'], []), '. These zero modes correspond to infinitesimal shifts of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' and therefore may be absorbed by redefining these quantities ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '.')]), '. Furthermore, if the solution at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n-1'], []), ' is non-singular at all nonzero ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ', it is guaranteed to produce a non-singular source at all nonzero ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), '. This is particularly important since implies that the non-singular ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_n'], []), ' can be inductively constructed.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Outline of the first order computation')]), '\n', '\nHaving described the recursive procedure for constructing a perturbative solution of Einstein equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ein')]), '), in this section we can give an outline of the derivation of the metric at first order. \n\nThe zeroth order ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ansatz'), ' for the metric, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ', has been formulated in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('guess')]), '). The equations that determine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' are ultralocal, consequently it is sensible to solve the problem point by point. We can pick a point on the boundary ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = x^', TexCmd('mu'), '_0'], []), ', which by exploiting the Killing symmetries of the background can be chosen to be the origin. At ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu'), '_0'], []), ' we can use the local scaling symmetry to set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(0)'), ' = 1'], []), ' and pass to a local inertial frame so that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i=0'], []), '. \n\nMaking these choices, the metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('guess')]), ') can be expanded to the first order in the neighbourhood of the origin \n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ['s_', BraceGroup('(0)'), '^2 = 2', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'v ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'r -r^2', '\\,', ' f(r)', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'v^2 + r^2', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'x_i ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'x^i - 2', '\\,', ' x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'x^i ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'r \n - 2', '\\,', ' x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i ', '\\,', ' r^2', '\\,', ' ', '(1-f(r))', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'x^i ', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'v  - d ', '\\,', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' x^', TexCmd('mu'), '\\,', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' b^', BraceGroup('(0)')), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('d-2'))]), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'v^2   .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('expmetric')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d')]), '\t\nThe metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expmetric')]), ') together with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup('MN'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' has a background part (the first three terms) which is simply the metric of a uniform black brane, plus a correction consisting of first derivatives some of which are known (the last four terms in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('expmetric')]), ')) and the reminder of which are to be determined.\n\nWe now need to make an ansatz for the metric correction at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' O'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('varepsilon')), ')'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), ', which we wish to determine. As was pointed out in the previous section one can exploit the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SO(d-1)'], []), ' spatial rotation symmetry at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu'), '_0'], []), ' to decompose modes into various representations of this symmetry. Modes of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), ' transforming under different representations decouple from each other by symmetry. We have  the following decomposition into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SO(d-1)'], []), ' irreducible  representations:\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '& ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('scalars:')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('vv'), ',  G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('vr'), ', ', TexCmd('sum'), '_i', '\\,', '  G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('ii'), ',  ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('vectors:')]), '  ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('vi'), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('tensors:')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' .\n'], []), "\nEinstein's equations can be solved sector by sector. In the scalar sector, one finds that the constraint equations imply that \n", TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i', TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i =  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_v b^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '   , \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('scalarcons')]), '\n'], []), '\t\n while in the vector sector we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i b^', BraceGroup('(0)'), ' =  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_v ', TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('veccons')]), '\n'], []), '\t\nThese two equations are equations of energy momentum conservation. \n\nThe differential operators entering in the dynamical equations for the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' defining the terms  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), ' are of the form\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('vector')]), ':&& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' d-1')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('dr')]), '\\,', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('d-1'))]), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('dr')]), '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), ') ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('tensor')]), ':&& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H'), '_', BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d(d+1)'), BraceGroup('2')]))), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('dr')]), '\\,', '(r^', BraceGroup('d+1'), '\\,', ' f(r)', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('dr')]), '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), ') \n'], []), '\t\nwhere the index of the operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H')], []), ' is the representation label of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['SO(d-1)'], []), ' rotational symmetry. The scalar sector involves some mixing between different fields and is slightly more involved.  As expected the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H'], []), ' operators are simple differential operators in the radial variable alone  (the form of the differential operator remains invariant in the course of the perturbation expansion) and can be inverted to find the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' F')], []), ' once the source ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_n'], []), ' is specified. \n\nExtending this procedure, the calculation can in principle be carried out to any desired order in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), ' expansion. Clearly it is necessary to compute at any given order the source terms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_n'], []), '. In addition one always has to ensure that the lower order stress tensor conservation equations are satisfied. For instance, in order for the source terms which appear in the determination of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), '  to be ultra-local  at our chosen boundary point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu'), '_0'], []), ', we have to ensure that the first order fluid equations of motion are satisfied. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Outline of the second order computation')]), '\n', "\nOnce the procedure has been implemented at first order, it is then possible to move on to find a solution to Einstein's equation at the second order. Before proceeding, it is necessary to pause for a moment to notice that the first order computation was performed as a Taylor expansion in the neighbourhood of a special point ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' that we chose as the origin. This was enough to obtain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), ', while in order to solve the second order problem it is necessary to ensure oneself that the first order constraint is solved to the second order in Taylor expansion of the fields ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i'], []), ' about the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' that we chose. Therefore the proper requirement is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('addconstraint')]), '\n', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '_', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(x^', TexCmd('alpha'), ') = 0  , \n'], []), '\nthis is equivalent to requiring that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '_', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' satisfies the conservation equation to the order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), '^2'], []), ' before attempting to find the second order stress tensor. In general the right procedure would have been to satisfy the conservation equation globally, however the ultralocality of the set-up allows one to have less stringent requirements, that amounting to checking that conservation holds only at the order at which we are working.', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('A good way to rephrase this requirement is to say that before proceed to the second order expansion it is necessary to control that the background defined with the first order calculation solve the first order fluid dynamics.')]), '\n', '\nOnce we have checked the requirement (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('addconstraint')]), '), it is possible to reexpress Einstein equations schematically as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' G^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '(x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', ') = s_a + s_b  ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' H'), BracketGroup('G^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '(', TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i, b^', BraceGroup('(0)'), ')')]), ' \nwhere for convenience the source term was written as a sum of the pieces. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_a'], []), ' is a local functional of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(0)')], []), ' up to the second order in field theory derivatives. Terms entering in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_a'], []), ' originated from two field theory derivatives acting on the metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(0)'), '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), ' or one field theory derivative acting on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('MN')], []), '.  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s_b'], []), ' arises from first order derivatives of the velocity and temperature corrections ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_i'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), '. The second part of the source term is new with respect to the first order computation. \n\nHaving defined the new source terms, the second order step of the perturbative calculation proceeds similarly to the first order computation', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('A detailed derivation of the results for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d=4,5'], []), ' at first and second order can be found in the original work  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]))]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Weyl covariance of the metric')]), '\n', '\nAn important aspect of the bulk metric dual to fluid dynamics is that it has to transform covariantly under the Weyl transformation ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008ji')]), '. Under the gauge choice (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gaugecond2')]), ') the bulk metric can be cast in the general form\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('generalform'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d')]), 's^2 = -2 u_', TexCmd('mu'), '(x) ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), '(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'r+', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), '(r,x) ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), ')+', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '(r,x)', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d'), 'x^', TexCmd('mu', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathrm'), ' d')]), 'x^', TexCmd('nu'), '  \n'], []), '\nwhere  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is transverse to the velocity field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), ',  \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nu^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=0 . \n'], []), '\nAll the Greek indices are raised and lowered using the boundary metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' defined by\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('eq:bndmet')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\ng_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('rarrow ', TexCmd('infty')), ' r^', BraceGroup('-2'), '[', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '-  u_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('mu')), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ')'), ' ', ']', '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is the unit time-like velocity field in the boundary, i.e., ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), 'u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = -1 '], []), '.\n\n\nLet us consider a bulk diffeomorphism of the form ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')])], []), ' supplemented by a scaling in the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b=e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('b')])], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '=', TexCmd('phi'), '(x)'], []), ' is defined as a function of the boundary co-ordinates. Components of the metric scale as \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '& u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' = e^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('u')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ',  \n&', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), '[', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '+', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('phi'), ' ', ']', ',\n&', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' =', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('and')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=(', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]))]), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '\n', '&dr +', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' = e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), ' ', '(d', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('r')]), '+', TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]))]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ') .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Weylscaling')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nTherefore we conclude that consistency demands that  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'))], []), ' shall transforms like a connection under a Weyl transformation while ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')])), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' remains invariant. These properties of the metric components yield a prescription for constructing these two objects as appropriate sums of objects with the right transformation properties under Weyl scaling. Therfore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')])), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' will be a linear sum of Weyl invariant forms, while ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '-r', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' will be a linear sum of Weyl-covariant vectors with weight unity. The form of the coefficients is not determined by symmetry requirements and have to be fixed by direct calculation.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The metric dual to hydrodynamics')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('defmetric')]), '\n', '\nFollowing the procedure described in the previous sections up to the second order, one find the metric dual to the hydrodynamics on the boundary. In this section we report the results of the calculation that yield, up to second order, a map identifying fluid solutions in the boundary field theory with black brane solutions in the  bulk geometry. \n\nThe metric can be cast in different forms, using different conventions. For the sake of completeness we give in the following a brief overview of some of them. \n\nA very neat and explicit form is\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nds^2 = &-2 u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '( dr + r A_', TexCmd('nu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ') + ', '[', ' r^2 g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' +u_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('mu')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ')', TexCmd('lambda')), 'u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' -', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('nu')), ']', 'dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(br)^d')]), '(r^2-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ') u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&+2(br)^2 F(br)', '[', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b')]), '  ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' +  F(br)', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ']', 'dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&-2(br)^2 ', '[', 'K_1(br)', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('d-1')]), 'P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + K_2(br)', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu')), BraceGroup('(br)^', BraceGroup('d'))]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('2(d-1)')]), ' . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&.  -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('L(br)'), BraceGroup('(br)^', BraceGroup('d'))]), '  u_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('mu')), 'P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ')'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), ']', ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&-2(br)^2 H_1(br)', '[', 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '+', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('d-1')]), 'P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('beta')), 'u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', ']', 'dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&+2(br)^', BraceGroup('2'), ' H_2(br)', '[', 'u^', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('metric-1')]), '\n'], []), '\nWhere the functions appearing in the metric are defined by \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nF(br) &', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-2'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy ,\nH_2(br)&', '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), 'y^', BraceGroup('d-3'), 'dy ', '[', '1+(d-1)y F(y) +2 y^', BraceGroup('2'), " F'(y) ", ']', ' \n', '&=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' F(br)^2-', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '(', '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '^2'), BracketGroup('1-', TexCmd('xi'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), "-1)F'(", ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&. TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), TexCmd('xi'), '^', BraceGroup('d-1'), 'd', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' dy ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y-1'), BraceGroup('y^3(y^d-1)')]), '  .\n'], []), '\nThe integral functions have the following asymptotics ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nF(br) & ', TexCmd('approx'), '  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('br')]), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d(br)^d')]), '+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(d+1)(br)^', BraceGroup('d+1'))]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('\\#'), BraceGroup('(br)^', BraceGroup('2d'))]), '+', TexCmd('ldots'), ',\nH_1(br) &', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2(br)^2')]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d(br)^d')]), '+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(d+2)(br)^', BraceGroup('d+2'))]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('\\#'), BraceGroup('(br)^', BraceGroup('2d'))]), '+', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ,\nH_2(br)&', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2(br)^2')]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d(br)^d')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-2'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy ,\nK_1(br) &', TexCmd('approx'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), ', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('lambda')), '\\,', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('nu')), '+ 2', '\\,', ' ', '(b', '\\,', 'r)^2', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(b', '\\,', 'r)', '\\,', ' ', '[', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b')]), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(b', '\\,', 'r) ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '^', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('lambda')), '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ']', ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\,', '- ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_2(b', '\\,', 'r)  ', '\\,', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('d-1')]), ' ', '\\,', ' P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' - [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The boundary stress tensor')]), '\n', '\nThe dual stress tensor corresponding to the metric at the second order presented in the previous section can be determined quite straightforwardly using the holographic prescription in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Henningson:1998gx,Balasubramanian:1999re')]), '. To perform the computation one has to define a regularisation  of the asymptotically AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), ' spacetime at some cut-off hypersurface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r  = ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('c')])], []), ' and consider the induced metric on this surface, which up to a scale factor involving ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('c')]))], []), ' is our boundary metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), '. The holographic stress tensor is given in terms of the extrinsic curvature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' and metric data of this  cut-off hypersurface\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nK_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('rho')), '\\,', TexCmd('nabla'), '^', TexCmd('rho'), ' n_', TexCmd('nu'), '\n'], []), '\t\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is the outward normal to the surface. Now, for asymptotically AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('5')], []), ' spacetimes the prescription in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Balasubramanian:1999re')]), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' = ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('c')]), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' ', TexCmd('infty')), '\\;', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), '_', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('c')]), '^', BraceGroup('d-2')), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', '\\,', ' G_N^', BraceGroup('(d+1)'))]), ' ', '\\,', ' ', '[', ' K^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' - K ', '\\,', ' g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' - (d-1)', '\\,', ' g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-2')]), '\\,', '  ', '(R^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', ' R ', '\\,', ' g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ')', ']', ' .\n'], []), '\t\n', '\nImplementing this procedure, one is able to determine the dual stress tensor corresponding to the metric in the previous subsection\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&= p(g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '+d u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', ')-2', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&-2', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('omega', [BracketGroup('u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '+', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '+', TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('nu', [BraceGroup()]), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('lambda')), ' ')]), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&+2', TexCmd('eta'), ' b', '[', 'u^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '+', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('d-1')]), 'P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '+ C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('beta')), 'u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', ']', '\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nb &=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('pi'), ' T')]), ' ,  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' p=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('AdS')])), 'b^d')]), ', \n', TexCmd('eta'), ' ', '&=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('AdS')])), 'b^', BraceGroup('d-1'))]), ' ,', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega')), ' =  b ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-2'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy .\n'], []), '\nSubstituting the standard entropy density, one gets\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('eta')), BraceGroup('s')]), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('pi'))]), '  ,\n'], []), '\nthe celebrated ratio of shear viscosity to entropy density ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kovtun:2004de')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Horizon location for the dual metric')]), '\n', '\nA last point to assess is the regularity of the horizon of the black brane metrics that we have derived', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('In this section we will follow the derivation proposed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), '.')]), '. The event horizon ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^+'], []), ' of a given spacetime is defined as the boundary of the past lightcone of future null infinity. This is a formal statement of the physical fact that the spacetime events inside the event horizon of the black hole cannot communicate to the asymptotic region. The future null infinity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' I'), '^+'], []), ' is the set of points which are approached asymptotically by null rays which can escape to infinity and it is time-like for asymptotically AdS spacetimes. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^+'], []), ' is the boundary of a causal set, it is a null surface which is, in particular, generated by null geodesics in the spacetime. \n\nThe event horizon of the spacetimes dual to the hydrodynamics on the boundary is the unique null hypersurface that tends, at late times, to the known event horizons of the late time limit of our solutions. As seen above, the metric we found can written, in the gauge ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('rr'), '=0'], []), ',  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('r', TexCmd('mu')), '=-u_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', in the form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('metric-3')]), ') that makes explicit the invariance under boundary Weyl transformations. \n\nLet us suppose that the event horizon is given by the equation \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), TexCmd('equiv'), ' r-r_', BraceGroup('_H'), '(x)=0 ,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('_H')], []), ' is the radial position of the horizon. The vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '_A'], []), '  normal to the horizon is defined by the one-form\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n dS= ', TexCmd('xi'), '_A dy^A = dr -', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' r_H dx^', TexCmd('mu'), '  ,\n '], []), '\nthat can be written in a manifestly Weyl covariant form\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('xi'), '_A dy^A = dS= (dr+', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' dx^', TexCmd('lambda'), ')-', TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), '  .\n '], []), ' \nAlso its dual normal vector can be written in Weyl covariant form as\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('xi'), '^A', TexCmd('partial'), '_A &= ', BraceGroup('G'), '^', BraceGroup('AB'), TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('A'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('B'), '= n^', TexCmd('mu'), '(', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '-', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('partial'), '_r)-u^', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('partial'), '_r ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&= n^', TexCmd('mu', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '+', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' r_', BraceGroup('_H'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_r')]), ' =n^', TexCmd('mu', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'))]), '_', BraceGroup('r=r_', BraceGroup('_H')), '  .\n'], []), '\nIn the above expression we introduced two new Weyl-covariant vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '=e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('kappa'))]), '^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n^', TexCmd('mu'), '=e^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('phi')), TexCmd('tilde', [BraceGroup('n')]), '^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' defined via the expressions \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '&', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' r_', BraceGroup('_H'), '+', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' H'), ' \nn^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '&', TexCmd('equiv'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), '-(', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_H^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' .\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nThe subscript ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H'], []), ' indicates that the functions are to be evaluated at the event-horizon.\n\nThe induced metric on the horizon ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '(x)'], []), ' is defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nds^2_H = ', '[', 'G_', BraceGroup('AB'), '(y) dy^A dy^B', ']', '_', BraceGroup('r=r_', BraceGroup('_H'), '(x)'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '(x) dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), '  ,\n'], []), '\nwhere the boundary coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' have been used as the coordinates on the event horizon. Therefore we have \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '= ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '-u_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('mu')), TexCmd('kappa'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ')'), '\n'], []), '\nand the null-condition on the horizon, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'G_', BraceGroup('AB'), ']', '_H ', TexCmd('xi'), '^A ', TexCmd('xi'), '^B= ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), 'n^', TexCmd('mu'), ' n^', TexCmd('nu'), '=0'], []), ' corresponds to\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '(', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = 2 u^', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nullcond')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nNow it is possible to construct a Weyl-covariant derivative expansion', BraceGroup(TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('As noted in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), ' since there is no first order Weyl-covariant scalar, there are no corrections to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('_H')], []), ' at the first order in the derivative expansion. A detailed classification of the possible Weyl-covariant tensors is contained in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008ji')]), '.')])), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r_', BraceGroup('_H')], []), ', ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nr_', BraceGroup('_H'), ' ', '&= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b')]), '+b (h_1 ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' + h_2 ', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' +h_3 ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')]), ' ', ') +', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&= r_', BraceGroup('_H'), '^', BraceGroup('(0)'), ' + r_', BraceGroup('_H'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '+', TexCmd('ldots'), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nComputing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' one gets\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('kappasol:eq')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\n', TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '&= ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' b^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' - ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('lambda')), ' u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' -2 L_H P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), '   \n', '&', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '  + u_', TexCmd('mu', [BracketGroup(' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]), TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' \n+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('K_', BraceGroup('2H')), BraceGroup('2(d-1)')]), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('2b')]), 'r_', BraceGroup('_H'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '\n')]), ' +', TexCmd('ldots'), '\n n^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '&= u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' - b^2 P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '[', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' b^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' -', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda')), ' u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' -2 L_H ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ']', '\n ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), '_', BraceGroup('d-1'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_H')]), ' ', '&= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^', BraceGroup('d-1')), BracketGroup('1+(d-1)br_', BraceGroup('_H'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '+\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('b^2'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '-b^2 K_', BraceGroup('1H'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')))]), '\n b^', BraceGroup('d-1'), ' n^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), '_', BraceGroup('d-1'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_H')]), ' ', '&=', '[', '1+(d-1)br_', BraceGroup('_H'), '^', BraceGroup('(2)'), '+\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('b^2'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '-b^2 K_', BraceGroup('1H'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' ', ']', 'u^', TexCmd('mu'), '\n ', '&', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' - b^2 P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '[', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' b^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' - ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('lambda')), ' u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' -2 L_H ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'))), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu')), ']', '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nNow substituting the expression for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('nullcond')]), ', and after some manipulations, one finds the position of the event horizon as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nr_', BraceGroup('_H'), ' ', '&= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b')]), '+b (h_1 ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' + h_2 ', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' +h_3 ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')]), ' ', ') +', TexCmd('ldots'), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nh_1&=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2(d^2+d-4)'), BraceGroup('d^2(d-1)(d-2)')]), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('K_', BraceGroup('2H')), BraceGroup('d(d-1)')]), '\nh_2&=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d+2'), BraceGroup('2d(d-2)')]), '  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('and')]), TexCmd('quad'), ' h_3=-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d(d-1)(d-2)')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup('2H')], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ['\n K_', BraceGroup('2H'), ' = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '^2'), BracketGroup('1-', TexCmd('xi'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), "-1)F'(", TexCmd('xi'), ') -2(d-1)', TexCmd('xi'), '^', BraceGroup('d-1'), ' .\n . ', TexCmd('quad'), ' +2((d-1)', TexCmd('xi'), '^d-(d-2))', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), "dy y^2 F'(y)^2 ")]), ' .\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Boundary entropy current')]), '\n', '\nDissipative fluids are characterized by entropy production. On the other side of the duality, for black holes at equilibrium there is a natural definition of entropy associated with the area of the event horizon which is the usual Bekenstein-Hawking entropy of a back hole. Unfortunately, in general, when we consider deviations from equilibrium, there is no unambiguous notion of entropy. Indeed, the substantial requirement for the entropy current is to satisfy the second law\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' J^', TexCmd('mu'), '_S ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  ,\n'], []), '\nand it is possible, in principle, to adopt any local function having positive divergence to characterize the irreversibility of the fluid dynamical flow. The only constraint is that the candidate Boltzmann H-function must agree with the thermodynamic notion of entropy in global equilibrium. However since in the case of stationary black holes, as discussed in the first chapter,  the area of the event horizon is associated the entropy of the dual field theory, it seems quite natural to associate the entropy of the field theory with the area of the event horizon', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('In ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rangamani:2009xk')]), " it has been noticed that this point is quite delicate. Indeed, a key feature of the event horizon is its ``teleological nature'', ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), ', the fact that the entire future evolution of the spacetime is needed in order to determine its location. This may clash with the attempts to determine the horizon perturbatively. Associating an entropy current with the event horizon may lead to a non-local and acausal definition of entropy ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chesler:2008hg')]), '. Moreover in  the case of the conformal soliton flow ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Friess:2006kw')]), ', a simple hydrodynamic flow on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb'), ' R'), '^', BraceGroup('d-1,1')], []), ', it was shown that the event horizon area does not capture the entropy of the dual field theory ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Figueras:2009iu')]), '. Therefore under certain one should use the area of apparent horizons (more precisely dynamical horizons), to define the entropy current.')]), '.\n \nIn the previous section the geometry of a regular future event horizon ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^+'], []), ' for the  spacetimes dual to boundary fluid dynamics was derived. It is possible, starting from the entropy associated to the area of this horizon, to define an entropy current directly for the field theory in the boundary. To this end, consider spatial sections of the event horizon, which are co-dimension two surfaces in the spacetime, which we label as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^+_v'], []), '. We are working in a coordinate chart where the coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '^i'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i =', '\\{', '1,', TexCmd('cdots'), ' d-1', '\\}'], []), ' define a chart on  the spatial section and we use as an affine parameter, the boundary coordinate  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', to propagate these surfaces forward along the horizon generator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '^A'], []), '. On the surface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^+_v'], []), '  it is natural to define  a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(d-1)'], []), '-form whose integral gives the area of the spatial section. The entropy of the black hole will be - assuming that the null energy condition satisfied - proportional to this area. Using the Bekenstein-Hawking formula, in terms of the area of the event horizon, the entropy density is found to be\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\ns = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4', '\\,', 'G_N^', BraceGroup('(d+1)'))]), ' ', '\\,', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^', BraceGroup('d-1'))]), '   , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' b =  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('pi'), '\\,', ' T')]), '  . \n'], []), '\n', '\nTo get the entropy current of the field theory, one has to pull the entropy of the black hole back to the boundary. In ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008xc')]), ' the authors proposed that one pull-back the area form on the horizon using radially ingoing null geodesics, which provide an isomorphism between the spatial sections on the boundary  and the corresponding ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^+_v'], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' H'), '^+'], []), '. The general procedure detailed in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008xc')]), ' yields the boundary entropy current\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nJ^', TexCmd('mu'), '_S &=& ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), '^', BraceGroup('(n)'), '_', BraceGroup('d-1'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]))])), BraceGroup('4 G_', BraceGroup('AdS'))]), 'n^', TexCmd('mu'), ' \n', '&=& ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), '^', BraceGroup('(n)'), '_', BraceGroup('d-1'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]))])), BraceGroup('4 G_', BraceGroup('AdS')), BracketGroup('u^', TexCmd('mu'), '-(', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_H^', BraceGroup('-1'), ')^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), TexCmd('kappa'), '_', TexCmd('nu'))]), '  .\n'], []), '\nTo define ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), '^', BraceGroup('(n)'), '_', BraceGroup('d-1'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' one has to split the boundary co-ordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(v,x^i)'], []), '. After this split, the components of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' are further split into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(n^v,n^i)'], []), '. We denote the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-1'], []), ' dimensional induced metric on the constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' submanifolds of the event horizon by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('h')]), '_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '. Finally, one can define\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), '^', BraceGroup('(n)'), '_', BraceGroup('d-1'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]))]), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), '_', BraceGroup('d-1'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('h')]))])), BraceGroup('n^v ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('det')]), ' g')]))]), '  \n'], []), ' \nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is the boundary metric and the expression on the right hand side has been assumed to be pulled back from the horizon to the boundary via the ingoing null-geodesics. \n\nFollowing this procedure one finds that the entropy current takes the form:\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ['\nJ^', TexCmd('mu'), '_S = s', '\\,', 'u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' + s', '\\,', ' b^2 ', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', '(A_1 ', '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), '+A_2 ', '\\,', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), ' +A_3 ', '\\,', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('R')]), '\\,', ')\n + s', '\\,', ' b^2 ', '\\,', '( B_1 ', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('lambda')), ' + B_2 ', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('lambda')), ' ', ') + ', TexCmd('cdots'), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s'], []), ' is the entropy density and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_', BraceGroup('1,2,3')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B_', BraceGroup('1,2')], []), ' are arbitrary numerical  coefficients. Requiring positivity of the divergence one finds that two of the coefficients must solve the following linear constraint\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nB_1 + 2', '\\,', ' A_3 = 0  . \n'], []), '\t\nAn interesting result is that the entropy current in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' dimensions is a Weyl covariant vector of weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '. This is consequence of the fact that the entropy density scales like the inverse spatial volume, since the total entropy is dimensionless, and the velocity field scales according to (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Weylscaling')]), '). Using the geometric data of the space-time described by the metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('metric-3')]), ') the coefficients are fixed to be\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nA_1 &= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('d^2')]), '\\,', ' ', '(d+2) -( ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_2(1) +', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(' 2'), BraceGroup('d')]), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_2(1)) , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' A_2 = -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2', '\\,', 'd')]), '  ,', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\nB_1 &= -2 ', '\\,', ' A_3 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('d', '\\,', ' ', '(d-2)')]), '  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' B_2 = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-2')]), '   .\n'], []), '\t\nWe conclude this section by observing that, writing the divergence of the gravitational entropy current as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['_', TexCmd('mu'), ' J^', TexCmd('mu'), '_S = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', '\\,', TexCmd('eta')), BraceGroup('T')]), ' ', '\\,', ' ', '(', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', ' ', '[', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('4', TexCmd('pi'), '\\,', 'T')]), '\\,', ' ', '(1+ A_1 ', '\\,', '  d) - ', TexCmd('tau'), '_', TexCmd('pi'), ']', '\\,', ' u^', TexCmd('alpha'), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ')^2 + ', TexCmd('cdots'), '   ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' D')]), '\t\nwhich is accurate up  to third order in the derivative expansion, it is possible to check that it satisfies the requirement of non-negative divergence at this order.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BracketGroup('Non-relativistic solutions'), BraceGroup('The gravity solution dual to hydrodynamics in the non-relativistic regime')]), '\n', '\nIn chapter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2'], []), ' we discussed the non-relativistic scaling limit ofthe  hydrodynamic equations. In particular it was shown that, under this scaling, the incompressible non-relativistic Navier-Stokes equations are equivalent to the relativistic equations of fluid dynamics dual to gravity up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3)'], []), ".  In this section we will report some results about the gravitational dual to a solution of the non-relativistic Navier-Stokes equations constructed as a small fluctuation about a black brane background that solves all of Einstein's equations up to order ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3)'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '.\n\nIn computing the bulk metric up to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3)'], []), ', it turns out that only contributions from the zeroth order and the first order in the derivative expansion of the gravitational solutions of are relevant. Keeping in mind the discussion in section ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['2.7'], []), ', the metric up to first order in derivatives is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nds^2  = ds_0^2 + ds_1^2\n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\nds_0^2 &=& -2 u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dr + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^d r^', BraceGroup('d-2'))]), 'u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' + r^2 g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), 'dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nds_1^2 &=& -2 r u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '(u^', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ') u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', '&+& ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), 'r (', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ') u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' + 2 b r^2 F(b r) ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), 'dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '(u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '(u^', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ') u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' \n+ u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '(u^', TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ') u_', TexCmd('nu'), ') - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), '(', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ')(u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' + g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ') ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nb &=& ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d'), BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' T')]), ' = b_0 + ', TexCmd('delta'), ' b\nT &=& T_0 + ', TexCmd('delta'), ' T .\n'], []), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla')], []), ' denotes the covariant derivative with respect to the full boundary metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' which is equal to a background ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' plus perturbation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['H_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', while ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_0'], []), ' is the temperature of the background black brane. \n\nContributions of the metric in which the derivative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla')], []), '  appears can be re-written as covariant derivatives of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-1'], []), ' velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v_i'], []), ' and the metric perturbation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A_i = H_', BraceGroup('0i')], []), ' with respect to the spatial part of the background metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ', ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' i.e.'), '\n', TexNamedEnv('eqnarray', ['\n', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_iu_j &=& ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_iv_j + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4)', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_iu_0 + ', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_0u_i &=& ', TexCmd('partial'), '_0(v_i + A_i) - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('partial'), '_i h_', BraceGroup('00'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('partial'), '_i(v_jv^j) - v^jF_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4)', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '&=& ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_jv^j + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4)', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nu^', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_0 &=& ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4) \nu^', TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('bar'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_i &=& ', TexCmd('partial'), '_0(v_i + A_i) - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('partial'), '_i h_', BraceGroup('00'), ' + (v^j', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j)v_i - v^jF_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4)', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \nF_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' ', '&=&  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_i A_j - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_j A_i . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('derivates')]), '\n'], []), '\nNow ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla')], []), ' is the covariant derivative with respect to the background metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '. The raising and lowering of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup('i,j')], []), ' indices is to be performed using the metric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '. To simplify the expression of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('derivates')]), ' the constraint ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_i v^i = 0'], []), ' has been used.\n\nSubstituting in the metric, the first order part takes the form\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nds_1^2 &= b_0 r^2 F(b_0 r)(', TexCmd('nabla'), '_iv_j + ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j v_i)dx^i dx^j - 2 b_0 r^2 F(b_0 r)v^j(', TexCmd('nabla'), '_iv_j + ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j v_i)dt~dx^i\n& +2r (', TexCmd('partial'), '_0(v_i + A_i) - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('partial'), '_i h_', BraceGroup('00'), ' - v^j F_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' + (v^j', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j)v_i)dt~dx^i + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('cal'), ' O'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), '^4)\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere the first term is of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2'], []), ' and the last two terms are of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3'], []), '. The constraint equation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_i v^i = 0'], []), ', was used to cancel out contributions from the scalar sector. \n\nAlso the zeroth order metric can be expanded in powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), '. One finds that to solve Einstein equation up to order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^3'], []), ', it is sufficient to expand the zeroth order metric up to order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2'], []), ' in the fluctuations. The result is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexNamedEnv('split', ['\nds_0^2 &= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b_0^d r^', BraceGroup('d-2'))]), ' dt^2 + r^2(-dt^2 + g_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' dx^i dx^j)  + 2 dt~ dr\n&- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('b_0^dr^', BraceGroup('d-2'))]), '(A_i + v_i)dt~ dx^i - 2(A_i + v_i)dx^i dr\n&+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b_0^', BraceGroup('d+1'), 'r^', BraceGroup('d-2'))]), '(-d~', TexCmd('delta'), ' b + v_jv^j - h_', BraceGroup('00'), ')dt^2 \n&+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^', BraceGroup('d-2'))]), '(A_i + v_i)(A_j + v_j)dx^idx^j  - (-v_jv^j + h_', BraceGroup('00'), ')dt~dr\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nwhere the first line is of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^0'], []), ', the second line is of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^1'], []), ' and the third and the fourth are of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon'), '^2'], []), '.\n\nIt is possible to show by a direct calculation that the proposed metric solves Einsteins equations up to the third order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ',  provided that the velocity and temperature fields above obey the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('NS')]), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '.\n\nAn important observation arises from the equation that determines ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' T'], []), ' ', '(and hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' b'], []), ')\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 T'), BraceGroup('T_0')]), ' = -', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i v^j ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j v^i - v^i v^j R_', BraceGroup('ij'), '  \n+ ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_i ', '[', ' ', '( -', TexCmd('nu'), ' R^i_j + F^i_j ) v^j ', ']', ' +\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 h_', BraceGroup('00'), ' - ', TexCmd('partial'), '_0 (', TexCmd('nabla'), '. A)  . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n'], []), '\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta'), ' T'], []), ' is a spatially nonlocal but temporally ultralocal functional of the velocity fields ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v^i'], []), '. Therefore, even though the bulk metric at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is \ndetermined locally as a function of temperatures and velocities at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ', it is not determined locally as a function of velocities at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), '. This nonlocality is a consequence of the infinite speed of sound in the scaling limit.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('chapter', [BraceGroup('Matter and Gravity')]), '\n', '\n', '\nIn this chapter we will discuss some techniques and issues that are relevant to the study of black holes and singular hypersurfaces in gravity.\n\nIn particular we will start by reviewing various possible ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' energy conditions'), ' that enter in black holes physics ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hawking:1973uf, Wald:1984rg')]), '. Then we discuss the issue of the violation of the loosest among these condition, the null energy condition, and its physical consequences ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hsu:2004vr, Dubovsky:2005xd, Buniy:2005vh')]), '.\n\nLater on we will introduce some geometric notions useful in the description of hypersurfaces and in particular the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' extrinsic curvature'), ". These concepts will be used in applying Israel's seminal work on singular hypersurfaces ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ' to the configuration that we will present in the next chapter. \n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Energy conditions')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Energysec')]), '\n', "\nIn general relativity, an energy condition is one of various alternative conditions which can be applied to the matter content to define some of its properties. Since almost every spacetime is a possible solution to Einstein's equations for some particular choice of energy-momentum tensor ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ', it is important to understand what general restrictions can hold on the energy-momentum of a physical system and which are their implications. Indeed, energy conditions play a critical role in the study of black holes and cosmological singularities,  entering in important theorems such as the no hair theorem and the laws of black hole thermodynamics ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hawking:1973uf, Wald:1984rg')]), '.
