Moreover, even though a violation of an energy condition does not necessarily imply a pathology in a physical system, the violation of the null energy condition has been related to the insurgence of instabilities and superluminal propagation (one can see ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' e.g.'), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hsu:2004vr, Dubovsky:2005xd, Buniy:2005vh')]), ').\n\n\nLet us start  with the weak energy condition. \n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Weak energy condition')]), ': The energy-momentum tensor at each point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' on a manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' M')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' M')])], []), ', obeys the inequality \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' w^', TexCmd('mu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  ,\n'], []), '\nfor any timelike vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' in the tangent space at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w ', TexCmd('in'), ' T_p'], []), '. By continuity this will also be true for any null vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w ', TexCmd('in'), ' T_p'], []), '.'), '\n', '\n', '\nThe weak energy condition is equivalent to the statement that the energy density of any matter distribution, as measured by any observer in spacetime, must be nonnegative. Indeed, for an observer whose world line at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' has unit tangent ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ', the local energy density is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' V^', TexCmd('mu'), ' V^', TexCmd('nu')], []), '. \n\nFollowing ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hawking:1973uf')]), ', we will explore more in depth the meaning of this assumption using the fact that it is possible to cast the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['4'], []), '-dimensional stress tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' in four canonical forms, with respect to an orthonormal basis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', ' ', TexCmd('bf', [BraceGroup('e_0, e_1, e_2, e_3')]), '\\}'], []), '.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Type', '\\,', '\\,', ' I')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' \nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '=\n', TexNamedEnv('bmatrix', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', '& 0 & 0  & 0 \n0 & p_1 & 0  & 0  \n0 & 0 & p_2 & 0  \n0 & 0 & 0  & p_3 \n'], []), '\n'], []), ' \nIn this case, the stress tensor has a unique timelike eigenvector (unless ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '= -p_i'], []), ', (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i = 1,2,3'], []), ')). ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' is the energy-density measured by an observer whose world line has unit tangent vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e_0')], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ', while the three eigenvectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' are the pressures in the three spacelike direction spanned by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('bf'), ' e_i')], []), ' ', '(', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i = 1,2,3'], []), ')', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('As discussed in chapter 2, if the stress tensor is that of a perfect fluid, then the pressures in the spacelike directions are equal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1=p_2=p_3=p'], []), '.')]), '. The energy-momentum tensor can be cast in this form for fields with non-zero rest mass and for some zero rest mass fields, except those of the Type II.\n\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Type', '\\,', '\\,', ' II')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '=\n', TexNamedEnv('bmatrix', ['\n', TexCmd('nu'), ' +', TexCmd('kappa'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '& 0  & 0 \n', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('nu'), ' -', TexCmd('kappa'), ' ', '& 0  & 0  \n0 & 0 & p_1 & 0  \n0 & 0 & 0  & p_2 \n'], []), '\n ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  ', TexCmd('nu'), ' = ', TexCmd('pm'), ' 1\n'], []), ' \nIn this case, the stress tensor has a double null eigenvector (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bf', [BraceGroup('e_0+e_1')])], []), '). The stress tensor has this form in the case of radiation traveling in the direction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bf', [BraceGroup('e_0+e_1')])], []), '. In this case ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_2'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('kappa')], []), ' are zero.\n\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Type', '\\,', '\\,', ' III')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' \nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '=\n', TexNamedEnv('bmatrix', ['\n', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '& 0 & 0  & 0 \n0 & - ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '& 1  & 1  \n0 & 1 & -', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '& 0  \n0 & 1 & 0  & p \n'], []), '\n'], []), '\nThe stress tensor of this type has a triple null eigenvector (', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bf', [BraceGroup('e_0+e_1')])], []), '). Actually there is no observed field of this kind.\n\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Type', '\\,', '\\,', ' IV')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' \nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '=\n', TexNamedEnv('bmatrix', ['\n0 & ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '& 0  & 0 \n', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', '& - ', TexCmd('kappa'), ' ', '& 0  & 0  \n0 & 0 & p_1 & 0  \n0 & 0 & 0  & p_2 \n'], []), '\n', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('kappa'), '^2 < 4 ', TexCmd('nu'), '^2\n'], []), '\nThis stress tensor corresponds to the case in which there is no timelike or null eigenvector. No field of this type has been observed.\n\nThe week energy condition holds for type I under conditions\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0 ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ' + p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0 ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('for')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  i = 1,2,3  ;\n'], []), '\nand for type II if\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\np_1 ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_2 ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('kappa'), TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  ,', TexCmd('qquad'), '  ', TexCmd('nu'), ' = +1  ;\n'], []), '\nwhile it does not hold for type III and IV.\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Dominant energy condition (A)')]), ': The energy-momentum tensor at each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' M')])], []), ', obeys the inequality \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' w^', TexCmd('mu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  ,\n'], []), '\nfor any future directed timelike vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w ', TexCmd('in'), ' T_p'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' is a future directed non-spacelike vector.'), '\n', '\n', '\nThe dominant energy condition embodies the notion that matter should flow along timelike or null worldlines. It may also be interpreted stating that to any observer the local energy density should appear nonnegative and the local energy flow should be non-spacelike. It is possible to restate the dominant energy condition as:\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Dominant energy condition (B)')]), ': In any orthonormal basis the energy dominates the other components of the stress tensor\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT^', BraceGroup('00'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' |T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '| ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('for any')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('mu'), ', ', TexCmd('nu'), ')  .\n'], []), '\n'), '\n', '\n', '\nThis condition holds for type I if\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0 ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  - ', TexCmd('rho'), ' ', TexCmd('leq'), ' p_i ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), '  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('for')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  i = 1,2,3  ;\n'], []), '\nwhile it holds for type II under the conditions\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nu'), ' = +1 , ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  ', TexCmd('kappa'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' 0 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' p_1 ', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('kappa'), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('for')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  i = 1,2   ;\n'], []), '\nand again it does not hold for type III and IV. Therefore the dominant energy condition, in addition to requirement of the weak energy condition, states that the pressure should not exceed the energy density.\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Strong energy condition')]), ': The energy-momentum tensor at each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' M')])], []), ', obeys the inequality \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '(T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'T g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ')w^', TexCmd('mu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  ,\n'], []), '\nfor any future directed normailsed timelike vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w ', TexCmd('in'), ' T_p'], []), '.'), '\n', '\n', '\nSince the Einstein equation implies \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' T g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('8', TexCmd('pi'))]), ' R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '\n'], []), '\nthe strong energy condition is a statement about the Ricci tensor.\n\nThe strong energy condition holds in type I for\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^3 p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ' + p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0 ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('for')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' i=1,2,3  ,\n'], []), '\nand for Type II if\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nu'), ' = +1, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('kappa'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_1', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0,  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_2', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  .\n'], []), '\nIt is useful to notice that this condition does not imply the weak one. \n\n\nIn presence of a cosmological constant term, the strong energy condition is known as ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' the null convergence condition'), '. In this case the statement is simply modified to \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '(T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'T g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('8', TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('Lambda'), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ')w^', TexCmd('mu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  .\n'], []), '\nThe conditions for type one now are \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^3 p_i - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('Lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ' + p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0 ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('for')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' i=1,2,3  ,\n'], []), '\nand for Type II read\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nu'), ' = +1, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('kappa'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_1', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0,  ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_2', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' p_1+p_2 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('pi'))]), TexCmd('Lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe weakest requirements on the stress tensor are formulated in the null energy condition.\n\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ', TexCmd('textbf', [BraceGroup('Null energy condition (NEC)')]), ': The energy-momentum tensor at each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p ', TexCmd('in', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' M')])], []), ', obeys the inequality \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' k^', TexCmd('mu'), ' k^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  ,\n'], []), '\nfor any future directed null vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k ', TexCmd('in'), ' T_p'], []), '.'), '\n', '\n', '\nThe null energy condition holds for type I under the condition\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' + p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0 ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('for')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  i= 1,2,3  ,\n'], []), '\nand for type II if\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('nu'), ' = +1, ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), '+', TexCmd('kappa'), '+p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0 ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' i=1,2  .\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nIt is easy to convince oneself that the null energy condition is implied by both strong and weak conditions, while the weak one is implied by the dominant energy condition. Relations among different energy conditions are summarised in the following diagram:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('empheq', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('qquad'), ' .\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n', '\\,', ' ', '& ', '\\,', ' ', '& ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Strong E.C.')]), ' \n', '\\,', ' ', '& ', '\\,', ' ', '& ', '\\,', ' \n', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Dominant E.C.')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('Longrightarrow'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Weak E.C.')]), ' \n'], [BraceGroup('ccc')]), '\n', '\\}', ' ', '\\,', ' ', '\\,', ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Longrightarrow'), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('Null E.C.')]), ' ', TexCmd('qquad'), '\n', '\n'], [BracketGroup('box=\n', TexCmd('fbox')), BraceGroup('align*')]), '\n', '\n', '\nIn table 4.1 we summarise energy conditions and their associated constraints on type I stress tensors. The discussion above - that we carried on in 4 dimensions - can be easily generalised to higher dimensional spaces. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('table', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('tabular', ['\n', TexCmd('toprule'), '\nName & Statement & Conditions for Type I \n', TexCmd('midrule'), '\nWeak & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' w^', TexCmd('mu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0, ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ' + p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ' \nDominant &', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' future directed & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0, ', '\\,', '   | ', TexCmd('rho'), ' | ', TexCmd('geq'), ' p_i'], []), ' \nStrong & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'T g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ')w^', TexCmd('mu'), ' w^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^3 p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0, ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('rho'), ' + p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ' \nNull & ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' k^', TexCmd('mu'), ' k^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ' ', '& ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), ' + p_i ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'], []), ' \n', TexCmd('bottomrule'), '\n'], [BraceGroup('lcc')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('Energy conditions.')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('tb')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Violation of the null energy condition')]), '\n', '\nEnergy conditions are typically fulfilled by classical fields. However it is well known that they can be violated by quantized matter fields. The most common example is the Casimir vacuum energy between two conduction plates separated by a distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('delta')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), ' = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), '^2'), BraceGroup('720')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('hbar')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('delta'), '^4')]), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nIn this kind of situation ione usually formulates an averaged version of the energy conditions. Indeed, for each of the energy conditions listed in the previous section it is possible to formulate a corresponding averaged version. Average energy condition requirements of non-negativity must hold only on average along the flowlines of the appropriate vector fields. For example  the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' averaged null energy condition'), ' states that the integral along a null geodesic ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' k^', TexCmd('mu'), ' k^', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' must be non-negative\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', TexCmd('gamma'), ' T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' k^', TexCmd('mu'), ' k^', TexCmd('nu'), ' d', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0  .\n'], []), '\nThis condition holds for noninteracting scalar and electromagnetic fields in arbitrary quantum states; this is true even though ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' k^', TexCmd('mu'), ' k^', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' may be locally negative.\n\n\nEven though, in some cases energy conditions are violated (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' e.g.'), ' the strong energy condition may be violated in some inflation scenarios), it is generally believed that any well behaved physical systems should respect at least the null energy condition. In various settings it has been been shown that the violation of the null energy condition results in the insurgence of instabilities in the system sourcing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Hsu:2004vr, Dubovsky:2005xd')]), '. \n\nFor example, in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Dubovsky:2005xd')]), ' the authors showed that classical solutions of both minimally and non-minimally coupled scalar-gauge models which violate the null energy condition are unstable. Moreover it was also proven that perfect fluids which violate the NEC are unstable. Finally quantum states in which the expectation of the energy-momentum tensor violates the NEC cannot be the ground state, including models with fermions. On the basis of these results, it seems that physically interesting cases of violation of the null energy condition are likely to be ephemeral.\n\t\t\nIn ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Buniy:2005vh')]), ' the authors studied systems of derivatively coupled scalar fields with coordinate dependent condensates, without taking into account gravitational back-reactions. In this setting it was suggested that a violation of the null energy condition does not strictly imply instabilities - such as ghosts or imaginary frequencies - in the system. Indeed, it was proven that there may exist an acceptable effective field theory with a positive definite Hamiltonian for quadratic perturbations around a background whose energy momentum violates the null energy condition. It turns out that a necessary feature of such a model is the anisotropy of the background and the presence of superluminal modes. More generally it was suggested that  for systems that are either isotropic or do not feature superluminality, a violation of the null energy condition always implies an unescapable instability.  In the next chapter we will be interested in two nonisotropic backgrounds which both violate the (averaged) null energy condition on a hypersurface.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Some notions on hypersurfaces')]), '\n', '\nLet us introduce some notation and some concepts related to the study of hypersurfaces in General Relativity ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Misner:1974qy')]), '. We will introduce concepts in four dimensions. These can be readily generalised to higher dimensions.\n\nConsider a curve parametrised by a parameter ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau')], []), ' on  a four-dimensional Riemannian manifold ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' of class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C^4'], []), '. The covariant derivative of a smooth vector function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' defined on this curve will be denoted (we adopt the notation of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Weinberg')]), ') as:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D A^', TexCmd('mu'), '(', TexCmd('tau'), ')'), BraceGroup('D ', TexCmd('tau'))]), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d A^', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup('d ', TexCmd('tau'))]), ' + A^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d x^', TexCmd('nu')), BraceGroup('d ', TexCmd('tau'))]), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A^', TexCmd('mu'), '(u, v)'], []), ' is defined on a two-space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = x^', TexCmd('mu'), '(u, v)'], []), ', the standard definition of the Riemann tensor spells out \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' A^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = R^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('kappa')), ' A^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^', TexCmd('lambda')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' u')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^', TexCmd('kappa')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' v')]), '  ,\n'], [BracketGroup(' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D ', '\\,', '\\,'), BraceGroup('D v')]), ', ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('D ', '\\,', '\\,'), BraceGroup('D u')]), ' ')]), '\n', '\nNow, let us consider a smooth hypersurface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('M')])], []), ' with unit normal \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nn', TexCmd('cdot'), ' n = ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(n) = \n', '\\{', '\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n+1 & ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('spacelike')]), ' ', '\\,', ' n \n-1 & ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('timelike')]), ' ', '\\,', ' n \n'], [BraceGroup('lc')]), '\n.  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nAn infinitesimal displacement on the hypersurface can be expressed in terms of the intrinsic coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '^i'], []), ' as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['s = e_', BraceGroup('(i)'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' d'), TexCmd('xi'), '^i  ,\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('rm'), ' d')]), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('(i)')], []), ' are a natural set of independent tangent vectors associated with the intrinsic coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '^i'], []), '. In terms of the system of coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\\{', 'x^', TexCmd('mu'), '\\}'], []), ' defined on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V'], []), ', the vector  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('(i)')], []), ' can be expressed as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\ne_', BraceGroup('(i)'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^', TexCmd('mu')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '^i')]), ' .\n'], []), '\nIn what follows we will write explicitly 4-dimensional indices only when necessary, otherwise leaving them implicit to avoid confusion. \n\nGiven a tangent vector function lying in the hypersurface, it is possible to define intrinsic components as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nA = A^i ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(i)'), '  ,\n'], []), '\nThe scalar product of this vector with the base vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('(j)')], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '(A ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(j)'), ') = A^i (e_', BraceGroup('(i)'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(j)'), ') = A^i g_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = A_j  ,\n'], []), '\nwhere the metric three tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' was introduced.\n\nThe covariant derivative of the vector A in the direction ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('(i)')], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '^', BraceGroup('(4)'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup('e_', BraceGroup('(i)')), ' A = ^', BraceGroup('(4)'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_i A = ^', BraceGroup('(4)'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup('e_', BraceGroup('(i)')), ' ', '(e_j A^j) = e_j ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' A^j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^i')]), '+ (^', BraceGroup('(4)'), TexCmd('Gamma'), '^', TexCmd('mu'), '_', BraceGroup('ji'), ' e_', TexCmd('mu'), ') A^j  \n'], []), '\nwhere we used the notation ``', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('(4)')], []), "'' to make evident the dimension of the spacetime in which objects are defined. Indeed, the above definition has components  ``out of the hypersurface''. \n\nTo get a covariant derivative defined intrinsically to the 3-dimensional hypersurface it is necessary to project the above derivative orthogonally onto ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '. In this way one gets\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nA_', BraceGroup('h|i'), ' ', TexCmd('equiv'), ' e_h', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('(3)'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_', BraceGroup('e_', BraceGroup('(i)')), ' A = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' A_h'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^i')]), ' - A^m ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('m,hi'), '  .\n'], []), ' \n', '\nThe connection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('m,hi')], []), ' in three dimensions can be expressed in terms of the basis vector and of the metric 3-tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup('ij'), '=e_', BraceGroup('(i)'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(i)')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('3gamma')]), '\n', '^', BraceGroup('(3)'), TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('m,hi'), ' = e_', BraceGroup('(m)'), ' ', TexCmd('cdot'), '  ', '^', BraceGroup('(3)'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_i e_', BraceGroup('(h)'), '  .\n'], []), '\nGiven this definition, it is evident that intrinsic covariant derivatives and the associated intrinsic Riemann 3-tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R^i_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' jmn')], []), ' do not depend on the nature of the embedding and are therefore invariant under changes of the embedding space that preserve the intrinsic metric on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '.\n\nWe are now in a position to define the notion of ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' extrinsic curvature'), ', that can be seen as a description of the curvature of a slice of the 3-geometry relative to that of the 4-geometry. This is measured by the covariant variation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['^', BraceGroup('(4)'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_i n'], []), ' of the unit normal. In components the extrinsic curvature is defined', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('In the definition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' we adopt the sign convention of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ', which is opposite to that in  ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Misner:1974qy')]))]), ' by \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '^', BraceGroup('(4)'), TexCmd('nabla'), '_i n = K_i^', BraceGroup('\\,', ' j'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(j)'), ' .\n'], []), '\nTaking the scalar product of this definition with the basis vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('(m)')], []), ' and remembering that \n', TexDisplayMathModeEnv('$$', ['e_', BraceGroup('(m)'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' n=0'], []), '\nby definition, we get\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ksym')]), '\nK_', BraceGroup('im'), '=K_i^', BraceGroup('\\,', ' j'), 'g_', BraceGroup('jm'), ' = e_', BraceGroup('m'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' n'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '^i')]), '= - n ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' e_', BraceGroup('m')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '^i')]), ' =- n ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' e_', BraceGroup('i')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '^m')]), ' = K_', BraceGroup('ji'), '  ,\n'], []), '\nthat spells out the symmetry properties of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), '.\n\nThe Gauss-Weingarten equations can be derived directly form (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('3gamma')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ksym')]), ')\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' e_', BraceGroup('i')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', TexCmd('xi'), '^i')]), '  = - ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(n) K_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' n + ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^h_', BraceGroup('ij'), 'e_', BraceGroup('(h)'), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nIt is possible to work out a different expression relating the extrinsic curvature to the standard Riemann tensor. Particularly useful are the equations of Gauss and Codazzi:\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '& ^', BraceGroup('(4)'), 'R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta')), ' e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(b)'), '^', TexCmd('beta'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(c)'), '^', TexCmd('gamma'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(d)'), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' = ^', BraceGroup('(3)'), 'R_', BraceGroup('abcd'), ' + K_', BraceGroup('ac'), ' K_', BraceGroup('bd'), ' - K_', BraceGroup('bc'), 'K_', BraceGroup('ad'), ' , \n& ^', BraceGroup('(4)'), 'R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('delta')), ' n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(b)'), '^', TexCmd('beta'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(c)'), '^', TexCmd('gamma'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(d)'), '^', TexCmd('delta'), ' = K_', BraceGroup('bd|c'), '-K_', BraceGroup('bc|d'), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('codazzo')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nEquations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('codazzo')]), ') can be contracted using respectively ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g^', BraceGroup('bc'), ' g^', BraceGroup('ad')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g^', BraceGroup('bd')], []), ' and observing that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\ng^', BraceGroup('bc'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(b)'), '^', TexCmd('beta'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(c)'), '^', TexCmd('gamma'), ' = g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('beta'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma')), ' - ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(n) n^', TexCmd('beta'), ' n^', TexCmd('gamma'), '  . \n'], []), '\nThe contracted versions of the equations of Gauss and Codazzi are\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n- 2 ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', '(n) ^', BraceGroup('(4)'), 'G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', '&= ^', BraceGroup('(3)'), 'R + K_', BraceGroup('ab'), 'K^', BraceGroup('ab'), '- K^2  , \n^', BraceGroup('(4)'), 'G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', '&= K^b_', BraceGroup('a|b'), '- K_', BraceGroup('|a'), ' ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('codazzi')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K= g^', BraceGroup('ab'), 'K_', BraceGroup('ab')], []), ' and all terms are independent of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' coordinates.\n\nConsider now a 3-tensor field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('ab')], []), ' living on the hypersurface ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ', it is possible to define an associated 4-dimensional discontinuous vector 4-tensor as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nS^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' =\n', '\\{', '\n ', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n S^', BraceGroup('ab'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' e_', BraceGroup('(b)'), '^', TexCmd('beta'), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('on')]), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), ' \n 0 & ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('off')]), ' ', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('Sigma'), ' \n '], [BraceGroup('lc')]), '\n .  ,\n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Sext')]), '\n'], []), '\nthen we have\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nablaesse')]), '\n', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' S^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' = e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' S^', BraceGroup('ab'), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '|b'), '-', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(n)S^', BraceGroup('ab'), 'K_', BraceGroup('ab'), 'n^', TexCmd('alpha'), '  \n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' is the standard covariant derivative defined on the coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('mu')], []), '.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BracketGroup('Singular hypersurfaces'), BraceGroup('Singular hypersurfaces  in General Relativity')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Israelsec')]), '\n', '\nAn important issue in gravitational theory is the formulation of correct junction conditions at surfaces of discontinuity. These surfaces can be characterised by a jump discontinuity in the density, such as ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' boundary layers'), ' or  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' shock waves'), '; or by the fact that the density become infinity, as happens for ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' surface layers'), '. In Newtonian gravitation, one has to set a system of coordinates which has to be ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' a priori'), " well defined, supplemented by the appropriate continuity  and jump conditions connecting the potential and its first derivatives across the surface. In Einstein's theory of gravitation, the issue is more complicated. Indeed, the smoothness of the gravitational potential ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))], []), ' is determined by the smoothness of the physical conditions ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' and'), ' by the smoothness of the coordinates one chooses to describe the space-time manifold ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ". The problem is therefore made more subtle by the necessity of distinguishing between the physical discontinuity and spurious ``bumps'' that may arise from an unhappy choice of coordinates.\n\nLet us define in a more precise form the classification of  surfaces of discontinuity. Let us focus on a hypersurface ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' which separates the spacetime in two four-dimensional manifolds ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), '. Moreover we assume that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), ' are both  of class ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C^4'], []), ' and contain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' as part of their boundaries. The normal ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ', that we can choose to be directed from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), ', is assumed to be spacelike everywhere. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^-_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^+_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' be the two extrinsic curvatures of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' associated respectively with embeddings ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), '.\n\nGiven extrinsic curvatures, we can give a definition of singular hypersurfaces  independent of the choice of four-dimensional coordinates. We define, ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' singular hypersurfaces of higher order'), ' surfaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' for which everywhere\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nK^-_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = K^+_', BraceGroup('ij'), '  ,\n'], []), '\nand  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' singular hypersurfaces of order one'), '  or histories of a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' surface layer'), ' as those surfaces ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' for which\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nK^-_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' ', TexCmd('neq'), ' K^+_', BraceGroup('ij'), '  .\n'], []), '\nIn particular, (the histories of)  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' boundary layers'), ' are part of the class of the  ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' singular hypersurfaces of higher order'), ' that contain also all of the regular hypersurfaces.\n\nThe case of boundary surfaces can be rapidly assessed. From eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('codazzi')]), ') we find\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n. G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta'), '|^-= . G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta'), '|^+  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' . G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta'), '|^-= . G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta'), '|^+  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('boudsurf')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere we considered the limits of the function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' n^', TexCmd('beta')], []), ' at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ', and we used the fact that the expressions (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('codazzi')]), ') have a continuous right hand side across ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '. Equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('boudsurf')]), ') establish identities between terms that may be evaluated distinctly in two independently chosen 4-dimensional coordinate systems on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), '. It is interesting to notice that there is no requirement about the continuous matching of charts ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_+'], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '. The only requirement about the two charts is that, given the set of intrinsic coordinates ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('xi'), '^i'], []), ', the equations of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nx_-^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' = f(', TexCmd('xi'), '^1, ', TexCmd('xi'), '^2, ', TexCmd('xi'), '^3)  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), ' x_+^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' = g^', TexCmd('alpha'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), '^1, ', TexCmd('xi'), '^2, ', TexCmd('xi'), '^3)  ,\n'], []), '\nmust be formulated in terms of two ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C^4'], []), ' functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f^', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g^', TexCmd('alpha')], []), '. \n\nThe case of a ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' surface layer'), ' is more interesting. We start by defining the non-vanishing 3-tensor\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gammaij')]), '\n', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = K^+_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' - K^-_', BraceGroup('ij'), '   .\n'], []), '\nIn terms of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' it is possible to define the ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' surface energy tensor'), ' of the layer, as', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('As before we set the Newton constant and the speed of light in vacuum equal to one, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G= c = 1'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n8 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' S_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' =  - ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' + g_', BraceGroup('ij'), TexCmd('gamma'), '_k^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', 'k'), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('esse')]), '\n'], []), '\nEq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('esse')]), ') can be reformulated as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gamma2')]), '\n', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), '= - 8 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', '(S_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' g_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' S )  ,\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S= S_k^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', 'k')], []), '.\n\nFor a surface layer in vacuo ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '=0'], []), ' both in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), ', therefore equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('codazzi')]), ') are reduced to constraints on the extrinsic curvature:\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '^', BraceGroup('(3)'), 'R+ K_', BraceGroup('ab'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), 'K^', BraceGroup('ab'), '_', TexCmd('pm'), ' -K^2_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), ' ', '&= 0  , \n (K^', TexCmd('pm'), ')^', BraceGroup('b'), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', 'a|b'), ' - K^', TexCmd('pm'), '_', BraceGroup('|a'), ' ', '&= 0  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('constK')]), '\n'], []), '\n ', '\nAfter some manipulations  eq (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('constK')]), ') can be recast as the following group of constraints:\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Szero')]), '\nS^', BraceGroup('ab'), '_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '\\,', '|b'), ' ', '&=0  , \n ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '^b_', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' a|b'), ' -', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '_', BraceGroup('|a'), '  ', '&= 0  , \n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Szero2')]), '\n ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '_', BraceGroup('ab'), ' S^', BraceGroup('ab'), ' ', '&= 0  , \n^', BraceGroup('(3)'), 'R+ ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '_', BraceGroup('ab'), TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '^', BraceGroup('ab'), ' - ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '^2 & = - 16 ', TexCmd('pi'), '^2 (S_', BraceGroup('ab'), 'S^', BraceGroup('ab'), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' S^2)  ,\n'], []), '\nwhere \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', [' \n ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '_', BraceGroup('ab'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '(K_', BraceGroup('ab'), '^+K_', BraceGroup('ab'), '^-)  , ', TexCmd('qquad'), '   ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), ' = g^', BraceGroup('ab'), '  ', TexCmd('widetilde', [BraceGroup('K')]), '_', BraceGroup('ab'), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nGiven two independent charts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), ', respectively ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('alpha'), '_+'], []), ', we can define, using eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sext')]), '), 4-dimensional extensions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^', TexCmd('pm'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('ab')], []), ' in the two domains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^', TexCmd('pm')], []), '. Hence, we can reformulate condition (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Szero')]), ') using relation (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nablaesse')]), ') as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Scondizioni')]), '\n. e_', BraceGroup('(a)'), '^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' S_', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '|^', TexCmd('pm'), ' = 0  ,  ', TexCmd('qquad'), '  . n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' S_', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '|^', TexCmd('pm'), ' = - K_', BraceGroup('ab'), '^', TexCmd('pm'), ' S^', BraceGroup('ab'), '  .\n'], []), '\nFinally, using equations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gamma2')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Szero2')]), ') we find\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', '& .. n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' S_', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '|^+ + n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' S_', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '|^- = 0  , \n& .. n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' S_', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '|^+ - n^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('beta'), ' S_', TexCmd('alpha'), '^', BraceGroup('\\,', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '|^- =   8 ', TexCmd('pi'), '  ', '(S_', BraceGroup('ab'), 'S^', BraceGroup('ab'), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' S^2 )  ,\n'], []), '\nthat can be seen as the relativistic analogues of the Newtonian formula for the normal components of mechanical force due to self-attraction of the two faces of a plane layer of surface density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ':\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), ' F^- ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' n = - ', TexCmd('sigma'), ' F^+ ', TexCmd('cdot'), ' n = 2 ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^2  .\n'], []), '\nThe tangential force, on the contrary cancels out, in agreement with the first equation of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Scondizioni')]), ').\n\n\nWe can conclude this section by giving a heuristic argument for the definition of the surface energy tensor (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('esse')]), '). Let us consider a layer of finite thickness ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), ' separating the two vacuum regions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), ' and having respective boundaries ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^+'], []), '. It is useful to introduce ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' Gaussian coordinates'), ' ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^', TexCmd('alpha')], []), ', based on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^-'], []), ' by setting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^i = ', TexCmd('xi'), '^i'], []), ', and letting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^0'], []), ' equal the geodesic distance normal to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^-'], []), ', taken with sign plus or minus respectively for points in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^+'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['V^-'], []), '. With these coordinate, the equations for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma'), '^', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' are respectively ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^1=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^1=', TexCmd('varepsilon')], []), '. Moreover, for a 3-space ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x^1= ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('cost')]), '.'], []), ', one finds the following expression for the extrinsic curvature\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nK_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', '^', BraceGroup('(4)'), 'g_', BraceGroup('ij')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^1')]), '  ,\n'], []), '\nwhile \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', '^', BraceGroup('(4)'), 'R_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' K_', BraceGroup('ij')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^1')]), ' + Z_', BraceGroup('ij'), '  ,\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('riccilayer')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' is defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nZ_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = ^', BraceGroup('(3)'), 'R_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' - K K_', BraceGroup('ij'), '+ 2 K^h_i K_', BraceGroup('hj'), '  .\n'], []), '\n', "\nAt this point it is possible integrate Einstein's field equation over the layer\n", TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nR_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' = -  8 ', TexCmd('pi'), '  ', '(T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' T  )  .\n'], []), '\nRemembering expression (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('riccilayer')]), ') one gets\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n-  8 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '  ', '(T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' T  ) dx^1 = K^+_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' -  K^-_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' + ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' Z_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' dx^1  .\n'], []), '\nIn the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'], []), ', for given values of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^', TexCmd('pm'), '_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ', if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' remains bounded in the layer then the integral of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Z_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' over the layer will converge to zero. Hence ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' defined in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('esse')]), ') is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nS_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = ', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' ', TexCmd('to'), ' 0'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('varepsilon'), ' T_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' dx^1  ,\n'], []), '\nor in other words, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' is the integral of the stress tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' over the surface layer. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('chapter', [BraceGroup('The Surface Layers Dual to Hydrodynamic Boundaries')]), '\n', '\n', '\nThe AdS/hydrodynamics correspondence provides a 1-1 map between large wavelength features of AdS black branes and conformal fluid flows, so long as the fluid variables are constant over distances large compared with the inverse temperature.  For example progress towards gravity duals of shock waves and vortices has appeared in Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('shock')]), ' and ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('vortices')]), '.  A case of particular interest is represented by gravity duals to turbulent flows.  Turbulence is generic in fluid flows under a wide range of conditions.  The dual of these fluid conditions then provides some condition on a gravity solution under which it to generically decays into a turbulent configuration.  An example of such a situation was presented in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008ji')]), '.  It would of course be interesting to characterize the gravity duals of turbulent flows, and of the conditions under which turbulence may be expected.  In hydrodynamics, even the most basic scaling laws are altered by turbulence.  If gravitational solutions near, for example, spacelike singularities (where indeed chaotic evolution is expected ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('BKL')]), ") or certain event horizons do generically decay to turbulent solutions, it would be difficult to overstate the potential consequences for, for example, the horizon problem.\n\nPerhaps the best understood turbulence is steady state turbulence, in which energy is injected into a system at the same rate at which it dissipates.  Richardson's cascade model ", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rich')]), ' of steady (3+1)-dimensional turbulence is as follows.  Energy is injected into a system at large characteristic distance scales, for example, a lake warms the air.  This creates large vortices, which decay into smaller vortices.  Thus the energy flows to smaller distance scales.  At sufficiently small distance scales, higher order derivative terms in the equations of motion become relevant, such as viscosity terms.  These lead to dissipation of the energy in sufficiently small vortices.  Thus energy cascades from the long length scale in which it is introduced, down to the dissipation scale.\n\nTo realize steady state turbulence, one needs to inject energy into a system.  There are two principal ways to do this.  First, one may deform the fluid via external perturbations.  Second, one may apply boundary conditions, for example one may consider fluid flow in a pipe or wind tunnel.  The first approach was applied to the AdS/hydrodynamics correspondence in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008ji')]), ', where it was argued that a laminar fluid flow and the dual gravity solution decay to turbulent configurations.  This approach has the disadvantage that solutions are quite complicated, due to the necessarily inhomogeneous forcing and to the geometric implementation of the forcing on the gravity side.  \n\nIn what follows we will take a preliminary step towards a realization of the second approach to creating steady state turbulence, we will investigate boundary conditions in the AdS/hydrodynamic correspondence.  For simplicity, we will consider nonrelativistic, incompressible flows.  Consider the surface which separates a solid object from such a fluid.  The normal velocity of the fluid into the solid must vanish.  If furthermore the fluid is viscous, as fluids in the AdS/hydrodynamics correspondence are ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('D1979')]), ', then the tangential relative velocity of the fluid must also vanish.\n\nWhat does this correspond to on the gravity side?  The answer to this question is not necessarily unique, one may define a dual and then attempt to understand its dynamics.  One interesting case, which is already sufficient to generate turbulence, is a solid which is a thin, infinite sheet with a stationary fluid on the left side and a moving fluid on the right.  In this case a natural choice would be to consider the gravity duals of both fluids and then to attempt to glue them together.  Equivalently one may choose to think of the entirety of the left side as a solid wall, filling the left half of spacetime, and a liquid filling the right half.  The wall is stationary and so one chooses the dual to be a stationary black brane in half of AdS.  Whatever one chooses to think, the logic is that one imposes that the left half of the gravity dual be a static black brane in AdS, and that the right side be the gravity dual given by the prescription of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '.\n\nSo how does one glue these two vacuum gravity solutions together?  Clearly there are many inequivalent choices.  One possibility is to simply attach them and then use the Israel matching conditions ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ' to determine the stress tensor on the surface layer that separates the two sides.  This is equivalent to letting the gravitational solution continuously interpolate between the two solutions over a finite distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' and then taking the limit as this distance tends to zero.  While there are many ways of performing this interpolation, so long as the extrinsic curvature is kept finite, they all lead to the same stress tensor as the interpolation distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['darrow 0'], []), '.\n\nAnother possibility is to let the fluid configuration continuously interpolate between the two solutions, and then take the dual using the prescription of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ".  As the fluid is not a solution of the Navier-Stokes equation in this region, the dual will not be a solution of the vacuum Einstein equations in this region.  Instead it will solve Einstein's equations with a nonvanishing stress tensor supported on a surface layer.  The ultralocality of the duality map implies that the vacuum Einstein equations will however be solved way from the surface layer.  In this case, one cannot take the interpolation distance ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' to zero, because the dual is not defined when derivatives are large with respect to the inverse of the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '.  Thus the minimum size of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' will be of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/T'], []), '.  Again there are many inequivalent ways of performing the interpolation.  But we will see that, at least for the quantities at we are able to calculate, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' is large with respect to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/T'], []), ', the difference between these prescriptions is suppressed by powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['dT'], []), " and so, like Israel's method, there is a single answer.\n\nThe perhaps surprising result is that the two methods yield bulk stress tensors which differ by a finite amount.  They did not need to agree, indeed one is derived at small ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' and the other for large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ".  The reason that they disagree is as follows.  The construction of the metric from the fluid flow proceeds order by order in the derivatives of the fluid's velocity.  The boundary conditions imply that the velocity of the fluid is the same on both sides of the wall, however the first derivatives differ.  Therefore, whatever regularization scheme one uses on the fluid side, the second derivative of the velocity diverges at small ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '.  This means that the metric corrections derived using the map of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' will diverge at small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ", invalidating the finiteness assumption in Israel's derivation.  In fact, we will see that the disagreement between the two calculations of the stress tensor differ only in these higher derivative terms.  Of course the fluid map is not defined at small ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ', as it yields a divergent series, and so no divergences appear within the range of validity of either approach.\n\nWe will begin in Sec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('flowsez')]), ' by describing the flow of interest.  The velocity will be kept sufficiently arbitrary to allow a general interpolation between the flows on the two sides of the wall, and in Sec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gravsez')]), ' the na', '\\"', 'ive gravity dual will be calculated using the prescription of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '.  We will see that those higher order derivative corrections which we calculate are indeed suppressed by factors of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['dT'], []), '.  Then in Sec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tsez')]), ' we will calculate the bulk stress tensor of the interpolation between the two gravity solutions.  First it will be calculated for the interpolation dual to a continuously interpolating fluid flow.  It will be seen that contributions from the second derivative of the velocity are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '-independent, while higher order contributions are suppressed by powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['dT'], []), '.  Thus the result is independent of the interpolation scheme when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' is sufficiently large.  The stress tensor will then be calculated directly from the Israel matching conditions on the two solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations.  It will be seen that the two stress tensors agree up to terms corresponding to a divergence in the extrinsic curvature at small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ', and that only the second stress tensor contains a nonvanishing stress.\n\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The Flow')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('flowsez')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' ansatz'))]), '\n', '\nWe will consider a hydrodynamic flow in 4-dimensional Minkowski space, using a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-,+,+,+)'], []), ' metric. To highlight the essential features of the boundary condition, we will consider the simplest possible flow.  The liquid will only move in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' direction, with a velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=v(x)'], []), ' that only depends on the coordinate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '.  The velocity will be taken to be small, and we will drop all terms which are quadratic in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '.  In fact, as described in Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008kq,vortices')]), ' we will work in the nonrelativistic, incompressible limit.  More precisely, we will show that our flow satisfies both the full relativistic equations of motion at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), ' and also the incompressible Navier-Stokes equation.\n\nWe will set ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=1'], []), '.  The conformal fluid which is dual to Einstein gravity with a negative cosmological constant is very particular.  Being conformal, all of its transport coefficients may be expressed in terms of a single dimensionful quantity, such as the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ', and certain constants which may be calculated from the gravity dual.  In the case at hand for example the shear viscosity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ', pressure ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p'], []), ' and density ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' have been found in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('eta'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), '^2'), BraceGroup('16G_N')]), 'T^3', TexCmd('hsp'), '\np=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), '^3'), BraceGroup('16G_N')]), 'T^4', TexCmd('hsp'), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3', TexCmd('pi'), '^3'), BraceGroup('16G_N')]), 'T^4 ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('rapporti')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G_N'], []), " is the dual Newton's constant.  \nThe relativistic velocity 4-vector ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u'], []), ' is, to linear order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', simply \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nu_', TexCmd('mu'), ' = (', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-v^2')]))]), ', 0, ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-v^2')]))]), ', 0) ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', '(1,0,v,0). ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('u')]), '\n'], []), '\nWe will be interested in the fluid velocity in three regions, as illustrated in Fig.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('vy')]), '.  First, on the left, where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=0'], []), '.  Second, we will be interested in the velocity on the right, where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' will be linear in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ".  We will show momentarily that this is a solution to the hydrodynamic equations of motion and so will be dual to a vacuum solution of Einstein's equations.  Finally, we will be interested in an interpolating region where ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), " will be arbitrary and we will not impose the equations of motion, therefore the dual metric will not solve the vacuum Einstein equations but, like any metric, will solve Einstein's equations with some stress tensor.\n\n\n", TexNamedEnv('figure', ['\n', TexNamedEnv('center', ['\n', TexCmd('includegraphics', [BracketGroup('scale=.58'), BraceGroup('fig5.eps')]), '\n', TexCmd('caption', [BraceGroup('The fluid velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' is in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' direction, and it depends on the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' coordinate.  On the left the fluid is stationary, on the right the fluid velocity is linear.  These two regions solve the fluid equations of motion at linear order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '.  There is an interpolating region of width ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ', which must be larger than the inverse temperature, in which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' does not satisfy the equations of motion.  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and its first derivative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' are continuous at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x=d'], []), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('vy')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nClearly the left, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=0'], []), ', satisfies the fluid equations of motion.  We will now verify that the region on the right satisfies the relativistic equations of motion, which are simply the conservation of the stress tensor\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n0=', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('edm')]), '\n'], []), '\nIn accordance with the usual fluid approximation ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Landau:1965pi')]), ', we will work at large enough distance scales that only the velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and its first derivative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' need be considered in the stress tensor.  This approximation in general is problematic, leading for example to superluminal propagation ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ac')]), '.  However, as we will be interested in velocities well below the speed of light, no problems will arise.  Later, when we will consider the interpolating region, where the second derivative may be large, we will make no such approximation.  We will consider the bulk stress tensor to higher order, calculating all terms up to two derivatives and several terms up to three or four derivatives to check that they are subdominant.  However we do not impose that the interpolating region satisfies the equations of motion, indeed that would lead to a vanishing bulk stress tensor.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Relativistic and nonrelativistic equations of motion')]), '\n', '\nAs discussed in Chapter 2 (see Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('confluid')]), '), dropping all higher derivatives of the velocity and using the fact that the fluid is conformal to eliminate the bulk viscosity and replace ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho')], []), ' with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['3p'], []), ', the hydrodynamic stress tensor is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=p(', TexCmd('eta'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '+4u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' u^', TexCmd('nu'), ')-2', TexCmd('eta'), TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Tfluido')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere the shear strain rate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha')), ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha')), ' u_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('beta'), ')'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('3')]), TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sigdef')]), ' \n'], []), '\nHere parenthesis denote, as usually, symmetrization with a factor of one half and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' is the projector onto the spacelike directions in the reference frame of the fluid\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nP_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = ', TexCmd('eta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' u_', TexCmd('nu'), ' \n= (\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^2'), BraceGroup('1- v^2')]), ' ', '& 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('1- v^2')]), ' ', '& 0 \n 0 & 1  & 0 & 0 \n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('1- v^2')]), ' ', '& 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('1- v^2')]), ' ', '& 0\n 0 & 0 & 0 & 1\n'], [BraceGroup('cccc')]), '\n', '). ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('proj')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nSubstituting the velocity ansatz (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('u')]), ') into the definition (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sigdef')]), ') one easily finds the shear strain at linear order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', '(\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \n 0 & 0  & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), " v' & 0 \n 0 & ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), " v' & 0 & 0\n 0 & 0 & 0 & 0\n"], [BraceGroup('cccc')]), '\n', ')  .', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sigma')]), ' \n'], []), '\nThe constants of proportionality (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rapporti')]), ') in this particular fluid can then be inserted into the general formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Tfluido')]), ') for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' to express the stress tensor in terms of the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' and the velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), '^3T^4'), BraceGroup('16G_N')]), '(\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n 3 & 0 & 4v & 0 \n 0 & 1  & -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v', TexCmd('p')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), ' T')]), ' ', '& 0 \n 4v & -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v', TexCmd('p')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), ' T')]), ' ', '& 1 & 0\n 0 & 0 & 0 & 1\n'], [BraceGroup('cccc')]), '\n', ')  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe velocity only depends on the coordinate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '.  Let us choose boundary conditions so that the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' also only depends on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '.  Then the equations of motion (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('edm')]), ') are simply\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n0=', TexCmd('partial'), '_x T^', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('nu')), '.\n'], []), '\nHowever all of the components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup('x', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' are constants except for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup('xx')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup('xy')], []), '.  Therefore the only nontrivial equation of motion at linear order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n0=', TexCmd('partial'), '_x T^', BraceGroup('xx'), '+', TexCmd('partial'), '_x T^', BraceGroup('xy'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), '^3T^3'), BraceGroup('4G_N')]), 'T', TexCmd('p'), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), '^2'), BraceGroup('16G_N')]), TexCmd('partial'), '_x (T^3 v', TexCmd('p'), ').\n'], []), '\nWhen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' is linear in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ', its second derivative vanishes.  Therefore this equation of motion, the conservation of momentum in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' direction, implies that the temperature is constant.  More precisely it implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('partial'), ' T)/T'], []), ' is negligible in this approximation.  In light of the relations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rapporti')]), ') this is consistent with the incompressibility assumption that we have imposed on our fluid.  \n\nTherefore we recover the fact that at sufficiently small velocities, a constant temperature and a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), '-velocity which is linear in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' solve the equations of motion (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('edm')]), ').  Intuitively this is clear.  Further to the right, the fluid is moving faster.  Therefore the viscous force on a unit of fluid exerted by the faster fluid on its right (in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+x'], []), ' direction) will accelerate it in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['+y'], []), ' direction, whereas the slower fluid on its left will exert a viscous force that decelerates it.  A steady flow occurs when these two forces cancel, which implies that the second derivative of the flow vanishes.  Had there been a temperature gradient, then the viscosity to density ratio would also have been stronger on one side by (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rapporti')]), '), and so this balance could only be maintained by introducing a second derivative of the velocity. \n\nClearly a linear velocity also satisfies the nonrelativistic Navier-Stokes equation for an incompressible, Newtonian fluid\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('rho'), '(', TexCmd('partial'), '_t v_k + (v', TexCmd('cdot'), TexCmd('partial'), ') v_k)=-', TexCmd('partial'), '_k p + ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^2 v_k. \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('nonrel')]), '\n'], []), ' \nIn fact, each term vanishes independently.  Note that the vanishing of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), ' p'], []), ' term is not merely a consequence of incompressibility.  In incompressible flows it may be of the same order as the viscous term.  It vanishes in this case because this provides a solution to (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('nonrel')]), ') and it is consistent with the various nonrelativistic, small gradient and incompressible limits taken above.\n\n\nIn conclusion, we have considered fluid flows with an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '-dependent velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' direction.  We have verified that, to linear order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', these satisfy both the relativistic and nonrelativistic equations of motion when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' is linear in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' and the temperature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is constant.  Our flows of interest will have ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v=0'], []), ' on the left, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), " linear on the right and an interpolating region inbetween.  Thus the equations of motion will be satisfied on the left and the right but not in the interpolating region, leading to a dual gravity solution which solves Einstein's vacuum equations on the left and right, but inbetween requires material described by a nontrivial stress tensor.  We have also found formula (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('proj')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('sigma')]), ') for the projector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' and the shear tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' for general functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', and so these results may be applied to the interpolating region.\n\nClearly if the fluid velocity is linear over a large enough distance, it will eventually approach the speed of light and the nonrelativistic approximation will break down.  Therefore our analysis is only relevant near the boundary.  The solution may be made global by introducing a second boundary, such that the velocity is constant on the other side of the second boundary.  We will see below that the stress tensor on the second boundary, to linear order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', will be minus the stress tensor of the first boundary.  Of course at higher orders one may expect an attraction between the two boundaries, and so this solution will not be stationary.  The underlying assumption in this note is that the walls on the gravity side are built of a solid which remains fixed.  The fact that the null energy condition is violated may be a sign that such a material would be inconsistent, as some null energy violating configurations lead to superluminal propagation or instabilities ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Dubovsky:2005xd')]), ', although some do not ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('tranquilli')]), ', in which case this configuration should only be considered over a sufficiently short timescale.  It may be that this timescale is never sufficient for turbulence to develop.\n\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The Gravity Dual')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gravsez')]), '\n', '\nIn Chapter 3 we gave a detailed presentation of the AdS/hydrodynamics correspondence, that yields a black brane metric dual to arbitrary flows in very particular conformal fluids, which for example obey the relations (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('rapporti')]), ').  If the flow satisfies the hydrodynamic equations of motion (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('edm')]), '), the dual satisfies the vacuum Einstein equations, in this case with a negative cosmological constant.  \n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('A note on ultralocality')]), '\n', '\nAs mentioned in the construction of the gravity dual to a generic conformal fluid, the correspondence, at least in the incarnation in Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' and ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), ', is ultralocal.  It is useful at this point to explain a bit further what this means. Consider the set of ingoing null geodesics which run from the boundary to the black brane horizon.  Clearly each point in the bulk is on precisely one such geodesic.  Also each point on the boundary is on one such geodesic.  Therefore these geodesics can be used to associate a fixed single boundary point to each bulk point.  This association is not one to one, there is an entire geodesic worth of bulk points associated to each boundary point.  \n\nTo implement the map, one identifies the boundary with the Minkowski space on which the fluid lives.  The metric and its derivatives at a point in the bulk are determined entirely by the fluid velocity and temperature and their derivatives at the associated boundary point.  One does not need to know the behavior of the fluid elsewhere.  This is the ultralocality of the correspondence.  In particular, the fact that the fluid satisfies the hydrodynamic equations of motion on the left and right (at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x<0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x>d'], []), ') implies that the dual metric will satisfy the vacuum Einstein equations on the left and right, so long as the characteristic distance over which these quantities vary is greater than the inverse temperature.\n\nOur fluid does not satisfy the hydrodynamic equations of motion at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0<x<d'], []), ".  This means that the dual gravitational configuration will not satisfy the vacuum Einstein equations, instead it will only satisfy Einstein's equations with a nonzero stress tensor, which we will calculate in Sec.~", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tsez')]), '.\n\nThis ultralocality is somewhat different from the ultralocality that one encounters in classical field theories, or in the BKL limit of gravity theories, in that the bulk geometry is ultralocal in terms of null and not temporal evolution.  This ingoing null identification identifies the temporal evolution of the fluid with outward radial evolution for the gravity theory.  That is to say, the metric at larger radii but the same time is determined by the fluid in the future but at the same location.
