In particular, a timeslice of the bulk geometry is determined by the evolution of the boundary fluid during a fixed interval of time.  This interval is of order the inverse temperature, and so no appreciable evolution may occur during this interval if the temperature is large enough for the correspondence to hold.  In this sense any fixed timeslice of the gravity dual contains only as much information as a fixed timeslice of the fluid, despite being one dimension greater.\n\nAs each event in the fluid is identified with an inward null geodesic in the bulk, the metric corresponding to this event appears to be falling towards the black hole at the speed of light.  This is not at all to say that there is a Killing vector in the inward null direction, the metric changes in that direction, but in a fashion which is fixed by the map.  Thus a disturbance on the boundary creates gravity waves which fly inward at the speed of light to the horizon.  Similarly, pasting together an infinite sequence of bulk timeslices which are separated by time intervals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/T'], []), ', one obtains a pattern which falls from the boundary in to the horizon at the speed of light.  Although each individual timeslice is too small to see any evolution, the entire pattern is dual to the entire history of the flow.  Like a movie reel, the pattern in turn allows one to reconstruct the gravity dual, as it contains the timeslices.\n\nOne may use this identification to speculate on the gravitational dual of decaying turbulence.  For example, the inverse cascade of decaying (2+1)-dimensional turbulence consists of a chaotic period during which the fluid is subjected to random external forces followed by a relaxation period, characterized by the merging of well-separated vortices ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kraichnan, mcwilliams')]), '.  This would then be dual to a kind of forest of gravity waves falling from the boundary to the horizon, beginning when the boundary is subjected to a random perturbation.  First the canopy, representing the chaotic period, falls out of the boundary into the horizon.  When the external perturbation is turned off, it is followed by the branches representing the vortices, and then the branches merge into trunks as the vortices merge.  The usual cascade ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Kol1,Kol2')]), ' in (3+1)-dimensional turbulence may be similarly described, but when the boundary is randomly perturbed, the trunk falls out first.  This leads to the rather bizarre observation that black brane geometries in AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_4'], []), ' and AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_5'], []), ' respond very differently to random perturbations of their boundaries.  Needless to say, it would be interesting to make this picture precise, or to see whether it is inconsistent with the various approximations involved in the duality.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The metric')]), '\n', '\nWe will now calculate the metric dual to the flow (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('u')]), ') using the map in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' with the simplified notation of Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz, Rangamani:2009xk')]), '.  This map takes regions in which the flow satisfies the fluid equations to regions in which the metric satisfies the source-free Einstein equations.  Acting on the region in which the fluid does not satisfy the hydrodynamic equation, the map is not known to have any special properties other than continuity, which will produce an interpolation between the vacuum Einstein metrics on the two sides.  Therefore the choice of this map corresponds to a rather arbitrary choice of interpolation.  However we will see that this interpolation has two nice properties.  First, it is reasonably independent of the interpolating velocity function chosen.  In particular, the third and higher derivatives of the velocity will yield contributions to the integrated stress tensor which are suppressed by powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['dT'], []), ', while the leading contribution is independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ".  Second, the resulting stress tensor is simpler than the Israel stress tensor, it will have zero stress, whereas Israel's stress tensor has shear stress.\n\nUltralocality in the ingoing null direction implies that the simplest coordinates in which to express the metric are Gaussian null coordinates, in which ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' parametrizes the ingoing null lines.  In these coordinates, the bulk 5-dimensional metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('metric-3')]), ') corresponding to an ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), '-dependent 4-dimensional fluid flow is ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nds^2 =  G_', BraceGroup('MN'), ' dX^M dX^N = - 2 u_', TexCmd('mu'), '(x) ', '\\,', ' dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', '(dr + ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), '(r, x) ', '\\,', ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ') + ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '(r, x) dx^', TexCmd('mu'), ' dx^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('met')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhere, up to second derivatives in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' are defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = r ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda')), ' u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' - ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(br) P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' \n+ u_', TexCmd('mu', [BracketGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' r^2 (1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('(br)^4')]), ') - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4(br)^4')]), TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_2(br) ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('d-1')]), ' ')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('vdef')]), '\n'], []), '\nand\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ['\n', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = r^2 P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' - ', TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + 2 (br)^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(br)', '[', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b')]), TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(br) ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu')), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ']', ' - ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_2(br)  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'))), BraceGroup('d-1')]), ' P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' \n- ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_3 (br) ', '[', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('1 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T')]), '_', BraceGroup('3 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '+ 2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ']', ' + ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_4(br)', '[', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('1 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' +', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', ']', '  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gdef')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe functions that appear in this definition were introduced in Sec. ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('defmetric')]), ', (one can refer also to the Appendix).\n\nEq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('met')]), ') is the bulk metric dual to a fluid flow in an arbitrary curved space.  The fluid is conformally invariant, and the conformal invariance has been used to write the metric in a compact form using objects which transform covariantly under the conformal symmetry.  We are interested in a flat boundary, and so many of these objects will vanish.  In fact, since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u'], []), ' only depends on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ', but only has nonvanishing components in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' directions, even the gauge field for a Weyl transformation will vanish\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' = u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), 'u_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u_', TexCmd('lambda'), '=0 \n'], []), '\nas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u_', TexCmd('mu'), '=0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' u^', TexCmd('lambda'), ' =0'], []), '. This implies that the Weyl-covariant derivative reduces to the ordinary derivative\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '  = ', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\n', '\nThe Weyl-covariant Schouten tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')])], []), ' ', '(defined in eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Schouten')]), ')) is proportional to the Weyl-covariant curvature of the boundary.  As the Weyl-covariant derivative is just the ordinary derivative, this is just the ordinary curvature.  As the boundary is Minkowski space, the curvature vanishes, and so the Weyl-covariant Schouten tensor also vanishes\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('S')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = 0  .\n'], []), '\nSimilarly the Weyl-covariant Weyl curvature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('C')])], []), ' is the sum of the ordinary Weyl curvature and the curvature of the Weyl tensor (see eq. (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Weyltensor')]), ')), which both vanish and so\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('C')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma')), ' = 0 .\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe vorticity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' does not vanish, however like the shear strain ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' it is of first order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '.  Therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '^2'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '^2'], []), ' terms are all of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^2)'], []), ' and so do not contribute at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), '.  Thus only the third and fourth terms of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('vdef')]), ') contribute to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), '.  The third term is easily evaluated\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), '=', TexCmd('partial'), '_', TexCmd('lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', TexCmd('lambda'), '_', TexCmd('nu'), ' =  ', TexCmd('partial'), '_x ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^x_', TexCmd('nu'), '\n', TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', '(\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n 0\n 0\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), " v''\n 0\n"], [BraceGroup('c')]), '\n', ')  .\n'], []), '\nAdding the third and fourth terms one finds ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('mu')], []), ' at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('V')]), '_', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('simeq', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), '_1(br) \n (\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n 0\n 0\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), " v''\n 0\n"], [BraceGroup('c')]), '\n', ') + \n (\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n 1\n 0\n v\n 0\n'], [BraceGroup('c')]), '\n', ') ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '(r^2-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4r^2')]), '). ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('v2')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T')], []), ', reported in Table 2.1, are easily expressed in terms of the shorthand notation ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['<>'], []), ', which symmetrizes and contracts with the projectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), '.  The first two are identically zero, while the second two are of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^2)'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['_', BraceGroup('1 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&= 2 u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('D')]), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = 0 \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('2 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&= C_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), ' u^', TexCmd('alpha'), ' u^', TexCmd('beta'), ' = 0\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('3 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&= 4 ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('mu')), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('rangle')), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0 \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('4 ', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '&= 4 ', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('langle'), ' ', TexCmd('mu')), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('rangle')), '_', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' 0. '], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' T')]), '\nTherefore only the first and third terms of (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gdef')]), ') contribute to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu'))], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('G')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' ', TexCmd('simeq'), '  \nr^2 (\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n 0 & 0 & v & 0 \n 0 & 1  & 0 & 0 \n v & 0 & 1 & 0\n 0 & 0 & 0 & 1\n'], [BraceGroup('cccc')]), '\n', ') \n+  b r^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(br)  \n(\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ["\n 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \n 0 & 0  &  v' & 0 \n 0 & v' & 0 & 0\n 0 & 0 & 0 & 0\n"], [BraceGroup('cccc')]), '\n', ')  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('g2')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nFinally, inserting Eqs.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('v2')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('g2')]), ') into (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('met')]), '), one finds the final form of the metric ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Evslin:2010ss')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ['\nds^2 = - r^2 (1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^4')]), ')dt^2 - 2 dt dr  + (2 ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), '+', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "_1(br) v'' ) dt dy \n +r^2(dx^2 + dy^2+dz^2)+ 2 r^2 b", '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), ' ', "_1(br) v' dx dy - 2 v dy dr\n"], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b=1/', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), ' T')], []), ' and the functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1'], []), ' are defined in Eqs.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('v1')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('g1')]), ').  Using the basis ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(t,x,y,z,r)'], []), ', we may write the metric in matrix form as\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\ng_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '=\n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ['\n-(r^2-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), ') & 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), "_1(br) v''  & 0 & -1\n0 & r^2 & r^2 b", '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), ' ', "_1(br) v'  & 0 & 0\n ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), "_1(br) v''  &  r^2 b", '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), ' ', "_1(br) v'  & r^2 & 0 & - v \n 0 & 0 & 0 & r^2 & 0\n -1 & 0 & -v & 0 & 0\n"], []), '    ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('metfin')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhile the inverse metric is\n', TexDisplayMathEnv('displaymath', ['\ng^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '=\n', TexNamedEnv('pmatrix', ['\n 0 & 0 & -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', '& 0 & -1\n 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', '& - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('b', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), ' ', "_1(br) v'"), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', '& 0 & 0\n -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', '& - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('b', '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), ' ', "_1(br) v'"), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', '& ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', '& 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "_1(br) v''"), BraceGroup('2 r^2')]), ' + v\n 0 & 0 & 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', '& 0\n -1 & 0 & ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "_1(br) v''"), BraceGroup('2 r^2')]), ' + v & 0 & r^2 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), '\n'], []), '  .\n'], []), '\n ', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Christoffel symbols')]), '\n  ', '\nIn Sec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tsez')]), ' we will see that the leading contribution to the stress tensor comes from the second derivative of the velocity.  Contributions at that order come from the second derivative of the velocity in the curvature, which in turn contains contributions from first and second derivatives of the velocity in the Christoffel symbols, as well as from Christoffel symbols which are velocity independent as these are multiplied by velocity-dependent terms when calculating the curvature.  We will now calculate all of the Christoffel symbols up to first order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p')], []), ', although the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' terms will not contribute to the stress tensor.\n\nWe will begin with the terms at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^0)'], []), ', these are just the Christoffel symbols of the static black brane \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('tt'), '^t &= -(r+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4r^3')]), '), & ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('tt'), '^r &=r^3 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^8 r^5')]), ', & ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('xx'), '^t &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('yy'), '^t = ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('zz'), '^t = r, & ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('tr'), '^r &=  ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('rt'), '^r= r + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^3')]), ', &', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('xr'), '^x &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('rx'), '^x = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r')]), ', & ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('yr'), '^y &=', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ry'), '^y= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r')]), ', & ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('zr'), '^z &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('rz'), '^z = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r')]), ', & ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('xx'), '^r &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('yy'), '^r = ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('zz'), '^r = -(r^3-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r')]), '). ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Chris0')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe new terms, at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), ', are\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ty'), '^t &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('yt'), '^t = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]), 'b', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(br) v'' - ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^3')]), ', ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('yr'), '^x &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ry'), '^x = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('2 r^2')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('b^2'), BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g')]), "_1(br) v'", TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('tt'), '^y &= (r+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^3')]), ')(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "_1(br) v''"), BraceGroup('2 r^2')]), ' + v) ,', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('tx'), '^y &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('xt'), '^y = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('2 b^4 r^4')]), TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('xx'), '^y &= b ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "_1(br) v'' - vr- ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "_1(br) v''"), BraceGroup('2 r')]), ',', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('tr'), '^y &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('rt'), '^y = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v'), BraceGroup('r')]), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(br) b v''"), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('xr'), '^y &= ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('rx'), '^y = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' b^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br) v' - ", TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Chris1')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The Riemann tensor and the Ricci tensor and scalar')]), '\n', '\nUsing the Christoffel symbols one can now easily compute the Riemann tensor.  The order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^0)'], []), ' terms again are just those of the static AdS black brane\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nR_', BraceGroup('trtr'), ' ', '&=  1 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^4')]), ' \nR_', BraceGroup('txtx'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('tyty'), ' = R_', BraceGroup('tztz'), ' = r^4 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^8 r^4')]), ' \nR_', BraceGroup('txrx'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('tyry'), ' = R_', BraceGroup('tzrz'), ' = r^2 + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), ' \nR_', BraceGroup('xyxy'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('xzxz'), ' = R_', BraceGroup('yzyz'), ' = - r^4 + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4')]), '. \n'], []), ' \n', '\nThe bulk stress tensor is entirely determined by the contributions to the Riemann tensor which do not solve the fluid equations of motion, as it is these that do not solve the vacuum Einstein equations.  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' is a constant, this yields the boosted black brane, which satisfies the vacuum Einstein equations.  If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' is linear, then again this is a solution of the linear order fluid equations as we have checked above, and therefore as we will check below ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' will not contribute to the gravitational stress tensor at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), '. b^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "''_1 ) .  \n"], []), '\n', '\nAs a check on our calculation, we will also calculate the contributions to the various tensors at linear order in the nondifferentiated velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nR_', BraceGroup('txyx'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('tzyz'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4')]), '(1- ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^4')]), ') v   \nR_', BraceGroup('tytr'), ' ', '&= - (2 + b^4 r^4 + (b^5 r^5 + b r)(2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(br)+ br ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br))) ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('2 b^4 r^3')]), '   \nR_', BraceGroup('trxy'), ' ', '&= - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("2 v'"), BraceGroup('b^4 r^3')]), '   \nR_', BraceGroup('xzyz'), ' ', '&= - (b^3 r^3 + (b^4 r^4 -1)(2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(br)+ br ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br))) ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('2 b^3')]), '   \nR_', BraceGroup('xryr'), ' ', '&= - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), " b^2 r v' (2 ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br)+ br ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "''_1(br))  .\n"], []), '\n', '\nThe Ricci tensor is now easily calculated.  Again the order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^0)'], []), ' terms are those of the static black brane solution\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nR_', BraceGroup('tt'), ' ', '&= 4 r^2 - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), '  \nR_', BraceGroup('tr'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('rt'), ' = 4 \nR_', BraceGroup('xx'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('yy'), ' = R_', BraceGroup('zz'), ' = - 4r^2  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nContributions to the stress tensor will arise from the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["v''"], []), ' terms, (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["v= v' = 0"], []), ') \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nR_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('yt'), ' = -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''"), BraceGroup('4 b^4 r^4')]), '(2 + 4(1+ b^4 r^4) ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(br)+ (b^5r^5 -br)(', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(br)+b r", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "''_1(br))) \nR_", BraceGroup('ry'), ' ', '&= R_', BraceGroup('yr'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''"), BraceGroup('4 r^2')]), '(2+ 4 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1  + br(2 br ', '\\,', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br)- ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(br)+ b r ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "''_1(br) )  .\n"], []), '\n', '\nThe terms in the Ricci tensor proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' are those of a rigidly boosted black brane\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nR^', BraceGroup('(v)'), '_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' = - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('4 v'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('hsp'), '\nR^', BraceGroup('(v)'), '_', BraceGroup('yr'), ' = 4 v  \n'], []), "\nwhich provides an exact solution both to the hydrodynamic equations and to Einstein's equations with a negative cosmological constant.  Again the terms linear in ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ["v'"], []), " yield a solution to the fluid equations and so Einstein's equations, although only to linear order ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nR_', BraceGroup('xy'), ' = - (8 b^3 r^3 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(br)+ (5 b^4 r^4 -1)', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br))", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('2 b^2 r')]), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nUsing the large ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), ' asymptotic expansions of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['_1 &', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b r')]), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4 b^4 r^4')]), ' + ', TexCmd('dots', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), '_1 &', TexCmd('sim'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('12 b^4 r^4')]), '+ ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('5 b^3 r^3')]), ' + ', TexCmd('dots'), '  \n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g')]), '\nwe find that the asymptotic behaviors of the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p')], []), ' terms in the Ricci tensor are\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nR_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' ', '&', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('13'), BraceGroup('10')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''"), BraceGroup('b^3 r^3')]), '   \nR_', BraceGroup('ry'), ' ', '&', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('5')]), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''"), BraceGroup('b^2 r^4')]), '  . \n'], []), '\n', '\nThe Ricci scalar is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nR = -20  .\n'], []), '\nThere is no contribution at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), ' to the Ricci scalar.  This is guaranteed for any solution of the vacuum Einstein equations with cosmological constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '=-6'], []), ', and so there could not have been any corrections from the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' terms.  There are no corrections from the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p')], []), ' terms at linear order because the corresponding components of the inverse metric are themselves of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), ', and so the contributions to the Ricci tensor are of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^2)'], []), '.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Contributions to the Ricci tensor at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^', BraceGroup('(3)'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^', BraceGroup('(4)'), ')'], []))]), '\n', '\nBefore continuing with the calculation of the bulk stress tensor, we will pause to discuss some of the approximations that we have made.  We have made two truncations.  First, we have calculated everything at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), '.  As we are working in units in which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['c=1'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' is small for nonrelativistic speeds and so this is a valid approximation in a region in which the flow is sufficiently slow.\n\nA more dangerous truncation is that of higher derivatives of the velocity.  The gravity/hydrodynamics correspondence is a one to one map between gravitational and fluid solutions in a derivative expansion.  More precisely, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), 'th order map relates the truncation of the fluid equations to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' derivatives and that of the gravity equations to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(k+1)'], []), ' derivatives.  The iterative procedure described in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' in principle determines this map for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ', however in practice this map has only been determined to order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=2'], []), '.  In other words, it provides a metric as a function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p')], []), ", however a perfect matching with Einstein's equations would require also corrections involving the higher derivatives ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v^', BraceGroup('(k)')], []), ' which are not known.\n\nGeneral arguments based on dimensional analysis suggest that these corrections become smaller at higher ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), '.  In general one expects that each derivative leads to a contribution which is subdominant by a factor of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Tl'], []), ' with respect the previous derivative, where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l'], []), ' is the distance scale of the derivative.  Ideally one would like to check this claim for all terms with, say, three or four derivatives.  However this would require a knowledge of the map at orders ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=3'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=4'], []), '.\n\nThe map at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=2'], []), ', which we have used, does produce some terms in the curvature which depend on the third and fourth derivatives of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '.  In this subsection we will verify that two of these have the expected convergence scaling, and determine the corresponding condition on our fluid flow.  In other words, we determine a necessary condition for the derivative expansion to apply to our flow.\n\nThe Ricci tensor components ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('xy')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('ty')], []), ' have corrections from the third and fourth derivatives of the velocity respectively \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nR_', BraceGroup('xy'), '^', BraceGroup('(3)'), ' ', '&= -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^', BraceGroup('(3)'), '(x) (b r ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(b r)+", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(b r))'), BraceGroup('4 r')]), '   \nR_', BraceGroup('ty'), '^', BraceGroup('(4)'), ' ', '&= -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '(x) ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(b r)'), BraceGroup('4 r^2')]), '  .\n'], []), '\nWe want to determine the condition under which ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('ty'), '^', BraceGroup('(4)')], []), ' is subdominant to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('xy'), '^', BraceGroup('(3)')], []), '.  As the higher derivatives of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' define an interpolating function between two solutions over an interval of length ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ', each derivative is larger than the previous one by about ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/d'], []), '.  In other words, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('partial'), '_x', TexCmd('sim'), ' 1/d'], []), '.  \n\nTo test the subdominance of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('ty'), '^', BraceGroup('(4)')], []), ', it is sufficient to compare it to the similar term in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', BraceGroup('xy'), '^', BraceGroup('(3)')], []), ', which contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1'], []), '.  The ratio of these terms is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('R_', BraceGroup('ty'), '^', BraceGroup('(4)')), BraceGroup('R_', BraceGroup('xy'), '^', BraceGroup('(3)'))]), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v^', BraceGroup('(4)'), '(x)'), BraceGroup('rv^', BraceGroup('(3)'), '(x)')]), ' ', TexCmd('sim'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r d')]), '\n'], []), '\ntherefore the fourth order term is subdominant if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d', TexCmd('gg'), '1/r'], []), ' in the entire bulk.  The bulk extends from the horizon at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=1/b=', TexCmd('pi'), ' T'], []), ' to the boundary at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.  Therefore convergence requires\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nd', TexCmd('gg'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('pi'), ' T')]), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('spesso')]), '\n'], []), '\nThis fourth order term is suppressed by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), ' d T'], []), ' with respect to the third order term, in line with the above expectations from dimensional analysis.  This means that the gravity duality procedure is only convergent when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' is sufficiently large.  Of course, the duality never yields a solution of the vacuum Einstein equations, and so one may argue that its convergence is immaterial.  Nonetheless, it is only well-defined as a series when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' satisfies (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('spesso')]), ').\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The static black brane solution')]), '\n', '\nAs a check on our calculation and conventions, we recover that the static ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(v=0)'], []), ' black brane satisfies the vacuum Einstein equations with cosmological constant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '=-6'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nR_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' R g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = (\n', TexNamedEnv('array', ['\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('6'), BraceGroup('b^4 r^2')]), '-6 r^2 & 0 & 0 & 0 & -6 \n 0 & 6 r^2 & 0 & 0 & 0 \n 0 & 0 & 6 r^2 & 0 & 0 \n 0 & 0 & 0 & 6 r^2 & 0 \n -6 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0\n'], [BraceGroup('ccccc')]), '\n', ')  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('bn')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Two Calculations of the Stress Tensor')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tsez')]), '\n', '\nIn this section we will calculate the bulk stress tensor of the surface layer interpolating between the vacuum gravity solutions using two different methods, corresponding to two different metrics.  First, we will apply the duality map of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' to a fluid flow which interpolates between the two solutions, the stationary solution on the left and the linear velocity solution on the right.  In this case, as we have seen, the interpolating region is necessarily larger than the inverse temperature.  Next, we will directly interpolate between the gravitational solutions using the Israel matching conditions ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), '.  This method requires the interpolating region to be very thin, and uses the assumption that in this limit the extrinsic curvature remains bounded.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Interpolating between the hydrodynamic flows')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('T1sez')]), '\n', '\nThe duality map of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), ' takes a fluid flow and yields a dual metric.  This dual metric solves the vacuum Einstein equations when the fluid flow satisfies the hydrodynamic equations of motion (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('edm')]), ").  If the flow does not satisfy the equations of motion, the dual metric does not satisfy the vacuum Einstein equations.  Thus apparently there is no benefit in using this map over any other map.  However we will use the map, and observe the consequences.  The resulting dual metric will necessarily solve Einstein's equations with some value of the stress tensor\n", TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n8', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N T_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' = R_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' R g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), ' + ', TexCmd('Lambda'), ' g_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), '  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('ein')]), '\n'], []), '\nWe will determine this value. \n\nWe saw in Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('bn')]), ') that there is no contribution to the stress tensor at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^0)'], []), '.  We have argued that, at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), ', the dominant contributions to the stress tensor are proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p')], []), '.  These are easily found from (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('ein')]), ') to be \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nT_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' ', '&= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''(x) (4 (b^4 r^4-1) ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(b r)-b r (b^4 r^4-1) (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(b r)+b r ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "''_1(b\n   r))-2)"), BraceGroup('32', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N b^4 r^4')]), ' ', '\\,', ' \nT_', BraceGroup('ry'), ' ', '&= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''(x) (4 ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(b r)+b r (2 b r ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(b r)-", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(b r)-b r\n   ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "''_1(b r))+2)"), BraceGroup('32', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N r^2')]), ' .\n'], []), '\nThere appears to also be a contribution proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup('xy'), ' = -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'(x) (b r ((b^4 r^4-1) ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "''_1(b r)+3 b r)+(5 b^4 r^4-1) ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(b r))"), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N b^2 r')]), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('txy')]), '\n'], []), '\nAt order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' one expects no contributions to the stress tensor, as a solution with a linear velocity satisfies the fluid equations at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), '.  Therefore a nontrivial contribution would be in contradiction with the gravity/hydrodynamics correspondence.  We will see shorty that this contribution is in fact equal to zero.\n\n\nThe functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(r)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(r)'], []), ' are defined as\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['_1(r) &= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('r'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' dx ', '\\,', ' x^3 ', TexCmd('int'), '_x^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' dy ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y-1'), BraceGroup('y^3(y^4-1)')]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('v1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g')]), '_1(r) &= ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('r'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' dx ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('x^3-1'), BraceGroup('x(x^4-1)')]), '  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('g1')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), '\nIntegrating we ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')]), ' obtain analytical expressions for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(r)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1(r)'], []), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['_1 &= - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('8 r^2')]), '(r^4-1)(', TexCmd('log', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(r^2+1)'), BraceGroup('(r+1)^2')]))]), '+2 ', TexCmd('tan'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(r)-', TexCmd('pi'), ') \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1 &= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]), ' ', '(', TexCmd('log', [BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('(1+r)^2(1+r^2)'), BraceGroup('r^4')]), ')')]), '-2 ', TexCmd('tan'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(r)+', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', ')   .\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), '\nThe derivatives of these expressions are\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ["'_1 &= ", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', '(', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('r^2+1')]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^2+1')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r+1')]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('r')]), ')  ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gp'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g')]), "''_1 &= -", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r^2'), BraceGroup('(r^2+1)^2')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('r'), BraceGroup('(r^2+1)^2')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2(r^2+1)')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), '-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2(r+1)^2')]), '   ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('gpp')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g')]), '\nand\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ["'_1 = -", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4 r^3')]), ' ', '( ', TexCmd('pi'), '  r^4+2 (r^4+1) ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(r+1)-2 (r^4+1) ', TexCmd('tan'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(r) .  \n. -4 r^3+2 r^2-(r^4+1) ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(r^2+1)+', TexCmd('pi'), ') \n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('multline', ["''_1 = -", TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4 r^4 (r+1) (r^2+1)')]), '   ', '(3 ', TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(r^2+1)+', TexCmd('pi'), '  ', '(r+1) (r^2+1) (r^4-3)  .\n+(r (r+1) (r^4+r^2-3)-3) r (2 ', TexCmd('log'), '\n   ', '(r+1) . \n     -', TexCmd('log'), '.  (r^2+1))-2 (r+1) (r^2+1) (r^4-3) ', TexCmd('tan'), ' ', '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(r)\n    . -2 (2 r^4+r^3+r^2+r+3) r^2-6 ', TexCmd('log'), '\n   ', '(r+1)) .\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v')]), '\n', '\nThe explicit formula Eqs.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gp')]), ') and (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gpp')]), ') for the derivatives of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1'], []), ' can be combined to show that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nr ((r^4-1) ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "''_1(r)+3 r)+(5 r^4-1)", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(r) = 0  .\n"], []), '\nThis combination is proportional to formula (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('txy')]), ') for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('xy')], []), ', therefore\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup('xy'), '=0\n'], []), '\nand there are no contributions proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), '.  \n\nSimilarly one may evaluate the combination of functions that appears in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('ry')], []), ' \n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nr (2 r ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(r)-r ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "''_1(r)-", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), "'_1(r))+4 ", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(r)+2 = 0  .\n'], []), '\nThis implies that\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup('ry'), '=0\n'], []), '\nleaving only ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('ty')], []), ', the momentum in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' direction.  Thus the bulk stress tensor contains no stress, only momentum.\n\nWe may use the exact expressions for the functions ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1'], []), ' to simplify the only nonvanishing component of the stress tensor ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Evslin:2010ss')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nT_', BraceGroup('ty'), '= -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p'), ' ', '(x)'), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N b^3 r^3')]), '  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('tty')]), '\n'], []), '\nUsing the fundamental theorem of calculus, this may be integrated over the interpolating region to obtain\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('int'), '_0^d dx T_', BraceGroup('ty'), '= -', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('v', TexCmd('p')), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N b^3 r^3')]), ' \n'], []), '\nwhere ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' is the derivative of the velocity in the region ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x>d'], []), '.  In particular, at this leading order the integrated stress tensor of the surface layer is independent of the interpolation and independent of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '.  Of course it still depends on the map that we used to generate the dual metric.\n\nHad the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p')], []), ' term been the dominant contribution, the stress tensor would have been constant, and so the integral would be have proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '.  Similarly a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v^', BraceGroup('(3)')], []), ' term would have led to a stress tensor proportional to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/d'], []), ', and higher powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' to other scalings.  Therefore it is somewhat nontrivial that the leading contribution to the integrated stress tensor is in fact ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '-independent.  Clearly this ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '-independence is desirable, as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' is not a physical quantity but merely an artifact of the scheme that we used to regularize the divergent second derivative of the fluid velocity.\n\nThe bulk stress tensor does not satisfy any of energy conditions we discussed in Sec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Energysec')]), ', not even the null energy condition.  As the only nonvanishing component is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('ty')], []), ', the only nonvanishing product of a null vector ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' and the stress tensor is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nw^', TexCmd('perp'), ' Tw=2w^t T_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' w^y. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prod')]), '\n'], []), '\nAs ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('ty')], []), ' is already of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), ', at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v)'], []), ' one need only consider the terms in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' of order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('O')]), '(v^0)'], []), '.  That is to say, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w'], []), ' only needs to be null with respect to the static black brane metric.  Consider for example the null vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_', TexCmd('pm')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nw^t_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '=r', TexCmd('hsp'), '\nw^y_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('pm')), '=', TexCmd('pm'), ' r', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4r^4')]))]), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('w')]), '\n'], []), '\nThe product (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prod')]), ') is \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nw_', TexCmd('pm'), '^', TexCmd('perp'), ' Tw_', TexCmd('pm'), '=', TexCmd('mp'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''(x)"), BraceGroup('8', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N b^3 r')]), TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('b^4r^4')]))]), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('prod2')]), '\n'], []), '\nwhich is nonzero.  However ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_+'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_-'], []), ' yield opposite signs, as incidentally do the two choices of signs of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), '.  Therefore at least one of these will yield a negative product, and so the bulk stress tensor does not satisfy the null energy condition.  This may or may not mean that no external matter may be consistently added which produces such a surface layer.\n\n \n \n\n \n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup("Israel's matching conditions on the gravity duals")]), '\n', '\nWe will now calculate the bulk stress tensor in a different geometry.  Following Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ' and discussion in Sec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Israelsec')]), ', we will consider the vacuum Einstein solution corresponding to a static fluid on the left and that corresponding to a linear velocity flow on the right.  These solutions will be glued together by interpolating continuously between the two metrics over a distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' and taking the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['darrow 0'], []), ' such that the extrinsic curvature remains bounded.  In Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ', Israel has shown that the resulting configuration contains two solutions separated by a surface layer whose bulk stress tensor is independent of the interpolation used.\n\nFollowing Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ', the first step in the calculation of the stress tensor is the definition of the unit normal vector to the hyperplane\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nn_', TexCmd('mu'), ' = ', '\\{', '0, r, 0, 0, 0', '\\}', '  ,\n'], []), '\nwhich satisfies the normalization condition\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nn_', TexCmd('mu'), ' g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), ' ', TexCmd('nu')), 'n_', TexCmd('nu'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('r^2')]), '(n_x)^2 = 1  .\n'], []), '\nThe surface layer ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' extends along all of the directions except for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' direction.  A basis of tangent vectors to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Sigma')], []), ' is\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nds = e_', BraceGroup('(i)'), ' d x^i \n'], []), '\nwhere\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\ne_', BraceGroup('(t)'), ' ', '&= ', '\\{', '1, 0, 0, 0, 0', '\\}', '    \ne_', BraceGroup('(y)'), ' ', '&= ', '\\{', '0, 0, 1, 0, 0', '\\}', '   \ne_', BraceGroup('(z)'), ' ', '&= ', '\\{', '0, 0, 0, 1, 0', '\\}', '    \ne_', BraceGroup('(r)'), ' ', '&= ', '\\{', '0, 0, 0, 0, 1', '\\}', '  .\n'], []), '\nIn terms of these tangent vectors the extrinsic curvature may be calculated as\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\nK_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = e_', BraceGroup('(j)'), TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_j n = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' n_j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^i')]), ' - n^m ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('m,ji'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' n_j'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' x^i')]), ' - n_m ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^m_', BraceGroup('ji'), '  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('K')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nOn the left, where the fluid is static (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v = 0'], []), '), substituting (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Chris0')]), ') into (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('K')]), ') one finds no extrinsic curvature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^', BraceGroup('(-)')], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nK_', BraceGroup('ty'), '^', BraceGroup('(-)'), ' ', '&= - r ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^x_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' = 0   \nK_', BraceGroup('yr'), '^', BraceGroup('(-)'), ' ', '&= - r ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^x_', BraceGroup('yr'), ' =  0   .\n'], []), '\nOn the right, where the fluid velocity is linear, the Christoffel symbols of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Chris1')]), ') yield a nontrivial extrinsic curvature ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K^', BraceGroup('(+)')], []), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nK^', BraceGroup('(+)'), '_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' ', '&= - r ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^x_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('2 b^4 r^3')]), '   \nK^', BraceGroup('(+)'), '_', BraceGroup('yr'), ' ', '&= - r ', TexCmd('Gamma'), '^x_', BraceGroup('yr'), ' =  ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('2 r')]), '(1 + b^2 r^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br) )  . \n"], []), '\n', '\nThe tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ' ', '(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('gammaij')]), ') is defined to be the difference between the extrinsic curvatures on the two sides of the surface layer\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = K^', BraceGroup('(+)'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' - K^', BraceGroup('(-)'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), '  .\n'], []), '\nThe bulk stress tensor integrated over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' is equal to the tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S_', BraceGroup('ij')], []), ', defined by \n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n-8 ', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N  S_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' = ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' - g_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' ', TexCmd('gamma'), '_', BraceGroup('m'), '^m  . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('Sdef')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe expression (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sdef')]), ') for the integrated bulk stress tensor was derived in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ' for a 4-dimensional space with no cosmological constant.  While several factors in the derivation change in our current 5-dimensional situation, Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sdef')]), ') remains unchanged.  The cosmological constant term yields a contribution proportional to the integral of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' times the metric integrated over the thickness ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ' of the surface layer.  As the metric is taken to be finite, this term vanishes in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['darrow 0'], []), ' limit.\n\nThe trace of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(v^2)'], []), ', therefore (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('Sdef')]), ') yields the integrated bulk stress tensor\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nS_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' ', '&= - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N b^4 r^3')]), '   \nS_', BraceGroup('yr'), ' ', '&=  - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v'"), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N r')]), '(1 + b^2 r^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br) )  .\n"], []), '\nThese are equal to the integrals over the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' direction', TexCmd('footnote', [BraceGroup('Note that, following Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Israel:1966rt')]), ', the measure of this integral must be that of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' rescaled to normal coordinates.  Therefore the integral contains an additional factor of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r=', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('g_', BraceGroup('xx'))])], []), '.')]), ' of the stress tensors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T^', BraceGroup('(1)')], []), ' of Subsec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('T1sez')]), ' at order ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k=1'], []), ', in other words, without the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1'], []), ' term that entered into the metric (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('metfin')]), ') multiplied by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p')], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Evslin:2010ss')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nT^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('ty'), ' ', '&= - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''"), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N b^4 r^4')]), '   \nT^', BraceGroup('(1)'), '_', BraceGroup('yr'), ' ', '&=  - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup("v''"), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), ' G_N r^2')]), '(1 + b^2 r^2 ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), "'_1(br) )  .\n"], []), '\nThe ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1'], []), ' terms arose from the dualization of the interpolating region, which did not satisfy the equations of motion.  It therefore cannot enter into the Israel calculation, which uses only the solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations.  Indeed, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1'], []), ' terms in (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('metfin')]), ') are singular in the limit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['darrow 0'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v', TexCmd('p'), TexCmd('p')], []), ' diverges as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/d'], []), ", and therefore the boundedness of the extrinsic curvature assumed in Israel's derivation fails for the metric interpolation (", TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('metfin')]), ').\n\nLike the stress tensor (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('tty')]), ') calculated by interpolating the hydrodynamic flow, the Israel stress tensor does not satisfy the null energy conditions.  Again, to linear order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', one may consider vectors which are null with respect to the static black brane metric.  Therefore, again one may consider the null vectors ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w_', TexCmd('pm')], []), ' of Eq.~(', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('w')]), ').  As ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('ty')], []), ' is, at least for any finite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), ', equal to that of Subsec.~', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('T1sez')]), ' divided by the positive combination ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['br'], []), ', the sign of the inner product (', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('prod2')]), ') is unchanged.  Therefore the null energy condition is also violated by this stress tensor.  \n\nThe main difference between the two stress tensors is then that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T_', BraceGroup('yr')], []), ' does not vanish for the Israel tensor.  Remembering that in our Gaussian null coordinates the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['r'], []), " direction is the sum of a spatial and temporal piece, the spatial component implies that there is a nonzero stress.  More precisely, while both Israel's thin surface layer and the thick fluid surface layer have a nonvanishing ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' momentum, the Israel surface layer also has a flux of this ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' momentum in the radial direction, from the boundary into the horizon of the black brane.  As the black brane is infinite in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' direction, this is not problematic for the time-independence of the solution.\n\n\n', TexCmd('chapter*', [BraceGroup('Conclusions ', '\\&', ' future directions')]), '\n', TexCmd('addcontentsline', [BraceGroup('toc'), BraceGroup('chapter'), BraceGroup('Conclusions ', '\\&', ' future directions')]), '\n', '\n', '\nTurbulence often arises as a result of the boundary conditions placed on a fluid.  As a preliminary step towards an understanding of turbulence in gravity, we have proposed two gravitational duals of such boundaries.  Both of these duals involve the addition of a surface layer of matter, with a certain stress tensor.  These proposals are in a sense trivial, as the dynamics of the duals is defined not by any known equations of motion, but by the duality map itself.  It remains to be shown whether such matter can exist.  For example, even if the equations of motion which it obeys can be found, the existence of a UV completion of the matter theory may be fundamentally obstructed as in Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('nima')]), '.  Or the failure of the null energy condition may imply that, whatever the ultraviolet theory may be, the wall simply disintegrates before it has any significant effect on the fluid.  \n\nOf course, an ultraviolet completion is not necessarily a prerequisite for learning something interesting about whatever the gravitational dual to turbulence may be.  After all, no ultraviolet completion of Einstein gravity is used in this correspondence.  The surface layer implies the existence of equations of motion which are distinct from the Einstein vacuum equations and perhaps pathological.  However the interesting part of the fluid, the turbulent part, is not at the wall.  For example, if we consider the motion of a fluid in a pipe, the flow may be turbulent throughout the interior of the pipe.  The ultralocality of the duality map implies that, at a distance greater than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1/T'], []), " from the pipe, the vacuum Einstein equations are still satisfied by the gravity dual.   Thus in a sense the ultralocality decouples the problem of understanding turbulence in gravity from the problem of defining a gravity dual of a boundary.\n\nBesides trying to characterize the gravitational dual of turbulent flow, the other interesting question is to find the gravitational dual of the conditions under which turbulence can occur.  In nonrelativistic, incompressible flows, turbulence is expected when the product of a system's characteristic scale ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' times the characteristic velocity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ' of a fluid is much greater than the kinematic viscosity.  In Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008ji')]), ', the authors claim that for the conformal fluids dual to AdS black branes, turbulence is expected when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['LTv', TexCmd('gg'), '1'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' is the temperature of the fluid.  The AdS/hydrodynamics correspondence is expected to be reliable at scales ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' such that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['LT', TexCmd('gg'), '1'], []), '.  Therefore since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v<1'], []), ', it appears that whenever turbulence is expected, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['LT>LTv', TexCmd('gg'), '1'], []), ' and so the correspondence can be trusted at least for quantities that vary over a distance ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), '.  ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(3+1)'], []), '-dimensional turbulence is characterized by vortices of various sizes from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ' down to the dissipation scale ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rich')]), '.  Thus the duality appears to be reliable at least for the largest vortices in a turbulent flow.  The dissipation scale is a function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['L'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['v'], []), ', and so in principle one may determine whether or not the duality is reliable for vortices all of the way down to this scale and so for the entire flow.\n\nUnderstanding the gravity duals of turbulent flows, as described above, may yield new insights into the dynamics of black branes in AdS space, perhaps revealing a surprising difference between branes in AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_4'], []), ' and AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_5'], []), ', or indicating that generically they come with funnels attached as in Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('MarolfRang')]), '.  The main weakness of this program is the dependence on asymptotically AdS geometry in the duality map of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008jc')]), '.  There was no such restriction in the original correspondence of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('D1979')]), ', nor in other identifications of black holes and viscous fluids such as the blackfold program of Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('bf1,bf2')]), ' and the Wilsonian identification of Ref.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Strominger')]), '.  An extension of turbulence to asymptotically Minkowski space could relate (3+1)-dimensional fluid dynamics to wealth of studies of asymptotically Minkowski 5d black objects, such as Refs.~', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('5d')]), '.  More importantly, relaxing the asymptotically AdS condition may mean that fluid mechanics, perhaps in only 2+1 dimensions, has something to teach us about real world gravity.  \n \n ', TexCmd('appendix'), '\n ', '\n ', TexCmd('chapter', [BraceGroup('Conventions ', '\\&', ' Notation')]), '\n ', '\nWe work in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(-++', TexCmd('ldots'), ')'], []), ' signature. ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mu'), ',', TexCmd('nu')], []), ' denote space-time indices, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i,j=1 ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' k'], []), ' label the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['k'], []), ' different conserved charges. The dimension of the spacetime in which the conformal fluid lives is denoted by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d'], []), '. In the context of AdS/CFT, the dual AdS', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['_', BraceGroup('d+1')], []), ' space has ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d+1'], []), ' spacetime dimensions.\n \n We adopt standard symmetrization and anti-symmetrization conventions. For any tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['F_', BraceGroup('ab')], []), ' we define the symmetric part as\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n F_', BraceGroup('(ab)'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '\\,', ' ', '(F_', BraceGroup('ab'), ' + F_', BraceGroup('ba'), ') \n '], []), '\n and the anti-symmetric part as\n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['\n F_', BraceGroup('[', 'ab', ']'), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '( F_', BraceGroup('ab'), ' - F_', BraceGroup('ba'), ')  .\n '], []), '\n We also use ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' D')], []), ' to indicate the velocity projected covariant derivative: \n ', TexNamedEnv('equation', [TexCmd('equiv'), ' u^', TexCmd('mu'), ' ', '\\,', ' ', TexCmd('nabla'), '_', TexCmd('mu'), '  .\n '], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathscr'), ' D')]), '\n For any two tensor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' T'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'))], []), ' we denote the symmetric traceless projections transverse to the velocity field as:\n', TexNamedEnv('equation', ['^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('langle'), TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('rangle')), ' = P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('alpha')), ' ', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('nu'), TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup('(', TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), ')'), ' - ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('d-1')]), '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mu'), TexCmd('nu')), ' ', '\\,', ' P^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('beta')), '\\,', ' ', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' T'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), TexCmd('beta')), '  .\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('angleb')]), '\n'], [BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathcal'), ' T')]), '\t\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Integral functions')]), '\n', '\nWe list in the following the two different conventions on integral functions entering in the second order metric dual to fluid solutions on the boundary. The definitions adopted in many works (', BraceGroup(TexCmd('it'), ' e.g. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Bhattacharyya:2008mz')])), ') are\n\n ', TexNamedEnv('align', ['\nF(br) &', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-1'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy ,\nH_1(br)&', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-2'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy ,\nH_2(br)&', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), '^d-1)')]), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), 'y^', BraceGroup('d-3'), 'dy ', '[', '1+(d-1)y F(y) +2 y^', BraceGroup('2'), " F'(y) ", ']', ' \n', '&=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' F(br)^2-', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), '^d-1)')]), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-2'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy , \nK_1(br) &', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '^2')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), "dy y^2 F'(y)^2 , \nK_2(br) &", TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '^2'), BracketGroup('1-', TexCmd('xi'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), "-1)F'(", TexCmd('xi'), ') -2(d-1)', TexCmd('xi'), '^', BraceGroup('d-1'), ' . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' \n', '&. ', TexCmd('quad'), ' +(2(d-1)', TexCmd('xi'), '^d-(d-2))', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), "dy y^2 F'(y)^2 ")]), ' ,\nL(br) &', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), TexCmd('xi'), '^', BraceGroup('d-1'), 'd', TexCmd('xi'), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' dy ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y-1'), BraceGroup('y^3(y^d-1)')]), '  .\n'], []), '\n', '\nDefinitions adopted in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Rangamani:2009xk')]), ' are\n\n ', TexNamedEnv('align', ['_1(br)  &', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-1'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy ,\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_2(br)  &', TexCmd('equiv'), ' 2', '\\,', '(rb)^2 ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '^2')]), TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), "dy y^2 F'(y)^2 , \n", BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_3(br) &', TexCmd('equiv'), '  ', '(br)^2 ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('y^', BraceGroup('d-2'), '-1'), BraceGroup('y(y^', BraceGroup('d'), '-1)')]), 'dy ,\n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' g'), '_4(br) &', TexCmd('equiv'), ' ', '(br)^2 ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('br'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('d', TexCmd('xi')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi'), '(', TexCmd('xi'), '^d-1)')]), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('xi')), 'y^', BraceGroup('d-3'), 'dy ', '[', '1+(d-1)y F(y) +2 y^', BraceGroup('2'), " F'(y) ", ']', ' \n', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathfrak'), ' v'), '_1(br) &', TexCmd('equiv'), '
