The entering times ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '^i'], []), ', the exploration rate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_t'], []), ', and the learning rate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '_t'], []), ', will be specified in Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thInf')]), '.')]), '\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('figbFPLinf')]), '\n'], []), '\n'], [BracketGroup('t!')]), '\n', '\nHere, we sketch a variant of bFPL, taken from\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Poland:05dule')]), ', with guaranteed worst-case\nperformance against a bandit with countably infinitely many\narms. So we consider the following setup: The adversary\nsubsequently generates cost vectors '], []), 'c_t', TexCmd('in', [BracketGroup('0,1')]), '^', TexCmd('infty'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [',\nand at each time '], []), 't', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' we have to select one index or expert\n'], []), 'i', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' and incur its cost '], []), 'c_t^i', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. We learn only the cost of\nthe selected expert. \n\nAs a prerequisite, we need that each of the infinitely many\nexperts is associated with a ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('prior weight')]), ' '], []), 'w^i', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' such\nthat '], []), TexCmd('sum'), '_i', TexCmd('leq'), ' 1', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. Since in order to obtain a cost\nestimate '], []), TexCmd('hat'), ' c', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', the observed cost is divided by the\nweight of the sampled expert, we have to be careful not to\nadmit too small weights. We need to keep control of the\nmaximum possible expected cost, since otherwise the step\nfrom FPL to IFPL would be problematic. \nOne possibility to do so is defining an ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('entering time')]), '\n'], []), TexCmd('tau'), '^i', TexCmd('geq'), ' 1', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' for each expert. Prior to '], []), TexCmd('tau'), '^i', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', the\nexpert is not active and cannot be chosen. We choose\n'], []), TexCmd('tau'), '^i=', TexCmd('lceil'), TexCmd('big(\'), 'frac', BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('w^i'), TexCmd('big)^', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), '\n')]), TexCmd('rceil'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [', with '], []), '0<', TexCmd('alpha'), '<1', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' to be defined later. Then\nit is not hard to see that the minimum weight of any active\nexpert at time '], []), 't', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' is lower bounded:\n'], []), TexCmd('min'), '\\{', 'w^i:t', TexCmd('geq'), TexCmd('tau'), '^i', '\\}', TexCmd('geq'), ' t^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('alpha')), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. Letting the\nexploration rate be '], []), TexCmd('gamma'), '_t=t^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('beta')), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' with '], []), '0<', TexCmd('beta'), '<1', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\nto be defined later, the maximum unbiasedly estimated cost\nis at most '], []), 't^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '+', TexCmd('beta')), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. For the step from FPL to IFPL\nto go through, we thus may choose\n'], []), TexCmd('eta'), '_t=t^', BraceGroup('-2', TexCmd('alpha'), '-2', TexCmd('beta')), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. Then both steps from bFPL to\nFPL and from FPL to IFPL each cause a regret of at most\n'], []), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('t=1'), '^T t^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('beta')), TexCmd('leq'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('beta'))]), 'T^', BraceGroup('1-', TexCmd('beta')), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\nOn the other hand, '], []), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('eta'), '_T')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' causes a regret of at\nmost '], []), 'T^', BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('alpha'), '+2', TexCmd('beta')), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. In order to minimize these bounds\nsimultaneously, we choose '], []), TexCmd('beta'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1-2', TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('3')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['.\n\nIn order to guarantee that the step from IFPL to some fixed\nexpert holds, we have to correctly assign estimated costs to\ninactive experts. For example, if an expert enters the game\nand previously has been assigned no estimated cost at all,\nthen a bound w.r.t. this expert may be difficult to obtain.\nWe therefore assign ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('maximum possible')]), ' estimated costs\nto all inactive experts. Then one can show\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Poland:05dule')]), " that, evaluating the expected costs,\nthe step IFPL to some fixed reference expert holds almost\nwithout modification. Clearly, the reference expert's\nestimated costs now exceed its true costs by at most \n"], []), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('t=1'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('tau'), '^i-1'), 't^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '+', TexCmd('beta')), TexMathModeEnv('$', [', which is easily\nshown to be upper bounded by\n'], []), TexCmd('big(\'), 'frac', BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('w^i'), TexCmd('big)^', [BraceGroup('1+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('beta')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'))]))]), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['. This gives another ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('additive')]), ' bound to the\nregret in terms of the weight of the reference expert --\nthere is not multiplicative factor of '], []), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('w^i')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' any\nmore. This is an artifact of \nthe design of the algorithm and proof technique and does not\nmean that the new variant performs better than the old one.\nActually, since '], []), TexCmd('alpha'), '>0', TexMathModeEnv('$', [', the bound is now\n'], []), 'O', TexCmd('big(t'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('3')]), '+', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2', TexCmd('alpha')), BraceGroup('3')])), TexCmd('big)$'), ' as opposed to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O', TexCmd('big(t'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('3')])), TexCmd('big)$'), ' before. Choosing a large\n'], []), TexCmd('alpha'), TexMathModeEnv('$', [' results in a small '], []), TexCmd('big(\'), 'frac', BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('w^i'), TexCmd('big)$'), ' term,\nbut the order in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' gets large, while a small ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha')], []), ' has\nthe opposite effect.  \n\nThe complete algorithm is specified in Figure\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('figbFPLinf')]), '. The following statement, which improves on\nthe bounds given in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Poland:05dule')]), ' ', '(they are based\non the workaround from ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McMahan:04')]), ') is an example\nwhere we select ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '=', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('8')])], []), '. \n\n', TexNamedEnv('Theorem', [TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('thInf')]), '\nConsider a bandit problem with countably many arms/experts,\neach expert ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), ' having a prior weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['w^i'], []), ' such that the\nweights sum up to at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), '.\nThen the above described bFPL variant with entering times\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('tau'), '^i=', TexCmd('lceil'), TexCmd('big(\'), 'frac', BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('w^i'), TexCmd('big)^'), '8', TexCmd('rceil')], []), ',\nexploration rate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma'), '_t=t^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('4')]))], []), ', and learning\nrate ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '_t=t^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('4')]))], []), ', satisfies the regret bound\n', TexCmd('beqn'), '\n', TexCmd('Expect'), ' c', TexCmd('leqT'), TexCmd('bfpl'), '-c', TexCmd('leqT'), '^i ', TexCmd('leq'), '\nO(', TexCmd('Big(\'), 'tfrac', BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('w^i'), TexCmd('Big)^', [BraceGroup('11')]), '+T^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3'), BraceGroup('4')])), TexCmd('log'), '\nw^i)\n', TexCmd('eeqn'), '\nfor all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T', TexCmd('geq'), ' 1'], []), ', any adaptive assignment of the cost\nvectors and any reference expert ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe formal proof is omitted. It follows the outline of Theorem ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('thMain')]), ',\nusing the arguments discussed above. Many of the arguments, including the step\nfrom IFPL to the reference expert, are formally carried out in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Poland:05dule')]), '.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Discussion')]), TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('secDC')]), '\n', '\nThe main statement of this paper is the following:\n\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('1ex')]), '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\n', TexCmd('hspace*', [BraceGroup('0.1', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('minipage', ['\n', TexCmd('itshape'), '\nIf we have a regret\nminimization algorithm with a bound guaranteed against an oblivious adversary,\nand if the algorithm chooses the current action/expert by some\nindependent random sampling based on past cumulative scores (e.g. FPL or\nweighted majority), then the same bound also holds against an adaptive\nadversary. This is true both for full and partial observations.\n'], [BraceGroup('0.8', TexCmd('textwidth'))]), '\n', TexCmd('vspace', [BraceGroup('1ex')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('noindent'), '\nWe have used this argument for showing bounds for FPL in the adversarial bandit\nproblem. The strategy to use only feedback from exploration rounds which is\ncommon for FPL achieves a regret bound of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(t^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('3')])), ')'], []), '. As the\nalgorithm is label efficient, this bound is sharp. Using all observations\nallows to push the regret down to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(', TexCmd('sqrt'), ' t)'], []), '. Then however the sampling\nprobabilities have to be approximated.\n\nIn the same way, it is possible to use our argument for the general geometric\nonline optimization problem ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('McMahan:04,Awerbuch:04')]), ', also resulting in a\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(t^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('2'), BraceGroup('3')])), ')'], []), ' regret bound against adaptive adversary. An interesting\nopen problem is the following: Under which conditions and how is it possible to\nuse all observations in the geometric online optimization problem, hopefully\narriving at a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['O(', TexCmd('sqrt'), ' t)'], []), ' bound?\n\nWe conclude with a note on ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('regret against an adaptive adversary')]), '. We\nconsidered the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('external')]), ' regret w.r.t. the best action/strategy/expert\nfrom a pool. There are two directions from here. One is to go to different\nregret definitions, such as internal regret. The other one is to change the\nreference and compare to the ', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('hypothetical')]), ' performance of the best\nstrategy, in this way accepting a stronger type of \ndependency of the future costs from\nthe currently selected action (see e.g. ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Poland:05dule')]), ' and the references\ntherein). It is one of the major open problems to propose refined algorithms and\nprove better bounds in this model.\n\n\n', TexCmd('bibliographystyle', [BraceGroup('alpha')]), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('thebibliography', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('bibitem', [BracketGroup('ACBFS95'), BraceGroup('Auer:95')]), '\nP.~Auer, N.~Cesa-Bianchi, Y.~Freund, and R.~E. [BraceGroup(TexCmd('dz')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' z')]))]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('theorem'), BraceGroup('Theorem'), BracketGroup('section')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('corr'), BracketGroup('theorem'), BraceGroup('Corrollary')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('lemma'), BracketGroup('theorem'), BraceGroup('Lemma')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('prop'), BracketGroup('theorem'), BraceGroup('Proposition')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('remark'), BraceGroup('Remark')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('definition'), BraceGroup('Definition')]), '\n', TexCmd('newtheorem', [BraceGroup('example'), BraceGroup('Example')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('document', ['\n', '\n', TexCmd('markboth', [BraceGroup('Susama Agarwala'), BraceGroup('Momentum cut-off and dimensional\n  regularization')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('title', [BraceGroup('Geometrically relating momentum cut-off and dimensional\n  regularization')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('author', [BraceGroup('SUSAMA AGARWALA')]), '\n', TexCmd('address', [BraceGroup(' Mathematics Department  California Institute of Technology \n1200 E California Ave. \nPasadena, CA 91106')]), '\n', TexCmd('email', [BraceGroup('susama@caltech.edu')]), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('maketitle'), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('abstract', [' The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for a scalar field theory describes the\n  dependence of the coupling constant on the renormalization mass\n  scale. This dependence is affected by the choice of regularization\n  scheme. I explicitly relate the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions of momentum cut-off\n  regularization and dimensional regularization on scalar field\n  theories by a gauge transformation using the Hopf algebras of the\n  Feynman diagrams of the theories.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexCmd('keywords', [BraceGroup(TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function, Hopf Algebra, momentum cut-off regularization, dimensional regularization')]), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Introduction')]), "\nPerturbative quantum field theories (QFTs), when naively calculated,\nlead to divergent integrals and undefined quantities. To address this\nproblem, physicists have developed many regularization and\nrenormalization schemes to extract finite values from divergent\nintegrals. Introducing a regularization parameter forces the\nquantities in the Lagrangian of the field theory to be dependent on\nthe energy scale of the calculation. This scale dependence is captured\nby a new parameter called the renormalization mass. The theory's\ndependence on the renormalization mass is described by a set of\ndifferential equations, called the renormalization group equations, or\nRGEs. The simplest of these solves for the dependence of the coupling\nconstant on the renormalization mass, and gives the ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function\nof the theory. In the perturbative case, the RGEs depend on the\nregularization scheme. Different regularization schemes give rise to\ndifferent RGEs. Very little is understood about the relationship\nbetween different regularization schemes.\n\nIn this paper, I compare regularization schemes with logarithmic\nsingularities and finite poles to those with only finite\npoles. Specifically, I study the relationship between sharp momentum\ncut-off regularization and dimensional regularization, and the\nassociated ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions.\n\nRecent literature has emerged geometrically describing this process of\nrenormalization and regularization for a QFT in which the perturbative\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for dimensional regularization is defined by a\nconnection on a renormalization bundle in which different\nregularization schemes correspond to sections ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK00, CK01, CM06,\n  EGK04, EM, thesis1')]), '.  I extend the analysis in these papers in two\ndirections. First, I extend the Birkhoff decomposition of characters\ndeveloped in the literature to include algebras with logarithmic\nsingularities found in momentum cut-off and related regularization\nschemes. Second, I look at a renormalization bundle that admits a\nnumber of different renormalization group actions. Geometrically, the\nperturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function is the vector field generating the group\nof one parameter diffeomorphisms induced by the renormalization group\naction.  By incorporating multiple renormalization group actions into\none bundle, where each defines a one parameter family of\ndiffeomorphisms, I can write the perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for\neach of these renormalization group actions in terms of a connection\non this extended renormalization bundle. As a result, perturbative\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions for dimensional regularization and momentum cut-off,\nwhich are known to be different for gauge theories beyond the three\nloop level can be related in terms of a gauge transformation.\n\nSection 1 recalls some useful facts about Feynman integrals,\ndimensional regularization and cut-off regularization. Section 2\nconstructs the new renormalization bundle and defines the relevant\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions in terms of connections on it.\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('Momentum Cut-off and Dimensional Regularization')]), '\n', '\nIn this section I consider Feynman integrals of a massive ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^4'], []), '\ntheory in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^4'], []), ' ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), ' = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), ' ', TexCmd('phi'), '(', TexCmd('Delta'), ' + m^2)', TexCmd('phi'), '\n+ g ', TexCmd('phi'), '(x)^4 ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' The same arguments can be made for other\nrenormalizable theories. For a graph, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['l'], []), ' loops, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['I'], []), '\ninternal edges, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J'], []), ' external edges with assigned momenta ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_1\n', TexCmd('ldots'), ' e_J'], []), ', the Feynman integral is of the form ', TexCmd('ba'), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^', BraceGroup('4l')), TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^I ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)^2 + m^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^ld^4p_i ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('example')]), '\\;', ' ,', TexCmd('ea'), ' where the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' are the\nloop momentum assigned to each loop, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(p_i,e_j)'], []), ' is a linear\ncombination of the loop and external momenta representing the momenta\nassigned to each internal leg, and the square refers to a dot product\nof the vectors. All calculations in this paper are done in Euclidean\nspace, all integrals have been Wick rotated. These integrals,\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('example')]), ', are generally divergent as written. The process of\nregularization and renormalization extracts physical, finite values\nfrom these divergent integrals. In this section, I recall properties\nof dimensional regularization and momentum cut-off regularization. The\nlatter can be renormalized using the BPHZ algorithm, which iteratively\nsubtracts off certain Taylor jets in the external momenta. The former\ncan be renormalized using the BPHZ algorithm with a minimal\nsubtraction operator replacing the Taylor jet subtraction\noperator. Section ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('BPHZcutoff')]), ' recalls that using the minimal\nsubtraction operator for momentum-cutoff regularization gives a valid\nrenormalization scheme.\n\nFor dimensional regularization, write the integral in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('example')]), '\nin spherical coordinates, ', TexCmd('bas'), ' A(4)^l ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('infty'), TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^I\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)^2 + m^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^lp_i^3 dp_i ', '\\;', ' ,', TexCmd('eas'), ' where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A(d) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('Gamma'), '(d)'), BraceGroup('(4', TexCmd('pi'), ')^', BraceGroup('d/2'))])], []), ' is the volume of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S^', BraceGroup('d-1')], []), ',\nthe sphere in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d-1'], []), ' dimensions. Dimensional regularization exploits\nthe fact that the integral above is convergent if taken over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d = 4+\nz'], []), ', dimensions, with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' a complex parameter. Notice that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A(d)'], []), ' is\nholomorphic in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ', and does not contribute to the polar structure of\nthe graph. The dimensionally regularized integral is ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = A(d)^l ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('infty'), TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^I\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)^2 + m^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^lp_i^', BraceGroup('d-1'), ' dp_i ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), '\nPut another way, dimensional regularization assigns a holomorphic\nfunction, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A(d)'], []), ', times the Mellin transform of each loop integral in\nthe Feynman integral.  If the original integral is divergent, this\nexpression has a pole at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['d = 4'], []), '.\n\nMomentum cut-off regularization multiplies the integrand of the\nFeynman integral in polar coordinates by a cutoff function. The\nsimplest is to impose a sharp cut-off function ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('chi'), '_', TexCmd('Lambda'), '(p)\n=', TexNamedEnv('cases', [' 1 & ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p', TexCmd('leq'), ' ', TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ',')]), '  0 &', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p >\n  ', TexCmd('Lambda')], []), '.')])], []), ' ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), " However, this destroys some nice\nanalytic properties, and sometimes it is better to examine a smooth\ncutoff function. The calculations in the paper are done using sharp\ncut-off, but the analysis generalizes to the smooth case. The\nphilosophy behind cut-off regularization is that physical theories are\nonly valid in a certain domain. Once the energy scale is large enough,\none doesn't expect the theory to hold. Therefore, one should only\nconsider energy scales at which the theory is valid.  The momentum\ncut-off regularized version of ", TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('example')]), ' is ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('Lambda')), '^', TexCmd('Lambda'), TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^I\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)^2 + m^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^l d^4p_i ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' \n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nA one particle irreducible graph, or a 1PI graph, is a connected graph that\nis still connected after the removal of any single (internal)\nedge.'], []), '\n', '\nDimensional analysis and power counting arguments show that the only\ndivergent integrals of renormalizable ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^4'], []), ' theory in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^4'], []), ' are\nthose associated to 1PI graphs with either 2 or 4 external legs (', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['J\n', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', '2, 4', '\\}'], []), ') ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nFor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^4'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^4'], []), ', the superficial degree of divergence of a 1PI\ngraph, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = 4l -2I'], []), '. '], []), '\n', '\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') <0'], []), ' then the integral is convergent. If\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('geq'), '0'], []), ', the integral is divergent, ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), ' ', TexCmd('S'), '8.1.3.\nDimensional regularization of integrals in renormalizable theories\ngives holomorphic functions with finite poles at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z = 0'], []), '. Momentum\ncutoff regularization with a sharp cut-off function has logarithmic and\npolynomial singularities at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ', ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), '\n', TexCmd('S'), ' 8.2.1. One can impose different cut-off functions to maintain\nsmoothness or other analytic properties. Then the regulator depends on\nthe cutoff function.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Renormalization group action')]), '\nIn this section I explicitly show the effect of the renormalization\ngroup on Feynman rules regulated by dimensional regularization and\nmomentum cutoff regularization. The unregularized Lagrangian for a\nfield theory is scale invariant, ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^4'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(x) d^4x =\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^4'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(tx) d^4(tx) ', TexCmd('eas'), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('>0')], []), '. Let\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(z, x)'], []), ' be the regularized Lagrangian density, with\nregulator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), '. This scale invariance no longer holds ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^4'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(z, x) d^4x ', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^4'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(z, tx)\nd^4(tx) ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' The action of the renormalization group translates\nbetween the results of different energy scales of the Lagrangian\ndensity for a theory.\n\nStrictly speaking, the renormalization group is actually a torsor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['M\n', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), TexCmd('simeq'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('>0')], []), '. Fixing an energy scale for the theory determines the\nidentity of the renormalization group. To see the effect of the\nrenormalization group on Feynman integrals, I write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(m,\ne_j, t, z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(m, e_j, t, ', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' as\nthe Feynman integral associated to the graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '. Here ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' is the\nmass, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_j'], []), ', the external momenta and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' the scale at which the\ntheory is being evaluated. A Feynman integral taken at the energy\nscale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t'], []), ' is integrated against the variables ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['tp_i'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['p_i'], []), ' are\nthe loop momenta of the graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '. Explicitly, ', TexCmd('ba'), '\nt^', BraceGroup('zl'), TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(m, e_j, 1, z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')=\nt^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'), TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(tm, te_j, t, z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') \n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('scalingdr')]), '  ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(m, e_j, 1, ', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')=\nt^', BraceGroup('-', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'), TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(tm, te_j,t, t', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')\n(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('scalingmc')]), ' ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('ea'), '\n', '\nThe extra factor of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t^', BraceGroup('zl')], []), " in the case of dimensional\nregularization, is called the t'Hooft mass. The integrals are written\nin this manner to keep certain quantities dimensionless. On the level of the Lagrangian density, introducing the\nenergy scale also affects the coupling constant ", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g'], []), ' and the field\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi')], []), '.\n\nThe effect of the action on the Lagrangian defining the theory is\ncalculated by writing the regularized Lagrangian in terms of\nrenormalized and counterterm components. The bare, or unrenormalized,\nLagrangian is ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_B = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '(|d', TexCmd('phi'), '_B|^2\n-m_B^2', TexCmd('phi'), '_B^2) + g_B', TexCmd('phi'), '_B^3', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), " A renormalized theory gives\nGreen's functions of a renormalized field, ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('phi'), '_B = ', TexCmd('sqrt', [BraceGroup('Z(g_B, m_B,\n  z)')]), TexCmd('phi'), '_r'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('z arrow 0'), ' Z-1 = ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.  Then the\nbare Lagrangian can be written ', TexCmd('ba'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_B &=\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), 'Z|d', TexCmd('phi'), '_r|^2 -m_r^2Z', TexCmd('phi'), '_r^2) + g_rZ^', BraceGroup('3/2'), TexCmd('phi'), '_r^3 ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('bare')]), ' ', '&=\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '(|d', TexCmd('phi'), '_r|^2 -m_r^2', TexCmd('phi'), '_r^2) + g_r', TexCmd('phi'), '_r^3 ', TexCmd('nonumber'), '  ', '& ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('quad'), ' + ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('2')]), '((Z - 1)|d', TexCmd('phi'), '_r|^2 - (Z\n-1)m_r^2', TexCmd('phi'), '_r^2)+(Z^', BraceGroup('3/2'), '-1)g_r', TexCmd('phi'), '_r^3 ', '\\;', ' . ', TexCmd('nonumber'), ' ', TexCmd('ea'), ' The second line is\ncalled the renormalized Lagrangian, consisting of finite quantities\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('fp')], []), ', and the last line is the counterterm\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('ct')], []), '. Writing the Lagrangian as the sum ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_B = ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C'), BraceGroup('ct')]), ' + ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '_', BraceGroup('fp'), ' ', TexCmd('eas'), ' shows the\ncomponents that lead to counterterm and finite parts of the Feynman\nintegrals. For more details on this process see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Ti')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ', chapters 21\nand 10.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('remark', ['\nNotice that the expression for ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('bare')]), ' is only possible if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['dZ\n= 0'], []), '. This condition is known as locality of counterterms. A theory\nhas local counterterms if the counterterms can be expressed as\npolynomials in the external momenta and mass of degree at most\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '. In the case of dimensional regularization, where the\ncounterterms are defined by the projection onto the singular part of\nthe Laurent series, this condition is equivalent to saying that the\ncounterterms are free of the energy scale. Momentum cut-off\nregularization, with counterterms defined by Taylor jets taken at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), '\nexternal momenta, as in BPHZ, also has local counterterms\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), TexCmd('S'), ' 8.1. '], []), '\n', '\nThe quantities ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '_r'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m_r'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['g_r'], []), ' depend on the scale of the\ntheory. The differential equation ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '(g_r) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('t')]), '\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' g_r'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), TexCmd('eas'), ' gives the dependence of the\ncoupling constant on the scale. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function is useful in\nsolving the other dependencies. For a perturbative theory, it is\napproximated by an asymptotic expansion by loop number of the theory. For\nexample, to one loop order, the perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for a\nscalar theory is ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '(g) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('3g^2'), BraceGroup('16', TexCmd('pi'), '^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' For\nQED, it is ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '(e) = ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^3'), BraceGroup('12', TexCmd('pi'), '^2')]), ' .', TexCmd('eas'), '\n', '\nThe perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for a theory can change depending on\nwhich regularization method is employed. For a scalar field theory, as\nin the example computed above, and for gauge theories, such as QED,\nthe perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for dimensional regularization and cut off\nregularization are the same up to 3 loop orders ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), '. In this\npaper, I study two perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions: ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')], []), ', from\ndimensional regularization, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')], []), ' from momentum cut-off\nregularization. In section 2 of this paper, I show how these two\nquantities are vector fields on a bundle generating the\nrenormalization group action of the respective regularization scheme.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('BPHZ on momentum cut-off regularization ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('BPHZcutoff')]))]), '\n', '\nThe divergences in momentum cut-off regularization can be subtracted\noff by BPHZ renormalization ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), '. The BPHZ algorithm calculates\nthe counterterms, or divergent quantity, associated to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' as the\nTaylor series of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(e_i)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' in its external\nmomenta, evaluated at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' external momenta, calculated up to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_I'], []), ' be the multi-index ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(e_', BraceGroup('i_1'), ', ', TexCmd('ldots'), ',\ne_', BraceGroup('i_I'), ')'], []), ', with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e_', BraceGroup('i_j'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '\\{', 'e_1, ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' e_', BraceGroup('J-1'), '\\}'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D_', BraceGroup('e_I'), ' =\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' e_', BraceGroup('i_1'))]), ' ', TexCmd('ldots'), ' ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), '\n  e_', BraceGroup('i_I'))])], []), '. Then ', TexCmd('bas'), ' T(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(tm, te_j, t', TexCmd('Lambda'), '))(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') =\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k=0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('|I|= k'), '(D_', BraceGroup('e_I'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(tm,\nte_j, t', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')|_', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A'), BraceGroup(TexCmd('vec', [BraceGroup('e')]), ' = 0')]), ')', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e_', BraceGroup('i_1'), TexCmd('ldots'), '\n  e_', BraceGroup('i_I')), BraceGroup('i!')]), ' ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' be the Taylor series operator described above, ', TexCmd('bas'), ' T(f(e_j,\n', TexCmd('Lambda'), ') (', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')) = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k=0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('|I|=\n  k'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e_', BraceGroup('i_1'), TexCmd('ldots'), ' e_', BraceGroup('i_I')), BraceGroup('i!')]), 'D_', BraceGroup('e_I'), ' f(e_j, ', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')\n', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' '], []), '\n', '\nWrite the unrenormalized quantity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ',\nm, e_i) (', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '.  The counterterm is then ', TexCmd('bas'), ' C_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') =\n-T(U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') + ', TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), '\n    ', TexCmd('Gamma')))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('divergent')])), ' C_T(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ),\n', TexCmd('eas'), ' where the sum is over all sub-graphs of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' that are\ndivergent. The graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' is obtained by replacing each\nconnected component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' by a single vertex. The renormalized\npart is the sum, ', TexCmd('bas'), ' R_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') + C_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') +\n', TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma')))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('divergent')])), '\nC_T(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' If I define a preparation map ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') + ', TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), '\n    ', TexCmd('Gamma')))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('divergent')])), 'C_T(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')U(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Spec ')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ') ', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('eas'), '\nthen ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_T= (1-T) ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_T = -T ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T'], []), TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), '.  The\ncounterterms thus derived are local. Let ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup('C_T'), '(m, e_i,\np_j)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')), '(m, e_i, p_j)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' be the kernels of\nthe integrals ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '. By ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' C_T(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')\nU(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ', I mean the convolution product ', TexCmd('bas'), ' C_T(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')\nU(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')= ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', TexCmd('Lambda'), ' K_', BraceGroup('C_T'), '(m, e_i,\np_j)(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('phi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')), '(m, e_i, p_j)(', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('gamma'), ')', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('j=1'), '^l dp_j ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), '\n', '\nNotice that if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' has 2 external edges, then\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') + 2 = ', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '. That is, there is an\nextra vertex in the contracted graph that represents the insertion\npoint of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK01')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', ['\nThe superficial degree of divergence of a graph is conserved under\naddition of the superficial degrees of divergence of subgraphs and\ncontracted graphs: ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') +\n', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('degree')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nWrite ', TexCmd('bas'), TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = dL(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') - 2I(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = dL(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') -\n2I(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') + dL(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') - 2I(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' This proves\nthe theorem.\n'], []), '\n', '\nFor momentum cut-off regularization, as with dimensional\nregularization, the Taylor subtraction operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ' can be replaced by\na minimal subtraction operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nThe minimal subtraction operator for a regularization method ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' is\na projection onto only the terms in a series that are singular at a\npredefined limit.\n'], []), '\n', '\nFor any function of this form, ', TexCmd('bas'), ' f(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ', e_i, m) = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k=\n  -', TexCmd('infty')), '^n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j = 0'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' a_', BraceGroup('k,j'), '(m, e_i) ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^k\n', TexCmd('log'), '^j(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '/m) ', '\\;', ',', TexCmd('eas'), ' the minimal subtraction operator projects\nonto the terms that are ill defined as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ',\n', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', '(f) = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j > 0, k', TexCmd('geq'), ' 0'), ' a_', BraceGroup('k,j'), '(m, e_i) ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^k\n', TexCmd('log'), '^j(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '/m) + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k > 0'), ' a_', BraceGroup('k,0'), '(m, e_i) ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^k ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' In\nthe case of momentum cut-off regularization, one can write\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Collinsbook')]), ' ', TexCmd('S'), '5.11 ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ') = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('k=\n  -', TexCmd('infty')), '^n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j = 0'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' a_', BraceGroup('k,j'), '(m, e_i) ', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^k\n', TexCmd('log'), '^j(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '/m) ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('east'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), ' The preparation map associated to the\nminimal subtraction is ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') +\n', TexCmd('mathop', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma')))]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('divergent')])), ' C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')\nU(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), '))', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('eas'), ' with ', TexCmd('bas'), ' C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') =\n-', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gammat'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), ') ', TexCmd('quad'), ' ', TexCmd('textrm'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ' ', TexCmd('quad'), ' R_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') =\n(1-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' It is a well established fact in\nthe physics literature that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is finite and that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is local, for instance, see ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Collinsbook')]), '. In\nthis paper, I present a different proof of these facts. First, I need\nthe following lemma.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', ['\nThe quantity ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is finite as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '\narrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' and a polynomial in external momenta of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '\nof degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('otherway')]), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nThe finite limit comes from the fact that both\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('I')]), '(-T)(', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '))'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('I')]), '(-', TexCmd('pi'), ')(', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '))'], []), ' are\nfinite by construction. The singular terms are exactly ', TexCmd('ba'), '\n', TexCmd('pi'), '(R_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')) = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i>0, j>0'), 'a_', BraceGroup('ij'), '(p)', TexCmd('Lambda'), '^i', TexCmd('log'), '^j(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '/m)\n+ ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(' j>0'), 'a_', BraceGroup('0j'), '(p)', TexCmd('log'), '^j(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '/m) ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('piRt')]), TexCmd('ea'), ' where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', BraceGroup('ij'), '(p)'], []), ' are polynomials of degree at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' in the\nexternal momenta of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '. Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is local, this shows\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is polynomial of at most degree\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' in the external momenta.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nThe BPHZ preparation map, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' on momentum cut-off\nregularization, defines local counterterms, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', TexCmd('pi')], []), ' and finite\nrenormalized quantities, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R_', TexCmd('pi')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\n', '\nThe renormalized quantity is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' R_', TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('I')]), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = ( - ', TexCmd('pi'), ')\n(', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') )'], []), '  is finite since the\noperator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('I')]), '( - ', TexCmd('pi'), ')'], []), ' projects onto the terms that are finite as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.\n\nThe counterterm ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['-', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is local if\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is a polynomial in the external momenta\nof ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' of at most degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' and finite as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '\narrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Chetyrkyn')]), '. I prove this by induction on the\nnumber of subgraphs of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '.\n\nDefine ', TexCmd('bas'), ' f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') - C_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' Since\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('I')]), '( - ', TexCmd('pi'), ') ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('I')]), '( - T) ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '\nare finite by definition, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'), ' arrow ', TexCmd('infty')), '\nf(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is always finite. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' is a graph with no\nsubdivergences, then ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') =\nU(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' The counterterm ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') = -', TexCmd('pi'), '(U(', TexCmd('gamma'), '))'], []), '\nis a polynomial of homogeneous degree at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), '\nand external momenta ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), ' pg. 385.  Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['- f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') =\n(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is finite and of the correct degree by Lemma\n', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('otherway')]), '.\n\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' has a single subdivergence, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ', ', TexCmd('ba'), '\n', '(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = (T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') + (T-', TexCmd('pi'), ') C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')\nU(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')', '\\;', ' . ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('1sd')]), ' ', TexCmd('ea'), ' The graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' has no\nsubdivergences. This can be rewritten ', TexCmd('bas'), '(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('I')]), TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = (T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') +\n(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ') f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('eas'), ' Writing ', TexCmd('bas'), ' U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') = R_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') + f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') - C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('eas'), ' gives ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', '(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = (T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') -\n (T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', '[', 'f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')(C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') -f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') -\n  R_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), '))', ']', ' ', '\\;', ' . ', TexCmd('eas'), ' From Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('otherway')]), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is finite and of the correct degree. By\ndefinition of the operators ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), '(f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')\n(f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')F R_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')))= 0'], []), ' since both ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')+ R_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ' are finite. The term\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T(f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')(f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') - R_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), '))'], []), ' is a polynomial\nof the correct degree (by virtue of the external ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), ') and finite,\nsince all the components are finite. It remains to examine\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')(f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), '))'], []), '. The term ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ' is a\npolynomial of degree at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ' is a\npolynomial of degree at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), '. Therefore,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ')'], []), ' is a polynomial of degree at most\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') + ', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ', and ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', '(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ') f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') = ( -', TexCmd('pi'), ')\nf(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')C_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('eas'), ' which is finite by definition of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' and a polynomial of the correct degree. Thus ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', '(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ') ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('eas'), '  is a\npolynomial of degree ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ', and finite as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), '\narrow ', TexCmd('infty')], []), '.\n\nThis implies that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is finite and of degree at most\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' a graph with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['1'], []), ' divergent\nsubdiagram. Write ', TexCmd('bas'), ' f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = (T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') +\n(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') - T(', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')) +\n', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' the first term is finite and of the\ncorrect degree by the argument above. The second term is finite and of\nthe correct degree by Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('otherway')]), '. The third term is of the\ncorrect degree by definition of the operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['T'], []), '. By the explicit\nexpression in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('piRt')]), ', the last term is also of the correct\ndegree.\n\nSuppose ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is a polynomial of degree at most ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '\nin the external momenta, for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' with fewer than ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), '\nsubdivergences. Then,\n', TexCmd('bas'), '(T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') =  (T-', TexCmd('pi'), ')', '[', '\n  ', TexCmd('bar', [BraceGroup('R')]), '_T(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('subset'), '\n    ', TexCmd('Gamma')), 'f(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')U(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ', ']', '\\;', ' ,', TexCmd('eas'), ' where each divergent subgraph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), '\nhas ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['j<n'], []), ' subdivergent graphs. This is finite and of the correct degree\nby the arguments presented in the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n = 1'], []), ' case. Furthermore,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), ' is also finite and a polynomial of the correct degree\nfor ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' a graph with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['n'], []), ' divergent subgraphs.\n\n'], []), '\n', '\nConnes and Kreimer use BPHZ renormalization on dimensional\nregularization with the minimal subtraction operator instead of the\nTaylor series operator in their work ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK00, CK01')]), '. In this paper,\nI extend their work to include cutoff regularization. The substitution\nof the minimal subtraction operator for the Taylor series operator in\nBPHZ renormalization of different regularization schemes is well\nestablished. For example, Collins ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Collins75')]), ' does so for\ndimensional regularization, Speer ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Speer74')]), ' for analytic\nregularization, and ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Collinsbook')]), ' ', TexCmd('S'), ' 5.11.3 or ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('Reisz88')]), ' for\nlattice regularization. In the dimensional regularization the\nregularized integral is of the form ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') =\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i= -n'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), ' a_iz^i ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('east'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), ' The minimal subtraction operator\nprojects onto the polar part of the Laurent series ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', TexCmd('circ'), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('sumt'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), '_', BraceGroup('i= -n'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' a_iz^i ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), '\n', '\nHaving established that both dimensional regularization and momentum\ncut-off regularization can be renormalized by BPHZ renormalization\nunder a minimal subtraction operator, I define the target algebras of\nthe regulated integrals such that the same minimal subtraction\noperator suffices for both regulation schemes. The regulator for\ndimensional regularization, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ', is a complex parameter, where as the\nregulator for momentum cut-off, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda')], []), ' is real. First I show that\nthe regulator for momentum cut-off can be extended to a complex\nparameter as well.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', [' \nAs a complex regulation scheme, cut-off momentum regulation is\nidentical to the real case. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('theta')), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('int'), '_C', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^I\n', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)')]), ' + m^2')]), '\n', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^l d^4p_i = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' '], []), '\nt', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nTo analytically continue the momentum cut-off regulator, consider the\nFeynman integral with complex momentum ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^', BraceGroup('4l')), TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^I ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)', TexCmd('cdot'), '\n  ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)')]), ' + m^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^ld^4p_i ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' Then for\na complex cutoff regulator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('theta')), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', the regulated\nFeynman integral is ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('theta')), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') =\n', TexCmd('int'), '_C', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('k=1'), '^I ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)', TexCmd('cdot'), ' ', TexCmd('overline', [BraceGroup('f_k(p_i,e_j)')]), '\n  + m^2')]), ' ', TexCmd('prod'), '_', BraceGroup('i=1'), '^l d^4p_i ', TexCmd('eas'), ' taken along the contour ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C = t\ne^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('theta'))], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('in', [BracketGroup('-', TexCmd('Lambda'), ', ', TexCmd('Lambda'))])], []), '. The symmetries of the\nintegrand give ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Lambda'), '\ne^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('theta')), ')(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nNotice that ', TexCmd('ba'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('in'), '\n', ']', ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('dralg')]), TexCmd('ea'), ' for any Feynman diagram\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '. Rewrite ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Lambda'), ' e^', BraceGroup('i', TexCmd('theta')), ' = 1/z'], []), '. Then\n', TexCmd('ba'), TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(z)(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', ']', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('mcalg')]), TexCmd('ea'), ' for any Feynman diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '. I\nkeep the factor of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['m'], []), ' in the logarithmic term for dimensional\nconsiderations. Next I define an algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ' containing both the\nalgebras defined in ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('dralg')]), ' and ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('mcalg')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nDefine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '  := ', ']', '[', '[', 'y', ']', ']', '/(e^y -zm)'], []), ' to be the target\nalgebra for dimensional regularization and momentum cut-off\nregularization.\n'], []), '\n', '\nFor any Feynman diagram ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '),\n', TexCmd('varphi'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), '. Any element ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ' can be\nwritten ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f = ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=0'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i= -n'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' a_', BraceGroup('ij'), '\nz^iy^j'], []), '. The minimal subtraction operator is a projection onto the\nsubalgebra of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ' that contains only the term that are singular at\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z = 0'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' be the the projection on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('bas'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ' : \n&arrow& _-: = (z^', BraceGroup('-1'), ']', TexCmd('oplus'), ' y', ']', ')/(e^y -\nzm)  ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j=0'), '^', TexCmd('infty'), TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i= -n'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('infty')), ' a_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' z^iy^j &', TexCmd('mapsto'), '&\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('i<0'), ' a_', BraceGroup('ij'), ' z^iy^j + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('j >0'), ' a_', BraceGroup('0j'), ' y^j ', TexCmd('eas'), ' that maps to\nthe subalgebra of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ' that is singular at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z= 0'], []), ', (as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y\narrow -', TexCmd('infty')], []), '). Define ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_+'], []), ' to be the subalgebra such that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' = ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_- ', TexCmd('oplus'), ' ', '_+'], []), '. This is the subalgebra of terms that\nare finite at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z=0'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThis is the same as the minimal subtraction operator for momentum\ncutoff regularization.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nThe operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ':  arrow _-'], []), ' restricts to minimal\nsubtraction operator for dimensional regularization.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nDefine ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), 'A =', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ']', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), '. This is the target algebra\nof dimensional regularization. Since this the exactly the space where\nthe powers of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ', restricting ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' to this domain gives ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('pi'), '|_A : A arrow A_- :=  ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), 'A_+ = ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ']', '\n', TexCmd('subset'), ' ', '_+'], []), '. Thus the projection map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), ' restricts to the\nminimal subtraction operator for dimensional regularization.\n'], []), '\n', '\nIn the rest of the paper, I apply the methods of ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK00')]), ',\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK01')]), ', and ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CM06')]), ' to build a Hopf algebra of Feynman\ndiagrams, define the counterterms using Birkhoff decomposition, and\ndefine the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for cut-off regularization on the\ncorresponding renormalization bundle.\n\n\n', TexCmd('section', [BraceGroup('The Renormalization Bundle ')]), '\nIn ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK00')]), ', Connes and Kreimer build a Hopf algebra, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ', out of\nthe divergence structure of the Feynman diagrams for a scalar field\ntheory under dimensional regularization. They use the BPHZ algorithm\nto renormalize the theory, replacing Taylor subtraction around ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), "\nexternal momenta with the minimal subtraction operator. The key to\nconstructing this Hopf algebra is the sub-divergence structure of the\ngraphs as defined by power counting arguments. The co-product of the\nHopf algebra is defined to express the same sub-divergence data as in\nZimmermann's subtraction formula for BPHZ renormalization\n", TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), '. Replacing the Taylor series operator in BPHZ for the\nminimal subtraction operator does not change the divergence structure\nof the diagrams. Therefore, I use the same Hopf algebra to study\ncut-off regularization. In ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('vS06')]), ', van Suijlekom constructs a\nHopf algebra that captures the renormalization structure of QED under\ndimensional regularization. This is the same Hopf algebra that is\nneeded to study QED under cut-off regularization. The arguments in\nthis paper apply to both scalar ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '^4'], []), ' and QED, even though cut-off\nregularization does not preserve the gauge symmetries of QED.\n\nTo briefly recall notation, let ', TexCmd('bas'), '  =  ', TexCmd('eas'), '  be the Hopf algebra of Feynman\ndiagrams, with multiplication defined by disjoint union. It is graded\nby loop number, with ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y'], []), ' the grading operator. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_n'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Y(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = n', TexCmd('Gamma')], []), '. The co-unit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('geq'), ' 1')], []), ', and is\nthe identity map on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_0'], []), '. An admissible sub-graph of a 1PI graph,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' is a graph, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), ', or product of graphs, that can be\nembedded into ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma')], []), ' such that each connected component has 2 or 4\nexternal edges. The graph ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma')], []), ' is the graph obtained by\nreplacing each connected component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('gamma')], []), " with a vertex. The\nadmissible sub-graphs correspond to the divergences subtracted by\nZimmermann's subtraction algorithm. Using Sweedler notation, the\nco-product on ", TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' is given by the sum ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('Delta'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma'), ' = 1 ', TexCmd('otimes'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), ' + ', TexCmd('Gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('otimes'), ' 1 +', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' admis')])), TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('otimes'), '\n', TexCmd('Gamma'), '/', TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta')], []), ' denote the co-unit\nand unit of this Hopf algebra.\n\nThe Hopf algebra is connected and each graded component ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_n'], []), ' is\nfinitely generated as an algebra. Write the graded dual of this Hopf\nalgebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '^* = ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('oplus'), '_n _n^*'], []), '. The product on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '^*'], []), ' is the\nconvolution product ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f', TexCmd('star'), ' g (', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = m(f ', TexCmd('otimes'), ' g)\n', TexCmd('Delta'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ')'], []), '. The antipode, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['S'], []), ', on the restricted dual defines the\ninverse of a map under this convolution product, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), ' = S\n(f)'], []), '. By the Milnor-Moore theorem, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '^* ', TexCmd('simeq'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('U')]), '()'], []), ' is\nisomorphic to the universal enveloping algebra of the Lie algebra\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')])], []), ', generated by the infinitesimal derivatives ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('delta'), '_', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), "') = ", TexNamedEnv('cases', [' 1 & ', TexCmd('Gamma'), ' = ', TexCmd('Gamma'), "' ", TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('\n    1PI')]), '  0 & ', TexCmd('Gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('neq'), ' ', TexCmd('Gamma'), "' "], []), ' ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' The generators\nof the Lie algebra are infinitesimal characters ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('delta'), '_', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), TexCmd('Gamma'), "') = ", TexCmd('epsilon'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ', TexCmd('delta'), '_', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), "')\n+ ", TexCmd('epsilon'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), "') ", TexCmd('delta'), '_', TexCmd('Gamma'), '(', TexCmd('gamma'), ') ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' The Lie bracket is\ngiven by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['[', 'f, g', ']', ' = f', TexCmd('star'), ' g - g', TexCmd('star'), ' f'], []), '. The corresponding Lie group\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), 'G = e + '], []), ' is the group of algebra homomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), '_', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Spec ')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H'), BraceGroup('alg')]), '(, )\n=  '], []), '. See ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EM')]), ' for more discussion of this Lie group and\nLie algebra.\n\nIn this paper, I study regularization procedures that induce maps from\n the Hopf algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' to the algebra generated by the regulation\nparameter, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), '.  In dimensional regularization, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), " corresponds to\nthe complex ``dimension'' regulator. In momentum cut-off regulation,\n", TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ' corresponds to the complexification of the inverse of the cut-off,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z= ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('e^', BraceGroup('-i', TexCmd('theta'))), BraceGroup(TexCmd('Lambda'))])], []), ', and polynomials in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' correspond\nto polynomials in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('log'), ' ', '(|z|m)'], []), '.  Minimal subtraction on both these\nregulation schemes is encoded by considering the direct sum\ndecomposition ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' = ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_- ', TexCmd('oplus'), ' ', '_+'], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_-=\n(z^', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C'), BraceGroup('-1')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ']', TexCmd('oplus'), ' y', ']', ')/(e^y - zm)'], []), '. The projection map\n', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('pi'), ' :  arrow _-', TexCmd('eas'), ' is the subtraction map used\nin minimal subtraction for both schemes. This projection map is a\nRota-Baxter operator on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), '. The algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ' and this\nRota-Baxter operator are discussed in detail in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('ManchonPaycha')]), '\nin the context of cut-off regularization, and other applications.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', [' A\n  Rota-Baxter operator, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ', of weight ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('theta')], []), ' on an algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['A'], []), ' is a\n  linear map ', TexCmd('bas'), ' R: A arrow A ', TexCmd('eas'), ' that satisfies the\n  relationship ', TexCmd('bas'), ' R(x)R(y) + ', TexCmd('theta'), ' R(xy) = R(xR(y)) + R(R(x)y)\n  ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' The pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(A, R)'], []), ' is called a Rota-Baxter\n  algebra. '], []), '\n', '\n', '\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('Generalization of Birkhoff decomposition')]), '\n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'), ' , ', TexCmd('varphi'), TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), '_', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A'), BraceGroup('dr')]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(, )'], []), ' be the algebra\nhomomorphisms from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ', the Hopf algebra of Feynman graphs, to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ' the algebra spanned by the regulating parameters corresponding\nto momentum cut-off regularization and dimensional regularization\nrespectively. Paralleling the work of Connes and Kreimer in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK00')]), ', I write the counterterm and the renormalized part\nof cut-off regularization and dimensional regularization under minimal\nsubtraction as a Birkhoff-type decomposition of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')], []), '.\n\nEbrahimi-Fard, Guo and Kreimer show\nthat, if the algebra ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ' is endowed with a Rota-Baxter\noperator, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ', there is an unique expression for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '\n', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(, )'], []), ' as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_- ', TexCmd('star'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_+'], []), ' such that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_-'], []), ' lies in the image of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ', if ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_-'], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_+ ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(, )'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' corresponds to a\nsubtraction operator for BPHZ, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_-(x)'], []), ' corresponds to the\ncounterterm of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['x'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_+(x)'], []), ' the renormalized part\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EGK04')]), '. The following theorem follows directly from this result.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(,)'], []), '. Define the projection map\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ':  arrow _-'], []), '.
