There is a unique decomposition of\neach ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), ' = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_-^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_+'], []), ' with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_-(', TexCmd('Gamma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_-'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('ker'), ' ', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), ',\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('phi'), '_-(1)= 1'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' G(_+)'], []), '.  '], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' Notice that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ': arrow _-'], []), ' is a\nRota-Baxter operator of weight 1. Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '(, )'], []), ' be the algebra\nof linear maps from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ', with point-wise multiplication and\nunit ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e = ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('eta'), '_ ', TexCmd('circ'), ' ', TexCmd('epsilon')], []), '. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '(, )'], []), ',\nlet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R = ', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', TexCmd('circ'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi')], []), '. Then ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['R'], []), ' is a Rota-Baxter operator on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '(, )'], []), '. By extending the convolution product on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '^*'], []), ' to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '(, )'], []), ', each algebra homomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(,\n)'], []), ' can be uniquely decomposed according to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('pi')], []), '. For all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), '\n', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('ker'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_-(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = -', TexCmd('pi'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') +\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup(' admis.')])), TexCmd('varphi'), '_-(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')', TexCmd('varphi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '//', TexCmd('gamma'), ')\n ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_+(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') = (e-', TexCmd('pi'), ')(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), ') + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('text', [BraceGroup('\n    admis.')])), TexCmd('varphi'), '_-(', TexCmd('gamma'), ')', TexCmd('varphi'), '(', TexCmd('Gamma'), '//', TexCmd('gamma'), ')) ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' The maps\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi')], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_+'], []), ' are algebra homomorphisms from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' to\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('oplus'), ' ', '_-'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '_+'], []), ' respectively. That is, ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '(1) = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_-(1) = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_+(1) = 1_', '\\;', ' . ', TexCmd('eas'), ' However, for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Gamma'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', TexCmd('ker'), '(', TexCmd('epsilon'), ')'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_-(', TexCmd('Gamma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_-'], []), '. '], []), '\n', '\nThis is a generalization of the Birkhoff decomposition theorem, which\nsays that for any simple closed curve, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['C'], []), ', in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('P')]), '^1'], []), ' that does not pass\nthrough ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ' or ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('infty')], []), ', and a map ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' : C arrow G ', '\\;', ',', TexCmd('eas'), '\nfor a complex Lie group ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ', there is a function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_-'], []), ' that is\nholomorphic on the connected component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('P')]), '^1 ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' C'], []), ' that\ncontains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('infty')], []), ' and a function ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_+'], []), ' that is holomorphic on the\nconnected component of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('P')]), '^1 ', TexCmd('setminus'), ' C'], []), ' that contains ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), ', such\nthat ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '= ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_- ', TexCmd('star'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_+'], []), '. In the setting of dimensional\nregularization, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(, ', ']', ') =\nG(', ']', ')'], []), ', is viewed as a map from a loop in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Spec ')]), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '\n', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), ']', ' ', TexCmd('subset'), ' '], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Spec ')]), TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), 'G =  '], []), '. The Birkhoff\ndecomposition theorem on loops directly gives the existence of such a\ndecomposition. The Rota-Baxter algebra argument in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EGK04')]), ' generalizes the Birkhoff decomposition setting to other\nalgebras.\n\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('The geometric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function')]), '\nSo far, I have considered ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Hom')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), '\n', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(, )'], []), ' to be sections of a (trivial) ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' principal\nbundle over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Spec ')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' '], []), '. Call this bundle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K ', TexCmd('simeq'), TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Spec ')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Spec ')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' G', TexCmd('times'), ' \n arrow  '], []), '. Sections of this bundle correspond to\nalgebra homomorphisms from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')])], []), '. \nI follow the notation in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CM06')]), ' and consider a complex\nrenormalization group, instead of a real group. For the following\narguments the renormalization group is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nDefine the renormalization group as ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), '. Parametrize\nit by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t = e^s'], []), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), '.  '], []), '\n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' be a one parameter family of diffeomorphism on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), '\nwritten ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), ': ^', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), ' G() &arrow& G()\n (t, ', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)) &', TexCmd('mapsto'), '& ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y) ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' These\none parameter family of diffeomorphisms are a natural generalization\nof the renormalization group action on a regularized QFT, written as\nan element of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), '. \n', TexNamedEnv('definition', [' Write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_t ', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '\n', TexCmd('textrm', [BraceGroup('Diff')]), '(G())'], []), '. The orbit under this group of\ndiffeomorphisms, ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '\\{', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)) | t ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('times'), '\\}', '\\;', ',\n', TexCmd('eas'), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y) ', TexCmd('in'), ' G '], []), ' is a one parameter curve in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' which I also denote ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t (', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y))'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), '. '], []), '\n', '\nConsider the bundle ', TexCmd('bas'), ' P ', TexCmd('simeq'), ' K ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('times'), ' arrow B\n', TexCmd('simeq'), '   ', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('times'), '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' Sections of this bundle\nare algebra homomorphism from ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('otimes'), ' '], []), '. I\nwrite these sections ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), ': B arrow P'], []), ' as ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), ' ', '(z, y, t)\n', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_', BraceGroup('alg'), '(, ) = G()', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' The\nrenormalization group acts, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' acts on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ',\nthe sections of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Parrow B'], []), ', as ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('times'), ' ', TexCmd('times'), '\nG() &arrow G()  (t,\n', TexCmd('psi'), '(z,y, u)) &', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '(z,y,tu) ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' The bundle\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Parrow B'], []), ' is not ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' equivariant. Each one parameter diffeomorphism of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' defines a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' subbundle of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nFor every one parameter diffeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', there is a\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' equivariant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' principal bundle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' arrow B'], []), '\nwith sections corresponding to the curves ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_t(', TexCmd('phi'), '(z,y))'], []), ' for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y) ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' G()'], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', [' \nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' be the trivial ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' bundle over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ' defined by\nthe one parameter diffeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '. This is a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), '\nequivariant bundle over ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), '. The\nsections of this bundle are of the form ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', '(t, ', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)) :\nBarrow K_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' These sections are compatible with the\nrenormalization group action defined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.  For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('in'), '\n', '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_u(t, ', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)) = (ut,\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_u(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y))).', TexCmd('eas'), ' Therefore the bundle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma'), '\narrow B'], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' equivariant. There is a bundle injection ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('xymatrix', [BraceGroup(' K_', TexCmd('sigma'), '\n  ', TexCmd('ar'), '@', BraceGroup('^', BraceGroup('('), '->'), '[', 'rr', ']', '^', BraceGroup('i_', TexCmd('sigma')), ' ', TexCmd('ar', [BracketGroup('dr')]), '_', TexCmd('pi'), ' ', '& &P ', TexCmd('ar', [BracketGroup('dl')]), '^', TexCmd('pi'), '  ', '& B & ')]), '\n', TexCmd('eas'), ' defined on sections of the bundles as ', TexCmd('bas'), ' i_', TexCmd('sigma'), ': ^', TexCmd('times'), '\n', TexCmd('times'), ' G() &arrow G()  (t, ', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y))\n& ', TexCmd('mapsto'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)) ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' The injection fixes a unit\nfor the action of the renormalization group, mapping ', TexCmd('bas'), ' i_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(1,\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_1', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y, 1): = ', TexCmd('psi'), '(z,y,1) ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' In this manner\n', TexCmd('emph', [BraceGroup('all')]), ' possible one parameter diffeomorphisms on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' can be represented as sections of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P arrow B'], []), '.\n\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' be a one parameter diffeomorphism on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' that\ncorresponds to a renormalization group action on a QFT. The geometric\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is the vector field ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), '\nTG()'], []), ' defined by the logarithmic differential on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K'], []), ', ', TexCmd('bast'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), '\n', TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)) = ', '[', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y))^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), '\n   ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y))', ']', '|_', BraceGroup('t=1'), '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' This vector field\ngenerates the one parameter diffeomorphism on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\n '], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nFirst I check that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' TG()'], []), ' by verifying that\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y) ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), '\nG()'], []), '. Calculating the derivative gives ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(a)(b)'), TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', "(a')", TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', "(b') ", TexCmd('times', [BracketGroup(' ', '(', TexCmd('dt'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), "(z, y) (a''))|_", BraceGroup('t=1'), TexCmd('varphi'), "(z, y) (b'')\n  + ", TexCmd('varphi'), "(z, y) (a'')", TexCmd('dt'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), "(z, y) (b''))|_", BraceGroup('t=1'), ' \n  ')]), ' ', TexCmd('eas'), ' which rearranges to ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(a)(b)'), TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,\ny)^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', "(a')( ", TexCmd('sigma'), '_t ', TexCmd('varphi'), "(z, y) (a''))|_", BraceGroup('t=1'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,\ny)^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', "(b') ", TexCmd('varphi'), "(z, y) (b'') + ", TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)^', BraceGroup('-1'), '\n', "(a')", TexCmd('varphi'), "(z, y) (a'') ", TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', "(b') (", TexCmd('varphi'), "(z,\ny) (b''))|_", BraceGroup('t=1'), '   = ', TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), ')(a) ', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(b)\n+', TexCmd('varepsilon'), '(a)  ', TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('varphi'), ')(b)', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' Thus\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()'], []), '. The second statement comes from\ndefinition.\n'], []), '\n', '\nIt remains to check that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' defines a one to one\ncorrespondence between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '()'], []), ' for each ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nThe renormalization group action of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' induces a\ndiffeomorphism on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '()'], []), '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('betainv')]), ' '], []), '\n', '\nThis is just an extension of the proof of the similar statement in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EM, thesis1')]), '.\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nWe have shown that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), []), ' is well defined and in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '.\n\nFor any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()'], []), 't', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), ', and one parameter diffeomorphism ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', define a map ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' : () arrow G() ', TexCmd('eas'), ' recursively by\n', TexCmd('ba'), '  ', '(', TexCmd('rho'), TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)) =\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)) ', TexCmd('star'), '\n', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t) ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('recursiveinverse')]), ' ', TexCmd('ea'), ' with the initial\ncondition that ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(t)(', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)) (1) = 1 ', TexCmd('quad'), '\n', TexCmd('forall'), ' t ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('times'), ' ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' It is easy to check that ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(1)(t', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), ')) = ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', '\\;', ' ,', TexCmd('eas'), ' for t', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '\n', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' G()'], []), '. If it is well defined with appropriate domain, it is\nthe desired inverse function.\n\nIt remains to check that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is well defined for all\nt', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()'], []), ' and has a domain contained in t', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), '. This\nI do recursively on the grading on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')])], []), '. I use the notation ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('Deltat'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' t')]), '(a) = 1', TexCmd('otimes'), ' a + a ', TexCmd('otimes'), ' 1 + ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(a)'), "a' ", TexCmd('otimes'), " a''\n", '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' To ease notation, let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t) ', TexCmd('in'), '\\{', '\n', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t))', '\\}'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_0'], []), ', both sides of\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('recursiveinverse')]), ' are ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['0'], []), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_1'], []), ',\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('recursiveinverse')]), ' becomes ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t_0)(a) =\n', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', BraceGroup('t_0'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a)'), BraceGroup('t')]), ' dt ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' Therefore,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)'], []), ' is well defined on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '_1'], []), '. By\ninduction, for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_n'], []), ', ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('recursiveinverse')]), ' becomes ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t_0)(a) = ', TexCmd('int'), '_0^', BraceGroup('t_0'), TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a) +\n  ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(a)'), TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(a')", TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(a'')"), BraceGroup('t')]), ' dt\n', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' Since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["Y(a'), Y(a'') < n"], []), ', the kernel of the integral is known by\ninduction, and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)'], []), ' is unique.\n\nTo see that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '(z,y,t) ', TexCmd('in'), ' G()'], []), ', consider by induction\non loop number its action on composite elements ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['ab ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a, ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '\\;', 'b', TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), '  are indecomposables. For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a, b ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '_1'], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), ' \n', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(ab) = ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b)', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a)\n+ ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a)', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b)\n ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b) ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a) +\n', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a) ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b) = \n(', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a) ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b) ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' For general\nindecomposables ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a, ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), '\\;', 'b', TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), '  ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(ab) =\n', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b)', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a) +\n', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a)', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b) +\n ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(a)'), TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(ba')", TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(a'') +\n", TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(b)'), TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(ab')", TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(b'')  =\n", TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b)', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a) +\n', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a)', TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b) + ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(b)\n', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(a)'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(a' )", TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(a'') +\n", TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y,t)(a) ', TexCmd('sum'), '_', BraceGroup('(b)'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(b')\n", TexCmd('alpha'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), "(z,y,t)(b'') ", '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' The second equality comes from the\ninduction step, since ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["Y(ab') < Y(ab)"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["Y(ba') < Y(ab)"], []), '. Thus for\nall ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a, b ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('H')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y, t) (ab) = ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y, t)\n(a) ', TexCmd('psi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y, t) (b) ', TexCmd('eas'), ' showing that it is in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' as\ndesired.\n\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe geometric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function and the perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function\nfor a theory are related objects. The geometric object ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), '\nis the generator for a specified one parameter family of\ndiffeomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '. The perturbative\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function, on the other hand, calculates the scale dependence\nof a regularized QFT.\n\nRecall that regularized Lagrangians are no longer scale\ninvariant: ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^n'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(x, z, y) d^nx ', TexCmd('neq'), '\n', TexCmd('int'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('R')]), '^n'), ' ', TexCmd('mathcal', [BraceGroup('L')]), '(tx, z, y) d^n(tx) ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' The action of the\nrenormalization group on a regularized Lagrangian is defined by the\nscale dependence of the regularized theory. The ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function of a\nQFT is measured (perturbatively) with respect to this action.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nThe perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function is the geometric ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function,\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), ')'], []), ' defined on a pair ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(', TexCmd('varphi'), ', ', TexCmd('sigma'), ')'], []), ', where\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi')], []), ' corresponds to the Feynman rules under an appropriate\nregularization scheme, and the one parameter family of diffeomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '\nis defined by the scale dependence of the Feynman rules introduced by\nthe regularization scheme. '], []), '\n', '\nI relate the perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions for dimensional\nregularization and momentum cut-off regularization under these\nconventions.\n\nThe relevant renormalization group action for dimensional\nregularization is ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,t'), TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y) =\nt^', BraceGroup('zY'), TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)', '\\;', ' ,', TexCmd('eas'), ' as defined by ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('scalingdr')]), '. If ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t =\ne^s'], []), ', for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['s ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('in'), ' '], []), ', the relevant renormalization group action for\nmomentum cut-off is ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,t'), TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y) = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '(tz_0,\ny_0 + s)', '\\;', ' ,', TexCmd('eas'), ' for some fixed ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z_0'], []), ' where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['e^', BraceGroup('y_0'), ' = z_0'], []), ' as defined\nby ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('scalingmc')]), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('remark', ['\nIn this notation, the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function for dimensional regularization\nis ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), ') = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), '\nzY', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'), ' ', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('eas'), ' which is actually ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z ', TexCmd('beta')], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' is\nthe relevant ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function defined in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK01')]), '. It is further\nworth noting that due to the form of the renormalization group action\nfor dimensional regularization, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'))], []), ' defines a set\nbijection between ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '()'], []), ' ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('EM')]), '. This bijection\ndoes not exist for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe fiber over every point ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['(z, y, ', TexCmd('varphi'), ') ', TexCmd('in'), ' K'], []), ' in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma'), '\narrow K'], []), ' represents the energy scale of the character. The\ninitial energy scale of which an physical theory is evaluated\ncorresponds to a section ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y, 1)'], []), '.  Two different sections\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('eta'), '(z,y) ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' G()'], []), ' represent the same\ncharacter at different energy scales if there exists a one parameter\nfamily of diffeomorphisms ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' and a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['t ', TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' such that\n', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t ', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y) = ', TexCmd('eta'), '(z, y)', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' I show this\nexplicitly in the case of momentum cut-off regularization and\ndimensional regularization.\n\nFix the regulators ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z_0'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["z_o'"], []), '. For momentum cut-off\nregularization, write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z(t) = z_0t'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [" z'(t) = z_0't "], []), ', where ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ["z_0\n= u z_0'"], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u = e^v'], []), '. Let the character ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc, z_0'), '(z(t),\ny(s))'], []), ', correspond to the Feynman rules cut off at the momentum\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('z(t)')])], []), ' at the energy scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup('1'), BraceGroup('z_0')])], []), '. Then ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,u'), TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup("mc, z'_0"), "(z'(t), y'(s)) =", TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,\n  z_0'), "(z'(tu), y'(s+v)) = ", TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc, z_0'), '(z(t), y(s))', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), '\n', '\nIn the case of dimensional regularization, write the character\nassociated to the field theory evaluated at the energy scale ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['u'], []), ' as\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z)'], []), '. The action of the renormalization group is given\nby ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr, t'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u/t'), '(z) = t^', BraceGroup('zY'), TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u/t'), '(z)\n= ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z).', TexCmd('eas'), ' The subtlety of keeping track of the\nrenormalization scale is a minor point in the case of dimensional\nregularization because of the independence of the regulator and the\nenergy scale. The notation keeping track of the energy scale is\ndropped, but it is implicit in the definition of equisingularity in\n', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CM06')]), '.\n\nThe perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions for dimensional regularization and\nmomentum cut-off regularization are defined by the vector fields\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'))], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'))], []), '\nrespectively. Evaluating them on characters ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z)'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc, z_0'), '(z(t), y(s))'], []), ' respectively gives the corresponding perturbative ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), '\nfunction.  For dimensional regularization, ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z)) = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z) ', TexCmd('star'), '\n t^', BraceGroup('zY'), TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z) |_', BraceGroup('t=1'), ' = z', TexCmd('varphi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z) ', TexCmd('star'), ' Y\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z)', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), ' This vector field is a function of the\nregulator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), ', the complex dimension. That is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['\n', TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z)) ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()'], []), ' for all ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), '\nG()'], []), '. The physical ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function is only interesting at\ninteger dimension, when ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z=0'], []), '. Evaluated at ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z=0'], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('lim'), '_', BraceGroup('zarrow 0'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), ' ', '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z)) ', TexCmd('in'), '\n', '()', TexCmd('eas'), ' is the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function defined in ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CK01, CM06, EM,\n  thesis1')]), '. The limit is well defined because ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u')], []), ' has\nlocal counterterms.\n\nFor momentum cutoff regularization, the physical ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' function is\n', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc, z_0'), '(z(t), y(s))) =\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0'), '(z_0, y_0) ', TexCmd('star'), '  ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0'), '(z(t), y(s))\n|_', BraceGroup('t=1'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), ' It is a constant valued element of the Lie\nalgebra.\n\n', TexCmd('subsection', [BraceGroup('A connection on the renormalization bundle')]), '\n', '\nIn this section I define a connection on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' defined by the\nlogarithmic differential of sections ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,t): B arrow\nP'], []), '.  Following ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('CM06')]), ', I call this connection\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '^*', TexCmd('omega')], []), '. Following ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('thesis1')]), ', I show that these\nconnections are defined by ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', . The physical ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), '\nfunctions for a regularization scheme appear as pullbacks along\nspecific sections.  This brings me to the main theorem of the paper,\nwhich I prove at the end of this section.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nThe two physical ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z, y))'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc, z_0'), '(z(t),y(s))'], []), ' can be related by a\ngauge transformation on the bundle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P arrow B'], []), '. '], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', [' Let ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' be a differential operator.\n', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('bas'), ' D:G() &arrow\n', TexCmd('Omega'), '^1(())  ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', '(z, y,t) &', TexCmd('mapsto'), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,t)^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), TexCmd('star'), ' d(', TexCmd('varphi'), '( z,y,t))', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('eas'), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '^1(P, )'], []), ' be a connection on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' defined\nlocally by the differential operator ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), ' defined above.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('lemma', ['For ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f ', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' G()'], []), ', the differential\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D(f) = f^', TexCmd('star'), ' ', TexCmd('omega')], []), ' defines a connection on\n  section ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f'], []), ' of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P arrow B'], []), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('logmult')])], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nIf ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['D'], []), ' defines a connection, it must satisfy equation ', TexCmd('ba'), ' ', '(f^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star'), '\n  -1'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), ' g)^*', TexCmd('omega'), ' = g^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'dg + g^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), '(f^*', TexCmd('omega'), ') g ', '\\;', '\n,', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('pullbackcond')]), TexCmd('ea'), ' for ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['f,', TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '\\,', ' g ', TexCmd('in'), ' G()'], []), '. Since\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['df^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' =- f^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' df f^', BraceGroup('-1')], []), ', ', TexCmd('bas'), ' D(f^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' g) = Dg - g^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'f\nf^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'df f^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'g ', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('eas'), ' or ', TexCmd('bas'), ' Dg = D(f^', BraceGroup('-1'), ' g) + (f^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'g)^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'Df\n(f^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'g) ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' which satisfies equation\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('pullbackcond')]), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nThe objects of interest in this paper are the vector fields\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), ' ', TexCmd('in'), ' TG()'], []), '. To define these, I define a related connection\non the bundle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('definition', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' ', TexCmd('in'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), ' ', TexCmd('Omega'), '^1(K_', TexCmd('sigma'), ', )'], []), ' be the connection on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' defined ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), ' := i_', TexCmd('sigma'), '^*', TexCmd('omega')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\nViewing ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' as a ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['G'], []), ' principal bundle over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ', one can write\nthe corresponding connection over ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' as ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', '(', TexCmd('varphi'), ',\nt)^*', TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z, y, t) = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), 'd (', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), ')', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), ' As\nan element in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('Omega'), TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), '^1(B, )'], []), ', I write it as ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', '(', TexCmd('varphi'), ',t)^*', TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z, y, t) = a_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,t) dz +\nb_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,t) dy + c_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y, t) dt ', '\\;', ' , ', TexCmd('eas'), ' with ', TexCmd('ba'), '\n a_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,t) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)^', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), '\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' z')]), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', '(z,y)\n ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('adef')]), ' b_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,t) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)^', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), '\n ', TexCmd('frac', [BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial')), BraceGroup(TexCmd('partial'), ' y')]), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', '(z,y)', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('bdef')]), '\n  c_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,t) = ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)^', BraceGroup(' ', TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), ' \n ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t ', TexCmd('varphi'), ' ', '(z,y)\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('cdef')]), ' ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('ea'), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nThe connection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' equivariant for any\nrenormalization group action ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\n'], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nThis is a result of the bundle ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' being ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), '\nequivariant and that the derivative in ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathbb', [BraceGroup('C')]), '^', TexCmd('times')], []), ' is\nexponential. Explicitly, one can check this on sections.\n\nBy equations ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('adef')]), ' and ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('bdef')]), ', the coefficients\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', TexCmd('varphi')], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b_', TexCmd('varphi')], []), ' involve derivatives with respect to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['z'], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['y'], []), ' respectively. Therefore ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_u(a_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y, t)) =\na_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y , tu) '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('sigma'), '_u(b_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y, t) = b_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,\ny , tu))'], []), '. Notice that ', TexCmd('bas'), ' c_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y, 1) =\n', '[', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(z, y) ', TexCmd('star'), ' \n  ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)', ']', '|_', BraceGroup('t=1'), ' = ', TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y))', '\\;', '\n.', TexCmd('eas'), ' Furthermore, ', TexCmd('ba'), ' ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_u(', TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y)))\n= ', '[', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '^', BraceGroup('-1'), '(z, y) ', TexCmd('star'), ' \n  ', TexCmd('sigma'), '_t', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y)', ']', '|_', BraceGroup('t=u'), ' ', '\\;', '. ', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('sigmabeta')]), TexCmd('ea'), ' This,\ncombined with the fact that ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is a bijection between\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), 'G()'], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), '(A)'], []), ' gives the following:\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nThe connection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ' is defined by the vector field\ngenerating the renormalization group action, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), '.\n', TexCmd('label', [BraceGroup('betadef')])], []), '\n', '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nLet ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), '(z, y) ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(1)'], []), ' the inverse\nfunction of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', TexCmd('sigma')], []), ', as defined in Lemma ', TexCmd('ref', [BraceGroup('betainv')]), '.  Notice\nthat the quantities ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['a_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,1)'], []), ', and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['b_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z, y, 1)'], []), ' are\nall functions of ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(1)(c_', TexCmd('varphi'), '(z,y,1))'], []), '.\n\nTherefore, for any ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('alpha'), ' ', TexCmd('mathfrak', [BraceGroup('g')]), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), TexCmd('in'), ' ', '()'], []), ', I can write ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('psi'), '(z, y)\n:=', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), TexCmd('mathscr', [BraceGroup('A')]), '(1)(', TexCmd('alpha'), ')', TexCmd('in'), ' G()'], []), '. This defines a connection on\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '^*', TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y, 1) =\nD(', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(1)(', TexCmd('alpha'), '(z,y,1)))', '\\;', ', ', TexCmd('eas'), ' and by equation\n', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('sigmabeta')]), ' ', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('psi'), '^*', TexCmd('omega'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(z,y, t) =\nD(', TexCmd('rho'), '_', TexCmd('sigma'), '(t)(', TexCmd('alpha'), '(z,y,t))) ', '\\;', '.', TexCmd('eas'), '\n'], []), '\n', '\nThis allows one to relate two different physical ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), '\nfunctions.\n\n', TexNamedEnv('theorem', ['\nThe physical ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z))'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0'), '(z, y))'], []), ' both define pullbacks of\na global connection, ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' to ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), '. Therefore, they can be\nrelated by a gauge transformation.\n'], []), '\n', TexNamedEnv('proof', ['\nBy theorem ', TexCmd('eqref', [BraceGroup('betadef')]), ', ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'))], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'))], []), ' define the connections ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'))], []), '\nand ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'))], []), ' on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'))], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['K_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc'))], []), '\nrespectively. These are both pullbacks of a connection ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega')], []), ' defined\non ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['P'], []), ' by logarithmic differentiation.\n\nSince ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), ' = i_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), TexCmd('omega')], []), ', for\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['i_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr'))], []), ' and inclusion map, ', TexCmd('bas'), '\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '^*', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), ' = ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '^*', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('eas'), ' and\n', TexCmd('bas'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0'), '^*', TexCmd('omega'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')), ' =\n', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '^*', TexCmd('omega'), TexCmd('eas'), ' are both connections on ', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['B'], []), ' with\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), ' '], []), ' and ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0')], []), ' both sections of\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', ['Parrow B'], []), '. The connections defined by\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('dr')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,u'), '(z))'], []), ' and\n', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta'), '_', BraceGroup(TexCmd('sigma'), '_', BraceGroup('mc')), '(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0'), '(z(t),y(s)))'], []), ' can be related by the\ngauge transformation ', TexCmd('bas'), ' D(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr, u'), ' ', TexCmd('star'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc, z_0'), ') =\nD (', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0'), ')+ ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc, z_0'), '^', BraceGroup(TexCmd('star'), ' -1'), TexCmd('star'), ' D(', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('dr,\n  u'), ')', TexCmd('star'), ' ', TexCmd('varphi'), '_', BraceGroup('mc,z_0'), ' ', '\\;', ' .', TexCmd('eas'), '\n'], []), '\n', '\n Loop-wise calculations for the ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions for dimensionally\n regularized and cut-off regularized quantum electrodynamics give\n different values, starting at the 3-loop level ', TexCmd('cite', [BraceGroup('IZ')]), '. This\n theorem gives a geometric structure for understanding the relation\n between the two renormalization schemes.  While this paper has\n specifically examined a sharp momentum cut-off regulator, there are\n other related regularization schemes, such as smooth cut-off or\n Pauli-Villars regularization, that also have a structure of\n logarithmic singularities and finite order poles. Theories under\n these regularization schemes, and their ', TexMathModeEnv('$', [TexCmd('beta')], []), ' functions, can also\n be expressed in terms of sections and connections of this\n renormalization bundle.\n\n', TexCmd('bibliographystyle', [BraceGroup('amsplain')]), '\n/home/mithu/bibliography/Bibliography Bibliography file not found \n', TexCmd('bibliography', [BraceGroup('/home/mithu/bibliography/Bibliography'), BraceGroup()]), '\n', '\n', '\n'], []), '\n']
